original: Namo tassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa
analyzed: namaḥ tassa bhagavataḥ arahataḥ sammāsambuddhassa
translated: Homage to that Blessed One, accomplished and fully enlightened.

original: Abhidhammapiṭake🔽Vibhaṅga-mūlaṭīkā🔽1. Khandhavibhaṅgo
analyzed: abhidhamma piṭake           khandha vibhaṅgo
translated: In the Abhidhamma Piṭaka🔽The Root Commentary on the Vibhaṅga🔽The Exposition of the Aggregates

original: 1. Suttantabhājanīyavaṇṇanā
translated: The Commentary on the Suttas

original: Catusaccadasoti cattāri saccāni samāhaṭāni catusaccaṃ, catusaccaṃ passīti catusaccadaso.
analyzed: catusaccadasaḥ iti cattāri saccāni samāhaṭāni catusaccam catusaccam passi iti catusaccadasaḥ
translated: The one who sees the four noble truths: the four truths are collected together in the four noble truths, which are seen by the one who sees the four noble truths.

original: Satipi sāvakānaṃ paccekabuddhānañca catusaccadassanabhāve anaññapubbakattā bhagavato
analyzed: sati pi sāvakānam paccekabuddhānam ca catu sacca dassana bhāve anañña pubbaka ttā bhagavato
translated: Although disciples and paccekabuddhas also see the four noble truths, the Blessed One is the one who sees the four noble truths in the sense of seeing them first,

original: catusaccadassanassa tattha ca sabbaññutāya dasabalesu ca vasībhāvassa pattito parasantānesu
analyzed: catu acca dassanassa tattha ca sabbaññu tāya dasa balesu ca vasībhāvassa pattitaḥ para santānesu
translated: and he is the one who sees the four noble truths in the sense of seeing them in all their aspects and of mastering them by the ten powers.

original: ca pasāritabhāvena supākaṭattā bhagavāva visesena “catusaccadaso”ti thomanaṃ arahatīti.
analyzed: ca pasārita bhāvena visesena thomanam arahati iti
translated: Therefore, because of his pre-eminence in seeing the four noble truths, the Blessed One is the one who sees the four noble truths.

original: Nāthatīti nātho, veneyyānaṃ hitasukhaṃ āsīsati pattheti, parasantānagataṃ vā kilesabyasanaṃ
analyzed: nāthati iti nāthaḥ veneyyānam hita sukham āsīsati pattheti para santāna gatam vā kilesa byasanam
translated: The protector: he is a protector because he seeks and wishes for the welfare and happiness of his disciples, or because he inflicts suffering on the defilements in the mental continuity of others,

original: upatāpeti, “sādhu, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kālena kālaṃ attasampattiṃ paccavekkhitā”tiādinā
analyzed: upatāpeti sādhu bhikkhave bhikkhu kālena kālam atta sampattim paccavekkhitā iti ādinā
translated: saying: “It is good, bhikkhus, if a bhikkhu from time to time reviews the extent to which his own mind is purified” ,

original: vā taṃ taṃ hitapaṭipattiṃ yācatīti attho. Paramena cittissariyena samannāgato, sabbasatte
analyzed: vā tam tam hita paṭipattim yācati iti paramena cittissariyena samannāgato sabba satte
translated: or he requests the performance of some beneficial practice.

original: vā guṇehi īsati abhibhavatīti paramissaro bhagavā “nātho”ti vuccati. “Saddhamme gāravaṃ🔽katvā karissāmī”ti sotabbabhāve kāraṇaṃ vatvā puna savane niyojento āha “taṃ suṇātha🔽samāhitā”ti. “Porāṇaṭṭhakathānayaṃ vigāhitvā karissāmī”ti vā etena sakkaccasavane
analyzed: vā guṇehi īsati abhibhavati iti para missaraḥ bhagavā nātho ti vuccati saddhamme gāravam  katvā karissāmi iti sotabba bhāve kāraṇam vatvā puna savane niyojentaḥ āha tam suṇātha  samāhitā ati porāṇa ṭṭhakathā nayam vigāhitvā karissāmi iti vai etena sakkaccasavane
translated: The Blessed One is called “Lord” because he is endowed with the highest mind and heart, or because he is the supreme lord who surpasses all beings in virtue.🔽Having stated the reason for listening, namely, “having paid respect to the True Dhamma,” he again enjoins listening, saying, “Listen to it well.”

original: ca kāraṇaṃ vatvā tattha niyojento āha “saddhamme gāravaṃ katvā taṃ suṇāthā”ti.
analyzed: ca kāraṇam vatvā tattha niyojentaḥ āha saddhamme gāravam katvā tam suṇātha ati
translated: Or, having rejected the method of the old commentaries, he states the reason for listening respectfully, namely, “having paid respect to the True Dhamma,” and again enjoins listening, saying, “Listen to it well.”

original: Ettha ca “catusaccadaso”ti vacanaṃ thomanameva catuppabhedāya desanāya samānagaṇanadassanaguṇena,
analyzed: ettha ca catur accadasā iti vacanam thomanam eva catu pabhedāya desanāya samāna gaṇana dassana guṇena
translated: And here the statement “the four truths” is a praise of the teaching that has four divisions by way of the quality of showing the same number of truths.

original: “aṭṭhārasahi buddhadhammehi upeto”ti ca aṭṭhārasappabhedāya desanāya samānagaṇanaguṇehīti
analyzed: aṭṭhārasahi buddha dhammehi upetaḥ ti ca aṭṭhārasa ppabhedāya desanāya samāna gaṇana guṇehi iti
translated: And the statement “endowed with the eighteen qualities of a Buddha” is a praise of the teaching that has eighteen divisions by way of the quality of showing the same number of qualities.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Yathāvuttena vā niratisayena catusaccadassanena bhagavā catudhā dhammasaṅgaṇiṃ
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam yathā vuttena vā niratisayena catu sacca dassanena bhagavā catudhā dhamma saṅgaṇim
translated: should be seen. Or else, the Blessed One is the fourfold collection of the True Idea,🔽

original: desetuṃ samattho ahosi, aṭṭhārasabuddhadhammasamannāgamena aṭṭhārasadhā vibhaṅganti
analyzed: desetum samatthaḥ ahosi aṭṭhārasa buddha dhamma samannāgamena aṭṭhārasadhā
translated: The Blessed One was able to teach the fourfold recitation of the Dhamma by means of the aforesaid unexcelled vision of the Four Noble Truths. The Vibhaṅga is divided into eighteen sections by means of the eighteen qualities of a Buddha.

original: yathāvuttadesanāsamatthatāsampādakaguṇanidassanametaṃ “catusaccadaso upeto buddhadhammehi
analyzed: yathā vutta desanā samattha tā sampādaka guṇa nidassanam etam upetaḥ buddha dhammehi
translated: This shows the qualities that accomplish the ability to teach the aforesaid recitation. “The Dhamma of the Buddha, endowed with the vision of the Four Truths,🔽is accompanied by the eighteen qualities.”

original: aṭṭhārasahī”ti. Tena yathāvuttāya desanāya sabbaññubhāsitattā aviparītataṃ dassento
analyzed: aṭṭhārasa hi iti tena yathā vuttāya desanāya sabbaññu bhāsita ttā aviparīta tam dassento
translated: By this, showing that the recitation is spoken by the Omniscient One and is therefore unmistaken,

original: tattha satte uggahādīsu niyojeti, niṭṭhānagamanañca attano vāyāmaṃ dassento aṭṭhakathāsavane
analyzed: tattha satte uggaha ādīsu niyojeti niṭṭhāna gamanam ca attanaḥ vāyāmam dassento aṭṭhakathā savane
translated: he directs the attention of beings to the recitation, etc., and shows the attainment of the goal, and his own effort.🔽He also generates respect for listening to the commentary.

original: ca ādaraṃ uppādayati, yathāvuttaguṇarahitena asabbaññunā desetuṃ asakkuṇeyyataṃ dhammasaṅgaṇīvibhaṅgappakaraṇānaṃ🔽dassento tattha tadaṭṭhakathāya ca sātisayaṃ gāravaṃ janayati, buddhādīnañca ratanānaṃ
analyzed: ca ādaram uppādayati yathāvutta guṇa rahitena asabbaññunā desetum dhamma saṅgaṇī vibhaṅga ppakaraṇānam  dassentaḥ tattha tad aṭṭhakathāya ca sa atisayam gāravam janayati buddha ādīnam ca
translated: Showing that the recitation and the Vibhaṅga treatise cannot be taught by one who is not omniscient and who lacks the aforesaid qualities,🔽he generates even greater respect for the commentary on them.

original: sammāsambuddhatādiguṇe vibhāveti.
analyzed: sammāsambuddha tā ādi guṇe vibhāva iti
translated: He also analyzes the qualities of the Buddha, etc., which are the jewels of the Buddha, etc.

original: Tattha cattāri saccāni pākaṭāneva, aṭṭhārasa pana buddhadhammā evaṃ veditabbā – “atītaṃse
analyzed: tattha cattāri saccāni aṭṭhārasa pana buddha dhammāḥ evam veditabbāḥ atīta aṃse
translated: Herein, the four Truths are evident. But the eighteen properties of a Buddha should be understood as follows:

original: buddhassa bhagavato appaṭihataṃ ñāṇaṃ, anāgataṃse…pe… paccuppannaṃse…pe… imehi tīhi
analyzed: buddhassa bhagavataḥ a paṭihatam ñāṇam anāgata sepe paccuppanna sepe imehi tīhi
translated: The Enlightened One, the Blessed One, has to do with the past: his knowledge is unobstructed. He has to do with the future: his knowledge is unobstructed. He has to do with the present: his knowledge is unobstructed.

original: dhammehi samannāgatassa buddhassa bhagavato sabbaṃ kāyakammaṃ ñāṇapubbaṅgamaṃ ñāṇānuparivattaṃ,🔽sabbaṃ vacīkammaṃ…pe. … sabbaṃ manokammaṃ…pe… imehi chahi dhammehi samannāgatassa
analyzed: dhammehi samannāgatassa buddhassa bhagavataḥ sabbam kāya kammam ñāṇa pubbaṅgamam ñāṇa anuparivattam  sabbam vacī kammaṃpe sabbam manaḥ kammaṃpe imehi chahi dhammehi samannāgatassa
translated: Endowed with these three ideas, the Enlightened One, the Blessed One, has all his bodily action preceded by knowledge, followed by knowledge,🔽all his verbal action … all his mental action …

original: buddhassa bhagavato natthi chandassa hāni, natthi dhammadesanāya, natthi vīriyassa,🔽natthi samādhissa, natthi paññāya, natthi vimuttiyā hāni. Imehi dvādasahi dhammehi
analyzed: buddhassa bhagavataḥ natthi chandassa hāni natthi dhamma desanāya natthi vīriyassa  natthi samādhissa natthi paññāya natthi vimuttiyāḥ hāni imehi dvādasahi dhammehi
translated: Endowed with these six ideas, the Enlightened One, the Blessed One, has no loss of zeal, no loss of virtue, no loss of heedfulness, no loss of energy,🔽no loss of mindfulness, no loss of concentration, no loss of understanding.

original: samannāgatassa buddhassa bhagavato natthi davā, natthi ravā, natthi aphuṭaṃ, natthi
analyzed: samannāgatassa buddhassa bhagavataḥ natthi davā natthi ravā natthi aphuṭam natthi
translated: Endowed with these twelve ideas, the Enlightened One, the Blessed One, has no rashness, no unruliness, no unalertness,

original: vegāyitattaṃ, natthi abyāvaṭamano, natthi appaṭisaṅkhānupekkhā”ti.
analyzed: vegāyita ttam natthi a byāvaṭa manaḥ natthi a paṭisaṅkhā an upekkhā ati
translated: no elation, no elfishness, no unconcentratedness, no uninquiescence, no inattentiveness.

original: Tattha natthi davāti khiḍḍādhippāyena kiriyā natthi. Natthi ravāti sahasā kiriyā
analyzed: tattha natthi davāti khiḍḍa adhippāyena kiriyā natthi natthi ravāti sahasā kiriyā
translated: Herein, there is no play means there is no action with the aim of amusement. There is no jest means there is no action in haste.

original: natthi. Natthi aphuṭanti ñāṇena aphusitaṃ natthi. Natthi vegāyitattanti turitakiriyā🔽natthi. Natthi abyāvaṭamanoti niratthako cittasamudācāro natthi. Natthi appaṭisaṅkhānupekkhāti🔽aññāṇupekkhā natthi. Katthaci pana “natthi dhammadesanāya hānī”ti alikhitvā “natthi
analyzed: natthi natthi aphuṭanti ñāṇena aphusitam natthi natthi turita kiriyā  natthi natthi a byāvaṭa manaḥ ti niratthakaḥ citta samudācāraḥ natthi natthi appaṭisaṅkhā anupekkhā ati  aññāṇupekkhā natthi katthaci pana natthi dhamma desanāya hāni iti a likhitvā natthi
translated: There is no unprobed entry means there is no action unprobed by knowledge. There is no hasty action means there is no quick action.

original: chandassa hāni, natthi vīriyassa, natthi sattiyā”ti likhanti.🔽1. Dhammasaṅgahe dhamme kusalādike tikadukehi saṅgahetvā te eva dhamme suttante khandhādivasena🔽vutte vibhajituṃ vibhaṅgappakaraṇaṃ vuttaṃ. Tattha saṅkhepena vuttānaṃ khandhādīnaṃ
analyzed: chandassa hāni natthi vīriyassa natthi sattiyā ati likhanti  dhamma saṅgahe dhamme kusala ādike tika dukehi saṅgahetvā te eva dhamme suttante khandha ādi vasena  vutte vibhajitum vibhaṅga ppakaraṇam vuttam tattha saṅkhepena vuttānam khandha ādīnam
translated: There is no uncollectedness of mind means there is no purposeless mental action. There is no equanimity that is uninquiring means there is no equanimity of unknowing. But in some places, instead of “there is no loss in the teaching of the Dhamma,” it is written “there is no loss of desire, there is no loss of energy, there is no loss of mindfulness.”🔽The Vibhanga is stated in order to analyze the aggregates, etc., which are stated in the suttas under the headings of aggregates, sense bases, and elements, after collecting the wholesome, etc., states under the three headings of aggregates, sense bases, and elements in the Dhamma-saṅgaṇi.🔽Herein, the analysis of the aggregates, etc., stated in brief in the Dhamma-saṅgaṇi is the vibhanga.

original: vibhajanaṃ vibhaṅgo. So so vibhaṅgo pakato adhikato yassā pāḷiyā, sā “vibhaṅgappakaraṇa”nti
analyzed: vibhajanam vibhaṅgo saḥ saḥ vibhaṅgo pakataḥ adhikataḥ yassā pāḷiyā sā vibhaṅga pakaraṇanti
translated: That Vibhanga is called a “book” in the sense of a collection of the various kinds of aggregates, etc., that are analyzed, and in the sense of a collection of the various kinds of texts that analyze them.

original: vuccati. Adhikatoti ca vattabbabhāvena pariggahitoti attho. Tattha vibhaṅgappakaraṇassa
analyzed: vuccati adhikataḥ ti ca vattabba bhāvena pariggahito ti attho tattha vibhaṅga ppakaraṇassa
translated: is said. The meaning is: it is included by the fact that it should be stated. Herein, the Vibhanga-book

original: ādibhūte khandhavibhaṅge “pañcakkhandhā rūpakkhandho…pe… viññāṇakkhandho”ti idaṃ
analyzed: ādi bhūte khandha vibhaṅge pañca kkhandhāḥ viññāṇa kkhandho ti idam
translated: is said. The meaning is: it is included by the word “etc.” in the sense of what should be mentioned. Herein, in the Khandha-Vibhanga, which is the first of the Vibhanga-Pakarana, the passage beginning “The five aggregates are as follows: the form aggregate … the consciousness aggregate” is called the “Sutta-Basket.”

original: suttantabhājanīyaṃ nāma. Nanu na ettakameva suttantabhājanīyanti? Saccaṃ, iti-saddena🔽pana ādi-saddatthajotakena pakāratthajotakena vā sabbaṃ suttantabhājanīyaṃ saṅgahetvā
analyzed: suttantabhājanīyam nāma nanu na ettakam eva suttantabhājanīyanti saccam iti saddena  pana ādi sadda attha jotakena pakāra attha jotakena vā sabbam suttanta bhājanīyam saṅgahetvā
translated: But is not the Sutta-Basket more than that? It is true, but the word “etc.”

original: viññāṇakkhandhoti evamādi evaṃpakāraṃ vā idaṃ suttantabhājanīyanti veditabbaṃ. Atha
analyzed: viññāṇa kkhandhaḥ ti evamādi evaṃpakāram vā idam suttanta bhājanīyanti veditabbam atha
translated: indicates the meaning of “beginning with” or the meaning of “ending with.” So it should be understood that the Sutta-Basket is indicated by the words “the consciousness aggregate” and so on, or by the words “beginning with” and so on.

original: vā ekadesena samudāyaṃ nidasseti pabbatasamuddādinidassako viya. Tattha nibbānavajjānaṃ🔽sabbadhammānaṃ saṅgāhakattā sabbasaṅgāhakehi ca āyatanādīhi appakatarapadattā khandhānaṃ
analyzed: vā eka desena samudāyam nidasseti pabbata samudda ādi nidassakaḥ viya tattha nibbāna vajjānam  sabba dhammānam saṅgāhaka ttā sabba saṅgāhakehi ca āyatana ādīhi appakatara pada ttā khandhānam
translated: Or alternatively, it indicates the totality by a part, like the indication of a mountain or an ocean by a single stone or a single drop of water.

original: khandhavibhaṅgo ādimhi vutto.
analyzed: khandha vibhaṅgaḥ ādimhi vuttaḥ
translated: Herein, the Khandha-Vibhanga is stated first because it includes all states except Nibbāna, and because the words “aggregate” and so on are less comprehensive than the words “base” and so on.

original: Na tato heṭṭhāti rūpādīnaṃ vedayitādisabhāvattābhāvā yasmiṃ sabhāve atītādayo rāsī🔽katvā vattabbā, tassa ruppanādito aññassābhāvā ca heṭṭhā gaṇanesu saṅkhatadhammānaṃ🔽aniṭṭhānaṃ sāvasesabhāvaṃ, na heṭṭhā gaṇanamattābhāvaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Chaṭṭhassa
analyzed: na tatas heṭṭhā ati rūpa ādīnam yasmin sabhāve atīta ādayaḥ  katvā vattabbā tassa ruppana āditaḥ ca heṭṭhā gaṇanesu saṅkhata dhammānam  aniṭṭhānam sa avasesa bhāvam na heṭṭhā gaṇana matta abhāvam sandhāya vuttam chaṭṭhassa
translated: “Not below that” : because there is no such state as the feeling, etc., of visible form, etc., and because there is no state other than the state of materiality, etc., in which the past, etc., can be spoken of as a “heap,”

original: pana khandhassa abhāvā “na uddha”nti āha. Na hi savibhāgadhammehi nissaṭassa atītādibhāvarahitassa
analyzed: pana khandhassa abhāvā na uddhanti āha na hi savibhāga dhammehi nissaṭassa atīta ādi bhāva rahitassa
translated: the meaning of “not below” should be understood as the incompleteness of the classification, not as the non-existence of the classification. But the sixth aggregate does not exist, and therefore it is said: “Not above.” For the state of Nibbāna, which is devoid of the aggregates with their divisions, and which is free from the states of past, etc.,

original: ekassa nibbānassa rāsaṭṭho atthīti. “Rāsimhī”ti saddatthasahitaṃ khandha-saddassa🔽visayaṃ dasseti. “Guṇe paṇṇattiyaṃ ruḷhiya”nti visayameva khandha-saddassa dasseti,🔽na saddatthaṃ. Lokiyalokuttarabhedañhi sīlādiguṇaṃ nippadesena gahetvā pavattamāno
analyzed: ekassa nibbānassa rāsaṭṭhaḥ atthi iti rāsimhi iti saddattha sahitam khandha saddassa  visayam dasseti guṇe paṇṇattiyam visayam eva khandha saddassa dasseti  na saddattham lokiya lokuttara bhedam hi sīla ādi guṇam nippadesena gahetvā pavattamānaḥ
translated: has no meaning of a “heap.” The word “heap” is a mere designation for a collection of things with divisions.🔽The word “aggregate” is a mere designation for a collection of things without divisions. “In a quality, a designation, a heap” : this shows the meaning of the word “aggregate” as a mere designation.🔽It does not show the meaning of the word “aggregate” as a mere word. For the word “aggregate,” occurring as a mere designation, shows the meaning of a “heap” qualified by the qualities of virtue, etc.,

original: khandha-saddo sīlādiguṇavisiṭṭhaṃ rāsaṭṭhaṃ dīpetīti. Keci pana “guṇaṭṭho ettha khandhaṭṭho”ti
analyzed: khandha saddaḥ sīla ādi guṇa visiṭṭham rāsaṭṭham dīpeti iti keci pana guṇa ṭṭhaḥ ettha khandha ṭṭhaḥ ti
translated: but the word “heap” shows only the meaning of a “heap.” “In the mundane and supramundane” : this shows the meaning of the word “aggregate” as a mere designation for the qualities of virtue, etc., whether mundane or supramundane.

original: vadanti. Dārukkhandhoti ettha pana na khandha-saddo paññatti-saddassa atthe vattati,
analyzed: vadanti dāru khandhaḥ ti ettha pana na khandha saddo paññatti saddassa atthe vattati
translated: But they say that in the case of the word “log” the word “aggregate” does not occur in the sense of the word “concept.”

original: tādise pana puthulāyate dārumhi dārukkhandhoti paññatti hotīti paññattiyaṃ nipatatīti
analyzed: tādise pana puthulāyate dārumhi dāru khandho ti paññatti hoti iti paññattiyam nipatati iti
translated: But the concept of a log is a concept in a piece of wood that is long and thick, so it is said to occur in a concept.

original: vuttaṃ. Tathā ekasmimpi viññāṇe pavatto viññāṇakkhandhoti khandha-saddo na ruḷhī-saddassa🔽atthaṃ vadati, samudāye pana niruḷho khandha-saddo tadekadese pavattamāno tāya eva
analyzed: vuttam tathā ekasmim pi viññāṇe pavattaḥ viññāṇa kkhandho ti khandha saddaḥ na ruḷhī saddassa  attham vadati samudāye pana niruḷhaḥ khandha saddo tad eka dese pavattamāno tāya eva
translated: Similarly, the word “aggregate” in the case of a single consciousness does not occur in the sense of the word “occurrence.”

original: ruḷhiyā pavattatīti khandha-saddo ruḷhiyaṃ nipatatīti vuttaṃ.🔽Rāsito guṇatoti sabbattha nissakkavacanaṃ visayasseva khandha-saddappavattiyā kāraṇabhāvaṃ
analyzed: ruḷhiyā pavattati iti khandha saddaḥ ruḷhiyam nipatati iti vuttam  rāsitaḥ guṇato ti sabbattha nissakka vacanam visayassa iva khandha sadda ppavattiyā kāraṇa bhāvam
translated: But the word “aggregate,” which is established in the sense of a collection, occurs in what occurs in a part of that collection by the same usage, so it is said to occur in usage.🔽“As a heap, as a quality”: the word “everywhere” should be understood as said with reference to the fact that the word “aggregate” occurs only in the sense of a collection.

original: sandhāya katanti veditabbaṃ. “Rāsito”ti imamatthaṃ saddatthavasenapi niyametvā dassetuṃ
analyzed: sandhāya katam ti veditabbam rāsito ti imam attham saddattha vasena api niyametvā dassetum
translated: In order to show and define the meaning of “as a heap” by means of the meaning of the word,

original: “ayañhi khandhaṭṭho nāma piṇḍaṭṭho”tiādimāha. Koṭṭhāsaṭṭhe khandhaṭṭhe chaṭṭhenapi
analyzed: ayam hi khandha ṭṭhaḥ nāma piṇḍa ṭṭhā ti ādim āha koṭṭhāsa ṭṭhe khandha ṭṭhe chaṭṭhena pi
translated: he says, “For this ‘aggregate meaning’ is the ‘heap meaning.’ ” In the “part meaning” of “aggregate,” it occurs even with the sixth🔽case.

original: khandhena bhavitabbaṃ. Nibbānampi hi chaṭṭho koṭṭhāsoti. Tasmā “khandhaṭṭho nāma
analyzed: khandhena bhavitabbam nibbānam pi hi chaṭṭhaḥ koṭṭhāsaḥ ti tasmā khandhaṭṭhaḥ nāma
translated: Therefore it is proper to say that the meaning of ‘part’ is the meaning of ‘heap.’

original: rāsaṭṭho”ti yuttaṃ. Yesaṃ vā atītādivasena bhedo atthi, tesaṃ ruppanādilakkhaṇavasena🔽taṃtaṃkoṭṭhāsatā vuccatīti bhedarahitassa nibbānassa koṭṭhāsaṭṭhena ca khandhabhāvo
analyzed: rāsaṭṭhaḥ ti yuttam yesam vā atīta ādi vasena bhedaḥ atthi tesam ruppana ādi lakkhaṇa vasena  tad tad koṭṭhāsa tā vuccati iti bheda rahitassa nibbānassa koṭṭhāsa aṭṭhena ca khandha bhāvo
translated: Or, in the case of those things that are divided into past, etc., it is said that they are so many parts by characteristic as the states of arising, etc.,

original: na vuttoti veditabbo.
analyzed: na vuttaḥ iti veditabbaḥ
translated: so it should be understood that nibbana, which is not divided, is not called a part in the sense of a part consisting of states of arising, etc.

original: Ettāvatāti uddesamattenāti attho. Cattāro ca mahābhūtā…pe… rūpanti evaṃ vibhatto.
analyzed: ettāvatā ati uddesa mattena ati attho cattāro ca mahābhūta āpe evam vibhatto
translated: ‘So far’: the meaning is: in the mere statement. ‘The four great entities and the form derived from the great entities’ is analysed thus: ‘What is the form base?

original: Katthāti ce? Ekādasasu okāsesu. Iti-saddena nidassanatthena sabbo vibhajananayo dassito.
analyzed: kattha ati ce ekādasasu okāsesu iti saddena nidassana tthena sabbaḥ vibhajana nayaḥ dassitaḥ
translated: If it be asked, ‘Where?’ it is in the eleven instances. The word ‘so’ is in the sense of ‘thus’; it shows the whole method of analysis.

original: Idañca vibhajanaṃ oḷārikādīsu cakkhāyatanantiādivibhajanañca yathāsambhavaṃ ekādasasu
analyzed: idam ca vibhajanam oḷārika ādīsu cakkhāyatana nti ādi vibhajanam ca yathāsambhavam ekādasasu
translated: And this analysis and the analysis beginning ‘The eye base: the eye faculty, material, formed, …’ should be applied as appropriate to the eleven instances,

original: okāsesu yojetabbaṃ, evaṃ vedanākkhandhādīsupi. Viññāṇakkhandho pana ekādasokāsesu
analyzed: okāsesu yojetabbam evam vedanā kkhandha ādīsu pi viññāṇa kkhandho pana ekādasa ukāsesu
translated: and so too to the feeling aggregate, etc. But the consciousness aggregate is in the eleven instances

original: purime okāsapañcake “cakkhuviññāṇaṃ…pe… manoviññāṇa”nti chaviññāṇakāyavisesena vibhatto,
analyzed: purime okāsa pañcake cakkhu viññāṇam pe manaḥ viññāṇan ti cha viññāṇa kāya visesena vibhatto
translated: In the first five sections, “Eye-consciousness … mind-consciousness” is distinguished by the six kinds of consciousness.

original: na tattha manodhātu manoviññāṇadhātūti vibhajanaṃ atthi. Taṃ pana dvayaṃ manoviññāṇanti
analyzed: na tattha manaḥ dhātu manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu uti vibhajanam atthi tam pana dvayam manaḥ viññāṇam ti
translated: But there is no distinction there as to whether it is the mind element or the mind-consciousness element. But that pair is called mind-consciousness.

original: vuttanti imamatthaṃ dassetuṃ aṭṭhakathāyaṃ “manodhātu manoviññāṇadhātū”ti vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: vuttanti imam attham dassetum aṭṭhakathāyam manaḥ dhātu manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu iti vuttan ti daṭṭhabbam
translated: The meaning intended is that it should be regarded as “the mind element and the mind-consciousness element” in the commentary.

original: Evaṃ pāḷinayena pañcasu khandhesu dhammaparicchedaṃ dassetvā puna aññena pakārena dassetuṃ “apicā”tiādimāha. Etthāti etasmiṃ khandhaniddese.
analyzed: evam pāḷi nayena pañcasu khandhesu dhamma paricchedam dassetvā puna aññena pakārena dassetum api ca ati ādim āha ettha iti etasmim khandha niddese
translated: Having thus shown the exposition of ideas in the five aggregates by the method of the texts, he now said “Besides” in order to show it by another method. Herein, in this description of the aggregates.

original: 1. Rūpakkhandhaniddesavaṇṇanā🔽2. Yaṃ kiñcīti ettha yanti sāmaññena aniyamanidassanaṃ, kiñcīti pakārantarabhedaṃ🔽āmasitvā aniyamanidassanaṃ. Ubhayenapi atītaṃ vā…pe… santike vā appaṃ vā bahuṃ vā
analyzed: rūpa kkhandha niddesa vaṇṇanā  yam kiñci iti ettha yanti sāmaññena aniyama nidassanam kiñci iti pakāra antara bhedam  āmasitvā aniyama nidassanam ubhayena api atītam vāpe santike vā appam vā bahum vā
translated: Description of the form aggregate🔽In the passage “Any kind of form there is, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near—any kind of form—all form should be seen as it really is with correct wisdom thus: ‘This is not mine, this I am not, this is not my self’” , the word “any” shows non-restriction by specifying in general; the word “kind” shows non-restriction by specifying a particular instance;

original: yādisaṃ vā tādisaṃ vā yaṃ kiñcīti napuṃsakaniddesārahaṃ sabbaṃ byāpetvā saṅgaṇhātīti
analyzed: yādisam vā tādisam vā yam kiñci iti napuṃsaka niddesa araham sabbam byāpetvā saṅgaṇhāti iti
translated: and the words “whether past, future, or present” show non-restriction by specifying a class. By both together all kinds of form are shown without restriction.

original: aññesupi napuṃsakaniddesārahesu pasaṅgaṃ disvā tassa adhippetatthaṃ aticca pavattito
analyzed: aññesu pi napuṃsaka niddesa arahesu pasaṅgam disvā tassa adhippeta ttham ati cca pavattitaḥ
translated: and in other places where a neuter noun is appropriate, it occurs by passing over the intended meaning.🔽In order to restrain such excessive passing over, he said “rūpa.”

original: atippasaṅgassa niyamanatthaṃ “rūpa”nti āha. Yaṃkiñcīti sanipātaṃ yaṃ-saddaṃ kiṃ-saddañca
analyzed: atippasaṅgassa niyamana attham rūpanti āha yaṃ kiñci iti sa nipātam yaṃsaddam kiṃsaddam ca
translated: “Yaṃkiñcī” means “whatever” and “kiñcī” means “any.”

original: aniyamekatthadīpanavasena ekaṃ padanti gahetvā “padadvayenapī”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: aniyama ekattha dīpana vasena ekam padanti gahetvā pada dvayena api iti vuttam
translated: Taking the two words as one compound because they express an indefinite meaning, it is said “by two words.”

original: Kiñca, bhikkhave, rūpaṃ vadethāti tumhepi rūpaṃ rūpanti vadetha, taṃ kena kāraṇena
analyzed: kiñca bhikkhave rūpam vadetha ati tumhe api rūpam rūpam ti vadetha tam kena kāraṇena
translated: “And what, bhikkhus, do you call rūpa?” means “you call rūpa rūpa,” the meaning is, “by what reason?”

original: vadethāti attho, atha vā kena kāraṇena rūpaṃ, taṃ kāraṇaṃ vadethāti attho. Athetesu
analyzed: vadetha ati atthaḥ atha vā kena kāraṇena rūpam tam kāraṇam vadetha ati atthaḥ atha itesu
translated: Or else, the meaning is, “by what reason is it rūpa? State that reason.” Then,

original: bhikkhūsu tuṇhībhūtesu bhagavā āha “ruppatīti kho”tiādi.🔽Bhijjatīti sītādisannipāte visadisasantānuppattidassanato purimasantānassa bhedaṃ
analyzed: bhikkhūsu tuṇhībhūtesu bhagavā āha ruppati iti kho tiādi  bhijjati iti sītā ādi sannipāte visadisa santāna uppatti dassanato purima santānassa bhedam
translated: when the bhikkhus were silent, the Exalted One said, “It is rūpa because it is broken up,” and so on.🔽“It is broken up” means that it is broken up by the appearance of a different continuity when there is a combination of cold, etc., and it refers to the breaking up of the previous continuity.

original: sandhāyāha. Bhedo ca visadisatāvikārāpattīti bhijjatīti vikāraṃ āpajjatīti attho.
analyzed: sandhāya āha bhedaḥ ca visadisa tā vikāra āpatti iti bhijjati iti vikāram āpajjati iti attho
translated: And breaking up is a change, so the meaning is that it undergoes a change.

original: Vikārāpatti ca sītādisannipāte visadisarūpuppattiyeva. Arūpakkhandhānaṃ pana atilahuparivattito🔽yathā rūpadhammānaṃ ṭhitikkhaṇe sītādīhi samāgamo hoti, yena tattha utuno ṭhitippattassa
analyzed: vikāra āpatti ca sītā ādi sannipāte visadisa rūpa uppattiyā iva arūpa kkhandhānam pana ati lahu parivattito  yathā rūpa dhammānam ṭhiti kkhaṇe sītā ādīhi samāgamaḥ hoti yena tattha utuno ṭhiti ppattassa
translated: And the occurrence of alteration is the appearance of a different colour in the cold, etc., conjunction. But the immaterial aggregates are extremely volatile,

original: purimasadisasantānuppādanasamatthatā na hoti āhārādikassa vā, evaṃ aññehi samāgamo
analyzed: purima sadisa santāna uppādana samattha tā na hoti āhāra ādikassa vā evam aññehi samāgamaḥ
translated: Just as there is conjunction with cold, etc., at the moment of presence of material phenomena, by which there is no ability to produce a homogeneous continuity in what has reached presence through temperature, or in nutriment, etc.,

original: natthi. Saṅghaṭṭanena ca vikārāpattiyaṃ ruppana-saddo niruḷho, tasmā arūpadhammānaṃ🔽saṅghaṭṭanavirahitattā rūpadhammānaṃ viya pākaṭassa vikārassa abhāvato ca “ruppantī”ti
analyzed: natthi saṅghaṭṭanena ca vikāra āpattiyam ruppana saddo niruḷho tasmai arūpa dhammānam  saṅghaṭṭana virahita ttā rūpa dhammānam viya pākaṭassa vikārassa abhāvato ca ruppanti iti
translated: so there is no such conjunction with the immaterial aggregates. And the term “is altered” is used in the sense of “is conjoined” in the occurrence of alteration. Therefore,

original: “ruppanalakkhaṇā”ti ca na vuccanti. Jighacchāpipāsāhi ruppanañca udaraggisannipātena🔽hotīti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Ettha ca kuppatīti etena kattuatthe rūpapadasiddhiṃ dasseti, ghaṭṭīyati
analyzed: ruppana lakkhaṇā ti ca na vuccanti jighacchā pipāsāhi ruppanam ca udara aggi sannipātena  hoti iti daṭṭhabbam ettha ca kuppati iti etena kattu atthe rūpa pada siddhim dasseti ghaṭṭīyati
translated: because the immaterial dhammas are devoid of conjunction and because there is no obvious alteration in them as there is in material dhammas, they are not said to “alter” or to have “alteration” as their characteristic. And the alteration by hunger and thirst should be regarded as occurring through the conjunction of the fire element in the stomach.

original: pīḷīyatīti etehi kammatthe. Kopādikiriyāyeva hi ruppanakiriyāti. So pana kattubhūto
analyzed: pīḷīyati iti etehi kammatthe kopa ādi kiriyāya iva hi ruppana kiriyā ati saḥ pana kattu bhūtaḥ
translated: And here, by the phrase “is altered” he shows the derivation of the noun rūpa in the sense of agent. By the phrases “is conjoined” and “is oppressed” he shows it in the sense of action. For the action of alteration is the same as the action of breaking up, etc. But the agent that breaks up, etc., is the materiality itself.

original: kammabhūto ca attho bhijjamāno hotīti imassatthassa dassanatthaṃ “bhijjatīti attho”ti🔽vuttaṃ. Atha vā ruppatīti rūpanti kammakattutthe rūpapadasiddhi vuttā. Vikāro hi
analyzed: kamma bhūto ca atthaḥ bhijjamānaḥ hoti iti imassa atthassa dassana attham bhijjati iti attho ti  vuttam atha vā ruppati iti kamma kattutthe vuttā vikāraḥ hi
translated: And the meaning of “is broken” is shown by the words “The meaning is ‘is broken.’ ”🔽Or alternatively, the derivation of the word rūpa as a noun formed from a past participle is stated thus: “It is broken, thus it is rūpa,” for “is broken” is a synonym for “is deformed.”

original: ruppananti. Teneva “bhijjatīti attho”ti kammakattutthena bhijjati-saddena atthaṃ
analyzed: ruppananti tena iva bhijjati iti attho ti kamma kattutthena bhijjati saddena attham
translated: That is why the meaning of the word “is broken” is shown by the word “is broken” as a past participle.

original: dasseti. Yaṃ pana ruppati bhijjati, taṃ yasmā kuppati ghaṭṭīyati pīḷīyati, tasmā
analyzed: dasseti yam pana ruppati bhijjati tam yasmai kuppati ghaṭṭīyati pīḷīyati tasmai
translated: But since what is broken is also what is torn, what is struck, what is afflicted,🔽the meaning of the words “is torn” and “is struck” and “is afflicted” is made clear by these words.

original: etehi ca padehi padattho pākaṭo katoti. “Kenaṭṭhenā”ti pucchāsabhāgavasena “ruppanaṭṭhenā”ti🔽vuttaṃ. Na kevalaṃ saddatthoyeva ruppanaṃ, tassa panatthassa lakkhaṇañca hotīti atthalakkhaṇavasena
analyzed: etehi ca padehi padattho pākaṭaḥ kataḥ iti kenaṭṭhena ati pucchā sabhāga vasena ruppana ṭṭhena ati  vuttam na kevalam sadda atthaḥ yeva ruppanam tassa pana atthassa lakkhaṇam ca hoti iti attha lakkhaṇa vasena
translated: “For what reason?” is said by way of the question, and “for the reason of breaking” is said by way of the answer.

original: “ruppanalakkhaṇena rūpantipi vattuṃ vaṭṭatī”ti āha.
analyzed: ruppana lakkhaṇena vattum vaṭṭati iti āha
translated: Breaking is not only the meaning of the word; it is also the characteristic of that meaning. Therefore he said, “It is also allowable to say ‘Rūpa is so called because of the characteristic of breaking’ as a characteristic of meaning.”

original: Chijjitvāti mucchāpattiyā muccitvā aṅgapaccaṅgānaṃ chedanavasena vā chijjitvā. Accantakhārena
analyzed: chijjitvā iti mucchā āpattiyāḥ muccitvā aṅga paccaṅgānam chedana vasena vā chijjitvā accanta khārena
translated: “Having been broken” means having been released from the state of being a foetus by the breaking of the limbs and minor parts.

original: sītodakenāti atisītabhāvameva sandhāya accantakhāratā vuttā siyā. Na hi taṃ kappasaṇṭhānaṃ
analyzed: sīta udakena ati ati sīta bhāvam eva sandhāya accanta khāra tā vuttā siyā na hi tam kappa saṇṭhānam
translated: “Cold water” : the extreme coldness is meant. For that water is not of the shape of lye.

original: udakaṃ sampattikaraṃ pathavīsandhārakaṃ kappavināsaudakaṃ viya khāraṃ bhavituṃ arahati.
analyzed: udakam sampatti karam pathavī sandhārakam kappa vināsa odakam viya khāram bhavitum arahati
translated: It is not proper that it should be lye, like the water that destroys the aeon, which is capable of dissolving the earth and of supporting the water.🔽For if it were so, the earth would melt.

original: Tathā hi sati pathavī vilīyeyyāti. Avīcimahānirayeti saussadaṃ avīcinirayaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: tathā hi sati pathavī vilīyeyyāti avīci mahāniraya iti saussadam avīci nirayam vuttam
translated: “The great hell Avīci” : the hell Avīci with its surrounding area is meant.🔽Therefore it is said: “For there” , etc.🔽The meaning intended is that there are beings of such a kind.

original: Teneva “tattha hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Petti…pe… na hontīti evaṃvidhāpi sattā atthīti adhippāyo
analyzed: tena iva tattha hi itiādi vuttam pettipe na honti iti evaṃvidhā api sattā atthi iti adhippāyaḥ
translated: The meaning is that there are beings of such a kind, but not that there are only beings of such a kind.🔽The same method applies to the case of the black sugar-cane juice, etc.

original: evaṃvidhāyeva hontīti niyamābhāvato. Evaṃ kālakañjikādīsupīti. Sarantā gacchantīti
analyzed: evaṃvidhāya iva honti iti niyama abhāvataḥ evam kālakañjikā ādīsu pi iti sarantāḥ gacchanti iti
translated: “They go on and on” :

original: sarīsapa-saddassa atthaṃ vadati.🔽Abhisaññūhitvāti ettha samūhaṃ katvātipi attho. Etena sabbaṃ rūpaṃ…pe… dassitaṃ hotīti🔽etena rūpakkhandha-saddassa samānādhikaraṇasamāsabhāvaṃ dasseti. Tenevāha “na hi
analyzed: sarīsapa saddassa attham vadati  ettha samūham katvā atipi atthaḥ etena sabbam dassitam hoti iti  etena rūpa kkhandha saddassa samāna adhikaraṇa samāsa bhāvam dasseti tena iva āha na hi
translated: he explains the meaning of the word sarīsapa.🔽“Having formed them into a mass” : the meaning is also “having collected them.”🔽By this he shows that the compound rūpakkhandha is a tatpuruṣa compound.

original: rūpato…pe… atthī”ti.
analyzed: atthi iti
translated: Therefore he says: “For there is no rūpa apart from the four great elements” .

original: 3. Pakkhipitvāti ettha ekādasokāsesu rūpaṃ pakkhipitvāti attho. Na hi tattha mātikaṃyeva pakkhipitvā mātikā ṭhapitā, atha kho pakaraṇappattaṃ rūpanti.
analyzed: pakkhipitvā ti ettha ekādasa ukāsesu rūpam pakkhipitvā ati atthaḥ na hi tattha mātikam yeva pakkhipitvā mātikā ṭhapitā atha kho pakaraṇa ppattam rūpam ti
translated: ‘Including’ means including the materiality in the eleven remaining sections. For it is not only the headings that are included there, but also the materiality that falls under the categories.

original: Aparo nayo…pe… ettheva gaṇanaṃ gatanti etena atītaṃsenāti bhummatthe karaṇavacananti
analyzed: aparaḥ etthā iva gaṇanam etena atīta ṃsena ati bhumma tthe karaṇa vacana nti
translated: Another method … ‘Gone to enumeration’ here is the instrumental case in the sense of a reason.

original: dasseti. Yena pakārena gaṇanaṃ gataṃ, taṃ dassetuṃ “cattāro ca mahābhūtā”tiādi vuttanti
analyzed: dasseti yena pakārena gaṇanam gatam tam dassetum cattāro ca mahābhūtā ti ādi vuttan ti
translated: He shows that by the words ‘The four great entities and the materiality derived by clinging to them.’

original: imasmiṃ atthe sati mahābhūtupādāyarūpabhāvo atītakoṭṭhāse gaṇanassa kāraṇanti āpajjati.
analyzed: imasmin atthe sati mahābhūta upādāya rūpa bhāvaḥ atīta koṭṭhāse gaṇanassa kāraṇan ti āpajjati
translated: If the meaning were that the existence of the great primaries and the derived materiality is the reason for the inclusion in the past section,

original: Na hi atītaṃsānaṃ vedanādīnaṃ nivattanatthaṃ idaṃ vacanaṃ “yaṃ rūpa”nti eteneva tesaṃ
analyzed: na hi atītaṃsānam vedanā ādīnam nivattana attham idam vacanam yam etena iva tesam
translated: then it would follow that the words ‘What materiality …’ are stated for the purpose of excluding feeling, etc., which are past,

original: nivattitattā, nāpi rūpassa aññappakāranivattanatthaṃ sabbappakārassa tattha gaṇitattā,
analyzed: nivattita ttā na api rūpassa añña ppakāra nivattana attham sabba ppakārassa tattha gaṇita ttā
translated: because they are already included by the words ‘past’; and that the words ‘What materiality’ are stated for the purpose of excluding the other modes of materiality, because all the modes are already included there;🔽and that the words ‘past’ are stated for the purpose of excluding the other modes, namely, future and present, because the past is already included by the words ‘past.’

original: na ca anāgatapaccuppannākāranivattanatthaṃ atītaṃsavacanena taṃnivattanatoti. Atha
analyzed: na ca anāgata paccuppanna ākāra nivattana attham atīta savacanena tad nivattanato ti atha
translated: But that is not so.

original: pana yaṃ atītaṃsena gaṇitaṃ, taṃ cattāro ca…pe… rūpanti evaṃ gaṇitanti ayamattho
analyzed: pana yam atīta ṃsena gaṇitam tam cattāro cape evam gaṇitanti ayam attho
translated: But the meaning intended is this: “What is counted by means of the past is the four great primaries and the materiality derived by clinging from the four great primaries, and that is counted as ‘materiality.’ ”

original: adhippeto, evaṃ sati gaṇanantaradassanaṃ idaṃ siyā, na atītaṃsena gaṇitappakāradassanaṃ,
analyzed: adhippetaḥ evam sati gaṇa nantara dassanam idam siyā na atīta aṃsena gaṇita ppakāra dassanam
translated: If that is so, then this is the contemplation of the number after counting, not the contemplation of the kind of materiality counted by means of the past.

original: taṃdassane pana sati bhūtupādāyarūpappakārena atītaṃse gaṇitaṃ taṃsabhāvattāti āpannameva🔽hoti, na ca evaṃsabhāvatā atītaṃse gaṇitatāya kāraṇaṃ bhavituṃ arahati evaṃsabhāvasseva
analyzed: tad dassane pana sati bhūta upādāya rūpa ppakārena atīta aṃse gaṇitam taṃsa bhāva ttā ati āpannam eva  na ca evaṃsabhāva tā gaṇita tāyai kāraṇam bhavitum arahati
translated: But if that were contemplated, then it would follow that what is counted by means of the past is of the same nature as the primary elements and the derived materiality,🔽and it is not proper that being of the same nature should be the reason for counting by means of the past, since it is also counted in the present and future, and since the nature of pleasure, etc., is counted in the past.

original: paccuppannānāgatesu gaṇitattā sukhādisabhāvassa ca atītaṃse gaṇitattā, tasmā purimanayo
analyzed: paccuppanna anāgatesu gaṇita ttā sukha ādi sabhāvassa ca gaṇita ttā tasmā purima nayo
translated: Therefore the former method is the proper one.

original: eva yutto. Ajjhattabahiddhāniddesesupi tādiso evattho labbhatīti.🔽Suttantapariyāyatoti pariyāyadesanattā suttassa vuttaṃ. Abhidhammaniddesatoti nippariyāyadesanattā
analyzed: eva yuttaḥ ajjhatta bahiddhā niddesesu pi tādisaḥ eva tthaḥ labbhati iti  suttanta pariyāyato ti pariyāya desana ttā suttassa vuttam abhidhamma niddesato ti nippariyāya desana ttā
translated: And the same meaning can be found in the exposition of internal and external.

original: abhidhammassa nicchayena deso niddesoti katvā vuttaṃ. Kiñcāpītiādīsu ayamadhippāyo
analyzed: abhidhammassa nicchayena desaḥ niddesaḥ ti katvā vuttam kiñcā api iti ādīsu ayam adhippāyaḥ
translated: “In the Suttas” : this is said because the teaching in the Suttas is by way of synonyms. “In the Abhidhamma” : this is said because the teaching in the Abhidhamma is by way of etymologies, the meaning of “niddesa” being “etymology.”🔽“Although” : the intention is this:

original: – suttantabhājanīyattā yathā “atītaṃ nanvāgameyyā”tiādīsu addhānavasena atītādibhāvova
analyzed: yathā atītam addhāna vasena
translated: As in the passages beginning, “If he were to go back to the past,” etc., the past, etc., are stated by way of time.

original: vutto, tathā idhāpi niddisitabbo siyā. Evaṃ santepi suttantabhājanīyampi abhidhammadesanāyeva🔽suttante vuttadhamme vicinitvā vibhajanavasena pavattāti abhidhammaniddeseneva atītādibhāvo niddiṭṭhoti.
analyzed: vuttaḥ tathā idha api niddisitabbo siyā evam sante pi suttanta bhājanīyam pi abhidhamma desanāya iva  suttante vutta dhamme vicinitvā vibhajana vasena pavattā ati abhidhamma niddesena iva atīta ādi bhāvaḥ niddiṭṭhaḥ ti
translated: So too, it could be demonstrated here in the same way. But even though it is demonstrated by way of the suttas, the teaching of the Abhidhamma is still🔽more distinguished. For the teaching of the Abhidhamma is the demonstration of the past, etc., by way of the exposition of the Abhidhamma, since it occurs by way of investigating and discerning the states taught in the suttas.

original: Addhāsantatisamayakhaṇavasenāti ettha cutipaṭisandhiparicchinne kāle addhā-saddo🔽vattatīti “ahosiṃ nu kho ahamatītamaddhāna”ntiādisuttavasena viññāyati. “Tayome,
analyzed: addhā santati samaya khaṇa vasena ati ettha cuti paṭisandhi paricchinne kāle addhā saddo  vattati iti ahosim nu kho aham atītam addhā ananti ādi sutta vasena viññāyati tayo me
translated: By way of time, continuity, occasion, and moment: here the word “time” occurs in the sense of the period delimited by death and rebirth-linking.

original: bhikkhave, addhā. Katame tayo? Atīto addhā, anāgato addhā, paccuppanno addhā”ti ettha
analyzed: bhikkhave addhā katame tayo atītaḥ addhā anāgataḥ addhā paccuppannaḥ addhā ati ettha
translated: This is known from the passage beginning, “Did I exist in the past?” “There are, bhikkhus, these three times. What three? The past time, the future time, and the present time.”

original: pana paramatthato paricchijjamāno addhā niruttipathasuttavasena khaṇaparicchinno
analyzed: pana paramatthato paricchijjamāno addhā nirutti patha sutta vasena khaṇa paricchinno
translated: But here the time that is delimited in the ultimate sense is to be taken as delimited by the moment, according to the passage beginning, “The path of linguistic expression.”

original: yutto. Tattha hi “yaṃ, bhikkhave, rūpaṃ jātaṃ pātubhūtaṃ, ‘atthī’ti tassa saṅkhā”ti
analyzed: yuttaḥ tattha hi yam bhikkhave rūpam jātam pātubhūtam atthi iti tassa
translated: For there it is said: “Bhikkhus, whatever material form exists, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near—this is called the material form category” .

original: vijjamānassa paccuppannatā tato pubbe pacchā ca atītānāgatatā vuttāti. Yebhuyyena
analyzed: vijjamānassa paccuppanna tā tatas pubbe pacchā ca atīta anāgata tā vuttā ati yebhuyyena
translated: and the present is the time when it is present. The past and future are stated as prior to and subsequent to that.

original: pana cutipaṭisandhiparicchinno suttesu atītādiko addhā vuttoti so eva idhāpi “addhāvasenā”ti🔽vutto. Sītaṃ sītassa sabhāgo, tathā uṇhaṃ uṇhassa. Yaṃ pana sītaṃ uṇhaṃ vā sarīre
analyzed: pana cuti paṭisandhi paricchinno suttesu atīta ādikaḥ addhā vuttaḥ ti saḥ eva idha api addhā vasena ati  vuttaḥ sītam sītassa sabhāgaḥ tathā uṇham uṇhassa yam pana sītam uṇham vā sarīre
translated: But in the suttas the time division is generally stated as past, etc., by way of death and rebirth-linking. So that is what is meant by “by way of time” here.

original: sannipatitaṃ santānavasena pavattamānaṃ anūnaṃ anadhikaṃ ekākāraṃ, taṃ eko utūti
analyzed: sannipatitam santāna vasena pavattamānam anūnam anadhikam eka ākāram tam
translated: Cold is homogeneous with cold, and hot with hot. But that which is cold or hot occurring in a continuity in the body without deficiency or excess and of one kind is called “one season.”

original: vuccati. Sabhāgautuno anekantasabhāvato ekagahaṇaṃ kataṃ, evaṃ āhārepi. Ekavīthiekajavanasamuṭṭhānanti
analyzed: vuccati sabhā gautunaḥ anekanta sabhāvataḥ eka gahaṇam katam evam āhāre pi eka vīthi eka javana samuṭṭhāna nti
translated: The single term “season” is used because of the homogeneity of the many kinds of seasons. So too with nutriment.🔽“Arisen from one cognitive series, from one impulsion” is said with reference to the five doors and the sixth.

original: pañcachaṭṭhadvāravasena vuttaṃ. Santatisamayakathā vipassakānaṃ upakāratthāya aṭṭhakathāsu kathitā.
analyzed: pañca chaṭṭha dvāra vasena vuttam santati samaya kathā vipassakānam upakāra atthāya aṭṭhakathāsu kathitā
translated: The explanation of continuity and of occasion is given in the commentaries for the benefit of meditators.

original: Niṭṭhitahetupaccayakiccaṃ, niṭṭhitahetukiccamaniṭṭhitapaccayakiccaṃ, ubhayakiccamasampattaṃ,
analyzed: niṭṭhita hetu paccaya kiccam niṭṭhita hetu kiccam aniṭṭhita paccaya kiccam ubhaya kiccam asampattam
translated: The function of the cause is finished, but not that of the condition; the function of neither is finished;

original: sakiccakkhaṇe paccuppannaṃ. Janako hetu, upatthambhako paccayo, tesaṃ uppādanaṃ upatthambhanañca
analyzed: sa kicca khaṇe paccuppannam janakaḥ hetu upatthambhako paccayaḥ tesam uppādanam upatthambhanañca
translated: At the moment of its own function it is present. The generator is the cause; the supporter is the condition. The function of these is the generating and the supporting.

original: kiccaṃ. Yathā bījassa aṅkuruppādanaṃ pathavīādīnañca tadupatthambhanaṃ kammassa kaṭattārūpavipākuppādanaṃ
analyzed: kiccam yathā bījassa aṅkura uppādanam pathavī ādīnam ca tad upatthambhanam kammassa kaṭattā rūpa vipāka uppādanam
translated: Just as the seed’s function is the generating of the sprout and that of the earth, etc., is the supporting of it, so too the function of the kamma that generates the materiality that is its ripening is the generating of it,

original: āhārādīnaṃ tadupatthambhanaṃ, evaṃ ekekassa kalāpassa cittuppādassa ca janakānaṃ🔽kammānantarādipaccayabhūtānaṃ upatthambhakānañca sahajātapurejātapacchājātānaṃ kiccaṃ
analyzed: āhāra ādīnam tat upatthambhanam evam ekekassa kalāpassa cittuppādassa ca janakānam  kamma anantara ādi paccaya bhūtānam upatthambhakānam ca sahajāta purejāta pacchājātānam kiccam
translated: and that of nutriment, etc., is the supporting of it. Likewise the function of the kamma-resultant materiality that is the cause of the arising of each of the aggregates and of consciousness is the generating of them,🔽and that of the conascent and prenascent and postnascent conditions that are the supporters of it is the supporting of them. This should be understood in each instance according to the way in which the function of the cause and the function of the condition are stated.

original: yathāsambhavaṃ yojetabbaṃ. Tattha uppādakkhaṇe hetukiccaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ, tīsupi khaṇesu
analyzed: yathāsambhavam yojetabbam tattha uppāda khaṇe hetu kiccam daṭṭhabbam tīsu pi khaṇesu
translated: Herein, the function of the cause should be understood as the function of the cause of generation, and the function of the condition as the function of the condition of support.

original: paccayakiccaṃ. Pathavīādīnaṃ sandhāraṇādikaṃ phassādīnaṃ phusanādikañca attano attano
analyzed: paccaya kiccam pathavī ādīnam sandhāraṇa ādikam phassa ādīnam phusana ādikam ca attanaḥ attanaḥ
translated: The function of earth, etc., is the supporting, etc., of the material body, and the function of contact, etc., is the impressing, etc., of an impression on the material body.

original: kiccaṃ sakiccaṃ, tassa karaṇakkhaṇo sakiccakkhaṇo. Saha vā kiccena sakiccaṃ, yasmiṃ
analyzed: kiccam sa kiccam tassa karaṇa kkhaṇaḥ sa kicca kkhaṇaḥ saha vā kiccena sa kiccam yasmin
translated: The moment of the performance of that is the moment of its own function. Or alternatively, that which has the function is the function itself;

original: khaṇe sakiccaṃ rūpaṃ vā arūpaṃ vā hoti, so sakiccakkhaṇo, tasmiṃ khaṇe paccuppannaṃ.
analyzed: khaṇe sa kiccam rūpam vā arūpam vā hoti saḥ sa kicca khaṇaḥ tasmin khaṇe paccuppannam
translated: At the moment of its own function, the materiality or immateriality is present.

original: 6. Ettakamevāti “tesaṃ tesa”nti iminā āmeḍitavacanena abhibyāpanatthena vuttatthameva.🔽“Aparassa aparassā”ti dīpanaṃ aparadīpanaṃ. Pariyesatūti etena pariyesanāya aniṭṭhanāmanivattanassa🔽akāraṇabhāvaṃ dasseti. Kammadosena hi cittavipallāsadosena ca gūthabhakkhapāṇādayo
analyzed: ettakam eva ati tesam tesam ti iminā āmeḍita vacanena abhibyāpana atthena vutta ttham eva  aparassa aparassa ati dīpanam apara dīpanam pariyesatu uti etena pariyesanāya aniṭṭha nāma nivattanassa  akāraṇa bhāvam dasseti kamma dosena hi citta vipallāsa dosena ca gūtha bhakkha pāṇa ādayo
translated: ‘Only this much’: the word ‘each’ in the phrase ‘of each’ is a distributive particle, and so the meaning is stated by the words ‘is present’.

original: ummattakādayo ca pariyeseyyuṃ diṭṭhivipallāsena ca yonakādayo na ārammaṇassa pariyesitabbasabhāvattā,
analyzed: ummattaka ādayo ca pariyeseyyum diṭṭhi vipallāsena ca yonaka ādayaḥ na ārammaṇassa pariyesitabba sabhāva ttā
translated: ‘And of the other, the other’ is the ‘further illustration’. ‘May seek’ : by this he shows that the seeking is not the cause of the non-occurrence of the undesirable name. For the cannibals, the men who eat excrement, etc., would seek it through the fault of kamma and through the fault of the perversion of consciousness. And the hermaphrodites, etc., would seek it through the perversion of view. But it is not the nature of the object to be sought,

original: apariyesitabbasabhāvattā pana etassa aniṭṭhamicceva nāmanti attho.
analyzed: a pariyesitabba sabhāva ttā pana etassa aniṭṭham icca eva nāman ti attho
translated: and it is not the nature of the object not to be sought, and so the meaning is that it is undesirable.

original: Sampattivirahatoti rūpādīnaṃ devamanussasampattibhave kusalakammaphalatā samiddhasobhanatā
analyzed: sampatti virahataḥ ti rūpa ādīnam deva manussa sampatti bhave kusala kamma phala tā samiddha sobhana tā
translated: ‘Absence of excellence’: the excellence of materiality, etc., is the state of being the fruit of profitable kamma in the case of the excellence of the divine and human kinds of existence, and the state of being well-formed and beautiful.

original: ca sampatti, tabbirahatoti attho. Tato eva taṃ na pariyesitabbanti. Sobhanāni ca
analyzed: ca sampatti tad birahato ti attho tatas eva tam na pariyesitabbanti sobhanāni ca
translated: The absence of that is the meaning. And that is why it should not be sought. And the beautiful

original: kānici hatthirūpādīni akusalakammanibbattāni na tesaṃyeva hatthiādīnaṃ sukhassa hetubhāvaṃ🔽gacchantīti tesaṃ saṅgaṇhanatthaṃ “akanta”nti vuttaṃ. Tassa tasseva hi sattassa attanā
analyzed: kānici hatthi rūpa ādīni akusala kamma nibbattāni na tesam yeva hatthi ādīnam sukhassa hetu bhāvam  gacchanti iti tesam saṅgaṇhana attham akantam ti vuttam tassa tassa iva hi sattassa attanā
translated: Some things born of unprofitable kamma, such as elephants, etc., do not become a cause of pleasure for those same elephants, etc.,

original: katena kusalena nibbattaṃ sukhassa paccayo hoti, akusalena nibbattaṃ dukkhassa. Tasmā
analyzed: katena kusalena nibbattam sukhassa paccayaḥ hoti akusalena nibbattam dukkhassa tasmā
translated: because they are tormented by being made to carry heavy loads, etc., and because they are killed and their tusks and so on are taken. So in order to include them, “unloved” is said. For it is a condition for the pleasure of each being that is born of the profitable kamma done by that very being himself, and it is a condition for the pain of each being that is born of the unprofitable kamma done by that very being himself. Therefore

original: kammajānaṃ iṭṭhāniṭṭhatā kammakārakasattassa vasena yojanārahā siyā. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ🔽pana “kusalakammajaṃ aniṭṭhaṃ nāma natthī”ti idameva vuttaṃ, na vuttaṃ “akusalakammajaṃ
analyzed: kamma jānaṃ iṭṭha aniṭṭha tā kamma kāraka sattassa vasena yojana arahā siyā aṭṭhakathāyaṃ  pana kusala kamma jam aniṭṭham nāma natthi iti idam eva vuttam na vuttam akusala kamma jam
translated: the desirability or undesirability of what is born of kamma should be interpreted according to the being who is the doer of the kamma.

original: iṭṭhaṃ nāma natthī”ti. Tena akusalakammajampi sobhanaṃ parasattānaṃ iṭṭhanti anuññātaṃ
analyzed: iṭṭham nāma natthi iti tena akusala kamma jam pi sobhanam para sattānam iṭṭhanti anuññātam
translated: But in the commentary only this is said: “There is nothing unloved that is born of profitable kamma.” It is not said: “There is nothing loved that is born of unprofitable kamma.” So it is allowed that what is born of unprofitable kamma is beautiful and loved by other beings.

original: bhavissati. Kusalakammajaṃ pana sabbesaṃ iṭṭhamevāti vadanti. Tiracchānagatānaṃ pana
analyzed: bhavissati kusala kamma jam pana sabbesam iṭṭham eva ati vadanti tiracchāna gatānam pana
translated: But they say that what is born of profitable kamma is loved by all.

original: kesañci manussarūpaṃ amanāpaṃ, yato te disvāva palāyanti. Manussā ca devatārūpaṃ
analyzed: kesañci manussa rūpam amanāpam yatas te disvā ava palāyanti manussā ca devatā rūpam
translated: But some animals dislike the human form, since they run away on seeing people. And some people dislike the form of deities,

original: disvā bhāyanti, tesampi vipākaviññāṇaṃ taṃ rūpaṃ ārabbha kusalavipākaṃ uppajjati,
analyzed: disvā bhāyanti tesam pi vipāka viññāṇam tam rūpam ārabbha kusala vipākam uppajjati
translated: and they are afraid of it. And their resultant consciousness arises as profitable resultant in the case of visible data, etc., as the object of that.

original: tādisassa pana puññassa abhāvā na tesaṃ tattha abhirati hotīti adhippāyo. Kusalakammajassa
analyzed: tādisassa pana puññassa abhāvā na tesam tattha abhirati hoti iti adhippāyaḥ kusala kamma jassa
translated: But the intention is that they do not delight in it because there is no such kind of merit.

original: pana aniṭṭhassābhāvo viya akusalakammajassa sobhanassa iṭṭhassa abhāvo vattabbo.
analyzed: pana aniṭṭhassa abhāvaḥ viya akusala kamma jassa sobhanassa iṭṭhassa abhāvaḥ vattabbo
translated: But it should be said that the unprofitableness of what is produced by profitable kamma is like the unprofitableness of what is produced by unprofitable kamma.

original: Hatthiādīnampi hi akusalakammajaṃ manussānaṃ akusalavipākasseva ārammaṇaṃ, kusalakammajaṃ🔽pana pavatte samuṭṭhitaṃ kusalavipākassa. Iṭṭhārammaṇena pana vomissakattā appakaṃ🔽akusalakammajaṃ bahulaṃ akusalavipākuppattiyā kāraṇaṃ na bhavissatīti sakkā vattunti.
analyzed: hatthi ādīnam pi hi akusala kamma jam manussānam akusala vipākassa iva ārammaṇam kusala kamma jam  pana pavatte samuṭṭhitam kusala vipākassa iṭṭha ārammaṇena pana vomissaka ttā appakam  akusala kamma jam bahulam akusala vipāka uppattiyā kāraṇam na bhavissati iti sakkā vattun ti
translated: For the kamma-born elephant, etc., are the object of only the unprofitable resultants of human beings,🔽but what is produced by profitable kamma in the course of an existence is the object of profitable resultants.🔽But since it is mixed with a desirable object, it is not a cause for the occurrence of unprofitable resultants in the way that what is produced by unprofitable kamma is.🔽So it can be said that it is not a cause for the occurrence of unprofitable resultants in the way that what is produced by unprofitable kamma is.

original: Vipākaṃ pana katthaci na sakkā vañcetunti vipākavasena iṭṭhāniṭṭhārammaṇavavatthānaṃ
analyzed: vipākam pana katthaci na sakkā vañcetun ti vipāka vasena iṭṭha aniṭṭha ārammaṇa vavatthānam
translated: But it is not possible to deceive with resultants in any instance. So the definition of desirable and undesirable objects by way of resultants is well given.

original: suṭṭhu vuttaṃ. Tasmā taṃ anugantvā sabbattha iṭṭhāniṭṭhatā yojetabbā.
analyzed: suṭṭhu vuttam tasmā tam anugantvā sabbattha iṭṭha aniṭṭha tā yojetabbā
translated: So it should be construed as desirable and undesirable in all instances in accordance with that.

original: Aniṭṭhā pañca kāmaguṇāti kasmā vuttaṃ, nanu “cakkhuviññeyyāni rūpāni iṭṭhānī”ti evamādinā
analyzed: aniṭṭhā pañca kāmaguṇā ti kasmā vuttam nanu cakkhu viññeyyāni rūpāni iṭṭhāni iti evamādinā
translated: Why is it said that the five strands of sensual desire are unlovely? Are not only lovely visible forms, etc., stated in the way beginning, “Visible forms cognizable by the eye that are desirable, lovely … ” ?

original: iṭṭhāneva rūpādīni “kāmaguṇā”ti vuttānīti? Kāmaguṇasadisesu kāmaguṇavohārato, sadisatā🔽ca rūpādibhāvoyeva, na iṭṭhatā. “Aniṭṭhā”ti vā vacanena akāmaguṇatā dassitāti kāmaguṇavisabhāgā
analyzed: rūpa ādīni kāmaguṇā ti vuttāni iti kāmaguṇa sadisesu kāmaguṇa vohārato sadisa tā  ca rūpa ādi bhāvoyā iva na iṭṭha tā aniṭṭhā ati vā vacanena akāma guṇa tā dassitā ati kāma guṇa visabhāgā
translated: The visible-form, etc., that are similar to the strands of sensual desire are called “strands of sensual desire” because they are spoken of as strands of sensual desire.🔽The similarity is their mere nature as visible form, etc., not their loveliness.

original: rūpādayo “kāmaguṇā”ti vuttā asive “sivā”ti vohāro viya. Sabbāni vā iṭṭhāniṭṭhāni
analyzed: rūpa ādayaḥ kāma guṇā ti vuttā asive sivā ti vohāraḥ viya sabbāni vā iṭṭha aniṭṭhāni
translated: Or the visible forms, etc., that are dissimilar to the strands of sensual desire are called “strands of sensual desire” because the word “unlovely” shows that they are not strands of sensual desire, just as the word “peaceful” is used for what is not peaceful.

original: rūpādīni taṇhāvatthubhāvato kāmaguṇāyeva. Vuttañhi “rūpā loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpa”ntiādi.
analyzed: rūpa ādīni taṇhā vatthu bhāvato kāma guṇāya iva vuttam hi rūpāḥ loke piya rūpam sāta rūpa ntiādi
translated: Or all visible forms, etc., whether lovely or unlovely, are strands of sensual desire because they are bases for craving. For it is said: “In the world, visible forms are lovely and desirable …” .

original: Atisayena pana kāmanīyattā suttesu “kāmaguṇā”ti iṭṭhāni rūpādīni vuttānīti.🔽Dvīsupi hīnapaṇītapadesu “akusalakammajavasena kusalakammajavasenā”ti vacanaṃ “tesaṃ
analyzed: atisayena pana kāmanīya ttā suttesu kāma guṇā ti iṭṭhāni rūpa ādīni vuttāni iti  dvīsupi hīna paṇīta padesu akusala kamma ja vasena kusala kamma ja vasena ati vacanam tesam
translated: But in the suttas the lovely visible forms, etc., are called “strands of sensual desire” because they are particularly desirable.🔽The words “by the unprofitable and profitable courses of kamma” in the passages on the inferior and superior are stated in order to show that the distinction is made by way of the beings.

original: tesaṃ sattāna”nti sattavasena niyametvā vibhajitattā, ayañcattho “tesaṃ tesa”nti
analyzed: tesam sattānam ti satta vasena niyametvā vibhajita ttā ayam ca atthaḥ tesam tesam ti
translated: The meaning is this: “The inferior and superior are distinguished by way of those beings who are inferior and superior by reason of their unprofitable and profitable courses of kamma respectively.”

original: avayavayoge sāmivacanaṃ katvā vuttoti veditabbo. Sattasantānapariyāpannesu kammajaṃ
analyzed: avayava yoge sāmi vacanam katvā vuttaḥ iti veditabbo satta santāna pariyāpannesu kamma jam
translated: The plural should be understood as said by taking the owner as the basis.🔽The best in the continuity of beings

original: visiṭṭhanti “kammajavasenā”ti vuttaṃ. Yadi pana tehi tehīti etasmiṃ atthe tesaṃ tesanti🔽sāmivacanaṃ, visayavisayīsambandhe vā, na kammajavaseneva rūpādīni vibhattāni, sabbesaṃ
analyzed: visiṭṭhanti kamma ja vasena ati vuttam yadi pana tehi tehi iti etasmin atthe tesam tesam ti  sāmi vacanam visaya visayī sambandhe vā na kamma ja vasena iva rūpa ādīni vibhattāni sabbesam
translated: is said to be “by the speed of kamma.” But if the meaning of the words “by the three” is “by the three of them,”🔽then the plural is by the owner. Or it is in the relation of object and objective. The materiality, etc., are not classified by the speed of kamma alone, but they are classified by the eye faculty, etc.,

original: pana indriyabaddhānaṃ vasena vibhattānīti viññāyanti. Ettha ca pākaṭehi rūpādīhi
analyzed: pana indriya baddhānam vasena vibhattāni iti viññāyanti ettha ca pākaṭehi rūpa ādīhi
translated: of all of them. And here the method is shown by the obvious materiality, etc.,

original: nayo dassitoti cakkhādīsupi hīnapaṇītatā yojetabbā.
analyzed: nayaḥ dassito ti cakkha ādīsu pi hīna paṇīta tā yojetabbā
translated: so that the inferiority and superiority of the eye, etc., should be construed.🔽The best is in the desirable, I say,

original: Manāpapariyantanti manāpaṃ pariyantaṃ mariyādābhūtaṃ pañcasu kāmaguṇesu vadāmīti
analyzed: manāpa pariyantanti manāpam pariyantam mariyādā bhūtam pañcasu kāmaguṇesu vadāmi iti
translated: in the five cords of sense desire. The meaning is: I say that the best is in the desirable, which is the limit, the end, the extreme.

original: attho. Kiṃ kāraṇanti? Yasmā te ekaccassa manāpā honti, ekaccassa amanāpā, yassa yeva🔽manāpā, tassa teva paramā, tasmā tassa tassa ajjhāsayavasena kāmaguṇānaṃ paramatā
analyzed: attho kim kāraṇan ti yasmā te ekaccassa manāpāḥ honti ekaccassa amanāpāḥ yassa yā iva  manāpā tassa tā iva paramā tasmā tassa tassa ajjhāsaya vasena kāma guṇānam parama tā
translated: And why? Because they are desirable to some and undesirable to others.

original: hoti, na tesaṃyeva sabhāvato.
analyzed: hoti na tesaṃyā iva sabhāvataḥ
translated: To the one to whom they are desirable they are the best. Therefore the best is in the sense desires according to the inclination of each one, not according to their own-nature.

original: Evanti imasmiṃ sutte vuttanayena. Ekasmiṃyeva assādanakujjhanato ārammaṇasabhāvasseva
analyzed: evam ti imasmin sutte vutta nayena ekasmin yeva assādana kujjhanataḥ ārammaṇa sabhāvassa iva
translated: “Thus”: in the way stated in this sutta. Because of the single mode of relishing and of irritation,🔽and because of the fact that the object is the same,

original: iṭṭhāniṭṭhābhāvato aniṭṭhaṃ “iṭṭha”nti gahaṇato ca, iṭṭhaṃ “aniṭṭha”nti gahaṇato🔽ca iṭṭhāniṭṭhaṃ nāma pāṭiyekkaṃ paṭivibhattaṃ natthīti attho. Saññāvipallāsena cātiādinā
analyzed: iṭṭha aniṭṭha abhāvataḥ aniṭṭham iṭṭhanti gahaṇato ca iṭṭham aniṭṭhanti gahaṇato  ca iṭṭha aniṭṭham nāma pāṭiyekkam paṭivibhattam natthi iti attho saññā vipallāsena ca ati ādinā
translated: and because of the taking of the unlovely as lovely and of the lovely as unlovely,🔽there is no such thing as a separate division of objects into lovely and unlovely.

original: nibbāne viya aññesu ārammaṇesu saññāvipallāsena iṭṭhāniṭṭhaggahaṇaṃ hoti. Pittummattādīnaṃ
analyzed: nibbāne viya aññesu ārammaṇesu saññā vipallāsena iṭṭha aniṭṭha ggahaṇam hoti pittummatta ādīnam
translated: “And by perversion of perception”: the taking of objects as lovely and unlovely is due to perversion of perception as in the case of nibbāna.

original: khīrasakkarādīsu dosussadasamuṭṭhitasaññāvipallāsavasena tittaggahaṇaṃ viyāti imamatthaṃ
analyzed: khīra sakkara ādīsu dosussada samuṭṭhita saññā vipallāsa vasena titta ggahaṇam viyā ti imamattham
translated: The taking of milk, sugar, etc., as bitter is due to the perversion of perception arisen from bile, etc.

original: sandhāya manāpapariyantatā vuttāti dasseti.🔽Vibhattaṃ atthīti ca vavatthitaṃ atthīti attho, aṭṭhakathācariyehi vibhattaṃ pakāsitanti
analyzed: sandhāya manāpa pariyanta tā vuttā iti dasseti  vibhattam atthi iti ca vavatthitam atthi iti attho aṭṭhakathā cariyehi vibhattam pakāsitanti
translated: The meaning intended is this: “The end of the pleasant” is said in order to show that.🔽“There is a division”: the meaning is that there is a definition. Or it can be taken as meaning that it is defined, made clear, by the teachers in the commentaries.

original: vā. Tañca majjhimakasattassa vasena vavatthitaṃ pakāsitañca, aññesañca vipallāsavasena
analyzed: vā tat ca majjhimaka sattassa vasena vavatthitam pakāsitam ca aññesam ca vipallāsa vasena
translated: And that is defined, made clear, in terms of the middle-aged man, and it is made clear by others in terms of perversions.

original: idaṃ iṭṭhaṃ aniṭṭhañca hotīti adhippāyo. Evaṃ vavatthitassa paniṭṭhāniṭṭhassa aniṭṭhaṃ🔽iṭṭhanti ca gahaṇe na kevalaṃ saññāvipallāsova kāraṇaṃ, dhātukkhobhavasena indriyavikārāpattiādinā
analyzed: idam iṭṭham aniṭṭham ca hoti iti adhippāyaḥ evam vavatthitassa paniṭṭha aniṭṭhassa aniṭṭham  ca gahaṇe na kevalam saññā vipallāsaḥ uva kāraṇam dhātu kkhobha vasena indriya vikāra āpatti ādinā
translated: And when the desirable and undesirable have been defined in this way, the undesirable is taken as desirable🔽and the desirable as undesirable. And in this taking of the undesirable as desirable and the desirable as undesirable, it is not only perversion of perception that is the cause, but also the perversion of cognizance and perversion of view.🔽And it can be said that the perversion of cognizance and perversion of view are the cause of the perversion of perception.🔽And it can be said that the perversion of perception is the cause of the perversion of cognizance and perversion of view.

original: kusalākusalavipākuppattihetubhāvopīti sakkā vattuṃ. Tathā hi sītudakaṃ ghammābhitattānaṃ
analyzed: kusala akusala vipāka uppatti hetu bhāvaḥ api iti sakkā vattum tathā hi sīta udakam
translated: And it can be said that the perversion of cognizance and perversion of view are the cause of the perversion of perception.🔽And it can be said that the perversion of cognizance and perversion of view are the cause of the perversion of perception.🔽And it can be said that the perversion of perception is the cause of the perversion of cognizance and perversion of view.

original: kusalavipākassa kāyaviññāṇassa hetu hoti, sītābhibhūtānaṃ akusalavipākassa. Tūlapicusamphasso
analyzed: kusala vipākassa kāya viññāṇassa hetu hoti sītā abhibhūtānam akusala vipākassa tūla picu samphasso
translated: And it can be said that the perversion of perception is the cause of the perversion of cognizance and perversion of view.🔽And it can be said that the perversion of cognizance and perversion of view are the cause of the perversion of perception.🔽And it can be said that the perversion of perception is the cause of the perversion of cognizance and perversion of view.🔽And it can be said that the perversion of perception is the cause of the perversion of cognizance and perversion of view.🔽And it can be said that the perversion of cognizance and perversion of view are the cause of the perversion of perception.

original: vaṇe dukkho nivaṇe sukho, mudutaruṇahatthasambāhanañca sukhaṃ uppādeti, teneva hatthena
analyzed: vaṇe dukkhaḥ nivaṇe sukhaḥ mudu taruṇa hattha sambāhanam ca sukham uppādeti tena iva hatthena
translated: And it can be said that the perversion of perception is the cause of the perversion of cognizance and perversion of view.

original: paharaṇaṃ dukkhaṃ, tasmā vipākavasena ārammaṇavavatthānaṃ yuttaṃ.
analyzed: paharaṇam dukkham tasmā vipāka vasena ārammaṇa vavatthānam yuttam
translated: And it can be said that the perversion of perception is the cause of the perversion of cognizance and perversion of view.🔽And it can be said that the perversion of cognizance and perversion of view are the cause of the perversion of perception.🔽And it can be said that the perversion of perception is the cause of the perversion of cognizance and perversion of view.🔽And it can be said that the perversion of perception is the cause of the perversion of cognizance and perversion of view.

original: Kiñcāpītiādinā satipi saññāvipallāse buddharūpadassanādīsu kusalavipākasseva gūthadassanādīsu
analyzed: kiñcāpi itiādinā sati pi saññā vipallāse buddha rūpa dassana ādīsu kusala vipākassa iva gūtha dassana ādīsu
translated: And it can be said that the perversion of cognizance

original: ca akusalavipākassa uppattiṃ dassento tena vipākena ārammaṇassa iṭṭhāniṭṭhataṃ dasseti.
analyzed: ca akusala vipākassa uppattim dassento tena vipākena ārammaṇassa iṭṭha aniṭṭha tam dasseti
translated: and in showing the occurrence of unprofitable result he shows the pleasantness and unpleasantness of the object by means of that result.

original: Vijjamānepi saññāvipallāse ārammaṇena vipākaniyamadassanaṃ ārammaṇaniyamadassanatthameva katanti.🔽Apica dvāravasenapītiādinā dvārantare dukkhassa sukhassa ca paccayabhūtassa dvārantare🔽sukhadukkhavipākuppādanato vipākena ārammaṇaniyamadassanena ekasmiṃyeva ca dvāre🔽samānasseva maṇiratanādiphoṭṭhabbassa saṇikaṃ phusane pothane ca sukhadukkhuppādanato
analyzed: vijjamāne api saññā vipallāse ārammaṇena vipāka niyama dassanam ārammaṇa niyama dassana attham eva katam ti  apica dvāra vasena pi iti ādinā dvāra antare dukkhassa sukhassa ca paccaya bhūtassa dvāra antare  sukha dukkha vipāka uppādanataḥ vipākena ārammaṇa niyama dassanena ekasmiṃyeva ca dvāre  samānassa iva maṇi ratana ādi phoṭṭhabbassa saṇikam phusane pothane ca sukha dukkha uppādanato
translated: And although there is perversion of perception, the showing of the result’s being governed by the object is done only in order to show the object’s governance.🔽Besides, in the words “Also, by way of door” , etc., it is because of the production of painful and pleasant results in another door that the object’s governance by the result is shown by means of the result.

original: vipākavasena iṭṭhāniṭṭhatā dassitāti viññāyati.🔽Heṭṭhimanayoti majjhimakasattassa vipākassa ca vasena vavatthitaṃ ārammaṇaṃ gahetvā
analyzed: vipāka vasena iṭṭha aniṭṭha tā dassitā iti viññāyati  heṭṭhima nayo ti majjhimaka sattassa vipākassa ca vasena vavatthitam ārammaṇam gahetvā
translated: And in the words “And in one door only” , etc., it is because of the production of painful and pleasant results by mere contact and mere pressure of the jewel, etc., that the pleasantness and unpleasantness by means of the result is shown.

original: “tesaṃ tesaṃ sattānaṃ uññāta”nti ca ādinā vuttanayo. Sammutimanāpanti majjhimakasattassa
analyzed: tesam tesam sattānam ca ādinā vutta nayo majjhimaka sattassa
translated: “The lower method” is the method stated thus “The object is defined by means of the result of the middle kind of being” and “The object is agreeable to such and such beings” , etc. “Conventional pleasantness” is the pleasantness of the middle kind of being.

original: vipākassa ca vasena sammataṃ vavatthitaṃ manāpaṃ, taṃ pana sabhāveneva vavatthitanti🔽abhinditabbatova na bhindatīti adhippāyo. Saññāvipallāsena nerayikādīhipi puggalehi
analyzed: vipākassa ca vasena sammatam vavatthitam manāpam tam pana sabhāvena iva vavatthitanti  a bhinditabbataḥ va na bhindati iti adhippāyaḥ saññā vipallāsena nerayika ādīhi pi puggalehi
translated: and it is agreeable because of the ripening of kamma. But that is agreeable only in the sense of its own individual essence.

original: manāpanti gahitaṃ puggalamanāpaṃ “taṃ taṃ vā panā”tiādinā bhindati. Vemānikapetarūpampi
analyzed: manāpanti gahitam puggala manāpam tam tam vā panāti ādinā bhindati vemānika peta rūpam pi
translated: The intention is that it is not divided because it cannot be divided. He divides the disagreeable in the case of the puggala who apprehends it as agreeable by the words “or any other” , etc., because of the perversion of perception.

original: akusalakammajattā kammakāraṇādidukkhavatthubhāvato ca “manussarūpato hīna”nti vuttaṃ.🔽7. Oḷārikarūpānaṃ vatthārammaṇapaṭighātavasena supariggahitatā, sukhumānaṃ tathā
analyzed: akusala kamma jattā kamma kāraṇa ādi dukkha vatthu bhāvataḥ ca manussa rūpataḥ hīnanti vuttam  oḷārika rūpānam vattha ārammaṇa paṭighāta vasena su pariggahita tā sukhumānam tathā
translated: The appearance of the petas who are ghosts is said to be “inferior to human appearance” because it is the result of unprofitable kamma and because it is a basis for suffering due to kamma, etc.🔽The gross kinds of appearance are to be construed as “well apprehended” because they are apprehended by means of the physical base, object, and resistance, and the subtle kinds as “ill apprehended” because they are not so apprehended.

original: abhāvato duppariggahitatā ca yojetabbā. Duppariggahaṭṭheneva lakkhaṇaduppaṭivijjhanatā
analyzed: abhāvataḥ duppariggahita tā ca yojetabbā duppariggaha ṭṭhena iva lakkhaṇa duppaṭivijjhana tā
translated: The difficulty of penetrating their characteristics should be understood as due to the very fact that they are ill apprehended.

original: daṭṭhabbā. Dasavidhanti “dūre”ti avuttassa dassanatthaṃ vuttaṃ. Vuttampi pana okāsato dūre hotiyeva.
analyzed: daṭṭhabbā dasavidhanti dūre iti avuttassa dassana attham vuttam vuttam pi pana okāsataḥ dūre hoti yeva
translated: The tenfold is mentioned in order to show the seeing of what is not mentioned as “far away.” But what is mentioned is also far away in the sense of location.

original: Heṭṭhimanayoti “itthindriyaṃ…pe… idaṃ vuccati rūpaṃ santike”ti evaṃ lakkhaṇato dvādasahatthavasena🔽vavatthitaokāsato ca dassetvā niyyātitanayo. So lakkhaṇokāsavasena dūrasantikena
analyzed: idam vuccati rūpam santikā iti evam lakkhaṇataḥ dvādasa hattha vasena  vavatthita okāsataḥ ca dassetvā niyyāti tanayaḥ so lakkhaṇa ukāsa vasena dūra santikena
translated: That method, by defining it in terms of the location, has gone by way of the near and the far,🔽taking the near and the far together, and so it has gone by way of the mixed.🔽Or alternatively, “by the method of the lower” is the method stated by the passage beginning, “The femininity faculty … this is called visible form that is near” , showing the nearness by defining it in terms of the twelve fingerbreadths and by defining it in terms of the location.

original: saha gahetvā niyyātitattā bhindamāno missakaṃ karonto gato. Atha vā bhindamānoti
analyzed: saha gahetvā niyyātitattā bhindamānaḥ missakam karontaḥ gataḥ atha vā bhindamānaḥ iti
translated: That method, by defining it in terms of the location, has gone by way of the near and the far,🔽taking the near and the far separately, and so it has gone by way of the mixed.🔽Or alternatively, “by the method of the lower” is the method stated by the passage beginning, “The femininity faculty … this is called visible form that is near” , showing the nearness by defining it in terms of the twelve fingerbreadths and by defining it in terms of the location.🔽That method, by defining it in terms of the location, has gone by way of the near and the far,

original: sarūpadassanena lakkhaṇato yevāpanakena okāsatoti evaṃ lakkhaṇato okāsato ca visuṃ
analyzed: sarūpa dassanena lakkhaṇataḥ yevāpanakena okāsato ti evam lakkhaṇataḥ okāsato ca visum
translated: taking the near and the far separately, and so it has gone by way of the mixed.

original: karonto gatoti attho. Atha vā lakkhaṇato santikadūrānaṃ okāsato dūrasantikabhāvakaraṇena
analyzed: karontaḥ gataḥ ti attho atha vā lakkhaṇato santika dūrānaṃ okāsataḥ dūra santika bhāva karaṇena
translated: Or alternatively, “by the method of the lower” is the method stated by the passage beginning, “The femininity faculty … this is called visible form that is near” , showing the nearness by defining it in terms of the twelve fingerbreadths and by defining it in terms of the location.🔽That method, by defining it in terms of the location, has gone by way of the near and the far,

original: santikabhāvaṃ bhinditvā dūrabhāvaṃ, dūrabhāvañca bhinditvā santikabhāvaṃ karonto
analyzed: santika bhāvam bhinditvā dūra bhāvam dūra bhāvam ca bhinditvā santika bhāvam karontaḥ
translated: taking the near and the far separately, and so it has gone by way of the mixed.

original: pavattoti “bhindamāno gato”ti vuttaṃ. Idha panāti “taṃ taṃ vā pana rūpaṃ upādāya
analyzed: pavattaḥ iti bhindamānaḥ gataḥ ti vuttam idha pana iti tam tam vā pana rūpam upādāya
translated: Or alternatively, “by the method of the lower” is the method stated by the passage beginning, “The femininity faculty … this is called visible form that is near” , showing the nearness by defining it in terms of the twelve fingerbreadths and by defining it in terms of the location.🔽That method, by defining it in terms of the location, has gone by way of the near and the far,

original: upādāyā”ti idha purimanayena lakkhaṇato dūraṃ okāsato santikabhāvakaraṇena na bhindati
analyzed: upādāya ati idha purima nayena lakkhaṇataḥ dūram okāsataḥ santika bhāva karaṇena na bhindati
translated: taking the near and the far separately, and so

original: bhagavā, na ca okāsadūrato visuṃ karaṇena, nāpi okāsadūrena vomissakakaraṇenāti attho.
analyzed: bhagavā na ca okāsa dūrataḥ visum karaṇena na api okāsa dūrena vomissaka karaṇena ati attho
translated: and the Blessed One does not do so by making them separate by means of remoteness of place, nor by making them mixed up by means of remoteness of place.

original: Kiṃ pana karotīti? Okāsato dūrameva bhindati. Ettha pana na pubbe vuttanayena tidhā
analyzed: kim pana karoti iti okāsataḥ dūram eva bhindati ettha pana na pubbe vutta nayena tidhā
translated: But what does he do? He makes them separate by means of remoteness of place. But here the meaning should not be regarded as threefold in the way already stated ,

original: attho daṭṭhabbo. Na hi okāsato dūraṃ lakkhaṇato santikaṃ karoti, lakkhaṇato vā visuṃ
analyzed: atthaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ na hi okāsataḥ dūram lakkhaṇataḥ santikam karoti lakkhaṇataḥ vā visum
translated: for he does not make what is remote by place near by characteristic, nor does he make what is near by characteristic remote by place, nor does he make what is remote by place remote by characteristic,

original: tena vā vomissakanti. Okāsato dūrassa pana okāsatova santikabhāvakaraṇaṃ idha “bhedana”nti🔽veditabbaṃ. Idha pana na lakkhaṇato dūraṃ bhindatīti etthāpi vā na pubbe vuttanayena🔽tidhā bhedassa akaraṇaṃ vuttaṃ, lakkhaṇato santikadūrānaṃ pana lakkhaṇato upādāyupādāya
