analyzed: tena vā okāsataḥ dūrassa pana okāsataḥ va santika bhāva karaṇam idha bhedana nti  veditabbam idha pana na lakkhaṇataḥ dūram bhindati iti ettha api vā na pubbe vutta nayena  tidhā bhedassa akaraṇam vuttam lakkhaṇato santika dūrānam pana lakkhaṇato upādāya upādāya
translated: nor what is near by characteristic near by place. But the making of what is remote by place near by place should be understood here as “separating” .🔽But here too the meaning should not be regarded as threefold in the way already stated ,🔽for the separation is not made in that way. But what is remote by characteristic and what is near by characteristic are not respectively remote and near by characteristic.

original: dūrasantikabhāvo natthīti lakkhaṇato dūrassa lakkhaṇatova santikabhāvākaraṇaṃ lakkhaṇato
analyzed: dūra santika bhāvaḥ natthi iti lakkhaṇataḥ dūrassa lakkhaṇataḥ va santika bhāva akaraṇam lakkhaṇato
translated: So the non-separating of what is remote by characteristic should be understood as “non-making near by characteristic of what is remote by characteristic.”

original: dūrassa abhedananti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Purimanayo viya ayaṃ nayo na hotīti ettakameva hi
analyzed: dūrassa abhedananti daṭṭhabbam purima nayaḥ viya ayam nayaḥ na hoti iti ettakam eva hi
translated: This method is not like the previous one. For it is only this much that is said:

original: ettha dassetīti bhindamānoti ettha ca aññathā bhedanaṃ vuttaṃ, bhedanaṃ idha ca aññathā vuttanti.
analyzed: ettha dasseti iti bhindamānaḥ ti ettha ca aññathā bhedanam vuttam bhedanam idha ca aññathā vuttanti
translated: Here it is shown thus. And here the breaking is stated otherwise than in the case of the material groups, and the breaking there is stated otherwise than here.

original: Rūpakkhandhaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: rūpa kkhandha niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of the materiality aggregate is ended.

original: 2. Vedanākkhandhaniddesavaṇṇanā🔽8. Cakkhādayo pasādā oḷārikamanomayattabhāvapariyāpannā kāyavohāraṃ arahantīti tabbatthukā
analyzed: vedanā khandha niddesa vaṇṇanā  cakkhu ādayo pasādāḥ oḷārika manaḥ maya tta bhāva pariyāpannā kāya vohāram arahanti iti tabbatthukā
translated: Description of the feeling aggregate🔽The sensitive materiality of the eye, etc., which is included in the gross and mind-made physical bodies, is a basis for bodily intimation,

original: adukkhamasukhā “kāyikā”ti pariyāyena vuttā, na kāyapasādavatthukattā. Na hi cakkhādayo🔽kāyapasādā hontīti. Santativasena khaṇādivasena cāti ettha addhāsamayavasena atītādibhāvassa🔽avacanaṃ sukhādivasena bhinnāya atītādibhāvavacanato. Na hi sukhāyeva addhāvasena
analyzed: adukkham asukhā kāyikā ati pariyāyena vuttā na kāya pasāda vatthuka ttā na hi cakkha ādayaḥ  kāya pasādāḥ honti iti santati vasena khaṇa ādi vasena ca ati ettha addhā samaya vasena atīta ādi bhāvassa  avacanam sukha ādi vasena bhinnāya atīta ādi bhāva vacanataḥ na hi sukhāya iva addhā avasena
translated: and it is called “bodily” in a derived sense, not because it is a basis for the sensitive materiality of the body. For the sensitive materiality of the eye, etc.,🔽is not the sensitive materiality of the body.🔽As to continuity and as to moment: here the past, etc., state of the feeling is not mentioned as to life-period and as to occasion,🔽because it is mentioned as past, etc., according to pleasure, etc., since it is distinguished as past, etc., according to pleasure, pain, and neither-pain-nor-pleasure. For it is not only pleasure that is past, etc., as to life-period and as to occasion;

original: samayavasena ca atītādikā hoti, tathā dukkhā adukkhamasukhā ca kāyikacetasikādibhāvena
analyzed: samaya vasena ca atīta ādikā hoti tathā dukkhā adukkhamasukhā ca kāyika cetasika ādi bhāvena
translated: so too pain and neither-pain-nor-pleasure are distinguished as bodily, mental, etc.,

original: bhinnā. Tena vedanāsamudayo addhāsamayavasena atītādibhāvena vattabbataṃ arahati
analyzed: bhinnā tena vedanā samudayaḥ addhā samaya vasena atīta ādi bhāvena vattabbatam arahati
translated: Therefore the origin of feeling is not stated as to past, etc., state according to life-period and according to occasion,

original: samudāyassa tehi paricchinditabbattā, vedanekadesā pana ettha gahitāti te santatikhaṇehi
analyzed: samudāyassa tehi paricchinditabba ttā vedanā eka desā pana ettha gahitā ati te santati khaṇehi
translated: because the collection is to be defined by them, but the many individual instances are included here. So they are fit to be defined by the series and the moment.

original: paricchedaṃ arahanti tattha tathāparicchinditabbānaṃ gahitattāti. Ekasantatiyaṃ pana
analyzed: paricchedam arahanti tattha tathā a paricchinditabbānam gahita ttā ati eka santatiyam pana
translated: Herein, it is because those that are to be defined in this way are included in the series and the moment. But in a single continuity

original: sukhādianekabhedasabbhāvena tesu yo bhedo paricchinditabbabhāvena gahito, tassa ekappakārassa🔽pākaṭassa paricchedikā taṃsahitadvārālambanappavattā, avicchedena taduppādakekavidhavisayasamāyogappavattā
analyzed: sukha ādi aneka bheda sabbhāvena tesu yaḥ bhedaḥ paricchinditabba bhāvena gahito tassa eka ppakārassa  pākaṭassa paricchedikā tad sahita dvāra ālambana ppavattā avicchedena tad uppādaka ekavidha visaya samāyoga ppavattā
translated: the difference that is to be defined as the many kinds of pleasure, etc., is included in the single kind that is manifest.🔽So the series is fit to be the definition of that, which occurs with that as its door and object, and which occurs with the single kind of object that produces it without a break.

original: ca santati bhavituṃ arahatīti tassa bhedantaraṃ anāmasitvā paricchedakabhāvena gahaṇaṃ🔽kataṃ. Lahuparivattino vā dhammā parivattaneneva paricchedaṃ arahantīti santatikhaṇavasena
analyzed: ca santati bhavitum arahati iti tassa bheda antaram an āmasitvā paricchedaka bhāvena gahaṇam  katam lahu parivattinaḥ vā dhammā parivattanena iva paricchedam arahanti iti santati khaṇa vasena
translated: So the definition is made by including it as the definition without mentioning any other difference of it.🔽Or else, it is said that the definition is stated by means of the series and the moment because states that are rapidly changing are fit to be defined by the change itself.

original: paricchedo vutto. Pubbantāparantamajjhagatāti etena hetupaccayakiccavasena vuttanayaṃ dasseti.
analyzed: paricchedaḥ vuttaḥ pubba anta apara anta majjha gatā ti etena hetu paccaya kicca vasena vutta nayam dasseti
translated: As to past, future, and present: he shows the method stated by means of cause, condition, and function.

original: 11. Kilesaggisampayogato sadarathā. Etena sabhāvato oḷārikataṃ dasseti, dukkhavipākaṭṭhenāti🔽etena oḷārikavipākanipphādanena kiccato. Kammavegakkhittā kammapaṭibaddhabhūtā ca
analyzed: kilesa aggi sampayogataḥ etena sabhāvataḥ oḷārika tam dasseti dukkha vipāka ṭṭhena ati  etena oḷārika vipāka nipphādanena kiccato kamma vega kkhittā kamma paṭibaddha bhūtā ca
translated: By “because of being associated with the defilement-fire” he shows the grossness by nature. By “because of having painful result” he shows it by function, since it produces a gross result.🔽The result is “without exertion” because it is impelled by kamma and is bound up with kamma. The functional is “with exertion” because it is not impelled by kamma and is not bound up with kamma.

original: kāyakammādibyāpāravirahato nirussāhā vipākā, saussāhā ca kiriyā avipākā. Savipākā🔽ca sagabbhā viya oḷārikāti tabbipakkhato avipākā sukhumāti vuttā.
analyzed: kāya kamma ādi byāpāra virahataḥ nirussāhā vipākā saussāhā ca kiriyā avipākā sa vipākā  ca sa gabbhā viya oḷārikā ti tad bipakkhataḥ avipākā sukhumā iti vuttā
translated: The result is “gross” because it is accompanied by the embryo, etc., and the functional is said to be “subtle” because it is the opposite of that.

original: Asātaṭṭhenāti amadhuraṭṭhena. Tena sātapaṭipakkhaṃ aniṭṭhasabhāvaṃ dasseti. Dukkhaṭṭhenāti🔽dukkhamaṭṭhena. Tena dukkhānaṃ santāpanakiccaṃ dasseti. “Yāyaṃ, bhante, adukkhamasukhā
analyzed: asāta ṭṭhena āti amadhura ṭṭhena tena sāta paṭipakkham aniṭṭha sabhāvam dasseti dukkha ṭṭhena āti  dukkham aṭṭhena tena dukkhānam santāpana kiccam dasseti yā ayam bhante adukkha masukhā
translated: By “because of being unpleasant” he shows the opposite of that, namely, the nature of being unloved, since it is not sweet. By “because of being painful” he shows the function of pain, namely, burning.

original: vedanā, santasmiṃ esā paṇīte sukhe vuttā bhagavatā”ti vacanato adukkhamasukhā pharaṇasabhāvavirahato
analyzed: vedanā santasmin esā paṇīte sukhe vuttā bhagavatā ati vacanato adukkham asukhā pharaṇa sabhāva virahato
translated: “Bhikkhus, that pleasant feeling which arises, which is born of a cause, which is caused by kamma, that pleasant feeling was called by the Exalted One a gross form of pleasure” .

original: asantānaṃ kāmarāgapaṭighānusayānaṃ anusayanassa aṭṭhānattā santā, sukhe nikantiṃ
analyzed: asantānam kāma rāga paṭigha anusayānam anusayanassa aṭṭhāna ttā santā sukhe nikantim
translated: Since it is devoid of the nature of pervading, the neither-painful-nor-pleasant is “not a continuum” because it is not a basis for the underlying tendency to lust for sensual pleasure and for resentment.🔽It is “pleasure” because of the inclination to pleasure in it.

original: pariyādāya adhigantabbattā padhānabhāvaṃ nītāti paṇītāti. Tathā anadhigantabbā ca
analyzed: pariyādāya adhigantabba ttā padhāna bhāvam nītā ati paṇītā ati tathā an adhigantabbā ca
translated: And it is not to be surpassed because it is not surpassed by any other jhāna in the same way.

original: kāmāvacarajātiādisaṅkaraṃ akatvā samānajātiyaṃ ñāṇasampayuttavippayuttādike samānabhede
analyzed: kāmāvacara jāti ādi saṅkaram a katvā samāna jātiyam ñāṇa sampayutta vippayutta ādike samāna bhede
translated: And it is peaceful because it is not mixed up with the defilements of the lower jhānas, etc., and because it is characterized by the unification of mind that is, because it is characterized by the single function of the mind.🔽It is sublime because it is the most excellent owing to the excellence of the mode of purification, and so on.🔽It is peaceful because it is characterized by the absence of disturbance of the elements, and so on.

original: sukhato paṇītāti yojetabbā. Upabrūhitānaṃ dhātūnaṃ paccayabhāvena sukhā khobheti
analyzed: sukhatas paṇītā iti yojetabbā upabrūhitānam dhātūnam paccaya bhāvena sukhā khobheti
translated: It is sublime because it is the most excellent owing to the excellence of the mode of purification, and so on.

original: vibādhitānaṃ paccayabhāvena dukkhā ca. Ubhayampi kāyaṃ byāpentaṃ viya uppajjatīti
analyzed: vibādhitānam paccaya bhāvena dukkhā ca ubhayam pi kāyam byāpentam viya uppajjati iti
translated: It is peaceful because it is characterized by the absence of disturbance of the elements, and so on.🔽It is sublime because it is the most excellent owing to the excellence of the mode of purification, and so on.🔽It is peaceful because it is characterized by the absence of disturbance of the elements, and so on.

original: pharati. Madayamānanti madaṃ karontaṃ. Chādayamānanti icchaṃ uppādentaṃ, avattharamānaṃ
analyzed: pharati madayamānanti madam karontam chādayamānanti iccham uppādentam avattharamānam
translated: It is sublime because it is the most excellent owing to the excellence of the mode of purification, and so on.🔽It is peaceful because it is characterized by the absence of disturbance of the elements, and so on.

original: vā. Ghammābhitattassa sītodakaghaṭena āsittassa yathā kāyo upabrūhito hoti, evaṃ
analyzed: vā ghamma abhitattassa sītā udaka ghaṭena āsittassa yathā kāyaḥ upabrūhitaḥ hoti evam
translated: It is sublime because it is the most excellent owing to the excellence of the mode of purification, and so on.🔽It is peaceful because it is characterized by the absence of disturbance of the elements, and so on.🔽It is sublime because it is the most excellent owing to the excellence of the mode of purification, and so on.🔽It is peaceful because it is characterized by the absence of disturbance of the elements, and so on.🔽It is sublime because it is the most excellent owing to the excellence of the mode of purification, and so on.🔽It is peaceful because it is characterized by the absence of disturbance of the elements, and so on.🔽It is sublime because it is the most excellent owing to the excellence of the mode of purification, and so on.🔽It is peaceful because it is characterized by the absence of disturbance of the elements, and so on.🔽It is sublime because it is the most excellent owing to the excellence of the mode of purification, and so on.

original: sukhasamaṅginopīti katvā “āsiñcamānaṃ viyā”ti vuttaṃ. Ekattanimitteyevāti pathavīkasiṇādike🔽ekasabhāve eva nimitte. Caratīti nānāvajjane javane vedanā viya vipphandanarahitattā sukhumā.
analyzed: sukha samaṅginaḥ api iti katvā āsiñcamānam viya iti vuttam pathavīkasiṇa ādike 🔽eka sabhāve eva nimitte carati iti nānā vajjane javane vedanā viya vipphandana rahita ttā sukhumā
translated: It is peaceful because it is characterized by the absence of disturbance of the elements, and so on.🔽It is sublime because it is the

original: Adhippāye akusalatāya akovido. Kusalattike…pe… āgatattāti “kusalākusalā vedanā oḷārikā,
analyzed: adhippāye akusala tāya akovidaḥ kusala atti kepe āgata ttā ati kusala akusalā vedanā oḷārikā
translated: neutral feeling is subtle” .

original: abyākatā vedanā sukhumā”ti evaṃ āgatattā. Bhūmantarabhede dassetuṃ “yampī”tiādi āraddhaṃ.
analyzed: abyākatā vedanā sukhumā ati evam āgata ttā bhūmantara bhede dassetum yat pi itiādi āraddham
translated: In order to show the classification of the planes, the text is stated thus: “And again, bhikkhus” .🔽By this method: by this method of showing the gross and subtle state in each instance by way of the individual essence, etc.,

original: Iminā nīhārenāti etena “kāmāvacarasukhato kāmāvacarupekkhā sukhumā”tiādinā sabhāvādibhedena🔽ca oḷārikasukhumabhāvaṃ tatra tatreva kathento na bhindatīti nayaṃ dasseti.🔽Lokiyalokuttaramissakā kathitā, tasmā ekantapaṇīte hīnapaṇītānaṃ uddhaṭattā evameva
analyzed: iminā nīhārena ati etena kāmāvacara sukhataḥ kāmāvacara upekkhā sukhumā ati ādinā sa bhāva ādi bhedena  ca oḷārika sukhuma bhāvam tatra tatra iva kathentaḥ na bhindati iti nayam dasseti  kathitā tasmai ekanta paṇīte hīna paṇītānam evam eva
translated: as follows: “Compared with the pleasure of the sense sphere, equanimity of the sense sphere is gross; compared with the pleasure of the first jhāna, equanimity of the sense sphere is gross” , etc.🔽The mundane and supramundane are mixed in the exposition. Therefore, since the gross and subtle states of the entirely desirable and the entirely undesirable are brought out in the way stated,

original: ekantahīne ca yathāsambhavaṃ hīnapaṇītatā uddharitabbāti anuññātaṃ hotīti ubhayattha
analyzed: ekanta hīne ca yathāsambhavam hīna paṇīta tā uddharitabbā ati anuññātam hoti iti ubhayattha
translated: it is permitted that the gross and subtle states of the entirely undesirable should be brought out in the same way, as far as possible.

original: taduddharaṇe na kukkuccāyitabbanti attho.
analyzed: tad uddharaṇe na kukkuccāyitabbanti attho
translated: The meaning is that one should not hesitate to bring out the gross and subtle states in both instances.

original: Akusalānaṃ kusalādīhi sukhumattābhāvato pāḷiyā āgatassa aparivattanīyabhāvena “heṭṭhimanayo
analyzed: akusalānam kusala ādīhi sukhuma tā abhāvataḥ pāḷiyā āgatassa a parivattanīya bhāvena heṭṭhima nayo
translated: Because the unwholesome is not subject to reversal, it is not gross in the way stated in the texts, being devoid of grossness in comparison with the wholesome, etc.

original: na oloketabbo”ti vuttanti vadanti, taṃtaṃvāpanavasena kathanepi parivattanaṃ natthīti🔽na parivattanaṃ sandhāya “heṭṭhimanayo na oloketabbo”ti vuttaṃ, heṭṭhimanayassa pana
analyzed: na oloketabbaḥ iti vuttan ti vadanti taṃ taṃ vāpana vasena kathane pi parivattanam natthi iti  na parivattanam sandhāya heṭṭhima nayaḥ na oloketabbaḥ iti vuttam heṭṭhima nayassa pana
translated: and it is said that the higher method should not be looked at. But there is no reversal in the way of explanation by way of the various kinds of repetition.🔽So it is not because of reversal that it is said that the higher method should not be looked at. But because the higher method is stated,

original: vuttattā avuttanayaṃ gahetvā “taṃ taṃ vā panā”ti vattuṃ yuttanti “heṭṭhimanayo na🔽oloketabbo”ti vuttanti veditabbo. Bahuvipākā akusalā dosussannatāya oḷārikā, tathā
analyzed: vutta ttā a vutta nayam gahetvā tam tam vā pana ati vattum yuttam ti heṭṭhima nayaḥ na  oloketabbaḥ ti vuttanti veditabbaḥ bahu vipākā akusalā dosussannatāya oḷārikā tathā
translated: it is proper to say “or any other” , taking the method not stated there. So it should be understood that it is said that the higher method should not be looked at.

original: appavipākā kusalā. Mandadosattā appavipākā akusalā sukhumā, tathā bahuvipākā kusalā
analyzed: appa vipākā kusalā manda dosattā appa vipākā akusalā sukhumā tathā bahu vipākā kusalā
translated: The unprofitable action with much result is gross because of the abundance of hate in it, and likewise the profitable action with little result. The unprofitable action with little result is subtle because of the paucity of hate in it, and likewise the profitable action with much result.

original: ca. Oḷārikasukhumanikantivatthubhāvato kāmāvacarādīnaṃ oḷārikasukhumatā. Sāpīti bhāvanāmayāya🔽bhedanena dānamayasīlamayānañca paccekaṃ bhedanaṃ nayato dassitanti veditabbaṃ. Sāpīti
analyzed: ca kāmāvacara ādīnam oḷārika sukhuma tā sā api iti bhāvanā mayāya  bhedanena dāna maya sīlam ayānam ca paccekam bhedanam nayataḥ dassitam ti veditabbam sā api iti
translated: The grossness and subtlety of the sense-desire-element, etc., is according to the grossness and subtlety of the physical basis.🔽And that should be understood to be shown by the method of analysis of the three kinds of joy.

original: vā tividhāpīti yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: vā tividhā api iti yojetabbam
translated: Or the threefold joy should be construed with each of the three kinds of generosity.

original: 13. Jātiādivasena asamānakoṭṭhāsatā visabhāgaṭṭho. Dukkhavipākatādivasena asadisakiccatā,
analyzed: jāti ādi vasena asamāna koṭṭhāsa tā visa bhāga ṭṭhaḥ dukkha vipāka tā ādi vasena asadisa kicca tā
translated: The meaning of “dissociated” is the state of being different in the sense of having different characteristics, as birth, etc., and different functions, as ripening in suffering, etc.,

original: asadisasabhāvatā vā visaṃsaṭṭho, na asampayogo. Yadi siyā, dūravipariyāyena santikaṃ
analyzed: asadisa sabhāva tā vā visaṃsaṭṭhaḥ na a sampayogaḥ yadi siyā dūra vipariyāyena santikam
translated: or the state of being dissimilar in nature. It is not the state of being unassociated. If it were, then what is far away would be near,

original: hotīti saṃsaṭṭhaṭṭhena santikatā āpajjati, na ca vedanāya vedanāsampayogo atthi.
analyzed: hoti iti saṃsaṭṭha aṭṭhena santika tā āpajjati na ca vedanāya vedanā sampayogaḥ atthi
translated: and the state of being near would be included in the meaning of “associated.” But there is no association of feeling with feeling.

original: Santikapadavaṇṇanāya ca “sabhāgaṭṭhena sarikkhaṭṭhena cā”ti vakkhatīti vuttanayeneva attho veditabbo.🔽Na dūrato santikaṃ uddharitabbanti kasmā vuttaṃ, kiṃ yathā santikato akusalato akusalā
analyzed: santika pada vaṇṇanāya ca sabhāga ṭṭhena sa rikkha ṭṭhena ca ati vakkhati iti vutta nayena iva atthaḥ veditabbaḥ  na dūratas santikam uddharitabban ti kasmā vuttam kim yathā santikataḥ akusalataḥ akusalā
translated: And the meaning should be understood in the way stated in the description of the word “near” as “in the sense of similarity and in the sense of association.”

original: dūreti uddharīyati, tathā tato dūrato kusalato kusalā santiketi uddharituṃ na sakkāti?
analyzed: dūrā iti uddharīyati tathā tatas dūratas kusalatas kusalā santikā iti uddharitum na sakkāti
translated: Why is it said that “it should not be taken as near by removing it from far away”? Is it because it cannot be taken as near by removing it from the profitable as far away and from the unprofitable as near?

original: Na sakkā. Tathā hi sati kusalā kusalāya santiketi katvā santikato santikatā eva uddharitā
analyzed: na sakkā tathā hi sati kusalā kusalāya santikā iti katvā santikatā u santikatā eva uddharitā
translated: It cannot be so taken. For if it could, then since the profitable would be near to the profitable, the state of being near would be included in the meaning of “associated.”

original: siyā, tathā ca sati santikasantikataratāvacanameva āpajjati, upādāyupādāya dūrasantikatāva🔽idha vuccati, tasmā dūrato dūruddharaṇaṃ viya santikato santikuddharaṇañca na sakkā
analyzed: siyā tathā ca sati santika santikatara tā vacanam eva āpajjati upādāya upādāya dūra santika tā vacanam  idha vuccati tasmai dūratas dūra uddharaṇam viya santikatas santika uddharaṇam ca na sakkā
translated: and if it were, then it would follow that the words “nearer and nearer” are superfluous.🔽It is the nearness and farness in relation to the given object that is referred to here.

original: kātuṃ dūradūrataratāya viya santikasantikataratāya ca anadhippetattā. Atha pana vadeyya
analyzed: kātum dūra dūratara tāya viya santika santikatara tāya ca an adhippeta ttā atha pana vadeyya
translated: So it is impossible to remove it from the near side as it were from the far side.🔽And if he were to say:

original: “na kusalā kusalāya eva santiketi uddharitabbā, atha kho yato sā dūre, tassā akusalāyā”ti,
analyzed: na kusalā kusalāya eva santikā iti uddharitabbā atha kho yatas sā dūre tassāḥ akusalāya ati
translated: “The profitable should not be removed from the profitable, but from the unprofitable from which it is far away,”🔽that is not so, because the unprofitable is never near to the profitable.

original: tañca natthi. Na hi akusalāya kusalā kadāci santike atthīti. Athāpi vadeyya “yā akusalā🔽kusalāya santike, sā tato dūrato kusalato uddharitabbā”ti, tadapi natthi. Na hi kusale🔽akusalā atthi, yā tato santiketi uddhariyeyya, tasmā idha vuttassa dūrassa dūrato
analyzed: tat ca natthi na hi akusalāya kusalā kadāci santike atthi iti atha api vadeyya yā akusalā  kusalāya santike sā tatas dūratas kusalataḥ uddharitabbā ati tat api natthi na hi kusale  akusalā atthi yā tatas santikā iti uddhariyeyya tasmai idha vuttassa dūrassa dūratas
translated: And if he were to say:🔽“That unprofitable which is near to the profitable should be removed from the profitable,” that is not so either, because the unprofitable is not in the profitable.

original: accantavisabhāgattā dūre santikaṃ natthīti na sakkā dūrato santikaṃ uddharituṃ, santike
analyzed: accanta visabhā gattā dūre santikam natthi iti na sakkā dūratas santikam uddharitum santike
translated: So it is impossible to remove it from the near side as it were from the far side, because of the utter unlikelihood of what is stated here.

original: panidha vutte bhinne tattheva dūraṃ labbhatīti āha “santikato pana dūraṃ uddharitabba”nti.🔽Upādāyupādāya dūrato ca santikaṃ na sakkā uddharituṃ. Lobhasahagatāya dosasahagatā
analyzed: vutte bhinne tattha iva dūram labbhati iti āha santikataḥ pana dūram uddharitabbanti  upādāya upādāya dūratas ca santikam na sakkā uddharitum lobha sahagatāya dosa sahagatā
translated: but when it is stated here, it is far from the near that is to be taken out.

original: dūre lobhasahagatā santiketi hi vuccamāne santikatova santikaṃ uddharitaṃ hoti. Tathā
analyzed: dūre lobha sahagatā santikā iti hi vuccamāne santikatas va santikam uddharitam hoti tathā
translated: It cannot be taken out from far to near according to the object of the defilement. For if it were said that the unprofitable associated with hate is far from that associated with greed, and that associated with greed is near to it, then the near would be taken out from the near.

original: dosasahagatāya lobhasahagatā dūre dosasahagatā santiketi etthāpi sabhāgato sabhāgantarassa
analyzed: dosa sahagatāya lobha sahagatā dūre dosa sahagatā santikā iti ettha api sabhāgataḥ sabhāgantarassa
translated: And if it were said that the unprofitable associated with greed is far from that associated with hate, and that associated with hate is near to it, then the similar would be taken out from the similar.

original: uddhaṭattā, na ca sakkā “lobhasahagatāya dosasahagatā dūre sā eva ca santike”ti vattuṃ🔽dosasahagatāya santikabhāvassa akāraṇattā, tasmā visabhāgatā bhedaṃ aggahetvā na
analyzed: na ca sakkā lobha sahagatāya dosa sahagatā dūre sā eva ca santikā iti vattum  dosa sahagatāya santika bhāvassa akāraṇa ttā tasmā visabhāga tā bhedam aggahetvā na
translated: But it cannot be said that that associated with hate is far from that associated with greed and that it is near to it,🔽because it is not the cause of the nearness of that associated with hate. So it does not occur without taking the difference of dissimilar kinds as the reason.

original: pavattatīti sabhāgābyāpakattā dūratāya dūrato santikuddharaṇaṃ na sakkā kātuṃ. Na
analyzed: pavattati iti dūratāya dūratas
translated: Therefore it cannot be taken out from far to near because of farness, since it is not the pervasion of the similar.

original: hi dosasahagatā akusalasabhāgaṃ sabbaṃ byāpetvā pavattatīti. Sabhāgatā pana bhedaṃ
analyzed: hi dosa sahagatā akusala sabhāgam sabbam byāpetvā pavattati iti sabhāga tā pana bhedam
translated: For that associated with hate does not occur as the pervasion of all the similar unprofitable. But the similar is the reason for the difference of kinds.

original: antogadhaṃ katvā pavattatīti visabhāgabyāpakattā santikatāya santikato dūruddharaṇaṃ
analyzed: antogadham katvā pavattati iti visabhāga byāpaka ttā santikatāya santikatas dūr uddharaṇam
translated: It occurs as if it were inside, and so it is removed from far away by nearness, because it pervades what is unlike itself.

original: sakkā kātuṃ. Akusalatā hi lobhasahagatādisabbavisabhāgabyāpikāti. Tenāha “na dūrato🔽santikaṃ uddharitabba”ntiādi.🔽Vedanākkhandhaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: sakkā kātum akusala tā hi lobha sahagata ādi sabba visabhāga byāpikā iti tena āha na dūratas  santikam uddharitabba ntiādi  vedanā khandha niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: It is possible to remove it from far to near because it is a pervasion of the dissimilar, since it occurs pervading the dissimilar. For unprofitableness pervades all the dissimilar, such as that accompanied by greed, and so on. That is why he said, “It cannot be removed from far to near” and so on. The description of the feeling aggregate is ended

original: 3. Saññākkhandhaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: saññā khandha niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: Description of the perception aggregate

original: 17. Cakkhusamphassajā saññāti ettha yadipi vatthuto phassassa nāmaṃ phassato ca saññāya,
analyzed: cakkhu samphassa jā saññā ti ettha yadi pi vatthutaḥ phassassa nāmam phassato ca saññāya
translated: In the case of the perception born of eye-contact: although the name of the contact is according to the physical basis and the name of the perception is according to the contact,

original: vatthuvisiṭṭhaphassena pana visiṭṭhasaññā vatthunā ca visiṭṭhā hoti phassassa viya
analyzed: vatthu visiṭṭha phassena pana visiṭṭha saññā vatthunā ca visiṭṭhā hoti phassassa viya
translated: nevertheless the perception, being distinguished by the contact distinguished by the physical basis, is itself distinguished by the physical basis, as the contact is by the object.

original: tassāpi tabbatthukattāti “vatthuto nāma”nti vuttaṃ. Paṭighasamphassajā saññāti etthāpi
analyzed: tassa api tad vatthuka ttā ti vatthutaḥ nāman ti vuttam paṭigha samphassa jā saññā ti ettha api
translated: So it is said to be “according to the physical basis.” In the case of the perception born of resistance-contact:

original: yathā phasso vatthārammaṇapaṭighaṭṭanena uppanno, tathā tato jātasaññāpīti “vatthārammaṇato
analyzed: yathā phassaḥ vattha ārammaṇa paṭighaṭṭanena uppannaḥ tathā tatas jāta saññā api iti vattha ārammaṇato
translated: just as the contact arises through the impact of the physical basis and the object, so too the perception that arises from that is called “according to the physical basis and the object” because it arises through the impact of the physical basis and the object.

original: nāma”nti vuttaṃ. Ettha ca paṭighajo samphasso, paṭighaviññeyyo vā samphasso paṭighasamphassoti
analyzed: nāman ti vuttam ettha ca paṭigha jaḥ samphassaḥ paṭigha viññeyyaḥ vā samphassaḥ paṭigha samphassaḥ ti
translated: and so on. Herein, contact that is born of resistance or contact that is to be known by resistance is contact with resistance.

original: uttarapadalopaṃ katvā vuttanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: uttara pada lopam katvā vuttam iti veditabbam
translated: It should be understood that this is said by ellipsis of the middle term.

original: Viññeyyabhāve vacanaṃ adhikicca pavattā, vacanādhīnā vā arūpakkhandhā, adhivacanaṃ🔽vā etesaṃ pakāsanaṃ atthīti “adhivacanā”ti vuccanti, tatojo samphasso adhivacanasamphasso,🔽samphassoyeva vā yathāvuttehi atthehi adhivacano ca samphasso cāti adhivacanasamphasso,
analyzed: viññeyya bhāve vacanam adhikicca pavattā vacana adhīnāḥ vā arūpa kkhandhāḥ adhivacanam  vā etesam pakāsanam atthi iti adhivacanā ati vuccanti samphassaḥ adhivacana samphasso  vā yathā vuttehi atthehi adhivacanaḥ ca samphasso ca ati adhivacana samphassaḥ
translated: The mental-data element is called “idea” because the words that occur in the mode of expression are dependent on it, or because it is the means of revealing them,🔽Contact that is born of that is contact with ideas.🔽Or contact itself is contact with ideas because it is ideas in the way already stated.🔽Or contact that is to be known by ideas is contact with ideas.

original: adhivacanaviññeyyo vā samphasso adhivacanasamphasso, tato tasmiṃ vā jātā adhivacanasamphassajā.🔽Pañcadvārikasamphassepi yathāvutto attho sambhavatīti tena pariyāyena tatojāpi saññā
analyzed: adhivacana viññeyyaḥ vā samphassaḥ adhivacana samphassaḥ tatas tasmin vā jātāḥ adhivacana samphassa jā  pañca dvārika samphasse pi yathā vuttaḥ attho sambhavati iti tena pariyāyena tatojā api saññā
translated: Or it is born of that, or it has that as its source.🔽And since the meaning stated applies to the five-door contact too, perception born of that is called “born of contact with ideas” in that secondary sense.

original: “adhivacanasamphassajā”ti vuttā. Yathā pana aññappakārāsambhavato manosamphassajā
analyzed: adhivacana samphassa jāti vuttā yathā pana añña ppakāra asambhavataḥ manaḥ samphassa jā
translated: But because it is impossible to apply the meaning stated to the mind-door, perception born of mind-contact is called “born of contact with ideas” in the primary sense.

original: nippariyāyena “adhivacanasamphassajā”ti vuccati, na evaṃ ayaṃ paṭighasamphassajā
analyzed: nippariyāyena adhivacana samphassa jāti vuccati na evam ayam paṭigha samphassa jā
translated: but this is not so in the case of the contact classed as “arisen from impingement.”

original: āveṇikappakārantarasambhavatoti adhippāyo.
analyzed: āveṇika ppakāra antara sambhavato ti adhippāyaḥ
translated: The intention is that it is not so because it has a different and unique mode of being.

original: Yadi evaṃ cattāro khandhāpi yathāvuttasamphassato jātattā “adhivacanasamphassajā”ti
analyzed: yadi evam cattāraḥ khandhāḥ api yathāvutta samphassataḥ jāta ttā adhivacana samphassa jāti
translated: If that is so, then since the four aggregates are born from the contact classed as “arisen from impingement” as described, it is proper to call them “arisen from impingement.”🔽Why is only perception so described?

original: vattuṃ yuttā, saññāva kasmā evaṃ vuttāti? Tiṇṇaṃ khandhānaṃ atthavasena attano pattampi
analyzed: vattum yuttā saññā ava kasmai evam vuttā ati tiṇṇam khandhānam attha vasena
translated: The meaning of the three aggregates is that the name of the aggregate of perception itself

original: nāmaṃ yattha pavattamāno adhivacanasamphassaja-saddo niruḷhatāya dhammābhilāpo hoti,
analyzed: nāmam yattha pavattamānaḥ adhivacana samphassa ja saddaḥ niruḷha tāya dhamma abhilāpaḥ hoti
translated: is the sound of the expression “arisen from impingement” because it is well known as the verbal intimation of the object.

original: tassā saññāya eva āropetvā sayaṃ nivattanaṃ hoti. Tenāha “tayo hi arūpino khandhā”tiādi.
analyzed: tassā saññāya eva āropetvā sayam nivattanam hoti tena āha tayo hi arūpino khandha atiādi
translated: It is only perception that turns back after superimposing the name on the object. Therefore it is said: “For the three immaterial aggregates” and so on.

original: Atha vā saññāya paṭighasamphassajāti aññampi visiṭṭhaṃ nāmaṃ atthīti adhivacanasamphassajānāmaṃ
analyzed: atha vā saññāya paṭigha samphassa jāti aññam pi visiṭṭham nāmam atthi iti adhivacana samphassa jā nāmam
translated: Or alternatively, since there is another name for the birth of perception classed as “arisen from impingement,”

original: tiṇṇaṃyeva khandhānaṃ bhavituṃ arahati. Te pana attano nāmaṃ saññāya datvā nivattāti
analyzed: tiṇṇam yeva khandhānam bhavitum arahati te pana attanaḥ nāmam saññāya da tvā nivattāti
translated: the name “arisen from impingement” is proper only for the three aggregates. But they, after giving their own name to perception, turn back.

original: imamatthaṃ sandhāyāha “tayo hi arūpino khandhā”tiādi. Pañcadvārikasaññā oloketvāpi🔽jānituṃ sakkāti idaṃ tena tenādhippāyena hatthavikārādikaraṇe tadadhippāyavijānananimittabhūtā
analyzed: imam attham sandhāya āha tayo hi arūpino khandha ati ādi pañcadvārika saññā oloketvā api  jānitum sakkā ati idam tena tena adhippāyena hattha vikāra ādi karaṇe tad adhippāya vijānana nimitta bhūtā
translated: It is possible to know by looking at the five doors’ perceptions.🔽The looking is the cause for the knowledge of the state of being attached, etc., in the case of attachment, etc., to looking, etc., just as the intimation is the cause for the knowledge of the intention in the case of the making of gestures, etc., by the hand, etc., with that or that intention.

original: viññatti viya rajjitvā olokanādīsu rattatādivijānananimittaṃ olokanaṃ cakkhuviññāṇavisayasamāgame
analyzed: viññatti viya rajjitvā olokana ādīsu ratta tā ādi vijānana nimittam olokanam cakkhu viññāṇa visaya samāgame
translated: When the object comes into the range of the eye-consciousness, the looking becomes evident.

original: pākaṭaṃ hotīti taṃsampayuttāya saññāyapi tathāpākaṭabhāvaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ.
analyzed: pākaṭam hoti iti tad sampayuttāya tathā apākaṭa bhāvam sandhāya vuttam
translated: Therefore, it is said with reference to the fact that the perception associated with it also becomes evident in the same way.

original: Rajjitvā olokanādivasena pākaṭā javanappavattā bhavituṃ arahatīti etissā āsaṅkāya🔽nivattanatthaṃ “pasādavatthukā evā”ti āha. Aññaṃ cintentanti yaṃ pubbe tena cintitaṃ
analyzed: rajjitvā olokana ādi vasena pākaṭā javana pavattā bhavitum arahati iti etissā āsaṅkāya  nivattana attham pasāda vatthukāḥ evā ti āha aññam cintentanti yam pubbe tena cintitam
translated: “It is possible that it occurs in the javanas as evident by way of looking, etc., with attachment,” and because of this doubt,🔽“It is only based on confidence” is said in order to remove it.

original: ñātaṃ, tato aññaṃ cintentanti attho.🔽Saññākkhandhaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽4. Saṅkhārakkhandhaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: ñātam tatas aññam attho 🔽saññā kkhandha niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā 🔽saṅkhāra khandha niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: “Thinking of something else”: the meaning is that it thinks of something other than what was previously thought of and known.

original: 20. Heṭṭhimakoṭiyāti ettha bhummaniddesova. Tattha hi padhānaṃ dassitanti. Yadi evaṃ
analyzed: heṭṭhima koṭiyā ti ettha bhumma niddesaḥ uva tattha hi padhānam dassitam ti yadi evam
translated: ‘The lower end’ is the demonstration of the plane here. For the effort is shown there.

original: uparimakoṭiyā taṃ na dassitanti āpajjatīti? Nāpajjati, uparimakoṭigatabhāvena vinā
analyzed: uparima koṭiyā tam na dassitanti āpajjati iti na āpajjati uparima koṭi gata bhāvena vinā
translated: If that is so, then it follows that it is not shown in the upper end?🔽It does not follow, because without the state of being in the upper end there is no state of being in the lower end. For the lower end is all-pervading.

original: heṭṭhimakoṭigatabhāvābhāvato. Heṭṭhimakoṭi hi sabbabyāpikāti. Dutiye karaṇaniddeso,
analyzed: heṭṭhima koṭi gata bhāva abhāvataḥ heṭṭhima koṭi hi sabba byāpikā ati dutiye karaṇa niddeso
translated: In the second case the demonstration is of the instrument,

original: heṭṭhimakoṭiyā āgatāti sambandho. Purimepi vā “heṭṭhimakoṭiyā”ti yaṃ vuttaṃ, tañca
analyzed: heṭṭhima koṭiyā āgatā iti sambandho purime api vā heṭṭhima koṭiyā iti yat vuttam tat ca
translated: the construction being ‘having come to the lower end.’ Or alternatively, what is said in the first case, namely, ‘at the lower end,’🔽can be construed as a demonstration of the instrument by the method of showing the effort,

original: padhānasaṅkhāradassanavasenāti sambandhakaraṇena karaṇaniddesova. Taṃsampayuttā saṅkhārāti🔽ekūnapaññāsappabhede saṅkhāre āha. Gahitāva honti tappaṭibaddhattā.
analyzed: padhāna saṅkhāra dassana vasena ati sambandha karaṇena karaṇa niddesaḥ u va tad sampayuttā saṅkhārā ti  saṅkhāre āha gahitāḥ ava honti tad paṭibaddha ttā
translated: and the formations associated with it are the formations classed as forty-nine.🔽They are included because they are bound up with it.

original: Saṅkhārakkhandhaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: saṅkhāra khandha niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of the formations aggregate is ended.

original: Pakiṇṇakakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: pakiṇṇaka kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the miscellaneous discussion

original: Samuggama-saddo sañjātiyaṃ ādiuppattiyaṃ niruḷho. Taṃtaṃpaccayasamāyoge hi purimabhavasaṅkhātā
analyzed: samuggama saddaḥ ādi uppattiyam niruḷhaḥ tad tad paccaya samāyoge hi purima bhava saṅkhātā
translated: The word ‘arising’ is established in the sense of origination, which is the beginning of birth. For when there is a concurrence of the several conditions, the state called the previous existence

original: purimantato uddhaṅgamanaṃ samuggamo, sandhiyaṃ vā paṭisandhiyaṃ uggamo samuggamo.
analyzed: purimantataḥ uddhaṅgamanam samuggamaḥ sandhiyam vā paṭisandhiyam uggamaḥ samuggamaḥ
translated: The emergence of the aggregates that have gone on before is the emergence of the past. Or the emergence of the aggregates at the time of rebirth-linking is the emergence of the past.

original: So pana yattha pañcakkhandhā paripuṇṇā samuggacchanti, tattheva dassito. Etena nayena
analyzed: saḥ pana yattha pañca kkhandhā paripuṇṇā samuggacchanti tattha iva dassitaḥ etena nayena
translated: But that is shown only where the five aggregates emerge complete. By this method

original: aparipuṇṇakhandhasamuggamo ekavokāracatuvokāresu sakkā viññātunti. Atha vā yathādhigatānaṃ
analyzed: a paripuṇṇa khandha samuggamaḥ ekavokāra catuvokāresu sakkā viññātunti atha vā yathā adhigatānam
translated: the emergence of the incomplete aggregates can be understood in the case of the one-constituent and the four-constituent kinds of becoming.

original: pañcannampi khandhānaṃ saha uggamo uppatti samuggamo. Etasmiṃ atthe vikaluppatti
analyzed: pañcannam pi khandhānam saha uggamaḥ uppatti samuggamaḥ etasmin atthe vikala uppatti
translated: Or alternatively, the emergence, the arising, of the five aggregates together, according to how they are acquired, is the emergence of the past. In this sense, the arising of the incomplete aggregates is not included.

original: asaṅgahitā hoti. Himavantappadese jātimantaeḷakalomaṃ jātiuṇṇā. Sappimaṇḍabindūti
analyzed: a saṅgahitā hoti himavanta ppadese jātimanta eḷaka lomam jāti uṇṇā sappimaṇḍa bindu iti
translated: In the Himavanta country, the hair of a wild buffalo is called jāti, and a drop of ghee is called a bindu.

original: evaṃ etthāpi bindu-saddo yojetabbo. Evaṃvaṇṇappaṭibhāganti evaṃvaṇṇaṃ evaṃsaṇṭhānañca.
analyzed: evam ettha api bindu saddaḥ yojetabbaḥ evaṃvaṇṇa paṭibhāgam ti evaṃvaṇṇam evaṃsaṇṭhānam ca
translated: So here too the word bindu should be construed in the same way. “Of the same colour and appearance”: of the same colour and the same shape.

original: Paṭibhajanaṃ vā paṭibhāgo, sadisatābhajanaṃ sadisatāpattīti attho. Evaṃvidho vaṇṇappaṭibhāgo
analyzed: paṭibhajanam vā paṭibhāgaḥ sadisa tā bhajanam sadisa tā āpatti iti atthaḥ evaṃvidhaḥ vaṇṇa ppaṭibhāgaḥ
translated: Or the appearance is the appearing; the meaning is that the similarity is the attainment of similarity. He has such an appearance of the same colour and shape,

original: etassāti evaṃvaṇṇappaṭibhāgaṃ.
analyzed: etassa iti evaṃvaṇṇa paṭibhāgam
translated: thus he is of the same colour and appearance.

original: Santatisīsānīti santatimūlāni, santatikoṭṭhāsā vā. Anekindriyasamāhārabhāvato hi
analyzed: santati sīsāni iti santati mūlāni santati koṭṭhāsāḥ vā aneka indriya samāhāra bhāvataḥ hi
translated: “Roots of continuity” : roots of the continuity, or sections of the continuity.🔽For the “head” is called so because of the gathering together of many faculties.

original: padhānaṅgaṃ “sīsa”nti vuccati, evaṃ vatthudasakādikoṭṭhāsā anekarūpasamudāyabhūtā
analyzed: padhāna aṅgam sīsanti vuccati evam vatthu dasaka ādi koṭṭhāsā aneka rūpa samudāya bhūtā
translated: Thus the sections of the ten bases, etc., which are a collection of many material things,

original: “sīsānī”ti vuttānīti.
analyzed: sīsāni iti vuttāni iti
translated: are called “roots of continuity.”

original: Pañcakkhandhā paripuṇṇā hontīti gaṇanāpāripūriṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ, na tassa tassa khandhassa🔽paripuṇṇataṃ. Kammasamuṭṭhānapaveṇiyā vuttattā “utucittāhārajapaveṇī ca ettakaṃ kālaṃ
analyzed: pañca kkhandhā paripuṇṇāḥ honti iti gaṇanā pāripūrim sandhāya vuttam na tassa tassa khandhassa  kamma samuṭṭhāna paveṇiyāḥ vutta ttā utu citta āhāra ja paveṇī ca ettakam kālam
translated: “The five aggregates are complete” : this is said with reference to the completion of the enumeration, not to the completion of each aggregate.🔽Since the “series of temperature, consciousness, and nutriment” is mentioned in the “originated from kamma” section, it should be said that “the series of temperature, consciousness, and nutriment lasts for so long a time.”

original: atikkamitvā hotī”tiādinā vattabbā siyā, taṃ pana “pubbāparato”ti ettha vakkhatīti
analyzed: atikkamitvā hoti itiādinā vattabbā siyā tam pana pubba aparato ti ettha vakkhati iti
translated: But that is stated in the “before and after” section.

original: akathetvā kammajapaveṇī ca na sabbā vuttāti avuttaṃ dassetuṃ opapātikasamuggamo nāma
analyzed: a kathetvā kamma ja paveṇī ca na sabbā vuttā ti avuttam dassetuṃ opapātikasamuggamaḥ nāma
translated: Therefore, without stating it, the “series of kamma” is not mentioned in its entirety. In order to show what is not mentioned, the “appearance of the apparitional being” is shown.

original: dassito. Evaṃ…pe… pañcakkhandhā paripuṇṇā hontīti paripuṇṇāyatanānaṃ vasena nayo
analyzed: dassitaḥ evam pe pañca kkhandhā paripuṇṇāḥ honti iti paripuṇṇa āyatanānam vasena nayaḥ
translated: Thus … the five aggregates are complete: the method is shown with reference to those who have complete sense bases.

original: dassito, aparipuṇṇāyatanānaṃ pana kāmāvacarānaṃ rūpāvacarānaṃ parihīnāyatanassa vasena
analyzed: dassitaḥ a paripuṇṇa āyatanānam pana kāmāvacarānam rūpāvacarānam parihīna āyatanassa vasena
translated: But with reference to those who have incomplete sense bases, i.e., those in the sense-sphere and fine-material-sphere planes, and those who have lost a sense base,

original: santatisīsahāni veditabbā.
analyzed: santati sīsa hāni veditabbā
translated: and the destruction of the continuity.

original: Pubbāparatoti ayaṃ vicāraṇā na pañcannaṃ khandhānaṃ uppattiyaṃ, atha kho tesaṃ rūpasamuṭṭhāpaneti
analyzed: pubba aparato ti ayam vicāraṇā na pañcannam khandhānam uppattiyam atha kho tesam rūpa samuṭṭhāpanā iti
translated: As to before and after: this consideration is not about the arising of the five aggregates but about their production of materiality.

original: daṭṭhabbā. Taṃ dassento āha “evaṃ panā”tiādi. Apacchāapure uppannesūti etena saṃsayakāraṇaṃ🔽dasseti. Sahuppannesu hi idameva paṭhamaṃ rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti, idaṃ pacchāti adassitaṃ
analyzed: daṭṭhabbā tam dassentaḥ āha evam pana iti ādi apacchā apure uppannesu iti etena saṃsaya kāraṇam  dasseti sahuppannesu hi idam eva paṭhamam rūpam samuṭṭhāpeti idam pacchā ati a dassitam
translated: Showing that, he said, “But in this way” , etc. By “arising before and after” he shows the reason for the doubt.

original: na sakkā viññātuṃ. Ettha ca “pubbāparato”ti etissā vicāraṇāya vatthubhāvena paṭisandhiyaṃ
analyzed: na sakkā viññātum ettha ca pubba aparato ti etissā vicāraṇāya vatthu bhāvena paṭisandhiyam
translated: For when they arise together it is not possible to know which materiality produces which, since it is not seen that “This produces that first, and that afterwards.”

original: uppannā pavattā pañcakkhandhā gahitā. Tattha ca niddhāraṇe bhummaniddesoti “rūpaṃ🔽paṭhamaṃ rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpetī”ti āha. Aññathā bhāvenabhāvalakkhaṇatthe bhummaniddese
analyzed: uppannā pavattā pañca kkhandhā gahitā tattha ca niddhāraṇe bhumma niddeso ti rūpam  paṭhamam rūpam samuṭṭhāpeti iti āha aññathā bhāvena bhāva lakkhaṇa atthe bhumma niddese
translated: And here the five aggregates arisen in rebirth-linking are included as the basis for this consideration as to before and after.🔽And in the definition of the terms there he said “materiality produces materiality” as the definition of the term “before” .

original: sati rūpassa rūpasamuṭṭhāpanakkhaṇe kammassapi rūpasamuṭṭhānaṃ vadantīti ubhayanti
analyzed: sati rūpassa rūpa samuṭṭhāpana khaṇe kammassa api rūpa samuṭṭhānam vadanti iti ubhayanti
translated: Otherwise, if the definition of the terms were given in the sense of the characteristic of non-existence as absence of presence,🔽then, since they would be non-existent, it would be impossible to define them.

original: vattabbaṃ siyāti. Rūpārūpasantatiñca gahetvā ayaṃ vicāraṇā pavattāti “rūpaṃ paṭhamaṃ🔽rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpetī”ti vuttaṃ. Aññathā paṭisandhikkhaṇe eva vijjamāne gahetvā vicāraṇāya
analyzed: vattabbam siyā iti rūpa arūpa santatiñca gahetvā ayam vicāraṇā pavattā iti rūpam paṭhamam  rūpam samuṭṭhāpeti iti vuttam aññathā paṭisandhi kkhaṇe eva vijjamāne gahetvā vicāraṇāya
translated: So it is said, “Materiality first produces materiality.”

original: kariyamānāya arūpassa rūpasamuṭṭhāpanameva natthīti pubbāparasamuṭṭhāpanavicāraṇāva🔽idha na upapajjatīti vattabbaṃ siyāti. Vatthu uppādakkhaṇe dubbalaṃ hotīti sabbarūpānaṃ🔽uppādakkhaṇe dubbalataṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Tadā hi taṃ pacchājātapaccayarahitaṃ āhārādīhi
analyzed: kariyamānāya arūpassa rūpa samuṭṭhāpanam eva natthi iti pubba apara samuṭṭhāpana vicāraṇā va  idha na upapajjati iti vattabbam siyāti vatthu uppāda kkhaṇe dubbalam hoti iti sabbarūpānam  uppāda kkhaṇe dubbala tam sandhāya vuttam tadā hi tam pacchājāta paccaya rahitam āhāra ādīhi
translated: Otherwise, if it were done by taking only what exists at the moment of rebirth-linking, it would have to be said that immateriality has no production of materiality,🔽and then the consideration of production in succession would not apply here.🔽“The basis is weak at the moment of arising”: this is said with reference to the weakness of all material instances at the moment of their arising.

original: ca anupatthaddhanti “dubbala”nti vuttaṃ. Kammavegakkhittattāti idaṃ satipi bhavaṅgassa🔽kammajabhāve sāyaṃ vipākasantati paṭisandhikkhaṇe purimabhavaṅgasamuṭṭhāpakato aññena
analyzed: ca anupatthaddhanti dubbalanti vuttam kamma vega kkhitta ttā ti idam sati pi bhavaṅgassa  kamma ja bhāve sāyam vipāka santati paṭisandhi kkhaṇe purima bhavaṅga samuṭṭhāpakato aññena
translated: For then it is devoid of postnascence conditions and is not yet sustained by nutriment, etc., and so it is called “weak.”

original: kammunā khittā viya appatiṭṭhitā, tato parañca samānasantatiyaṃ anantarapaccayaṃ
analyzed: kammunā khittā viya appatiṭṭhitā tatas parañca samāna santatiyam anantara paccayam
translated: “Because it is impelled by the force of kamma”: this refers to the fact that although the life-continuum is kamma-born, the continuity of resultants at the moment of rebirth-linking is, as it were, unestablished, being impelled by a different kamma from that which impelled the preceding life-continuum.

original: purejātapaccayañca labhitvā patiṭṭhitāti imamatthaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ.🔽Paveṇī ghaṭiyatīti cakkhādivatthusantati ekasmiṃ vijjamāne eva aññassa nirodhuppattivasena
analyzed: purejāta paccayam ca labhitvā patiṭṭhitā ti imam attham sandhāya vuttam  paveṇī ghaṭiyati iti cakkha ādi vatthu santati ekasmin vijjamāne eva aññassa nirodha uppatti vasena
translated: and when it has obtained the condition of prenascence it is established.🔽The line “The stream is strung together” means that the continuity of the physical basis such as the eye is strung together,

original: ghaṭiyati, na cutipaṭisandhinissayavatthūnaṃ viya vicchedappavattīti attho. Aṅgatoti
analyzed: na cuti paṭisandhi nissaya vatthūnam viya viccheda ppavattī iti atthaḥ aṅgataḥ ti
translated: that is, it occurs without interruption, like the physical basis for death and rebirth-linking, not by the arising and ceasing of one after another.🔽“From the factors” means from the jhāna factors.

original: jhānaṅgato. Jhānaṅgāni hi cittena saha rūpasamuṭṭhāpakāni, tesaṃ anubaladāyakāni
analyzed: jhāna aṅgataḥ jhāna aṅgāni hi cittena saha rūpa samuṭṭhāpakāni tesam anubala dāyakāni
translated: For the jhāna factors are the producers of materiality together with consciousness. The path factors, etc., are the supporters of their power.

original: maggaṅgādīni tesu vijjamānesu visesarūpappavattidassanato. Atha vā yāni cittaṅgāni
analyzed: maggaṅga ādīni tesu vijjamānesu visesa rūpa ppavatti dassanato atha vā yāni cittaṅgāni
translated: The meaning is that they are seen to occur as special kinds of materiality when they are present. Or alternatively, the meaning is that they are not deprived of the jhāna factors, etc.,

original: cetanādīni cittassa rūpasamuṭṭhāpane aṅgabhāvaṃ sahāyabhāvaṃ gacchanti, tesaṃ baladāyakehi
analyzed: cetanā ādīni cittassa rūpa samuṭṭhāpane aṅga bhāvam sahāya bhāvam gacchanti tesam bala dāyakehi
translated: which are the supporters of the power of the mind’s factors, such as intention, etc., that go to make up the mind’s function as a producer of materiality.

original: jhānaṅgādīhi aparihīnanti attho. Tato parihīnattā hi cakkhuviññāṇādīni rūpaṃ na samuṭṭhāpentīti.
analyzed: jhāna aṅga ādīhi a parihīnanti attho tatas parihīna ttā hi cakkhu viññāṇa ādīni rūpam na samuṭṭhāpenti iti
translated: For eye-consciousness, etc., do not produce materiality when they are deprived of them.

original: Yo pana vadeyya “paṭisandhicittena sahajātavatthu tassa ṭhitikkhaṇe ca bhaṅgakkhaṇe
analyzed: yaḥ pana vadeyya paṭisandhi cittena sahajāta vatthu tassa ṭhiti khaṇe ca bhaṅga kkhaṇe
translated: But if anyone should say this: “The physical basis that is conascent with rebirth-linking consciousness is the support for the consciousness that arises next to that,

original: ca purejātanti katvā paccayavekallābhāvato tasmiṃ khaṇadvaye rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpetū”ti,🔽taṃ nivārento āha “yadi hi citta”ntiādi. Tattha ṭhitibhaṅgakkhaṇesupi tesaṃ dhammānaṃ
analyzed: ca purejātanti katvā paccaya vekalla abhāvataḥ tasmim khaṇa dvaye rūpam samuṭṭhāpetu uti  tam nivārentaḥ āha yadi hi citta ntiādi tattha ṭhiti bhaṅga kkhaṇesu pi tesam dhammānam
translated: and the materiality in the two instants would arise because of the absence of deficiency in conditions, taking the prenascent as the condition.”🔽To forestall this he says, “If, at the instant of … and at the instant of … the materiality would arise, then it would arise at the rebirth-linking too.” Herein, he allows that it cannot be said that at the instants of presence and dissolution the materiality’s physical basis is prenascent.🔽But he shows the fault in that too: “If it were to arise then, it would arise at the rebirth-linking too according to your view.

original: vatthu purejātaṃ na hotīti na vattabbamevetanti anujāni, tatthāpi dosaṃ dasseti.
analyzed: vatthu purejātam na hoti iti na vattabbam eva etat ti anujāni tattha api dosam dasseti
translated: But there is no arising of materiality then.

original: Yadi tadā rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpeyya, tava matena paṭisandhicittampi samuṭṭhāpeyya, tadā
analyzed: yadi tadā rūpam samuṭṭhāpeyya tava matena paṭisandhi cittam pi samuṭṭhāpeyya tadā
translated: And when there is the arising of materiality, then at the instant of arising, according to your view,

original: pana rūpuppādanameva natthi. Yadā ca rūpuppādanaṃ, tadā uppādakkhaṇe tava matenapi🔽paccayavekallameva paṭisandhikkhaṇe purejātanissayābhāvato, tasmā paṭisandhicittaṃ
analyzed: pana rūpa uppādanam eva natthi yadā ca rūpa uppādanam tadā uppāda kkhaṇe tava matena api  paccaya vekallam eva paṭisandhi kkhaṇe purejāta nissaya abhāvato tasmā paṭisandhi cittam
translated: there is deficiency in conditions too, because there is no prenascent condition by way of dependence at the rebirth-linking instant.🔽So the rebirth-linking consciousness does not give rise to materiality. This is the intention here.

original: rūpaṃ na samuṭṭhāpetīti ayamettha adhippāyo. Uppādakkhaṇe aṭṭha rūpāni gahetvā uṭṭhahati.
analyzed: rūpam na samuṭṭhāpeti iti ayam ettha adhippāyaḥ uppāda kkhaṇe aṭṭha rūpāni gahetvā uṭṭhahati
translated: It arises taking the eight kinds of materiality at the instant of arising.

original: Kasmā? Arūpadhammānaṃ anantarādipaccayavasena savegānaṃ paripuṇṇabalānameva uppattito.
analyzed: kasmai arūpa dhammānam anantara ādi paccaya vasena sa vegānam paripuṇṇa balānam eva uppattitaḥ
translated: Why? Because immaterial states arise only with impetus and with full strength by means of the condition being prenascent, etc.,

original: Avisayatāyāti agatapubbassa gāmassa āgantukassa avisayabhāvato. Appahutatāyāti tattha🔽tassa anissarabhāvato. Cittasamuṭṭhāna…pe… ṭhitānīti idaṃ yehākārehi cittasamuṭṭhānarūpānaṃ
analyzed: avisaya tāya ati agata pubbassa gāmassa āgantukassa avisaya bhāvataḥ appahuta tāya ati tattha  tassa anissara bhāvato citta samuṭṭhāna pe ṭhitāni iti idam yehākārehi
translated: ‘Because it is not their domain’: because it is not the domain of one who has not been there before, of a visitor to a village. ‘Because it is not their province’:

original: cittacetasikā paccayā honti, tehi sabbehi paṭisandhiyaṃ cittacetasikā samatiṃsakammajarūpānaṃ🔽yathāsambhavaṃ paccayā hontīti katvā vuttaṃ.
analyzed: citta cetasikā paccayāḥ honti tehi sabbehi paṭisandhiyam citta cetasikā sama tiṃsa kamma ja rūpānam  yathāsambhavam paccayāḥ honti iti katvā vuttam
translated: because it is not their resort there. ‘The kinds of states that are conascent with consciousness, etc., are conditions, as presence condition, for the kinds of materiality originated by consciousness, etc.’: this is said because the states of consciousness and its concomitants that arise at rebirth-linking are conditions, as appropriate, for the thirty kinds of materiality originated by kamma.

original: Vaṭṭamūlanti taṇhā avijjā vuccati. Cuticittena uppajjamānaṃ rūpaṃ tato purimatarehi uppajjamānaṃ viya na bhavantare uppajjatīti vaṭṭamūlassa vūpasantattā anuppatti vicāretabbā.
analyzed: vaṭṭamūlanti taṇhā avijjā vuccati cuti cittena uppajjamānam rūpam tatas purimatarehi uppajjamānam viya na bhava antare uppajjati iti vaṭṭamūlassa vūpasanta ttā anuppatti vicāretabbā
translated: ‘The root of the round’: craving and ignorance are what is meant. The materiality that arises with the death consciousness does not arise in the next becoming as it did before, and so its arising should be investigated as due to the cessation of the root of the round.

original: Rūpassa natthitāyāti rūpānaṃ nissaraṇattā arūpassa, virāgavasena pahīnattā uppādetabbassa
analyzed: rūpassa na atthitāya ati rūpānam nissaraṇa ttā arūpassa virāga vasena pahīna ttā uppādetabbassa
translated: ‘Because of the absence of materiality’: because of the escape from materiality, which is immaterial, and because of the abandoning of what is to be produced by means of fading away of greed,

original: abhāvaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Rūpokāse vā rūpaṃ atthīti katvā rūpapaccayānaṃ rūpuppādanaṃ
analyzed: abhāvam sandhāya vuttam rūpa ukāse vā rūpam atthi iti katvā rūpa paccayānam rūpa uppādanam
translated: ‘there is no arising of materiality’ is said. Or alternatively, because there is materiality in the space where materiality is, the production of materiality by the conditions for materiality is

original: hoti, arūpaṃ pana rūpassa okāso na hotīti yasmiṃ rūpe sati cittaṃ aññaṃ rūpaṃ uppādeyya,
analyzed: hoti arūpam pana rūpassa okāsaḥ na hoti iti yasmin rūpe sati cittam aññam rūpam uppādeyya
translated: But materiality is not a condition for immaterial dhammas.

original: tadeva tattha natthīti attho. Purimarūpassapi hi paccayabhāvo atthi puttassa pitisadisatādassanatoti.
analyzed: tat eva tattha natthi iti attho purima rūpassa api hi paccaya bhāvaḥ atthi puttassa
translated: The meaning is that it is not present there. For the first materiality is a condition for the second, as the father is for the son.

original: Utu pana paṭhamaṃ rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti paṭisandhicittassa ṭhitikkhaṇe samuṭṭhāpanatoti🔽adhippāyo. Utu nāma cesa dandhanirodhotiādi utussa ṭhānakkhaṇe uppādane kāraṇadassanatthaṃ
analyzed: utu pana paṭhamam rūpam samuṭṭhāpeti paṭisandhi cittassa ṭhiti khaṇe samuṭṭhāpanato ti  adhippāyaḥ utu nāma ca isa dandha nirodhaḥ tiādi utussa ṭhāna kkhaṇe uppādane kāraṇa dassana attham
translated: But temperature generates the first materiality, because it generates it at the moment of the life-continuum consciousness’s presence.🔽This is the intention. The words “Temperature is a slow-acting cessation” and so on are said🔽in order to show the cause of temperature’s generating at the moment of its presence and in order to show the time of the arising of the immaterial dhammas.

original: arūpānaṃ uppādakāladassanatthañca vuttaṃ. Dandhanirodhattā hi so ṭhitikkhaṇe balavāti🔽tadā rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti, tasmiṃ dharante eva khippanirodhattā soḷasasu cittesu uppannesu
analyzed: arūpānam uppāda kāla dassana attham ca vuttam dandha nirodha ttā hi so ṭhiti kkhaṇe balavā ti  tadā rūpam samuṭṭhāpeti tasmin dharante eva khippa nirodha ttā soḷasasu cittesu uppannesu
translated: For because it is a slow-acting cessation, it is strong at the moment of its presence.🔽Therefore it generates materiality. The intention is that the temperature that generates materiality at the moment of the presence of the life-continuum consciousness generates it again in the sixteen consciousnesses that arise while that materiality lasts, because it ceases quickly.

original: paṭisandhianantaraṃ cittaṃ utunā samuṭṭhite rūpe puna samuṭṭhāpetīti adhippāyo. Tasmiṃ
analyzed: paṭisandhi anantaram cittam utunā samuṭṭhite rūpe puna samuṭṭhāpeti iti adhippāyaḥ tasmin
translated: The consciousness that arises next to the rebirth-linking consciousness generates materiality again in the materiality generated by temperature.

original: dharante eva soḷasa cittāni uppajjitvā nirujjhantīti etena pana vacanena yadi uppādanirodhakkhaṇā🔽dharamānakkhaṇe eva gahitā, “soḷasacittakkhaṇāyukaṃ rūpa”nti vuttaṃ hoti, athuppādakkhaṇaṃ🔽aggahetvā nirodhakkhaṇova gahito, “sattarasacittakkhaṇāyuka”nti, sace nirodhakkhaṇaṃ🔽aggahetvā uppādakkhaṇo gahito, “adhikasoḷasacittakkhaṇāyuka”nti, yadi pana uppādanirodhakkhaṇā🔽dharamānakkhaṇe na gahitā, “adhikasattarasacittakkhaṇāyuka”nti. Yasmā pana “tesu
analyzed: dharante eva soḷasa cittāni uppajjitvā nirujjhanti iti etena pana vacanena yadi uppāda nirodha kkhaṇā  dharamāna khaṇe eva gahitā soḷasa cittakkhaṇa āyukam rūpanti vuttam hoti atha uppāda kkhaṇam  aggahetvā nirodha kkhaṇaḥ uva gahito satta rasa citta kkhaṇa āyukam ti sace nirodha kkhaṇam  aggahetvā uppāda khaṇaḥ gahitaḥ adhika soḷasa citta kkhaṇa āyukam ti yadi pana uppāda nirodha kkhaṇā  na gahitāḥ yasmā pana tesu
translated: But by the words, “Sixteen consciousnesses arise and cease while that materiality is persisting,” if the moment of arising and the moment of ceasing🔽and the moment of persistence are included, then it is said that “materiality has a life of sixteen consciousnesses.” But if the moment of arising is not🔽included and only the moment of ceasing is included, then it is said that “it has a life of seventeen consciousnesses.” If the moment of ceasing is not🔽included and only the moment of arising is included, then it is said that “it has a life of more than sixteen consciousnesses.” But if the moment of arising🔽and the moment of ceasing and the moment of persistence are not included, then it is said that “it has a life of more than seventeen consciousnesses.”🔽But since it is said that “in the case of the first material moment, the second moment is the persistence of the first,”🔽

original: paṭisandhianantara”nti paṭisandhipi tassa dharamānakkhaṇe uppannesu gahitā, tasmā🔽uppādakkhaṇo dharamānakkhaṇe gahitoti nirodhakkhaṇe aggahite adhikasoḷasacittakkhaṇāyukatā🔽vakkhamānā, gahite vā soḷasacittakkhaṇāyukatā adhippetāti veditabbā.
analyzed: paṭisandhi anantaranti tassa dharamāna khaṇe uppannesu gahitā tasmā 🔽uppāda kkhaṇaḥ dharamāna kkhaṇe gahito ti nirodha kkhaṇe aggahite adhika soḷasa citta kkhaṇa āyuka tā 🔽vakkhamānā gahite vā soḷasa cittakkhaṇa āyuka tā adhippetā ati veditabbā
translated: But by the words “sixteen consciousnesses arise and cease while it endures” it is shown that if the arising and ceasing moments and the enduring moment are included, then it is said that materiality lasts for sixteen moments of consciousness. But if the arising moment is not included and only the ceasing moment is included, then it lasts for seventeen moments of consciousness. If the ceasing moment is not included and only the arising moment is included, then it lasts for more than sixteen moments of consciousness. But if neither the arising nor the ceasing moment is included, then it lasts for more than seventeen moments of consciousness. But since the rebirth-linking is included among those that arise in the enduring moment, it is said that “after the rebirth-linking” . Therefore, since the arising moment is included in the enduring moment, it is said that it lasts for more than sixteen moments of consciousness if the ceasing moment is not included, or it is said that it lasts for sixteen moments of consciousness if the ceasing moment is included.

original: Ojā kharāti savatthukaṃ ojaṃ sandhāyāha. Sabhāvato sukhumāya hi ojāya vatthuvasena atthi oḷārikasukhumatāti.🔽Cittañcevāti cittassa pubbaṅgamatāya vuttaṃ, taṃsampayuttakāpi pana rūpasamuṭṭhāpakā🔽hontīti. Yathāha “hetū hetusampayuttakānaṃ dhammānaṃ taṃsamuṭṭhānānañca rūpānaṃ hetupaccayena🔽paccayo”tiādi. Cittanti vā cittuppādaṃ gaṇhāti, na kammacetanaṃ viya ekadhammameva
analyzed: ojā kharā ti sa vatthukam ojam sandhāya āha sabhāvataḥ sukhumāya hi ojāya vatthu vasena atthi oḷārika sukhuma tā ti  cittam ca iva āti cittassa pubbaṅgama tāya vuttam tad sampayuttakā api pana rūpa samuṭṭhāpakā  honti iti yathā āha hetū hetu sampayuttakānam dhammānam tad samuṭṭhānānam ca rūpānam hetu paccayena  paccaya uti ādi cittanti vā cittuppādam gaṇhāti na kamma cetanam viya eka dhammam eva
translated: He says “nutriment” with reference to the nutriment consisting of physical nutriment, for the nutriment consisting of fine material food is gross and subtle according to the physical basis.🔽“And mind” is said because mind precedes . But the material instances generated by the mind are also

original: avijjamānaṃ. Kammasamuṭṭhānañca taṃsampayuttehipi samuṭṭhitaṃ hotūti ce? Na, tehi🔽samuṭṭhitabhāvassa avuttattā, avacanañca tesaṃ kenaci paccayena paccayabhāvābhāvato.🔽Addhānaparicchedatoti kālaparicchedato. Tattha “sattarasa cittakkhaṇā rūpassa addhā,
analyzed: a vijjamānam kamma samuṭṭhānam ca tad sampayuttehi pi samuṭṭhitam hotu uti ce na tehi 🔽samuṭṭhita bhāvassa a vutta ttā avacanam ca tesam kenacid paccayena paccaya bhāva abhāvato 🔽addhāna paricchedato ti kāla paricchedato tattha sattarasa cittakkhaṇāḥ rūpassa addhā

generated by the mind are also the material instances generated by the mind are also the material instances generated by the mind are also the material instances generated by the mind are also the
