original: rūpassa sattarasamo bhāgo arūpassā”ti eso addhānaparicchedo adhippeto. Paṭisandhikkhaṇeti
analyzed: rūpassa sattarasamaḥ bhāgaḥ arūpassa ati esaḥ addhāna paricchedaḥ adhippeto paṭisandhi kkhaṇe ti
translated: The meaning intended is that the proportion of materiality is seventeen times that of the immaterial.

original: idaṃ nayadassanamattaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ tato parampi rūpārūpānaṃ sahuppattisabbhāvato,🔽na panetaṃ paṭisandhikkhaṇe asahuppattiabhāvaṃ sandhāya vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ, paṭisandhicittassa
analyzed: idam naya dassana mattam daṭṭhabbam tatas param pi rūpa arūpānam sahuppatti sabbhāvato  na pana etam paṭisandhi khaṇe asahuppatti abhāvam sandhāya vuttan ti daṭṭhabbam paṭisandhi cittassa
translated: The “moment of rebirth-linking” should be regarded as merely an illustration. For after that, too, materiality and the immaterial are still born together,🔽but it should be understood that this is not said with reference to the fact that they are not born together at the moment of rebirth-linking. For the text itself will say later that materiality is born at the moment of the life-continuum and at the moments of death

original: ṭhitibhaṅgakkhaṇesupi rūpuppattiṃ sayameva vakkhatīti. Phalappattanidassanena ca
analyzed: ṭhiti bhaṅga kkhaṇesu pi rūpa uppattim sayam eva vakkhati iti phala ppatta nidassanena ca
translated: By the statement of the attainment of fruition,

original: rūpārūpānaṃ asamānakālataṃ nidasseti, na sahuppādaṃ tadatthaṃ anāraddhattā. Sahuppādena
analyzed: asamāna kāla tam nidasseti na sahuppādam tad attham anāraddha ttā sahuppādena
translated: he shows that materiality and the immaterial are not of the same time, not that they are born together, because that is not the point of the passage.

original: pana asamānakālatā sukhadīpanā hotīti taṃdīpanatthameva sahuppādaggahaṇaṃ.🔽Yadi evaṃ rūpārūpānaṃ asamānaddhattā arūpaṃ ohāya rūpassa pavatti āpajjatīti etassā
analyzed: pana asamāna kāla tā sukha dīpanā hoti iti tad dīpana attham eva sahuppāda ggahaṇam  yadi evam rūpa arūpānam a samānaddhattā arūpam ohāya rūpassa pavatti āpajjati iti etassā
translated: But the mention of their being born together is for the purpose of showing that they are not of the same time,🔽If that is so, then since materiality and the immaterial are not of the same time, it follows that materiality occurs without the immaterial.🔽To prevent this he says, “Although this is so, nevertheless … ”

original: nivāraṇatthamāha “tattha kiñcāpī”tiādi. Ekappamāṇāvāti nirantaraṃ pavattamānesu rūpārūpadhammesu
analyzed: nivāraṇa attham āha tattha kiñcā api itiādi nirantaram pavattamānesu rūpa arūpa dhammesu
translated: In the phrase “in the same measure” ,

original: nicchiddesu arūparahitaṃ rūpaṃ, rūparahitaṃ vā arūpaṃ natthīti katvā vuttaṃ. Ayañca
analyzed: nicchiddesu arūpa rahitam rūpam rūpa rahitam vā arūpam natthi iti katvā vuttam ayaṃ ca
translated: and in the case of the interruptions, it is said because there is no materiality apart from the immaterial or immateriality apart from the material.

original: kathā pañcavokāre kammajarūpappavattiṃ nibbānapaṭibhāganirodhasamāpattirahitaṃ sandhāya
analyzed: kathā pañcavokāre kamma ja rūpa ppavattim nibbāna paṭibhāga nirodha samāpatti rahitam sandhāya
translated: And this discussion should be regarded as referring to the occurrence of materiality due to kamma in the five-constituent kind of becoming,🔽which is devoid of the cessation due to insight and that of the attainment of cessation.

original: katāti daṭṭhabbā. Pade padanti attano pade eva padaṃ nikkhipanto viya lahuṃ lahuṃ
analyzed: katā ati daṭṭhabbā pade padanti attano pade eva padam nikkhipantaḥ viya lahum lahum
translated: “He places his foot on his foot”: the meaning is that he mounts quickly, as it were, on his own foot.

original: akkamitvāti attho. Anohāyāti yāva cuti, tāva avijahitvā, cutikkhaṇe pana saheva nirujjhantīti.🔽Yasmiñcaddhāne aññamaññaṃ anohāya pavatti, so ca paṭisandhicutiparicchinno ukkaṃsato
analyzed: akkamitvā iti atthaḥ anohāya ati yāva cuti tāva a vijahitvā cuti khaṇe pana saha iva nirujjhanti iti  yasmin ca hāne aññam aññam anohāya pavatti so ca paṭisandhi cuti paricchinnaḥ ukkaṃsataḥ
translated: “Without wavering”: without abandoning it until death; for it ceases together with death.🔽And the extent of the life-continuum is bounded by rebirth-linking and death, and it is the maximum extent of these that is referred to here.

original: etesaṃ addhāti. Evanti etena pubbe vuttaṃ avakaṃsato addhāpakāraṃ imañca saṅgaṇhātīti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: etesam addhā iti evam ti etena pubbe vuttam avakaṃsataḥ addhā apakāram imam ca saṅgaṇhāti iti daṭṭhabbam
translated: “Thus”: this should be regarded as including the minimum extent of the life-continuum mentioned earlier.

original: Ekuppādanānānirodhatoti etaṃ dvayamapi saha gahetvā rūpārūpānaṃ “ekuppādanānānirodhato”ti
analyzed: ekuppāda nānā nirodhato ti etam dvayam api saha gahetvā ekuppāda nānā nirodhato ti
translated: “Because of the single arising and the multiple cessation”: this pair is taken together. The material and immaterial states have a single arising and multiple cessation.

original: eko daṭṭhabbākāro vuttoti daṭṭhabbo. Evaṃ ito paresupi. Pacchimakammajaṃ ṭhapetvāti
analyzed: ekaḥ daṭṭhabba ākāraḥ vutto ti daṭṭhabbaḥ evam itas paresu pi pacchima kamma jam ṭhapetvā ati
translated: “Excepting the last-arisen kamma-born” :

original: tassa cuticittena saha nirujjhanato nānānirodho natthīti katvā vuttanti vadanti.
analyzed: tassa cuti cittena saha nirujjhanataḥ nānā nirodho natthi iti katvā vuttanti vadanti
translated: they say that this is stated because there is no difference in the cessation of the last-arisen kamma-born materiality and the cessation of the death consciousness.

original: Tassa pana ekuppādopi natthi heṭṭhā soḷasake pacchimassa bhaṅgakkhaṇe uppattivacanato.
analyzed: tassa pana eka uppādaḥ api natthi heṭṭhā soḷasake pacchimassa bhaṅga kkhaṇe uppatti vacanato
translated: But it has no single arising, because it is said to arise at the moment of dissolution of the preceding one in the sixteenfold group.

original: Yadi pana yassa ekuppādanānānirodhā dvepi na santi, taṃ ṭhapetabbaṃ. Sabbampi cittassa
analyzed: yadi pana yassa eka uppāda nānā nirodhāḥ dve api na santi tam ṭhapetabbam sabbam pi cittassa
translated: If, however, it is to be excepted if it has neither single arising nor difference in cessation, then all materiality arising at the moment of dissolution of consciousness should be excepted.

original: bhaṅgakkhaṇe uppannaṃ ṭhapetabbaṃ siyā, pacchimakammajassa pana uppattito parato
analyzed: bhaṅga kkhaṇe uppannam ṭhapetabbam siyā pacchima kamma jassa pana uppattitaḥ paratas
translated: But it is said: “Excepting the last-arisen kamma-born” because, after the arising of the last-arisen kamma-born materiality,

original: cittesu pavattamānesu kammajarūpassa anuppattito vajjetabbaṃ gahetabbañca tadā natthīti
analyzed: cittesu pavattamānesu kamma ja rūpassa anuppattitaḥ vajjetabbam gahetabbam ca tadā natthi iti
translated: there is no materiality to be rejected or to be taken up, since kamma-born materiality does not arise in the consciousnesses that occur.🔽Therefore it should be understood that this is stated “excepting the last-arisen kamma-born.”

original: “pacchimakammajaṃ ṭhapetvā”ti vuttanti veditabbaṃ. Tato pubbe pana aṭṭhacattālīsakammajarūpapaveṇī
analyzed: pacchima kamma jam ṭhapetvā iti vuttan ti veditabbam tatas pubbe pana aṭṭha cattālīsa kamma ja rūpa paveṇī
translated: But before that, there is a series of forty-eight kinds of kamma-born materiality.

original: atthīti tattha yaṃ cittassa uppādakkhaṇe uppannaṃ, taṃ aññassa uppādakkhaṇe nirujjhatīti
analyzed: atthi iti tattha yam cittassa uppāda khaṇe uppannam tam aññassa uppāda khaṇe nirujjhati iti
translated: Therefore, that which arises at the moment of arising of consciousness ceases at the moment of arising of another consciousness.

original: “ekuppādanānānirodha”nti gahetvā ṭhitibhaṅgakkhaṇesu uppannarūpāni vajjetvā evaṃ
analyzed: eka uppāda nānā nirodha nti gahetvā ṭhiti bhaṅga khaṇesu uppanna rūpāni vajjetvā evam
translated: “It arises together and ceases separately” is the interpretation to be understood thus:

original: ekuppādanānānirodhato veditabbāti yojanā katāti daṭṭhabbā. Tañhi rūpaṃ arūpena, arūpañca
analyzed: eka uppāda nānā nirodhataḥ veditabbā ati yojanā katā ati daṭṭhabbā tat hi rūpam arūpena arūpam ca
translated: having excluded the materiality arisen at the moments of arising and of dissolution,🔽that materiality arises together with the immaterial and ceases separately from it.

original: tena ekuppādanānānirodhanti. Tattha saṅkhalikassa viya sambandho paveṇīti katvā aṭṭhacattālīsakammajiyavacanaṃ
analyzed: tena eka uppāda nānā nirodhanti tattha saṅkhalikassa viya sambandhaḥ paveṇī iti katvā aṭṭha cattālīsa kamma jiya vacanam
translated: Herein, the statement “forty-eight processes” is made by taking the continuity as a single unit, as in the case of a chain,

original: kataṃ, aññathā ekūnapaññāsakammajiyavacanaṃ kattabbaṃ siyā.
analyzed: katam aññathā ekūna paññāsa kammajiya vacanam kattabbam siyā
translated: otherwise the statement would have to be made as “forty-seven processes.”

original: Nānuppāda…pe… pacchimakammajena dīpetabbāti tena sudīpanattā vuttaṃ. Etena hi nayena
analyzed: na anuppādape pacchima kamma jena dīpetabbā ti tena su dīpana ttā vuttam etena hi nayena
translated: “It is not to be demonstrated as non-arisen … or as ceased by the last process” is said because it is well demonstrated in this way:

original: sakkā tato pubbepi ekassa cittassa bhaṅgakkhaṇe uppannarūpaṃ aññassapi bhaṅgakkhaṇe
analyzed: sakkā tatas pubbe pi ekassa cittassa bhaṅga kkhaṇe uppanna rūpam aññassa api bhaṅga kkhaṇe
translated: for by this method it can be understood that the materiality arisen at the moment of dissolution of one consciousness ceases

original: eva nirujjhatīti taṃ arūpena, arūpañca tena nānuppādaṃ ekanirodhanti viññātunti.
analyzed: eva nirujjhati iti tam arūpena arūpam ca tena na anuppādam eka nirodhanti viññātum ti
translated: with that immaterial and is not arisen with it and does not cease with it.

original: Ubhayatthāpi pana aññassa cittassa ṭhitikkhaṇe uppannaṃ rūpaṃ aññassa ṭhitikkhaṇe,
analyzed: ubhayattha api pana aññassa cittassa ṭhiti kkhaṇe uppannam rūpam aññassa ṭhiti kkhaṇe
translated: But in both cases the materiality arisen at the moment of presence of one consciousness ceases with that of another,

original: tassa ṭhitikkhaṇe uppajjitvā ṭhitikkhaṇe eva nirujjhanakaṃ arūpañca na saṅgahitaṃ,🔽taṃ “nānuppādato nānānirodhato”ti ettheva saṅgahaṃ gacchatīti veditabbaṃ. Catusantatikarūpena🔽hi nānuppādanānānirodhatādīpanā ettha ṭhitikkhaṇe uppannassa dassitattā adassitassa
analyzed: tassa ṭhiti khaṇe uppajjitvā ṭhiti khaṇe eva nirujjhanakam arūpam ca na saṅgahitam  tam na anuppādataḥ nānā nirodhataḥ ti etthā iva saṅgaham gacchati iti veditabbam catu santatika rūpena  hi na anuppāda nānā nirodha tā dīpanā ettha ṭhiti kkhaṇe uppannassa dassita ttā adassitassa
translated: and the immaterial that arises and ceases at the moment of its presence is not included in the clause “not as non-arisen, not as non-ceased,”🔽but it should be understood that it is included in the clause “not as non-arisen, not as non-ceased” in the following way.🔽For the purpose of showing the non-arisen and the non-ceased is not fulfilled by the materiality of the four primary elements,

original: vasena nayadassanaṃ hotīti. Samatiṃsakammajarūpesu eva ṭhitassapi gabbhe gatassa🔽maraṇaṃ atthīti tesaṃ eva vasena pacchimakampi yojitaṃ. Amarā nāma bhaveyyuṃ, kasmā?
analyzed: vasena naya dassanam hoti iti sama tiṃsa kamma ja rūpesu eva ṭhitassa api gabbhe gatassa  maraṇam atthi iti tesam eva vasena yojitam amarāḥ nāma bhaveyyum kasmā
translated: because what has arisen at the moment of its presence is shown there, and the non-arisen and the non-ceased are shown by the rest.🔽And in the case of the materiality of the three-times-repeated action, though there is death in the womb,🔽the last repetition is stated in the way beginning, “They would not die” because of the materiality of the three-times-repeated action.

original: Yathā channaṃ vatthūnaṃ pavatti, evaṃ taduppādakakammeneva bhavaṅgādīnañca tabbatthukānaṃ
analyzed: yathā channam vatthūnam evam tad uppādaka kammena iva bhavaṅga ādīnam ca tad vatthukānam
translated: For it is only by the action that produces them that the occurrence of the life-continuum, etc.,

original: pavattiyā bhavitabbanti. Na hi taṃ kāraṇaṃ atthi, yena taṃ kammajesu ekaccaṃ pavatteyya,
analyzed: pavattiyā bhavitabbanti na hi tam kāraṇam atthi yena tam kamma jesu ekaccam pavatteyya
translated: which have that as their object, must occur. There is no reason why some of the materiality of the three-times-repeated action should occur and some of it should not.

original: ekaccaṃ na pavatteyyāti. Tasmā āyuusmāviññāṇādīnaṃ jīvitasaṅkhārānaṃ anūnattā vuttaṃ
analyzed: ekaccam na pavatteyya ti tasmai āyu usmā viññāṇa ādīnam jīvita saṅkhārānam anūna ttā vuttam
translated: Therefore it is said that it is because the life-formations consisting of life, heat, and consciousness, etc., are not deficient.

original: “amarā nāma bhaveyyu”nti.🔽“Uppādakkhaṇe uppannaṃ aññassa uppādakkhaṇe nirujjhati, ṭhitikkhaṇe uppannaṃ aññassa🔽ṭhitikkhaṇe, bhaṅgakkhaṇe uppannaṃ aññassa bhaṅgakkhaṇe nirujjhatī”ti idaṃ aṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: amarā nāma  uppāda kkhaṇe uppannam aññassa uppāda kkhaṇe nirujjhati ṭhiti kkhaṇe uppannam aññassa  ṭhiti kkhaṇe bhaṅga kkhaṇe uppannam aññassa bhaṅga kkhaṇe nirujjhati iti idam aṭṭhakathāyam
translated: “They would be immortals.”

original: āgatattā vuttanti adhippāyo. Attano panādhippāyaṃ uppādakkhaṇe uppannaṃ nirodhakkhaṇe,
analyzed: āgata ttā vuttanti adhippāyaḥ attanaḥ pana adhippāyam uppāda khaṇe uppannam nirodha kkhaṇe
translated: “What arises at the moment of arising ceases at the moment of another’s arising; what arises at the moment of presence ceases at the moment of another’s presence; what arises at the moment of dissolution ceases at the moment of another’s dissolution.” This is said because it is found in the commentary. But the intention is this: what arises at the moment of arising ceases at the moment of cessation,

original: ṭhitikkhaṇe uppannañca uppādakkhaṇe, bhaṅgakkhaṇe uppannaṃ ṭhitikkhaṇe nirujjhatīti
analyzed: ṭhiti khaṇe uppannam ca uppāda kkhaṇe bhaṅga kkhaṇe uppannam ṭhiti kkhaṇe nirujjhati iti
translated: and what arises at the moment of presence ceases at the moment of arising. What arises at the moment of dissolution ceases at the moment of presence.

original: dīpetiyeva. Evañca katvā addhānaparicchede “taṃ pana sattarasamena cittena saddhiṃ
analyzed: evam ca katvā tam pana sattarasamena cittena saddhim
translated: This is what is indicated. And in that way the words “It ceases together with the seventeenth consciousness” in the Description of the Path of Development are not contradicted.

original: nirujjhatī”ti vuttaṃ. Imāya pāḷiyā virujjhati, kasmā? Catusamuṭṭhānikarūpassapi samānāyukatāya🔽bhavitabbattāti adhippāyo. Yathā pana etehi yojitaṃ, tathā rūpassa ekuppādanānānirodhatā
analyzed: nirujjhati iti vuttam imāya pāḷiyā virujjhati kasmā catu samuṭṭhānika rūpassa api samāna āyuka tāya  bhavitabba ttā ti adhippāyaḥ yathā pana etehi yojitam tathā rūpassa eka uppāda nānā nirodha tā
translated: Why is it not contradicted? Because it is necessary that materiality should be of the same duration as the consciousnesses that give rise to it, even though it is derived from the four primaries.

original: nānuppādekanirodhatā ca natthiyeva.
analyzed: na anuppāda eka nirodha tā ca
translated: But it is not that materiality has a single arising and a multiple cessation or a multiple arising and a single cessation, as it is construed in the commentary.

original: Yā pana etehi rūpassa sattarasacittakkhaṇāyukatā vuttā, yā ca aṭṭhakathāyaṃ tatiyabhāgādhikasoḷasacittakkhaṇāyukatā,🔽sā paṭiccasamuppādavibhaṅgaṭṭhakathāyaṃ atītārammaṇāya cutiyā anantarā paccuppannārammaṇaṃ🔽paṭisandhiṃ dassetuṃ “ettāvatā ekādasa cittakkhaṇā atītā honti, tathā pañcadasa cittakkhaṇā
analyzed: yā pana etehi rūpassa satta rasa cittakkhaṇa āyuka tā vuttā yā ca aṭṭhakathā ayam tatiya bhāga adhika soḷasa cittakkhaṇa āyuka tā  sā paṭiccasamuppāda vibhaṅga ṭṭhakathā ayam atīta ārammaṇāya cutiyāḥ anantarā paccuppanna ārammaṇam  paṭisandhim dassetuṃ ettāvatā ekādasa cittakkhaṇāḥ atītāḥ honti tathā pañcadasa cittakkhaṇāḥ
translated: But the seventeen-moment life of materiality stated by these, and the life of sixteen moments with an excess of a third part stated in the commentary,

original: atītā honti, athāvasesapañcacittaekacittakkhaṇāyuke tasmiṃ yevārammaṇe paṭisandhicittaṃ🔽uppajjatī”ti dassitena soḷasacittakkhaṇāyukabhāvena virujjhati. Na hi sakkā “ṭhitikkhaṇe🔽eva rūpaṃ āpāthamāgacchatī”ti vattuṃ. Tathā hi sati na rūpassa ekādasa vā pañcadaseva
analyzed: atītāḥ honti atha avasesa pañca citta eka citta khaṇa āyuke tasmin yā iva ārammaṇe paṭisandhi cittam  uppajjati iti dassitena soḷasa citta kkhaṇa āyuka bhāvena virujjhati na hi sakkā ṭhiti khaṇe  eva rūpam āpātham āgacchati iti vattum tathā hi sati na ekādasa vā pañcadasā iva
translated: are incompatible with the life of sixteen moments shown in the Paṭiccasamuppāda- vibhaṅga Commentary in order to show the rebirth-linking with a present object immediately next to the death with a past object, thus: “At this point eleven moments of consciousness have passed, and likewise fifteen moments of consciousness have passed, and then the rebirth-linking consciousness arises in that same object with a life of five or one moment remaining.”

original: vā cittakkhaṇā atītā, atha kho atirekaekādasapañcadasacittakkhaṇā. Tasmā yadipi pañcadvāre
analyzed: vā cittakkhaṇāḥ atītāḥ atha kho atireka ekādasa pañcadasa cittakkhaṇā tasmā yadi pi pañca dvāre
translated: For it cannot be said that the materiality comes into focus only at the moment of its presence. For if that were so, then eleven or fifteen moments of consciousness would not have passed with respect to the materiality, but more than eleven or fifteen moments of consciousness would have passed. So although it is said in the Paṭṭhāna that the materiality of the five doors is a condition for the consciousness of the five doors, and that the materiality of the five doors is a condition for the mind element and mind-consciousness element,

original: ṭhitippattameva rūpaṃ pasādaṃ ghaṭṭetīti yujjeyya, manodvāre pana uppādakkhaṇepi
analyzed: ṭhiti pattam eva rūpam pasādam ghaṭṭeti iti yujjeyya manaḥ dvāre pana uppāda kkhaṇe pi
translated: It would be logical to say that materiality, which has reached its state of presence, impinges on the sensitive matter. But in the case of the mind door it must be admitted that it comes into focus even at the moment of arising.

original: āpāthamāgacchatīti icchitabbametaṃ. Na hi manodvāre atītādīsu kiñci āpāthaṃ nāgacchatīti.
analyzed: āpātham āgacchati iti icchitabbam etam na hi manaḥ dvāre atīta ādīsu kiñci āpātham na āgacchati iti
translated: For nothing in the mind door comes into focus as past, etc.,

original: Manodvāre ca evaṃ vuttaṃ “ekādasa cittakkhaṇā atītā, athāvasesapañcacittakkhaṇāyuke”ti.
analyzed: manaḥ dvāre ca evam vuttam ekādasa cittakkhaṇāḥ atītāḥ atha avasesa pañca cittakkhaṇa āyukā iti
translated: And in the case of the mind door it is said: “Eleven mind-moments are past, and then the remaining five mind-moments have the same object” .

original: Yo cettha cittassa ṭhitikkhaṇo vutto, so ca atthi natthīti vicāretabbo. Cittayamake🔽hi “uppannaṃ uppajjamānanti? Bhaṅgakkhaṇe uppannaṃ, no ca uppajjamāna”nti ettakameva
analyzed: yaḥ ca ittha cittassa ṭhiti khaṇaḥ vutto saḥ ca atthi natthi iti vicāretabbo citta yamake  hi uppannam uppajjamānanti bhaṅga kkhaṇe uppannam no ca uppajjamānanti ettakam eva
translated: And the moment of presence of consciousness mentioned there should be investigated as to whether it is or is not.🔽For in the Consciousness Group it is said: “Arisen, is it arising? At the moment of dissolution it is arisen, but it is not arising.🔽Not arising, is it arisen? At the moment of arising it is not arising, but it is arisen.

original: vuttaṃ, na vuttaṃ “ṭhitikkhaṇe bhaṅgakkhaṇe cā”ti. Tathā “nuppajjamānaṃ nuppannanti?
analyzed: vuttam na vuttam ṭhiti kkhaṇe bhaṅga kkhaṇe ca ati tathā n uppajjamānam na uppannam ti
translated: Not ceased, is it ceasing? At the moment of arising it is not ceasing, but it is ceased.

original: Bhaṅgakkhaṇe nuppajjamānaṃ, no ca nuppanna”nti ettakameva vuttaṃ, na vuttaṃ “ṭhitikkhaṇe
analyzed: bhaṅga kkhaṇe nuppajjamānam no ca nuppannanti ettakam eva vuttam na vuttam ṭhiti kkhaṇe
translated: Not ceased, is it not ceasing? At the moment of dissolution it is not ceasing, but it is ceased.🔽Not arisen, is it arising? At the moment of dissolution it is not arising, but it is arisen.🔽Not arisen, is it not arising? At the moment of dissolution it is not arising, but it is arisen.🔽Not ceased, is it ceasing? At the moment of arising it is not ceasing, but it is ceased.

original: bhaṅgakkhaṇe cā”ti. Evaṃ “na niruddhaṃ na nirujjhamānaṃ, na nirujjhamānaṃ na niruddha”nti
analyzed: bhaṅga kkhaṇe ca ati evam na niruddham na nirujjhamānam na nirujjhamānam na niruddham ti
translated: Not ceased, is it not ceasing? At the moment of arising it is not ceasing, but it is ceased” .

original: etesaṃ paripuṇṇavissajjane “uppādakkhaṇe anāgatañcā”ti vatvā “ṭhitikkhaṇe”ti avacanaṃ,🔽atikkantakālavāre ca “bhaṅgakkhaṇe cittaṃ uppādakkhaṇaṃ vītikkanta”nti vatvā “ṭhitikkhaṇe”ti
analyzed: etesam paripuṇṇa vissajjane uppāda khaṇe anāgatam ca ati vatvā ṭhiti khaṇa iti avacanam  atikkanta kālavāre ca bhaṅga kkhaṇe cittam uppāda kkhaṇam vītikkantanti vatvā ṭhiti kkhaṇa iti
translated: and the words “at the moment of arising, the future” are not followed by the words “at the moment of presence” in the passage “At the moment of arising, the future is present. At the moment of presence, the present is present. At the moment of dissolution, the past is present” ,

original: avacanaṃ ṭhitikkhaṇābhāvaṃ cittassa dīpeti. Suttesupi hi “ṭhitassa aññathattaṃ paññāyatī”ti
analyzed: avacanam ṭhiti kkhaṇa abhāvam cittassa dīpeti suttesu pi hi ṭhitassa aññathattam paññāyati iti
translated: and the words “at the moment of dissolution, the consciousness has passed beyond the moment of arising” are not followed by the words “at the moment of presence” in the passage “At the moment of arising, the future is present. At the moment of presence, the present is present. At the moment of dissolution, the past is present. At the moment of dissolution, the consciousness has passed beyond the moment of arising” ,

original: tasseva ekassa aññathattābhāvato “yassā aññathattaṃ paññāyati, sā santatiṭhitī”ti🔽na na sakkā vattunti, vijjamānaṃ vā khaṇadvayasamaṅgiṃ ṭhitanti.
analyzed: tassa iva ekassa aññathatta abhāvataḥ yassā aññathattam paññāyati sā santati ṭhitī iti  na na sakkā vattunti vijjamānam vā khaṇa dvaya samaṅgim ṭhitanti
translated: and the words “the alteration of what is present is evident” are not followed by the words “at the moment of presence” in the passage “The alteration of what is present is evident, but not its presence” ,🔽and the words “the alteration of what is present is evident” are not followed by the words “at the moment of presence” in the passage “The alteration of what is present is evident, but not its presence” ,🔽and the words “the alteration of what is present is evident” are not followed by the words “at the moment of presence” in the passage “The alteration of what is present is evident, but not its presence” ,

original: Yo cettha cittanirodhakkhaṇe rūpuppādo vutto, so ca vicāretabbo “yassa vā pana samudayasaccaṃ🔽nirujjhati, tassa dukkhasaccaṃ uppajjatīti? Noti vutta”nti. Yo ca cittassa uppādakkhaṇe
analyzed: yaḥ ca ittha citta nirodha kkhaṇe rūpuppādo vutto so ca vicāretabbo yassa vā pana samudaya saccam  nirujjhati tassa dukkha saccam uppajjati iti no ti vuttanti yaḥ ca cittassa uppāda kkhaṇe
translated: and the words “the alteration of what is present is evident” are not followed by the words “at the moment of presence” in the passage “The alteration of what is present is evident, but not its presence” ,🔽and the words “the alteration of what is present is evident” are not followed by the words “at the moment of presence” in the passage “The alteration of what is present is evident, but not its presence” ,🔽and the words “the alteration of what is present is evident” are not followed by the words “at the moment of presence” in the passage “The alteration of what is present is evident, but not its presence” ,🔽and the words “the alteration of what is present is evident” are not followed by the words “at the moment of presence” in the passage “The alteration of what is present is evident, but not its presence” ,

original: rūpanirodho vutto, so ca vicāretabbo “yassa kusalā dhammā uppajjanti, tassa abyākatā
analyzed: rūpa nirodho vutto so ca vicāretabbaḥ yassa kusalāḥ dhammāḥ uppajjanti tassa abyākatā
translated: and the words “the alteration of what is present is evident” are not followed by the words “at the moment of presence” in the passage “The alteration of what is present is

original: dhammā nirujjhantīti? Notiādi vutta”nti. Na ca cittasamuṭṭhānarūpameva sandhāya paṭikkhepo🔽katoti sakkā vattuṃ cittasamuṭṭhānarūpādhikārassa abhāvā, abyākatasaddassa ca cittasamuṭṭhānarūpesveva🔽appavattito. Yadi saṅkhārayamake kāyasaṅkhārassa cittasaṅkhārena sahuppādekanirodhavacanato🔽abyākata-saddena cittasamuṭṭhānamevettha gahitanti kāraṇaṃ vadeyya, tampi akāraṇaṃ.🔽Na hi tena vacanena aññarūpānaṃ cittena sahuppādasahanirodhapaṭikkhepo kato, nāpi🔽nānuppādanānānirodhānujānanaṃ, neva cittasamuṭṭhānato aññassa abyākatabhāvanivāraṇañca
analyzed: dhammā nirujjhanti iti no tiādi vuttanti na ca citta samuṭṭhāna rūpam eva sandhāya paṭikkhepaḥ  kato ti sakkā vattum citta samuṭṭhāna rūpa adhikārassa abhāvā abyākata saddassa ca citta samuṭṭhāna rūpesu eva  appavattitaḥ yadi saṅkhāra yamake kāya saṅkhārassa citta saṅkhārena sahuppāda eka nirodha vacanato  abyākata saddena citta samuṭṭhānam evā ittha gahitan ti kāraṇam vadeyya tam pi akāraṇam  na hi tena vacanena añña rūpānam cittena sahuppāda saha nirodha paṭikkhepaḥ kataḥ na api  na anuppāda nānā nirodha anujānanam na iva citta samuṭṭhānataḥ aññassa abyākata bhāva nivāraṇam ca
translated: “Are mental data …?” “No” and so on is said.🔽And it cannot be said that the denial is made only with reference to materiality originated by consciousness,🔽because there is no discussion of materiality originated by consciousness and because the word “indeterminate” does not apply to materiality originated by consciousness.🔽If it be said that the reason is that in the case of the pair “formations” the bodily formation has the same arising and cessation as the mental formation,🔽and that therefore only what is originated by consciousness is meant by the word “indeterminate,” that is no reason.🔽For by that statement there is no denial of the same arising and cessation with consciousness in the case of other material instances,🔽nor is there any allowance of their arising and cessation without that, nor is there any prevention of their being indeterminate other than as originated by consciousness.

original: kammajādīnaṃ etena cittassa uppādakkhaṇe nirodho paṭikkhittoti na sakkā kammajādīnaṃ
analyzed: kamma ja ādīnam etena cittassa uppāda kkhaṇe nirodho paṭikkhitto ti na sakkā kamma ja ādīnam
translated: And since this rejects the cessation of the kinds of derived matter originated by kamma, etc., at the moment of arising of consciousness, it is not possible to say that the cessation of the kinds of derived matter originated by kamma, etc.,

original: cittassa uppādakkhaṇe nirodhaṃ vattuṃ. Yamakapāḷianussaraṇe ca sati uppādānantaraṃ
analyzed: cittassa uppāda kkhaṇe nirodham vattum yamaka pāḷi anussaraṇe ca sati uppāda anantaram
translated: is at the moment of arising of consciousness. And when the two- fold continuity is remembered, then at the moment of arising of consciousness,

original: cittassa bhijjamānatāti tasmiṃ khaṇe cittaṃ na ca rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti vinassamānattā,
analyzed: cittassa bhijjamāna tā ati tasmin khaṇe cittam na ca rūpam samuṭṭhāpeti vinassamāna ttā
translated: the consciousness is being born, not originated by materiality, because it is perishing;

original: nāpi ca aññassa rūpasamuṭṭhāpakassa sahāyabhāvaṃ gacchatīti paṭisandhicittena sahuppanno
analyzed: na api ca aññassa rūpa samuṭṭhāpakassa sahāya bhāvam gacchati iti paṭisandhi cittena sahuppannaḥ
translated: nor does it become a companion to any other materiality-originated matter. So the materiality originated by temperature that arises together with the rebirth-linking consciousness

original: utu tadanantarassa cittassa uppādakkhaṇe rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpeyya. Evañca sati rūpārūpānaṃ🔽ādimhi saha rūpasamuṭṭhāpanato pubbāparatoti idampi natthi, atilahuparivattañca cittanti
analyzed: tad anantarassa cittassa uppāda kkhaṇe rūpam samuṭṭhāpeyya evam ca sati  ādimhi saha rūpa samuṭṭhāpanato pubba aparato ti idam pi natthi ati lahu parivattam ca cittan ti
translated: would originate materiality at the moment of arising of the next consciousness. And that being so, there is no such thing as prior and subsequent between materiality and immateriality,

original: yena sahuppajjati, taṃ cittakkhaṇe rūpaṃ uppajjamānamevāti sakkā vattuṃ. Teneva hi
analyzed: yena sahuppajjati tam cittakkhaṇe rūpam uppajjamānam eva ati sakkā vattum tena iva hi
translated: since they originate materiality at the beginning, and the consciousness turns over very quickly. So it is possible to say that the materiality that arises together with what arises is arising at the moment of the consciousness.🔽And so it is not possible for anyone to say of the materiality that arises together with the rebirth-linking consciousness that it is originated by consciousness, since it is not originated by any consciousness prior to death consciousness,

original: taṃ paṭisandhito uddhaṃ acittasamuṭṭhānānaṃ attanā saha uppajjamānānaṃ na kenaci
analyzed: tam paṭisandhitaḥ uddham acitta samuṭṭhānānam attanā saha uppajjamānānam na kenacid
translated: and that it is not originated by materiality, since it is not originated by temperature that arises together with it.

original: paccayena paccayo hoti, tadanantarañca taṃ ṭhitippattanti tadanantaraṃ cittaṃ tassa
analyzed: paccayena paccayaḥ hoti tad anantaram ca tam tad anantaram cittam tassa
translated: and it is a condition for that by way of decisive support. And that is the next-to-last consciousness that has reached presence.🔽It is a condition for that by way of post-nascence, not by way of conascence.

original: pacchājātapaccayo hoti, na sahajātapaccayoti. Yadi evaṃ “yassa kāyasaṅkhāro uppajjati,
analyzed: pacchājāta paccayaḥ hoti na sahajāta paccayaḥ ti yadi evam yassa kāya saṅkhāro uppajjati
translated: If it is asked, “Then should it be said that when there is arising of bodily formation,🔽there is cessation of verbal formation?” it should be replied, “No.”

original: tassa vacīsaṅkhāro nirujjhatīti? No”ti, vattabbanti ce? Na, cittanirodhakkhaṇe rūpuppādārambhābhāvatoti.
analyzed: tassa vacī saṅkhāraḥ nirujjhati iti no ti vattabbanti ce na citta nirodha kkhaṇe rūpa uppāda ārambha abhāvato ti
translated: Because at the moment of cessation of consciousness there is no beginning of arising of materiality.

original: Nippariyāyena hi cittassa uppādakkhaṇe eva rūpaṃ uppajjamānaṃ hoti, cittakkhaṇe pana
analyzed: nippariyāyena hi cittassa uppāda khaṇe eva rūpam uppajjamānam hoti citta kkhaṇe pana
translated: For in the very moment of arising of consciousness materiality is arising in the strict sense of the words. But in the moment of consciousness

original: avītivatte taṃ attano rūpasamuṭṭhāpanapurejātapaccayakiccaṃ na karoti, arūpañca tassa
analyzed: avītivatte tam attanaḥ rūpa samuṭṭhāpana purejāta paccaya kiccam na karoti arūpam ca tassa
translated: that has not yet elapsed it does not perform the function of being a prenascent condition for the production of its materiality. And immaterial dhammas

original: pacchājātapaccayo na hotīti ṭhitippattivisesālābhaṃ sandhāya pariyāyena idaṃ vuttanti.
analyzed: pacchājāta paccayaḥ na hoti iti ṭhiti patti visesa alābham sandhāya pariyāyena idam vuttan ti
translated: are not post-nascence conditions for it. So this is said by implication referring to the acquisition of a special kind of presence.

original: Tato paraṃ panāti etassa “ettha pana yadeta”ntiādikāyapi saṅgahakathāya niṭṭhitāya
analyzed: tatas param pana ati etassa ettha pana yat etat ti ādikāya api saṅgaha kathāya niṭṭhitāya
translated: But after that: after the conclusion of the general discussion beginning with the words “Herein, what is …? ”

original: purimakathāya sanniṭṭhānato “tato paṭṭhāya kammajarūpapaveṇī na pavattatī”ti etena
analyzed: purima kathāya sanniṭṭhānato tatas paṭṭhāya kamma ja rūpa paveṇī na pavattati iti etena
translated: and the conclusion of the previous discussion by the words “after that the stream of kamma-born materiality does not occur” .

original: saha sambandhoti cutito paranti attho.
analyzed: saha sambandho ti cutitaḥ paranti attho
translated: ‘Together with its related states’ means ‘from death to the next becoming.’

original: Rūpaṃ pana rūpena sahātiādinā yathā aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttaṃ, tathā ekuppādekanirodhatā rūpānaṃ arūpehi, arūpānaṃ rūpehi ca natthīti katvā rūpānaṃ rūpeheva, arūpānañca arūpehi yojitā.
analyzed: rūpam pana rūpena saha āti ādinā yathā aṭṭhakathāyam vuttam tathā eka uppāda eka nirodha tā rūpānam arūpehi arūpānam rūpehi ca natthi iti katvā rūpānam rūpehi iva arūpānam ca arūpehi yojitā
translated: ‘But matter is together with matter’ and so on is stated in the commentary in the way it is because there is no single arising and single cessation of material instances with immaterial instances, and of immaterial instances with material instances.

original: Sarīrassa rūpaṃ avayavabhūtanti attho, ghanabhūto puñjabhāvo ghanapuñjabhāvo, na
analyzed: sarīrassa rūpam avayava bhūtanti atthaḥ ghana bhūtaḥ puñja bhāvaḥ ghana puñja bhāvaḥ na
translated: The meaning is: matter is a part of the body. The meaning is: a mass that is a compact whole is a mass that is a compact whole.🔽Not like a mass of sesame seeds and beans, etc., which are loosely connected.

original: tilamuggādipuñjā viya sithilasambandhanānaṃ puñjoti attho. Ekuppādāditāti yathāvutte tayo pakāre āha.🔽Heṭṭhāti rūpakaṇḍavaṇṇanāyaṃ. Parinipphannāva hontīti vikārarūpādīnañca rūpakaṇḍavaṇṇanāyaṃ
analyzed: tila mugga ādi puñjāḥ viya sithila sambandha nānam puñjaḥ ti attho eka uppāda ādi tā iti yathā vutte pakāre āha  heṭṭhā ati rūpa kaṇḍa vaṇṇanāyam parinipphannāḥ ava honti iti vikāra rūpa ādīnam ca rūpa kaṇḍa vaṇṇanāyam
translated: ‘Single arising, etc.’: he mentions the three modes stated thus.🔽‘Below’ in the description of the material form aggregate.🔽‘They are only the resultant’ is said because the mode of the resultant is stated in the description of the material form aggregate for the material instances that are modifications, etc.

original: parinipphannatāpariyāyo vuttoti katvā vuttaṃ. Parinipphannanipphannānaṃ ko visesoti?
analyzed: parinipphanna tā pariyāyaḥ vuttaḥ iti katvā vuttam parinipphanna nipphannānam kaḥ visesaḥ iti
translated: What is the difference between the resultant and the non-resultant?

original: Pubbantāparantaparicchinno paccayehi nipphādito tilakkhaṇāhato sabhāvadhammo parinipphanno,
analyzed: pubbanta aparanta paricchinnaḥ paccayehi nipphādito ti lakkhaṇa āhataḥ sa bhāva dhammo parinipphanno
translated: The resultant is a state that is a real essence, delimited by a prior and subsequent end, produced by conditions, and stamped with the three characteristics.

original: nipphanno pana asabhāvadhammopi hoti nāmaggahaṇasamāpajjanādivasena nipphādiyamānoti.
analyzed: nipphannaḥ pana asabhāva dhammaḥ api hoti nāma ggahaṇa samāpajjana ādi vasena nipphādiyamānaḥ ti
translated: But what is produced is also a non-existent state, since it is produced by being apprehended by name, by being attained in jhāna, and so on.

original: Nirodhasamāpatti panāti etena sabbampi upādāpaññattiṃ tadekadesena dassetīti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: nirodha samāpatti pana ati etena sabbam pi upādā paññattim tad ekadesena dasseti iti veditabbam
translated: But the attainment of cessation should be understood to show all the kinds of description of assuming as a part of that.

original: Pakiṇṇakakathāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: pakiṇṇaka kathā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of the miscellaneous section is ended.

original: Kamādivinicchayakathāvaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the exposition of sense desires, etc.

original: Dassanena pahātabbātiādinā paṭhamaṃ pahātabbā paṭhamaṃ vuttā, dutiyaṃ pahātabbā dutiyanti
analyzed: dassanena pahātabbā ati ādinā paṭhamam pahātabbā paṭhamam vuttā dutiyam pahātabbā dutiyam
translated: Those that are to be given up through seeing are stated first because they are the first to be given up, and those that are to be given up through development are stated second because they are the second to be given up.

original: ayaṃ pahānakkamo. Anupubbapaṇītā bhūmiyo anupubbena vavatthitāti tāsaṃ vasena desanāya
analyzed: ayam pahāna kkamaḥ anupubba paṇītāḥ bhūmiyaḥ anupubbena vavatthitā ati tāsam vasena desanāya
translated: This is the order of giving up. The stages that are taught in order are the stages that are defined in order. So the order of teaching is in accordance with them.

original: bhūmikkamo. “Cattāro satipaṭṭhānā”tiādiko ekakkhaṇepi satipaṭṭhānādisambhavato desanākkamova.🔽Dānakathādayo anupubbukkaṃsato kathitā, uppattiādivavatthānābhāvato pana dānādīnaṃ
analyzed: bhūmikkamo cattāro sati paṭṭhāna ati ādiko eka khaṇe pi sati paṭṭhāna ādi sambhavataḥ desanā kkamaḥ va  dāna kathā ādayaḥ anupubbukkaṃsataḥ kathitāḥ uppatti ādi vavatthāna abhāvato pana dāna ādīnam
translated: The order of teaching is that of the four foundations of mindfulness, and so on, because the four foundations of mindfulness, and so on, are possible in a single conscious moment.🔽The talk on giving, and so on, is stated in order because of the order of their arising, and so on. But the order of teaching is stated here because there is no definition of giving, and so on, in the order of their arising, and so on.

original: idha desanākkamavacanaṃ. Desanākkamoti ca yathāvuttavavatthānābhāvato anekesaṃ vacanānaṃ
analyzed: desanākkama vacanam ca yathā vutta vavatthāna abhāvataḥ anekesam
translated: And the order of teaching is the order in which the words are stated because there is no definition as stated.

original: saha pavattiyā asambhavato yena kenaci pubbāpariyena desetabbattā tena tenādhippāyena
analyzed: saha pavattiyāḥ asambhavataḥ yena kenaci pubbāpariyena desetabba ttā tena tena adhippāyena
translated: Because of the impossibility of occurrence together, and because of the fact that it can be taught in any order, in this or that intention,

original: desanāmattasseva kamo vuccati. Abhedena hīti rūpādīnaṃ bhedaṃ akatvā piṇḍaggahaṇenāti
analyzed: desanā mattassa iva kamaḥ vuccati abhedena hi iti rūpa ādīnam bhedam a katvā piṇḍa ggahaṇena ati
translated: the order of the teaching is said to be the order of the teaching itself. ‘Without distinction’ means without making a distinction between materiality, etc., by taking them as a whole.

original: attho. Cakkhuādīnampi visayabhūtanti ekadesena rūpakkhandhaṃ samudāyabhūtaṃ vadati.
analyzed: cakkhu ādīnam pi visaya bhūtanti ekadesena rūpa kkhandham samudāya bhūtam vadati
translated: The meaning is: ‘as a whole’. He says that the materiality aggregate is a part of the eye, etc., and is the whole of the object of the eye, etc.🔽The intention is this: ‘in the way stated thus’. ‘The king who is lord of the six doors’ and ‘Ideas have mind as their forerunner’

original: Evanti ettha vuttanayenāti adhippāyo. “Chadvārādhipati rājā”ti “manopubbaṅgamā dhammā”ti🔽ca vacanato viññāṇaṃ adhipati.🔽Rūpakkhandhe “sāsavaṃ upādāniya”nti vacanaṃ anāsavānaṃ dhammānaṃ sabbhāvato rūpakkhandhassa🔽taṃsabhāvatānivattanatthaṃ, na anāsavarūpanivattanatthanti. Anāsavāva khandhesu vuttāti
analyzed: evam ti ettha vutta nayena ati adhippāyaḥ cha dvāra adhipati rājā ati manaḥ pubbaṅgamāḥ dhammā ti  ca vacanataḥ viññāṇam adhipati  rūpakkhandhe sa āsavam upādāniyanti vacanam anāsavānam dhammānam sabbhāvataḥ rūpakkhandhassa  taṃsa bhāva tā nivattana attham na anāsava rūpa nivattana attham anāsavā ava khandhesu vuttā ati
translated: are said in the way beginning ‘The eye is the lord of visible objects’ .🔽The words ‘With the materiality aggregate’ are said in order to show that the materiality aggregate is the object of the eye, etc., and the words ‘With the other four’ are said in order to show that the other four aggregates are the object of mind.🔽The words ‘The materiality aggregate’ are said in order to show that the materiality aggregate is the object of the eye, etc., and the words ‘The other four’ are said in order to show that the other four aggregates are the object of mind.

original: ettha aṭṭhānappayutto eva-saddo daṭṭhabbo, anāsavā khandhesveva vuttāti attho.
analyzed: ettha aṭṭhāna ppayuttaḥ eva saddo daṭṭhabbo anāsavā khandhesu eva vuttā iti attho
translated: The words ‘The materiality aggregate’ are said in order to show that the materiality aggregate is the object of the eye, etc., and the words ‘The other four’ are said in order to show that the other four aggregates are the object of mind.🔽The words ‘The materiality aggregate’ are said in order to show that the materiality aggregate is the object of the eye, etc., and the words ‘The other four’ are said in order to show that the other four aggregates are the object of mind.🔽The words ‘The materiality aggregate’ are said in order to show that the materiality aggregate is the object of the eye, etc., and the words ‘The other four’ are said in order to show that the other four aggregates are the object of mind.🔽The words ‘The materiality aggregate’ are said in order to show that the materiality aggregate is the object of the eye, etc., and the words ‘The other four’ are said in order to show that the other four aggregates are the object of mind.🔽The words ‘The materiality aggregate’ are said in order to show that the materiality aggregate is the object of the eye, etc.,

original: Sabbasaṅkhatānaṃ sabhāgena ekajjhaṃ saṅgaho sabbasaṅkhatasabhāgekasaṅgaho. Sabhāgasabhāgena🔽hi saṅgayhamānā sabbasaṅkhatā phassādayo pañcakkhandhā honti. Tattha ruppanādisāmaññena
analyzed: sabba saṅkhatānam sabhāgena ekajjham saṅgahaḥ sabba saṅkhata sabhāga ika saṅgahaḥ sa bhāga sabhāgena  hi phassa ādayaḥ pañca kkhandhāḥ honti tattha ruppana ādi sāmaññena
translated: The inclusion of all the formed under one heading by their commonality is the inclusion of all the formed by the commonality of the formed.

original: samānakoṭṭhāsā “sabhāgā”ti veditabbā. Tesu saṅkhatābhisaṅkharaṇakiccaṃ āyūhanarasāya
analyzed: samāna koṭṭhāsā sabhāgā ati veditabbā tesu saṅkhata abhisaṅkharaṇa kiccam āyūhana rasāya
translated: For when they are included by the commonality of the formed, the five aggregates, namely, contact, etc., are formed. Herein, the states that are similar in being the formed should be understood as “similar” in the sense of having a common location by the similarity of their being the formed.

original: cetanāya balavanti sā “saṅkhārakkhandho”ti vuttā, aññe ca ruppanādivisesalakkhaṇarahitā🔽phassādayo saṅkhatābhisaṅkharaṇasāmaññenāti daṭṭhabbā. Phusanādayo pana sabhāvā visuṃ
analyzed: cetanāya balavanti sā saṅkhāra kkhandhaḥ ti vuttā aññe ca ruppana ādi visesa lakkhaṇa rahitā  phassa ādayo saṅkhata abhisaṅkharaṇa sāmaññena ati daṭṭhabbā phusana ādayo pana sabhāvāḥ visum
translated: Among them, the volition that has the function of forming the formed and has the nature of accumulation is strong, and it is called the “formations aggregate” . The others, namely, contact, etc., are devoid of the particular characteristics of arising, etc.,🔽and they should be regarded as similar in being the formed by the similarity of their function of forming the formed. But the states that are different in their individual essences, namely, contact, etc., are not separately expressible by the word “aggregate” .

original: khandha-saddavacanīyā na hontīti dhammasabhāvaviññunā tathāgatena phassakhandhādayo🔽na vuttāti daṭṭhabbāti. “Ye keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā sassatavādā sassataṃ
analyzed: khandha sadda vacanīyāḥ na honti iti dhamma sabhāva viññunā tathāgatena phassa khandha ādayo  na vuttā ati daṭṭhabbā ati ye keci bhikkhave samaṇāḥ vā brāhmaṇāḥ vā sassata vādāḥ sassatam
translated: So it should be understood that the states beginning with contact are not called “contact aggregates,” etc., by the Tathāgata, who is acquainted with the individual essences of states.🔽“Bhikkhus, whatever ascetics or brahmins there are who proclaim a doctrine of eternalism, and who on four grounds proclaim the self and the world to be eternal—all these … do so on the basis of these five aggregates or on the basis of one of them.

original: lokañca paññapenti attānañca, sabbe te imeyeva pañcupādānakkhandhe nissāya paṭicca,
analyzed: lokañca paññapenti attānañca sabbe te ime eva pañca upādānakkhandhe nissāya paṭicca
translated: “And what, bhikkhus, are the five aggregates?

original: etesaṃ vā aññatara”ntiādīnañca suttānaṃ vasena attattaniyagāhavatthussa etaparamatā🔽daṭṭhabbā, etena ca vakkhamānasuttavasena ca khandhe eva nissāya parittārammaṇādivasena
analyzed: etesam vā aññatara nti ādīnam ca suttānam vasena atta tta niya gāha vatthussa eta parama tā  daṭṭhabbā etena ca vakkhamāna sutta vasena ca khandhe eva nissāya paritta ārammaṇa ādi vasena
translated: and so on, and also by the sutta quoted above in §11, the extreme view of the self’s finitude should be understood.🔽And the view that arises in dependence on the aggregates only, not in dependence on a self, should be understood as limited in scope, etc.,

original: na vattabbā ca diṭṭhi uppajjati, khandhanibbānavajjassa sabhāvadhammassa abhāvatoti
analyzed: na vattabbā ca diṭṭhi uppajjati khandha nibbāna vajjassa sabhāva dhammassa abhāvato
translated: because there is no such thing as an individual essence of a real entity that is the self’s extinction.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Aññesañca khandha-saddavacanīyānaṃ sīlakkhandhādīnaṃ sabbhāvato na pañcevāti
analyzed: vuttam hoti aññesam ca khandha sadda vacanīyānam sīla kkhandha ādīnam sabbhāvataḥ na pañca iva ati
translated: And the aggregates other than the feeling aggregate, such as the virtue aggregate, etc., are not the five aggregates.

original: etaṃ codanaṃ nivattetumāha “aññesañca tadavarodhato”ti.🔽Dukkhadukkhavipariṇāmadukkhasaṅkhāradukkhatāvasena vedanāya ābādhakattaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽Rāgādisampayuttassa vipariṇāmādidukkhassa itthipurisādiākāraggāhikā taṃtaṃsaṅkappamūlabhūtā
analyzed: etam codanam nivattetum āha aññesam ca tad avarodhato ti  dukkha dukkha vipariṇāma dukkha saṅkhāra dukkha tā vasena vedanāya ābādhaka ttam daṭṭhabbaṃ  rāga ādi sampayuttassa vipariṇāma ādi dukkhassa itthi purisa ādi ākāra ggāhikā taṃ taṃ saṅkappa mūla bhūtā
translated: In order to refute this objection, the author says, “Because the other aggregates are included in it.”🔽The feeling aggregate should be regarded as the disease because it is the source of the three kinds of suffering: suffering due to suffering, suffering due to the constituents , and suffering due to change .🔽The perception aggregate is the origin of the suffering due to change, etc., in one who is associated with lust, etc., because it is the grasping of the individual forms of the object, and it is the root of the various kinds of conceiving.

original: saññā samuṭṭhānaṃ. Rogassa pittādīni viya āsannakāraṇaṃ samuṭṭhānaṃ, utubhojanavesamādīni
analyzed: saññā samuṭṭhānam rogassa pitta ādīni viya āsanna kāraṇam samuṭṭhānam utu bhojana vesama ādīni
translated: The origin is the proximate cause of a disease, like bile, etc., of a fever, etc.

original: viya mūlakāraṇaṃ nidānaṃ. “Cittassaṅgabhūtā cetasikā”ti cittaṃ gilānūpamaṃ vuttaṃ,
analyzed: viya mūla kāraṇam nidānam citta ssaṅga bhūtā cetasikā ati cittam gilāna upamam vuttam
translated: and the mental factors are the cause of the mind’s being bound up, they are like the disease.

original: sukhasaññādivasena vedanākāraṇāya hetubhāvato vedanābhojanassa chādāpanato ca saññā🔽aparādhūpamā byañjanūpamā ca, “pañca vadhakā paccatthikāti kho, bhikkhave, pañcannetaṃ
analyzed: sukha saññā ādi vasena vedanā kāraṇāya hetu bhāvataḥ vedanā bhojanassa chādāpanato ca saññā  aparādha upamā byañjana upamā ca pañca vadhakā paccatthikā ati kho bhikkhave
translated: The feeling is like the food because it is the cause of the perception of pleasure, etc., and because it covers up the disease.🔽The perception is like the thief and the poison because it conceals the disease by the perception of beauty, etc., and because it is the cause of the craving that is the cause of the disease.

original: upādānakkhandhānaṃ adhivacana”nti āsivisūpame vadhakāti vuttā, “bhāroti kho, bhikkhave,
analyzed: upādānakkhandhānam adhivacananti āsi visūpame vadhakā ati vuttā bhāraḥ ti kho bhikkhave
translated: The formations are like the murderers and the enemies because they are the cause of the disease.

original: pañcannetaṃ upādānakkhandhānaṃ adhivacana”nti bhārasutte bhārāti, “atītaṃpāhaṃ addhānaṃ🔽rūpena khajjiṃ, seyyathāpāhaṃ etarahi paccuppannena rūpena khajjāmi, ahañceva kho
analyzed: upādānakkhandhānam adhivacananti bhāra sutte bhārāti atītam pāham  rūpena khajjim seyyathā apa aham etarahi paccuppannena rūpena khajjāmi aham ca iva kho
translated: The consciousness is like the burden because it is the cause of the disease.🔽“In the past I was devoured by form, just as I am now devoured by present form.

original: pana anāgataṃ rūpaṃ abhinandeyyaṃ, anāgatenapāhaṃ rūpena khajjeyyaṃ. Seyyathāpetarahi🔽khajjāmī”tiādinā khajjanīyapariyāyena khādakāti, “so aniccaṃ rūpaṃ ‘aniccaṃ rūpa’nti
analyzed: pana anāgatam rūpam abhinandeyyam anāgatena pāham rūpena khajjeyyam seyyathā apa itarahi 🔽khajjāmi iti ādinā khajjanīya pariyāyena saḥ aniccam rūpam aniccam
translated: If I were to delight in future form, I would be devoured by future form, just as I am now devoured by present form” .🔽The consciousness is like the devourer because it is the cause of the disease in the way stated in the passage beginning, “If he delights in form, bhikkhus, that is his fetter there” .

original: yathābhūtaṃ nappajānātī”tiādinā yamakasutte aniccādikāti. Yadipi imasmiṃ vibhaṅge🔽avisesena khandhā vuttā, bāhullena pana upādānakkhandhānaṃ tadantogadhānaṃ daṭṭhabbatā
analyzed: yathābhūtam na ppajānāti itiādinā yamaka sutte anicca ādikā ati imasmin vibhaṅge  avisesena khandhāḥ vuttāḥ bāhullena pana upādāna kkhandhānam tad antogadhānam daṭṭhabba tā
translated: He does not understand as it really is. ” In the Yamaka Sutta, etc., it is said: “impermanence, etc.”🔽Although in this exegesis the aggregates are mentioned without distinction,

original: vuttāti veditabbāti.
analyzed: vuttā iti veditabbā ati
translated: it should be understood that it is said that the clinging-aggregates are included in the aggregates because of their abundance.

original: Desitādiccabandhunāti desitaṃ ādiccabandhunā, desitāni vā. Gāthāsukhatthaṃ anunāsikalopo, nikāralopo vā kato.
analyzed: desita ādiccabandhunā ati desitam ādiccabandhunā desitāni vā gāthā sukha attham anunāsika lopaḥ nikāra lopaḥ vā kato
translated: “Taught by the Kinsman of the Sun”: taught by the Kinsman of the Sun, or taught as. The nasal sound is elided for the sake of ease in expression, or the syllable “ka” is elided.

original: Gahetuṃ na sakkāti niccādivasena gahetuṃ na yuttanti attho.
analyzed: gahetum na sakkā ati nicca ādi vasena gahetum na yuttam ti attho
translated: “Cannot be grasped”: the meaning is that it is not proper to grasp it as permanent, etc.

original: Rūpena saṇṭhānena phalakasadiso dissamāno kharabhāvābhāvā phalakakiccaṃ na karotīti
analyzed: rūpena saṇṭhānena phalaka sadisaḥ dissamāno khara bhāva abhāvā phalaka kiccam na karoti iti
translated: Because it lacks the quality of hardness, it does not perform the function of a plank, although it appears like a plank in shape and color.🔽Therefore it is said: “one cannot take it and make a plank or a bench out of it.”

original: “na sakkā taṃ gahetvā phalakaṃ vā āsanaṃ vā kātu”nti āha. Na tathā tiṭṭhatīti niccādikā
analyzed: na sakkā tam gahetvā phalakam vā āsanam vā kātunti āha na tathā tiṭṭhati iti nicca ādikā
translated: “Does not remain so”: the meaning is that it is not permanent, etc.

original: na hotīti attho, taṇhādiṭṭhīhi vā niccādiggahaṇavasena uppādādianantaraṃ bhijjanato
analyzed: na hoti iti attho taṇhā diṭṭhīhi vā nicca ādi gahaṇa vasena uppāda ādi anantaram bhijjanato
translated: Or, because it breaks up immediately after arising, etc., by way of the grasping of permanence, etc., through craving and views.

original: gahitākārā hutvā na tiṭṭhatīti attho. Koṭisatasahassasaṅkhyāti idaṃ na gaṇanaparicchedadassanaṃ,
analyzed: gahita ākārā hutvā na tiṭṭhati iti attho koṭi sata sahassa saṅkhyā ati idam na gaṇana pariccheda dassanam
translated: The meaning is that it does not stand as a grasped aspect. The words “a hundred thousand koṭis” are not a statement of enumeration;

original: bahubhāvadassanameva panetaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Udakajallakanti udakalasikaṃ. Yathā udakatale
analyzed: bahu bhāva dassanam eva pana itam daṭṭhabbam udaka jallakanti udaka lasikam yathā udaka tale
translated: they should be understood as a statement of the number of times. The “water bubble” is the water spray.

original: bindunipātajanito vāto udakajallakaṃ saṅkaḍḍhitvā puṭaṃ katvā pupphuḷaṃ nāma karoti,
analyzed: bindu nipāta janitaḥ vātaḥ udaka jallakam saṅkaḍḍhitvā puṭam katvā pupphuḷam nāma karoti
translated: Just as the wind that arises from the falling of the drops of water on the surface of the water collects the water spray and makes it into a ball called a “bubble,”

original: evaṃ vatthumhi ārammaṇāpāthagamanajanito phasso anupacchinnaṃ kilesajallaṃ sahakārīpaccayantarabhāvena🔽saṅkaḍḍhitvā vedanaṃ nāma karoti. Idañca kilesehi mūlakāraṇabhūtehi ārammaṇassādanabhūtehi
analyzed: evam vatthumhi ārammaṇa āpātha gamana janitaḥ phassaḥ anupacchinnam kilesa jallam sahakārī paccaya antara bhāvena  saṅkaḍḍhitvā vedanam nāma karoti idam ca kilesehi mūla kāraṇa bhūtehi ārammaṇa ssādana bhūtehi
translated: so too, the contact that arises from the object’s coming into the field of the faculties collects the water spray of defilements that are not yet cut off and, by becoming a condition by the means of a co-nascent condition,

original: ca nibbattaṃ vaṭṭagatavedanaṃ sandhāya vuttanti veditabbaṃ. Ukkaṭṭhaparicchedena
analyzed: ca nibbattam vaṭṭa gata vedanam sandhāya vuttan ti veditabbam ukkaṭṭha paricchedena
translated: makes it into the feeling called “feeling-formation.” And this should be understood as said with reference to the feeling that has arisen in the round of rebirths, which is produced by the defilements that are the root cause and by the object that is the cause of enjoyment.🔽Or else, the four conditions are stated by way of the maximum number;

original: vā cattāro paccayā vuttā, ūnehipi pana uppajjateva.
analyzed: vā cattāro paccayāḥ vuttāḥ ūnehi pi pana uppajjateva
translated: but it arises even with less than that.

original: Nānālakkhaṇoti vaṇṇagandharasaphassādīhi nānāsabhāvo. Māyāya dassitaṃ rūpaṃ “māyā”ti
analyzed: nānā lakkhaṇo ti vaṇṇa gandha rasa phassa ādīhi nānā sabhāvaḥ māyāya dassitam rūpam māyā ati
translated: “With various characteristics” means with various natures such as color, odor, taste, and nutritive essence. The form that is shown by the magic is called “magic.”

original: āha. Pañcapi upādānakkhandhā asubhādisabhāvā eva kilesāsucivatthubhāvāditoti asubhādito
analyzed: āha pañca api upādānakkhandhāḥ asubha ādi sabhāvāḥ eva kilesa asuci vatthu bhāva āditas ti asubha āditas
translated: He said: The five aggregates as objects of clinging should be regarded as foul, etc., in the sense of being the basis for the defilements of foulness, etc., and in the sense of being the basis for the impurities of the defilements.

original: daṭṭhabbā eva. Tathāpi katthaci koci viseso sukhaggahaṇīyo hotīti āha “visesato cā”tiādi.
analyzed: daṭṭhabbāḥ eva tathā api katthaci koci visesaḥ sukha ggahaṇīyaḥ hoti iti āha visesataḥ ca atiādi
translated: But even so, in some places some distinction can be discerned that is easy to grasp, and so he said “In particular, etc.”

original: Tattha cattāro satipaṭṭhānā catuvipallāsappahānakarāti tesaṃ gocarabhāvena rūpakkhandhādīsu🔽asubhādivasena daṭṭhabbatā vuttā.
analyzed: tattha cattāro sati paṭṭhānā tesam gocara bhāvena rūpa kkhandha ādīsu  asubha ādi vasena daṭṭhabba tā vuttā
translated: Herein, the four foundations of mindfulness are the removers of the four perversions. So their object is stated in terms of foulness, etc., in the case of the materiality aggregate, and so on.

original: Khandhehi na vihaññati parividitasabhāvattā. Vipassakopi hi tesaṃ vipattiyaṃ na dukkhamāpajjati,
analyzed: khandhehi na vihaññati parividita sabhāva ttā vipassakaḥ api hi tesam vipattiyam na dukkham āpajjati
translated: He is not troubled by the aggregates because he has penetrated their individual essences. For the meditator does not suffer misfortune in the breakup of the aggregates,

original: khīṇāsavesu pana vattabbameva natthi. Te hi āyatimpi khandhehi na bādhīyantīti. Kabaḷīkārāhāraṃ🔽parijānātīti “āhārasamudayā rūpasamudayo”ti vuttattā ajjhattikarūpe chandarāgaṃ pajahanto
analyzed: khīṇāsavesu pana vattabbam eva natthi te hi āyatim pi khandhehi na bādhīyanti iti kabaḷīkāra āhāram  parijānāti iti āhāra samudayā rūpa samudayā iti vutta ttā ajjhattika rūpe chanda rāgam pajahanto
translated: but there is nothing to be said about those whose cankers are destroyed, for they are not troubled by the aggregates even in the future.🔽He fully understands the kind of nutriment that is edible food.

original: tassa samudayabhūte kabaḷīkārāhārepi chandarāgaṃ pajahatīti attho, ayaṃ pahānapariññā.
analyzed: tassa samudaya bhūte kabaḷīkāra āhāre pi chanda rāgam pajahati iti atthaḥ ayam pahāna pariññā
translated: Since it is said, “With the arising of nutriment there is the arising of materiality” , the meaning is that he abandons desire and lust in regard to internal materiality and thereby he abandons desire and lust in regard to the kind of nutriment that is edible food, which is the cause of the arising of materiality. This is the full understanding of abandoning.

original: Ajjhattikarūpaṃ pana pariggaṇhanto tassa paccayabhūtaṃ kabaḷīkārāhārampi pariggaṇhātīti
analyzed: ajjhattika rūpam pana pariggaṇhanto tassa paccaya bhūtam kabaḷīkāra āhāram pi pariggaṇhāti iti
translated: But when he discerns the internal material form, he discerns the material form of nutriment consisting of gross or fine food that is a condition for it.

original: ñātapariññā. Tassa ca udayavayānupassī hotīti tīraṇapariññā ca yojetabbā. Kāmarāgabhūtaṃ
analyzed: ñāta pariññā tassa ca udaya vaya anupassī hoti iti tīraṇa pariññā ca yojetabbā kāma rāga bhūtam
translated: So this is also the kind of full-understanding as “understanding of what is known.” And he contemplates the rise and fall of that material form, so that this should be construed as the kind of full-understanding as “repeated акт тот. ”🔽He said “the bodily tie of covetousness” referring to covetousness, which is a state of lust for sensual desires.

original: abhijjhaṃ sandhāya “abhijjhākāyagantha”nti āha. Asubhānupassanāya hi kāmarāgappahānaṃ
analyzed: abhijjham sandhāya abhijjhā kāya gantham ti āha asubha anupassanāya hi kāma rāga ppahānam
translated: For the abandoning of lust for sensual desires comes about through contemplation of ugliness.🔽Or he is speaking of the abandoning of all greed by means of the abandoning of lust for sensual desires.

original: hotīti. Kāmarāgamukhena vā sabbalobhappahānaṃ vadati. “Phassapaccayā vedanā”ti vuttattā
analyzed: hoti iti kāma rāga mukhena vā sabba lobha ppahānam vadati phassa paccayā vedanā ti vutta ttā
translated: And since it is said that “With contact as condition, feeling” ,

original: āhāraparijānane vuttanayena phassaparijānanañca yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: āhāra parijānane vutta nayena phassa parijānanam ca yojetabbam
translated: the full-understanding of contact should be construed in the way given in the Description of Nutriment .

original: Sukhatthameva bhavapatthanā hotīti vedanāya taṇhaṃ pajahanto bhavoghaṃ uttarati.🔽Sabbaṃ vedanaṃ dukkhato passanto attano parena apubbaṃ dukkhaṃ uppāditaṃ, sukhaṃ
analyzed: sukhattham eva bhava patthanā hoti iti vedanāya taṇham pajahantaḥ bhava ogham uttarati  sabbam vedanam dukkhataḥ passantaḥ attanaḥ parena apubbam dukkham uppāditam sukham
translated: Since the aspiration for existence is for the sake of pleasure, he crosses the flood of becoming by abandoning craving for feeling.

original: vā vināsitaṃ na passati, tato “anatthaṃ me acarī”tiādiāghātavatthuppahānato byāpādakāyaganthaṃ
analyzed: vā vināsitam na passati tatas anattham me acari iti ādi āghāta vatthu ppahānataḥ byāpāda kāya gantham
translated: When he sees all feeling as pain, he does not see that he himself has caused any new pain to arise in another or has destroyed another’s pleasure, and so he abandons the grounds for annoyance, thinking “He has done me harm,” etc., and so he crosses the bodily tie of ill will.

original: bhindati. “Sukhabahule sugatibhave suddhī”ti gahetvā gosīlagovatādīhi suddhiṃ parāmasanto
analyzed: bhindati sukha bahule sugati bhave suddhī iti gahetvā gosīla govata ādīhi suddhim
translated: and he breaks through the conceit “I am” by seeing the five aggregates as not-self.🔽He misapprehends purification as the attainment of the bliss of the higher deva-world, and he misapprehends purification as the attainment of the bliss of the human world by means of the practice of the cow-pen ascetic, the dog-duty ascetic, etc.

original: sukhapatthanāvaseneva parāmasatīti vedanāya taṇhaṃ pajahanto sīlabbatupādānaṃ na
analyzed: sukha patthanā vasena iva parāmasati iti vedanāya taṇham pajahantaḥ sīlabbata upādānam na
translated: He misapprehends purification by means of the aspiration for bliss.

original: upādiyati. Manosañcetanā saṅkhārakkhandhova, saññā pana taṃsampayuttāti saññāsaṅkhāre
analyzed: upādiyati manaḥ sañcetanā saṅkhāra kkhandhaḥ iva saññā pana tad sampayuttā ti saññā saṅkhāre
translated: The volition of the mind is the formations aggregate only, but perception is associated with it.

original: anattato passanto manosañcetanāya chandarāgaṃ pajahati eva, tañca pariggaṇhāti tīreti
analyzed: anattataḥ passantaḥ manaḥ sañcetanāya chanda rāgam pajahati eva tat ca pariggaṇhāti tīra iti
translated: Therefore, by seeing perception and formations as not-self, he abandons desire and lust for the volition of the mind.🔽He comprehends it, he abandons it, he does not grasp it.

original: cāti “saññaṃ saṅkhāre…pe… parijānātī”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ca ati saññam parijānāti iti vuttam
translated: Therefore it is said: “He fully understands perception, he fully understands formations” .🔽The ignorant grasps consciousness as a unity.

original: Avijjāya viññāṇe ghanaggahaṇaṃ hotīti ghanavinibbhogaṃ katvā taṃ aniccato passanto
analyzed: avijjāya viññāṇe ghana ggahaṇam hoti iti ghana vinibbhogam katvā tam aniccato passanto
translated: Therefore, by seeing it as impermanent, he crosses the flood of ignorance.

original: avijjoghaṃ uttarati. Mohabaleneva sīlabbataparāmāsaṃ hotīti taṃ pajahanto sīlabbataparāmāsakāyaganthaṃ bhindati.
analyzed: uttarati moha balena iva sīlabbata parāmāsam hoti iti tam pajahantaḥ sīlabbata parāmāsa kāya gantham bhindati
translated: He breaks through the conceit “I am” by seeing the five aggregates as not-self.

original: “Yañca kho etaṃ, bhikkhave, vuccati cittaṃ itipi mano itipi viññāṇaṃ itipi, tatrāssutavā
analyzed: yat ca kho etam bhikkhave vuccati cittam iti pi manaḥ iti pi viññāṇam iti pi
translated: “Bhikkhus, what is called mind, mentation, the mind faculty, the mind-consciousness element, and whatever else is name, is reckoned as the internal, home-based phenomenon.

original: puthujjano nālaṃ nibbindituṃ, nālaṃ virajjituṃ, nālaṃ vimuccituṃ. Taṃ kissa hetu?
analyzed: puthujjanaḥ na alam nibbinditum na alam virajjitum na alam vimuccitum tam kissa hetu
translated: The worldling is not able to become dispassionate towards it, nor to become detached from it, nor to be released from it. And why not?

original: Dīgharattaṃhetaṃ, bhikkhave, assutavato puthujjanassa ajjhositaṃ mamāyitaṃ parāmaṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: dīgharattam ha etam bhikkhave assutavataḥ puthujjanassa ajjhositam mamāyitam parāmaṭṭham
translated: Because, bhikkhus, for a long time this has been desired, claimed, and misapprehended by the uninstructed worldling as ‘mine,’ as ‘I,’ as ‘my self.’

original: ‘etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā”ti –
analyzed: etam mama esaḥ aham asmi esaḥ me attā ati
translated: ‘This is me, this is my self, this is what I shall be when I come into existence in the future.’

original: Vacanato viññāṇaṃ niccato passanto diṭṭhupādānaṃ upādiyatīti aniccato passanto taṃ na upādiyatīti.🔽Kamādivinicchayakathāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: vacanataḥ viññāṇam niccatas passantaḥ diṭṭhupādānam upādiyati iti aniccatas passantaḥ tam na upādiyati iti  kama ādi vinicchaya kathā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: When he sees consciousness as permanent, he clings to the percepts as ‘mine,’ but when he sees it as impermanent, he does not cling to them as ‘mine.’🔽The explanation of the exposition of the analysis of sense desires, etc., is ended.

original: Suttantabhājanīyavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: suttantabhājanīya vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the exposition of the discourses is ended.

original: 2. Abhidhammabhājanīyavaṇṇanā🔽34. Evaṃ yā ekavidhādinā vuttavedanānaṃ bhūmivasena jānitabbatā, taṃ vatvā puna sampayuttato🔽dassitatādijānitabbappakāraṃ vattumāha “apicā”tiādi. Aṭṭhavidhena tatthāti tattha-saddassa
analyzed: evam yā ekavidha ādinā vutta vedanānam bhūmi vasena jānitabba tā tam vatvā puna sampayuttato  dassita tā ādi jānitabba ppakāram vattum āha apica atiādi aṭṭhavidhena tattha āti tattha saddassa
translated: The explanation of the exposition of the Abhidhamma🔽Having thus shown how the kinds of feeling stated under the headings of “onefold,” etc., should be known by way of plane, he now undertakes to show the way in which they should be known by way of association, etc., saying “Moreover, they should be known as eightfold, etc.” The word “there” in the phrase “therein, as eightfold” is to be construed

original: sattavidhabhedeneva yojanā chabbidhabhedena yojanāya sati aṭṭhavidhattābhāvato.
analyzed: sattavidha bhedena iva yojanā chabbidha bhedena yojanāya sati aṭṭhavidha tā bhāvato
translated: with the sevenfold analysis, since there is no eightfold analysis.

original: Pūraṇatthameva vuttoti dasavidhatāpūraṇatthameva vutto, na navavidhabhede viya nayadānatthaṃ.
analyzed: pūraṇa attham eva vutto ti dasavidha tā pūraṇa attham eva vuttaḥ na navavidha bhede viya naya dāna attham
translated: It is stated only for the sake of filling out: it is stated only for the sake of filling out the tenfold division, not for the sake of giving a method as in the ninefold division.

original: Kasmā? Tattha nayassa dinnattā. Bhinditabbassa hi bhedanaṃ nayadānaṃ, tañca tattha🔽katanti. Yathā ca kusalattiko, evaṃ “kāyasamphassajā vedanā atthi sukhā, atthi dukkhā”ti
analyzed: kasmā tattha nayassa dinna ttā bhinditabbassa hi bhedanam naya dānam tat ca tattha  katam ti yathā ca kusalattikaḥ evam kāya samphassa jā vedanā atthi sukhā atthi dukkhā ati
translated: Why? Because the method has been given there. For the giving of a method is the opening up of what is to be opened up, and that has been done there.

original: idampi pūraṇatthamevāti dīpitaṃ hoti aṭṭhavidhabhede nayassa dinnattā.
analyzed: idam pi pūraṇa ttham eva ati dīpitam hoti aṭṭhavidha bhede nayassa dinna ttā
translated: And just as the skilled man, so too this is shown by the words “There is pleasant bodily feeling” and so on, which are stated only for the sake of filling out, because the method has been given in the ninefold division.

original: Pubbe gahitato aññassa gahaṇaṃ vaḍḍhanaṃ gahaṇavaḍḍhanavasena, na purimagahite ṭhite
analyzed: pubbe gahitataḥ aññassa gahaṇam vaḍḍhanam gahaṇa vaḍḍhana vasena na purima gahite ṭhite
translated: The filling out by taking what has not been taken is the filling out by taking; it is not the filling out by adding to what has already been taken and left.

original: aññupacayavasena. Vaḍḍhana-saddo vā chedanattho kesavaḍḍhanādīsu viyāti pubbe gahitassa🔽aggahaṇaṃ chindanaṃ vaḍḍhanaṃ, dukatikānaṃ ubhayesaṃ vaḍḍhanaṃ ubhayavaḍḍhanaṃ, ubhayato
analyzed: aññ upacaya vasena vaḍḍhana saddo vā chedana atthaḥ kesa vaḍḍhana ādīsu viyā ti pubbe gahitassa  aggahaṇam chindanam vaḍḍhanam dukatikānam ubhayesam vaḍḍhanam ubhaya vaḍḍhanam ubhayatas
translated: Or the word “filling out” has the meaning of “cutting off” as in the expressions “cutting the hair” and “cutting the nails,” and so “the filling out of what has been taken” is the cutting off of what has been taken.

original: vā pavattaṃ vaḍḍhanaṃ ubhayavaḍḍhanaṃ, tadeva ubhatovaḍḍhanakaṃ, tena nayanīharaṇaṃ
analyzed: vā pavattam vaḍḍhanam ubhaya vaḍḍhanam tat eva ubhatovaḍḍhanakam tena nayanī haraṇam
translated: The filling out of both is the filling out of both sides. Or the filling out that occurs on both sides is the filling out of both sides. That is what is meant by “the filling out of both sides.” The taking away of the method by that is

original: ubhatovaḍḍhanakanīhāro. Vaḍḍhanakanayo vā vaḍḍhanakanīhāro, ubhayato pavatto vaḍḍhanakanīhāro
analyzed: ubhatovaḍḍhanaka nīhāraḥ vaḍḍhanaka nayaḥ vā vaḍḍhanaka nīhāraḥ ubhayatas pavattaḥ vaḍḍhanaka nīhāro
translated: The “both-sides-increase method” is the method of increase or the method of increase is the “both-sides-increase method.”🔽The “both-sides-increase method” is the method of increase that occurs on both sides.

original: ubhatovaḍḍhanakanīhāro. Tattha dukamūlakatikamūlakaubhatovaḍḍhanakesu duvidhatividhabhedānaṃyeva
analyzed: ubhatovaḍḍhanaka nīhāro tattha dukamūlaka tikamūlaka obhatovaḍḍhanakesu
translated: Herein, the difference in the “both-sides-increase method” with the “two-factored” and the “three-factored” is only that of the twofold and threefold division.

original: hi viseso. Aññe bhedā avisiṭṭhā, tathāpi paññāppabhedajananatthaṃ dhammavitakkena
analyzed: hi visesaḥ aññe bhedāḥ a visiṭṭhā tathā api paññā appabheda janana ttham dhamma vitakkena
translated: The other divisions are not specified. Nevertheless, in order to generate the understanding of the divisions,🔽in order to prevent unprofitable thinking such as thinking about one’s relatives,

original: ñātivitakkādiniratthakavitakkanivāraṇatthaṃ imañca pāḷiṃ vitakkentassa dhammupasaṃhitapāmojjajananatthaṃ🔽ekekassa vārassa gahitassa niyyānamukhabhāvato ca duvidhatividhabhedanānattavasena
analyzed: ñāti vitakka ādi niratthaka vitakka nivāraṇa attham imam ca pāḷim vitakkentassa dhamma upasaṃhita pāmojja janana attham  ekekassa vārassa gahitassa niyyāna mukha bhāvataḥ ca duvidha tividha bheda nānatta vasena
translated: and in order to generate joy connected with the True Idea in one who is thinking this text,🔽the other divisions should be understood as stated by way of the variety of the twofold and threefold division, since each time a turn is taken, it is the door of deliverance.

original: itarepi bhedā vuttāti veditabbā aññamaññāpekkhesu ekassa visesena itaresampi visiṭṭhabhāvato.
analyzed: itare api bhedāḥ vuttā iti veditabbāḥ aññamañña apekkhesu ekassa visesena itaresam pi visiṭṭha bhāvataḥ
translated: For when one is specified by the difference of the other, the other is also specified.

original: Na kevalaṃ ekavidhova, atha kho duvidho ca. Na ca ekaduvidhova, atha kho tividhopi.
analyzed: na kevalam ca na ca atha kho tividhaḥ api
translated: Not only is there a single kind, but there is also a twofold kind. Not only is there a single kind and a twofold kind, but there is also a threefold kind.

original: Nāpi eka…pe… navavidhova, atha kho dasavidhopīti hi evañca te bhedā aññamaññāpekkhā,
analyzed: na api ekape navavidhaḥ uva atha kho dasavidhaḥ upi iti hi evañca te bhedāḥ aññamañña apekkhā
translated: Nor is it only one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, but it is also tenfold, and so on.🔽So these divisions are mutually dependent.

original: tasmā eko bhedo visiṭṭho attanā apekkhiyamāne, attānañca apekkhamāne aññabhede visesetīti
analyzed: tasmai ekaḥ bhedaḥ visiṭṭhaḥ attanā apekkhiyamāne attānam ca apekkhamāne añña bhede viseseti iti
translated: Therefore, since one division is distinguished by its own dependence and by the dependence of the other divisions on it,

original: tassa vasena tepi vattabbataṃ arahantīti vuttāti daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: tassa vasena te api vattabba tam arahanti iti vuttā ati daṭṭhabbā
translated: it is said that they are to be mentioned in terms of that.

original: Sattavidhenātiādayo aññappabhedanirapekkhā kevalaṃ bahuppakāratādassanatthaṃ vuttāti
analyzed: sattavidhena ati ādayaḥ añña ppabheda nirapekkhā kevalam bahu ppakāra tā dassana ttham vuttā iti
translated: The words “in seven ways” and so on are said without reference to other divisions, only in order to show the many kinds.

original: sabbehi tehi pakārehi “bahuvidhena vedanākkhandhaṃ dassesī”ti vuttaṃ. Mahāvisayo🔽rājā viya savisaye bhagavāpi mahāvisayatāya appaṭihato yathā yathā icchati, tathā
analyzed: sabbehi tehi pakārehi bahuvidhena vedanā khandham dassesi iti vuttam mahā visayaḥ  rājā savisaye bhagavā api mahā visaya tāya appaṭihataḥ yathā yathā icchati tathā
translated: Therefore it is said that he showed the feeling aggregate in many ways by all those kinds.🔽The Blessed One, like a king, is unobstructed in his great domain, and he is able to teach in whatever way he wishes, as he likes, by virtue of his unobstructed knowledge of omniscience.

original: tathā desetuṃ sakkoti sabbaññutānāvaraṇañāṇayogatoti attho. Duke vatvā tikā vuttāti
analyzed: tathā desetum sakkoti sabbaññu tā anāvaraṇa ñāṇa yogato ti atthaḥ duke vatvā tikā vuttā ati
translated: The subcommentary is said to be included in the dukas.

original: tikā dukesu pakkhittāti yuttaṃ, dukā pana kathaṃ tikesu pakkhittāti? Parato vuttepi
analyzed: tikā dukesu pakkhittā ati yuttam dukā pana katham tikesu pakkhittā ati paratas vutte api
translated: It is appropriate that the subcommentary is included in the dukas, but how are the dukas included in the tukas?

original: tasmiṃ tasmiṃ tike apekkhakāpekkhitabbavasena dukānaṃ yojitattā.
analyzed: tasmim tasmim tike apekkhaka apekkhitabba vasena dukānam yojita ttā
translated: because the three in each case are yoked together as that which is looked at and that which looks.

original: Kiriyamanodhātu āvajjanavasena labbhatīti vuttaṃ, āvajjanā pana cakkhusamphassapaccayā
analyzed: kiriya manaḥ dhātu āvajjana vasena labbhati iti vuttam āvajjanā pana cakkhu samphassa paccayā
translated: The function of the mind-element is said to be found as adverting, but the adverting is not due to eye-contact as condition.

original: na hoti. Na hi samānavīthiyaṃ pacchimo dhammo purimassa koci paccayo hoti. Ye ca
analyzed: na hoti na hi samāna vīthiyam pacchimaḥ dhammaḥ purimassa koci paccayaḥ hoti ye ca
translated: For no preceding state is a condition for a subsequent one in the same cognitive series.

original: vadanti “āvajjanavedanāva cakkhusaṅghaṭṭanāya uppannattā evaṃ vuttā”ti, tañca na
analyzed: vadanti āvajjana vedanā va cakkhu saṅghaṭṭanāya uppanna ttā evam vuttā ati tat ca na
translated: And those who say that it is only the adverting and the feeling that are so described because they arise with the impact of the eye are not correct.

original: yuttaṃ. Na hi “cakkhurūpapaṭighāto cakkhusamphasso”ti katthaci sutte vā aṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: yuttam na hi cakkhu rūpa paṭighāto cakkhu samphasso ti katthaci sutte vā aṭṭhakathāyam
translated: For nowhere in the suttas or commentaries is it said that “eye-contact is the impact of the eye on visible forms.”

original: vā vuttaṃ. Yadi so ca cakkhusamphasso siyā, cakkhuviññāṇasahajātāpi vedanā cakkhusamphassapaccayāti
analyzed: vā vuttam yadi so ca cakkhu samphasso siyā cakkhu viññāṇa sahajātā api vedanā cakkhu samphassa paccayā ti
translated: If that were eye-contact, then feeling that arises together with eye-consciousness would be due to eye-contact as condition,

original: sā idha aṭṭhakathāyaṃ na vajjetabbā siyā. Pāḷiyañca “cakkhusamphassapaccayā vedanā
analyzed: sā idha aṭṭhakathāyam na vajjetabbā siyā pāḷiyam ca cakkhu samphassa paccayā vedanā
translated: and it would not be proper to omit it from this commentary here. And it would be unnecessary to state “feeling born of eye-contact” in the text,

original: atthi abyākatā”ti ettha saṅgahitattā puna “cakkhusamphassajā vedanā”ti na vattabbaṃ
analyzed: atthi abyākatā ti ettha saṅgahita ttā puna cakkhu samphassa jā vedanā ti na vattabbam
translated: because it would be included in the passage “There is feeling due to eye-contact that is wholesome … unwholesome … indeterminate” .

original: siyāti. Ayaṃ panetthādhippāyo – āvajjanavedanaṃ vinā cakkhusamphassassa uppatti natthīti
analyzed: siyā ti ayam pana itthā adhippāyaḥ āvajjana vedanam vinā cakkhu samphassassa uppatti natthi iti
translated: “Siyā” means “may be.” The intention here is this: since there is no arising of eye-contact without the arising of adverting and feeling,

original: taduppādikā sā tappayojanattā pariyāyena cakkhusamphassapaccayāti vattuṃ yuttāti,
analyzed: tad uppādikā sā tad payojana ttā pariyāyena cakkhu samphassa paccayā ti vattum yuttā ti
translated: the latter, as the purpose of the former, may be called “with eye-contact as condition” figuratively.

original: nippariyāyena pana cakkhusamphassassa paratova vedanā labbhanti.
analyzed: nippariyāyena pana cakkhu samphassassa paratas va vedanāḥ labbhanti
translated: But literally feeling is only found after eye-contact.

original: Catuttiṃsacittuppādavasenāti ettha rūpārūpāvacarānaṃ aggahaṇaṃ tesaṃ sayameva manodvārabhūtattā.
analyzed: catuttiṃsa cittuppāda vasena ati ettha rūpa arūpāvacarānam aggahaṇam tesam sayam eva manaḥ dvāra bhūta ttā
translated: “By way of the forty-four types of consciousness”: the fine-material and immaterial types are not included here because they are themselves the mind door.

original: Sabbabhavaṅgamano hi manodvāraṃ, cutipaṭisandhiyo ca tato anaññāti. Imasmiṃ pana
analyzed: sabba bhavaṅga manaḥ hi mano dvāram cuti paṭisandhiyaḥ ca tatas anaññā iti imasmin pana
translated: For the death and rebirth-linking consciousnesses are the mind door, and the life-continuum consciousness is the mind door too, since it is the mind door in the sense of being the mind at the door.

original: catuvīsatividhabhede cakkhusamphassapaccayādikusalādīnaṃ samānavīthiyaṃ labbhamānatā
analyzed: catuvīsatividha bhede cakkhu samphassa paccaya ādi kusala ādīnam samāna vīthiyam labbhamāna tā
translated: But in this classification of twenty-four types of consciousness, the profitable and so on that occur in the same cognitive process as eye-contact as condition are found

original: aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttā, pāḷiyaṃ pana ekūnavīsaticatuvīsatikā saṅkhipitvā āgatāti “cakkhusamphassapaccayā
analyzed: aṭṭhakathā āyam vuttā pāḷiyam pana ekūnavīsati catuvīsatikā saṅkhipitvā āgatā ti cakkhu samphassa paccayā
