translated: in the commentary, but in the text only nineteen and twenty-four are given in brief thus: “With eye-contact as condition there is feeling in one not fully understanding … and so on.

original: vedanākkhandho atthi anupādinnaanupādāniyo asaṃkiliṭṭhaasaṃkilesiko avitakkaavicāro”tiādinā
analyzed: vedanā khandho atthi anupādinna anupādāniyaḥ asaṃkiliṭṭha asaṃkilesikaḥ avitakka avicāraḥ ti ādinā
translated: “With eye-contact as condition there is the aggregate of feeling that is not clung to and does not cling, that is uncorrupted and not a condition for corruption, that is without thinking and pondering” ,

original: nānāvīthigatānaṃ labbhamānatāya vuttattā kusalattikassapi nānāvīthiyaṃ labbhamānatā🔽yojetabbā. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana samānavīthiyaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayādikatā ekantikāti
analyzed: nānā vīthi gatānam labbhamāna tāya vutta ttā kusala ttikassa api nānā vīthiyam labbhamāna tā  yojetabbā aṭṭhakathāyam pana samāna vīthiyam cakkhu samphassa paccaya ādika tā ekantikā ti
translated: because it is said that they are found in the various planes. So their being found in the various planes should be construed with the profitable triad.

original: katvā ettha labbhamānatā dassitā, na pana asamānavīthiyaṃ labbhamānatā paṭikkhittā.🔽Teneva “tāni sattavidhādīsu yattha katthaci ṭhatvā kathetuṃ vaṭṭantī”ti āha. Na hi🔽samānavīthiyaṃyeva upanissayakoṭisamatikkamabhāvanāhi labbhamānatā hoti. Tidhāpi
analyzed: katvā ettha labbhamāna tā dassitā na pana asamāna vīthiyam labbhamāna tā paṭikkhittā  tena iva tāni sattavidha ādīsu yattha katthaci ṭhatvā kathetum vaṭṭanti iti āha na hi  samāna vīthiyam yeva upanissaya koṭi samatikkama bhāvanāhi labbhamāna tā hoti tidhā api
translated: But in the commentary it is shown that they are found in the same plane as the eye contact, etc., because they are invariably found there, and it is not denied that they are found in different planes.🔽That is why it is said that they are allowable in any of the seven kinds of talk, etc. For they are not found only in the same plane as the condition by way of decisive support,

original: ca labbhamānataṃ sandhāya “yattha katthaci ṭhatvā kathetuṃ vaṭṭantī”ti vuccati.🔽Etānīti yathādassitāni kusalādīni cittāni vadati, vedanāniddesepi ca etasmiṃ pubbaṅgamassa
analyzed: ca labbhamāna tam sandhāya yattha katthacid ṭhatvā kathetum vaṭṭanti iti vuccati  etāni iti yathā dassitāni kusala ādīni cittāni vadati vedanā niddese pi ca etasmin pubbaṅgamassa
translated: but they are found in any of the three ways. And it is with reference to their being found in any of these three ways that it is said that they are allowable in any of the seven kinds of talk, etc.🔽‘These’: he is referring to the kinds of consciousness shown as profitable, etc., and in the description of feeling the connection with consciousness is made by way of the consciousness that precedes the feeling described,

original: cittassa vasena kathetuṃ sukhanti cittasambandho kato. Teneva pana cittāni sattavidhabhede
analyzed: cittassa vasena kathetum sukhanti citta sambandho kato tena iva pana cittāni sattavidha bhede
translated: which is the first of the three. That is why it is said: ‘Pleasurable when associated with profitable consciousness’ and so on. And it is because of that same connection with consciousness that the kinds of consciousness are classified in the seven ways,

original: tikabhūmivasena, catuvīsatividhabhede dvāratikavasena, tiṃsavidhabhede dvārabhūmivasena,🔽bahuvidhabhede dvāratikabhūmivasena dīpitānīti “tesu yattha katthaci ṭhatvā kathetuṃ🔽vaṭṭantī”ti vuttaṃ. Kusalādīnaṃ dīpanā kāmāvacarādibhūmivasena kātabbā, tā ca bhūmiyo🔽tiṃsavidhabhede sayamevāgatā, na ca sattavidhabhede viya dvāraṃ anāmaṭṭhaṃ, atibyattā🔽ca ettha samānāsamānavīthīsu labbhamānatāti tiṃsavidhe…pe… sukhadīpanāni hontī”ti🔽vuttaṃ. Kasmā pana tiṃsavidhasmiṃyeva ṭhatvā dīpayiṃsu, nanu dvāratikabhūmīnaṃ āmaṭṭhattā🔽bahuvidhabhede ṭhatvā dīpetabbānīti? Na, dīpetabbaṭṭhānātikkamato. Sattavidhabhedo
analyzed: tika bhūmi vasena catuvīsatividha bhede dvāra tika vasena tiṃsavidha bhede dvāra bhūmi vasena  bahuvidha bhede dvāratika bhūmi vasena dīpitāni iti tesu yattha katthaci ṭhatvā kathetum  vaṭṭanti iti vuttam kusala ādīnam dīpanā kāmāvacara ādi bhūmi vasena kātabbā tāḥ ca bhūmiyaḥ  tiṃsavidha bhede sayam eva āgatā na ca sattavidha bhede dvāram an āmaṭṭham ati byattā  ca ettha samāna asamāna vīthīsu sukha dīpanāni honti iti  vuttam kasmā pana tiṃsavidhasmin yeva ṭhatvā dīpayiṃsu nanu dvāratika bhūmīnam  bahuvidha bhede ṭhatvā dīpetabbāni iti na dīpetabba ṭhāna atikkamataḥ sattavidha bhedaḥ
translated: and in the twenty-four kinds classed according to the three planes, and in the thirty kinds classed according to the doors and the planes, and in the many kinds classed according to the doors, the planes, and the repetition of the doors and the planes. So it is said: “They are allowable to be told in any one of these” . The demonstration of the profitable, etc., should be done by means of the planes of the sense sphere, and so on. And those planes are included in the thirty kinds classed according to the doors and the planes, and they are not left out as the doors are in the seven kinds classed according to the doors. And they are more suitable here than in the many kinds classed according to the doors, the planes, and the repetition of the doors and the planes. So it is said: “The demonstrations of the profitable, etc., are in the thirty kinds classed according to the doors and the planes, and so on. … They are in the thirty kinds classed according to the doors and the planes, and so on, because the profitable, etc., are demonstrated by means of the planes of the sense sphere, and so on, and because those planes are included in the thirty kinds classed according to the doors and the planes, and because the doors are not left out as they are in the seven kinds classed according to the doors, and because they are more suitable here than in the many kinds classed according to the doors, the planes, and the repetition of the doors and the planes” . Why did they demonstrate them only in the thirty kinds classed according to the doors and the planes, and not in the many kinds classed according to the doors, the planes, and the repetition of the doors and the planes, since the doors and the planes are left out in the latter? —Because of the omission of the place of demonstration. The seven kinds classed according to the doors

original: hi dvārassa anāmaṭṭhattā dīpanāya aṭṭhānaṃ, catuvīsatividhabhede āmaṭṭhadvāratikā
analyzed: hi dvārassa an āmaṭṭha ttā dīpanāya aṭṭhānam catuvīsatividha bhede āmaṭṭhadvāratikā
translated: and in the twenty-four kinds classed according to the three planes, and in the thirty kinds classed according to the doors and the planes, and in the many kinds classed according to the doors, the planes, and the repetition of the doors and the planes. So it is said: “They are allowable to be told in any one of these” . The demonstration of the profitable, etc., should be done by means of the planes of the sense sphere, and so on. And those planes are already included in the thirty kinds. And the doors are not omitted as they are in the seven kinds. And they are very numerous in the many kinds classed according to the similar and dissimilar streets. So it is said: “The demonstrations of pleasure, etc., are in the thirty kinds, etc.” But why do they demonstrate only in the thirty kinds? Should they not be demonstrated in the many kinds classed according to the doors, the planes, and the repetition of the doors and the planes, since the doors and the planes have been omitted there? —No; because of the omission of the place of demonstration. For the seven kinds is not the place for demonstrating because the doors have been omitted there. And in the twenty-four kinds the doors and the planes have been omitted.

original: na bhūmiyo apekkhitvā ṭhapitā, tiṃsavidhabhede āmaṭṭhadvārabhūmiyo vuttā. Ye ca ṭhapitā,🔽te cettha tikā apekkhitabbarahitā kevalaṃ bhūmīhi saha dīpetabbāva. Tenedaṃ dīpanāya
analyzed: na bhūmiyaḥ apekkhitvā ṭhapitā tiṃsavidha bhede āmaṭṭha dvāra bhūmiyaḥ vuttāḥ ye ca ṭhapitā  te ca ittha tikā apekkhitabba rahitā kevalam bhūmīhi saha dīpetabbā ava tena idam dīpanāya
translated: They are not stated with reference to the planes, but they are stated with the planes of the thirty-two kinds of object.🔽And those that are stated

original: ṭhānaṃ, tadatikkame pana ṭhānātikkamo hotīti.
analyzed: ṭhānam tad atikkame pana ṭhāna atikkamaḥ hoti iti
translated: can be illustrated here without reference to the triplets.🔽So they can be illustrated thus:

original: Upanissayakoṭiyāti ettha “saddhaṃ upanissāya dānaṃ detī”tiādinā nānāvīthiyaṃ pakatūpanissayo🔽vuttoti ekavīthiyaṃ kusalādīnaṃ cakkhusamphassādayo tadabhāve abhāvato jāti viya
analyzed: upanissaya koṭiyā ti ettha saddham upanissāya dānam deti iti ādinā nānā vīthiyam pakatūpanissayaḥ  vuttaḥ ti eka vīthiyam kusala ādīnam cakkhu samphassa ādayo tad abhāve abhāvataḥ viya
translated: As to the “extreme of decisive-support condition”: here, the ordinary decisive- support condition is stated in the way beginning, “Depending on faith he gives a gift” , in various ways.

original: jarāmaraṇassa upanissayalesena paccayoti vattuṃ yujjeyya, idha pana “kasiṇarūpadassanahetuuppannā🔽parikammādivedanā cakkhusamphassapaccayā”ti vakkhati, tasmā nānāvīthiyaṃ gatāni etāni
analyzed: jarā maraṇassa upanissaya lesena paccayaḥ ti vattum yujjeyya idha pana kasiṇa rūpa dassana hetu uppannā  parikamma ādi vedanā cakkhu samphassa paccayā ti vakkhati tasmā nānā vīthiyam gatāni etāni
translated: So it would be proper to say that the eye-contact, etc., of the profitable, etc., in a single cognitive series are a condition by way of decisive-support condition for ageing-and-death, as is the case with birth, since they are absent when that is absent.🔽But here it is said, “The feeling that arises due to the seeing of the kasiṇa’s materiality is a condition, by way of contact condition, for the preliminary-work consciousness, etc.,” .

original: cittāni cakkhusamphassapaccayā labbhamānānīti na upanissayaleso upanissayakoṭi, balavabalavānaṃ
analyzed: cittāni cakkhu samphassa paccayā labbhamānāni iti na upanissaya lesaḥ upanissaya koṭi balava balavānam
translated: So these kinds of consciousness that occur in a single cognitive series are obtained by way of contact condition, and therefore the extreme of decisive-support condition is not the decisive-support condition that occurs in a single cognitive series.

original: pana parikammādīnaṃ upanissayānaṃ sabbesaṃ ādibhūto upanissayo upanissayakoṭi. “Vālakoṭi
analyzed: pana parikamma ādīnam upanissayānam sabbesam ādi bhūtaḥ upanissayaḥ upanissaya koṭi vāla koṭi
translated: But the support that is the beginning of the preliminary work, etc., is the extreme of support. “The tip of the grass

original: na paññāyatī”tiādīsu viya hi ādi, avayavo vā koṭi. Kasiṇarūpadassanato pabhuti ca
analyzed: na paññāyati iti ādīsu hi ādi avayavaḥ vā ca
translated: But the condition that is the first of all the conditions beginning with the preliminary work is the limit of the condition as decisive-support. For the beginning or the part is called the “limit” in such passages as “The tip of the hair is not discerned” .🔽And the condition as decisive-support occurs beginning with the seeing of the kasiṇa materiality.

original: kāmāvacarakusalādīnaṃ vedanānaṃ upanissayo pavattoti taṃ dassanaṃ upanissayakoṭi.
analyzed: kāmāvacara kusala ādīnam vedanānam upanissayo pavatto ti tam dassanam upanissaya koṭi
translated: So that seeing is the limit of the condition as decisive-support.

original: Parikammādīni viya vā na balavaupanissayo dassananti tassa upanissayantabhāvena upanissayakoṭitā
analyzed: parikamma ādīni viya vā na balavā upanissayaḥ dassananti tassa upanissaya anta bhāvena upanissaya koṭi tā
translated: Or alternatively, the seeing is not a strong condition as decisive-support like the preliminary work, etc.,🔽so it is called the limit of the condition as decisive-support because it is a condition as decisive-support in a low degree.

original: vuttā. Ghānādidvāresu tīsu upanissayakoṭiyā labbhamānattābhāvaṃ vadanto idha samānavīthi
analyzed: vuttāḥ ghāna ādi dvāresu tīsu upanissaya koṭiyā labbhamāna tta abhāvam vadantaḥ idha samāna vīthi
translated: He is saying that it is not found in the three instances of the limit of the condition as decisive-support in the case of the nose, etc., because it is not included in the same cognitive series.

original: na gahitāti dīpeti. Dassanasavanāni viya hi kasiṇaparikammādīnaṃ ghāyanādīni upanissayā🔽na hontīti tadalābho dīpitoti. Yadipi vāyokasiṇaṃ phusitvāpi gahetabbaṃ, purimena
analyzed: na gahitā ati dīpeti dassana savanāni viya hi kasiṇa parikamma ādīnam ghāyana ādīni upanissayā  na honti iti tad alābhaḥ yadi api vāyo kasiṇam phusitvā api gahetabbam purimena
translated: For smelling, etc., are not conditions as decisive-support for the preliminary work, etc., as seeing and hearing are.🔽So the non-occurrence of that is shown.🔽Or alternatively, although the air kasiṇa can be apprehended by touching, still that touching without the preceding hearing is not usually a strong condition as decisive-support by itself.

original: pana savanena vinā taṃ phusanaṃ sayameva mūlupanissayo yebhuyyena na hotīti tassa
analyzed: pana savanena vinā tam phusanam sayam eva mūla upanissayaḥ yebhuyyena na hoti iti tassa
translated: So the non-occurrence of that is shown.

original: upanissayakoṭitā na vuttā.
analyzed: upanissaya koṭi tā na vuttā
translated: But the end of the support is not stated.

original: Ajjhāsayena sampattigato ajjhāsayasampanno, sampannajjhāsayoti vuttaṃ hoti. Vattappaṭivattanti
analyzed: ajjhāsayena sampatti gataḥ ajjhāsaya sampannaḥ sampanna jjhāsayaḥ iti vuttam hoti vatta paṭivattanti
translated: One who has attained by means of aspiration is one who has the aspiration, one whose aspiration is fulfilled, is what is meant. The right and the wrong are

original: khuddakañceva mahantañca vattaṃ, pubbe vā kataṃ vattaṃ, pacchā kataṃ paṭivattaṃ.
analyzed: khuddakam ca iva mahantam ca vattam pubbe vā katam vattam pacchā katam paṭivattam
translated: the minor and the major duties. Or the right is the duty done previously, and the wrong is the duty done afterwards.

original: Evaṃ cakkhuviññāṇanti ādimhi uppannaṃ āha, tato paraṃ uppannānipi pana kasiṇarūpadassanakalyāṇamittadassanasaṃvegavatthudassanādīni
analyzed: evam cakkhu viññāṇan ti ādimhi uppannam āha tatas param uppannāni api pana kasiṇa rūpa dassana kalyāṇa mitta dassana saṃvega vatthu dassana ādīni
translated: Thus he said that what arises first is eye-consciousness, and so on. But what arises afterwards also is a support condition for the kasiṇa materiality, for the sight of a good friend, for the sight of a sight that inspires one to strive, and so on.

original: upanissayapaccayā hontiyevāti. Tena tadupanissayaṃ cakkhuviññāṇaṃ dassetīti veditabbaṃ.🔽Yathābhūtasabhāvādassanaṃ asamapekkhanā. “Asmī”ti rūpādīsu vinibandhassa. Sabhāvantarāmasanavasena
analyzed: upanissaya paccayāḥ honti yeva āti tena tad upanissayam cakkhu viññāṇam dasseti iti veditabbam  yathā bhūta sabhāvāt assanam a samapekkhanā asmi iti rūpa ādīsu vinibandhassa sabhāvantara āmasana vasena
translated: So it should be understood that he shows eye-consciousness with that as its support.🔽The failure to see the true individual essence is the failure to see the individual essence as it really is. The “I am” is the one who is bound to materiality, and so on. The “I am” is the one who has misapprehended by misapprehending a different individual essence. The meaning is: the one who has misapprehended misapprehends.

original: parāmaṭṭhassa, parāmaṭṭhavatoti attho. Ārammaṇādhigahaṇavasena anu anu uppajjanadhammatāya
analyzed: parāmaṭṭhassa parāmaṭṭhavato ti attho ārammaṇa adhigahaṇa vasena anu anu uppajjana dhamma tāya
translated: Because of the state of arising again and again by the mode of apprehending an object,

original: thirabhāvakilesassa thāmagatassa, appahīnakāmarāgādikassa vā. Pariggahe ṭhitoti vīmaṃsāya
analyzed: thira bhāva kilesassa thāma gatassa appahīna kāma rāga ādikassa vā pariggahe ṭhitaḥ ti vīmaṃsāya
translated: Steadied in the apprehending is steadied in the investigation.

original: ṭhito. Ettha ca asamapekkhanāyātiādinā mohādīnaṃ kiccena pākaṭena tesaṃ uppattivasena🔽vicāraṇā daṭṭhabbā. Rūpadassanena uppannakilesasamatikkamavasena pavattā rūpadassanahetukā🔽hotīti “cakkhusamphassapaccayā nāma jātā”ti āha. Ettha ca cakkhusamphassassa catubhūmikavedanāya
analyzed: ettha ca asamapekkhanāya ati ādinā moha ādīnam kiccena pākaṭena tesam uppatti vasena  vicāraṇā daṭṭhabbā rūpa dassanena uppanna kilesa samatikkama vasena pavattā rūpa dassana hetukā  hoti iti cakkhu samphassa paccayā nāma jātā ati āha ettha ca cakkhu samphassassa catu bhūmika vedanāya
translated: And here the occurrence of delusion, etc., should be regarded as the investigation of the way in which they arise with their functions evident, according to the passage beginning, “Without looking for” ,🔽The knowledge that arises with the surmounting of defilement that arose with the seeing of materiality is called “due to the seeing of materiality” .

original: upanissayabhāvo eva pakārantarena kathito, tathā “bhāvanāvasenā”ti ettha ca.🔽Kalāpasammasanena tīṇi lakkhaṇāni āropetvā udayabbayānupassanādikāya vipassanāpaṭipāṭiyā
analyzed: upanissaya bhāvaḥ eva pakāra antarena kathito tathā bhāvanā vasena ati ettha ca  kalāpa sammasanena tīṇi lakkhaṇāni āropetvā udaya bbaya anupassana ādikāya vipassanā paṭipāṭiyā
translated: And here the conditionality of eye-contact in the fourfold feeling is stated in another way as “by the means of development” .🔽Having imposed the three characteristics by means of the “contemplation of mentality-materiality in all its aspects” , and having comprehended the materiality that is the object of the “contemplation of origination and dissolution,” etc., in the order of insight,

original: ādimhi rūpārammaṇapariggahena rūpārammaṇaṃ sammasitvā, taṃmūlakaṃ vā sabbaṃ sammasanaṃ
analyzed: ādimhi rūpa ārammaṇa pariggahena rūpa ārammaṇam sammasitvā taṃmūlakam vā sabbam sammasanam
translated: or else having comprehended all the remaining things rooted in that ,

original: ādibhūte rūpārammaṇe pavattatīti katvā āha “rūpārammaṇaṃ sammasitvā”ti. Ettha ca
analyzed: ādi bhūte rūpa ārammaṇe pavattati iti katvā āha rūpa ārammaṇam sammasitvā iti ettha ca
translated: he comprehends the materiality that is the object of the beginning, and he does so because the insight that has that as its object occurs at the beginning. Therefore it is said, “having comprehended the materiality that is the object of the beginning.” And here

original: nāmarūpapariggahādi sabbaṃ sammasanaṃ bhāvanāti veditabbā. Rūpārammaṇaṃ sammasitvāti
analyzed: nāma rūpa pariggaha ādi sabbam sammasanam bhāvanā ati veditabbā rūpa ārammaṇam sammasitvā ati
translated: and the rest beginning with “name-and-form” should be understood as the development of the contemplation of dissolution.🔽“Having contemplated the visible-data object”:

original: ca yathāvuttacakkhuviññāṇassa ārammaṇabhūtaṃ rūpārammaṇaṃ vuttaṃ, na yaṃ kiñci. Ārammaṇena
analyzed: ca yathā vutta cakkhu viññāṇassa ārammaṇa bhūtam rūpa ārammaṇam vuttam na yam kiñci ārammaṇena
translated: what is meant is that the visible-data object that is the object of the eye-consciousness stated in the way already given is what is meant, not just any object whatever.🔽For the visible-data object is what is shown by the contact.

original: hi cakkhusamphassaṃ dassetīti. Evaṃ “rūpārammaṇe uppannaṃ kilesa”nti etthāpi veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: hi cakkhu samphassam dasseti iti evam rūpa ārammaṇe uppannam kilesam ti ettha api veditabbam
translated: So too in the case of “The defilement that arises with visible data as its object” and so on.

original: Idaṃ phoṭṭhabbaṃ kiṃnissitanti cakkhudvāre viya yojanāya yathāsambhavaṃ āpodhātuyā aññamaññassa ca vasena mahābhūtanissitatā yojetabbā.
analyzed: idam phoṭṭhabbam kiṃnissitanti cakkhu dvāre viya yojanāya yathāsambhavam āpodhātuyā aññamaññassa ca vasena mahābhūta nissita tā yojetabbā
translated: “This tangible datum is supported by what? “ : the support by the great primaries of the earth element, etc., should be construed in the way already stated in the case of the eye door, that is to say, by the earth element, etc., and by the mutual dependence of the elements.🔽“A powerful condition” :

original: Jāti…pe… balavapaccayo hotīti yathāvuttānaṃ bhayato dissamānānaṃ jātiādīnaṃ balavapaccayabhāvena
analyzed: jāti pe balava paccayaḥ hoti iti yathāvuttānam bhayataḥ dissamānānam jāti ādīnam balava paccaya bhāvena
translated: the meaning is that he shows that birth, etc., which are seen to be fearful in the way already stated, are powerful conditions

original: tesaṃ bhayato dassanena sahajātassa manosamphassassa, tassa vā dassanassa dvārabhūtassa🔽bhavaṅgamanosamphassassa balavapaccayabhāvaṃ dasseti.
analyzed: tesam bhayataḥ dassanena sahajātassa manaḥ samphassassa tassa vā dassanassa dvāra bhūtassa 🔽bhavaṅga manaḥ samphassassa balava paccaya bhāvam dasseti
translated: for the mind-contact associated with them or for the life-continuum mind-contact, which is the door to the seeing of them.

original: Dhammārammaṇeti na pubbe vutte jātiādiārammaṇeva, atha kho sabbasmiṃ rāgādivatthubhūte
analyzed: dhamma ārammaṇā iti na pubbe vutte jāti ādi ārammaṇā iva atha kho sabbasmim rāga ādi vatthu bhūte
translated: Not only in the way already stated, namely, as the objective fields of birth, etc., but also in the way stated in the Abhidhamma as the objective fields of the six kinds of consciousness, that is, as the objective fields of the six kinds of consciousness beginning with eye-consciousness.

original: dhammārammaṇe. Vatthunissitanti ettha vedanādisaṅkhātassa dhammārammaṇekadesassa🔽pariggahamukhena dhammārammaṇapariggahaṃ dasseti.
analyzed: dhamma ārammaṇe vatthu nissitan ti ettha vedanā ādi saṅkhātassa dhamma ārammaṇa ekadesassa  pariggaha mukhena dhamma ārammaṇa pariggaham dasseti
translated: The words “in the way stated in the Abhidhamma” are stated in order to show that the objective fields of the six kinds of consciousness are not only the visible-data base, etc., but also the mental-data base.🔽The words “in the way stated in the Abhidhamma” are stated in order to show that the mental-data base is the objective field of the six kinds of consciousness.🔽The words “in the way stated in the Abhidhamma” are stated in order to show that the mental-data base is the objective field of the six kinds of consciousness.

original: Manosamphassoti viññāṇaṃ samphassassa kāraṇabhāvena gahitaṃ, tadeva attano phalasseva🔽phalabhāvena vattuṃ na yuttaṃ kāraṇaphalasaṅkarabhāvena sotūnaṃ sammohajanakattāti
analyzed: manaḥ samphasso ti viññāṇam samphassassa kāraṇa bhāvena gahitam tat eva attanaḥ phalassa iva  phala bhāvena vattum na yuttam kāraṇa phala saṅkara bhāvena sotūnam sammoha janaka ttā ati
translated: The words “in the way stated in the Abhidhamma” are stated in order to show that the mental-data base is the objective field of the six kinds of consciousness.🔽The words “in the way stated in the Abhidhamma” are stated in order to show that the mental-data base is the objective field of the six kinds of consciousness.🔽The words “in the way stated in the Abhidhamma” are stated in order to show that the mental-data base is the objective field of the six kinds of consciousness.🔽The words “in the way stated in the Abhidhamma” are stated in order to show that the mental-data base is the objective field of the six kinds of consciousness.🔽The words “in the way stated in the Abhidhamma” are stated in order to show that the mental-data base is the objective field of the six kinds of consciousness.🔽The words “in the way stated in the Abhidhamma” are stated in order to show that the mental-data base is the objective field of the six kinds of consciousness.🔽The words “in the way stated in the Abhidhamma” are stated in order to show that the mental-data base is the objective field of the six kinds of consciousness.

original: āha “na hi sakkā viññāṇaṃ manosamphassajanti niddisitu”nti, na pana viññāṇassa manosamphassena
analyzed: āha na hi sakkā viññāṇam manaḥ samphassa janti niddisitunti na pana viññāṇassa manaḥ samphassena
translated: The words “in the way stated in the Abhidhamma” are stated in order to show that the mental-data base is the objective field of the six kinds of consciousness.

original: sahajātabhāvassa abhāvā. Yasmā vā yathā “tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso”ti vacanato indriyavisayā🔽viya viññāṇampi phassassa visesapaccayo, na tathā phasso viññāṇassa, tasmā indriyavisayā
analyzed: sahajāta bhāvassa abhāvā vā yathā vacanataḥ indriya visayā 🔽viya viññāṇam pi phassassa visesa paccayaḥ na tathā phassaḥ viññāṇassa tasmai indriya visayā
translated: The words “in the way stated in the Abhidhamma” are stated in order to show that the mental-data base is the objective field of the six

original: viya viññāṇampi cakkhusamphassajādivacanaṃ na arahatīti cakkhusamphassajādibhāvo
analyzed: viya viññāṇam pi cakkhu samphassa ja ādi vacanam na arahati iti cakkhu samphassa ja ādi bhāvaḥ
translated: So it should be understood that the state of being arisen from eye-contact, etc.,

original: na katoti veditabbo.
analyzed: na kataḥ iti veditabbo
translated: is not attributed to it.

original: Abhidhammabhājanīyavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: abhidhammabhājanīya vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of the “subject for the Abhidhamma” is ended.

original: 3. Pañhapucchakavaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the questioner

original: 150. Cittuppādarūpavasena taṃ taṃ samudāyaṃ ekekaṃ dhammaṃ katvā “pañcapaṇṇāsa kāmāvacaradhamme”ti
analyzed: cittuppāda rūpa vasena tam tam samudāyam ekekam dhammam katvā pañcapaṇṇāsa kāmāvacara dhammā iti
translated: Having taken each of the various aggregates as a single state by way of the materiality that arises with consciousness, he says, “fifty-five states in the sense sphere.”

original: āha. Rajjantassātiādīsu rāgādayo chasu dvāresu sīlādayo ca pañca saṃvarā yathāsambhavaṃ
analyzed: āha rajjantassa ati ādīsu rāga ādayaḥ chasu dvāresu sīla ādayaḥ ca pañca saṃvarāḥ yathāsambhavam
translated: In the case of the words “one who is intent on passion,” etc., the passions, etc., and the five kinds of restraint beginning with virtue should be construed respectively with the six doors,

original: yojetabbā, sammasanaṃ pana manodvāre eva. Rūpārūpāvacaradhammesu abhijjhādomanassādiuppatti
analyzed: yojetabbā sammasanam pana manaḥ dvāre eva rūpa arūpāvacara dhammesu abhijjhā domanassa ādi uppatti
translated: but the surmounting should be construed only with the mind door. And since there is the arising of covetousness and grief, etc., in the case of states in the fine-material and immaterial spheres,

original: atthīti tato satisaṃvaro ñāṇavīriyasaṃvarā ca yathāyogaṃ yojetabbā. Pariggahavacanena
analyzed: atthi iti tatas sati saṃvaraḥ ñāṇa vīriya saṃvarā ca yathāyogam yojetabbā pariggaha vacanena
translated: the restraint of mindfulness and the restraint of knowledge and energy should be construed respectively as appropriate. By the words “and so on”

original: sammasanapaccavekkhaṇāni saṅgaṇhāti. Teyevāti cattāro khandhā vuttā.
analyzed: sammasana paccavekkhaṇāni saṅgaṇhāti teyeva ati cattāraḥ khandhāḥ vuttā
translated: he includes the surmounting and reviewing. By the words “just these three” he includes the four aggregates.

original: Samāne desitabbe desanāmattassa parivaṭṭanaṃ parivaṭṭo. Tīsupi parivaṭṭesu katthaci kiñci ūnaṃ adhikaṃ vā natthīti katvā āha “ekova paricchedo”ti.
analyzed: samāne desitabbe desanā mattassa parivaṭṭanam parivaṭṭo tīsu pi parivaṭṭesu katthaci kiñci ūnam adhikam vā natthi iti katvā āha ekaḥ iva paricchedaḥ ti
translated: The turning back of the teaching of what should be taught is the turning back. In the three turnings there is nothing less or more anywhere, so he said “one section only.”

original: Pañhapucchakavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: pañha pucchaka vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the questions is finished.

original: Khandhavibhaṅgavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: khandha vibhaṅga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the analysis of the aggregates is finished.

original: 2. Āyatanavibhaṅgo
analyzed: āyatana vibhaṅgaḥ
translated: The analysis of the sense-spheres

original: 1. Suttantabhājanīyavaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Suttantabhajanīya

original: 152. Visesatoti āyatana-saddattho viya asādhāraṇato cakkhādisaddatthatoti attho.
analyzed: visesataḥ ti āyatana saddatthaḥ viya asādhāraṇato cakkha ādi saddatthato ti attho
translated: In particular: the meaning of the word sense-sphere is, as it were, the meaning of the word eye, etc., in the sense of what is not shared in common.

original: Assādetīti cakkhati-saddo “madhuṃ cakkhati byañjanaṃ cakkhatī”ti rasasāyanattho atthīti
analyzed: assādeti iti cakkhati saddaḥ madhum cakkhati byañjanam cakkhati iti rasa sāyana atthaḥ atthi iti
translated: It relishes: the word cakkhati has the meaning of relishing, as in “he relishes honey” and “he relishes a cosmetic.”

original: tassa vasena atthaṃ vadati. “Cakkhuṃ kho, māgaṇḍiya, rūpārāmaṃ rūparataṃ rūpasammudita”nti🔽vacanato cakkhu rūpaṃ assādeti. Satipi sotādīnaṃ saddārammaṇādiratibhāve niruḷhattā
analyzed: tassa vasena attham vadati cakkhum kho māgaṇḍiya rūpa ārāmam rūpa ratam rūpa sammuditanti  vacanato cakkhu rūpam assādeti sati pi sota ādīnam sadda ārammaṇa ādi rati bhāve niruḷha ttā
translated: He states the meaning by way of that. “The eye, Magandiya, delights in visible forms, it takes pleasure in visible forms, it rejoices in visible forms” .🔽Therefore the eye relishes visible forms. Even though the ear, etc., delight in sound, etc., as objects,

original: cakkhumhiyeva cakkhu-saddo pavattati padumādīsu paṅkajādisaddā viyāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: cakkhumhi yeva cakkhu saddo pavattati paduma ādīsu paṅkaja ādi saddāḥ viya ati daṭṭhabbam
translated: the word eye occurs only in the eye because of its established usage, as the words “lotus” , etc., occur only in a lotus, etc.

original: Vibhāveti cāti saddalakkhaṇasiddhassa cakkhati-saddassa vasena atthaṃ vadati. Cakkhatīti
analyzed: vibhāvā iti ca ati sadda lakkhaṇa siddhassa cakkhati saddassa vasena attham vadati cakkhati iti
translated: Vibhāveti cāti attho ti. The meaning is that it illuminates by means of the word cakkhati, which is established by the characteristic of sound.

original: hi ācikkhati, abhibyattaṃ vadatīti attho. Nayanassa ca vadantassa viya samavisamavibhāvanameva🔽ācikkhananti katvā āha “vibhāveti cāti attho”ti. Anekatthattā vā dhātūnaṃ vibhāvanatthatā
analyzed: hi ācikkhati abhibyattam vadati iti atthaḥ nayanassa ca vadantassa viya sama visama vibhāvanam eva  ācikkhananti katvā āha vibhāveti ca ati atthaḥ ti aneka attha tā vā dhātūnam vibhāvana ttha tā
translated: For cakkhati means to show, to speak out clearly.🔽As if it were the speaker’s eye, it shows the even and uneven by means of the word cakkhati.

original: cakkhu-saddassa daṭṭhabbā. Rattaduṭṭhādikālesu kakaṇṭakarūpaṃ viya uddarūpaṃ viya
analyzed: cakkhu saddassa daṭṭhabbāḥ ratta duṭṭha ādi kālesu kakaṇṭaka rūpam viya udda rūpam viya
translated: Or the meaning of the word cakkhati should be seen as the meaning of illumination, because of the plurality of meanings of roots.

original: ca vaṇṇavikāraṃ āpajjamānaṃ rūpaṃ hadayaṅgatabhāvaṃ rūpayati rūpamiva pakāsaṃ karoti,🔽saviggahamiva katvā dassetīti attho. Vitthāraṇaṃ vā rūpa-saddassa attho, vitthāraṇañca
analyzed: ca vaṇṇa vikāram āpajjamānam rūpam hadayaṅgata bhāvam rūpayati rūpam iva pakāsam karoti  sa viggaham iva katvā dasseti iti atthaḥ vitthāraṇam vā rūpa saddassa atthaḥ vitthāraṇam ca
translated: Just as the form of a person becomes changed in colour at the time of passion, anger, etc., so the form that has reached the heart makes the form manifest, makes it appear as if it were form,🔽the meaning is that it shows it as if it were detached. Or the meaning of the word rūpa is extension,🔽and extension is manifestation. Therefore it is said: “It manifests.”

original: pakāsanamevāti āha “pakāsetī”ti. Anekatthattā vā dhātūnaṃ pakāsanatthoyeva rūpa-saddo
analyzed: pakāsanam eva iti āha pakāseti iti aneka attha ttā vā dhātūnam pakāsana atthaḥ yā iva rūpa saddaḥ
translated: Or the word rūpa has the meaning of manifestation only, because of the plurality of meanings of roots.

original: daṭṭhabbo, vaṇṇavācakassa rūpa-saddassa rūpayatīti nibbacanaṃ, rūpavācakassa ruppatīti ayaṃ viseso.
analyzed: daṭṭhabbaḥ vaṇṇa vācakassa rūpa saddassa rūpayati iti nibbacanam rūpa vācakassa ruppati iti ayam visesaḥ
translated: The definition of the word rūpa, which signifies colour, is “it colours” . The definition of the word rūpa, which signifies materiality, is “it is molested” . This is the difference between them.🔽The word “is said” is taken to mean “is spoken” . And the word “sound” is not only

original: Udāharīyatīti vuccatīti-atthe vacanameva gahitaṃ siyā, na ca vacana-saddoyeva ettha
analyzed: udāharīyati iti vuccati iti atthe vacanam eva gahitam siyā na ca ettha
translated: sound itself,

original: saddo, atha kho sabbopi sotaviññeyyoti sappatīti sakehi paccayehi sappīyati sotaviññeyyabhāvaṃ🔽gamīyatīti attho. Sūcayatīti attano vatthuṃ gandhavasena apākaṭaṃ “idaṃ sugandhaṃ🔽duggandha”nti pakāseti, paṭicchannaṃ vā pupphādivatthuṃ “ettha pupphaṃ atthi campakādi,
analyzed: saddaḥ atha kho sabbaḥ api sota viññeyyaḥ ti sappati iti sakehi paccayehi sappīyati sota viññeyya bhāvam  gamīyati iti sūcayati iti vatthum gandha vasena apākaṭam idam sugandham  duggandhanti pakāseti paṭicchannam vā puppha ādi vatthum ettha puppham atthi campaka ādi
translated: but also everything cognizable by the ear. The meaning is that it is “tasted” by its own conditions, it becomes cognizable by the ear.

original: phalamatthi ambādī”ti pesuññaṃ karontaṃ viya hotīti attho. Rasaggahaṇamūlakattā āhārajjhoharaṇassa
analyzed: phalam atthi amba ādi iti pesuññam karontam viya hoti iti attho rasa ggahaṇa mūlaka ttā āhāra jjhoharaṇassa
translated: It “indicates” its own object, which is not evident as odour, by means of odour, as if it were saying, “This is a good odour, this is a bad odour.” Or the meaning is that it is as if it were saying, “There is a flower here, campaka, etc.,” or “There is a fruit here, mango, etc.,” and thus making known a concealed object such as a flower.

original: jīvitahetumhi āhārarase ninnatāya jīvitaṃ avhāyatīti jivhā vuttā niruttilakkhaṇena.
analyzed: jīvita hetumhi āhāra rase ninna tāya jīvitam avhāyati iti jivhā vuttā nirutti lakkhaṇena
translated: The tongue is called jivhā by the characteristic of etymology because it is bent for the sake of the grasping of taste, and because of the bending towards the taste of nutriment as the cause of life.

original: Kucchitānaṃ sāsavadhammānaṃ āyoti visesena kāyo vutto anuttariyahetubhāvaṃ anāgacchantesu
analyzed: kucchitānam sa āsava dhammānam āyo ti visesena kāyaḥ vuttaḥ anuttariya hetu bhāvam an āgacchantesu
translated: “The source of what is corruptible” is said specifically of the body because it is the cause of the unsurpassed,

original: kāmarāganidānakammajanitesu kāmarāgassa ca visesapaccayesu ghānajivhākāyesu kāyassa
analyzed: kāma rāga nidāna kamma janitesu kāma rāgassa ca visesa paccayesu ghāna jivhā kāyesu kāyassa
translated: and because the nose, tongue, and body, which are the source of sensual desire and the special conditions for the kamma that is born of sensual desire,

original: visesatarasāsavapaccayattā. Tena hi phoṭṭhabbaṃ assādentā sattā methunampi sevanti.
analyzed: visesa tara sa āsava paccaya ttā tena hi phoṭṭhabbam assādentā sattāḥ methunam pi sevanti
translated: are the special conditions for the corruptions of the body. For it is through the body that beings experience tangible object and engage in sexual intercourse.

original: Uppattidesoti uppattikāraṇanti attho. Kāyindriyavatthukā vā cattāro khandhā balavakāmāsavādihetubhāvato🔽visesena “sāsavā”ti vuttā, tesaṃ uppajjanaṭṭhānanti attho. Attano lakkhaṇaṃ dhārayantīti🔽ye visesalakkhaṇena āyatanasaddaparā vattabbā, te cakkhādayo tathā vuttāti aññe manogocarabhūtā
analyzed: uppatti deso ti uppatti kāraṇanti attho kāyindriya vatthukāḥ vā cattāro khandhāḥ balavaka āma āsava ādi hetu bhāvato  visesena sāsavā ti vuttā tesam uppajjana ṭṭhānanti attho attanaḥ lakkhaṇam dhārayanti iti  ye visesa lakkhaṇena āyatana sadda parā vattabbā te cakkha ādayaḥ tathā vuttā ati aññe manaḥ gocara bhūtā
translated: “The source of arising” means the cause of arising. Or alternatively, the four aggregates that are the physical basis of the body faculty are said to be “corruptible” because they are the cause of the strong corruptions of sensual desire, etc.,🔽and they are the source of the arising of those aggregates. The meaning is: they are the place of their arising.🔽“Bearing their own characteristics” means that the eye, etc., which should be called “sense bases” in the sense of their specific characteristics, are so called. But other dhammas that are the objects of the mind are brought under the one sense base of mental objects by their general characteristic only.

original: dhammā sāmaññalakkhaṇeneva ekāyatanattaṃ upanetvā vuttā. Oḷārikavatthārammaṇamananasaṅkhātehi
analyzed: dhammā sāmañña lakkhaṇena iva eka āyatana ttam upanetvā vuttāḥ oḷārika vattha ārammaṇa manana saṅkhātehi
translated: The sense bases are said to be “gross” because they are the objects of the grosser kinds of consciousness that occur in the sense sphere.

original: visayavisayibhāvehi purimāni pākaṭānīti tathā apākaṭā ca aññe manogocarā na attano
analyzed: visaya visayi bhāvehi purimāni pākaṭāni iti tathā apākaṭā ca aññe manogocarāḥ na attano
translated: The first are obvious because of the objective-field-and-object relation. And the others, which are not obvious, are not the mental-object-field of the mind.

original: sabhāvaṃ na dhārentīti imassatthassa dīpanattho dhamma-saddoti.
analyzed: sabhāvam na dhārenti iti imassa atthassa dīpana tthaḥ dhamma saddaḥ ti
translated: The word “idea” is the word for the purpose of illuminating this meaning: they do not bear their own individual essence.

original: Vāyamantīti attano kiccaṃ karonticceva attho. Imasmiñca atthe āyatanti etthāti āyatananti
analyzed: vāyamanti iti attanaḥ kiccam imasmin ca atthe āyatanti ettha ati
translated: “ Functioning” means only that they perform their own function. And in this meaning, “in the sense of extending” is “sense- sphere” .

original: adhikaraṇattho āyatana-saddo, dutiyatatiyesu kattuattho. Te cāti cittacetasikadhamme.
analyzed: adhikaraṇa atthaḥ āyatana saddaḥ dutiya tatiyesu kattu atthaḥ te ca ati citta cetasika dhamme
translated: The word “sense-sphere” has the meaning of “basis” , and in the second and third it has the meaning of “doer” . Those are the ideas of consciousness and its concomitants.

original: Te hi taṃtaṃdvārārammaṇesu āyanti āgacchanti pavattantīti āyāti. Vitthārentīti pubbe🔽anuppannattā līnāni apākaṭāni pubbantato uddhaṃ pasārenti pākaṭāni karonti uppādentīti attho.
analyzed: te hi taṃ taṃ dvāra ārammaṇesu āyanti āgacchanti pavattanti iti āya ati vitthārenti iti pubbe  anuppanna ttā līnāni apākaṭāni pubbantataḥ uddham pasārenti pākaṭāni karonti uppādenti iti atthaḥ
translated: For they extend, come, occur, in the various doors and objects, thus they are sense-spheres .🔽They extend, spread out, what was previously unarisen, contracted, not obvious, from the past, thus the meaning is that they cause it to arise, make it obvious.🔽“ In the sense of a place for the descent of the floods” , etc., is stated in order to show the meaning of the word “sense-sphere” in the sense of a place for the descent of the floods.

original: Ruḷhīvasena āyatana-saddassatthaṃ vattuṃ “apicā”tiādi āraddhaṃ. Taṃ nissitattāti
analyzed: ruḷhī vasena āyatana saddassa attham vattum apica atiādi āraddham tam nissita ttā ti
translated: “ Because they are dependent on it” :

original: ettha mano manoviññāṇādīnaṃ cittacetasikānaṃ nissayapaccayo na hotīti tassa nesaṃ
analyzed: ettha manaḥ manaḥ viññāṇa ādīnam citta cetasikānam nissaya paccayaḥ na hoti iti tassa na īsam
translated: the mind is not a support condition for the consciousness and its concomitants consisting of the mind-element, the mind-consciousness element, etc.; therefore it is not their sense-sphere.

original: dvārabhāvo nissayabhāvoti daṭṭhabbo. Atthatoti vacanatthato, na vacanīyatthato. Vacanattho🔽hettha vutto “cakkhatī”tiādinā, na vacanīyattho “yaṃ cakkhu catunnaṃ mahābhūtānaṃ
analyzed: dvāra bhāvaḥ nissaya bhāvaḥ ti daṭṭhabbaḥ atthato ti vacana tthataḥ na vacanīya tthataḥ vacana ttho  ha ittha vuttaḥ cakkhati iti ādinā na vacanīya atthaḥ yam cakkhu catunnam mahābhūtānam
translated: As to meaning: as to the meaning of the words, not as to the meaning of the expression. The meaning of the words

original: upādāya pasādo”tiādinā viyāti.
analyzed: upādāya pasāda ūti ādinā viyāti
translated: is stated here by the words “sees,” etc., not the meaning of the expression, as in the passage “The eye is that which is sensitivity dependent on the four great essentials” ,🔽etc.

original: Tāvatvatoti anūnādhikabhāvaṃ dasseti. Tattha dvādasāyatanavinimuttassa kassaci dhammassa🔽abhāvā adhikabhāvato codanā natthi, salakkhaṇadhāraṇaṃ pana sabbesaṃ sāmaññalakkhaṇanti🔽ūnacodanā sambhavatīti dassento āha “cakkhādayopi hī”tiādi. Asādhāraṇanti cakkhuviññāṇādīnaṃ
analyzed: tāva tvatā iti anūna adhika bhāvam dasseti tattha dvādasa āyatana vinimuttassa kassaci dhammassa  abhāvā adhika bhāvato codanā natthi salakkhaṇa dhāraṇam pana sabbesam sāmañña lakkhaṇan ti  ūna codanā sambhavati iti dassentaḥ āha cakkha ādayaḥ api hi itiādi asādhāraṇan ti cakkhu viññāṇa ādīnam
translated: As to extent: he shows the absence of excess and deficiency. Herein, since there is no state whatever that is not included in the twelve bases, there is no occasion for excess;🔽but since the bearing of its own characteristics is common to all, there is occasion for deficiency. Showing that, he says, “For the eye, etc., too” , etc.🔽As to the uncommon: the eye, etc., are uncommon to the eye-consciousness, etc.,

original: asādhāraṇaṃ. Satipi asādhāraṇārammaṇabhāve cakkhādīnaṃ dvārabhāvena gahitattā dhammāyatane🔽aggahaṇaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Dvārārammaṇabhāvehi vā asādhāraṇataṃ sandhāya “asādhāraṇa”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: asādhāraṇam sati pi asādhāraṇa ārammaṇa bhāve cakkha ādīnam dvāra bhāvena gahita ttā dhamma āyatane 🔽aggahaṇam daṭṭhabbam dvāra ārammaṇa bhāvehi vā asādhāraṇatam sandhāya asādhāraṇam ti vuttam
translated: because they are the door. The meaning should be regarded thus: although the eye, etc., are the uncommon object of the eye-consciousness, etc., they are not included in the base of mental data because they are included in the base of the eye, etc., as door. Or alternatively, the words “as to the uncommon” are said with reference to the uncommonness as to being the door and as to being the object.

original: Yebhuyyasahuppattiādīhi uppattikkamādiayutti yojetabbā. Ajjhattikesu hīti etena ajjhattikabhāvena
analyzed: yebhuyya sahuppatti ādīhi uppatti kkama ādi ayutti yojetabbā ajjhattikesu hi iti etena ajjhattika bhāvena
translated: The order of arising, etc., should be construed with the order of teaching.🔽By the words “among the internal” he shows that the internal should be taught first because of their internal nature

original: visayibhāvena ca ajjhattikānaṃ paṭhamaṃ desetabbataṃ dasseti. Tesu hi paṭhamaṃ desetabbesu🔽pākaṭattā paṭhamataraṃ cakkhāyatanaṃ desitanti. Tato ghānāyatanādīnīti ettha bahūpakārattābhāvena🔽cakkhusotehi purimataraṃ adesetabbāni saha vattuṃ asakkuṇeyyattā ekena kamena desetabbānīti
analyzed: visayi bhāvena ca ajjhattikānam paṭhamam desetabba tam dasseti tesu hi paṭhamam desetabbesu  pākaṭa ttā paṭhamataram cakkha āyatanam tatas ghāna āyatana ādīni iti ettha bahu upakāra ttā bhāvena  cakkhu sotehi purimataram a desetabbāni saha vattum a sakkuṇeyya ttā ekena kamena desetabbāni iti
translated: and because of their being the subjects. For among those that should be taught first,🔽the eye-base is taught first because it is the most obvious.🔽Then the nose-base, etc., are taught together by the nose-base, etc., because they cannot be taught earlier than the eye and ear-bases due to the absence of any greater usefulness, and because they cannot be taught separately due to the impossibility of teaching them in one act.

original: ghānādikkamena desitānīti adhippāyo. Aññathāpi hi desitesu na na sakkā codetuṃ, na
analyzed: ghāna ādi kkamena desitāni iti adhippāyaḥ aññathā api hi desitesu na na sakkā codetum na
translated: This is the intention. For if they were taught in another way, they could not be criticized, and they could not be taught without being taught.

original: ca sakkā sodhetabbāni na desetunti. Gocaro visayo etassāti gocaravisayo, mano. Kassa🔽pana gocaro etassa visayoti? Cakkhādīnaṃ pañcannampi. Viññāṇuppattikāraṇavavatthānatoti
analyzed: ca sakkā sodhetabbāni na desetunti gocaraḥ visayaḥ etassa ati gocara visayaḥ manaḥ kassa  pana gocaraḥ etassa visayaḥ ti cakkha ādīnam pañcannam pi viññāṇa uppatti kāraṇa vavatthānato ti
translated: The mind has the object-field as its domain.🔽But whose domain is its object-field? It is the domain of the five, the eye, etc.

original: etena ca cakkhādianantaraṃ rūpādivacanassa kāraṇamāha.
analyzed: etena ca cakkha ādi anantaram rūpa ādi vacanassa kāraṇam āha
translated: By this he shows the reason for the statement of the visible data, etc., immediately after the eye, etc.

original: Paccayabhedo kammādibhedo. Nirayādiko apadādigatinānākaraṇañca gatibhedo. Hatthiassādiko🔽khattiyādiko ca nikāyabhedo. Taṃtaṃsattasantānabhedo puggalabhedo. Yā ca cakkhādīnaṃ🔽vatthūnaṃ anantabhedatā vuttā, soyeva hadayavatthussa ca bhedo hoti. Tato manāyatanassa🔽anantappabhedatā yojetabbā dukkhāpaṭipadādito ārammaṇādhipatiādibhedato ca. Imasmiṃ🔽suttantabhājanīye vipassanā vuttāti vipassanupagamanañca viññāṇaṃ gahetvā ekāsītibhedatā🔽manāyatanassa vuttā niddesavasena. Nīlaṃ nīlasseva sabhāgaṃ, aññaṃ visabhāgaṃ, evaṃ🔽kusalasamuṭṭhānādibhedesu yojetabbaṃ. Tebhūmakadhammārammaṇavasenāti pubbe vuttaṃ
analyzed: paccaya bhedo kamma ādi bhedaḥ niraya ādiko gati bhedaḥ hatthi assa ādiko  khattiya ādiko ca nikāya bhedo taṃ taṃ satta santāna bhedo puggala bhedaḥ yā ca cakkha ādīnam  vatthūnam ananta bheda tā vuttā sā yā iva hadaya vatthussa ca bhedaḥ hoti tatas mana āyatanassa  ananta ppabheda tā yojetabbā dukkha apaṭipada āditaḥ ārammaṇa adhipati ādi bhedato ca imasmin  suttanta bhājanīye vipassanā vuttā iti vipassana upagamanam ca viññāṇam gahetvā ekāsīti bheda tā  manāyatanassa vuttā niddesa vasena nīlam nīlassa iva sa bhāgam aññam visabhāgam evam  kusala samuṭṭhāna ādi bhedesu yojetabbam tebhūmaka dhamma ārammaṇa vasena āti pubbe vuttam
translated: The analysis of conditions is the analysis into kamma, etc.; the analysis of destiny is the analysis of the destinies as hell, etc., and as non-percipient beings, etc.; the analysis of species is the analysis of species as elephant, horse, etc., and as warrior, brahmin, etc.; the analysis of person is the analysis of the individualities of the various continua of beings; and the analysis of the physical basis is the analysis of the eye, etc., into an infinite number of different kinds. The analysis of the physical basis is the analysis of the heart- basis into an infinite number of different kinds. The analysis of the mind-base should be construed with the infinite analysis of the heart-basis, with the infinite analysis of the physical basis, with the infinite analysis of the object, and with the infinite analysis of the mode of progress, etc., and with the infinite analysis of the object, etc., as object. In this sutta, which is the vessel for the teaching, insight is stated. And the infinite analysis of the mind-base is stated by way of definition, taking cognizance of the consciousness that is to be penetrated by insight. Blue is similar to blue, and dissimilar to the other . So too with the profitable, etc., kinds. By means of the three-plane states as object: this is said with reference to the profitable, etc., kinds.

original: cakkhādivajjaṃ dhammārammaṇaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ.
analyzed: cakkhu ādi vajjam dhamma ārammaṇam sandhāya vuttam
translated: The analysis of conditions is the analysis into kamma, etc.; the analysis of destiny is the analysis of destiny into hell, etc., and of the plane into the non-plane, etc.; the analysis of species is the analysis of species into elephant, horse, etc., and into warrior, brahmin, etc.; the analysis of individual is the analysis of individual into the individual of such and such a being’s continuum; and the analysis of the physical basis is the analysis of the physical basis of the eye, etc., which has already been stated as having an infinite number of divisions. The analysis of the mind-base should be construed as having an infinite number of divisions because of the physical basis of the heart, and because of the different kinds of painful and easy progress, etc., and because of the different kinds of object-predominance, etc. In this sutta-discourse the insight has been stated. And the mind-base has been stated as having eighty-nine divisions by way of indication, taking the consciousness that is the object of insight. Blue is similar to blue only, and dissimilar to any other. Likewise it should be construed in the case of the different kinds of profitable, etc., origination. By way of the states of the three planes: this was said with reference to the states of the eye, etc., which have already been stated as having an infinite number of divisions by way of the object, the state, the aspect, and the mode of progress, etc., of the states of the three planes.

original: Saparipphandakiriyāvasena īhanaṃ īhā. Cintanavasena byāpārakaraṇaṃ byāpāro. Tattha🔽byāpāraṃ dassento āha “na hi cakkhu rūpādīnaṃ evaṃ hotī”ti. Īhaṃ dassento āha “na🔽ca tānī”tiādi. Ubhayampi pana īhā ca hoti byāpāro cāti uppaṭipāṭivacanaṃ. Dhammatāvāti🔽sabhāvova, kāraṇasamatthatā vā. Īhābyāpārarahitānaṃ dvārādibhāvo dhammatā. Imasmiñca
analyzed: sa paripphanda kiriyā vasena īhanam īhā cintana vasena byāpāra karaṇam tattha  byāpāram dassentaḥ āha na hi cakkhu rūpa ādīnam evam hoti iti īham dassentaḥ āha na  ca tāni itiādi ubhayam pi pana īhā ca hoti byāpāro ca ati uppaṭi pāṭi vacanam  kāraṇa samattha tā vā īhā byāpāra rahitānam dvāra ādi bhāvaḥ dhamma tā imasmin ca

original: atthe yanti etassa yasmāti attho. Purimasmiṃ sambhavanavisesanaṃ yaṃ-saddo. “Suñño🔽gāmoti kho, bhikkhave, channetaṃ ajjhattikānaṃ āyatanānaṃ adhivacana”nti vacanato🔽suññagāmo viya daṭṭhabbāni. Annapānasamohitanti gahite suññagāme yaññadeva bhājanaṃ🔽parāmasīyati, taṃ taṃ rittakaṃyeva parāmasīyati, evaṃ dhuvādibhāvena gahitāni upaparikkhiyamānāni
analyzed: atthe yanti etassa yasmā ati atthaḥ purimasmin sambhavana visesanam yaṃsaddaḥ suññaḥ 🔽gāmaḥ iti kho bhikkhave channa itam ajjhattikānam āyatanānam adhivacananti vacanataḥ 🔽suñña gāmaḥ viya daṭṭhabbāni anna pāna samohitanti gahite suñña gāme yaññadeva bhājanam 🔽parāmasīyati tam tam parāmasīyati evam dhuva ādi bhāvena gahitāni upaparikkhiyamānāni
translated: The “seeking” is the seeking by way of the act of seeking. The “perplexity” is the perplexity by way of the act of perplexity. The “reflection” is the reflection by way of the act of reflection. The “investigation” is the investigation by way of the act of investigation. The “discernment” is the discernment by way of the act of discernment. The “consideration” is the consideration by way of the act of consideration. The “apprehending” is the apprehending by way of the act of apprehending. The “investigation” is the investigation by way of the act of investigation. The “inquiry” is the inquiry by way of the act of inquiry. The “examination” is the examination by way of the act of examination. The “reflection” is the reflection by way of the act of reflection. The “discernment” is the discernment by way of the act of discernment. The “consideration” is the consideration by way of the act of consideration. The “apprehending” is the apprehending by way of the act of apprehending. The “investigation” is the investigation by way of the act of investigation. The “inquiry” is the inquiry by way of the act of inquiry. The “examination” is the examination by way of the act of examination. The “reflection” is the reflection by way of the act of reflection. The “discernment” is the discernment by way of the act of discernment. The “consideration” is the consideration by way of the act of consideration. The “apprehending” is the apprehending by way of the act of apprehending. The “investigation” is the investigation by way of the act of investigation. The “inquiry” is the inquiry by way of the act of inquiry. The “examination” is the examination by way of the act of examination. The “reflection” is the reflection by way of the act of reflection.

original: rittakāneva etāni dissantīti. Cakkhādidvāresu abhijjhādomanassuppādakabhāvena rūpādīni🔽cakkhādīnaṃ abhighātakānīti vuttāni. Ahisusumārapakkhikukkurasiṅgālamakkaṭā cha pāṇakā.
analyzed: rittakāni eva etāni dissanti iti cakkha ādi dvāresu abhijjhā domanassa uppādaka bhāvena rūpa ādīni  cakkha ādīnam abhighātakāni iti vuttāni ahi susumāra pakkhi kukkura siṅgāla makkaṭā cha pāṇakā
translated: they are seen to be empty.🔽The visible-data base, etc., are called “the assailants of the eye, etc.,” because they are the cause of the arising of covetousness and grief in the eye, etc., as their respective doors.🔽The six animals are the snake, the scorpion, the centipede, the dog, the jackal, and the monkey.

original: Visamabilākāsagāmasusānavanāni tesaṃ gocarā. Tattha visamādiajjhāsayehi cakkhādīhi
analyzed: visama bila ākāsagāma susāna vanāni tesam gocarā tattha cakkha ādīhi
translated: The uneven places, the tree stumps, the village, the charnel ground, and the forest are their respective haunts. Herein, because of the uneven places, etc., as the respective natures of the eye, etc.,

original: visamabhāvabilākāsagāmasusānasannissitasadisupādinnadhammavanabhāvehi abhiramitattā
analyzed: visama bhāva bila ākāsa gāma susāna sannissita sadis upādinna dhamma vana bhāvehi abhiramita ttā
translated: and because of the delight in the visible-data, etc., as the respective states of the haunts of the uneven places, the tree stumps, the village, the charnel ground, and the forest,

original: rūpādīnampi visamādisadisatā yojetabbā.
analyzed: rūpa ādīnam pi visama ādi sadisa tā yojetabbā
translated: the visible data, etc., should be construed as the uneven places, etc.

original: Hutvā abhāvaṭṭhenāti idaṃ itaresaṃ catunnaṃ ākārānaṃ saṅgahakattā visuṃ vuttaṃ. Hutvā
analyzed: hutvā abhāva ṭṭhena ati idam itaresam catunnam ākārānam saṅgahaka ttā visum vuttam hutvā
translated: “By burning away, by non-existence”: this is mentioned separately because it includes the other four aspects.

original: abhāvākāro eva hi uppādavayattākārādayoti. Tattha hutvāti etena purimantavivittatāpubbakaṃ
analyzed: abhāva ākāraḥ eva hi uppāda vayatta ākāra ādayaḥ ti tattha hutvā iti etena purimanta vivitta tā pubbakam
translated: For the aspect of non-existence by burning away is the same as the aspects of arising, of fall, and of change in and out.🔽Herein, by “burning away” he shows the presence in the middle preceded by the absence before;

original: majjhe vijjamānataṃ dasseti, taṃ vatvā abhāvavacanena majjhe vijjamānatāpubbakaṃ,
analyzed: majjhe vijjamāna tam dasseti tam vatvā abhāva vacanena majjhe vijjamāna tā pubbakam
translated: and by the word “non-existence” he shows the absence at the end preceded by the presence in the middle.

original: aparante avijjamānataṃ, ubhayenapi sadā abhāvo aniccalakkhaṇanti dasseti. Sabhāvavijahanaṃ
analyzed: aparante avijjamāna tam ubhayena api sadā abhāvaḥ anicca lakkhaṇam ti dasseti sabhāva vijahanam
translated: and non-existence in the future. By both he shows the characteristic of impermanence as the state of never being in both.

original: vipariṇāmo, jarābhaṅgehi vā parivattanaṃ, santānavikārāpatti vā. Sadā abhāvepi ciraṭṭhānaṃ🔽siyāti taṃnivāraṇatthaṃ “tāvakālikato”ti āha. Uppādavayaññathattarahitaṃ niccaṃ,
analyzed: vipariṇāmaḥ jarā bhaṅgehi vā parivattanam santāna vikāra āpatti vā sadā abhāve pi cira ṭṭhānam  siyā iti tad nivāraṇa attham āha uppāda vayaññathatta rahitam niccam
translated: The alteration of the individual essence is the change of the individual essence, or the turning away of the ageing and dissolution, or the occurrence of alteration in the continuity.🔽Although there is never any existence, there is a state of long duration.🔽So he says ‘for a time’ in order to preclude that. It is permanent in the sense of being devoid of arising, dissolution, and alteration.

original: na itarathāti niccapaṭikkhepato aniccaṃ, niccapaṭipakkhatoti adhippāyo.🔽Jātidhammatādīhi aniṭṭhatā paṭipīḷanaṃ. Paṭipīḷanaṭṭhenāti ca yassa taṃ pavattati,
analyzed: na itarathā ti nicca paṭikkhepataḥ aniccam nicca paṭipakkhato ti adhippāyaḥ  jāti dhamma tā ādīhi aniṭṭha tā paṭipīḷanam paṭipīḷana ṭṭhena ati ca yassa tam pavattati
translated: It is impermanent in the sense of the opposite of that, is the meaning.🔽The state of being undesirable owing to the dhamma of birth, etc., is affliction. And the meaning is that it is in the sense of afflicting that it is impermanent, either by afflicting the person in whom it occurs,

original: taṃ puggalaṃ paṭipīḷanato, sayaṃ vā jarādīhi paṭipīḷanattāti attho. Parittaṭṭhitikassapi
analyzed: tam puggalam paṭipīḷanataḥ sayam vā jarā ādīhi attho paritta ṭṭhitikassa pi
translated: or by its own ageing, etc., afflicting it.🔽Although it lasts for a limited time,

original: attano vijjamānakkhaṇe uppādādīhi abhiṇhaṃ sampaṭipīḷanattā “abhiṇhasampaṭipīḷanato”ti
analyzed: attanaḥ vijjamāna kkhaṇe uppāda ādīhi abhiṇham sampaṭipīḷana ttā abhiṇha sampaṭipīḍana to ti
translated: it is impermanent in the sense of being frequently afflicted by the arising, etc., in its own presence. So he says ‘in the sense of being frequently afflicted’🔽in order to distinguish the former general characteristic. It is pain in the sense of afflicting the person,

original: purimaṃ sāmaññalakkhaṇaṃ visesetvā vadati, puggalassa pīḷanato dukkhamaṃ. Sukhapaṭipakkhabhāvato
analyzed: purimam sāmañña lakkhaṇam visesetvā vadati puggalassa pīḷanataḥ dukkhamam sukha paṭipakkha bhāvato
translated: It is pain in the sense of being the opposite of pleasure.

original: dukkhaṃ sukhaṃ paṭikkhipati nivāreti, dukkhavacanaṃ vā atthato sukhaṃ paṭikkhipatīti
analyzed: dukkham sukham paṭikkhipati nivāreti dukkha vacanam vā atthataḥ sukham paṭikkhipati iti
translated: He rejects, he denies, suffering, or the word “suffering” in the sense of what is to be denied.

original: āha “sukhapaṭikkhepato”ti.
analyzed: āha sukha paṭikkhepato ti
translated: So it is said: “Because it denies suffering.”

original: Natthi etassa vasavattanako, nāpi idaṃ vasavattanakanti avasavattanakaṃ, attano parasmiṃ🔽parassa ca attani vasavattanabhāvo vā vasavattanakaṃ, taṃ etassa natthīti avasavattanakaṃ,🔽avasavattanakassa avasavattanako vā attho sabhāvo avasavattanakaṭṭho, idañca sāmaññalakkhaṇaṃ.
analyzed: na atthi etassa vasavattanakaḥ na api idam vasavattanakam ti a vasavattanakam attanaḥ parasmin  parassa ca attani vasavattana bhāvaḥ vā vasavattanakam tam etassa natthi iti a vasavattanakam  avasavattanakassa avasavattanakaḥ vā attho sabhāvaḥ avasavattanakaṭṭhaḥ idam ca sāmañña lakkhaṇam
translated: It is not subject to his control, nor is it a state of being subject to control.🔽Or the meaning of “not subject to his control” is the individual essence of what is not subject to control. And this is the general characteristic of the state of being a recluse.

original: Tenāti parassa attani vasavattanākārena suññaṃ. Imasmiñca atthe suññatoti etasseva
analyzed: tena ati parassa attani vasa vattana ākārena suññam imasmin ca atthe etassa iva
translated: “By that”: empty of the state of being a recluse. And in this meaning the word “empty” is a specification of “not subject to his control.”

original: visesanaṃ “assāmikato”ti. Atha vā “yasmā vā etaṃ…pe… mā pāpuṇātū”ti evaṃ cintayamānassa
analyzed: visesanam assāmikato ti atha vā yasmai vā etaṃpe mā pāpuṇātu uti evam cintayamānassa
translated: Or alternatively, “since this is not subject to his control” can be interpreted as follows: when someone thinks, “Let this not happen to me! Let me not come to this!”

original: kassaci tīsu ṭhānesu vasavattanabhāvo natthi, suññaṃ taṃ tena attanoyeva vasavattanākārenāti
analyzed: kassaci tīsu ṭhānesu vasa vattana bhāvaḥ natthi suññam tam tena attanoyā iva vasa vattana ākārena ati
translated: in any of the three cases, he is not subject to control in any of the three cases. It is empty of the state of being subject to control by himself.

original: attho. Na idaṃ kassaci kāmakāriyaṃ, nāpi etassa kiñci kāmakāriyaṃ atthīti akāmakāriyaṃ.
analyzed: attho na idam kassaci kāmakāriyam na api etassa kiñci kāmakāriyam atthi iti akāmakāriyam
translated: It is not the case that this is for the sake of anyone’s desire, nor is it the case that anything is for the sake of its desire, thus it is not for the sake of desire.

original: Etena avasavattanatthaṃ visesetvā dasseti.
analyzed: etena avasa vattana attham visesetvā dasseti
translated: By this he shows by distinguishing it, for the purpose of non-domination.

original: Vibhavagati vināsagamanaṃ. Santatiyaṃ bhavantaruppattiyeva bhavasaṅkantigamanaṃ.
analyzed: vibhava gati vināsa gamanam santatiyam bhavantar uppattiyā iva bhava saṅkanti gamanam
translated: The state of destruction is the state of going to destruction. The state of going to the continuity of existence is the state of going to the continuity of existence.

original: Santatiyā yathāpavattākāravijahanaṃ pakatibhāvavijahanaṃ. “Cakkhu anicca”nti vutte
analyzed: santatiyāḥ yathā pavatta ākāra vijahanam pakati bhāva vijahanam cakkhu aniccanti vutte
translated: The state of abandoning the mode of appearance in the continuity is the state of abandoning the natural state. When it is said: “The eye is impermanent,”

original: cakkhuanicca-saddānaṃ ekatthattā aniccānaṃ sesadhammānampi cakkhubhāvo āpajjatīti
analyzed: cakkhu anicca saddānam ekattha ttā aniccānam sesa dhammānam pi cakkhu bhāvaḥ āpajjati iti
translated: because of the single meaning of the words “eye” and “impermanent,” the state of the eye is also subject to the impermanent remaining dhammas.

original: etissā codanāya nivāraṇatthaṃ visesasāmaññalakkhaṇavācakānañca saddānaṃ ekadesasamudāyabodhanavisesaṃ
analyzed: etissā codanāya nivāraṇa attham visesa sāmañña lakkhaṇa vācakānam ca saddānam eka desa samudāya bodhana visesam
translated: In order to prevent this objection, in order to show the distinction in the teaching of the single collection of words which express the general and specific characteristics,

original: dīpetuṃ “apicā”tiādimāha.🔽Kiṃ dassitanti vipassanācāraṃ kathentena kiṃ lakkhaṇaṃ dassitanti adhippāyo. “Katamā
analyzed: api ca ati ādim āha  kim dassitanti vipassanā ācāram kathentena kim lakkhaṇam dassitanti adhippāyaḥ katamā
translated: he said “Moreover,” etc.

original: cānanda, anattasaññā? Idhānanda, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato
analyzed: ca ānanda anatta saññā idha ānanda bhikkhu arañña gataḥ vā rukkha mūla gataḥ vā suññāgāra gataḥ
translated: What is shown? The intention is: when speaking of the practice of insight, what characteristic is shown? “What, Ānanda, is the perception of non-self? Here, Ānanda, a monk, having gone to the forest, to the foot of a tree, or to an empty place,

original: vā iti paṭisañcikkhati ‘cakkhu anattā’ti…pe… ‘dhammā anattā’ti. Iti imesu chasu ajjhattikabāhiresu🔽āyatanesu anattānupassī viharatī”ti avisesesu āyatanesu anattānupassanā vuttāti kāraṇabhūtānaṃ🔽cakkhādīnaṃ, phalabhūtānañca cakkhuviññāṇādīnaṃ kāraṇaphalamattatāya anattatāya anattalakkhaṇavibhāvanatthāya🔽āyatanadesanāti āha “dvādasannaṃ…pe… anattalakkhaṇa”nti. Yadipi aniccadukkhalakkhaṇāni
analyzed: vā iti paṭisañcikkhati cakkhu anatta atipe dhammā anatta ati iti imesu chasu ajjhattika bāhiresu  āyatanesu anatta anupassī viharati iti avisesesu āyatanesu anatta anupassanā vuttā ati kāraṇa bhūtānam  cakkha ādīnam phala bhūtānam ca cakkhu viññāṇa ādīnam kāraṇa phala matta tāya anatta tāya anatta lakkhaṇa vibhāvana tthāya  āyatana desanā iti āha anatta lakkhaṇanti yadi pi anicca dukkha lakkhaṇāni
translated: He reflects thus: ‘The eye is not-self.’ … ‘Ideas are not-self.’ So he dwells contemplating not-self in these six internal and external bases” . The contemplation of not-self in the bases without distinction is stated thus. The teaching of the bases is for the purpose of showing the characteristic of not-self by means of the not-selfness consisting in the mere cause-fruit relationship of the eye, etc., as the reasons, and of eye-consciousness, etc., as the fruits. So it is said: “The teaching of the twelve bases is for the purpose of showing the characteristic of not-self in the twelve bases” . Although the characteristics of impermanence and painfulness are also shown by the teaching of the bases, still the contemplation of not-self is mentioned here because of the predominance of the contemplation of not-self.

original: ettha dassitāni, tehi ca anattalakkhaṇameva visesena dassitanti adhippāyo. Veti cāti🔽ettha iti-saddo samāpanattho. Iccassāti ettha iti-saddo yathāsamāpitassa āropetabbadosassa🔽nidassanattho. Evanti “cakkhu attā”ti evaṃ vāde satīti attho. Iccassāti vā iti-saddo
analyzed: ettha dassitāni tehi ca anatta lakkhaṇam eva visesena dassitan ti adhippāyaḥ vā iti ca ati 🔽ettha iti saddo samāpana atthaḥ iccassa ati ettha iti saddaḥ yathā samāpitassa āropetabba dosassa 🔽nidassana atthaḥ evanti cakkhu attā ati evam vāde sati iti atthaḥ iccassa ati vā iti saddaḥ
translated: He reflects thus: ‘The eye is not-self’ … ‘Ideas are not-self.’ So he dwells contemplating not-self in these six internal and external bases” . The contemplation of not-self in the bases that are not distinguished is stated thus. The teaching of the bases is for the purpose of showing the characteristic of not-self by means of the not-selfness consisting in mere cause and effect of the eye, etc., which are the causes, and of eye-consciousness, etc., which are the effects. That is why he said “The teaching of the twelve bases is for the purpose of showing the characteristic of not-self in the twelve bases” . Although the characteristics of impermanence and pain are shown here too, the intention is that only the characteristic of not-self is shown in particular. The words “and so” are a summary. The word “thus” in the phrase “thus in regard to the eye” is a word for completion. The word “thus” in the phrase “thus in regard to the eye” is a word for completion. The word “thus” in the phrase “thus in regard to the eye” is a word for completion. The word “thus” in the phrase “thus in regard to the eye” is a word for completion.

original: “iti vadantassā”ti paravādissa dosalakkhaṇākāranidassanattho. Evanti dosagamanappakāranidassanattho.🔽Rūpe attani “evaṃ me rūpaṃ hotū”ti attaniye viya sāminiddesāpattīti ce? Na, “mama
analyzed: iti vadantassa ati paravādissa dosa lakkhaṇa ākāra nidassana ttho eva nti dosa gamana ppakāra nidassana ttho  rūpe attani evam me rūpam hotu uti attaniye viya sāmi niddesa āpatti iti ce na mama
translated: “Thus he speaks”: this is said in order to show the characteristic of hate and the way hate arises in the opponent’s view. “Thus” is said in order to show the way hate arises.🔽If it be said: “The expression ‘my self’ is used in the sense of ownership, as in ‘My body’,”—

original: attā”ti gahitattā. “Mama attā”ti hi gahitaṃ rūpaṃ vasavattitāya “evaṃ me hotū”ti🔽icchiyamānañca tatheva bhaveyya, icchatopi hi tassa rūpasaṅkhāto attā avasavatti🔽cāti. Ābādhāyāti evaṃ dukkhena. Paññāpananti paresaṃ ñāpanaṃ. Anattalakkhaṇapaññāpanassa🔽aññesaṃ avisayattā anattalakkhaṇadīpakānaṃ aniccadukkhalakkhaṇānañca paññāpanassa🔽avisayatā dassitā hoti.
analyzed: attā ati gahita ttā mama attā iti hi gahitam rūpam vasavatti tāya evam me hotu uti  icchiyamānam ca tathā iva bhaveyya icchataḥ api hi tassa rūpa saṅkhātaḥ attā  ca ati ābādhāya ati evam dukkhena paññāpananti paresam ñāpanam anatta lakkhaṇa paññāpanassa  aññesam a visaya ttā anatta lakkhaṇa dīpakānam anicca dukkha lakkhaṇānam ca paññāpanassa  avisaya tā dassitā hoti
translated: then the answer is: No, because the self is taken as “mine.” For if the body were taken as “my self,” it would be possible to will it as one’s own, thinking, “Let my body be thus, let it be otherwise.” But even though one wills it thus, the self, which is called the body, is not subject to one’s will.

original: Evaṃ pana duppaññāpanatā etesaṃ durūpaṭṭhānatāya hotīti tesaṃ anupaṭṭhahanakāraṇaṃ
analyzed: evam pana duppaññāpana tā etesam durūpaṭṭhāna tāya hoti iti tesam an upaṭṭhahana kāraṇam

original: pucchanto āha “imāni panā”tiādi. Ṭhānādīsu nirantaraṃ pavattamānassa heṭṭhā vuttassa
analyzed: pucchantaḥ āha imāni pana atiādi ṭhāna ādīsu nirantaram pavattamānassa heṭṭhā vuttassa
translated: The “continuum” is the occurrence of what was mentioned above without a break.

original: abhiṇhasampaṭipīḷanassa. Dhātumattatāya cakkhādīnaṃ samūhato vinibbhujjanaṃ nānādhātuvinibbhogo.
analyzed: abhiṇha sampaṭipīḷanassa dhātumat tatāya cakkha ādīnam samūhataḥ vinibbhujjanam nānā dhātu vinibbhogaḥ
translated: The “dispersal of the various elements” is the dissolution of the eye, etc., into the mere elements, by the “repeated pressure” mentioned above.

original: Ghanenāti cattāripi ghanāni ghanabhāvena ekattaṃ upanetvā vadati. Paññāyeva santativikopanāti🔽daṭṭhabbaṃ. Yāthāvasarasatoti aviparītasabhāvato. Sabhāvo hi rasiyamāno aviraddhapaṭivedhena
analyzed: ghanena ati ghanāni ghana bhāvena ekattam upanetvā vadati paññāya iva santati vikopanā ti  daṭṭhabbam yāthāvasara sato ti aviparīta sabhāvato sabhāvaḥ hi rasiyamānaḥ aviraddha paṭivedhena
translated: The “mass” is the four primary elements. He speaks of them as “one” by way of their “mass-ness.” The “disturbance of the continuity” should be seen as the “disturbance of the continuity of the wisdom.”

original: assādiyamāno “raso”ti vuccati. Aniccādīhi aniccalakkhaṇādīnaṃ aññattha vacanaṃ ruppanādivasena🔽pavattarūpādiggahaṇato visiṭṭhassa aniccādiggahaṇassa sabbhāvā. Na hi nāmarūpaparicchedamattena
analyzed: assādiyamānaḥ rasaḥ ti vuccati anicca ādīhi anicca lakkhaṇa ādīnam aññattha vacanam ruppana ādi vasena  pavatta rūpa ādi ggahaṇataḥ visiṭṭhassa anicca ādi ggahaṇassa sabbhāvāḥ na hi nāma rūpa pariccheda mattena
translated: “According to reality” means according to the undeluded true nature. For the true nature, when it is relished, is called “taste” when it is relished by the relishing of non-opposition.🔽The “disturbance of the nature” is the apprehension of impermanence, etc., which is distinguished by the apprehension of visible form, etc., that occurs by way of “appearance,” etc.🔽For success is not achieved merely by the delimitation of mentality-materiality. And impermanence, etc., should be seen as the aspects of visible form, etc. But these aspects, in the ultimate sense,

original: kiccasiddhi hoti, aniccādayo ca rūpādīnaṃ ākārā daṭṭhabbā. Te panākārā paramatthato
analyzed: anicca ādayo ca rūpa ādīnaṃ ākārā daṭṭhabbā te pana ākārā paramatthato
translated: are not the same as visible form, etc.

original: avijjamānā rūpādīnaṃ ākāramattāyevāti katvā aṭṭhasāliniyaṃ lakkhaṇārammaṇikavipassanāya
analyzed: a vijjamānā rūpa ādīnam ākāra mattāya iva ati katvā aṭṭha sāliniyam lakkhaṇa ārammaṇika vipassanāya
translated: and it is not the mere mode of materiality, etc., that is absent.

original: khandhārammaṇatā vuttāti adhippāyamatte ṭhātuṃ yuttaṃ, nātidhāvituṃ. “Anicca”nti
analyzed: khandha ārammaṇa tā vuttā ati adhippāya matte ṭhātum yuttam na atidhāvitum aniccanti
translated: So it is proper to stand on the mere intention stated in the Aṭṭhasālinī, namely, that the object of insight is the aggregates, and not to run too far ahead.

original: ca gaṇhanto “dukkhaṃ anattā”ti na gaṇhāti, tathā dukkhādiggahaṇe itarassāgahaṇaṃ.
analyzed: ca gaṇhantaḥ dukkham anattā ati na gaṇhāti tathā dukkha ādi gahaṇe itarassa a gahaṇam
translated: When he apprehends “impermanent,” he does not apprehend “painful” and “not-self.” Likewise, when he apprehends “painful,” he does not apprehend “impermanent” and “not-self.”

original: Aniccādiggahaṇāni ca niccasaññādinivattanakāni saddhāsamādhipaññindriyādhikāni tividhavimokkhamukhabhūtāni.
analyzed: anicca ādi gahaṇāni ca nicca saññā ādi nivattanakāni saddhā samādhi paññindriya adhikāni tividha vimokkha mukha bhūtāni
translated: And the apprehensions of “impermanent,” etc., are respectively the means for the avoidance of the perception of permanence, etc., and they are the three doors to freedom, being the faculties of faith, concentration, and understanding.

original: Tasmā etesaṃ ākārānaṃ pariggayhamānānaṃ aññamaññaṃ viseso ca atthīti tīṇi lakkhaṇāni vuttāni.
analyzed: tasmai etesam ākārānam pariggayhamānānam aññamaññam viseso ca atthi iti tīṇi lakkhaṇāni vuttāni
translated: So there is a difference between these modes when they are apprehended, and that is why the three characteristics are stated.

original: Suttantabhājanīyavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: suttantabhājanīya vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Suttantabhājanīya is ended.

original: 2. Abhidhammabhājanīyavaṇṇanā🔽167. Nāmarūpaparicchedakathā abhidhammakathāti suttante viya paccayayugaḷavasena
analyzed: nāma rūpa pariccheda kathā abhidhamma kathā ati suttante viya paccaya yugaḷa vasena
translated: The commentary on the Abhidhammabhajanīya🔽The exposition of the discernment of mentality-materiality is called the “exposition of the Abhidhamma” because it is expounded by way of the bases to be directly known, not by way of the pairs of conditions as in the case of the suttas.

original: akathetvā ajjhattikabāhiravasena abhiññeyyāni āyatanāni abbokārato abhidhammabhājanīye
analyzed: a kathetvā ajjhattika bāhira vasena abhiññeyyāni āyatanāni abbokārataḥ abhidhamma bhājanīye
translated: In the Abhidhammabhājanīya

original: kathitāni. Āgammāti sabbasaṅkhārehi nibbindassa visaṅkhāraninnassa gotrabhunā vivaṭṭitamānasassa
analyzed: kathitāni āgamma iti sabba saṅkhārehi nibbindassa visaṅkhāra ninnassa gotrabhunā vivaṭṭita mānasassa
translated: and the rest. “Having come to it”: for one who has become dispassionate towards all formations, who is indifferent to formations, who has turned his mind away from them by means of the path of non-return,

original: maggena sacchikaraṇenāti attho. Sacchikiriyamānañhi taṃ adhigantvā ārammaṇapaccayabhūtañca
analyzed: maggena sacchikaraṇena ati attho sacchikiriyamānam hi tam adhigantvā ārammaṇa paccaya bhūtam ca
translated: the meaning is, “having realized it by means of the path.” For when it is being realized, it is realized by depending on the object-condition and the predominance-condition,

original: paṭicca adhipatipaccayabhūte ca tamhi paramassāsabhāvena vinimuttasaṅkhārassa ca🔽gatibhāvena patiṭṭhānabhūte patiṭṭhāya khayasaṅkhāto maggo rāgādayo khepetīti taṃsacchikaraṇābhāve
analyzed: paṭicca adhipati paccaya bhūte ca tamhi parama ssāsa bhāvena vinimutta saṅkhārassa ca  gati bhāvena patiṭṭhāna bhūte patiṭṭhāya khaya saṅkhātaḥ maggaḥ rāga ādayaḥ khepeti iti tad sacchikaraṇa abhāve
translated: and by depending on the support-condition, which is the state of being the destination of the formation that is liberated in the sense of supreme confidence in it.

original: rāgādīnaṃ anuppattinirodhagamanābhāvā “taṃ āgamma rāgādayo khīyantī”ti vuttaṃ. Suttato🔽muñcitvāti suttapadāni muñcitvā. Añño suttassa attho “mātaraṃ pitaraṃ hantvā”tiādīsu
analyzed: rāga ādīnam anuppatti nirodha gamana abhāvā tam āgamma rāga ādayaḥ khīyanti iti vuttam suttato  muñcitvā iti sutta padāni muñcitvā aññaḥ suttassa atthaḥ mātaram pitaram hantvā atiādīsu
translated: Therefore, since the path, which is called “destruction,” is liberated from the defilements of lust, etc., it is said: “Having come to it, lust, etc., are destroyed.”

original: viya āharitabbo, natthi suttapadeheva nīto atthoti attho.
analyzed: viya āharitabbaḥ natthi sutta padehi iva nītaḥ attho ti attho
translated: “Having extracted from the suttas”: having extracted the words of the suttas. There is no other meaning of the sutta to be brought in, as in the case of the passage beginning, “Having killed mother and father” . The meaning is that the meaning is brought in only by the words of the sutta.

original: Ekaṃ nānanti cuṇṇitaṃ khuddakaṃ vā karaṇaṃ, cuṇṇīkaraṇanti abahumānena vadati. Na
analyzed: ekam nānā ti cuṇṇitam khuddakam vā karaṇam cuṇṇī karaṇa nti a bahu mānena vadati na
translated: “One kind of small-small” : he says “small-small” out of disrespect for the small.

original: tvaṃ ekaṃ nānaṃ jānāsīti kiṃ ettakaṃ tvameva na jānāsīti attho. Nanu ñāteti “yadipi
analyzed: tvam ekam nānam jānāsi iti kim ettakam tvam eva na jānāsi iti atthaḥ nanu ñātā iti yadi api
translated: “You know one, do you?” means: “Do you not know even this much?”

original: pubbe na ñātaṃ, adhunāpi ñāte nanu sādhu hotī”ti attano jānanaṃ paṭicchādetvā vikkhepaṃ🔽karontaṃ nibandhati. Vibhajitvāti akkharatthamatte aṭṭhatvā līnaṃ atthaṃ vibhajitvā
analyzed: pubbe na ñātam adhunā api ñāte nanu sādhu hoti iti attanaḥ jānanam paṭicchādetvā vikkhepam  karontam nibandhati vibhajitvā iti akkhara attha matte līnam attham vibhajitvā
translated: “Isn’t it good when it is known?” means: “Even if it was not known before, isn’t it good when it is known now?”🔽“Having analyzed it” means: having extracted and brought out the meaning that is hidden, not remaining in the mere meaning of the words.

original: uddharitvā nīharitvā kathitanti attho. Rāgādīnaṃ khayo nāma abhāvamatto, na ca abhāvassa🔽bahubhāvo atthi attano abhāvattāti vadantassa vacanapacchindanatthaṃ pucchati “rāgakkhayo🔽nāma rāgasseva khayo”tiādi. Yadi hi rāgakkhayo dosādīnaṃ khayo na hoti, dosakkhayādayo
analyzed: uddharitvā nīharitvā kathitanti atthaḥ rāga ādīnam khayaḥ nāma abhāva mattaḥ na ca abhāvassa  bahu bhāvaḥ atthi attanaḥ abhāvattā ati vadantassa vacana pacchindana attham pucchati rāga kkhayo  nāma rāgassa iva khayaḥ tiādi yadi hi rāga kkhayaḥ dosa ādīnam khayaḥ na hoti dosa kkhaya ādayaḥ
translated: The destruction of lust, etc., is mere non-existence, and non-existence has no multiplicity, because it is non-existence itself.🔽“The destruction of lust is the destruction of lust itself,” etc.

original: ca rāgādīnaṃ khayā, aññamaññavisiṭṭhā bhinnā āpannā hontīti bahunibbānatā āpannā
analyzed: ca rāga ādīnam khayā aññamañña visiṭṭhāḥ bhinnāḥ āpannāḥ honti iti bahu nibbāna tā āpannā
translated: If the destruction of lust is not the destruction of hatred, etc., and the destruction of hatred, etc., is not the destruction of lust, etc., then they are mutually distinguished, divided, and included, and so there is the fault of a multiplicity of Nibbāna.

original: eva hoti, aññamaññaviseso ca nāma nissabhāvassa natthīti sasabhāvatā ca nibbānassa.
analyzed: eva hoti aññamañña viseso ca nāma nissabhāvassa natthi iti sa sabhāva tā ca nibbānassa
translated: And mutual distinction does not exist for the non-existent, and so Nibbāna would have individual essence.

original: Nava taṇhāmūlakā “taṇhaṃ paṭicca pariyesanā”ti ādayo, tesu pariyesanādayo ca pariyesanādikarakilesā
analyzed: nava taṇhā mūlakā taṇham paṭicca pariyesanā ati ādayo tesu pariyesanā ādayo ca pariyesanā ādi kara kilesā
translated: The nine beginning with “With craving as condition, pursuit” are the defilements that cause pursuit, etc.,

original: daṭṭhabbā. Diyaḍḍhakilesasahassaṃ nidānakathāyaṃ vuttaṃ.
