analyzed: daṭṭhabbā diyaḍḍha kilesa sahassam nidāna kathāyam vuttam
translated: and these should be understood as the thousand and two hundred defilements stated in the Nidāna-kathā.

original: Oḷārikatāya kāretabboti atisukhumassa nibbānassa oḷārikabhāvadosāpattiyā bodhetabbo,🔽niggahetabbo vā. Vatthunti upādinnakaphoṭṭhabbaṃ methunaṃ. Acchādīnampi nibbānappatti
analyzed: oḷārika tāya kāretabbo ti ati sukhumassa nibbānassa oḷārika bhāva dosa āpattiyā bodhetabbo  niggahetabbaḥ vā vatthun ti upādinna ka phoṭṭhabbam methunam accha ādīnam pi nibbāna ppatti
translated: “Should be made gross”: he should be made to understand the fault of the grossness of Nibbāna, which is extremely subtle, or he should be made to grasp it.🔽“The object”: the tangible object clung to, namely, sexual intercourse.🔽Why is it said that the other four objects, namely, visible forms, etc., are also Nibbāna?

original: kasmā vuttā, nanu “kilesānaṃ accantaṃ anuppattinirodho nibbāna”nti icchantassa kilesānaṃ🔽vināso kañci kālaṃ appavatti nibbānaṃ na hotīti? Na, abhāvasāmaññato. Accantāpavatti
analyzed: kasmā vuttā nanu kilesānam accantam anuppatti nirodhaḥ nibbānam ti icchantassa kilesānam  vināso kañci kālam appavatti nibbānam na hoti iti na abhāva sāmaññato accanta apavatti
translated: If one maintains that Nibbāna is the absolute cessation of the defilements, then the destruction of the defilements, which is their non-occurrence for a time, is not Nibbāna, is it?🔽No, because of the similarity of non-existence. For absolute non-occurrence and non-occurrence for a time are simply non-existence. There is no difference between them.

original: hi kañci kālañca appavatti abhāvoyevāti natthi viseso. Savisesaṃ vā vadantassa abhāvatā
analyzed: hi kañci kālam ca appavatti natthi viseso savisesam vā vadantassa abhāva tā
translated: Or if one maintains that there is a difference, then one would be landed in the belief that Nibbāna is a non-existent.

original: āpajjatīti. Tiracchānagatehipi pāpuṇitabbattā tesampi pākaṭaṃ piḷandhanaṃ viya oḷārikaṃ
analyzed: āpajjati iti tiracchāna gatehi pi pāpuṇitabba ttā tesam pi pākaṭam piḷandhanam viya oḷārikam
translated: Because it is also reached by animals, the gross is like the obvious covering of the skin.

original: thūlaṃ. Kevalaṃ pana kaṇṇe piḷandhituṃ na sakkoti, piḷandhanatopi vā thūlattā na
analyzed: thūlam kevalam pana kaṇṇe piḷandhitum na sakkoti piḷandhanataḥ api vā thūla tā na
translated: but it is thick. It cannot be pierced by the ear, or it is not pierced because of its thickness,

original: sakkāti uppaṇḍento viya niggaṇhāti.
analyzed: uppaṇḍentaḥ viya niggaṇhāti
translated: as if it were being held back by the piercing.

original: Nibbānārammaṇakaraṇena gotrabhukkhaṇe kilesakkhayappatti panassa āpannāti maññamāno
analyzed: nibbāna ārammaṇa karaṇena gotrabhu khaṇe kilesa khaya ppatti pana assa āpannā ati maññamāno
translated: But he thinks that the destruction of defilements is attained by him at the moment of change-of-lineage by making Nibbāna the object.🔽So he says, “You have not destroyed the defilements that still remain,” etc.

original: āha “tvaṃ akhīṇesuyevā”tiādi. Nanu ārammaṇakaraṇamattena kilesakkhayo anuppattoti
analyzed: āha tvam nanu ārammaṇa karaṇa mattena kilesa khayaḥ anuppatto ti
translated: But it cannot be said that the destruction of defilements is attained by mere making the object.

original: na sakkā vattuṃ. Cittañhi atītānāgatādisabbaṃ ālambeti, na nipphannamevāti gotrabhupi
analyzed: na sakkā vattum cittam hi atīta anāgata ādi sabbam ālambeti na nipphannam eva ati gotra bhupi
translated: For the mind makes all past, future, etc., states its object, but it does not make them its own nature.

original: maggena kilesānaṃ yā anuppattidhammatā kātabbā, taṃ ārabbha pavattissatīti? Na, appattanibbānassa
analyzed: maggena kilesānam yā anuppatti dhamma tā kātabbā tam ārabbha pavattissati iti na appatta nibbānassa
translated: So will it occur in the future with reference to the state of the path that should be made to arise by the change-of-lineage?🔽No, because one who has not attained Nibbāna does not possess knowledge that has Nibbāna as its object.

original: nibbānārammaṇañāṇābhāvato. Na hi aññadhammā viya nibbānaṃ, taṃ pana atigambhīrattā
analyzed: nibbāna ārammaṇa ñāṇa abhāvataḥ na hi añña dhammāḥ viya nibbānam tam pana ati gambhīra ttā
translated: For Nibbāna is not like other states. But because it is extremely profound,

original: appattena ālambituṃ na sakkā. Tasmā tena gotrabhunā pattabbena tikālikasabhāvātikkantagambhīrabhāvena
analyzed: appattena ālambitum na sakkā tasmai tena gotrabhunā pattabbena ti kālika sabhāva atikkanta gambhīra bhāvena
translated: it cannot be made an object by one who has not attained it. Therefore it is the profound nature that transcends the three times, which is to be attained by the change-of-lineage,

original: bhavitabbaṃ, kilesakkhayamattataṃ vā icchato gotrabhuto puretaraṃ nipphannena kilesakkhayena.
analyzed: bhavitabbam kilesa khaya mattatam vā icchataḥ gotrabhutaḥ puretaram nipphannena kilesa kkhayena
translated: or else, if he wishes to make the mere exhaustion of defilements the object, he would have to make the exhaustion of defilements that arose earlier than the path consciousness the object.🔽Hence it is said: “You make nibbana, the exhaustion of defilements, known by you when the defilements are not exhausted.”

original: Tenāha “tvaṃ akhīṇesuyeva kilesesu kilesakkhayaṃ nibbānaṃ paññapesī”ti. Appattakilesakkhayārammaṇakaraṇe
analyzed: tena āha tvam akhīṇesu yeva kilesesu kilesa kkhayam nibbānam paññapesi iti appatta kilesa kkhaya ārammaṇa karaṇe
translated: For if he made nibbana, which is not the exhaustion of defilements that have not been exhausted, the object,

original: hi sati gotrabhuto puretaracittānipi ālambeyyunti.
analyzed: hi sati
translated: he would have to make the path consciousnesses that arose earlier the object too.

original: Maggassa kilesakkhayaṃ nibbānanti maggassa ārammaṇabhūtaṃ nibbānaṃ katamanti attho. Maggotiādinā purimapucchādvayameva vivarati.
analyzed: maggassa kilesa kkhayam nibbānanti maggassa ārammaṇa bhūtam nibbānam kataman ti atthaḥ magga uti ādinā purima pucchā dvayam eva vivarati
translated: “The path’s nibbana”: the meaning is: the nibbana that is the object of the path. He explains the first two questions with “The path” and so on.🔽“And yet it is not anything”: nibbana is not anything among materiality, etc., nor does it ever become anything.

original: Na ca kiñcīti rūpādīsu nibbānaṃ kiñci na hoti, na ca kadāci hoti, atītādibhāvena
analyzed: na ca kiñci iti rūpa ādīsu nibbānam kiñci na hoti na ca kadāci hoti atīta ādi bhāvena
translated: They say that it cannot be stated as past, etc.,

original: na vattabbanti vadanti, taṃ āgamma avijjātaṇhānaṃ kiñci ekadesamattampi na hoti,
analyzed: na vattabbanti vadanti tam āgamma avijjā taṇhānam kiñci eka desa mattam pi na hoti
translated: but it is proper to say that by it the entire mass of ignorance and craving does not become anything,

original: tadeva taṃ āgamma kadāci na ca hotīti attho yutto.🔽Abhidhammabhājanīyavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: tat eva tam āgamma kadāci na ca hoti iti atthaḥ yutto  abhidhammabhājanīya vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: and that by it nothing ever becomes anything.🔽The commentary on the section of the Abhidhamma is ended.

original: 3. Pañhapucchakavaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the questions and answers

original: 168. Na…pe… navattabbadhammārammaṇattāti yathā sārammaṇā parittādibhāvena navattabbaṃ kiñci ārammaṇaṃ karonti, evaṃ kiñci ālambanato na navattabbakoṭṭhāsaṃ bhajatīti attho.
analyzed: nape navattabba dhamma ārammaṇa ttā ti yathā sa ārammaṇā paritta ādi bhāvena navattabbam kiñci ārammaṇam karonti evam kiñci ālambanataḥ na navattabba koṭṭhāsam bhajati iti atthaḥ
translated: … nor do they have a new object that is not already existent, that is, they do not have any object that is not already existent by being limited, etc., as an object. The meaning is that they do not have any portion that is not already existent by being apprehended.

original: Pañhapucchakavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: pañha pucchaka vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the questions is ended.

original: Āyatanavibhaṅgavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽3. Dhātuvibhaṅgo
analyzed: āyatana vibhaṅga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  dhātu vibhaṅgaḥ
translated: The exposition of the bases is ended.🔽The exposition of the elements

original: 1. Suttantabhājanīyavaṇṇanā🔽172. Yadipi dhātusaṃyuttādīsu “dhātunānattaṃ vo, bhikkhave, desessāmi, katamañca,
analyzed: yadi pi dhātu saṃyutta ādīsu dhātu nānattam vaḥ bhikkhave desessāmi katamat ca
translated: The exposition of the Suttas

original: bhikkhave, dhātunānattaṃ? Cakkhudhātu…pe… manoviññāṇadhātū”tiādinā aṭṭhārasa dhātuyo🔽āgatā, tā pana abhidhamme ca āgatāti sādhāraṇattā aggahetvā suttantesveva āgate tayo
analyzed: bhikkhave dhātu nānattam cakkhu dhātu pe manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu uti ādinā aṭṭhārasa dhātuyaḥ  āgatā tā pana abhidhamme ca āgatā ati sādhāraṇa ttā aggahetvā suttantesu eva āgate tayo
translated: Although in the “Questions on Elements” , etc., it is said, “Bhikkhus, I shall teach you the diversity of elements. Now what, bhikkhus, is the diversity of elements? The eye element … the mind-consciousness element” , and although eighteen elements are stated there,

original: dhātuchakke gahetvā suttantabhājanīyaṃ vibhattanti veditabbaṃ. Sabbā dhātuyoti aṭṭhārasapi.
analyzed: dhātu chakke gahetvā suttanta bhājanīyam vibhattam ti veditabbam sabbāḥ dhātuyo ti aṭṭhārasa pi
translated: nevertheless, since they are also stated in the Abhidhamma, they are not included here because they are common to the Abhidhamma. So the exposition of the Suttas should be understood as the exposition of the three element groups stated in the Suttas. All elements: the eighteen.

original: Suññe sabhāvamatte niruḷho dhātu-saddo daṭṭhabbo. Asamphuṭṭhadhātūti catūhi mahābhūtehi
analyzed: suññe sa bhāva matte niruḷhaḥ dhātu saddaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ a samphuṭṭha dhātu iti catūhi mahābhūtehi
translated: The word element should be understood as being confined to the mere individual essence in the void.

original: abyāpitabhāvoti attho.🔽173. Pathavīdhātudvayanti aṭṭhakathāyaṃ paduddhāro kato, pāḷiyaṃ pana “dveya”nti
analyzed: a byāpita bhāvo ti attho  pathavī dhātu dvayanti aṭṭhakathā iyam paduddhāro kato pāḷiyam pana
translated: Not intermixed with the elements: not pervaded by the four great primaries.🔽The earth element twofold: the commentary has extracted the words, but in the text the words are “dveya” .

original: āgacchati, attho pana yathāvuttova. Dvayanti pana pāṭhe sati ayampi attho sambhavati.🔽Dve avayavā etassāti dvayaṃ, pathavīdhātūnaṃ dvayaṃ pathavīdhātudvayaṃ, dvinnaṃ pathavīdhātūnaṃ🔽samudāyoti attho. Dve eva vā avayavā samuditā dvayaṃ, pathavīdhātudvayanti. “Tattha
analyzed: āgacchati atthaḥ pana yathā vuttaḥ iva pana pāṭhe sati ayam pi atthaḥ sambhavati  dve avayavāḥ etassa ati dvayam pathavī dhātūnam dvayam pathavī dhātu dvayam dvinnam pathavī dhātūnam  samudāyaḥ ti atthaḥ dve eva vā avayavā samuditā dvayam
translated: But the meaning is as stated. If the reading is “dve va” , this meaning is possible:🔽it has two parts, thus it is twofold . The twofoldness of the earth element is the earth element twofold . The meaning is: the combination of the two earth elements. Or alternatively, the combination of the two parts is twofold . The earth element twofold is thus.

original: katamā pathavīdhātu? Pathavīdhātudvayaṃ, esā pathavīdhātū”ti saṅkhepena vissajjeti.
analyzed: katamā pathavī dhātu pathavī dhātu dvayam esā pathavī dhātu uti saṅkhepena vissajja iti
translated: Herein, what is the earth element? The earth element twofold is the earth element. He answers in brief.

original: Atthi ajjhattikā atthi bāhirāti ettha ajjhattikabāhira-saddā na ajjhattikaduke viya
analyzed: atthi ajjhattikā atthi bāhirā ti ettha ajjhattika bāhira saddāḥ na ajjhattika duke viya
translated: Herein, as to internal and external: the words internal and external are not used here in the way they are used in the

original: ajjhattikabāhirāyatanavācakā, nāpi ajjhattattike vuttehi ajjhattabahiddhā-saddehi
analyzed: ajjhattika bāhira āyatana vācakā na api ajjhatta ttike vuttehi ajjhatta bahiddhā saddehi
translated: The words “internal” and “external” do not have the same meaning as the words “internal” and “external” in the passage, “The internal earth element and the external earth element” .

original: samānatthā, indriyabaddhānindriyabaddhavācakā pana ete. Tena “sattasantānapariyāpannā”tiādi
analyzed: samāna atthāḥ indriya baddha anindriya baddha vācakā pana ete tena satta santāna pariyāpanna ati ādi
translated: They are words for what is bound up with faculties and what is not so bound up. That is why it is said above, “They are included in the continuity of a single being” , etc.

original: vuttaṃ. Niyakajjhattāti ca na paccattaṃ attani jātataṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ, atha kho
analyzed: vuttam niyaka jjhattā iti ca na paccattam attani jāta tam sandhāya vuttam atha kho
translated: And the words “internal to oneself” are not said with reference to what is born in one’s own self, but rather

original: sabbasattasantānesu jātatanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Ajjhattaṃ paccattanti vacanena hi sattasantānapariyāpannatāya🔽ajjhattikabhāvaṃ dasseti, na pāṭipuggalikatāya. Sabhāvākāratoti āpādīhi visiṭṭhena
analyzed: sabba satta santānesu jāta tanti daṭṭhabbam ajjhattam paccattanti vacanena hi satta santāna pariyāpanna tāya  ajjhattika bhāvam dasseti na pāṭipuggalika tāya sabhāva ākārato ti āpa ādīhi visiṭṭhena
translated: what is born in the continuity of all beings should be regarded as “internal to oneself.” For by the words “internal to oneself” he shows that they are “internal” because they are included in the continuity of a single being,🔽not because they are in one’s own person.

original: attano eva sabhāvabhūtena gahetabbākārena.
analyzed: attanaḥ eva sabhāva bhūtena gahetabba ākārena
translated: By their own individual essences and aspects: by their own individual essences, which are distinguished by the words “earth” , etc., and by the aspects that are to be apprehended as their individual essences.🔽Hairs of the head: because of the predominance of hardness they are said to have the characteristic of hardness.

original: Kesā kakkhaḷattalakkhaṇāti kakkhaḷatādhikatāya vuttā. Pāṭiyekko koṭṭhāsoti pathavīkoṭṭhāsamatto
analyzed: kesā kakkhaḷatta lakkhaṇā ti kakkhaḷa tā adhika tāya vuttā pāṭiyekkaḥ koṭṭhāso ti pathavī koṭṭhāsa matto
translated: A separate portion: the meaning is, the measure of a portion of earth.

original: suññoti attho. Matthaluṅgaṃ aṭṭhimiñjaggahaṇena gahitanti idha visuṃ na vuttanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: suññaḥ ti atthaḥ mattha luṅgam aṭṭhimiñja gahaṇena gahitanti idha visum na vuttan ti veditabbam
translated: The brain should be understood as not mentioned separately here because it is included in the grasping of the “membranes and bones.”

original: Imināti “seyyathidaṃ kesā”tiādinā. Kammaṃ katvāti payogaṃ vīriyaṃ āyūhanaṃ vā katvāti
analyzed: iminā ati seyyathidam kesāti ādinā kammam katvā ati payogam vīriyam āyūhanam vā katvā ati
translated: ‘By this’: by ‘such things as head hairs’. ‘Having done the work’: the meaning is that having done the work of the effort of application.

original: attho. Bhogakāmena kasiyādīsu viya arahattakāmena ca imasmiṃ manasikāre kammaṃ kattabbanti.
analyzed: atthaḥ bhoga kāmena kasiyā ādīsu viya arahatta kāmena ca imasmin manasikāre kammam kattabbanti
translated: One who desires Arahantship should do the work on this attention as one who desires wealth should do the work on agriculture, etc.

original: Pubbapalibodhāti āvāsādayo dīghakesādike khuddakapalibodhe aparapalibodhāti apekkhitvā vuttā.
analyzed: pubba palibodhā āti āvāsa ādayaḥ dīgha kesa ādike khuddaka palibodhe apara palibodhā ati apekkhitvā vuttā
translated: ‘Previous obstruction’: the dwelling place, etc., are called ‘previous obstruction’ because they are mentioned before the small obstruction of long hair, etc.

original: Vaṇṇādīnaṃ pañcannaṃ vasena manasikāro dhātupaṭikūlavaṇṇamanasikārānaṃ sādhāraṇo
analyzed: vaṇṇa ādīnam pañcannam vasena manasikāraḥ dhātu paṭikūla vaṇṇa manasikārānam sādhāraṇaḥ
translated: Attention by way of the five beginning with colour is common to the attention to the repulsiveness of elements and to the attention to the sign of the beautiful.

original: pubbabhāgoti nibbattitadhātumanasikāraṃ dassetuṃ “avasāne evaṃ manasikāro pavattetabbo”ti
analyzed: pubbabhāgaḥ ti nibbattita dhātu manasikāram dassetum avasāne evam manasikāro pavattetabbo ti
translated: ‘The beginning’: he said ‘at the end the attention should be given in this way’ in order to show the attention to the elements that have arisen.

original: āha. Aññamaññaṃ ābhogapaccavekkhaṇarahitāti kāraṇassa ca phalassa ca abyāpāratāya
analyzed: āha aññamaññam ābhoga paccavekkhaṇa rahitā ati kāraṇassa ca phalassa ca a byāpāra tāya
translated: ‘Without contact and review’: he shows that the mere elements are without contact and review because the cause and the fruit are without contact and review.

original: dhātumattataṃ dasseti. Ābhogapaccavekkhaṇādīnampi evameva abyāpāratā daṭṭhabbā. Na
analyzed: dhātumat tatam dasseti ābhoga paccavekkhaṇa ādīnam pi evam eva abyāpāra tā daṭṭhabbā na
translated: The absence of contact and review, etc., should be seen in the same way.

original: hi tāni, tesañca kāraṇāni ābhujitvā paccavekkhitvā ca uppajjanti karonti cāti. Lakkhaṇavasenāti
analyzed: hi tāni tesam ca kāraṇāni ābhujitvā paccavekkhitvā ca uppajjanti karonti ca ati lakkhaṇa vasena ati
translated: As to characteristic:

original: “kakkhaḷaṃ kharigata”ntiādivacanaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ.
analyzed: kakkhaḷam khari gata nti ādi vacanam sandhāya vuttam
translated: this is said referring to the words, “The earth element should be seen as the characteristic of hardness” , etc.

original: Vekantakaṃ ekā lohajāti. Nāganāsikalohaṃ lohasadisaṃ lohavijāti haliddivijāti viya.
analyzed: ekā loha jāti nāga nāsika loham loha sadisam loha vijāti haliddi vijāti
translated: The “extreme” is a single kind of metal. The “metal of the serpent’s nose” is like metal, it is a kind of metal like the kind called “yellow orpiment” .

original: Tiputambādīhi missetvā kataṃ karaṇena nibbattattā kittimalohaṃ. Morakkhādīni evaṃnāmānevetāni.
analyzed: tipu tamba ādīhi missetvā katam karaṇena nibbatta ttā kittima loham morakkha ādīni evaṃnāmāni iva etāni
translated: “Brass” is made by mixing with tin, etc., and it is called “brass” because it is produced by a process of manufacture. “Bronze” , etc., are named after their respective origins.

original: Sāmuddikamuttāti nidassanamattametaṃ, sabbāpi pana muttā muttā eva.🔽174. Appetīti āpo, ābandhanavasena sesabhūtattayaṃ pāpuṇāti silesatīti attho. Yūsabhūtoti
analyzed: sāmuddika muttā ati nidassana mattam etam sabbā api pana muttāḥ muttāḥ eva  appeti iti āpaḥ ābandhana vasena sesa bhūtattayam pāpuṇāti silesati iti atthaḥ yūsa bhūtaḥ ti
translated: “Sea-monster pearl” is mentioned merely as an example; for all pearls are pearls.🔽Water is “appet” because it “pet” , that is, it “goes” , by flowing, and it “a” , that is, it “comes” , by wetting the three remaining elements, which is the meaning.

original: rasabhūto. Vakkahadayayakanapapphāsāni tementanti ettha yakanaṃ heṭṭhābhāgapūraṇena,
analyzed: rasa bhūtaḥ vakka hadaya yakana papphāsāni ettha yakanam heṭṭhā bhāga pūraṇena
translated: The “juicy” state:🔽the “juicy” state is the liquid state. “The liver, heart, kidney, and lungs are moistened” : here the kidney is moistened by being filled below,

original: itarāni tesaṃ upari thokaṃ thokaṃ paggharaṇena temeti. Heṭṭhā leḍḍukhaṇḍāni temayamāneti
analyzed: itarāni tesam upari thokam thokam paggharaṇena tema iti heṭṭhā leḍḍu khaṇḍāni temayamānā iti
translated: the others are moistened by a little trickling over them. The “liver, heart, kidney, and lungs are moistened” is said

original: temakatemitabbānaṃ abyāpārasāmaññanidassanatthāyeva upamā daṭṭhabbā, na ṭhānasāmaññanidassanatthāya.
analyzed: temaka temitabbānam a byāpāra sāmañña nidassana tthāya iva upamā daṭṭhabbā na ṭhāna sāmañña nidassana tthāya
translated: The simile should be regarded as given only for the purpose of showing the similarity of the state of being drenched and the state of being heated, not for the purpose of showing similarity of location.

original: Sannicitalohitena temetabbānaṃ kesañci heṭṭhā, kassaci upari ṭhitatañhi satipaṭṭhānavibhaṅge🔽vakkhatīti, yakanassa heṭṭhābhāgo “ṭhitaṃ mayi lohita”nti na jānāti, vakkādīni “amhe🔽temayamānaṃ lohitaṃ ṭhita”nti na jānantīti evaṃ yojanā kātabbā. Yathā pana bhesajjasikkhāpade
analyzed: sannicita lohitena temetabbānam kesañci heṭṭhā kassaci upari sati paṭṭhāna vibhaṅge  vakkhati iti heṭṭhā bhāgaḥ ṭhitam mayi lohitanti na jānāti vakka ādīni amhe  temayamānam lohitam ṭhitanti na jānanti iti evam yojanā kātabbā yathā pana bhesajja sikkhāpade
translated: For some of those drenched by the accumulated blood are below and some are above, as will be stated in the description of the sensitive material septad in the following section.🔽The lower part of the liver does not know “Blood is situated in me,” nor do the spleen, etc., know “Blood situated in us is being heated.” The construction should be done in this way.

original: niyamo atthi “yesaṃ maṃsaṃ kappati, tesaṃ khīra”nti, evamidha natthi.🔽175. Tejanavasenāti nisitabhāvena tikkhabhāvena. Sarīrassa pakatiṃ atikkamitvā uṇhabhāvo
analyzed: niyamaḥ atthi yesam maṃsam kappati tesam khīram ti evam idha natthi  tejana vasena ati nisita bhāvena tikkha bhāvena sarīrassa pakatim a tikkamitvā uṇha bhāvaḥ
translated: But just as in the case of the training precept about medicine there is the restriction that “the milk of those animals in whose case meat is permitted is also permitted,” so here there is no such restriction.🔽By the heat of the fire: by the sharpness, by the keenness.

original: santāpo, sarīradahanavasena pavatto mahādāho paridāho. Ayametesaṃ viseso. Yena jīrīyatīti
analyzed: santāpaḥ sarīra dahana vasena pavattaḥ mahā dāhaḥ paridāhaḥ ayam etesam visesaḥ yena jīrīyati iti
translated: The heat that exceeds the normal temperature of the body is fever. The great burning, the burning up, which occurs by way of the burning of the body, is a burning heat. This is the difference between them. By which one wastes away.

original: ekāhikādijararogena jīrīyatītipi attho yujjati. Satavāraṃ tāpetvā udake pakkhipitvā🔽uddhaṭasappi satadhotasappīti vadanti. Rasasoṇitamedamaṃsanhāruaṭṭhiaṭṭhimiñjā rasādayo.🔽Keci nhāruṃ apanetvā sukkaṃ sattamadhātuṃ avocunti. Pākatikoti khobhaṃ appatto sadā🔽vijjamāno. Petaggi mukhato bahi niggatova idha gahito.🔽176. Vāyanavasenāti savegagamanavasena, samudīraṇavasena vā.
analyzed: ekāhika ādi jara rogena atthaḥ yujjati sata vāram tāpetvā udake pakkhipitvā  uddhaṭa sappi satadhā uta sappi iti vadanti rasa soṇita meda maṃsa nhāru aṭṭhi aṭṭhimiñjāḥ rasa ādayaḥ  keci nhārum apanetvā sukkam sattama dhātum avocunti pākatikaḥ iti khobham appatto sadā  vijjamānaḥ petaggi mukhataḥ bahi niggataḥ uva idha gahitaḥ  vāyana vasena ati sa vega gamana vasena samudīraṇa vasena vā
translated: They say that ghee that has been melted a hundred times and then put into water is “a hundred-times-melted ghee.”

original: 177. Iminā yasmiṃ ākāse…pe… taṃ kathitanti idaṃ kasiṇugghāṭimākāsassa akathitataṃ, ajaṭākāsassa ca kathitataṃ dassetuṃ vuttaṃ.🔽179. Sukhadukkhānaṃ pharaṇabhāvo sarīraṭṭhakautussa sukhadukkhaphoṭṭhabbasamuṭṭhānapaccayabhāvena🔽yathābalaṃ sarīrekadesasakalasarīrapharaṇasamatthatāya vutto, somanassadomanassānaṃ
analyzed: iminā yasmin tam kathitanti idam ajaṭa ākāsassa ca dassetum vuttam 🔽sukha dukkhānam pharaṇa bhāvaḥ sukha dukkha phoṭṭhabba samuṭṭhāna paccaya bhāvena 🔽yathābalam sarīra eka desa sakala sarīra pharaṇa samattha tāya vuttaḥ somanassa domanassānam
translated: “Blood, flesh, etc.,” “blood, flesh, pus, etc.,” “blood, flesh, pus, sweat, etc.,” “blood, flesh, pus, sweat, snot, tears, spittle, oil of the joints, and excrement,” “blood, flesh, pus, sweat, snot, tears, spittle, oil of the joints, excrement, and urine,” “blood, flesh, pus, sweat, snot, tears, spittle, oil of the joints, excrement, and urine,” “blood, flesh, pus, sweat, snot, tears, spittle, oil of the joints, excrement, and urine,” “blood, flesh, pus, sweat, snot, tears, spittle, oil of the joints, excrement, and urine,” “blood, flesh, pus, sweat, snot, tears, spittle, oil of the joints, excrement, and urine,” “blood, flesh, pus, sweat, snot, tears, spittle, oil of the joints, excrement, and urine,” “blood, flesh, pus, sweat, snot, tears, spittle, oil of the joints, excrement, and urine,” “blood, flesh, pus, sweat, snot, tears, spittle, oil of the joints, excrement, and urine,” “blood, flesh, pus, sweat, snot, tears, spittle, oil of the joints, excrement, and urine,” “blood, flesh, pus, sweat, snot, tears, spittle, oil of the joints, excrement, and urine,” “blood, flesh, pus, sweat, snot, tears, spittle, oil of the joints, excrement, and urine,” “blood, flesh, pus, sweat, snot, tears, spittle, oil of the joints, excrement, and urine,” “blood, flesh, pus, sweat, snot, tears, spittle, oil of the joints, excrement, and urine,” “blood, flesh, pus, sweat, snot, tears, spittle, oil of the joints, excrement, and urine,” “blood, flesh, pus, sweat, snot, tears,

original: iṭṭhāniṭṭhacittajasamuṭṭhāpanena tatheva pharaṇasamatthatāya. Evaṃ etesaṃ sarīrapharaṇatāya
analyzed: iṭṭha aniṭṭha citta ja samuṭṭhāpanena tathā iva pharaṇa samattha tāya evam etesam sarīra pharaṇa tāya
translated: and by the arousing of the desirable and undesirable, respectively, they are able to spread in the same way. So they spread in the body in this way.

original: ekassa ṭhānaṃ itaraṃ paharati, itarassa ca aññanti aññamaññena sappaṭipakkhataṃ dasseti,
analyzed: ekassa ṭhānam itaram paharati itarassa ca aññam ti aññamaññena sa paṭipakkha tam dasseti
translated: The words “one strikes the other’s place” and “the other’s” show that they are mutually opposed.

original: aññamaññapaṭipakkhaoḷārikappavatti eva vā etesaṃ pharaṇaṃ. Vatthārammaṇāni ca pabandhena
analyzed: aññamañña paṭipakkha oḷārika ppavatti eva vā etesam pharaṇam vattha ārammaṇāni ca pabandhena
translated: Or their spreading is the gross occurrence of mutual opposition. And the object and the physical basis should be regarded as the cause of their occurrence by being bound up with each other.

original: pavattihetubhūtāni pharaṇaṭṭhānaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ, ubhayavato ca puggalassa vasena ayaṃ🔽sappaṭipakkhatā dassitā sukhadassanīyattā.🔽181. Kilesakāmaṃ sandhāyāti “saṅkappo kāmo rāgo kāmo”ti ettha vuttaṃ saṅkappaṃ sandhāyāti🔽adhippāyo. Sopi hi vibādhati upatāpeti cāti kilesasanthavasambhavato kilesakāmo vibhatto
analyzed: pavatti hetu bhūtāni pharaṇa ṭṭhānam daṭṭhabbam ubhayavataḥ ca puggalassa vasena ayaṃ  sa paṭipakkha tā dassitā sukha dassanīya ttā  kilesa kāmam sandhāya ati saṅkappaḥ kāmaḥ rāgaḥ kāmaḥ iti ettha vuttam saṅkappam sandhāya ati  adhippāyaḥ saḥ api hi vibādhati upatāpeti ca ati kilesa santhava sambhavato kilesa kāmaḥ vibhatto
translated: And the mutual opposition is shown here in terms of the person who possesses both, because that is easy to see.🔽“Referring to the defilement lust”: the intention is the lust stated as “will is lust” and “longing is lust” .🔽That also is “defilement lust” because it is possible to have the continuity of defilement, or because it is possible to have the object of defilement.

original: kilesavatthusambhavato vā. Kāmapaṭisaṃyuttāti kāmarāgasaṅkhātena kāmena sampayuttā,
analyzed: kilesa vatthu sambhavataḥ vā kāma paṭisaṃyuttā ati kāma rāga saṅkhātena kāmena sampayuttā
translated: “Associated with lust” : associated with lust called “lust for sensual desire” .

original: kāmapaṭibaddhā vā. Aññesu ca kāmapaṭisaṃyuttadhammesu vijjamānesu vitakkeyeva kāmopapado
analyzed: kāma paṭibaddhā vā aññesu ca kāma paṭisaṃyutta dhammesu vijjamānesu vitakkeya iva kāma upapadaḥ
translated: or they are bound up with sense desires. And though other things connected with sense desires exist, only applied thought is called the “arising of sense desires”

original: dhātusaddo niruḷho veditabbo vitakkassa kāmappasaṅgappavattiyā sātisayattā. Esa nayo
analyzed: dhātu saddaḥ niruḷhaḥ veditabbaḥ vitakkassa kāma ppasaṅga ppavattiyā sa atisaya ttā esa nayo
translated: because it is the most outstanding in causing the occurrence of sense desires. So too with ill will, etc.🔽“Hurtfulness” is the wish to hurt another and oneself.

original: byāpādadhātuādīsu. Parassa attano ca dukkhāyanaṃ vihiṃsā. Vihiṃsantīti hantuṃ icchanti.🔽182. Ubhayattha uppannopi abhijjhāsaṃyogena kammapathajananato anabhijjhākammapathabhindanato
analyzed: byāpāda dhātu ādīsu parassa attano ca dukkhāyanam vihiṃsā vihiṃsanti iti hantum icchanti  ubhayattha uppannaḥ api abhijjhā saṃyogena kamma patha jananataḥ anabhijjhā kamma patha bhindanataḥ
translated: “Ill will” is the wish to hurt.

original: ca kāmavitakko “kammapathabhedo”ti vutto. Byāpādo panāti byāpādavacanena byāpādavitakkaṃ🔽dasseti. So hi byāpādadhātūti. Tathā vihiṃsāya vihiṃsādhātuyā ca byāpādavasena yathāsambhavaṃ
analyzed: ca kāma vitakko kamma patha bhedo ti vuttaḥ byāpādaḥ pana ati byāpāda vacanena byāpāda vitakkam  dasseti saḥ hi tathā vihiṃsāya vihiṃsā dhātuyā ca byāpāda vasena yathāsambhavam
translated: Though it arises in both, it is called “a way of thinking about sense desires” because it generates a course of action by being associated with greed, and because it is distinguished as a course of action by non-greed.🔽But ill will is shown by the word “hurtfulness” .🔽For that is the “ill-will element” . So too, “hurtfulness” and the “hurtfulness element” should be construed respectively as a course of action by way of ill will and as a way of thinking about sense desires by way of ill will and by way of killing breathing things, etc., as far as possible.

original: pāṇātipātādivasena ca kammapathabhedo yojetabbo. Etthāti dvīsu tikesu. Sabbakāmāvacarasabbakusalasaṅgāhakehi
analyzed: pāṇātipāta ādi vasena ca kamma patha bhedaḥ yojetabbaḥ ettha ati dvīsu tikesu sabba kāmāvacara sabba kusala saṅgāhakehi
translated: Herein, in the two triads,

original: itare dve dve saṅgahetvā kathanaṃ sabbasaṅgāhikakathā. Etthāti pana etasmiṃ chakketi
analyzed: itare dve dve saṅgahetvā kathanaṃ sabbasaṅgāhika kathā ettha ati pana etasmim chakkā iti
translated: The other two are called “all-inclusive” because they are spoken of by including two kinds of object each.

original: vuccamāne kāmadhātuvacanena kāmāvacarānaṃ nekkhammadhātuādīnañca gahaṇaṃ āpajjati.
analyzed: vuccamāne kāmadhātu vacanena kāmāvacarānam nekkhammadhātu ādīnam ca gahaṇam āpajjati
translated: Herein, when the words “in the six” are spoken, then by the words “sense-desire element” the inclusion of those of the fine-material sphere and those of the immaterial sphere is implied.

original: Labhāpetabbāti cakkhudhātādibhāvaṃ labhamānā dhammā nīharitvā dassanena labhāpetabbā.
analyzed: labhāpetabbā ti cakkhu dhātā ādi bhāvam labhamānāḥ dhammāḥ nīharitvā dassanena labhāpetabbā
translated: “Can be brought to”: the states that are capable of being brought to the state of the eye element, etc., can be brought to by seeing.

original: Carati etthāti cāro, kiṃ carati? Sammasanaṃ, sammasanassa cāro sammasanacāro, tebhūmakadhammānaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
analyzed: carati ettha ati cāro kim carati sammasanam sammasanassa cāro sammasana cāro tebhūmaka dhammānam adhivacanaṃ
translated: “The course is in that”: the course is that in which one courses. What does one course? One courses in the investigation. The course of the investigation is the course of investigation. It is a term for states in the three planes.

original: Suttantabhājanīyavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: suttantabhājanīya vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Suttantabhajanīya is ended.

original: 2. Abhidhammabhājanīyavaṇṇanā
translated: The Abhidhammabhajanīya

original: 183. Cakkhussāti visesakāraṇaṃ asādhāraṇasāmibhāvena niddiṭṭhaṃ. Tañhi puggalantarāsādhāraṇaṃ
analyzed: cakkhussa ati visesa kāraṇam asādhāraṇa sāmi bhāvena niddiṭṭham tat hi puggala antara asādhāraṇam
translated: “Of the eye”: the reason for the distinction is shown by the word “element” in the sense of a special kind of owner. For that is not common to other persons,

original: nīlādisabbarūpasādhāraṇañca. Vidahatīti evaṃ evañca tayā pavattitabbanti viniyujjamānaṃ
analyzed: nīla ādi sabba rūpa sādhāraṇam ca vidahati iti evam evam ca tayā pavattitabbanti viniyujjamānam
translated: but it is common to all visible data such as blue, etc.

original: viya uppādetīti attho. Vidahatīti ca dhātuattho eva visiṭṭho upasaggena dīpitoti
analyzed: viyaḥ uppādeti iti atthaḥ vidahati iti ca dhātu atthaḥ eva visiṭṭhaḥ upasaggena dīpitaḥ ti
translated: “It causes to see”: the meaning is that it causes to arise as if it were directing thus “You must occur thus and thus.” And the meaning of “element” is shown by the prefix vi- as a special one, since it is the cause of the seeing.

original: vināpi upasaggena dhātūti eso saddo tamatthaṃ vadatīti daṭṭhabbo. Kattukammabhāvakaraṇaadhikaraṇesu
analyzed: vinā api upasaggena dhātu uti esaḥ saddo tam attham vadati iti daṭṭhabbo kattu kamma bhāva karaṇa adhikaraṇesu
translated: The word dhātu should be regarded as expressing that meaning even without a prefix.🔽The five meanings stated are those of the doing, the action, the state, the instrument, and the cause.

original: dhātupadasiddhi hotīti pañcapi ete atthā vuttā. Suvaṇṇarajatādidhātuyo suvaṇṇādīnaṃ bījabhūtā selādayo.
analyzed: ete atthā vuttā suvaṇṇa rajata ādi dhātuyaḥ suvaṇṇa ādīnam bīja bhūtā
translated: The minerals such as gold, silver, etc., are the seeds of gold, etc.

original: Attano sabhāvaṃ dhārentīti dhātuyoti etthāpi dhātīti dhātūti padasiddhi veditabbā.
analyzed: attano sabhāvam dhārenti iti ettha api dhāti iti dhātu iti pada siddhi veditabbā
translated: They are called dhātu because they bear their own individual essence. Herein, the derivation of the word should be understood in this way: dhārayanti iti dhātuyo.🔽For the word dhātu has the meaning of “bearing” too.

original: Dhātu-saddo eva hi dhāraṇatthopi hotīti. Kattuatthopi cāyaṃ purimena asadisoti nissattasabhāvamattadhāraṇañca🔽dhātu-saddassa padhāno atthoti visuṃ vutto. Dhātuyo viya dhātuyoti ettha sīha-saddo
analyzed: dhātu saddaḥ eva hi dhāraṇa atthaḥ api hoti iti kattu atthaḥ api ca ayam purimena asadisaḥ iti nissatta sabhāva matta dhāraṇam ca  dhātu saddassa padhānaḥ atthaḥ ti visum vuttaḥ dhātuyaḥ viya dhātuyaḥ ti ettha sīha saddaḥ
translated: And this meaning of “doing” is different from the previous one. So the bearing of mere individual essence without a living being is stated🔽as the principal meaning of the word dhātu and is therefore mentioned separately.

original: viya kesarimhi niruḷho purisesu, selāvayavesu niruḷho dhātu-saddo ca cakkhādīsu upacarito
analyzed: viya kesarimhi niruḷhaḥ purisesu sela avayavesu niruḷhaḥ dhātu saddo ca cakkha ādīsu upacarito
translated: Herein, just as the word “lion” is established among lions and the word “man” is established among men, so too the word “dhātu” is established among the minerals, and the word “dhātu” is figuratively applied to the eye, etc.,🔽as if it were established among them.

original: daṭṭhabbo. Ñāṇañca ñeyyañca ñāṇañeyyāni, tesaṃ avayavā tappabhedabhūtā dhātuyo ñāṇañeyyāvayavā.
analyzed: daṭṭhabbaḥ ñāṇam ca ñeyyam ca ñāṇa ñeyyāni tesam avayavā tad pabheda bhūtāḥ dhātuyaḥ ñāṇa ñeyya avayavā
translated: The dhammas that are both knowledge and objects of knowledge are the dhammas that are knowledge and the dhammas that are objects of knowledge. The dhātus that are parts of the dhammas that are both knowledge and objects of knowledge are the dhātus that are parts of the dhammas that are knowledge and the dhātus that are parts of the dhammas that are objects of knowledge.

original: Tattha ñāṇappabhedā dhammadhātuekadeso, ñeyyappabhedā aṭṭhārasāpīti ñāṇañeyyāvayavamattā
analyzed: tattha ñāṇa ppabhedā dhammadhātu ekadeso ñeyya ppabhedā aṭṭhārasā api iti ñāṇa ñeyya avayava mattā
translated: Herein, the one part of the Dhamma-element consisting of knowledge is the division of knowledge, and the eighteen kinds of objects of knowledge are the division of what is to be known. So the elements are just the parts of knowledge and what is to be known.

original: dhātuyo honti. Atha vā ñāṇena ñātabbo sabhāvo dhātusaddena vuccamāno aviparītato
analyzed: dhātuyaḥ honti atha vā ñāṇena ñātabbaḥ sabhāvaḥ dhātu saddena vuccamānaḥ a viparītato
translated: Or alternatively, the individual essence that is to be known by means of knowledge is called an element in the sense of what is not misapprehended as the opposite,

original: ñāṇañeyyo, na diṭṭhiādīhi viparītaggāhakehi ñeyyoti attho. Tassa ñāṇañeyyassa avayavā🔽cakkhādayo. Visabhāgalakkhaṇāvayavesu rasādīsu niruḷho dhātu-saddo tādisesu aññāvayavesu
analyzed: ñāṇa ñeyyaḥ na diṭṭhi ādīhi viparīta ggāhakehi ñeyyaḥ ti attho tassa ñāṇa ñeyyassa avayavā  cakkha ādayaḥ visa bhāga lakkhaṇa avayavesu rasa ādīsu niruḷhaḥ dhātu saddo tādisesu añña avayavesu
translated: which is to be known by means of knowledge, not as what is to be known by means of views, etc., that apprehend the opposite. The parts of that which is to be known by means of knowledge🔽are the eye, etc.,🔽The term element, which is established in the case of taste, etc., as the parts that have different individual essences, should be regarded as figuratively used in the case of the other parts, the eye, etc.,

original: cakkhādīsu upacarito daṭṭhabbo, rasādīsu viya vā cakkhādīsu niruḷhova. Nijjīvamattassetaṃ
analyzed: cakkha ādīsu upacaritaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ rasa ādīsu viya vā cakkha ādīsu niruḷhaḥ uva nijjīva mattassa etam
translated: or it should be regarded as established in the case of the eye, etc., as in the case of taste, etc.

original: adhivacananti etena nijjīvamattapadatthe dhātu-saddassa niruḷhataṃ dasseti. Cha dhātuyo
analyzed: adhivacanam ti etena nijjīva matta padatthe dhātu saddassa niruḷha tam dasseti cha
translated: This is a mere designation for the individual essence. By this he shows that the term element is established in the sense of the mere individual essence.

original: etassāti chadhātuyo, yo loke “puriso”ti dhammasamudāyo vuccati, so chadhāturo channaṃ
analyzed: etassa ati cha dhātuyaḥ yaḥ loke puriso ti dhamma samudāyo vuccati so cha dhāturo channam
translated: The “six elements” are the “six elements” in the person called “a man” in the world. The person is the mere collection of the individual essences of the six elements, earth, etc.,

original: pathavīādīnaṃ nijjīvamattasabhāvānaṃ samudāyamatto, na ettha jīvo puriso vā atthīti attho.
analyzed: pathavī ādīnam nijjīva matta sabhāvānam samudāya mattaḥ na ettha jīvo puriso vā atthi iti attho
translated: there is no soul or person here.

original: Cakkhādīnaṃ kamo pubbe vuttoti idha ekekasmiṃ tike tiṇṇaṃ tiṇṇaṃ dhātūnaṃ kamaṃ dassento🔽āha “hetuphalānupubbavavatthānavasenā”ti. Hetuphalānaṃ anupubbavavatthānaṃ hetuphalabhāvova.
analyzed: cakkha ādīnam kamaḥ pubbe vuttaḥ ti idha ekekasmim tike tiṇṇam tiṇṇam dhātūnam kamam dassento  āha hetu phala anupubba vavatthāna vasena ati hetu phalānam anupubba vavatthānam hetu phala bhāvaḥ uva
translated: The order of the eye, etc., has already been stated above. So here, showing the order of the three elements in each triad, he said, “In accordance with the order of cause and fruit.” The order of cause and fruit is the state of being cause and fruit.

original: Tattha hetūti paccayo adhippeto. Phalanti paccayuppannanti āha “cakkhudhātū”tiādi.
analyzed: tattha hetū ti paccayaḥ adhippetaḥ phalanti paccaya uppannanti āha cakkhu dhātu utiādi
translated: Herein, cause is intended as condition. They fruit as arisen from conditions. Thus he said, “The eye element” and so on.

original: Manodhātudhammadhātūnañca manoviññāṇassa hetubhāvo yathāsambhavaṃ yojetabbo, dvārabhūtamanovasena
analyzed: manaḥ dhātu dhammadhātūnam ca manaḥ viññāṇassa hetu bhāvaḥ yathāsambhavam yojetabbaḥ dvāra bhūta manaḥ vasena
translated: And the state of being cause of the mind element and the mental-data element for the mind-consciousness element should be construed as appropriate.

original: vā tassā manodhātuyā.🔽Sabbāsaṃ vasenāti yathāvuttānaṃ ābhādhātuādīnaṃ pañcatiṃsāya dhātūnaṃ vasena. Aparamatthasabhāvassa
analyzed: vā tassā manaḥ dhātuyā  sabbāsam vasena ati yathā vuttānam ābhā dhātu ādīnam pañcatiṃsāya dhātūnam vasena aparamattha sabhāvassa
translated: Or it is the mind element as the door.

original: paramatthasabhāvesu na kadāci antogadhatā atthīti āha “sabhāvato vijjamānāna”nti.
analyzed: paramattha sabhāvesu na kadāci antogadha tā atthi iti āha sabhāvataḥ
translated: In all cases: in the case of the fifty-five elements stated thus, beginning with the light element. For there is never any inclusion of the individual essence of the ultimate reality in the ultimate realities. Thus he said, “Of those existing in the ultimate sense” .

original: Candābhāsūriyābhādikā vaṇṇanibhā evāti āha “rūpadhātuyeva hi ābhādhātū”ti. Rūpādipaṭibaddhāti
analyzed: canda ābhā sūriya ābhā ādikāḥ vaṇṇa nibhāḥ eva ati āha rūpa dhātuyā iva hi ābhā dhātu uti rūpa ādi paṭibaddhā ati
translated: The light of the moon, the light of the sun, etc., are only the appearance of colour. Thus he said, “For the light element is only the visible-data element” . Bound up with visible data, etc.,

original: rāgavatthubhāvena gahetabbākāro subhanimittanti sandhāya “rūpādayovā”ti avatvā paṭibaddhavacanaṃ
analyzed: rāga vatthu bhāvena subha nimittanti sandhāya rūpa ādayaḥ vāti avatvā paṭibaddha vacanam
translated: The mode of apprehension as a basis for lust is the sign of the beautiful. The words “or the visible-data base, etc.” are stated with reference to that.

original: āha. Asatipi rāgavatthubhāve “kusalavipākārammaṇā subhā dhātū”ti dutiyo vikappo vutto.
analyzed: āha asati api rāga vatthu bhāve kusala vipāka ārammaṇā subhā dhātu iti dutiyaḥ vikappaḥ vutto
translated: But the second alternative, “The beautiful elements are the result of profitable kamma,” is stated without reference to the mode of apprehension as a basis for lust.🔽The element of ill will is volition or desire to harm another.

original: Vihiṃsādhātu cetanā, paraviheṭhanachando vā. Avihiṃsā karuṇā.
analyzed: vihiṃsā dhātu cetanā para viheṭhana chandaḥ vai avihiṃsā karuṇā
translated: The element of non-ill will is kindness.🔽Both: the mind-consciousness element and the mental-data element.

original: Ubhopīti dhammadhātumanoviññāṇadhātuyo. Hīnādīsu purimanayena hīḷitā cakkhādayo hīnā,🔽sambhāvitā paṇītā, nātihīḷitā nātisambhāvitā majjhimāti khandhavibhaṅge āgatahīnadukatoyeva
analyzed: ubho api iti dhammadhātu manaḥ viññāṇa dhātuyaḥ hīna ādīsu purima nayena cakkha ādayaḥ hīnā  sambhāvitā paṇītā na ati hīḷitā na ati sambhāvitā majjhimā ati khandha vibhaṅge āgata hīna duka toyā iva
translated: The inferior, etc., are the eye, etc., that are despised in the way already stated.

original: nīharitvā majjhimā dhātu vuttāti veditabbā. Viññāṇadhātu yadipi chaviññāṇadhātuvasena🔽vibhattā, tathāpi “viññāṇadhātuggahaṇena tassā purecārikapacchācārikattā manodhātu
analyzed: nīharitvā majjhimā dhātu vuttā iti veditabbā viññāṇa dhātu yadi api cha viññāṇa dhātu vasena  vibhattā tathā api viññāṇa dhātu ggahaṇena tassā manaḥ dhātu
translated: The superior are those that are esteemed. The medium element should be understood as the medium pair stated in the Paṭṭhāna in the section on the aggregates, namely, those that are neither despised nor esteemed.🔽Although the consciousness element is analyzed into the six classes of consciousness, nevertheless it is said that “the mind element is included by the words ‘consciousness element’ because it precedes and follows the other classes of consciousness” .

original: gahitāva hotī”ti vuttattā āha “viññāṇadhātu…pe… sattaviññāṇasaṅkhepoyevā”ti. Anekesaṃ
analyzed: gahitā ava hoti iti vutta ttā āha viññāṇa dhātupe satta viññāṇa saṅkhepoyā iva ati anekesam
translated: That is why the consciousness element is said to be “the seven classes of consciousness in brief.”

original: cakkhudhātuādīnaṃ, tāsu ca ekekissā nānappakāratāya nānādhātūnaṃ vasena anekadhātunānādhātuloko
analyzed: cakkhu dhātu ādīnam tāsu ca ekekissā nānā pakāra tāya nānā dhātūnam vasena aneka dhātu nānā dhātu loko
translated: And in each of these there are many elements in the various aspects of the different kinds of eye element, etc.,

original: vuttoti āha “aṭṭhārasadhātuppabhedamattamevā”ti.
analyzed: vuttaḥ iti āha aṭṭhārasa dhātu pabheda mattam eva iti
translated: so the world is of many elements and various elements. That is why it is said, “merely the eighteen elements distinguished in this way.”

original: “Cakkhusotaghānajivhākāyamanomanoviññāṇadhātubhedenā”ti aṭṭhakathāyaṃ likhitaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: cakkhu sota ghāna jivhā kāya manaḥ manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu bhedena ati aṭṭhakathā ayam likhitam tattha
translated: “By the division of the eye element, ear element, nose element, tongue element, body element, mind element, mind-consciousness element” is written in the commentary. Herein,

original: na cakkhādīnaṃ kevalena dhātu-saddena sambandho adhippeto vijānanasabhāvassa pabhedavacanato.
analyzed: na cakkha ādīnam kevalena dhātu saddena sambandhaḥ adhippetaḥ vijānana sabhāvassa pabheda vacanato
translated: the eye, etc., are not intended by the mere word element, because that would be a misnomer, since it is a term for a kind of consciousness.🔽And if they were intended by the word “mind element,” then the two “mind” terms would not be necessary,

original: Viññāṇadhātu-saddena sambandhe kariyamāne dve manogahaṇāni na kattabbāni. Na hi dve
analyzed: viññāṇa dhātu saddena sambandhe kariyamāne dve manaḥ gahaṇāni na kattabbāni na hi dve
translated: for there is no such thing as two mind-consciousness elements.

original: manoviññāṇadhātuyo atthīti. “Cakkhu…pe… kāyamanoviññāṇamanodhātū”ti vā vattabbaṃ
analyzed: manaḥ viññāṇa dhātuyaḥ atthi iti cakkhu pe kāya manaḥ viññāṇa manaḥ dhātū ti vā vattabbam
translated: Or it could be said, “By the division of the eye element … the body element, mind element, mind-consciousness element”

original: atulyayoge dvandasamāsābhāvato. Ayaṃ panettha pāṭho siyā “cakkhu…pe… kāyaviññāṇamanomanoviññāṇadhātubhedenā”ti.
analyzed: atulya yoge dvanda samāsa abhāvataḥ ayam pana ittha pāṭhaḥ siyā cakkhupe kāya viññāṇa manaḥ manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu bhedena ati
translated: since a dvanda compound is not used for unequal things. But this reading could be: “By the division of the eye element … the body-consciousness element, mind element, mind-consciousness element.”

original: Khandhāyatanadesanā saṅkhepadesanā, indriyadesanā vitthāradesanāti tadubhayaṃ apekkhitvā
analyzed: khandha āyatana desanā saṅkhepa desanā indriya desanā vitthāra desanā ati tat ubhayam apekkhitvā
translated: The teaching in the “aggregates” section is a brief teaching, and the teaching in the “bases” section is an extended teaching. So,

original: nātisaṅkhepavitthārā dhātudesanā. Atha vā suttantabhājanīye vuttadhātudesanā atisaṅkhepadesanā,
analyzed: na ati saṅkhepa vitthārā dhātu desanā atha vā suttanta bhājanīye vutta dhātu desanā ati saṅkhepa desanā
translated: The teaching of the elements is neither too brief nor too detailed. Or alternatively, the teaching of the elements given in the “Basket of Discourses” is a brief teaching,

original: ābhādhātuādīnaṃ anekadhātunānādhātuantānaṃ vasena desetabbā ativitthāradesanāti tadubhayaṃ
analyzed: ābhā dhātu ādīnam aneka dhātu nānā dhātu antānam vasena desetabbā ati vitthāra desanā ati tat ubhayam
translated: and the teaching given in the “Basket of the Higher Teaching” is a detailed teaching, since it is to be taught by way of the many elements and the various elements.

original: apekkhitvā ayaṃ “nātisaṅkhepavitthārā”ti.
analyzed: apekkhitvā ayam na ati saṅkhepa vitthārā ati
translated: This teaching of the elements is neither too brief nor too detailed because it is given in consideration of both of these.

original: Bherītalaṃ viya cakkhudhātu saddassa viya viññāṇassa nissayabhāvato. Etāhi ca upamāhi🔽nijjīvānaṃ bherītaladaṇḍādīnaṃ samāyoge nijjīvānaṃ saddādīnaṃ viya nijjīvānaṃ cakkhurūpādīnaṃ
analyzed: bherī talam viya cakkhu dhātu saddassa viya viññāṇassa nissaya bhāvataḥ etāhi ca upamāhi  nijjīvānam bherī tala daṇḍa ādīnam samāyoge nijjīvānam sadda ādīnam viya nijjīvānam cakkhu rūpa ādīnam
translated: The eye element is like the surface of a drum, and consciousness is like the sound, because they are the support.🔽And by these similes he shows that the occurrence of the eye-consciousness, etc., which are devoid of life, is like the occurrence of the sounds, etc., which are devoid of life, when there is a combination of things devoid of life, such as the surface of the drum, the stick, etc.

original: samāyoge nijjīvānaṃ cakkhuviññāṇādīnaṃ pavattīti kāraṇaphalānaṃ dhātumattattā kārakavedakabhāvavirahaṃ dasseti.
analyzed: samāyoge nijjīvānam cakkhu viññāṇa ādīnam pavatti iti kāraṇa phalānam dhātumat ta ttā kāraka vedaka bhāva viraham dasseti
translated: He shows the absence of an agent and an experiencer because the elements are mere causes and effects.

original: Purecarānucarā viyāti nijjīvassa kassaci keci nijjīvā purecarānucarā viyāti attho.
analyzed: purecara anucarā viyā ati nijjīvassa kassaci keci nijjīvā purecara anucarā viyā attho
translated: Like the forerunners and followers: the meaning is that some things devoid of life are like the forerunners and followers of something else that is devoid of life.

original: Manodhātuyeva vā attano khaṇaṃ anativattantī attano khaṇaṃ anativattantānaṃyeva cakkhuviññāṇādīnaṃ🔽avijjamānepi purecarānucarabhāve pubbakālāparakālatāya purecarānucarā viya daṭṭhabbāti
analyzed: vā attanaḥ khaṇam an ativattantī attanaḥ khaṇam an ativattantānam yeva cakkhu viññāṇa ādīnam  a vijjamāne api purecara anucara bhāve pubba kāla apara kāla tāya purecara anucarāḥ viya daṭṭhabbā ati
translated: which do not outlive their own occasions.🔽It should be regarded as like a ladder, because of its association with the three kinds of suffering.🔽The suffering of change is the suffering of the change of what is desirable.

original: attho. Sallamiva sūlamiva tividhadukkhatāsamāyogato daṭṭhabbo. Āsāyeva dukkhaṃ āsādukkhaṃ,
analyzed: atthaḥ sallam iva sūlam iva tividha dukkha tā samāyogataḥ daṭṭhabbo āsāya iva dukkham āsādukkham
translated: For perception perceives what is desirable, such as visible forms, etc., as beautiful, etc., and it generates the hope for their acquisition.🔽When the desirable object is not acquired, the suffering of change arises in the form of the frustration of the hope.🔽The suffering of suffering is the suffering of the suffering of suffering.

original: āsāvighātaṃ dukkhaṃ vā. Saññā hi abhūtaṃ dukkhadukkhampi subhādito sañjānantī taṃ🔽āsaṃ tassā ca vighātaṃ āsīsitasubhādiasiddhiyā janetīti. Kammappadhānā saṅkhārāti🔽“paṭisandhiyaṃ pakkhipanato”tiādimāha. Jātidukkhānubandhanatoti attanā nibbattiyamānena
analyzed: āsā vighātam dukkham vā saññā hi a bhūtam dukkha dukkham pi subha āditas sañjānantī tam  ca vighātam janeti iti kamma ppadhānā saṅkhārā ati  paṭisandhiyam pakkhipanato tiādim āha jāti dukkha anubandhanato ti attanā nibbattiyamānena
translated: The suffering of suffering is the suffering that arises in the form of the suffering of suffering, which is called the suffering of suffering because it is the suffering that arises in the form of the suffering of suffering.🔽The suffering of suffering is the suffering that arises in the form of the suffering of suffering, which is called the suffering of suffering because it is the suffering that arises in the form of the suffering of suffering.🔽The suffering of suffering is the suffering that arises in the form of the suffering of suffering, which is called the suffering of suffering because it is the suffering that arises in the form of the suffering of suffering.🔽The suffering of suffering is the suffering that arises in the form of the suffering of suffering, which is called the suffering of suffering because it is the suffering that arises in the form of the suffering of suffering.🔽The suffering of suffering is the suffering that arises in the form of the suffering of suffering, which is called the suffering of suffering because it is the suffering that arises in the form of the suffering of suffering.🔽The suffering of suffering is the suffering that arises in the form of the suffering of suffering, which is called the suffering of suffering because it is the suffering that arises in the form of the suffering of suffering.🔽The suffering of suffering is the suffering that arises in the form of the suffering of suffering, which is called the suffering of suffering because it is the suffering that arises in the form of the suffering of suffering.

original: jātidukkhena anubandhattā. Bhavapaccayā jāti hi jātidukkhanti. Padumaṃ viya dissamānaṃ
analyzed: jāti dukkhena bhava paccayā jāti hi jāti dukkhanti padumam viya dissamānam
translated: The suffering of suffering is the suffering that arises in the form of the suffering of suffering, which is called the suffering of suffering because it is the suffering that arises in the form of the suffering of suffering.🔽The suffering of suffering is the suffering

original: khuracakkaṃ viya rūpampi itthiyādibhāvena dissamānaṃ nānāvidhupaddavaṃ janeti. Sabbe
analyzed: khura cakkam viya rūpam pi itthiya ādi bhāvena dissamānam nānā vidhu paddavam janeti sabbe
translated: Form, though seen as a woman, etc., generates various kinds of misfortune like a razor’s edge. All

original: anatthā rāgādayo jātiādayo ca visabhūtā asantā sappaṭibhayā cāti tappaṭipakkhabhūtattā
analyzed: anatthāḥ rāga ādayaḥ jāti ādayo ca asantā sappaṭibhayā ca ati tad paṭipakkha bhūta ttā
translated: harm is due to lust, etc., and to birth, etc., which are contrary, unreal, and dangerous. Therefore

original: amatādito daṭṭhabbā.🔽Muñcitvāpi aññaṃ gahetvāvāti etena makkaṭassa gahitaṃ sākhaṃ muñcitvāpi ākāse ṭhātuṃ🔽asamatthatā viya gahitārammaṇaṃ muñcitvāpi aññaṃ aggahetvā pavattituṃ asamatthatāya
analyzed: amata āditaḥ daṭṭhabbā  muñcitvā api aññam gahetvā avāti etena makkaṭassa gahitam sākham muñcitvā api ākāse ṭhātum  asamattha tā viya gahita ārammaṇam muñcitvā api aññam aggahetvā pavattitum asamattha tāya
translated: they should be seen as the opposite of the deathless.

original: makkaṭasamānataṃ dasseti. Aṭṭhivedhaviddhopi damathaṃ anupagacchanto duṭṭhasso assakhaḷuṅko.
analyzed: makkaṭa samāna tam dasseti aṭṭhi vedha viddhaḥ api damatham an upagacchantaḥ duṭṭhasso assa khaḷuṅko
translated: “Even if he lets go of one and seizes another”: just as a monkey, even if he lets go of a branch he has seized, is unable to stay in the air and must seize another branch, so too, the mind, even if it lets go of a previously cognized object, is unable to stay in the air without seizing another object. This shows the similarity of the mind to a monkey. A horse that, even when pierced by a goad, does not submit to control is called a “wild horse.”

original: Raṅgagato naṭo raṅganaṭo.
analyzed: raṅga gataḥ naṭaḥ raṅga naṭaḥ
translated: An actor on the stage is a “stage actor.”

original: 184. Cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe cātiādinā dvārārammaṇesu ekavacanabahuvacananiddesā ekanānāsantānagatānaṃ ekasantānagataviññāṇapaccayabhāvato ekanānājātikattā ca.
analyzed: cakkhum ca paṭicca rūpe ca ati ādinā dvāra ārammaṇesu ekavacana bahuvacana niddesāḥ eka nānā santāna gatānam eka santāna gata viññāṇa paccaya bhāvataḥ eka nānā jātika ttā ca
translated: “With eye and forms” and so on: the singular and plural forms in the expressions “with eye and with forms” are used because consciousness is a condition for the eye, etc., that are singular and plural, respectively, and because consciousness has a single and a multiple nature.

original: Sabbadhammesūti ettha sabba-saddo adhikāravasena yathāvuttaviññāṇasaṅkhāte ārammaṇasaṅkhāte
analyzed: sabba dhammesu iti ettha sabba saddaḥ adhikāra vasena yathā vutta viññāṇa saṅkhāte ārammaṇa saṅkhāte
translated: Herein, the word all in the phrase in regard to all ideas refers by ellipsis to the object consisting of the kinds of consciousness stated thus and to the object consisting of the ideas stated thus.

original: vā padesasabbasmiṃ tiṭṭhatīti daṭṭhabbo. Manoviññāṇadhātuniddese “cakkhuviññāṇadhātuyā
analyzed: vā padesa sabbasmin tiṭṭhati iti daṭṭhabbaḥ manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu niddese cakkhu viññāṇa dhātuyā
translated: Herein, the word all should be regarded as standing for the whole of the objective fields stated as “ consciousness” and “ mental datum” as already mentioned, or for the whole of the objective fields stated as “ visible data” and so on, according to context.

original: uppajjitvā niruddhasamanantarā uppajjati manodhātu, manodhātuyāpi uppajjitvā niruddhasamanantarā
analyzed: uppajjitvā niruddha samanantarā uppajjati manaḥ dhātu manaḥ dhātuyā api uppajjitvā niruddha samanantarā
translated: In the description of the mind-consciousness element, the words “arises next to the eye-consciousness element” and “arises next to the mind element” show that just as the mind element arises next to the eye-consciousness element, so it arises next to the mind element too.

original: uppajjati citta”nti cakkhuviññāṇadhātānantaraṃ manodhātu viya manodhātānantarampi🔽uppajjati cittanti yāva aññā manodhātu uppajjissati, tāva pavattaṃ sabbaṃ cittaṃ
analyzed: uppajjati cittam ti cakkhu viññāṇa dhātā anantaram manaḥ dhātu viya manaḥ dhātā anantaram pi  uppajjati cittanti yāva aññā manaḥ dhātu uppajjissati tāva pavattam sabbam cittam
translated: And the words “arises next to the mind element” show that just as the mind element arises next to the eye-consciousness element, so consciousness arises next to the mind element too.

original: ekattena gahetvā vuttanti evampi attho labbhati. Evañhi sati manoviññāṇadhātānantaraṃ
analyzed: ekattena gahetvā vuttan ti evam pi atthaḥ labbhati evam hi sati manaḥ viññāṇa dhātā anantaram
translated: So the meaning can also be regarded as follows: all consciousness occurring as long as there is the arising of the mind element is included under the heading of mind-consciousness element.

original: uppannāya manodhātuyā manoviññāṇadhātubhāvappasaṅgo na hotiyeva. Pañcaviññāṇadhātumanodhātukkamanidassanañhi
analyzed: uppannāya manaḥ dhātuyā manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu bhāva ppasaṅgaḥ na pañca viññāṇa dhātu manaḥ dhātu kkama nidassanam hi
translated: For in that case there is no question of the mind element that arises next to the mind-consciousness element being included in the mind-consciousness element.

original: tabbidhurasabhāvena uppattiṭṭhānena ca paricchinnassa cittassa manoviññāṇadhātubhāvadassanatthaṃ,🔽na anantaruppattimattenāti tabbidhurasabhāve ekattaṃ upanetvā dassanaṃ yujjati. Anupanītepi
analyzed: tad bidhu rasa bhāvena uppatti ṭṭhānena ca paricchinnassa cittassa manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu bhāva dassana attham  na anantara uppattimattena ati tad bidhu rasa bhāve ekattam upanetvā dassanam yujjati an upanīte pi
translated: and the purpose of the words “and so on” is to show that the consciousness delimited by the place of its origination, which has the same objective field as that, is the mind-consciousness element.🔽It is not because of mere immediate succession. So it is proper to show the unity of the same objective field by the words “and so on.”

original: ekatte tabbidhurasabhāve ekasmiṃ dassite sāmaññavasena aññampi sabbaṃ taṃ sabhāvaṃ🔽dassitaṃ hotīti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Pi-saddena manoviññāṇadhātusampiṇḍane ca sati “manoviññāṇadhātuyāpi🔽samanantarā uppajjati cittaṃ…pe… tajjā manoviññāṇadhātū”ti manoviññāṇadhātuggahaṇena
analyzed: eka atte tad bidhura sabhāve ekasmin dassite sāmañña vasena aññam pi sabbam tam sabhāvam  dassitam hoti iti daṭṭhabbam pi saddena manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu sampiṇḍane ca sati manaḥ viññāṇa dhātuyā api  samanantarā uppajjati cittaṃ pe tad jā manaḥ viññāṇa dhātū ti manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu ggahaṇena
translated: And even when the unity is not shown, it should be regarded as shown by the general statement, since all that has the same objective field is shown by the words “and so on.”🔽And if, when the words “and so on” include the mind-consciousness element, the words “after the mind-consciousness element consciousness arises … having that same as its object”🔽include the mind element that arises next to the life-continuum, then the words “after the mind-consciousness element” should be understood to include the mind element.

original: bhavaṅgānantaraṃ uppannaṃ manodhātucittaṃ nivattitaṃ hotīti ce? Na, tassā manoviññāṇadhātubhāvāsiddhito.
analyzed: bhavaṅga anantaram uppannam manaḥ dhātu cittam nivattitam hoti iti ce na tassāḥ manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu bhāva asiddhito
translated: But that is not so, because the mind element does not exist as the mind-consciousness element.

original: Na hi yaṃ codīyati, tadeva parihārāya hotīti.
analyzed: na hi yam codīyati tat eva parihārāya hoti iti
translated: For what is questioned is not the answer.

original: Manodhātuyāpi manoviññāṇadhātuyāpīti manadvayavacanena dvinnaṃ aññamaññavidhurasabhāvatā
analyzed: manaḥ dhātuyā api manaḥ viññāṇa dhātuyā api iti mana dvaya vacanena dvinnam añña mañña vidhu rasa bhāva tā
translated: And by the words “after the mind element and after the mind-consciousness element” the difference of the two is shown by the double expression.

original: dassitāti teneva manodhātāvajjanassa manoviññāṇadhātubhāvo nivattitoti daṭṭhabbo.🔽Vutto hi tassa manoviññāṇadhātuvidhuro manodhātusabhāvo “sabbadhammesu vā pana paṭhamasamannāhāro
analyzed: dassitā ati tena iva manaḥ dhātā avajjanassa manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu bhāvaḥ nivattito ti daṭṭhabbo  vuttaḥ hi tassa manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu vidhuraḥ manaḥ dhātu sabhāvaḥ sabba dhammesu vā pana paṭhama samannāhāraḥ
translated: “Is shown” should be understood as the state of the mind-consciousness element being turned away from the function of adverting by means of that adverting.🔽For the bare state of the mind element, which is the opposite of the mind-consciousness element, is stated thus: “Or the first adverting occurs to any of the six objects” .

original: uppajjatī”tiādinā. Sā sabbāpīti etaṃ mukhamattanidassanaṃ. Na hi javanapariyosānā🔽eva manoviññāṇadhātu, tadārammaṇādīnipi pana hontiyevāti. Evaṃ pañcaviññāṇadhātumanodhātuvisiṭṭhasabhāvavasena🔽sabbaṃ manoviññāṇadhātuṃ dassetvā puna manodvāravasena sātisayaṃ javanamanoviññāṇadhātuṃ🔽dassento “manañca paṭiccā”tiādimāha. Yadi pana channaṃ dvārānaṃ vasena javanāvasānāneva
analyzed: uppajjati itiādinā sā sabbā api iti etam mukha matta nidassanam na hi javana pariyosānā  eva manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu tad ārammaṇa ādīni pi pana evam pañca viññāṇa dhātu manaḥ dhātu visiṭṭha sabhāva vasena  sabbam manaḥ viññāṇa dhātum dassetvā puna manaḥ dvāra vasena sa atisayam javana manaḥ viññāṇa dhātum  dassentaḥ manam ca paṭicca ati ādim āha yadi pana channam vasena
translated: “All that” is said merely by way of a starting point. For the mind-consciousness element is not only the consciousnesses at the end of impulsion;🔽there are also those with that as object, etc., too.🔽So after showing all mind-consciousness element by means of its specific nature distinguished by the five consciousnesses and the mind element, he now said “With mind and mental object as condition” in order to show the mind-consciousness element of impulsion in excess by means of the mind door.

original: cittāni idha “manoviññāṇadhātū”ti dassitānīti ayamattho gayheyya, cutipaṭisandhibhavaṅgānaṃ
analyzed: cittāni idha manaḥ viññāṇa dhātū ti dassitāni iti ayam atthaḥ cuti paṭisandhi bhavaṅgānam
translated: But if the meaning conveyed were that only the consciousnesses at the end of impulsion by means of the six doors are shown here as “mind-consciousness element,” then the consciousnesses at death, rebirth-linking, and in the course of an existence

original: aggahitattā sāvasesā desanā āpajjati, tasmā yathāvuttena nayena attho veditabbo.
analyzed: aggahita ttā sa avasesā desanā āpajjati tasmā yathā vuttena nayena atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: Since it is not taken, the teaching is incomplete. Therefore the meaning should be understood in the way stated.

original: Chadvārikacittehi vā samānalakkhaṇāni aññānipi “manoviññāṇadhātū”ti dassitānīti veditabbāni.
analyzed: cha dvārika cittehi vā samāna lakkhaṇāni aññāni pi manaḥ viññāṇa dhātū ti dassitāni iti veditabbāni
translated: Or else, the other kinds of “mind-consciousness element” should be understood to have the same characteristics as the six kinds of consciousness.

original: Paṭiccāti āgataṭṭhāneti ettha “mano ca nesaṃ gocaravisayaṃ paccanubhotī”tiādīsu visuṃ
analyzed: paṭicca ati āgata ṭṭhāne ti ettha manaḥ ca na īsam gocara visayam paccanubhoti itiādīsu visum
translated: “With mind as their source”: here, in such passages as “Mind experiences the object that is the field of the eye,” it is proper to take the word “with” to mean “having come from.”

original: kātuṃ yuttaṃ, idha pana “cakkhuñca paṭiccā”tiādīsu ca-saddena sampiṇḍetvā āvajjanassapi🔽cakkhādisannissitatākaraṇaṃ viya manañca paṭiccāti āgataṭṭhāne manodvārasaṅkhātabhavaṅgasannissitameva
analyzed: kātum yuttam idha pana cakkhuñca paṭicca ati ādīsu ca saddena sampiṇḍetvā āvajjanassa api  cakkha ādi sannissita tā karaṇam viya manam ca paṭicca ati āgata ṭṭhāne manaḥ dvāra saṅkhāta bhavaṅga sannissitam eva
translated: But in such passages as “With the eye as a requisite condition,” by the word “with” the adverting is combined🔽as if it were dependent on the eye, etc., just as the adverting is dependent on the life-continuum, which is called the mind door.

original: āvajjanaṃ kātabbanti adhippāyo.
analyzed: āvajjanam kātabbanti adhippāyaḥ
translated: The intention is that the adverting should be done in the place “with mind as a requisite condition” as dependent on the life-continuum, which is called the mind door.

original: Abhidhammabhājanīyavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: abhidhammabhājanīya vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the section on the Abhidhamma is ended.

original: 3. Pañhapucchakavaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the section on the questions

original: Pañhapucchakaṃ heṭṭhā vuttanayattā uttānamevāti.🔽Pañhapucchakavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: pañha pucchakam heṭṭhā vutta naya ttā uttānam eva ati  pañha pucchaka vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: is obvious since it is stated in the way already given above.🔽The commentary on the section on the questions is ended.

original: Dhātuvibhaṅgavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽4. Saccavibhaṅgo
analyzed: dhātu vibhaṅga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  sacca vibhaṅgaḥ
translated: The commentary on the section on the elements is ended.🔽The Analysis of the Truths

original: 1. Suttantabhājanīyaṃ
analyzed: suttanta bhājanīyam
translated: The Section on the Suttas

original: Uddesavaṇṇanā🔽189. Sāsanakkamoti ariyasaccāni vuccanti ariyasaccadesanā vā. Sakalañhi sāsanaṃ bhagavato
analyzed: uddesa vaṇṇanā  sāsana kkamaḥ ti ariya saccāni vuccanti ariya sacca desanā vā sakalam hi sāsanam bhagavato
translated: Description of the recitation

original: vacanaṃ saccavinimuttaṃ natthīti saccesu kamati, sīlasamādhipaññāsaṅkhātaṃ vā sāsanaṃ🔽etesu kamati, tasmā kamati etthāti kamo, kiṃ kamati? Sāsanaṃ, sāsanassa kamo sāsanakkamoti
analyzed: vacanam sacca vinimuttam na atthi iti saccesu kamati sīla samādhi paññā saṅkhātam vā sāsanam  etesu kamati tasmā kamati ettha ati kamaḥ kim kamati sāsanam sāsanassa kamaḥ sāsana kkamaḥ iti
translated: The order of the Dispensation: the four noble truths are called the order of the Dispensation, or the teaching of the four noble truths is. For the whole of the Dispensation is the Blessed One’s word, and there is no word of his that is not truth, thus it “goes” in the truths. Or the Dispensation consisting of virtue, concentration, and understanding “goes” in these, thus it is an order, a “kam” . What goes? The Dispensation. The order of the Dispensation is the order of the Dispensation.

original: saccāni sāsanapavattiṭṭhānāni vuccanti, taṃdesanā ca tabbohārenāti.🔽Tathāti taṃsabhāvāva. Avitathāti amusāsabhāvā. Anaññathāti aññākārarahitā. Dukkhadukkhatātaṃnimittatāhi
analyzed: saccāni sāsana pavatti ṭṭhānāni vuccanti tad desanā ca tad bohārena ati  tathā ati avitathā ati anaññathā ati añña ākāra rahitā dukkha dukkha tā taṃnimitta tāhi
translated: The truths are called the order of the Dispensation because they are the foundation for the occurrence of the Dispensation, and the teaching of them is included in them.🔽Thus: in that same individual essence. Not otherwise: not in a false individual essence. Not in another way: not in a different manner.🔽The meaning of pain is the meaning of pain as pain, the meaning of pain as change, and the meaning of pain as a mental process.

original: aniṭṭhatā pīḷanaṭṭho, dvidhāpi paridahanaṃ, kilesadāhasamāyogo vā santāpaṭṭhoti ayametesaṃ🔽viseso. Puggalahiṃsanaṃ vā pīḷanaṃ, attano eva tikhiṇabhāvo santāpanaṃ santāpoti.
analyzed: aniṭṭha tā pīḷana ṭṭhaḥ dvidhā api paridahanam kilesa dāha samāyogaḥ vā santāpa ṭṭhaḥ ti ayam etesam 🔽viseso puggala hiṃsanam vā pīḷanam attanaḥ eva tikhiṇa bhāvaḥ santāpanam
translated: The meaning of pain as change is the meaning of pain as change, the meaning of pain as a mental process, and the meaning of pain as a universal characteristic. The meaning of pain as a mental process is the meaning of pain as a mental process, the meaning of pain as change, and the meaning of pain as a universal characteristic. The meaning of pain as a universal characteristic is the meaning of pain as a universal characteristic, the meaning of pain as change, and the meaning of pain as a mental process.🔽The meaning of pain as pain is the meaning of pain as pain, the meaning of pain as change, and the meaning of pain as a mental process. The meaning of pain as change is the meaning of pain as change, the meaning of pain as a mental process, and the meaning of pain as a universal characteristic. The meaning of pain as a mental process is the meaning of pain as a mental process, the meaning of pain as a universal characteristic, and the meaning of pain as change. The meaning of pain as a universal characteristic is the meaning of pain as a universal characteristic, the meaning of pain as a mental process, and the meaning of pain as change.🔽The meaning of pain as pain is the meaning of pain as pain, the meaning of pain as change, and the meaning of pain as a mental process. original: Ettha ca pīḷanaṭṭho dukkhassa saraseneva āvibhavanākāro, itare yathākkamaṃ samudayamagganirodhadassanehi
analyzed: ettha ca pīḷana ṭṭhaḥ dukkhassa sarasena iva āvi bhavana ākāraḥ itare yathākkamam samudaya magga nirodha dassanehi
translated: And here the meaning of oppressing is the mode of manifestation of the truth of suffering itself, while the other three meanings are the modes of manifestation of the truths of origin, path, and cessation respectively.

original: āvibhavanākārāti ayaṃ catunnampi viseso. Tatratatrābhinandanavasena byāpetvā ūhanaṃ🔽rāsikaraṇaṃ dukkhanibbattanaṃ āyūhanaṃ, samudayato āgacchatīti vā āyaṃ, dukkhaṃ.🔽Tassa ūhanaṃ pavattanaṃ āyūhanaṃ, sarasāvibhāvanākāro eso. Nidadāti dukkhanti nidānaṃ,🔽“idaṃ taṃ dukkha”nti sampaṭicchāpentaṃ viya samuṭṭhāpetīti attho. Dukkhadassanena🔽cāyaṃ nidānaṭṭho āvi bhavati. Saṃyogapalibodhaṭṭhā nirodhamaggadassanehi, te ca saṃsārasaṃyojanamagganivāraṇākārā daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: ayam tatra tatra abhinandana vasena ūhanam  rāsi karaṇam dukkha nibbattanam āyūhanam samudayataḥ āgacchati iti vai āyam dukkham  tassa ūhanam pavattanam āyūhanam sarasā vibhāvanā ākāraḥ esaḥ nidadāti dukkhanti nidānam  idam tam dukkhan ti sampaṭicchāpentam viya samuṭṭhāpeti iti atthaḥ dukkha dassanena  ca ayam nidāna ṭṭhaḥ āvi bhavati saṃyoga palibodha ṭṭhā nirodha magga dassanehi te ca saṃsāra saṃyojana magga nivāraṇa ākārāḥ daṭṭhabbā
translated: This is the difference between the four truths.

original: Nissaranti ettha sattā, sayameva vā nissaṭaṃ visaṃyuttaṃ sabbasaṅkhatehi sabbupadhipaṭinissaggabhāvatoti

original: nissaraṇaṃ. Ayamassa sabhāvena āvibhavanākāro. Vivekāsaṅkhatāmataṭṭhā samudayamaggadukkhadassanāvibhavanākārā,
analyzed: nissaraṇam ayam assa sabhāvena āvibhavana ākāraḥ viveka asaṅkha tā mata ṭṭhā samudaya magga dukkha dassana āvibhavana ākārā
translated: This is its mode of adverting by its individual essence. Its mode of adverting as seclusion is the path’s seeing of the origin, the seeing of the cessation, and the seeing of the suffering in the case of the three other truths.

original: samudayakkhayaappaccayaavināsitā vā. Saṃsārato niggamanaṃ niyyānaṃ. Ayamassa sarasena
analyzed: samudaya kkhaya appaccaya avināsi tā vā saṃsārataḥ niggamanam niyyānam ayam assa sa rasena
translated: Or it is the seeing of the origin’s destruction, the condition’s non-existence, and the non-disappearance.

original: pakāsanākāro, itare samudayanirodhadukkhadassanehi. Tattha palibodhupacchedavasena
analyzed: pakāsana ākāraḥ itare samudaya nirodha dukkha dassanehi tattha palibodha upaccheda vasena
translated: Its mode of adverting as escape is the going out from the round of rebirths. This is its mode of adverting by its individual essence. The others are its modes of adverting as the seeing of the origin, the seeing of the cessation, and the seeing of the suffering in the case of the three other truths.🔽Herein, the attainment of Nibbāna by the cutting off of impediments is the Nibbāna-sign in the sense of cause.

original: nibbānādhigamova nibbānanimittatā hetvaṭṭho. Paññāpadhānattā maggassa nibbānadassanaṃ,
analyzed: nibbāna adhigamaḥ uva nibbāna nimitta tā hetu aṭṭhaḥ paññā apadhāna ttā maggassa nibbāna dassanam
translated: The path’s seeing of Nibbāna is because of the predominance of understanding.

original: catusaccadassanaṃ vā dassanaṭṭho. Catusaccadassane kilesadukkhasantāpavūpasamane🔽ca ādhipaccaṃ karonti maggaṅgadhammā sampayuttadhammesūti so maggassa adhipateyyaṭṭhoti.
analyzed: catu acca dassanam vā catu acca dassane kilesa dukkha santāpa vūpasamane  ca ādhipaccam karonti maggaṅga dhammā sampayutta dhammesu iti saḥ maggassa adhipateyya ṭṭho ti
translated: Or the seeing of the four truths is the seeing-sign in the sense of seeing the four truths or in the sense of predominance of the path factors in the associated states in the stilling of defilements and of the suffering of the round of rebirths.

original: Visesato vā ārammaṇādhipatibhūtā maggaṅgadhammā honti “maggādhipatino dhammā”ti vacanatoti
analyzed: visesataḥ vā ārammaṇa adhipati bhūtāḥ maggaṅga dhammāḥ honti magga adhipatino dhammā ati vacanato ti
translated: Or the path factors are called “states that are the path’s predominance” because they are the predominance of the object in the seeing of the four truths and in the stilling of defilements and of the suffering of the round of rebirths.🔽Or alternatively, the path factors are “states that are the path’s predominance” because they are the predominance of the object in the seeing of the four truths and in the stilling of defilements and of the suffering of the round of rebirths.

original: so tesaṃ ākāro adhipateyyaṭṭho. Evamādi āhāti sambandho. Tattha abhisamayaṭṭhoti🔽abhisametabbaṭṭho, abhisamayassa vā visayabhūto attho abhisamayaṭṭho, abhisamayasseva
analyzed: saḥ tesam ākāraḥ adhipateyya ṭṭho evamādi āha ati sambandhaḥ tattha abhisamaya ṭṭho ti  abhisametabba ṭṭhaḥ abhisamayassa vā visaya bhūtaḥ atthaḥ abhisamayaṭṭhaḥ abhisamayassa iva
translated: This is its mode as predominance. The construction is: “Thus, etc., it is said.”

original: vā pavattiākāro abhisamayaṭṭho, so cettha abhisametabbena pīḷanādinā dassitoti daṭṭhabbo.🔽Kucchitaṃ khaṃ dukkhaṃ. “Samāgamo sameta”ntiādīsu kevalassa āgama-saddassa eta-saddassa🔽ca payoge saṃyogatthassa anupalabbhanato saṃ-saddassa ca payoge upalabbhanato “saṃyogaṃ🔽dīpetī”ti āha, evaṃ “uppannaṃ udita”nti etthāpi. Aya-saddo gatiatthasiddho hetu-saddo
analyzed: vā pavatti ākāraḥ abhisamaya ṭṭho so ca ittha abhisametabbena pīḷana ādinā dassito ti daṭṭhabbaḥ  kucchitam kham dukkham samāgamaḥ sameta nti ādīsu kevalassa āgama saddassa eta saddassa  ca payoge saṃyoga atthassa anupalabbhanato saṃsaddassa ca payoge upalabbhanato saṃyogaṃ  dīpeti iti āha evam uppannam uditam ti ettha api aya saddaḥ gati attha siddhaḥ hetu saddaḥ
translated: Herein, the meaning of penetration is the meaning of what is to be penetrated, or the meaning that is the province of penetration is the meaning of penetration, or the mode of occurrence of penetration itself is the meaning of penetration. That should be regarded as shown here by the affliction, etc., that are to be penetrated.

original: viya kāraṇaṃ dīpeti attano phalanipphādanena ayati pavattati, eti vā etasmā phalanti
analyzed: viya kāraṇam dīpeti attanaḥ phala nipphādanena ayati pavattati eti vā etasmai phalanti
translated: The void is suffering. Since the expression “coming together is meeting” is one in which only the words āgama and eta occur, and since the meaning of conjunction is not found there, he said “conjunction is indicated” since it is found in the expression “saṃyoga.” So too in the case of “arisen is appeared.” The word aya, like the word hetu, is established in the sense of “going” . It indicates a cause, since it goes by occurring in the production of its own fruit, or it goes from that, that is, it goes to its fruit.

original: ayoti, saṃyoge uppattikāraṇaṃ samudayoti ettha visuṃ payujjamānāpi upasagga-saddā
analyzed: saṃyoge uppatti kāraṇam ettha visum payujjamānā api upasagga saddā
translated: In the expression “the cause of arising in conjunction is origination,” the prefix sam is used separately, though it is also found in the expression “saṃyoga.”

original: sadhātukaṃ saṃyogatthaṃ uppādatthañca dīpenti kiriyāvisesakattāti veditabbā.🔽Abhāvo ettha rodhassāti nirodhoti etena nibbānassa dukkhavivekabhāvaṃ dasseti. Samadhigate
analyzed: sa dhātukam saṃyoga ttham uppāda ttham ca dīpenti kiriyā visesaka ttā iti veditabbā  abhāvaḥ ettha rodhassa ati nirodhaḥ iti etena nibbānassa dukkha viveka bhāvam dasseti samadhigate
translated: The state of being in the sense of non-appearance is the opposite of the state of being in the sense of occurrence.🔽The absence of the state of being in the sense of non-appearance is the absence of the state of being in the sense of non-appearance.🔽The absence of the state of being in the sense of non-appearance is the absence of the state of being in the sense of non-appearance.🔽The absence of the state of being in the sense of non-appearance is the absence of the state of being in the sense of non-appearance.🔽The absence of the state of being in the sense of non-appearance is the absence of the state of being in the sense of non-appearance.

original: tasmiṃ tadadhigamavato puggalassa rodhābhāvo pavattisaṅkhātassa rodhassa paṭipakkhabhūtāya🔽nivattiyā adhigatattāti etasmiñcatthe abhāvo etasmiṃ rodhassāti nirodhoicceva padasamāso.🔽Dukkhābhāvo panettha puggalassa, na nibbānasseva. Anuppādo eva nirodho anuppādanirodho.
analyzed: tasmim tad adhigamavataḥ puggalassa rodha abhāvo pavatti saṅkhātassa rodhassa paṭipakkha bhūtāya  nivattiyāḥ adhigata ttā ati etasmin ca atthe abhāvaḥ etasmin rodhassa ati nirodho iccā iva pada samāsaḥ  dukkha abhāvo pana ittha puggalassa na nibbānassa iva anuppādaḥ eva nirodhaḥ anuppāda nirodho
translated: The absence of the state of being in the sense of non-appearance is the absence of the state of being in the sense of non-appearance.🔽The absence of the state of being in the sense of non-appearance is the absence of the state of being in the sense of non-appearance.🔽The absence of the state of being in the sense of non-appearance is the absence of the state of being in the sense of non-appearance.🔽The absence of the state of being in the sense of non-appearance is the absence of the state of being in the sense of non-appearance.
