translated: the verbal adjective is appropriate in both cases. “Complete birth” is “birth in the full sense.” “Manifest birth” is “birth in the manifest sense.” “The manifestation of such and such beings” is a conventional expression because it occurs in terms of beings.

original: Tatra tatrāti ekacatuvokārabhavesu dvinnaṃ dvinnaṃ, sese rūpadhātuyaṃ paṭisandhikkhaṇe
analyzed: tatra tatra ati eka catu vokāra bhavesu dvinnam dvinnam sese paṭisandhi kkhaṇe
translated: “In such and such places” means in the four kinds of generation in the sense of two by two, and in the rest of the fine-material sphere in the sense of rebirth-linking.

original: uppajjamānānaṃ pañcannaṃ, kāmadhātuyaṃ vikalāvikalindriyānaṃ vasena sattannaṃ navannaṃ
analyzed: uppajjamānānam pañcannam vikala avikala indriyānam vasena
translated: In the sense-sphere realm, it is in the sense of the seven and the nine, according to whether the faculties are complete or incomplete.

original: dasannaṃ puna dasannaṃ ekādasannañca āyatanānaṃ vasena saṅgaho veditabbo. Ekabhavapariyāpannassa
analyzed: dasannam puna dasannam ekādasannam ca āyatanānam vasena saṅgahaḥ veditabbo eka bhava pariyāpannassa
translated: and by way of the ten, and again by way of the eleven bases.

original: khandhasantānassa paṭhamābhinibbattibhūtā paṭisandhikkhandhāti āha “paṭhamābhinibbattilakkhaṇā”ti.
analyzed: khandha santānassa paṭhama abhinibbatti bhūtā paṭisandhikkhandhā ti āha paṭhama abhinibbatti lakkhaṇā ti
translated: The aggregates at the rebirth-linking which are the first generation of the continuum of aggregates included in one becoming are called the aggregates at rebirth-linking.

original: Tameva santānaṃ niyyātentaṃ viya “handa gaṇhathā”ti paṭicchāpentaṃ viya pavattatīti🔽niyyātanarasā. Santatiyā eva ummujjanaṃ hutvā gayhatīti ummujjanapaccupaṭṭhānā. Dukkharāsissa
analyzed: tam eva santānam niyyātentam viya handa gaṇhatha ati paṭicchāpentam viya pavattati iti  niyyātana rasā santatiyā eva ummujjanam hutvā gayhati iti ummujjana paccupaṭṭhānā dukkha rāsissa
translated: It occurs as if it were sending out that very continuum, as if it were concealing it, saying, “Now, take it!”🔽It has the characteristic of sending out.🔽It is manifested as the arising of the continuum.

original: vicittatā dukkhavicittatā, dukkhavisesā vā tadavayavā, taṃ paccupaṭṭhāpeti phalatīti
analyzed: vicitta tā dukkha vicitta tā dukkha visesāḥ vā tad avayavā tam paccupaṭṭhāpeti phalati iti
translated: The diversity of suffering is the diversity of kinds of suffering, or the different kinds of suffering are its manifestations. It manifests, it brings about, that.

original: dukkhavicittatāpaccupaṭṭhānā.
analyzed: dukkha vicitta tā paccupaṭṭhānā
translated: It is manifested as the diversity of suffering.

original: Pariyāyanippariyāyadukkhesu yaṃ dukkhaṃ jāti hoti, taṃ dukkhabhāvoyeva tassā dukkhaṭṭho. Yadi akkhānena pāpuṇitabbaṃ siyā, bhagavā ācikkheyya. Bhagavatāpi –
analyzed: pariyāya nippariyāya dukkhesu yam dukkham jāti hoti tam dukkha bhāvoya iva tassā dukkhaṭṭhaḥ yadi akkhānena pāpuṇitabbam siyā bhagavā ācikkheyya bhagavatā api
translated: As regards the suffering of change and the suffering of suffering, the suffering that is birth is the mere suffering of that. If it could be reached by description, the Blessed One would describe it. The Blessed One said:

original: “Taṃ kiṃ maññatha, bhikkhave, katamo nu kho mahantataro? Yo cāyaṃ mayā paritto pāṇimatto
analyzed: tam kim maññatha bhikkhave katamaḥ nu kho mahantataraḥ yaḥ ca ayam mayā paritto pāṇimatto
translated: “What do you think, bhikkhus? Which is more: the little bit of soil that I have taken up in my fingernail or this great earth?”

original: pāsāṇo gahito, yo ca himavā pabbatarājāti. Appama…pe… gahito, himavantaṃ pabbatarājānaṃ🔽upanidhāya saṅkhampi na upeti, kalabhāgampi na upeti, upanidhampi na upeti. Evameva🔽kho, bhikkhave, yaṃ so puriso tīhi sattisatehi haññamāno tatonidānaṃ dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ
analyzed: pāsāṇaḥ gahitaḥ yaḥ ca himavā pabbata rājā ati appamape gahitaḥ himavantam pabbata rājānam  upanidhāya saṅkham pi na upeti kalabhāgam pi na upeti upanidham pi na upeti evam eva  kho bhikkhave yam saḥ purisaḥ tīhi satti satehi haññamānaḥ tatonidānam dukkham domanassam
translated: “The little bit of soil that the Blessed One has taken up in his fingernail is less; the great earth is more.”

original: paṭisaṃvedeti, taṃ nerayikassa dukkhassa upanidhāya saṅkhampi…pe… upanidhampi na upetī”ti –
analyzed: paṭisaṃvedeti tam nerayikassa dukkhassa upanidhāya upanidhampi na upeti iti
translated: “So too, bhikkhus, the suffering and sorrow of the man who is struck by three hundred spears is trifling compared with the suffering of hell. “

original: Upamāvasena pakāsitaṃ āpāyikadukkhaṃ. Sukhuppattikāraṇāni sucīni uppalādīnīti katvā
analyzed: upamā vasena pakāsitam āpāyika dukkham sukha uppatti kāraṇāni sucīni uppala ādīni iti katvā
translated: The suffering of the states of loss is illustrated by similes. The pure white lotuses, etc., are the causes for the arising of happiness.

original: tattha nibbattinivāraṇena jātiyā dukkhavatthubhāvaṃ dasseti “atha kho”tiādinā. Dukkhuppattikāraṇe
analyzed: tattha nibbatti nivāraṇena jātiyāḥ dukkha vatthu bhāvam dasseti atha kho ti ādinā dukkha uppatti kāraṇe
translated: The Blessed One shows the state of being a basis for suffering by preventing rebirth there with the words “But, bhikkhus, the man who is struck by three hundred spears” , etc.

original: nibbattanena gabbhapariharaṇūpakkamena vinā mātukucchisambhavameva dukkhaṃ gabbhokkantimūlakaṃ
analyzed: nibbattanena gabbha pariharaṇa upakkamena vinā mātukucchi sambhavam eva dukkham gabbha ukkanti mūlakam
translated: The suffering of being in the womb is due to the mere entering of the womb, not to the actual carrying in the womb or to the delivery.🔽For the latter two are not mentioned because they are not looked on as suffering.🔽The suffering of being born is due to the mere delivery, not to the carrying in the womb or to the entering of the womb.

original: aññānapekkhattā, upakkamanibbattaṃ pana pariharaṇamūlakaṃ okkantimattānapekkhattā. Ayametesaṃ viseso.
analyzed: añña an apekkha ttā upakkama nibbattam pana pariharaṇa mūlakam okkantimatta an apekkha ttā ayam etesam viseso
translated: For the latter two are not looked on as suffering. This is the difference between them.

original: Attano abhimukhaṃ kaḍḍhanaṃ ākaḍḍhanaṃ, parito sabbatobhāgena kaḍḍhanaṃ parikaḍḍhanaṃ.🔽Adho dhunanaṃ odhunanaṃ, tiriyaṃ, sabbato vā dhunanaṃ nidhunanaṃ. Tacchetvā khārapakkhipanaṃ khārāpaṭicchakaṃ.
analyzed: attanaḥ abhimukham kaḍḍhanaṃ ākaḍḍhanam paritas sabbatobhāgena kaḍḍhanam parikaḍḍhanam  adhas dhunanam odhunanam tiriyam sabbatas vā dhunanam nidhunanam tat śetvā khāra pakkhipanam khārā paṭicchakam
translated: The “pulling” is the pulling towards oneself. The “dragging” is the dragging all round on every side.🔽The “shaking” is the shaking up and down. The “rattling” is the shaking to and fro or all round. The “rubbing” is the rubbing in after cutting the umbilical cord and applying salt.

original: Sakalasarīranhāpanaṃ nhāpanaṃ, ekadesadhovanaṃ dhovanaṃ, sūriyābhimukhapavattanena ātāpanaṃ, pañcaggitāpena paritāpanaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Sabboyeva vā tāpo dvidhāpi vutto.
analyzed: sakala sarīra nhāpanam nhāpanam eka desa dhovanam dhovanam sūriya abhimukha pavattanena ātāpanam pañcaggi tāpena paritāpanam daṭṭhabbam sabbaḥ yeva vā tāpaḥ dvidhā api vutto
translated: The “washing” is the washing of the whole body. The “rinsing” is the rinsing of a part. The “warming” is the warming by turning towards the sun. The “drying” is the drying with a soft cloth. Or all the rest can be taken as “warming” since it is all a kind of heating.

original: Kuhiṃ nu patiṭṭhaṃ labhetha, jātiyā vinā na tassa dukkhassa patiṭṭhānaṃ atthīti attho,
analyzed: kuhim nu patiṭṭham labhetha jātiyā vinā na tassa dukkhassa patiṭṭhānam atthi iti attho
translated: Where can it find support? The meaning is that there is no support for that suffering except birth.

original: jātiyā vā vinā so satto kuhiṃ nu patiṭṭhaṃ, kattha nu patiṭṭhanto taṃ dukkhaṃ labhethāti
analyzed: jātiyā vā vinā so satto kuhim nu patiṭṭham kattha nu patiṭṭhantaḥ tam dukkham labhetha ati
translated: and without birth where would that being be established, and when established where would he get that suffering?

original: attho. Tattha tiracchānesu kathaṃ dukkhaṃ bhaveyya tahiṃ tiracchānesu jātiṃ vinā.
analyzed: attho tattha tiracchānesu katham dukkham bhaveyya tahim tiracchānesu jātim vinā
translated: is the meaning. Herein, how would there be suffering among animals? For there is no birth among animals.

original: Na cassāti na ce assa. Nanu nevatthīti sambandho kātabbo, nanu āhāti vā. Yadatoti
analyzed: na cassa ati na ce assa nanu na iva atthi iti sambandhaḥ kātabbaḥ nanu āha ati vā yat atas ti
translated: If there were not: the construction is to be made thus, “Would there not be? ” or “Would there not be so? ” From which:

original: yasmā nevatthi, tasmā āhāti attho.
analyzed: yasmai na iva atthi tasmai āha ati attho
translated: from which there is not, thus from that I say, is the meaning.

original: Jarāniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: jarā niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of Ageing

original: 192. Jīraṇameva jīraṇatā, jīraṇassa vā ākāro tā-saddena vutto.
analyzed: jīraṇam eva jīraṇa tā jīraṇassa vā ākāraḥ tā saddena vutto
translated: Ageing itself is ageing-process. Or alternatively, it is the mode of the aged that is expressed by the word “ageing-process” .

original: Yathāpure asallakkhenteti gāravakaraṇaupaṭṭhānādīni asallakkhente taṃnimittaṃ domanassaṃ uppajjatīti attho.
analyzed: yathāpure a saṃlakkhentā iti gārava karaṇa upaṭṭhāna ādīni tad nimittam domanassam uppajjati iti attho
translated: As formerly he did not notice: the meaning is that he becomes disconsolate on that account because of the non-noticing of the doing of the duties of respect and attendance, etc.

original: Satādīnanti satisutavīriyapaññādīnaṃ vippavāsanimittaṃ attanā apasādetabbehipi attano
analyzed: sata ādīnam ti sati suta vīriya paññā ādīnam vippavāsa nimittam attanā apasādetabbehi pi attano
translated: By loss of mindfulness, etc.: the loss of mindfulness, learning, energy, understanding, etc., is the reason for the disconsolation.

original: puttadārehi apasādanīyato. Avasavattaṅgapaccaṅgatāya suciasuciādivicāraṇavirahena
analyzed: putta dārehi apasādanīyataḥ suci asuci ādi vicāraṇa virahena
translated: By the disconsolation of his own wife and children, who are not to be disconsolated by himself, because of the loss of mindfulness, etc.;🔽and by the absence of the consideration of what is clean and unclean, etc., because of the absence of the condition of being a master and the condition of being a servant.

original: ca bālakumārakakālo viya jiṇṇakālo hotīti āha “bhiyyo bālattappattiyā”ti.
analyzed: ca bāla kumāraka kālaḥ viya jiṇṇa kālaḥ hoti iti āha bhiyyas bāla tta pattiyā iti
translated: and the time of being an old man comes about as if it were the time of being a boy.

original: Maraṇaniddesavaṇṇanā
translated: The description of death

original: 193. “Kālassa antakassa kiriyā”ti yā loke vuccati, sā cuti, maraṇanti attho. Cavanakāloyeva
analyzed: kālassa antakassa kiriyā ati yā loke vuccati sā cuti maraṇanti attho cavana kāloyā iva
translated: “The action of the time-terminator” is what is called in the world “death,” the meaning being “falling away.”

original: vā anatikkamanīyattā visesena kāloti vutto, tassa kiriyā cutikkhandhānaṃ bhedappattiyeva.🔽Maccu maraṇanti etthāpi samāsaṃ akatvā yo maccu vuccati bhedo, yañca maraṇaṃ pāṇacāgo,
analyzed: vā an atikkamanīya ttā visesena kālaḥ ti vuttaḥ tassa kiriyā cuti kkhandhānam bheda ppattiyā iva  ettha api samāsam a katvā yaḥ bhedaḥ yat ca maraṇam
translated: Or the time is called “time” in the special sense that it is not to be transgressed, and its “action” is the occurrence of the dissolution of the aggregates of death.

original: idaṃ vuccati maraṇanti visuṃ sambandho na na yujjati.
analyzed: idam vuccati visum sambandhaḥ na na yujjati
translated: As regards “death, which is called ‘death’,” the compound is not made because the dissolution that is called “death” and the giving up of the life faculty, which is called “death,”🔽are not inappropriate as separate references.

original: Yassa khandhabhedassa pavattattā “tisso mato, phusso mato”ti vohāro hoti, so khandhappabandhassa
analyzed: yassa khandha bhedassa pavatta ttā tissaḥ mataḥ phussaḥ mataḥ ti vohāraḥ hoti so khandha ppabandhassa
translated: The dissolution of the aggregates by means of which there is the usage “So-and-so is dead,” “So-and-so has died,” is called “death by convention”

original: anupacchinnatāya “sammutimaraṇa”nti vutto, pabandhasamucchedo ca “samucchedamaraṇa”nti.
analyzed: anupacchinna tāya sammuti maraṇanti vuttaḥ pabandha samucchedo ca samuccheda maraṇanti
translated: because the continuity of the aggregates is not interrupted. And the severing of the continuity is called “death by severance.”

original: Maraṇampi dukkhanti imasmiṃ panatthe dukkhasaccakathā vaṭṭakathāti katvā “sammutimaraṇaṃ
analyzed: maraṇam pi dukkhanti imasmin pana atthe dukkha sacca kathā vaṭṭa kathā ati katvā sammuti maraṇam
translated: As regards the meaning “death is suffering,” the explanation should be taken as the explanation of the truth of suffering, treating “death” as a synonym for “birth.”

original: adhippeta”nti āha. Tasseva nāmanti tabbhāvato tadekadesabhāvato ca maraṇa-saddabahutte🔽asammohatthaṃ vuttaṃ. Cutilakkhaṇanti “cavanatā”ti nidassitacavanalakkhaṇameva vadati.🔽Sampattibhavakhandhehi viyojetīti viyogarasaṃ, viyogakiriyābhūtatāya vā “viyogarasa”nti🔽vuttaṃ. Sattassa purimabhavato vippavāso hutvā upaṭṭhātīti vippavāsapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ.🔽Maraṇantikāti maraṇassa āsannā. Yadi maraṇaṃ na bhavissati, yathāvuttaṃ kāyikaṃ cetasikañca dukkhaṃ na bhavissatīti āha “dvinnampi dukkhānaṃ vatthubhāvenā”ti.🔽Pāpakammādinimittanti pāpakammanimittaṃ pāpagatinimittañcāti attho, kammampi vā ettha
analyzed: adhippetanti āha tassa iva nāman ti tad bhāvataḥ tad eka desa bhāvataḥ ca maraṇa sadda bahutte  asammoha attham vuttam cuti lakkhaṇan ti cavana tā ti nidassita cavana lakkhaṇam eva vadati  sampatti bhava khandhehi viyoja iti iti viyoga rasam viyoga kiriyā bhūta tāya vā  vuttam sattassa purima bhavataḥ vippavāsaḥ hutvā upaṭṭhāti iti vippavāsa paccupaṭṭhānam  maraṇantikā ati maraṇassa āsannā yadi maraṇam na bhavissati yathā vuttam kāyikam cetasikam ca dukkham na bhavissati iti āha dvinnam pi dukkhānam vatthu bhāvena ati  pāpa kamma ādi nimittam ti pāpa kamma nimittam pāpa gati nimittam ca ati attho kammam pi vā ettha
translated: “The meaning intended is this.” The word “death” is used in the sense of the characteristic of death, in the sense of the function of death, in the sense of the proximate cause of death, and in the sense of the manifestation of death.

original: “nimitta”nti vuttaṃ upapattinimittabhāvena upaṭṭhānato. Tadupaṭṭhānepi hi “akataṃ
analyzed: nimittam ti vuttam upapatti nimitta bhāvena upaṭṭhānataḥ tad upaṭṭhāne api hi akatam
translated: The word “death” is used in the sense of the characteristic of death in the passage, “What is death? It is the breakup, the casting off, the throwing off, the exhaustion, the casting away, the mortality of beings, passing away, dissolution, disappearance, death, making away with, the fact of being made away with, the event of being made away with, the arrival at death, the arrival at the fact of being made away with, the arrival at the event of being made away with, the arrival at the state of death, the arrival at the state of being made away with, the arrival at the state of the event of being made away with, the arrival at the state of death, the arrival at the state of being made away with, the arrival at the state of the event of being made away with, the arrival at the state of death, the arrival at the state of being made away with, the arrival at the state of the event of being made away with, the arrival at the state of death, the arrival at the state of being made away with, the arrival at the state of the event of being made away with, the arrival at the state of death, the arrival at the state of being made away with, the arrival at the state of the event of being made away with, the arrival at the state of death, the arrival at the state of being made away with, the arrival at the state of the event of being made away with, the arrival at the state of death, the arrival at the state of being made away with, the arrival at the state of the event of being made away with, the arrival at the state of death, the arrival at the state of being made away with, the arrival at the state of the event of being made away with, the arrival at the state of death, the arrival at the state of being made away with, the arrival at the state of the event of being made away with, the arrival at the state of death, the arrival at the state of being made away with, the arrival at the state of the event of being made away with, the arrival at the state of death, the arrival at the state of being made away with, the arrival at the state

original: vata me kalyāṇa”ntiādinā anappakaṃ domanassaṃ uppajjatīti. Bhaddassāti kalyāṇakammassāti🔽attho. Avisesatoti “sabbesa”nti etena yojetabbaṃ. Sabbesanti ca yesaṃ kāyikaṃ dukkhaṃ
analyzed: vata me kalyāṇa nti ādinā anappakam domanassam uppajjati iti bhaddassa ati kalyāṇa kammassa ati  atthaḥ avisesato ti sabbesan ti etena yojetabbam sabbesan ti ca yesam kāyikam dukkham
translated: “The fortunate” means the one of good kamma.

original: uppajjati, teyeva sabbe gahitā “vitujjamānamammāna”nti visesitattā. Sandhīnaṃ bandhanāni
analyzed: uppajjati te yeva sabbe gahitāḥ vitujjamāna mammānanti visesita ttā sandhīnam bandhanāni
translated: “Without distinction”: this should be construed with “all.” And “all” includes only those in whom bodily pain arises, because of the specification “those who are being cut up.”

original: sandhibandhanāni, tesaṃ chedanena nibbattaṃ dukkhaṃ “sandhibandhanacchedana”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: sandhibandhanāni tesam chedanena nibbattam dukkham sandhibandhana chedananti vuttam
translated: The joints’ bonds are the joints’ bonds. The pain produced by their cutting is called “the cutting of the joints’ bonds.”

original: Ādi-saddo vā kāraṇattho, sandhibandhanacchedanamūlakanti attho.
analyzed: ādi saddaḥ vā kāraṇa atthaḥ sandhi bandhana chedana mūlakanti attho
translated: Or the word “and so on” has the meaning of cause; the meaning is: “the cutting of the joints’ bonds is the root.”

original: Anayabyasanāpādanaṃ viyāti anayabyasanāpatti viyāti attho. Vāḷādīhi kate hi anayabyasanāpādane antogadhā anayabyasanāpatti ettha nidassananti.🔽Sokaniddesavaṇṇanā🔽194. Sukhakāraṇaṃ hitaṃ, tassa phalaṃ sukhaṃ. Ñātikkhayoti bhogādīhi ñātīnaṃ parihāni
analyzed: anaya byasana āpādanam viyā ati anaya byasana āpatti viyā ti atthaḥ vāḷa ādīhi kate hi anaya byasana āpādane antogadhā anaya byasana āpatti ettha nidassanan ti 🔽soka niddesa vaṇṇanā 🔽sukha kāraṇam hitam tassa phalam sukham ñāti khayaḥ ti bhoga ādīhi ñātīnam
translated: “Like the bringing about of misfortune and ruin”: the meaning is: “like the bringing about of misfortune and ruin.” For the bringing about of misfortune and ruin made by wild beasts, etc., is included in the misfortune and ruin brought about here, and is an illustration.

original: maraṇañca. Ayaṃ pana visesoti bhogabyasanādipadatthavisesaṃ rogabyasanādīsu samāsavisesañca🔽sandhāyāha. Ñātibhogā paññattimattā tabbināsāvāti iminā adhippāyena aparinipphannataṃ
analyzed: maraṇam ca ayam pana visesaḥ ti bhoga byasana ādi padattha visesam roga byasana ādīsu samāsa visesam ca  sandhāya āha ñāti bhogā paññattimattā iminā adhippāyena a parinipphanna taṃ
translated: and death. But the difference is this. The words “loss of wealth” and so on are different in meaning from the words “loss of relatives” and so on, and the compound words “loss of relatives” and so on are different in meaning from the words “loss of wealth” and so on.🔽With this difference in meaning in mind, he said “unreal”

original: sandhāya “anipphannānī”ti āha. Aparinipphannataṃyeva hi sandhāya visuddhimagge ca
analyzed: sandhāya anipphannāni iti āha aparinipphanna taṃyā iva hi sandhāya visuddhi magge ca
translated: with reference to the unreality of the five aggregates. For it is with reference to their unreality that in the Visuddhimagga

original: “dasa rūpāni anipphannānī”ti vuttaṃ. Rūpakaṇḍavaṇṇanāyañhi ni “aparinipphannānī”ti🔽vuttāni. Khandhavibhaṅge ca nipphādetabbassa nirodhasamāpattiādikassa nipphannatā
analyzed: dasa rūpāni anipphannāni iti vuttam rūpa kaṇḍa vaṇṇanāyan hi a parinipphannāni iti  vuttāni khandha vibhaṅge ca nipphādetabbassa nirodha samāpatti ādikassa nipphanna tā
translated: it is said: “The ten material instances are unreal.” For in the description of the aggregates they are called “unreal”🔽and in the description of the aggregates in the Khandha-vibhaṅga their reality is stated🔽with reference to the cessation of the aggregates, which are to be destroyed, and so on. But the reality of the unformed element, which is not a phenomenon subject to destruction,

original: vuttāti asabhāvadhammassa ca nipphannatā, nibbānasseva anipphannatāti.
analyzed: vuttā ati asabhāva dhammassa ca nipphanna tā nibbānassa iva anipphanna tā ti
translated: and the unreality of Nibbāna are not stated.🔽The word “dhamma” is here a synonym for cause. Thus he said: “By the cause of the arising of suffering.”

original: Dhamma-saddo hetuatthoti āha “dukkhassa uppattihetunā”ti. Jhāmanti daḍḍhaṃ. Pubbe
analyzed: dhamma saddaḥ hetu atthaḥ ti āha dukkhassa uppatti hetunā ti jhāmanti daḍḍham pubbe
translated: “Burned” means “cooked.”

original: vuttalakkhaṇādikā domanassavedanā sokoti tassa puna lakkhaṇādayo na vattabbā siyuṃ,
analyzed: vutta lakkhaṇa ādikā domanassa vedanā soko ti tassa puna lakkhaṇa ādayaḥ na vattabbā siyuṃ
translated: If grief were mere sorrow, then its characteristics and so on would not have to be stated again, since they were already stated

original: tathāpi domanassavisesattā sokassa ca visiṭṭhā lakkhaṇādayo vattabbāti “kiñcāpī”tiādimāha.
analyzed: tathā api domanassa visesa ttā sokassa ca visiṭṭhāḥ lakkhaṇa ādayaḥ vattabbā ti kiñcā api iti ādim āha
translated: Still, since grief is a special kind of sorrow, its characteristics, etc., should be stated. So he said, “And yet, etc.”

original: Visārarahitaṃ anto eva saṅkucitaṃ cintanaṃ, sukkhanaṃ vā antonijjhānaṃ. Parinijjhāyanaṃ🔽dahanaṃ. Ñātibyasanādianurūpaṃ socanaṃ anusocanaṃ, taṃ taṃ vā guṇaṃ dosañca anugantvā
analyzed: visāra rahitam antar eva saṅkucitam cintanam sukkhanam vā antonijjhānam parinijjhāyanam  dahanam ñāti byasana ādi anurūpam socanam anusocanam tam tam vā guṇam dosam ca anugantvā
translated: Thinking that is devoid of expansion, contracted within, or thinking that is inwardly fixed.🔽Rethinking is the burning.🔽Grieving is the sorrowing in conformity with the loss of relatives, etc.; or it is the sorrowing by following this or that quality or fault.

original: socanaṃ tappanaṃ anusocanaṃ.
analyzed: socanam tappanam anusocanam
translated: Regrieving is the burning by following this or that quality or fault.

original: Javanakkhaṇeti manodvārajavanakkhaṇe. Tathā hi taṃ dassento “ettakā me”tiādimāha.🔽Kāyaviññāṇādivīthiyampi pana javanakkhaṇe domanassassa paccayo hoti eva. Teneva “javanakkhaṇe
analyzed: java nakkhaṇa iti manaḥ dvāra java nakkhaṇe tathā hi tam dassentaḥ ettakā mā iti ādim āha  kāya viññāṇa ādi vīthiyam pi pana java nakkhaṇe domanassassa paccayo hoti eva tena iva java nakkhaṇe
translated: At the impulsion moment: at the impulsion moment of the mind door. For it is that which is shown by the words “I have so much, etc.”

original: cā”ti āha. Aññathā kāyikacetasikadukkhānaṃ kāyavatthukamanodvārappavattānameva paccayoti
analyzed: ca āti āha aññathā kāyika cetasika dukkhānam kāya vatthuka manaḥ dvāra ppavattānam eva paccayaḥ ti
translated: But it is also a condition for the impulsion moment in the street of bodily consciousness, etc., and so on. That is why he said “at the impulsion moment, etc.” Otherwise he would have taken it only as a condition for bodily and mental pain occurring in the body door and the mind door.

original: gaṇheyya tattha visesena kāyikacetasikasaddappavattito.
analyzed: gaṇheyya tattha visesena kāyika cetasika sadda ppavattito
translated: And the words “bodily” and “mental” would have been used there without distinction.

original: Tujjatīti “tudatī”ti vattabbe byattayavasena vuttanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: tujjati iti tudati iti vattabbe vyattaya vasena vuttam iti veditabbam
translated: It torments: it should be said “it torments” . But it should be understood that the form “it torments” is used because of the three sibilants.

original: Paridevaniddesavaṇṇanā
translated: Description of Lamentation🔽Lamentation is a sound made by those who, when they have lost their horses, etc.,

original: 195. Ādevanti etenāti ādevoti ādevana-saddaṃ katvā assuvimocanādivikāraṃ āpajjantānaṃ
analyzed: ādevanti etena ati ādevaḥ ti ādevana saddam katvā assu vimocana ādi vikāram āpajjantānam
translated: have become disconsolate and are uttering cries of lamentation, and it is called “lamentation” because it is the cause of their disconsolation.

original: tabbikārāpattiyā so saddo karaṇabhāvena vuttoti. Vīhipalāpādayo viya tucchaṃ vacanaṃ
analyzed: tad vikāra āpattiyā saḥ saddo karaṇa bhāvena vuttaḥ iti vīhi palāpa ādayaḥ viya tuccham vacanam
translated: But chatter is empty talk, like the prattle of parrots, mynah birds, etc.

original: palāpo. Guṇadose kitteti bodhetīti guṇadosakittanaraso lālappa-saddo. Atthānatthe
analyzed: palāpaḥ guṇa dose kitteti bodheti iti guṇa dosa kittana rasaḥ lālappa saddaḥ attha anatthe
translated: It is called “chatter” because it is the cause of the disclosure of good and bad qualities.

original: hiriyitabbajane ca avicāretvā puggalassa sambhamabhāvo hutvā paridevana-saddo upaṭṭhātīti
analyzed: ca a vicāretvā puggalassa sambhama bhāvaḥ hutvā paridevana saddaḥ upaṭṭhāti iti
translated: The sound of lamentation occurs in one who, without examining whether there is a reason for shame or not, is overcome by disconsolation.

original: “sambhamapaccupaṭṭhāno”ti vutto, sokavatthuavighātena vā sambhamo, na uttāsasambhamo,
analyzed: sambhama paccupaṭṭhāno ti vutto soka vatthu avighātena vā sambhamaḥ na uttāsa sambhamaḥ
translated: That is why it is said to be “accompanied by disconsolation.” Or alternatively, the disconsolation is not due to fear, but to the frustration of the object of sorrow.

original: so ca paridevana-saddena pākaṭo hotīti paridevo “sambhamapaccupaṭṭhāno”ti vutto.
analyzed: so ca paridevana saddena pākaṭaḥ hoti iti paridevaḥ sambhama paccupaṭṭhānaḥ ti vutto
translated: And that is evident through the sound of lamentation. That is why it is said that lamentation is “accompanied by disconsolation.”

original: Sokābhibhūto paridevananimittaṃ muṭṭhipothanādīni karoti, paridevananimittameva ca ñātiabbhatthaṅgamanādīni cintetīti paridevassa dukkhadomanassānaṃ vatthubhāvo vutto.
analyzed: soka abhibhūtaḥ paridevana nimittam muṭṭhi pothana ādīni karoti paridevana nimittam eva ca ñāti abbhatthaṅgamana ādīni cinteti iti paridevassa dukkha domanassānam vatthu bhāvaḥ vutto
translated: Lamentation is said to have the nature of pain and grief because one who is overcome by sorrow makes gestures of lamentation such as beating one’s breast, etc., and thinks of the reasons for lamenting such as the loss of relatives, etc.

original: Bhiyyoti yena vinā na hoti, tato paridevasamuṭṭhāpakadomanassato, pubbe vuttadukkhato
analyzed: bhiyyas ti yena vinā na hoti tatas parideva samuṭṭhāpaka domanassato pubbe vutta dukkhato
translated: and the bodily and mental pain that has that as its source, and also more than the grief that is the source of the lamenting, and more than the pain already mentioned,

original: vā bhiyyo, kaṇṭhoṭṭhatāluādisosajatopi vā bhiyyoti aññañca kāyikaṃ cetasikaṃ taṃnidānadukkhaṃ saṅgaṇhāti.
analyzed: vā bhiyyas vā bhiyyas ti aññam ca kāyikam cetasikam taṃnidāna dukkham saṅgaṇhāti
translated: and more than the pain in the throat, palate, etc., that is born together with it.

original: Dukkhadomanassaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dukkha domanassa niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the description of pain and grief

original: 196-7. Kāyikaṃ dukkhaṃ kāyikassa dukkhassa upanissayapaccayoti “dukkhitassa dukkhaṃ🔽uppajjatī”ti vuttaṃ. Etena dukkhena abhibhūtattā nakkhattaṃ kīḷituṃ na labhāmīti
analyzed: kāyikam dukkham kāyikassa dukkhassa upanissaya paccayo ti dukkhitassa dukkham  uppajjati iti vuttam etena dukkhena abhibhūta ttā nakkhattam kīḷitum na labhāmi iti
translated: . “Painful bodily feeling is a condition, as decisive support, for painful bodily feeling”: painful bodily feeling arises in one who is afflicted with pain.

original: balavadomanassaṃ uppajjatīti dukkhassa domanassavatthutā hoti.
analyzed: balava domanassam uppajjati iti dukkhassa domanassa vatthu tā hoti
translated: Because he is overcome by this pain, he says, “I am not getting a chance to play the game,” and so he arouses strong grief. Thus painful bodily feeling is a condition, as object, for grief.

original: Attano pavattikkhaṇaṃ sandhāya “pīḷetī”ti vuttaṃ kāyikadukkhaṃ, tadupanissayato vā.
analyzed: attanaḥ pavatti khaṇam sandhāya pīḷeti iti vuttam kāyika dukkham tad upanissayataḥ vā
translated: The bodily pain that is said to “afflict” is bodily pain that occurs in the present moment, or it is pain that is a condition for grief.

original: Āvaṭṭantīti parivaṭṭanti. Vivaṭṭantīti pabbhāre khittatthambho viya ludhanti. Mūlacchinnarukkho
analyzed: āvaṭṭanti iti parivaṭṭanti vivaṭṭanti iti pabbhāre khitta tthambhaḥ viya mūla chinna rukkho
translated: “Revolving”: turning round and round. “Rolling”: rolling like a ball. “Falling”: falling like a tree trunk thrown down from a cliff.

original: viya chinnapapātaṃ papatanti, paridayhamānacittā purimadomanassupanissayavasena cintenti,
analyzed: viya chinna papātam papatanti paridayhamāna cittā purima domanassa upanissaya vasena cintenti
translated: they fall as if falling down a steep cliff that has been cut, and with their minds burning they think in terms of the former grief,

original: vigate domanasse tathācintanaṃ natthīti.
analyzed: vigate domanasse tathā cintanam na atthi iti
translated: but when grief has gone there is no such thinking.

original: Upāyāsaniddesavaṇṇanā🔽198. Sabbavisayappaṭipattinivāraṇavasena samantato sīdanaṃ saṃsīdanaṃ, uṭṭhetumpi🔽asakkuṇeyyatākaraṇavasena atibalavaṃ, virūpaṃ vā sīdanaṃ visīdanaṃ. Aññaṃ visayaṃ🔽agantvā ñātibyasanādīsu virūpo āsaṅgo tattheva avabandhatā byāsatti. Nitthunanakaraṇato🔽nitthunanaraso. Visīdanaṃ visādo.
analyzed: sabba visaya paṭipatti nivāraṇa vasena samantataḥ sīdanam saṃsīdanam uṭṭhetum pi  asakkuṇeyya tā karaṇa vasena ati balavam virūpam vā sīdanam visīdanam aññam visayam  a gantvā ñāti byasana ādīsu virūpaḥ āsaṅgaḥ tattha iva avabandha tā byāsatti nitthunana karaṇato  nitthunana rasaḥ visīdanam visādaḥ
translated: The Description of Despair

original: Sayaṃ na dukkho dosattā saṅkhārakkhandhapariyāpannadhammantarattā vā. Ye pana domanassameva🔽upāyāsoti vadeyyuṃ, te “upāyāso tīhi khandhehi ekenāyatanena ekāya dhātuyā sampayutto,
analyzed: sayam na dukkhaḥ dosa ttā saṅkhāra kkhandha pariyāpanna dhamma antara ttā vā ye pana domanassam eva 🔽upāyāsaḥ ti vadeyyum te upāyāsaḥ tīhi khandhehi ekena āyatanena ekāya dhātuyā sampayuttaḥ
translated: It is a state of lying all round, that is, of lying down, by preventing the attainment of all objects. It is a state of lying down very strongly, or of lying down in a bad way, in the sense of being incapable of getting up. It is a state of lying down in a bad way, that is, of lying down in a bad way, in the sense of being incapable of going to another object. It is a state of lying down in a bad way, that is, of lying down in a bad way, in the sense of being incapable of going to another object. It is a state of lying down in a bad way, that is, of lying down in a bad way, in the sense of being incapable of going to another object. It is a state of lying down in a bad way, that is, of lying down in a bad way, in the sense of being incapable of going to another object. It is a state of lying down in a bad way, that is, of lying down in a bad way, in the sense of being incapable of going to another object. It is a state of lying down in a bad way, that is, of lying down in a bad way, in the sense of being incapable of going to another object. It is a state of lying down in a bad way, that is, of lying down in a bad way, in the sense of being incapable of going to another object. It is a state of lying down in a bad way, that is, of lying down in a bad way, in the sense of being incapable of going to another object. It is a state of lying down in a bad way, that is, of lying down in a bad way, in the sense of being incapable of going to another object. It is a state of lying down in a bad way, that is, of lying down in a bad way, in the sense of being incapable of going to another object. It is a state of lying down in a bad way, that is, of lying down in a bad way, in the sense of being incapable of going to another object. It is a state of lying down in a bad way, that is, of lying down in a bad way, in the sense of being

original: ekena khandhena ekenāyatanena ekāya dhātuyā kehici sampayutto”ti imāya pāḷiyā paṭikkhipitabbā.
analyzed: ekena khandhena ekena āyatanena ekāya dhātuyā kehici sampayuttaḥ ti imāya pāḷiyā paṭikkhipitabbā
translated: “With one aggregate, with one base, with one element, with some” .

original: Visādappattiyā sukhadukkhakāraṇaṃ agaṇayitvā dukkhaṭṭhānādīni karontānaṃ upāyāso🔽kāyikadukkhassa vatthu hoti, visādanavaseneva ñātivināsādīni cintentānaṃ domanassassa.
analyzed: visāda ppattiyā sukha dukkha kāraṇam a gaṇayitvā dukkha ṭṭhāna ādīni karontānam upāyāsaḥ  kāyika dukkhassa vatthu hoti visādana vasena iva ñāti vināsa ādīni cintentānam domanassassa
translated: The reason for the occurrence of grief is the occurrence of the state of being a victim of circumstances, which is the cause of pain and pleasure, in those who are victims of circumstances.🔽The state of being a victim of circumstances is the basis for bodily pain, and the state of being a victim of circumstances in those who are victims of circumstances and who think about the destruction of relatives, etc., is the basis for grief.

original: Attano pavattikkhaṇeyeva upāyāso domanassasampayogato cittaṃ paridahati, avipphārikatākaraṇavasena🔽kāyaṃ visādeti, tadubhayakaraṇeneva tato paraṃ taṃnimittaṃ kāyikaṃ cetasikañca adhimattaṃ
analyzed: attanaḥ pavatti kkhaṇeya iva upāyāsaḥ domanassa sampayogataḥ cittam paridahati a vipphārika tā karaṇa vasena  kāyam tad ubhaya karaṇena iva tatas param tad nimittam kāyikam cetasikam ca adhimattam
translated: The state of being a victim of circumstances, which occurs in the moment of its own occurrence, is the cause of the burning of the mind through association with grief.🔽The state of being a victim of circumstances is the cause of the burning of the body through the non-diffusion of the mind.

original: dukkhaṃ janayatīti dukkho vutto.
analyzed: dukkham janayati iti dukkhaḥ vutto
translated: The state of being a victim of circumstances is the cause of the arising of bodily and mental pain beyond that through the production of both. Thus it is called “pain.”

original: Appiyasampayoganiddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: appiya sampayoga niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the description of the meeting with the unloved

original: 199. Na appiyantīti na gamiyanti, na pavesīyantīti attho. Anatthanti byasanaṃ, dukkhaṃ
analyzed: na na gamiyanti na pavesīyanti iti atthaḥ anatthanti byasanam dukkham
translated: “Not going” : the meaning is, not entering. “Not beneficial” : misfortune, or suffering.

original: vā. Ahitanti tassa hetuṃ. Dutiye atthavikappe atthaṃ na kāmentīti anatthakāmātiādi
analyzed: vā ahitam ti tassa hetum dutiye attha vikappe attham na kāmenti iti anattha kāma atiādi
translated: “Not helpful” : the cause of that. In the second interpretation, “they do not do what is beneficial” is the same as “they do not wish what is beneficial.”

original: asamatthasamāsopi yojito. “Asūriyapassāni mukhānī”tiādīsu viya hi yena samāso, na
analyzed: asamattha samāsaḥ api yojitaḥ a sūriya passāni mukhāni iti ādīsu viya hi yena samāsaḥ na
translated: and the negative is joined with the compound. For just as in such passages as “faces without sun-shades” , so this negative a- is not a prohibition of that with which the compound is made.

original: tassāyaṃ paṭisedhako a-kāroti. Yasmiṃ kismiñci nibbhaye yogakkhema-saddo niruḷho
analyzed: tassa ayam paṭisedhakaḥ yasmin kismiñci nibbhaye yogakkhema saddaḥ niruḷhaḥ
translated: The word “refuge” is well known in the sense of “safety from danger”

original: dukkhayogato khemattā.
analyzed: dukkha yogataḥ khema ttā
translated: because of safety from the yoke of suffering.

original: Saṅgatiādīsu saṅkhāravasena yaṃ labbhati, taṃ gahetabbaṃ. Na hi saṅkhārānaṃ ṭhānanisajjādayo
analyzed: saṅgati ādīsu saṅkhāra vasena yam labbhati tam gahetabbam na hi ṭhāna nisajja ādayaḥ
translated: As to “meeting” and the rest, what is found in the sense of determinations should be taken. For there is no

original: bhojanādikiccesu vā sahakaraṇaṃ vijjatīti pacchimadvayaṃ tadatthavasena labbhatīti
analyzed: bhojana ādi kiccesu vā sahakaraṇam vijjati iti pacchima dvayam tad attha vasena labbhati iti
translated: meeting, sitting, etc., of determinations, nor is there any co-operation of them in the work of eating, etc., so the last two🔽are found in the sense of that, and it cannot be said that they are.

original: na sakkā vattunti. Yaṃ labbhatīti vā yaṃ atthajātaṃ labbhatīti attho. Tena yathā
analyzed: na sakkā vattunti yam labbhati iti vā yam attha jātam labbhati iti tena yathā
translated: What is found is what is found in the sense of meaning.

original: labbhati saṅgatiādīsu attho, tathā yojetabbo. Puggalassa hi saṅgati gantvā saṅkhārehi
analyzed: labbhati saṅgati ādīsu atthaḥ tathā yojetabbo puggalassa hi saṅgati gantvā saṅkhārehi
translated: So it should be construed according to the meaning found in “meeting” and the rest. For a person’s meeting, i.e. going to, is a

original: saṃyogo hoti, āgatehi ca tehi, puggalassa ca attano ṭhānādīsu saṅkhārehi sahabhāvo
analyzed: saṃyogaḥ hoti āgatehi ca tehi puggalassa ca attanaḥ ṭhāna ādīsu saṅkhārehi sahabhāvaḥ
translated: coming together with determinations, and his sitting, etc., is a co-existence with them in his own place, etc., and his work is a🔽mingling with them in all activities.

original: hoti, sabbakiriyāsu ca missībhāvoti. Anatthabhāvo upaddavabhāvo.
analyzed: hoti sabba kiriyāsu ca missībhāvaḥ ti anattha bhāvaḥ upaddava bhāvaḥ
translated: The state of non-advantage is the state of calamity.

original: Aniṭṭhānaṃ āpāthagamanamattaṃ taṃgahaṇamattañca appiyasampayogo, na pana pathaviphassādayo
analyzed: aniṭṭhānam āpātha gamana mattam appiya sampayogaḥ na pana pathavi phassa ādayo
translated: The mere coming into focus of what is not liked and the mere grasping of it are association with what is not liked, but there is no such thing as a single state called ‘association with what is not liked’ as there is such things as earth, fire, etc.

original: viya appiyasampayogo nāma eko dhammo atthīti āha “so atthato eko dhammo nāma natthī”ti.
analyzed: viya appiya sampayogaḥ nāma ekaḥ dhammo atthi iti āha so atthataḥ ekaḥ dhammo nāma natthi iti
translated: That is why he said ‘in fact there is no single state called “what is not liked” ’.

original: Aniṭṭhāni kaṇṭakādīni amittā ca usuādīhi vijjhanādidukkhaṃ uppādenti.
analyzed: aniṭṭhāni kaṇṭaka ādīni amittā ca usu ādīhi vijjhana ādi dukkham uppādenti
translated: What is not liked, such as thorns, etc., and enemies, etc., cause the pain of being pricked, etc.,

original: Idhāti imasmiṃ loke dukkhaṃ hotīti vā idha imasmiṃ dukkhasaccaniddese dukkho vuttoti vā yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: idha ati imasmin loke dukkham hoti iti vā idha imasmin dukkha sacca niddese dukkhaḥ vutto ti vā yojetabbam
translated: Here in this world, pain is, or pain is mentioned here in the description of the truth of suffering,

original: Piyavippayoganiddesavaṇṇanā
translated: Explanation of the Description of Separation from What is Liked

original: 200. Minantīti nāḷiyādīsu dhaññaṃ viya anto pakkhipanti, na bahi karontīti attho.
analyzed: minanti iti nāḷiya ādīsu dhaññam viya antar pakkhipanti na bahi karonti iti attho
translated: They are ‘miners’ because they put the loved object inside them as if it were grain in a bamboo tube, etc., and do not let it go outside.

original: Amā-saddo sahabhāvadīpako. Ñāyanti vā ajjhattikāicceva. Ñātibyasanādiko hutvā upaṭṭhātīti🔽byasanapaccupaṭṭhāno. Sokuppādaneneva sarīraṃ sosenti, kisaṃ karonti, akisampi nirojatākaraṇena
analyzed: amā saddaḥ sahabhāva dīpakaḥ vā ñāti byasana ādikaḥ hutvā upaṭṭhāti iti 🔽byasana paccupaṭṭhāno soka uppādanena iva sarīram sosenti kisam karonti a kisam pi niroja tā akaraṇena
translated: The word ‘together’ shows that they are co-existent. Or they are ‘together’ in the sense of ‘inside’ . They appear as the loss of relatives, etc.,🔽and so they are ‘the appearance of loss’. They ‘wither’ the body by producing sorrow and they ‘dry up’ it by making it emaciated, or even if it is not emaciated, by making it unhealthy.

original: milāpenti, tato ca kāyikaṃ dukkhaṃ uppajjatīti taduppādakatā vuttā.
analyzed: milāpenti tatas ca kāyikam dukkham uppajjati iti tad uppādaka tā vuttā
translated: and from that bodily pain arises. So it is said that it is the cause of that.

original: Sokasarasamappitāti etena cetasikadukkhaṃ dasseti, vitujjantīti etena kāyikaṃ dukkhaṃ.
analyzed: etena cetasika dukkham dasseti vitujjanti iti etena kāyikam dukkham
translated: “With grief and fever” : by this he shows mental pain. “They are torn” : by this he shows bodily pain.

original: Icchāniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: icchā niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of Want

original: 201. Yasmiṃ kāle jātiyā na āgantabbaṃ, taṃ kālaṃ gahetvā āha “parinibbutesu ca vijjamānaṃ🔽jātiyā anāgamana”nti. Yampīti yenapīti attho vutto. Yadāpi pana yaṃ-saddo “iccha”nti🔽etaṃ apekkhati, tadāpi alābhavisiṭṭhā icchā vuttā hoti. Yadā “na labhatī”ti etaṃ
analyzed: yasmin kāle jātiyā na āgantabbam tam kālam gahetvā āha parinibbutesu ca vijjamānam  jātiyāḥ anāgamanam ti yam pi iti yena pi iti atthaḥ vuttaḥ yadā api pana yaṃ saddaḥ icchanti  etam apekkhati tadā api alābha visiṭṭhā icchā vuttā hoti yadā na labhati iti etam
translated: At the time when there is no coming of birth, he takes that time and says, “The non-coming of birth exists in those who have attained extinction.”🔽The word yampi is used in the sense of yenapi . But when the word yam is dependent on icchā , then want, which is distinguished by icchā, is stated.

original: apekkhati, tadā icchāvisiṭṭho alābho vutto hoti. So panatthato añño dhammo natthi,🔽tathāpi alabbhaneyyaicchāva vuttā hoti. Apāpuṇitabbesu pavattattā eva “appattipaccupaṭṭhānā”ti
analyzed: apekkhati tadā icchā visiṭṭhaḥ alābho vutto hoti so pana atthataḥ aññaḥ dhammo natthi  tathā api alabbhaneyya aicchā ava vuttā hoti apāpuṇitabbesu pavatta ttā eva appatti paccupaṭṭhānā ti
translated: When it is dependent on na labhati , then non-gain, which is distinguished by icchā, is stated. But in meaning it is not a different state.🔽Nevertheless, it is said to be want that cannot be gained, because it occurs in regard to what cannot be reached.

original: vuttā. Yattha hi sā icchā pavattā, taṃ vatthuṃ apāpuṇantī hutvā gayhatīti.
analyzed: vuttā yattha hi sā icchā pavattā tam vatthum apāpuṇantī hutvā gayhati iti
translated: It is said to have non-attainment as its proximate cause, because it is apprehended as not reaching the object in which it occurs.

original: Chinnabhinnagaṇenāti nillajjena dhuttagaṇena, kappaṭikagaṇena vā.
analyzed: chinna bhinna gaṇena ati nillajjena dhutta gaṇena kappaṭika gaṇena vā
translated: With a crowd of shameless scoundrels: with a crowd of shameless rogues or with a crowd of scoundrels.

original: Vighātamayanti cittavighātamayaṃ domanassaṃ cittavighātato eva uppannaṃ ubbandhanajarātisārādikāyikaṃ dukkhañca. Icchitālābhanti alabbhaneyyaicchameva vadati.
analyzed: vighāta mayanti citta vighāta mayam domanassam citta vighātataḥ eva uppannam ubbandhana jarā atisāra ādi kāyikam dukkham ca icchita alābhanti vadati
translated: With a mass of grief: with a mass of grief consisting in mental pain, and with a mass of grief consisting in bodily pain arisen from mental pain, such as the pain of being bound, of being imprisoned, of being whipped, and so on. With a mass of want: he says “with a mass of want” of a want that is unobtainable.

original: Upādānakkhandhaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: upādāna kkhandha niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Aggregations as Clinging

original: 202. Vitthiṇṇassa dukkhassa ettakanti dassanaṃ dukkhassa saṅkhepo, taṃ kātuṃ na sakkā🔽vitthārassa anantattā. Dukkhavitthāragataṃ pana desanāvitthāraṃ pahāya yattha sabbo
analyzed: vitthiṇṇassa dukkhassa ettakan ti dassanam dukkhassa saṅkhepo tam kātum na sakkā  vitthārassa ananta ttā dukkha vitthāra gatam pana desanā vitthāram pahāya yattha sabbo
translated: The brief description of suffering is the seeing of suffering as just so much; it cannot be done in detail

original: dukkhavitthāro samodhānaṃ gacchati, tattha desanāya vavatthānaṃ saṅkhepo, taṃ kātuṃ
analyzed: dukkha vitthāraḥ samodhānam gacchati tattha desanāya vavatthānam saṅkhepaḥ tam kātum
translated: because the extent of suffering is infinite. But the detailed description of the teaching can be done by leaving out the detailed description of suffering and by defining the teaching in a place where the whole extent of suffering is included;

original: sakkā tādisassa vatthuno sabbhāvā.
analyzed: sakkā tādisassa vatthuno sabbhāvā
translated: that can be done because the nature of such a subject is such.

original: Desaṃ jānanto maggakkhāyikapuriso desako. Bhagavāpi dukkhassa desako. “Dukkhantadesakenā”ti vā pāṭho, dukkhantakkhāyikoti attho.
analyzed: desam jānantaḥ magga kkhāyika purisaḥ desakaḥ bhagavā api dukkhassa desakaḥ dukkhanta desakena ati vā pāṭhaḥ dukkhanta khāyikaḥ iti atthaḥ
translated: The man who knows the place is the guide; the Blessed One is the guide of the path to the end of suffering. Or the reading is “dukkhassa antakiriyāya,” the meaning being “the describer of the end of suffering.”

original: Pāvakādayo yathā indhanādīni bādhenti, evaṃ bādhayamānā. Māraṇantikadukkhābhighātenāti
analyzed: pāvaka ādayaḥ yathā indhana ādīni bādhenti evam bādhayamānāḥ māraṇa antika dukkha abhighātena ati
translated: As fire, etc., do so by afflicting fuel, etc., so do these afflictions. By the affliction of suffering that is near to death:

original: iminā atipākaṭena jātijarādukkhavighātajasokādayo dasseti. Tatoti paridevato uddhaṃ.
analyzed: iminā ati pākaṭena jāti jarā dukkha vighāta ja soka ādayaḥ dasseti tatas ti paridevataḥ uddham
translated: by this he shows grief, etc., which are born of the affliction of suffering due to birth and ageing. From that: from the lamenting.

original: Kaṇṭha sosādi sandhi bandhacchedanādi janaka dhātukkhobha samāyogato kāyassa ābādhanadukkhaṃ
analyzed: kaṇṭha sosa ādi sandhi bandha chedana ādi janaka dhātu khobha samāyogato kāyassa ābādhana dukkham
translated: The suffering of affliction of the body is the disturbance of the elements that causes the breaking of the joints in the neck, etc., and so on.

original: dukkhaṃ. Yesu kesucīti tissassa vā phussassa vā upādānakkhandhesu sabbampi cakkhurogādidukkhaṃ
analyzed: dukkham yesu kesuci iti tissassa vā phussassa vā upādānakkhandhesu sabbam pi cakkhu roga ādi dukkham
translated: Suffering: in whatever aggregates of clinging, whether of Tissa or Phussa, all the suffering beginning with eye disease,

original: sabbasattagataṃ evaṃpakāramevāti saṅkhipitvā dassentoti attho.
analyzed: sabba satta gatam evaṃpakāram eva ti saṅkhipitvā dassento ti attho
translated: all of which is of the same mode of occurrence in all beings. The meaning is: he shows this by way of abbreviation.

original: Dukkhasaccaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dukkha sacca niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the explanation of the truth of suffering is finished.

original: 2. Samudayasaccaniddesavaṇṇanā
translated: . Explanation of the truth of the origin

original: 203. Uttarapadalopaṃ katvā “punabbhavakaraṇaṃ punobbhavo”tiāha. “Manosamphasso”ti
analyzed: uttara pada lopam katvā punabbhava karaṇam punobbhavaḥ iti āha manaḥ samphassaḥ iti
translated: . He says “rebirth-producing is rebirth” by omitting the middle term. “Contact at the mind”

original: ettha mano viya ca purimapadassa okārantatā daṭṭhabbā. Atha vā sīlaṭṭhena ika-saddena
analyzed: ettha manaḥ viya ca purima padassa okāra anta tā daṭṭhabbā atha vā sīla aṭṭhena ika saddena
translated: . Here the last term should be regarded as having the locative case ending like the word “mind.” Or else, by the word “ika” in the sense of virtue,

original: gamiyatthattā kiriyāvācakassa saddassa adassanaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ yathā “apūpabhakkhanasīlo🔽āpūpiko”ti. “Taddhitā”iti bahuvacananiddesā vicittattā vā taddhitānaṃ abhidhānalakkhaṇattā🔽vā “punabbhavaṃ detī”tiādīsu atthesu ponobbhavikasaddasiddhi daṭṭhabbā. Tattha kammasahajātā🔽punabbhavaṃ deti, kammasahāyabhūtā tadasahajātā punabbhavāya saṃvattati, duvidhāpi🔽punappunaṃ bhave nibbatteti. Tenevāha “punabbhavassa dāyikāpī”tiādi. Ponobbhavikāyevāti
analyzed: gamiyatthattā kiriyā vācakassa saddassa adassanam daṭṭhabbam yathā apūpa bhakkhana sīlaḥ  āpūpikā iti bahuvacana niddesāḥ vicitta ttā vā taddhitānam abhidhāna lakkhaṇa ttā  vā punabbhavam deti itiādīsu atthesu ponobbhavika sadda siddhi daṭṭhabbā tattha kamma sahajātā  punabbhavam deti kamma sahāya bhūtā tad asahajātā punabbhavāya saṃvattati duvidhā api  punappunam bhave nibbattā iti tena iva āha punabbhavassa dāyikā api itiādi ponobbhavikāya iva ati
translated: The word “rebirth-linking” is to be understood as a verbal noun formed by the addition of a nominal affix to denote the act of giving, in the sense of “it gives rebirth-linking,” and so on. Herein, that which is conascent with kamma gives rebirth-linking; that which is not conascent with kamma but is a companion to kamma leads to rebirth-linking. Both kinds bring about rebirth again and again. That is why it is said, “It is a giver of rebirth-linking, etc.,” and “It is only what gives rebirth-linking.”🔽

original: nāmaṃ labhatīti punabbhavaṃ dāyikāpi adāyikāpi punabbhavaṃ deticceva ponobbhavikāti🔽samānavipākāti nāmaṃ labhati samānasabhāvattā tadānubhāvattā ca. Evaṃ itaresu daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽Tattha upadhimhi yathānibbatte attabhāve vipaccanakammaṃ etissāti upadhivepakkā.
analyzed: nāmam labhati iti punabbhavam dāyikā api a dāyikā api punabbhavam ponobbhavikā ati 🔽samāna vipākā ati nāmam labhati samāna sabhāva ttā tadā anubhāva ttā ca evam itaresu daṭṭhabbam 🔽tattha upadhimhi yathā nibbatte atta bhāve vipaccana kammam etissa ati upadhivepakkā
translated: The word “rebirth-linking” should be seen as a verbal noun formed from the verb “to give” (deti) in the sense of “giving rebirth-linking” . The word “rebirth-linking” is formed in the sense of “giving rebirth-linking” in the way in which the word “sugar-eater” is formed in the sense of “having the habit of eating sugar” . The word “rebirth-linking” is formed in the way stated in the sense of “giving rebirth-linking” by the addition of the suffix -aka, which has the characteristic of denoting “diversity” or “distinction” . Herein, the kamma that is conascent with the rebirth-linking consciousness gives rebirth-linking, and the kamma that is not conascent with it but is a condition for it by way of decisive support gives rebirth-linking by causing the occurrence of rebirth-linking. Both kinds of kamma cause rebirth-linking by producing rebirth in the various kinds of becoming again and again. That is why it is said, “It is the giver of rebirth-linking, too” , and so on. It is only the kamma that gives rebirth-linking that is called “rebirth-linking” because it is similar to the result, that is, rebirth-linking, and because it is the cause of it. So it is called “rebirth-linking” in the way that a tree is called a “mango” because it is similar to the mango fruit and is the cause of it. The kamma that does not give rebirth-linking is not called “rebirth-linking” in this way. Herein, kamma that is to be experienced in the present becomes kamma that is to be experienced here since it is kamma that is to be experienced in this becoming.

original: Nandanaṭṭhena nandī, rañjanaṭṭhena rāgo. Yo ca nandirāgo, yā ca taṇhā, ubhayametaṃ
analyzed: nandana ṭṭhena nandī rañjana ṭṭhena rāgaḥ yo ca nandi rāgaḥ yā ca taṇhā ubhayam etam
translated: Delight is in the sense of delighting, greed is in the sense of relishing. And the delight and greed and the craving are

original: ekatthaṃ, byañjanameva nānanti taṇhā “nandirāgena saddhiṃ atthato ekattaṃ gatā”ti
analyzed: ekattham byañjanam eva nānanti taṇhā nandi rāgena saddhim atthataḥ ekattam gatā ati
translated: all one in meaning, only the phrasing is different. So it is said that craving “has become one with delight and greed in meaning.”

original: vuttā. Rāgasambandhena “uppannassā”ti vuttaṃ. Rūpārūpabhavarāgo visuṃ vakkhatīti
analyzed: vuttā rāga sambandhena uppannassa ati vuttam rūpa arūpa bhava rāgaḥ visum vakkhati iti
translated: It is said “arisen” in the sense of the connection with greed. The greed for fine-material and immaterial becoming will be dealt with separately.

original: kāmabhave eva bhavapatthanāuppatti vuttāti veditabbā.🔽Tasmiṃ tasmiṃ piyarūpe paṭhamuppattivasena “uppajjatī”ti vuttā, punappunaṃ pavattivasena
analyzed: kāma bhave eva bhava patthanā uppatti vuttā iti veditabbā  tasmin tasmin piya rūpe paṭhama uppatti vasena uppajjati iti vuttā punappunam pavatti vasena
translated: So it should be understood that the wish for becoming is stated only in the case of sense-desire becoming.🔽It is said “arises” in the sense of first arising in the aspect of what is dear in this or that case,

original: “nivisatī”ti, pariyuṭṭhānānusayavasena vā uppattinivesā yojetabbā. Sampattiyanti🔽manussasobhagge devatte ca. Attano cakkhunti savatthukaṃ cakkhumāha, sapasādaṃ vā
analyzed: nivisati iti pariyuṭṭhāna anusaya vasena vā uppatti nivesā yojetabbā sampattiyanti  manussa sobhagge devatte ca attanaḥ cakkhunti sa vatthukam cakkhum āha sa pasādam vā
translated: and “it settles down” in the sense of its occurrence again and again, or else the arising and the settling down should be construed as the underlying tendency to the perversion of delight. In the case of success

original: maṃsapiṇḍaṃ. Vippasannapañcapasādanti parisuddhanīlapītalohitakaṇhaodātavaṇṇapasādaṃ.
analyzed: maṃsa piṇḍam vippasanna pañca pasādanti parisuddha nīla pīta lohita kaṇha odāta vaṇṇa pasādam
translated: means in the case of the success of human beings and gods. His own eye means the eye with a physical basis, or else the lump of flesh with the clear film. With the five kinds of beauty purified means with the five kinds of beauty, namely, blue, yellow, red, white, and black, purified.

original: Rajatapanāḷikaṃ viya chiddaṃ abbhantare odātattā. Pāmaṅgasuttaṃ viya lambakaṇṇabaddhaṃ.🔽Tuṅgā uccā dīghā nāsikā tuṅganāsikā, evaṃ laddhavohāraṃ attano ghānaṃ. “Laddhavohārā”ti
analyzed: rajata panāḷikam viya chiddam abbhantare odāta tā pāmaṅga suttam viya lamba kaṇṇa baddham  tuṅgā uccā dīghā nāsikā tuṅga nāsikā evam laddha vohāram attanaḥ ghānam laddha vohārā ati
translated: It is like a silver tube, because of its whiteness inside. It is like a fringe, because it is attached to the ear-lobe.

original: vā pāṭho. Tasmiṃ sati tuṅgā nāsikā yesaṃ, te tuṅganāsikā. Evaṃ laddhavohārā sattā
analyzed: vā tasmin sati tuṅgāḥ nāsikāḥ yesam te tuṅga nāsikā evam laddha vohārā sattā
translated: The nose is high, lofty, and long, thus it is high-nosed. The reading “having attained the name” is preferable. Those who have a high nose are high-nosed. Thus the meaning should be construed.

original: attano ghānanti yojanā kātabbā. Jivhaṃ…pe… maññanti vaṇṇā saṇṭhānato kiccato ca.
analyzed: attanaḥ ghānanti yojanā kātabbā jivhaṃpe maññanti vaṇṇā saṇṭhānato kiccato ca
translated: The tongue is long, slender, and soft, thus it is long, slender, and soft. It is like a lotus leaf, because of its color, shape, and function.

original: Manaṃ…pe… uḷāraṃ maññanti atītādiatthavicinanasamatthaṃ. Attanā paṭiladdhānīti ajjhattañca
analyzed: uḷāram maññanti atīta ādi attha vicinana samattham attanā paṭiladdhāni iti ajjhattam ca
translated: The mind is lofty, thus it is lofty. It is able to investigate the meaning of the past, etc., thus it is lofty. “Having attained” means having obtained.

original: sarīragandhādīni bahiddhā ca vilepanagandhādīni. Uppajjamānā uppajjatīti yadā uppajjamānā
analyzed: sarīra gandha ādīni bahiddhā ca vilepana gandha ādīni uppajjamānā uppajjati iti yadā uppajjamānā
translated: The internal odors of the body, etc., and the external odors of ointments, etc.

original: hoti, tadā ettha uppajjatīti sāmaññena gahitā uppādakiriyā lakkhaṇabhāvena vuttā,
analyzed: hoti tadā ettha uppajjati iti sāmaññena gahitā uppāda kiriyā lakkhaṇa bhāvena vuttā
translated: When it is arising, it arises here. The arising function, which is included by the word “arising” in the general sense, is stated as the characteristic in the specific sense.

original: visayavisiṭṭhā lakkhitabbabhāvena. Na hi sāmaññavisesehi nānattavohāro na hotīti.
analyzed: visaya visiṭṭhā lakkhitabba bhāvena na hi sāmañña visesehi nānatta vohāraḥ na hoti iti
translated: The characteristic is stated by way of the specific object, not by way of the general object. For there is no difference in the names of the general and specific objects.

original: Uppajjamānāti vā anicchito uppādo hetubhāvena vutto. Uppajjatīti nicchito phalabhāvena
analyzed: uppajjamānā ati vā anicchitaḥ uppādaḥ hetu bhāvena vuttaḥ uppajjati iti nicchitaḥ phala bhāvena
translated: Or else, “arising” is said to be a cause in the sense of an unchosen arising, and “arisen” in the sense of a chosen fruit.

original: “yadi uppajjamānā hoti, ettha uppajjatī”ti. So hi tena upayojito viya hoti.
analyzed: yadi uppajjamānā hoti ettha uppajjati iti saḥ hi tena upayojitaḥ viya hoti
translated: “If it is arising, it is arisen there.” For that is as if employed by it.

original: Samudayasaccaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: samudaya sacca niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of the truth of origin is ended.

original: 3. Nirodhasaccaniddesavaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the truth of cessation

original: 204. Anūhateti anuddhate, appahīneti attho.
analyzed: anūhata iti anuddhate appahīne ti attho
translated: “Not being shaken” : not being abandoned, is the meaning.

original: Sīho vedhake paṭipajjati, na usumhi, suvāno leḍḍumhi paṭipajjati, na pahārake. Khayagamanavasena
analyzed: sīhaḥ vedhake paṭipajjati na usumhi suvānaḥ leḍḍumhi paṭipajjati na pahārake khaya gamana vasena
translated: A lion attacks the killer, not the fire; a dog attacks the stone, not the stick.

original: virajjati, appavattigamanavasena nirujjhati. Anapekkhatāya cajanavasena hānivasena
analyzed: virajjati appavatti gamana vasena nirujjhati anapekkha tāya cajana vasena hāni vasena
translated: It “dispassion” in the sense of going to destruction, “ceases” in the sense of non-occurrence. It is “given up” in the sense of non-regard and in the sense of loss.

original: ca cajīyati, puna yathā na pavattati, tathā dūrakhipanavasena paṭinissajjīyati, bandhanabhūtāya
analyzed: ca cajīyati puna yathā na pavattati tathā dūra khipana vasena paṭinissajjīyati bandhana bhūtāya
translated: It is “released” in the sense of throwing far away so that it will not occur again, in the sense of being freed from the bond.

original: mocanavasena muccati, asaṃkilesavasena na allīyati. Āyūhanaṃ samudayo, tappaṭipakkhavasena anāyūhanaṃ.
analyzed: mocana vasena muccati asaṃkilesa vasena na allīyati āyūhanam samudayaḥ tad paṭipakkha vasena anāyūhanam
translated: It is “freed” in the sense of being freed from what has become a fetter. It is “not adhered to” in the sense of non-defilement. “Accumulation” is origin in the sense of heaping up. “Non-accumulation” is the opposite of that.

original: Apaññattinti apaññāpanaṃ, “tittaalābu atthī”ti vohārābhāvaṃ vā. Tittaalābuvalliyā🔽appavattiṃ icchanto puriso viya maggo daṭṭhabbo, tassa tassā appavattininnacittassa🔽mūlacchedanaṃ viya maggassa nibbānārammaṇassa taṇhāpahānaṃ. Tadāppavatti viya taṇhāya
analyzed: apaññattim ti a paññāpanam titta alābu atthi iti vohāra abhāvam vā titta alābu valliyā  appavattim icchanto purisaḥ viya maggaḥ daṭṭhabbo tassa tassā appavatti ninna cittassa  mūla chedanam viya maggassa nibbāna ārammaṇassa taṇhā apahānam viya taṇhāya
translated: “Non-proliferation” is non-proliferation of the idea of a water-lily. The path should be seen as the man who,🔽wanting to prevent the growth of the water-lily creeper,🔽cuts its roots, as it were. Cessation should be seen as the non-proliferation of craving, as the non-proliferation of the creeper.

original: appavattibhūtaṃ nibbānaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Dutiyūpamāya dakkhiṇadvāraṃ viya nibbānaṃ, coraghātakā🔽viya maggo daṭṭhabbo, purimā vā upamā maggena niruddhāya piyarūpasātarūpesu niruddhāti
analyzed: appavatti bhūtam nibbānam daṭṭhabbam dutiya upamāya dakkhiṇa dvāram viya nibbānam cora ghātakā  viya maggo daṭṭhabbo purimā vā upamā maggena niruddhāya piya rūpa sāta rūpesu niruddhā ati
translated: In the second simile, cessation should be seen as the southern gate, the path as the executioner,

original: vattabbatādassanatthaṃ vuttā, pacchimā nibbānaṃ āgamma niruddhāyapi.
analyzed: vattabba tā dassana attham vuttā pacchimā nibbānam āgamma
translated: and the objects of sensual pleasure as the thief. Or the first simile may be taken as stated in order to show that the cessation of the path is the cessation of the pleasant and painful,🔽and the second in order to show that the cessation of the path is the cessation of the pleasant and painful that has come to be in the past and that has not yet come to be in the future.

original: Nirodhasaccaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: nirodha sacca niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the truth of cessation is ended.

original: 4. Maggasaccaniddesavaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the truth of the path

original: 205. Aññamaggapaṭikkhepanatthanti titthiyehi kappitassa maggassa dukkhanirodhagāminipaṭipadābhāvaṃ
analyzed: añña magga paṭikkhepana attham titthiyehi kappitassa maggassa dukkha nirodha gāmini paṭipadā abhāvam
translated: “In order to reject other paths”: in order to show that the path formulated by the sectarians is not the way leading to the cessation of suffering,

original: paṭikkhepetunti attho, aññassa vā maggabhāvapaṭikkhepo aññamaggapaṭikkhepo. Puggalassa
analyzed: paṭikkhepetunti atthaḥ aññassa vā magga bhāva paṭikkhepaḥ añña magga paṭikkhepaḥ puggalassa
translated: the meaning is, “he rejects another’s being a path.” Or the rejection of another’s being a path is the rejection of another’s being a path.🔽He makes the noble, or he causes the noble to be obtained, because it causes the obtaining of the noble fruit.

original: ariyabhāvakarattā ariyaṃ karotīti ariyo, ariyaphalapaṭilābhakarattā ariyaṃ labhāpeti
analyzed: ariya bhāva karattā ariyam karoti iti ariyaḥ ariya phala paṭilābha karattā ariyam
translated: He generates, or he causes the noble to be generated, because it causes the obtaining of the noble fruit.

original: janetīti ariyo. Attano kiccavasena phalavasena ca ariyanāmalābho eva vuttoti daṭṭhabbo.🔽Aṭṭha aṅgāni assāti aññapadatthasamāsaṃ akatvā “aṭṭhaṅgāni assa santīti aṭṭhaṅgiko”ti
analyzed: janeti iti ariyaḥ kicca vasena phala vasena ca ariya nāmalābhaḥ eva vuttaḥ ti daṭṭhabbo  aṭṭha aṅgāni assa ati añña padattha samāsam a katvā aṭṭhaṅgāni assa santi iti aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ ti
translated: It should be regarded as the obtaining of the noble, which is stainless, in terms of its own function and in terms of the fruit.

original: padasiddhi daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: pada siddhi daṭṭhabbā
translated: Without making a compound of the words in the sense of another word, it should be regarded as the derivation of the expression “having eight factors” in the sense of “having eight factors as its own.”

original: Caturaṅgasamannāgatā vācā janaṃ saṅgaṇhātīti tabbipakkhaviratisabhāvā sammāvācā bhedakaramicchāvācāpahānena
analyzed: catur aṅga samannāgatā vācā janam saṅgaṇhāti iti tad vipakkha virati sabhāvā sammā vācā bheda karam icchā vācā apahānena
translated: Or speech endowed with four factors gathers people to oneself. Right speech, which has the nature of the abstention from the side of schism and wrong speech,

original: jane sampayutte ca pariggaṇhanakiccavatī hotīti “pariggahalakkhaṇā”ti vuttā. Yathā
analyzed: jane sampayutte ca pariggaṇhana kiccavatī hoti iti pariggaha lakkhaṇā ati vuttā yathā
translated: is said to have the characteristic of gathering because it has the function of gathering people to oneself by abandoning the schism and wrong speech.

original: cīvarakammādiko kammanto ekaṃ kātabbaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti nipphādeti, taṃtaṃkiriyānipphādako
analyzed: cīvara kamma ādikaḥ kammantaḥ ekam kātabbam samuṭṭhāpeti nipphādeti taṃ taṃ kiriyā nipphādako
translated: Just as a craft such as the making of robes, etc., produces, generates, a single thing to be done, and the production of the various actions

original: vā cetanāsaṅkhāto kammanto hatthapādacalanādikaṃ kiriyaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti, evaṃ sāvajjakattabbakiriyāsamuṭṭhāpakamicchākammantappahānena
analyzed: vā cetanā saṅkhātaḥ kammantaḥ hattha pāda calana ādikam kiriyam samuṭṭhāpeti evam sāvajja kattabba kiriyā samuṭṭhāpakam icchā kammanta ppahānena
translated: and volition, which is called “the formation of a kamma formation,” produces the action consisting in the shaking of the hand, foot, etc., so right action is the abandoning of wrong action that produces what is blameworthy and unwholesome,

original: sammākammanto niravajjasamuṭṭhāpanakiccavā hoti, sampayuttadhamme ca samuṭṭhāpento🔽eva pavattatīti “samuṭṭhāpanalakkhaṇo”ti vutto. Kāyavācānaṃ khandhasantānassa ca
analyzed: sammā kammantaḥ niravajja samuṭṭhāpana kiccavā hoti sampayutta dhamme ca samuṭṭhāpento  eva pavattati iti samuṭṭhāpana lakkhaṇo ti vutto kāya vācānam khandha santānassa ca
translated: and it has the function of producing what is blameless. It occurs in association with the associated states.🔽That is why it is said to have the characteristic of producing.

original: saṃkilesabhūtamicchāājīvappahānena sammāājīvo “vodāpanalakkhaṇo”ti vutto.
analyzed: saṃkilesa bhūta micchāājīva ppahānena sammāājīvaḥ vodāpana lakkhaṇo ti vutto
translated: Right livelihood is said to have the characteristic of cleansing because it is the abandoning of wrong livelihood, which is a defilement of body, speech, and the mental-data base.

original: Attano paccanīkakilesā diṭṭhekaṭṭhā avijjādayo. Passatīti pakāsetīti attho. Teneva hi aṅgena tattha paccavekkhaṇā pavattatīti. Tathevāti attano paccanīkakilesehi saddhinti attho.
analyzed: attano paccanīka kilesā diṭṭhekaṭṭhāḥ avijjā ādayo passati iti pakāseti iti attho tena iva hi aṅgena tattha paccavekkhaṇā pavattati iti tathā iva ati attano paccanīka kilesehi saddhinti attho
translated: The defilements that are opposed to it are ignorance, etc., which have the same object as the wrong view. “He sees” means he reveals. That is why the reviewing of that occurs through that factor. “In the same way” means together with the defilements that are opposed to it.

original: Kiccatoti pubbabhāgehi dukkhādiñāṇehi kattabbakiccassa idha nipphattito, imasseva
analyzed: kiccato ti pubba bhāgehi dukkha ādi ñāṇehi kattabba kiccassa idha nipphattitaḥ imassa eva
translated: “As the function” means that the function that has to be done by the knowledge of suffering, etc., in the prior stages is accomplished here.

original: vā ñāṇassa dukkhādippakāsanakiccato. Tīṇi nāmāni labhati kāmasaṅkappādippahānakiccanipphattito.
analyzed: vā ñāṇassa dukkha ādi ppakāsana kiccataḥ tīṇi nāmāni labhati kāma saṅkappa ādi ppahāna kicca nipphattito
translated: and the three kinds of knowledge are called “right view” because they have the function of illuminating suffering, etc. It has three names because it has the function of abandoning sensual-desire-lust, etc.

original: Sikkhāpadavibhaṅge “viraticetanā sabbe sampayuttadhammā ca sikkhāpadānī”ti vuttāti🔽tattha padhānānaṃ viraticetanānaṃ vasena “viratiyopi honti cetanāyopī”ti āha. Musāvādādīhi
analyzed: sikkhāpada vibhaṅge virati cetanā sabbe sampayutta dhammā ca sikkhāpadāni iti vuttā ati  tattha virati cetanānam vasena honti cetanāyaḥ api iti āha musāvāda ādīhi
translated: In the exposition of the training precepts it is said: “The volition of abstinence and all the associated states are the training precepts” .🔽So here he says “abstinences” and “volition” in order to include the volitions of abstinence and the associated states.🔽Or alternatively, the abstinences should be construed as “right speech” and the volitions as “right action” at the time of refraining from false speech, etc.,

original: viramaṇakāle vā viratiyo subhāsitādivācābhāsanādikāle ca cetanāyo yojetabbā, maggakkhaṇe
analyzed: viramaṇa kāle vā viratiyaḥ su bhāsita ādi vācā bhāsana ādi kāle ca cetanāyaḥ yojetabbā magga kkhaṇe
translated: and as “right speech” and “right action” at the time of uttering good speech, etc., respectively.

original: viratiyova cetanānaṃ amaggaṅgattā ekassa ñāṇassa dukkhādiñāṇatā viya ekāya viratiyā
analyzed: viratiyā uva cetanānaṃ amaggaṅga ttā ekassa ñāṇassa dukkha ādi ñāṇa tā viya ekāya viratiyā
translated: But at the moment of the path the abstinences are not factors of the volitions, just as the knowledge of suffering, etc., is not the knowledge of cessation, etc.,🔽and just as the abstinence from false speech, etc., is not the abstinence from malicious speech, etc.

original: musāvādādiviratibhāvo viya ca ekāya cetanāya sammāvācādikiccattayasādhanasabhāvābhāvā
analyzed: musāvāda ādi virati bhāvaḥ ca ekāya cetanāya
translated: And because the volitions do not have the nature of accomplishing the three functions of right speech, etc., by means of a single volition,

original: sammāvācādibhāvāsiddhito, taṃsiddhiyañca aṅgattayattāsiddhito ca.
analyzed: ca
translated: and because the establishment of that would entail the fault of over-extension, and because the establishment of that would entail the fault of the non-establishment of the three factors.

original: Pubbabhāgepi maggakkhaṇepi sammāsamādhi evāti yadipi samādhiupakārakānaṃ abhiniropanānumajjanasampiyāyanabrūhanasantasukhānaṃ
analyzed: pubbabhāge pi magga kkhaṇe pi sammāsamādhi eva ati yadi pi samādhi upakārakānam abhiniropana anumajjana sampiyāyana brūhana santa sukhānam
translated: Although right concentration is classified as fourfold by way of the four jhānas with applied thought, etc.,🔽nevertheless, just as energy does not perform the four functions of energy, namely, arousing unarisen unprofitable things, etc.,

original: vitakkādīnaṃ vasena catūhi jhānehi sammāsamādhi vibhatto, tathāpi vāyāmo viya anuppannākusalānuppādanādicatuvāyāmakiccaṃ,🔽sati viya ca asubhāsukhāniccānattesu kāyādīsu subhādisaññāpahānacatusatikiccaṃ, eko
analyzed: vitakka ādīnam vasena catūhi jhānehi sammāsamādhi vibhatto tathā api vāyāmaḥ viya anuppanna akusala anuppādana ādi catu vāyāma kiccam  ca asubha asukha anicca anattesu kāya ādīsu subha ādi saññā apahāna catusati kiccam ekaḥ
translated: and just as mindfulness does not perform the four functions of mindfulness, namely, preventing the arising of unarisen unprofitable things, etc.,

original: samādhi catukkajjhānasamādhikiccaṃ na sādhetīti pubbabhāgepi paṭhamajjhānasamādhicitte🔽jhānasamādhi paṭhamajjhānasamādhi eva maggakkhaṇepi, tathā pubbabhāgepi catutthajjhānasamādhicitte
analyzed: samādhi catukka jjhāna samādhi kiccam na sādheti iti pubba bhāge pi paṭhama jhāna samādhi citte  jhāna samādhi paṭhama jhāna samādhi eva magga kkhaṇe pi tathā pubbabhāge pi catuttha jhāna samādhi citte
translated: so too right concentration does not perform the four functions of concentration, namely, arousing unarisen profitable things, etc.🔽Therefore, although right concentration is classified as fourfold by way of the four jhānas,

original: jhānasamādhi catutthajjhānasamādhi eva maggakkhaṇepīti attho.
analyzed: jhāna samādhi catuttha jjhāna samādhi eva magga kkhaṇe pi iti attho
translated: nevertheless, just as energy and mindfulness are called factors of the path in the path consisting of eight factors, so too right concentration should be understood as one factor.

original: Vacībhedassa upakārako vitakko sāvajjānavajjavacībhedanivattanapavattanakarāya sammāvācāyapi
analyzed: vacībhedassa upakārako vitakko sāvajja anavajja vacībheda nivattana pavattana karāya
translated: Applied thought, which is a condition for speech, is also a condition for right speech, which prevents the occurrence of and causes the non-occurrence of blameworthy speech.

original: upakārako evāti “svāya”ntiādimāha. Vacībhedaniyāmikā vācā kāyikakiriyāniyāmakassa
analyzed: eva ati su āyanti ādim āha vacī bheda niyāmikā vācā kāyika kiriyā niyāmakassa
translated: and it is helpful to it, so he says “to itself” . Or alternatively, speech, which is the controller of the kinds of verbal action, is helpful to right action, which is the controller of the kinds of bodily action.🔽This energy is the energy of the four right endeavours.

original: sammākammantassa upakārikā. Idaṃ vīriyanti catusammappadhānavīriyaṃ. Gatiyoti nipphattiyo,
analyzed: sammākammantassa upakārikā idam vīriyanti catu sammappadhāna vīriyam gatiyaḥ ti
translated: The “going” is the fruition attainments,🔽or else it is the state of being the function, etc., of the path.

original: kiccādisabhāve vā. Samanvesitvāti upadhāretvā.
analyzed: kicca ādi sabhāve vā samanvesitvā ati upadhāretvā
translated: Having sought out: having investigated.🔽The construction is: having learnt the first two Truths.

original: Purimāni dve saccāni uggaṇhitvāti sambandho. Iṭṭhaṃ kantanti nirodhamaggesu ninnabhāvaṃ dasseti, na abhinandanaṃ, tanninnabhāvoyeva ca tattha kammakaraṇaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽Kiccatoti pariññādito. Ārammaṇapaṭivedhoti sacchikiriyāpaṭivedhamāha. Sabbampi paṭivedhañāṇaṃ
analyzed: purimāni dve saccāni uggaṇhitvā iti sambandho iṭṭham kantanti nirodha maggesu ninna bhāvam dasseti na abhinandanam ca tattha kamma karaṇam daṭṭhabbaṃ  kiccato ti pariññā āditaḥ ārammaṇa paṭivedho ti sacchikiriyā paṭivedham āha sabbam pi paṭivedha ñāṇam
translated: He shows that he is devoted to cessation and the path by the words “dear, beloved,” not that he delights in them. And the performance of his function should be understood as his devotion to them.🔽By the word “function” he shows that he has fully understood them by comprehending them as subject to suffering, etc.,🔽and by the words “penetration of the object” he shows that he has realized them by penetrating them.

original: lokuttaranti kasmā vuttaṃ, nanu uggahādipaṭivedho ca paṭivedhova, na ca so lokuttaroti?
analyzed: lokuttaran ti kasmā vuttam nanu uggaha ādi paṭivedho ca na ca so lokuttaraḥ ti
translated: Why is it said that all this is supramundane? But surely the learning, etc., are penetration, and they are not supramundane?🔽No. Because the learning, etc., are not referred to by the word “penetration” alone,

original: Na, kevalena paṭivedha-saddena uggahādipaṭivedhānaṃ avacanīyattā, paṭivedhanimittattā
analyzed: na kevalena paṭivedha saddena uggaha ādi paṭivedhānam avacanīya ttā paṭivedha nimitta ttā
translated: and because they are the cause of penetration.

original: vā uggahādivasena pavattaṃ dukkhādīsu pubbabhāge ñāṇaṃ “paṭivedho”ti vuttaṃ, na paṭivedhattā,
analyzed: vā uggaha ādi vasena pavattam dukkha ādīsu pubba bhāge ñāṇam paṭivedhaḥ iti vuttam na paṭivedha ttā
translated: Or else, knowledge occurring in the earlier stage in regard to suffering, etc., as apprehending, etc., is called “penetration” not because it penetrates but because it is the state of penetration.

original: paṭivedhabhūtameva pana ñāṇaṃ sandhāyāha “sabbampi paṭivedhañāṇaṃ lokuttara”nti.🔽Uggahaparipucchāñāṇānipi savanañāṇe eva avarodhaṃ gacchantīti “savanadhāraṇasammasanañāṇaṃ
analyzed: paṭivedha bhūtam eva pana ñāṇam sandhāya āha sabbam pi paṭivedha ñāṇam lokuttaran ti  uggaha paripucchā ñāṇāni pi savana ñāṇe eva avarodham gacchanti iti savana dhāraṇa sammasana ñāṇam
translated: And it is only knowledge that is the state of penetration that is supramundane, as it is said: “All penetration is supramundane” .🔽But the knowledge of apprehending and the knowledge of resolving also come under the knowledge of learning, so he says that there are only three kinds of knowledge: “The knowledge of learning, bearing in mind, and reviewing is mundane” .

original: lokiya”nti tividhameva ñāṇamāha. Uggahādīhi saccapariggaṇhanaṃ pariggaho.
analyzed: lokiyam ti tividham eva ñāṇam āha uggaha ādīhi sacca pariggaṇhanam pariggahaḥ
translated: Apprehending is the discerning of the truths by apprehending, etc.,🔽“Effort” is action or exertion. He illustrates the need for it to be greater and more difficult by the similes beginning with “in order to grasp the summit of becoming” .🔽“The path’s destruction”: the path gone by is called “the path” .

original: Payogoti kiriyā, vāyāmo vā. Tassa mahantatarassa icchitabbataṃ dukkarataratañca upamāhi dasseti “bhavaggagahaṇattha”ntiādinā.🔽Padaghātanti ettha gatamaggo “pada”nti vuccati. Yena cupāyena kāraṇena kāmavitakko🔽uppajjati, so tassa gatamaggoti tassa ghāto padaghāto. Ussukkāpetvāti uddhaṃ uddhaṃ
analyzed: payogo ti kiriyā vāyāmaḥ vā tassa mahantatarassa icchitabba tam dukkaratara tam ca upamāhi dasseti bhavagga gahaṇa ttha nti ādinā  pada ghātanti ettha gata maggo padanti vuccati yena ca upāyena kāraṇena kāma vitakko  uppajjati saḥ tassa gata maggo ti tassa ghāto pada ghāto ussukkāpetvā ati uddham uddham
translated: And the destruction of that is the destruction of the path. The destruction of the path is the destruction of the path.

original: santivisesayuttaṃ katvā, vaḍḍhetvāti attho.
analyzed: santi visesa yuttam katvā vaḍḍhetvā ti atthaḥ
translated: The destruction of the path is the destruction of the path. The destruction of the path is the destruction of the path. The destruction of the path is the destruction of the path. The destruction of the path is the destruction of the path. The destruction of the path is the destruction of the path. The destruction of the path is the destruction of the path. The destruction of the path is the destruction of the path. The destruction of the path is the destruction of the path. The destruction of the path is the destruction of the path. The destruction of the path is the destruction of the path. The destruction of the path is the destruction of the path. The destruction of the path is the destruction of the path. The destruction of the path is the destruction of the path. The destruction of the path is the destruction of the path. The destruction of the path is the destruction of the path. The destruction of the path is the destruction of the path. The destruction of the path is the destruction of the path. The destruction of the path is the destruction of the path. The destruction of the path is the destruction of the path. The destruction of the path is the destruction of the path. The destruction of the path is the destruction of the path.
