The destruction of the path is the destruction of the path. The destruction of the path is the destruction of the path. The destruction of the path is the destruction of the path. The destruction

original: Pāḷiyaṃ vibhattesūti katarapāḷiyaṃ? Dhammasaṅgahe tāva aṭṭha kasiṇāni dasa asubhā
analyzed: pāḷiyam vibhattesu iti katara pāḷiyam dhamma saṅgahe tāva aṭṭha kasiṇāni dasa asubhā
translated: In the text? —In the Dhatu Saṅgaha, for instance, the eight kasiṇas, the ten kinds of foulness,

original: cattāro brahmavihārā cattāri āruppāni vibhattāni, āgamesu dasa anussatiyo āhāre paṭikūlasaññā
analyzed: cattāro brahmavihārā cattāri āruppāni vibhattāni āgamesu dasa anussatiyaḥ āhāre paṭikūla saññā
translated: the four divine abidings, and the four immaterial states are treated; in the Āgamas, the ten recollections, the perception of the repulsiveness of food,🔽and the defining of the four elements; and in the Abhidhamma Piṭaka, the ten universal states of consciousness.

original: catudhātuvavatthānanti imāni cāti tattha tattha vibhattaṃ. Imesu tīsūti kāmādīsu tīsu ṭhānesu.
analyzed: catu dhātu vavatthānan ti imāni ca ati tattha tattha vibhattam imesu tīsu iti kāma ādīsu tīsu ṭhānesu
translated: In these three places, that is to say, in the three places beginning with sensuality.

original: Micchāvācāsaṅkhātāyāti etena ekāya cetanāya pahātabbaekattaṃ dasseti. Idha ariyasāvako🔽sakalyāṇaputhujjanako sekkho. Kāyadvāravītikkamāti ājīvahetukato pāṇātipātādito visuṃ
analyzed: micchā vācā saṅkhātāya ati etena ekāya cetanāya pahātabba ekattam dasseti idha ariya sāvako  sa kalyāṇa puthujjanakaḥ sekkhaḥ kāya dvāra vītikkamāti ājīva hetukataḥ pāṇātipāta āditaḥ visum
translated: Called wrong speech: this shows that it is abandoned by a single volition. Herein,

original: visuṃ viramaṇaṃ yojetabbaṃ.🔽Ayaṃ panassāti maggabhāvena catubbidhampi ekattena gahetvā assa maggassa ayaṃ jhānavasena
analyzed: visum viramaṇam yojetabbam  ayam pana assa ati magga bhāvena catubbidham pi ekattena gahetvā assa maggassa ayam jhāna vasena
translated: a noble disciple is a whole-perfected ordinary man. The breach of the bodily door: abstention from killing breathing things, etc., should be construed as the cause of livelihood.

original: sabbasadisasabbāsadisaekaccasadisatā viseso. Pādakajjhānaniyāmena hotīti idha pādakajjhānaniyāmaṃ
analyzed: sabba sadisa sabba asadisa ekacca sadisa tā viseso pādaka jjhāna niyāmena hoti iti idha pādaka jjhāna niyāmam
translated: This is its: this is the difference in the path’s similarity and dissimilarity in all aspects and in some aspects, taking it as one by way of the path. It is according to the method of the basic jhāna.

original: dhuraṃ katvā āha, aṭṭhasāliniyaṃ pana vipassanāniyāmaṃ tattha sabbavādāvirodhato,
analyzed: dhuram katvā āha aṭṭhasāliniyam pana vipassanā niyāmam tattha sabba vāda avirodhato
translated: He said it with the burden in mind. But in the Aṭṭhasālinī the definition of the supramundane jhāna is given there in terms of insight order, because there is no disagreement about that there.

original: idha pana sammasitajjhānapuggalajjhāsayavādanivattanato pādakajjhānaniyāmaṃ. Vipassanāniyāmo
analyzed: idha pana sammasita jjhāna puggala jhā saya vāda nivattanato pādaka jhāna niyāmam vipassanā niyāmaḥ
translated: But here it is given in terms of the basic jhāna order, because it prevents the misapprehension that the jhāna of the person who has attained insight is a jhāna of the jhānas.🔽But the definition of the supramundane jhāna in terms of insight order should be regarded as not excluded here too because it is common to all.

original: pana sādhāraṇattā idhāpi na paṭikkhittoti daṭṭhabbo. Aññe cācariyavādā vakkhamānā
analyzed: pana sādhāraṇa ttā idha api na paṭikkhittaḥ ti daṭṭhabbo aññe ca ācariya vādāḥ vakkhamānā
translated: And other teachers’ opinions will be stated and discussed later.

original: vibhajitabbāti yathāvuttameva tāva pādakajjhānaniyāmaṃ vibhajanto āha “pādakajjhānaniyāmena tāvā”ti.
analyzed: vibhajitabbā ti yathā vuttam eva tāva pādaka jjhāna niyāmam vibhajantaḥ āha pādaka jjhāna niyāmena tāva iti
translated: So he said, “As regards the basic jhāna order,” in order to comment on just the basic jhāna order as stated.

original: Āruppe catukkapañcaka…pe… vuttaṃ aṭṭhasāliniyanti adhippāyo. Nanu tattha “āruppe
analyzed: āruppe vuttam aṭṭhasāliniyan ti adhippāyaḥ nanu tattha āruppe
translated: The meaning intended is this: “In the immaterial sphere the triad and the tetrad arise, etc., is said in the Aṭṭhasālinī.”

original: tikacatukkajjhānaṃ uppajjatī”ti vuttaṃ, na “catukkapañcakajjhāna”nti? Saccaṃ, yesu🔽pana saṃsayo atthi, tesaṃ uppattidassanena, tenatthato catukkapañcakajjhānaṃ uppajjatīti
analyzed: tika catukka jjhānam uppajjati iti vuttam na catukka pañcaka jjhānan ti saccam yesu  pana saṃsayaḥ atthi tesam uppatti dassanena tenatthato catukka pañcaka jjhānam uppajjati iti
translated: But is it not said there, “In the immaterial sphere the triad and the tetrad arise,” not “The tetrad and the pentad arise”?🔽It is true, but it can be understood that he said it thus in order to show their arising in those about which there is doubt. So it should be understood that he said it in order to show that the tetrad and the pentad arise in meaning too.

original: vuttameva hotīti evamāhāti veditabbaṃ. Samudāyañca apekkhitvā “tañca lokuttaraṃ,
analyzed: vuttam eva hoti iti evam āha ati veditabbam samudāyañ ca apekkhitvā tat ca lokuttaram
translated: And with reference to the collection, it is said:

original: na lokiya”nti āha. Catutthajjhānameva hi lokiyaṃ tattha uppajjati, na catukkaṃ pañcakañcāti.
analyzed: na lokiyam ti āha catuttha jhānam eva hi lokiyam tattha uppajjati na catukkam pañcakam ca ati
translated: For only the fourth jhāna is mundane there, not the fourth or fifth jhāna.

original: Ettha kathanti pādakajjhānassa abhāvā kathaṃ daṭṭhabbanti attho. Taṃjhānikāva tassa
analyzed: ettha katham ti pādaka jjhānassa abhāvā katham daṭṭhabbanti attho taṃjhānikā ava tassa
translated: Herein, how? The meaning is, how should it be regarded, since there is no basic jhāna?

original: tattha tayo maggā uppajjanti tajjhānikaṃ paṭhamaphalādiṃ pādakaṃ katvā uparimaggabhāvanāyāti
analyzed: tattha tayaḥ maggāḥ uppajjanti tajjhānikam paṭhama phala ādim pādakam katvā upari magga bhāvanāya ati
translated: The intention is that the three paths arise there, and also the first fruition, etc., which are of the same jhāna as the basic jhāna, by developing the higher paths.

original: adhippāyo, tikacatukkajjhānikaṃ pana maggaṃ bhāvetvā tatthuppannassa arūpajjhānaṃ
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ tika catukka jhānikam pana maggam bhāvetvā tattha uppannassa arūpa jjhānam
translated: But when the path of the third or fourth jhāna is developed, then the immaterial jhāna that arises there

original: tajjhānikaṃ phalañca pādakaṃ katvā uparimaggabhāvanāya aññajhānikāpi uppajjantīti🔽jhānaṅgādiniyāmikā pubbābhisaṅkhārasamāpatti pādakaṃ, na sammasitabbāti phalassapi pādakatā daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: tad jhānikam phalam ca pādakam katvā upari magga bhāvanāya añña jhānikā api uppajjanti iti  jhāna aṅga ādi niyāmikā pubba abhisaṅkhāra samāpatti pādakam na sammasitabbā ati phalassa api pādaka tā daṭṭhabbā
translated: is of the same jhāna as that path, and the fruition is of the same jhāna as the basic jhāna.🔽So it should be regarded as the basic jhāna for the development of the higher paths.

original: Dukkhañāṇādīnaṃ rūpādichaḷārammaṇattā nekkhammasaṅkappādīnaṃ kasiṇāditaṃtaṃkusalārammaṇārammaṇattā
analyzed: dukkha ñāṇa ādīnam rūpa ādi chaṭṭha ārammaṇa ttā nekkhamma saṅkappa ādīnam kasiṇa ādi taṃ taṃ kusala ārammaṇa ārammaṇa ttā
translated: And since knowledge of painfulness, etc., have as object the six kinds of objects beginning with form, and since the inceptive and sustaining of the renunciation-born, etc., kinds of consciousness have as object the profitable beginning with the kasiṇa, etc.,

original: sammāvācādīnaṃ aṅgānaṃ taṃtaṃviramitabbādiārammaṇattā “yathānurūpa”nti āha. Tadanurūpoti🔽avippaṭisārakarasīlaṃ vāyāmassa visesapaccayoti sīlānurūpatā vāyāmassa vuttā sampayuttassapi,🔽sampayuttasseva ca vacanato “sīlabhūmiyaṃ patiṭṭhitassā”ti avatvā “patiṭṭhamānassā”ti
analyzed: sammā vācā ādīnam aṅgānam taṃ taṃ viramitabba ādi ārammaṇa ttā yathā anurūpanti āha tad anurūpā iti  a vippaṭisāra kara sīlam vāyāmassa visesa paccayaḥ ti sīla anurūpa tā vāyāmassa vuttā sampayuttassa api  sampayuttassa iva ca vacanataḥ sīlabhūmiyam patiṭṭhitassa ati avatvā patiṭṭhamānassa ati
translated: The virtue that causes non-remorse is a special condition for energy, thus it is said that energy is in accordance with virtue.🔽And this is said of the associated energy only,🔽not of the virtue itself, because it is said of the associated only.

original: vuttaṃ. Cetaso asammosoti “ekārakkho”ti ettha vuttena satārakkhena cetaso rakkhitatā.
analyzed: vuttam cetasaḥ asammoso ti eka ārakkho ti ettha vuttena satā ārakkhena cetasaḥ rakkhita tā
translated: “Guarding of the mind” is the guarding of the mind by the guarding of mindfulness mentioned in the passage, “He dwells practising body-contemplation on the body …” .

original: Tenāha “iti…pe… suvihitacittārakkhassā”ti.🔽Āsavakkhayañāṇassa vijjābhāvo vuttoti āsavakkhayasaṅkhāte magge tīhi khandhehi saṅgahite
analyzed: tena āha iti pe su vihita citta ārakkhassa ati  āsava khaya ñāṇassa vijjā bhāvaḥ vuttaḥ ti āsava kkhaya saṅkhāte magge tīhi khandhehi saṅgahite
translated: Hence it is said, “Thus … he is one who has well-guarded mind-door-guarding” .🔽The knowledge of the destruction of the cankers is called “clear vision” .🔽The three aggregates included in the path called “destruction of the cankers” are the aggregate of understanding .

original: paññākkhandho vijjā, sīlassa catunnañca jhānānaṃ caraṇabhāvo vuttoti itare dve khandhā
analyzed: paññā kkhandho vijjā sīlassa catunnam ca jhānānam caraṇa bhāvaḥ vutto ti itare dve khandhā
translated: The other two aggregates are the “way of practice” .

original: caraṇaṃ. Yanti etena nibbānaṃ gacchantīti yānaṃ, vipassanāva yānaṃ vipassanāyānaṃ.
analyzed: caraṇam yanti etena nibbānam gacchanti iti yānam vipassanā ava yānam vipassanāyānam
translated: “Going” is going to Nibbāna. The vehicle is the way. Insight is the vehicle, thus it is the vehicle of insight.

original: Sīlaṃ samādhissa visesapaccayo, samādhi vipassanāyāti samathassa upakārattā sīlakkhandho
analyzed: sīlam samādhissa visesa paccayaḥ samādhi vipassanāya āti samathassa upakāra ttā sīlakkhandho
translated: Virtue is a special condition for concentration, and concentration for insight. So the virtue aggregate is a prerequisite for concentration and insight.

original: ca samathayānena saṅgahito. Vipassanāyānena kāmesu ādīnavaṃ vibhāvento samathayānena
analyzed: ca samatha yānena saṅgahitaḥ vipassanā yānena kāmesu ādīnavam vibhāvento samatha yānena
translated: Virtue is a condition for concentration by way of pre-nascence condition, etc., and concentration is a condition for insight by way of proximity condition, etc., thus the virtue aggregate is included in the vehicle of serenity because it assists serenity.🔽By discerning the danger in sensual desires by means of the vehicle of insight,

original: nirāmisaṃ jhānasukhaṃ apariccajanto antadvayakummaggaṃ vivajjeti. Paññā viya mohassa,🔽sīlasamādhayo ca dosalobhānaṃ ujuvipaccanīkā adosālobhehi sādhetabbattā. Sīlasamādhipaññāyogato
analyzed: nirāmisam jhāna sukham a pariccajantaḥ anta dvaya kummaggam vivajjeti paññā viya mohassa  sīla samādhayaḥ ca dosa lobhānam uju vipaccanīkāḥ a dosa alobhehi sādhetabba ttā sīla samādhi paññā yogato
translated: and by not abandoning the jhāna happiness that is free from sense desires, one avoids the two extremes of indulgence in sensual pleasure and of self-mortification.🔽Just as wisdom is the direct opponent of delusion,🔽so virtue and concentration are the direct opponents of hate and greed respectively, because they are to be accomplished by non-hate and non-greed.

original: ādimajjhapariyosānakalyāṇaṃ. Sīlādīni hi sāsanassa ādimajjhapariyosānanti. Yasmiṃ
analyzed: ādi majjha pariyosāna kalyāṇam sīla ādīni hi sāsanassa ādi majjha pariyosānanti yasmin
translated: The Dispensation is good in the beginning, middle, and end because it is endowed with virtue, concentration, and wisdom.

original: ṭhito maggaṭṭho phalaṭṭho ca ariyo hoti, taṃ maggaphalasaṅkhātaṃ khandhattayasaṅgahitaṃ sāsanaṃ ariyabhūmi.🔽Maggasaccaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: ṭhitaḥ magga aṭṭho phala aṭṭho ca ariyaḥ hoti tam magga phala saṅkhātam khandha ttaya saṅgahitam sāsanam ariya bhūmi  magga sacca niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Dispensation is the Noble One’s Ground because one who abides in it is a noble one, and the Dispensation is included in the three aggregates, namely, the path, the fruit, and Nibbāna.🔽The exposition of the truth of the path is ended.

original: Suttantabhājanīyavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: suttantabhājanīya vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The exposition of the Dispensation as a receptacle of the discourses is ended.

original: 2. Abhidhammabhājanīyavaṇṇanā
translated: Exposition of the Dispensation as a Receptacle of the Abhidhamma

original: 206-214. Ariyasacca-saddo samudaye vattamāno pariññeyyabhāvarahite ekantapahātabbe🔽taṇhāsaṅkhāte samudaye pavattati, na pahātabbapariññeyyesu avasesakilesāvasesākusalesu🔽appahātabbesu ca sāsavakusalamūlāvasesasāsavakusalesūti sappadeso tattha samudayo
analyzed: ariya sacca saddaḥ samudaye vattamāno pariññeyya bhāva rahite ekanta pahātabbe  taṇhā saṅkhāte samudaye pavattati na pahātabba pariññeyyesu avasesa kilesa avasesa akusalesu  appahātabbesu ca sāsava kusala mūla avasesa sāsava kusalesu iti sappadesaḥ tattha samudayo
translated: The word “noble truth” occurring in the case of the origin is used of the origin consisting in craving, which is not devoid of the state of being what should be fully understood and is what should be entirely abandoned,🔽not of the remaining unprofitable states which are what should be abandoned by full understanding,🔽and of the remaining unprofitable roots and the remaining unprofitable states associated with ignorance which are not what should be abandoned. So the origin is the right place for the word “truth.”

original: hoti, kevalaṃ saccasadde nippadesoti āha “nippadesato samudayaṃ dassetu”nti. Dukkhanirodhā🔽pana ariyasaccadesanāyaṃ dhammato nippadesā eva. Na hi tato añño dhammo atthi, yo
analyzed: hoti kevalam sacca sadde nippadeso ti āha nippadesataḥ samudayam dassetun ti dukkha nirodhā  pana ariya sacca desanā ayam dhammataḥ nippadesā eva na hi tatas aññaḥ dhammo atthi yaḥ
translated: The word “noble truth” occurring in the case of the origin is applied to the origin consisting in craving, which is to be abandoned absolutely without remainder, and which is not to be fully understood. It is not applied to the remaining unprofitable things which are to be abandoned and fully understood, and to the remaining unprofitable roots and the remaining unprofitable things associated with the cankers which are not to be abandoned. So the origin is the place here where the word “noble truth” is applied. It is only in the word “truth” that there is no application. That is why he said “to show the origin without application.”

original: saccadesanāyaṃ dukkhaṃ nirodhoti ca vattabbo siyā, maggopi aṭṭhaṅgikapañcaṅgikavāresu🔽apubbo natthi, tasmā samudayameva “nippadesato dassetu”nti vadati tassa sabbattha
analyzed: sacca desanā ayam dukkham nirodhaḥ ti ca vattabbo siyā maggaḥ api aṭṭhaṅgika pañcaṅgika vāresu  apubbaḥ na atthi tasmā samudayam eva nippadesataḥ dassetun ti vadati tassa sabbattha
translated: But in the case of the noble truth of cessation, there is no application even in the word “truth.” For there is no other thing than that which could be called “cessation of suffering” in the teaching of the noble truth of cessation. And in the case of the path, there is no new path in the eightfold and fivefold versions.

original: tīsupi vāresu apubbassa dassitattā. Apubbasamudayadassanatthāyapi hi saccadesanāyaṃ
analyzed: tīsu pi vāresu apubbassa dassita ttā apubba samudaya dassana tthāya api hi sacca desanā ayam
translated: That is why he says “to show the origin without application.” And that is because in all three versions of the path there is nothing new shown. For the teaching of the noble truth is for the purpose of showing the origin not previously shown.

original: “tattha katamo dukkhasamudayo? Taṇhā”ti vacanaṃ kevalāya taṇhāya sacca-saddassa pavattidassanatthanti.
analyzed: tattha katamaḥ dukkha samudayaḥ taṇhā ati vacanam kevalāya taṇhāya sacca saddassa pavatti dassana tthan ti
translated: “Herein, what is the origin of suffering? Craving” .

original: Desanāvasena pana taṃ taṃ samudayaṃ ṭhapetvā dukkhaṃ tassa tassa pahānavasena nirodho
analyzed: desanā vasena pana tam tam samudayam ṭhapetvā dukkham tassa tassa pahāna vasena nirodho
translated: But in the teaching of the truths, suffering is not stated by way of any origin, and cessation is not stated by way of the abandoning of any one thing,

original: aṭṭhaṅgikapañcaṅgikasabbalokuttarakusalavasena maggo ca ariyasaccadesanāyaṃ na vuttoti
analyzed: aṭṭhaṅgika pañcaṅgika sabba lokuttara kusala vasena maggo ca ariya sacca desanā ayam na vutto ti
translated: and the path is not stated by way of the eight factors, the five factors, or any supramundane profitable .

original: dukkhādīni ca tattha sappadesāni dassitāni hontīti tāni ca nippadesāni dassetuṃ saccadesanā
analyzed: dukkha ādīni ca tattha sappadesāni dassitāni honti iti tāni ca nippadesāni dassetum sacca desanā
translated: So the truths are stated in order to show the location of suffering, etc., and to show their non-location.

original: vuttāti vattuṃ vaṭṭati. Paccayasaṅkhātanti kammakilesavasena jātiādidukkhassa mūlabhūtanti attho.
analyzed: vuttā iti vattum vaṭṭati paccaya saṅkhātanti kamma kilesa vasena jāti ādi dukkhassa mūla bhūtanti attho
translated: The cessation truth is shown by the words “with the remainder of condition” , which mean that it is the root of the suffering of birth, etc., by way of the defilements and kamma.

original: Nirodhasaccaṃ…pe… pañcahākārehi niddiṭṭhanti ariyasaccadesanato saccadesanāya visesaṃ
analyzed: nirodha saccaṃpe pañcahā akārehi niddiṭṭhanti ariya sacca desanataḥ sacca desanāya visesam
translated: The cessation truth is shown in five ways, which is how the teaching of the truths is distinguished from the teaching of the truths.

original: dasseti. Tattha “tiṇṇannañca kusalamūlānaṃ avasesānañca sāsavakusalānaṃ pahāna”nti
analyzed: dasseti tattha tiṇṇannam ca kusala mūlānam avasesānam ca sa āsava kusalānam
translated: Herein, “the abandoning of the three profitable roots and of the rest of the profitable with result” .

original: idaṃ tesaṃ paccayānaṃ avijjātaṇhāupādānānaṃ pahānavasena, avijjādīsu vā pahīnesu
analyzed: idam tesam paccayānam avijjā taṇhā upādānānam pahāna vasena avijjā ādīsu vā pahīnesu
translated: This should be understood as said in order to show the abandoning of those conditions, namely, ignorance, craving, and assuming, or else the non- occurrence of those conditions when ignorance, etc., have been abandoned.

original: tesaṃ appavattivasena vuttanti veditabbaṃ. Na hi kusalā pahātabbāti. Pahānanti ca🔽maggakiccavasena tadadhigamanīyaṃ nirodhaṃ dasseti, nirodhasseva vā taṇhādīnaṃ appavattibhāvo
analyzed: tesam appavatti vasena vuttanti veditabbam na hi kusalā pahātabbā ati pahānam ti ca  magga kicca vasena tad adhigamanīyam nirodham dasseti nirodhassa iva vā taṇhā ādīnam appavatti bhāvo
translated: For it is not that profitable states are to be abandoned. And “abandoning” is said

original: pahānanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽Yadipi “pubbeva kho panassa kāyakammaṃ vacīkammaṃ ājīvo suparisuddho hoti, evamassāyaṃ
analyzed: pahānam ti daṭṭhabbam  yadi api pubbā iva kho panassa kāya kammam vacī kammam ājīvaḥ su parisuddhaḥ hoti evam assa ayam
translated: in order to show cessation, which is to be reached by the function of the path, or else the abandoning of craving, etc., should be regarded as the non- occurrence of craving, etc.

original: ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchatī”ti lokuttaramaggakkhaṇe aṭṭhaṅgikamaggapāripūriyā
analyzed: ariyaḥ aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ maggaḥ bhāvanā pāripūrim gacchati iti lokuttara magga kkhaṇe aṭṭhaṅgika magga pāripūriyā
translated: Although this is said in order to show the condition for the fulfilment of the noble eightfold path by the fulfilment of the eight factors of the path at the moment of the supramundane path,

original: upanissayadassanatthaṃ idaṃ vuttaṃ, tathāpi “pubbeva kho panā”ti vacanaṃ kāyakammādisuddhiyā
analyzed: upanissaya dassana attham idam vuttam tathā api pubbā iva kho pana iti vacanam kāya kamma ādi suddhiyā
translated: still the words “but his bodily action, his verbal action, and his livelihood have already been well purified” show that the purification of bodily action, etc.,

original: dūratarupanissayataṃ, cakkhādīsu asārajjantassa asaṃyuttassa asammūḷhassa ādīnavānupassino
analyzed: dūratara upanissaya tam cakkha ādīsu a sārajjantassa a saṃyuttassa a sammūḍhassa ādīnava anupassinaḥ
translated: is a more remote condition. And the words “he is not intent on adornment” show that the purification of bodily action, etc., is a condition for the development of the path by the non-addicted person who is not confused and who sees danger in the least fault.

original: viharato tāyeva vuṭṭhānagāminiyā vipassanāya āyatiṃ pañcupādānakkhandhesu apacayaṃ
analyzed: viharataḥ tāya eva vuṭṭhāna gāminiyā vipassanāya āyatim pañca upādānakkhandhesu apacayam
translated: As he abides thus, the insight leading to emergence reduces the five aggregates that provide fuel for attachment to a mere handful,

original: gacchantesu sabbasaṅkhāresu vivaṭṭanavasena, ponobbhavikataṇhāya pahīyamānāya kilesadūrībhāvena,
analyzed: gacchantesu sabba saṅkhāresu vivaṭṭana vasena ponobbhavika taṇhāya pahīyamānāya kilesa dūrībhāvena
translated: and as the craving for further becoming is abandoned, the defilements are removed,

original: kāyikacetasikadarathasantāpapariḷāhesu pahīyamānesu passaddhakāyacittavasena kāyikacetasikasukhe
analyzed: kāyika cetasika daratha santāpa pariḷāhesu pahīyamānesu passaddha kāya citta vasena kāyika cetasika sukhe
translated: and as the bodily and mental fevers due to the defilements are allayed, the bodily and mental ease that is their opposite is experienced.🔽When the five aggregates are seen in this way, the five factors of right view, etc.,

original: paṭisaṃvediyamāne “yā tathābhūtassa diṭṭhi, sāssa hoti sammādiṭṭhī”tiādinā vuttānaṃ
analyzed: paṭisaṃvediyamāne yā tathābhūtassa diṭṭhi sā assa hoti sammādiṭṭhi iti ādinā vuttānam
translated: which are mentioned in the passage beginning, “The view that is his is the right view” ,

original: vuṭṭhānagāminivipassanākkhaṇe pavattānaṃ pañcannaṃ sammādiṭṭhādīnaṃ aṅgānaṃ āsannatarupanissayatañca
analyzed: vuṭṭhāna gāmini vipassanā khaṇe pavattānam pañcannam sammādiṭṭha ādīnam aṅgānam āsannatara upanissaya tat ca
translated: are proximate conditions for the five aggregates.

original: dassetīti āsannatarupanissayavasena pañcaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ sukhaṃ bujjhantānaṃ puggalānaṃ🔽ajjhāsayavasena pañcaṅgikamaggadesanāya pavattataṃ dīpeti. Tenāha “pubbeva kho…pe…
analyzed: dasseti iti āsannatara upanissaya vasena pañcaṅgikam maggam sukham bujjhantānam puggalānam 🔽ajjhāsaya vasena pañcaṅgika magga desanāya pavatta tam dīpeti tena āha pubbā iva khope
translated: The teaching of the five-factored path is given in accordance with the inclination of those who are easily awakened by the path with five factors.🔽Therefore the Exalted One says, “Even before this, bhikkhus, when I dwelt in the realm of the Tusita gods, I surveyed the world at dawn, out of compassion for beings.”

original: suparisuddho hotīti vacanato”tiādi. Evamidaṃ vacanatoti nissakkavacanaṃ desanupāyassa
analyzed: su parisuddhaḥ hoti iti vacanato tiādi evam idam vacanato ti nissakka vacanam desan upāyassa
translated: Thus this statement is a statement of the way of teaching,

original: ñāpakanidassanaṃ hoti, vacanatoti vā attano vacanānurūpaṃ pañcaṅgikopi maggo paṭipadā
analyzed: ñāpaka nidassanam hoti vacanato ti vā attanaḥ vacana anurūpam pañcaṅgikaḥ api maggo paṭipadā
translated: showing the way of teaching by means of the statement. Or else, the meaning is that the five-factored path is taught by the Blessed One as the way

original: evāti bhagavatā desitoti attho. Katthāti? Devapure, tasmā taṃ desitanayaṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: eva ati bhagavatā desito ti attho kattha ati devapure tasmai tam desi tanayam dassetum
translated: in accordance with his own statement. Where? In the Divine Palace. So in order to show the way of teaching there,

original: pañcaṅgikavāropi niddiṭṭho dhammasaṅgāhakehi. Atha vā “pubbeva kho panassā”ti vacaneneva
analyzed: pañcaṅgika vāraḥ api niddiṭṭhaḥ dhamma saṅgāhakehi atha vā pubbā iva kho panassa ati vacanena iva
translated: the five-factored path is also demonstrated by the compilers of the Dhamma. Or else, by the words “But before that”

original: ajjhāsayavisesakāraṇanidassakena puggalajjhāsayavasena pañcaṅgiko maggopi paṭipadā🔽evāti desito hotīti āha “pubbeva kho pana…pe… vacanato pana…pe… desito”ti, tasmā
analyzed: ajjhāsaya visesa kāraṇa nidassakena puggala jjhāsaya vasena pañcaṅgikaḥ maggaḥ api paṭipadā  eva ati desitaḥ hoti iti āha pubbā iva kho panape vacanato panape desito ti tasmā
translated: the five-factored path is also taught as the way in accordance with the inclination of the person, showing the reason for the special inclination.

original: taṃ suttante desitanayaṃ dassetuṃ pañcaṅgikavāropi niddiṭṭho bhagavatā devapureti attho.
analyzed: tam suttante desi tanayam dassetum pañcaṅgika vāraḥ api niddiṭṭhaḥ bhagavatā deva purā iti attho
translated: Thus it is said: “But before that … in the Divine Palace, the five-factored path is also demonstrated by the Blessed One in order to show the way of teaching there.”

original: Jhānehi desanāpaveso, bhāvanāpaveso vā jhānābhiniveso. Ekekasmiṃ koṭṭhāse catunnaṃ
analyzed: jhānehi desanā apavesaḥ bhāvanā apavesaḥ vā jhāna abhiniveso ekekasmin koṭṭhāse catunnam
translated: The “entry into the teaching by means of the jhānas” is the entry into the development of the jhānas, or the insistence on the jhānas. In each section there are four

original: catunnaṃ nayasahassānaṃ dassanaṃ gaṇanāsukhatthanti veditabbaṃ. Yathā pana pāḷi ṭhitā,
analyzed: catunnam naya sahassānam dassanam gaṇanā sukha atthan ti veditabbam yathā pana ṭhitā
translated: The “seeing” of the four thousand methods should be understood as the “counting” for the purpose of happiness.

original: tathā ekekissā paṭipadāya suññatādīsu ca pañca pañca koṭṭhāse yojetvā pāḷigamanaṃ🔽katanti viññāyati. Tattha aṭṭhaṅgikavāre dutiyajjhānādīsu tasmiṃ samaye sattaṅgiko
analyzed: tathā ekekissā paṭipadāya suññatā ādīsu ca pañca pañca koṭṭhāse yojetvā pāḷigamanam  katam ti viññāyati tattha aṭṭhaṅgika vāre dutiya jhāna ādīsu tasmin samaye sattaṅgikaḥ
translated: But it can be discerned that the text is recited by combining five sections under each of the four paths, beginning with the void, and so on.

original: maggo hotīti yojanā kātabbā, sabbasaṅgāhikavāre ca yathā vijjamānadhammavasenāti.
analyzed: maggaḥ hoti iti yojanā kātabbā sabba saṅgāhika vāre ca yathā vijjamāna dhamma vasena ati
translated: Herein, in the case of the section on the eight factors, the construction should be made in this way: “At that time the path is the seven factors” in the second jhāna, and so on. And in the case of the section on all together, “according to the way the states actually occur.”

original: Abhidhammabhājanīyavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: abhidhammabhājanīya vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Abhidhamma section is ended.

original: 3. Pañhapucchakavaṇṇanā🔽215. Evaṃ purimesupi dvīsūti kasmā vuttaṃ, nanu suttantabhājanīye dukkhanirodhagāminipaṭipadāniddese🔽lokiyalokuttaramissako maggo vutto. Tassa hi aṭṭhakathāyaṃ “catūsu saccesu uggahādivasena
analyzed: evam purimesu pi dvīsu iti kasmā vuttam nanu suttanta bhājanīye  lokiya lokuttara missakaḥ maggaḥ vuttaḥ tassa hi aṭṭhakathā ayam catūsu saccesu uggaha ādi vasena
translated: The commentary on the question🔽Why is it said, “So too in the first two”? Has not a mundane and supramundane mixed path been stated in the “Description of the Way Leading to the Cessation of Suffering” in the Suttanta section?

analyzed: vuttam tena suttanta bhājanīye pi dvinnam lokiya tā dvinnam lokuttara tā vuttā evam
translated: That is said. And in the Sutta-bhāṇavāra too the two kinds of mundane and two kinds of supramundane are stated.

original: 5. Indriyavibhaṅgo
analyzed: indriya vibhaṅgaḥ
translated: The analysis of faculties

original: 1. Abhidhammabhājanīyavaṇṇanā🔽219. Cakkhudvāre indaṭṭhaṃ kāretīti cakkhudvārabhāve taṃdvārikehi attano indabhāvaṃ
analyzed: cakkhu dvāre indaṭṭham kāreti iti cakkhu dvāra bhāve taṃdvārikehi attanaḥ inda bhāvam
translated: The commentary on the Abhidhamma-bhāṇavāra

original: paramissarabhāvaṃ kārayatīti attho. Tañhi te rūpaggahaṇe attānaṃ anuvatteti, te ca
analyzed: para missara bhāvam kārayati iti tat hi te rūpa ggahaṇe attānam anuvatteti te ca

analyzed: tam anuvattanti iti esa nayaḥ itaresu pi yena tad samaṅgī puggalo tad sampayutta dhammā
translated: follow it. The same method applies in the case of the other doors.

original: vā aññātāvino honti, so aññātāvibhāvo pariniṭṭhitakiccajānanaṃ.
analyzed: vā aññātāvino honti saḥ aññātāvi bhāvaḥ pariniṭṭhita kicca jānanaṃ
translated: The state of knowing is the state of knowing that is produced in one who has the requisite associated states or in one who has the requisite knowledge.

original: Katthaci dveti “dvinnaṃ kho, bhikkhave, indriyānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā khīṇāsavo

original: ariyā paññā, tadassa paññindriyaṃ. Yā hissa ariyā vimutti, tadassa samādhindriya”ntiādīsu🔽dve, “tiṇṇaṃ kho, bhikkhave, indriyānaṃ bhāvitattā bahulīkatattā piṇḍolabhāradvājena
analyzed: ariyā paññā tat assa paññindriyam yā hissa ariyā vimutti tat assa samādhindriya nti ādīsu  dve tiṇṇam kho bhikkhave indriyānam bhāvita ttā bahulīkata ttā piṇḍolabhāradvājena
translated: a monk makes a declaration of final knowledge, … with noble wisdom and noble liberation. For his noble wisdom is his wisdom faculty, and his noble liberation is his concentration faculty.”🔽In the first two passages the faculties are two,

original: bhikkhunā aññā byākatā…pe… satindriyassa samādhindriyassa paññindriyassā”ti, “tīṇimāni,
analyzed: bhikkhunā aññā byākatāpe sati indriyassa samādhi indriyassa paññā indriyassa ati tīṇimāni
translated: In the third passage they are three: “It is because of the development and the much practice of three faculties that the bhikkhu Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja has declared his final knowledge in such a way. … The faculty of mindfulness, the faculty of concentration, and the faculty of wisdom.”

original: bhikkhave, indriyāni. Katamāni tīṇi? Anaññātaññassāmītindriyaṃ aññindriyaṃ aññātāvindriya”nti,
analyzed: bhikkhave indriyāni katamāni tīṇi anaññātaññassāmi itindriyam aññindriyam aññātāvindriyanti
translated: In the fourth passage they are three: “Bhikkhus, there are these three faculties. What three? The faculty of final knowledge, the faculty of final knowing, and the faculty of one who has final knowledge.”

original: “tīṇimāni…pe… itthindriyaṃ purisindriyaṃ jīvitindriya”nti ca evamādīsu tīṇi, “pañcimāni,
analyzed: itthi indriyam purisa indriyam jīvitindriyanti ca evamādīsu tīṇi pañcimāni
translated: In the fifth passage they are three: “Bhikkhus, there are these three faculties. What three? The femininity faculty, the masculinity faculty, and the life faculty.”

original: brāhmaṇa, indriyāni nānāvisayāni…pe… cakkhundriyaṃ…pe… kāyindriya”nti, “pañci…pe…
analyzed: indriyāni cakkhu indriyaṃpe kāyindriya nti
translated: In the sixth passage they are five: “Brahmin, there are these five faculties … The eye faculty … the body faculty.”

original: sukhindriyaṃ…pe… upekkhindriya”nti, “pañci…pe… saddhindriyaṃ…pe… paññindriya”nti
analyzed: upekkhindriyanti saddhindriyaṃpe paññindriyanti
translated: In the seventh passage they are five: “There are, brahmin, these five faculties … The pleasure faculty … the equanimity faculty.”🔽In the eighth passage they are five: “There are, brahmin, these five faculties … The faith faculty … the wisdom faculty.”

original: ca evamādīsu pañca. Tattha suttante dukādivacanaṃ nissaraṇupāyādibhāvato dukādīnaṃ.
analyzed: ca evamādīsu pañca tattha suttante duka ādi vacanam nissaraṇa upāya ādi bhāvataḥ duka ādīnam
translated: and so on. Herein, the words “duka” and so on in the Suttas are so called because they are a means of escape from suffering, and so on.

original: Sabbāni pana indriyāni abhiññeyyāni, abhiññeyyadhammadesanā ca abhidhammoti idha
analyzed: sabbāni pana indriyāni abhiññeyyāni abhiññeyya dhamma desanā ca abhidhammaḥ ti idha
translated: But all the faculties are to be directly known, and the teaching of the states that are to be directly known is the “Dhamma in brief” . So all are mentioned here

original: sabbāni ekato vuttāni.
analyzed: sabbāni ekatas vuttāni
translated: as one.

original: Khīṇāsavassa bhāvabhūto hutvā uppattito “khīṇāsavasseva uppajjanato”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: khīṇāsavassa bhāva bhūtaḥ hutvā uppattitaḥ khīṇāsavassa iva uppajjanato ti vuttam
translated: Because they arise only in one whose cankers are destroyed, it is said: “because they arise only in one whose cankers are destroyed” .

original: Liṅgeti gameti ñāpetīti liṅgaṃ, liṅgīyati vā etenāti liṅgaṃ, kiṃ liṅgeti, kiñca vā🔽liṅgīyatīti? Indaṃ indo vā, indassa liṅgaṃ indaliṅgaṃ, indaliṅgassa attho taṃsabhāvo
analyzed: liṅga iti gama iti ñāpa iti iti liṅgam liṅgīyati vā etena ati liṅgam kim liṅga iti kiñca vā  liṅgīyati iti indam indaḥ vai indassa liṅgam inda liṅgam inda liṅgassa atthaḥ taṃsa bhāvaḥ
translated: It makes known the sex , thus it is a sex ; or it is a sex because it is what is signified by the word “sex” . What is the sex? Or what is signified by the sex?

original: indaliṅgaṭṭho, indaliṅgameva vā indriya-saddassa attho indaliṅgaṭṭho. Sajjitaṃ uppāditanti
analyzed: inda liṅga ṭṭhaḥ inda liṅgam eva vā indriya saddassa attho inda liṅga ṭṭhaḥ sajjitam uppāditanti
translated: The sex of Indra is indriya; the meaning of the sex of Indra is indriyaṭṭha ; or the meaning of the word indriya is indriyaṭṭha .

original: siṭṭhaṃ, indena siṭṭhaṃ indasiṭṭhaṃ. Juṭṭhaṃ sevitaṃ. Kammasaṅkhātassa indassa liṅgāni,
analyzed: siṭṭham indena siṭṭham inda siṭṭham juṭṭham sevitam kamma saṅkhātassa indassa liṅgāni
translated: What is prepared , produced, is siṭṭha ; what is prepared by Indra is indasiṭṭha . What is used , resorted to, is juṭṭha . The sex of Indra, which is called action,

original: tena ca siṭṭhānīti kammajāneva yojetabbāni, na aññāni. Te ca dve atthā kamme eva
analyzed: tena ca siṭṭhāni iti kamma jānā iva yojetabbāni na aññāni te ca dve atthā kamme eva
translated: is to be construed as “the sex of Indra, which is prepared by Indra, which is prepared by Indra, which is used by Indra, which is resorted to by Indra, which is action, which is action as sex” . But the two meanings are only in action.

original: yojetabbā, itare ca bhagavati evāti “yathāyoga”nti āha. Tenāti bhagavato kammassa🔽ca indattā. Etthāti etesu indriyesu. Ulliṅgenti pakāsenti phalasampattivipattīhi🔽kāraṇasampattivipattiavabodhato. “So taṃ nimittaṃ āsevatī”tiādīsu gocarakaraṇampi🔽āsevanāti vuttāti āha “kānici gocarāsevanāyā”ti. Tattha sabbesaṃ gocarīkātabbattepi
analyzed: yojetabbāḥ itare ca bhagavati eva ati yathāyogam ti āha tena ati bhagavato kammassa  ca indattā etthā ati etesu indriyesu ulliṅgenti pakāsenti phala sampatti vipattīhi  kāraṇa sampatti vipatti avabodhataḥ saḥ tam nimittam āsevati iti ādīsu gocara karaṇam pi  āsevanā ati vuttā ati āha kānici gocara āsevanāya ti tattha sabbesam gocarīkātabba tte pi
translated: “To be yoked” means to be yoked to the path. “To be brought about” means to be brought about as the path’s fruit. “To be understood” means to be understood as the path’s cause. “To be cultivated” means to be cultivated as the path’s object. “To be developed” means to be developed as the path’s condition. “To be comprehended” means to be comprehended as the path’s fruit. “To be realized” means to be realized as the path’s cause. “To be directly known” means to be directly known as the path’s object. “To be fully understood” means to be fully understood as the path’s condition. “To be abandoned” means to be abandoned as the path’s fruit. “To be destroyed” means to be destroyed as the path’s cause. “To be vanished” means to be vanished as the path’s object. “To be removed” means to be removed as the path’s condition. “To be realized” means to be realized as the path’s fruit. “To be directly known” means to be directly known as the path’s cause. “To be fully understood” means to be fully understood as the path’s object. “To be abandoned” means to be abandoned as the path’s condition.

original: “kānicī”ti vacanaṃ avipassitabbānaṃ bahulīmanasikaraṇena anāsevanīyattā. Paccavekkhaṇāmattameva🔽hi tesu hotīti. “Tassa taṃ maggaṃ āsevato”tiādīsu bhāvanā “āsevanā”ti vuttāti bhāvetabbāni🔽saddhādīni sandhāyāha “kānici bhāvanāsevanāyā”ti. Ādhipaccaṃ indriyapaccayabhāvo,🔽asati ca indriyapaccayabhāve itthipurisindriyānaṃ attano paccayavasena pavattamānehi
analyzed: kānici iti vacanam a vipassitabbānam bahulīmanasikaraṇena an āsevanīya ttā paccavekkhaṇā mattam eva 🔽hi tesu hoti iti tassa tam maggam āsevato tiādīsu bhāvanā āsevanā iti vuttā ati bhāvetabbāni 🔽saddhā ādīni sandhāya āha kānici bhāvanā sevanāya ati ādhipaccam indriya paccaya bhāvaḥ 🔽asati ca indriya paccaya bhāve itthi purisa indriyānam attano paccaya vasena pavattamānehi
translated: and the other faculties are to be developed in the Blessed One. So he said “as appropriate.” “Ten” : the Blessed One’s ten faculties of action and the faculty of femininity. “Here” : among these faculties. “They indicate” : they make known the success and failure of the fruit by the understanding of the success and failure of the cause. “He cultivates that sign” : the making of the object is called “cultivation” in such passages as this. So he said “some by the cultivation of the object.” Herein, although all are to be made objects, still the word “some” is used because those not to be contemplated are not to be cultivated by frequent attention. For there is only the mere reviewing of them. “He cultivates that path” : the development is called “cultivation” in such passages as this. So he said “some by the cultivation of development,” referring to faith, etc., which are to be developed. The state of being a condition by way of predominance is the state of being a faculty condition. And in the absence of the state of being a faculty condition, the femininity and masculinity faculties are not conditions by way of their own state of being a condition.

original: taṃsahitasantāne aññākārena anuppajjamānehi liṅgādīhi anuvattanīyabhāvo, imasmiñcatthe🔽indanti paramissariyaṃ karonticceva indriyāni. Cakkhādīsu dassitena nayena aññesañca
analyzed: tad sahita santāne añña ākārena anuppajjamānehi liṅga ādīhi anuvattanīya bhāvaḥ imasmin ca atthe  indanti para missariyam karonti cca iva indriyāni cakkha ādīsu dassitena nayena aññesañca
translated: and the state of being the object of the function of the faculties such as sex, etc., which occur in a different way in the continuity associated with that.🔽The meaning is this: they rule by making the supreme sovereignty their own, thus they are faculties.

original: tadanuvattīsu ādhipaccaṃ yathārahaṃ yojetabbaṃ.🔽Heṭṭhāti aṭṭhasāliniyaṃ. Amoho eva, na visuṃ cattāro dhammā, tasmā amohassa paññindriyapade
analyzed: tad anuvattīsu ādhipaccam yathāraham yojetabbam  heṭṭhā ti aṭṭhasāliniyam amoho eva na visum cattāro dhammā tasmai amohassa paññindriya pade
translated: In the case of the others, which are included among the faculties and are the domi-nant conditions in the way already stated in the case of the eye, etc., their domi-nant influence should be construed in the appropriate way.🔽“Below” in the “Eight-factored Root-cause Thread” .🔽There are not four things separately from non-delusion, so the definition, etc., of non-delusion should be understood as given under the “understanding faculty” in the “Eight-factored Root-cause Thread” .

original: vibhāvitāni lakkhaṇādīni tesañca veditabbānīti adhippāyo. Sesāni aṭṭhasāliniyaṃ lakkhaṇādīhi
analyzed: vibhāvitāni lakkhaṇa ādīni tesam ca veditabbāni iti adhippāyaḥ sesāni aṭṭhasāliniyam lakkhaṇa ādīhi
translated: This is the intention. The rest are given in the “Eight-factored Root-cause Thread” with their characteristics, etc., in their own terms.

original: sarūpeneva āgatāni. Nanu ca sukhindriyadukkhindriyānaṃ tattha lakkhaṇādīni na vuttānīti?
analyzed: sarūpena iva āgatāni nanu ca sukha indriya dukkha indriyānam tattha lakkhaṇa ādīni na vuttāni iti
translated: But have not the characteristics, etc., of the pleasure faculty and the pain faculty been omitted there?

original: Kiñcāpi na vuttāni, somanassadomanassindriyānaṃ pana vuttalakkhaṇādivasena viññeyyato
analyzed: kiñcā api na vuttāni somanassa domanassindriyānam pana vutta lakkhaṇa ādi vasena viññeyyato
translated: Though they are not stated there, still they can be known by the method stated in the case of the joy faculty and the grief faculty.

original: etesampi vuttāneva honti. Kathaṃ? Iṭṭhaphoṭṭhabbānubhavanalakkhaṇaṃ sukhindriyaṃ,
analyzed: etesam pi vuttāni eva honti katham iṭṭha phoṭṭhabba anubhavana lakkhaṇam sukha indriyam
translated: So they are stated too. How? The pleasure faculty has the characteristic of experiencing a desirable tangible datum.

original: iṭṭhākārasambhogarasaṃ, kāyikassādapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ, kāyindriyapadaṭṭhānaṃ. Aniṭṭhaphoṭṭhabbānubhavanalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: iṭṭha ākāra sambhoga rasam kāyika ssāda paccupaṭṭhānam kāyindriya padaṭṭhānam aniṭṭha phoṭṭhabba anubhavana lakkhaṇam
translated: The pleasure faculty has the characteristic of experiencing the aspect of pleasure. Its function is to manifest bodily satisfaction. It is manifested as the basis of the body faculty.

original: dukkhindriyaṃ, aniṭṭhākārasambhogarasaṃ, kāyikābādhapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ, kāyindriyapadaṭṭhānanti.🔽Ettha ca iṭṭhāniṭṭhākārānameva ārammaṇānaṃ sambhogarasatā veditabbā, na viparītepi
analyzed: dukkha indriyam aniṭṭha ākāra sambhoga rasam kāyika ābādha paccupaṭṭhānam kāyindriya padaṭṭhānam ti  ettha ca iṭṭha aniṭṭhākārānam eva ārammaṇānam sambhoga rasa tā veditabbā na viparīte api
translated: The pain faculty has the characteristic of experiencing the aspect of pain. Its function is to manifest bodily dissatisfaction. It is manifested as the basis of the body faculty.

original: iṭṭhākārena aniṭṭhākārena ca sambhogarasatāti.
analyzed: iṭṭhākārena an iṭṭhākārena ca sambhoga rasa tā ati
translated: And here the aspect of pleasure and the aspect of pain should be understood as the experience of the aspect of pleasure and the aspect of pain respectively, not as the experience of the opposite of pleasure and the opposite of pain.🔽For the aspect of pleasure is the experience of the aspect of pleasure, and the aspect of pain is the experience of the aspect of pain.

original: Sattānaṃ ariyabhūmipaṭilābho bhagavato desanāya sādhāraṇaṃ padhānañca payojananti🔽āha “ajjhattadhammaṃ pariññāyā”tiādi. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ itthipurisindriyānantaraṃ jīvitindriyadesanakkamo🔽vutto, so indriyayamakadesanāya sameti. Idha pana indriyavibhaṅge manindriyānantaraṃ
analyzed: ariya bhūmi paṭilābhaḥ bhagavataḥ desanāya sādhāraṇam padhānam ca  āha ajjhatta dhammam pariññāya atiādi aṭṭhakathā ayam itthi purisa indriya anantaram jīvitindriya desanā kkamaḥ  vuttaḥ saḥ indriya yamaka desanāya sameti idha pana indriya vibhaṅge man indriya anantaram
translated: The attainment of the noble plane by beings is the common fruit of the Blessed One’s teaching. The supreme effort is the purpose.🔽Therefore it is said: “Having fully understood the internal dhamma” , etc. In the commentary the life faculty is taught immediately after the femininity and masculinity faculties.🔽This order agrees with the teaching of the faculties. But in the exposition of the faculties in the Vibhaṅga the life faculty is taught immediately after the mind faculty.

original: jīvitindriyaṃ vuttaṃ, taṃ purimapacchimānaṃ ajjhattikabāhirānaṃ anupālakattena tesaṃ
analyzed: jīvita indriyam vuttam tam purima pacchimānam ajjhattika bāhirānam anupālaka ttena tesam
translated: That is in accordance with the order of the internal and external faculties.

original: majjhe vuttanti veditabbaṃ. Yañca kiñci vedayitaṃ, sabbaṃ taṃ dukkhaṃ. Yāva ca duvidhattabhāvānupālakassa
analyzed: majjhe vuttanti veditabbam yat ca kiñci vedayitam sabbam tam dukkham yāva ca
translated: and what is said in the middle should be understood as said of the rest.

original: jīvitindriyassa pavatti, tāva dukkhabhūtānaṃ etesaṃ vedayitānaṃ anivattīti ñāpanatthaṃ.
analyzed: jīvita indriyassa pavatti tāva dukkha bhūtānam etesam vedayitānam anivatti iti ñāpana attham
translated: And all that is felt is suffering: this is said in order to show that as long as the life faculty, which is the guardian of the state of being of the twofold feeling, continues, so long there is no turning away from these feelings, which are suffering.

original: Tena ca cakkhādīnaṃ dukkhānubandhatāya pariññeyyataṃ ñāpeti. Tato anantaraṃ bhāvetabbattāti
analyzed: tena ca cakkha ādīnam dukkha anubandha tāya pariññeyya tam ñāpeti tatas anantaram bhāvetabba ttā ti
translated: And by this he shows that the eye, etc., are to be fully understood because they are followed by suffering.

original: bhāvanāmaggasampayuttaṃ aññindriyaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Dassanānantarā hi bhāvanāti.
analyzed: bhāvanā magga sampayuttam aññindriyam sandhāya vuttam dassana anantarā hi bhāvanā ti
translated: Next to that, the faculty to be developed: this is said with reference to the other faculty associated with the path of development.🔽For development is next to seeing.

original: Satipi purejātādipaccayabhāve indriyapaccayabhāvena sādhetabbameva kiccaṃ “kicca”nti
analyzed: sati pi purejāta ādi paccaya bhāve indriya paccaya bhāvena sādhetabbam eva kiccam kiccanti
translated: Although the eye, etc., are a condition by way of prenascence condition, etc., still their function is to be accomplished by way of faculty condition.🔽This is why he said “function” .🔽And because it is not shared by others, and because the exposition of faculties is in progress,

original: āha tassa anaññasādhāraṇattā indriyakathāya ca pavattattā. Pubbaṅgamabhāvena manindriyassa
analyzed: āha tassa anañña sādhāraṇa ttā indriya kathāya ca pavatta ttā pubbaṅgama bhāvena manindriyassa
translated: the mind faculty is the forerunner in the sense of being the master.

original: vasavattāpanaṃ hoti, nāññesaṃ. Taṃsampayuttānipi hi indriyāni sādhetabbabhūtāneva
analyzed: vasavat tāpanam hoti na aññesam tad sampayuttāni pi hi indriyāni sādhetabba bhūtāni eva
translated: For the faculties associated with it are only what is to be accomplished.

original: attano attano indriyakiccaṃ sādhenti cetasikattāti. “Sabbattha ca indriyapaccayabhāvena🔽sādhetabba”nti ayaṃ adhikāro anuvattatīti daṭṭhabbo. Anuppādane anupatthambhe ca🔽tappaccayānaṃ tappavattane nimittabhāvo anuvidhānaṃ. Chādetvā pharitvā uppajjamānā🔽sukhadukkhavedanā sahajāte abhibhavitvā sayameva pākaṭā hoti, sahajātā ca tabbasena🔽sukhadukkhabhāvappattā viyāti āha “yathāsakaṃ oḷārikākārānupāpana”nti. Asantassa
analyzed: attanaḥ attanaḥ indriya kiccam sādhenti cetasika ttā ati sabbattha ca indriya paccaya bhāvena  sādhetabbanti ayam adhikāraḥ anuvattati iti daṭṭhabbaḥ an uppādane an upatthambhe ca  tad paccayānam tad pavattane nimitta bhāvaḥ anuvidhānam chādetvā pharitvā uppajjamānā  sukha dukkha vedanā sahajāte abhibhavitvā sayam eva pākaṭā hoti sahajātā ca tad basena  sukha dukkha bhāva pattāḥ viya iti āha yathāsakam oḷārika ākāra anupāpanam ti asantassa
translated: and they fulfil their respective functions as faculties by being mental states. “And in all cases it is to be fulfilled by being a condition for the faculties” — this is the extension of the application to be understood.

original: apaṇītassapi akusalatabbipākādisampayuttassa majjhattākārānupāpanaṃ yojetabbaṃ, samānajātiyaṃ🔽vā sukhadukkhehi santapaṇītākārānupāpanañca. Pasannapaggahitaupaṭṭhitasamāhitadassanākārānupāpanaṃ
analyzed: apaṇītassa api akusala tad vipāka ādi sampayuttassa majjhatta ākāra anupāpanam yojetabbam samāna jātiyam 🔽vā sukha dukkhehi santa paṇīta ākāra anupāpanam ca pasanna paggahita upaṭṭhita samāhita dassana ākāra anupāpanam
translated: The state of being a cause for the non-arising and the non-suppression of the faculties is the condition by prenascence. The state of being a cause for the occurrence of the faculties is the condition by kamma-result. The state of being a cause for the manifestation of the faculties is the condition by decisive support. The state of being a cause for the non-disappearance of the faculties is the condition by non-disappearance. The state of being a cause for the non-obstruction of the faculties is the condition by absence of obstruction. The state of being a cause for the non-suppression of the faculties is the condition by dissociation. The state of being a cause for the non-disappearance of the faculties is the condition by disappearance. The state of being a cause for the non-obstruction of the faculties is the condition by obstruction. The state of being a cause for the non-suppression of the faculties is the condition by suppression. The state of being a cause for the non-disappearance of the faculties is the condition by disappearance. The state of being a cause for the non-obstruction of the faculties is the condition by obstruction. The state of being a cause for the non-suppression of the faculties is the condition by suppression. The state of being a cause for the non-disappearance of the faculties is the condition by disappearance. The state of being a cause for the non-obstruction of the faculties is the condition by obstruction. The state of being a cause for the non-suppression of the faculties is the condition by suppression. The state of being a cause for the non-disappearance of the faculties is the condition by disappearance. The state of being a cause for the non-obstruction of the faculties is the condition by obstruction. The state of being a cause for the non-suppression of the faculties is the condition by suppression. The state of being a cause for the non-disappearance of the faculties is the condition by disappearance. The state of being a cause for the non-obstruction of the faculties is the condition by obstruction. The state of being a cause for the non-suppression of the faculties is the condition by suppression. The state of being a cause for the non-disappearance of the faculties is

original: yathākkamaṃ saddhādīnaṃ. Ādi-saddena uddhambhāgiyasaṃyojanāni gahitāni, maggasampayuttasseva
analyzed: yathākkamam saddhā ādīnam ādi saddena uddhambhāgiya saṃyojanāni gahitāni magga sampayuttassa iva
translated: and faith, etc., respectively. The word “etc.” includes the higher fetters.

original: ca indriyassa kiccaṃ dassitaṃ, teneva phalasampayuttassa taṃtaṃsaṃyojanānaṃyeva paṭippassaddhipahānakiccatā
analyzed: ca indriyassa kiccam dassitam tena iva phala sampayuttassa tad tad saṃyojanānaṃ yeva paṭippassaddhi pahāna kicca tā
translated: The function of the faculty associated with the path is shown. Thus the function of the faculties associated with the fruits is shown to be the abandoning of the respective fetters.

original: dassitā hotīti. Sabbakatakiccaṃ aññātāvindriyaṃ aññassa kātabbassa abhāvā amatābhimukhameva
analyzed: dassitā hoti iti sabba kata kiccam aññātau indriyam aññassa kātabbassa abhāvā amata abhimukham eva
translated: The faculty of final knowledge has the function of all the others, because there is nothing else for it to do. It is directed to the deathless element,

original: tabbhāvapaccayo ca hoti, na itarāni viya kiccantarapasutañca. Tenāha “amatābhimukhabhāvapaccayatā cā”ti.
analyzed: tad bhāva paccayo ca hoti na itarāni tena āha amata abhimukha bhāva paccaya tā ca ati
translated: and it is a condition by way of being the essence, not by way of the other conditions, and it is not interrupted by other functions, as are the others. Thus it is said, “It is directed to the deathless element and is a condition by way of being the essence.”

original: 220. Evaṃ santepīti satipi sabbasaṅgāhakatte vīriyindriyapadādīhi saṅgahetabbāni
analyzed: evam sante api iti sati pi sabba saṅgāhaka tte vīriya indriya pada ādīhi saṅgahetabbāni
translated: Even though this is so, the faculties of energy, etc., which are included by the words “energy faculty,” etc., are included by the words “eye faculty,” etc.,

original: kusalākusalavīriyādīni, cakkhundriyapadādīhi saṅgahetabbāni kālapuggalapaccayādibhedena
analyzed: kusala akusala vīriya ādīni cakkhu indriya pada ādīhi saṅgahetabbāni kāla puggala paccaya ādi bhedena
translated: because the eye, etc., are included by the words “eye faculty,” etc., which are distinguished by time, person, condition, etc., and because the wholesome, unwholesome, and functional energies, etc., are included by the words “energy faculty,” etc.

original: bhinnāni cakkhādīni saṅgaṇhanticceva sabbasaṅgāhakāni, na yassā bhūmiyā yāni na vijjanti,
analyzed: bhinnāni cakkha ādīni saṅgaṇhanti icca iva sabba saṅgāhakāni na yassā bhūmiyā yāni na vijjanti
translated: The words “eye faculty,” etc., are called “all-inclusive” because they include the eye, etc., which are distinguished by time, person, condition, etc.,

original: tesaṃ saṅgāhakattāti attho. Tena ca avisesitattā sabbesaṃ sabbabhūmikattagahaṇappasaṅge
analyzed: tesam saṅgāhaka ttā ati atthaḥ tena ca avisesita ttā sabbesam sabba bhūmika tta gahaṇa ppasaṅge
translated: the meaning is that they include them. And by that he shows that since they are not specified, the inclusion of all in all planes is implied.

original: taṃnivattanena sabbasaṅgāhakavacanaṃ avijjamānassa saṅgāhakattadīpakaṃ na hotīti dasseti.
analyzed: tad nivattanena sabba saṅgāhaka vacanam a vijjamānassa saṅgāhaka tta dīpakam na hoti iti dasseti
translated: By the refutation of that, he shows that the words “include all” do not indicate the inclusion of what is not included.

original: Abhidhammabhājanīyavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: abhidhammabhājanīya vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the section of the Abhidhamma is ended.

original: 2. Pañhapucchakavaṇṇanā🔽223. Idha anābhaṭṭhanti ekantānārammaṇattena bhāsitaṃ. “Rūpamissakattā anārammaṇesu🔽rūpadhammesu saṅgahita”nti kasmā vuttaṃ, nanu missakattā eva jīvitindriyaṃ anārammaṇesu🔽asaṅgahitaṃ. Na hi aṭṭhindriyā anārammaṇāti vuttāti? Saccametaṃ, jīvitindriyaekadesassa
analyzed: idha ekanta anārammaṇa ttena bhāsitam rūpa missaka ttā anārammaṇesu  rūpa dhammesu saṅgahitan ti kasmā vuttam nanu missaka ttā eva jīvitindriyam anārammaṇesu  asaṅgahitam na hi aṭṭh indriyā anārammaṇā ati vuttā ati saccam etam jīvitindriya eka desassa
translated: The commentary on the question🔽Herein, “not included” is said because of being a single, non-shared object. Why is it said, “Because of being included among the material dhammas that are not objects”? Is not the life faculty included among the not-objects because of being shared? For the eight faculties are not called “not-objects.”

original: pana anārammaṇesu rūpadhammesu saṅgahitataṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ, arūpakoṭṭhāsena parittārammaṇāditā🔽atthīti siyāpakkhe saṅgahitanti adhippāyo. Arūpakoṭṭhāsena pana parittārammaṇāditā,
analyzed: pana anārammaṇesu rūpa dhammesu saṅgahita tam sandhāya itam vuttam arūpa koṭṭhāsena paritta ārammaṇa ādi tā 🔽atthi iti siyā pakkhe saṅgahitanti adhippāyaḥ arūpa koṭṭhāsena pana paritta ārammaṇa ādi tā
translated: This is true, but it is said with reference to the fact that one part of the life faculty is included among the material dhammas that are not objects. The intention is this: “It may be that it has limited objects, etc., because of the part that is immaterial.” But it is included because of the part that is material.

original: rūpakoṭṭhāsena ca navattabbatā atthīti missakassa samudāyasseva vasena siyāpakkhe
analyzed: rūpa koṭṭhāsena ca navattabba tā atthi iti missakassa samudāyassa iva vasena siyā pakkhe
translated: and there is the state of not being classifiable as a form-group. So it should be regarded as included in the category of the mixed aggregate only, not in the category of the individual part.

original: saṅgahitaṃ, na ekadesavasenāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Na hi anārammaṇaṃ parittārammaṇādibhāvena
analyzed: saṅgahitam na eka desa vasena ati daṭṭhabbam na hi anārammaṇam paritta ārammaṇa ādi bhāvena
translated: For what is not a mental object is not unclassifiable as limited, exalted, etc.,

original: navattabbaṃ na hotīti. “Rūpañca nibbānañca anārammaṇā, sattindriyā anārammaṇā”tiādivacanañca
analyzed: na vattabbam na hoti iti rūpañca nibbānañca anārammaṇā satti indriyāḥ anārammaṇā ati ādi vacanañca
translated: “The immaterial states and Nibbāna are not mental objects. The seven faculties are not mental objects” .

original: avijjamānārammaṇānārammaṇesu navattabbesu anārammaṇattā navattabbataṃ dasseti, na
analyzed: avijjamāna ārammaṇa anārammaṇesu navattabbesu anārammaṇa ttā navattabba tam dasseti na
translated: This shows that the immaterial states and Nibbāna are unclassifiable because they are not mental objects,

original: sārammaṇasseva navattabbataṃ, navattabbassa vā sārammaṇataṃ. Na hi navattabba-saddo🔽sārammaṇe niruḷho. Yadipi siyā, “tisso ca vedanā rūpañca nibbānañca ime dhammā navattabbā
analyzed: sa ārammaṇassa iva navattabba tam navattabbassa vā sārammaṇa tam na hi navattabba saddaḥ  sa ārammaṇe niruḷhaḥ yadi api siyā tisso ca vedanā rūpam ca nibbānam ca ime dhammā
translated: not that they are unclassifiable because they are mental objects, or that they are mental objects and unclassifiable.🔽For the word “unclassifiable” is not used of a mental object.

original: sukhāya vedanāya sampayuttā”tiādi na vucceyya, athāpi parittārammaṇādisambandho navattabba-saddo
analyzed: sukhāya vedanāya sampayuttā atiādi na vucceyya atha api paritta ārammaṇa ādi sambandhaḥ
translated: If it were, then it would not be said that “three kinds of feeling and materiality and Nibbāna are unclassifiable states associated with pleasant feeling” , etc.

original: sārammaṇesveva vattati, “dvāyatanā siyā parittārammaṇā”tiādiṃ avatvā “manāyatanaṃ
analyzed: sa ārammaṇesu eva vattati dvi āyatanā siyā paritta ārammaṇā ati ādim avatvā mana āyatanam
translated: But even if the word “unclassifiable” is used only of mental objects, it does not follow that “the two bases are limited” should be stated as “the mind base and the mental-data base are limited” instead of as “the two bases are limited” .

original: siyā parittārammaṇaṃ…pe… appamāṇārammaṇa”ntipi, “dhammāyatanaṃ siyā parittārammaṇaṃ…pe…
analyzed: siyā paritta ārammaṇam pe appamāṇa ārammaṇan ti pi dhamma āyatanam siyā paritta ārammaṇam pe
translated: “The mental-data base may have a limited object … may have an immeasurable object” …🔽“It may have no object” should be said. For in the case of question-and-answer

original: appamāṇārammaṇa”ntipi, “siyā anārammaṇa”ntipi vattabbaṃ siyā. Na hi pañhapucchake
analyzed: appamāṇa ārammaṇam ti pi siyā anārammaṇam ti pi vattabbam siyā na hi pañha pucchake
translated: expositions there is no exposition that is not exhaustive.

original: sāvasesā desanā atthīti. “Aṭṭhindriyā siyā ajjhattārammaṇā”ti ettha ca jīvitindriyassa
analyzed: sa avasesā desanā atthi iti aṭṭhindriyā siyā ajjhatta ārammaṇā ti ettha ca jīvitindriyassa
translated: And in the case of the question “Are the eight faculties with a visible-data object … with a mental-data object?”

original: ākiñcaññāyatanakāle arūpassa rūpassa ca anārammaṇattā navattabbatā veditabbā.🔽Pañhapucchakavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: ākiñcaññāyatana kāle arūpassa rūpassa ca anārammaṇa ttā navattabba tā veditabbā  pañha pucchaka vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: it should be understood that the life faculty is not classifiable in the immaterial-data plane since it has no object.🔽The commentary on the question-and-answer exposition is ended.

original: Indriyavibhaṅgavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: indriya vibhaṅga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the exposition of the faculties is ended.

original: 6. Paṭiccasamuppādavibhaṅgo
analyzed: paṭiccasamuppāda vibhaṅgo
translated: The Dependent Origination Exposition

original: 1. Suttantabhājanīyaṃ
analyzed: suttanta bhājanīyam
translated: The Suttas in the Basket

original: Uddesavāravaṇṇanā
analyzed: uddesa vāra vaṇṇanā
translated: The Commentary on the Schedule

original: 225. “‘Kiṃvādī bhante sammāsambuddho’ti? ‘Vibhajjavādī mahārājā”’ti moggaliputtatissattherena
analyzed: kiṃvādī bhante sammāsambuddhaḥ ti vibhajja vādī mahā rāja ati moggaliputta tissa therena
translated: “‘What does the Blessed One say, venerable sir?’ ‘The Tathāgata speaks after making a division, great king’—so said the Elder Moggaliputtatissa.

original: vuttattā sammāsambuddhasāvakā vibhajjavādino. Te hi venayikādibhāvaṃ vibhajja vadanti,
analyzed: sammāsambuddha sāvakāḥ vibhajja vādinaḥ te hi venayika ādi bhāvam vibhajja vadanti
translated: So the disciples of the Blessed One speak after making a division. For they speak after making a division of what is to be expounded, etc.,

original: cīvarādīnaṃ sevitabbāsevitabbabhāvaṃ vā sassatucchedavāde vā vibhajja vadanti “sassato🔽attā ca loko cā”tiādīnaṃ ṭhapanīyānaṃ ṭhapanato rāgādikkhayassa sassatassa rāgādikāyaduccaritādiucchedassa
analyzed: cīvara ādīnam sevitabba a sevitabba bhāvam vā sassatu cheda vāde vā vibhajja vadanti sassato  attā ca ca ati ādīnam ṭhapanīyānam ṭhapanataḥ rāga ādi khayassa sassatassa rāga ādi kāya duccarita ādi ucchedassa
translated: or the distinction between what should and should not be cultivated in the case of robes, etc., or the distinction between eternalism and annihilationism, they say: “The self and the world are eternal,” etc., and they do not answer the questions that should be set aside. They do not understand that the annihilation of lust, etc., is eternal,🔽and that the annihilation of the body, etc., due to lust, etc., is annihilation.

original: ca vacanato, na pana ekaṃsabyākaraṇīyādayo tayo pañhe apanetvā vibhajjabyākaraṇīyameva
analyzed: ca vacanataḥ na pana ekaṃsa byākaraṇīya ādayo tayo pañhe apanetvā vibhajja byākaraṇīyam eva
translated: Or else they divide the question of what should and should not be cultivated in regard to robes, etc., or the doctrine of eternalism and annihilationism, and they answer: “The self and the world are eternal” and so on. They answer in this way by dividing the question in order to avoid the three kinds of answers that are not to be given, namely, the one-sided answers, the answers that are to be set aside, and the answers that are to be analyzed. But they do not answer by analyzing the three questions that are to be answered by analysis, namely, the one-sided questions, the questions that are to be set aside, and the questions that are to be answered by analysis.

original: vadantīti. Vibhajjavādīnaṃ maṇḍalaṃ samūho vibhajjavādimaṇḍalaṃ, vibhajjavādino vā🔽bhagavato parisā vibhajjavādimaṇḍalantipi vadanti. Ācariyehi vuttaaviparītatthadīpanena
analyzed: vadanti iti maṇḍalam samūhaḥ vibhajja vādi maṇḍalam vibhajja vādinaḥ vā  bhagavataḥ parisā vadanti ācariyehi vutta a viparīta attha dīpanena
translated: The circle of the Vibhajjavādins is the group of the Vibhajjavādins. Or else the circle of the Vibhajjavādins is the assembly of the Blessed One, the Vibhajjavādins.🔽By not contradicting the teachers’ explanation of the meaning of the questions,

original: te anabbhācikkhantena. “Avijjā puññāneñjābhisaṅkhārānaṃ hetupaccayo hotī”tiādiṃ vadanto
analyzed: te an abbhācikkhantena avijjā puñña aneñja abhisaṅkhārānam hetu paccayaḥ hoti itiādim vadanto
translated: and by saying: “Ignorance is a condition for the formations of merit, demerit, and imperturbability,” etc.,

original: kathāvatthumhi paṭikkhitte puggalavādādike ca vadanto sakasamayaṃ vokkamati nāma,
analyzed: kathā vatthumhi paṭikkhitte puggala vāda ādike ca vadanto saka samayam vokkamati nāma
translated: and by not deviating from one’s own doctrine when the topic of discussion is rejected and when one speaks of the doctrines of the individual, etc.,

original: tathā avokkamantena. Parasamayaṃ dosāropanabyāpāravirahena anāyūhantena. “Idampi
analyzed: tathā avokkamantena para samayam dosa āropana byāpāra virahena anāyūhantena idam pi
translated: So too, by one who does not misrepresent. By one who does not misrepresent another’s view by not misrepresenting it through a desire to find fault with it. “This too

original: yuttaṃ gahetabba”nti parasamayaṃ asampiṇḍentenāti keci vadanti.🔽“Tathāhaṃ bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmi, yathā tadevidaṃ viññāṇaṃ sandhāvati🔽saṃsarati anañña”ntiādiṃ vadanto suttaṃ paṭibāhati nāma, tathā appaṭibāhantena. “Tathāhaṃ
analyzed: yuttam gahetabbanti para samayam a sampiṇḍentena ati keci vadanti  tathā aham bhagavatā dhammam desitam ājānāmi yathā tat eva idam viññāṇam sandhāvati  saṃsarati anañña nti ādim vadanto suttam paṭibāhati nāma tathā appaṭibāhantena tathā aham
translated: is suitable to be taken up” — by one who does not misrepresent another’s view by not combining it with one’s own view, some say.

original: bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmi, yathā yeme antarāyikā dhammā vuttā bhagavatā,🔽te paṭisevato nālaṃ antarāyāyā”ti, “supinante kato vītikkamo āpattikaro hotī”ti ca
analyzed: bhagavatā dhammam desitam ājānāmi yathā ye me antarāyikāḥ dhammāḥ vuttāḥ bhagavatā  te paṭisevataḥ na alam antarāyāya ati supina ante kataḥ vītikkamaḥ āpatti karaḥ hoti iti ca
translated: “I understand the Dhamma taught by the Blessed One in this way: it is this consciousness that goes to the next world, not another” — by one who does not contradict the discourses in this way. So too, by one who does not contradict. “I understand the Dhamma taught by the Blessed One in this way: for one who engages in these obstructive things, there is no obstruction to Nibbāna” and “the transgression of a dream is a cause for offense” —

original: evamādiṃ vadanto vinayaṃ paṭilometi nāma, tabbipariyāyena taṃ anulomentena. Paṭilomento
analyzed: evamādim vadantaḥ vinayam paṭilomā iti nāma tad bipariyāyena tam anulomentena paṭilomentaḥ
translated: by one who does not contradict the Vinaya in this way. So too, by one who does not contradict. By one who does not contradict, by one who does not contradict the Vinaya in the opposite way. For one who contradicts

original: hi kammantaraṃ bhindanto dhammatañca vilometi. Suttante vutte cattāro mahāpadese,
analyzed: hi kammantaram bhindantaḥ dhamma tañca viloma iti suttante vutte cattāro mahāpadese
translated: breaks the continuity of his work and contradicts the Dhamma. And in the discourses, the four great authorities are stated:

original: aṭṭhakathāyañca vutte suttasuttānulomaācariyavādaattanomatimahāpadese olokentena.
analyzed: aṭṭhakathāyañca vutte sutta sutta anuloma ācariya vāda atta nomati mahā padese olokentena
translated: And when it is stated in the commentary, it should be looked at in the light of the Thread, the subcommentaries, the teachers’ opinions, the great authorities, and the meaning.

original: Taṃolokanena hi sutte vinaye ca santiṭṭhati nātidhāvati. Dhammanti paṭiccasamuppādapāḷiṃ.
analyzed: taṃolokanena hi sutte vinaye ca santiṭṭhati na atidhāvati paṭiccasamuppāda pāḷim
translated: For by looking at them he stands firm in the True Idea and Discipline and does not overshoot the mark. ‘ Idea ’ is the text of the Dependent Origination.

original: Atthanti tadatthaṃ. Hetuhetuphalāni idha nādhippetāni. “Dukkhādīsu aññāṇaṃ avijjā”ti
analyzed: attham ti tad attham hetu hetu phalāni idha na adhippetāni dukkha ādīsu aññāṇam avijjā ti
translated: ‘ Meaning ’ is its meaning. The causes and fruits are not intended here. ‘ The unknowing of the kinds of suffering is ignorance ’ .

original: vuttamatthaṃ parivattitvā puna “pubbante aññāṇa”ntiādīhi aparehipi pariyāyehi niddisantena.
analyzed: vutta mattham parivattitvā puna pubbante aññāṇa nti ādīhi aparehi pi pariyāyehi niddisantena
translated: Having turned round the meaning stated thus, he shows it again by other synonyms beginning with ‘ unknowing of the past ’ .

original: “Saṅkhārā iminā pariyāyena bhavoti vuccanti, taṇhā iminā pariyāyena upādāna”ntiādinā
analyzed: saṅkhārāḥ iminā pariyāyena vuccanti taṇhā iminā pariyāyena upādāna nti ādinā
translated: ‘ Formations are called being in this way, craving is called assuming in this way ’ , and so on.

original: niddisantenāti vadanti.
analyzed: vadanti
translated: He shows it thus, they say.

original: Sattoti sattasuññatāti vadanti, sattasuññesu vā saṅkhāresu sattavohāro. Paccayākārameva cāti paccayākāro eva ca, ma-kāro padasandhikaro.
analyzed: satto ti satta suñña tā ati vadanti satta suññesu vā saṅkhāresu satta vohāro paccaya ākāram eva ca ati paccaya ākāro eva ca makāro pada sandhi karo
translated: ‘ Creature ’ is the seven voidnesses, they say. Or else the sevenfold treatment of creatures is in the seven voidnesses. ‘ The mode of condition ’ is only the mode of condition. The letter ma is a word-joiner.

original: Tasmāti vuttanayena atthavaṇṇanāya kātabbattā dukkarattā ca.
analyzed: tasmā iti vutta nayena attha vaṇṇanāya kātabba ttā dukkara ttā ca
translated: ‘ Therefore ’ is because the commentary has to be made in the way stated and because it is difficult.

original: Patiṭṭhaṃ nādhigacchāmīti yattha ṭhitassa vaṇṇanā sukarā hoti, taṃ nayaṃ attanoyeva🔽ñāṇabalena nādhigacchāmīti attho. Nissayaṃ pana ācikkhanto āha “sāsanaṃ panida”ntiādi.
analyzed: patiṭṭham na adhigacchāmi iti yattha ṭhitassa vaṇṇanā sukarā hoti tam nayam attanoya iva  ñāṇa balena na adhigacchāmi iti attho nissayam pana ācikkhantaḥ āha sāsanam
translated: I do not find a footing for it: the meaning is, I do not find by the power of my own knowledge a method whereby the exposition would be easy to give.🔽But in explaining the support he says, “The Dispensation, however, is this … ” .

original: Idha sāsananti pāḷidhammamāha, paṭiccasamuppādameva vā. So hi anulomapaṭilomādinānādesanānayamaṇḍito
analyzed: idha sāsanam ti pāḷi dhammam āha paṭicca samuppādam eva vā saḥ hi anuloma paṭiloma ādi nānā desanā naya maṇḍitaḥ
translated: Herein, the Dispensation is the text of the Dhamma or else it is the dependent origination itself. For that is the support since it is adorned with the various methods of teaching in forward and reverse order, etc.,

original: abbocchinno ajjāpi pavattatīti nissayo hoti. Tadaṭṭhakathāsaṅkhāto ca pubbācariyamaggoti.
analyzed: abbocchinnaḥ ajja api pavattati iti nissayaḥ hoti tad aṭṭhakathā saṅkhāto ca pubba ācariya maggo ti
translated: and it has been handed down without break down to the present day. And the commentaries are the ancient teachers.

original: “Taṃ suṇātha samāhitā”ti ādarajanane kiṃ payojananti taṃ dassento āha “vuttañheta”ntiādi.
analyzed: tam suṇātha samāhitā ati ādara janane kim payojanam ti tam dassentaḥ āha vuttam ha etat tiādi
translated: “Listen with concentrated mind”: he said this in order to generate respect. The purpose of that is shown by the words, “For this is said” .

original: Aṭṭhiṃ katvāti atthaṃ katvā, yathā vā na nassati, evaṃ aṭṭhigataṃ viya karonto aṭṭhiṃ🔽katvā. Pubbakālato aparakāle bhavaṃ pubbāpariyaṃ. Paṭhamārambhādito pabhuti khaṇe
analyzed: aṭṭhim katvā iti attham katvā yathā vā na nassati evam aṭṭhi gatam viya karontaḥ aṭṭhim  katvā pubba kālataḥ apara kāle bhavam pubbāpariyam paṭhama ārambha āditaḥ khaṇe
translated: Making it the essence: making it the aim; or making it as if it were a bone, in other words, making it something that will not be lost.

original: khaṇe ñāṇavisesaṃ kilesakkhayavisesañca labhatīti attho.
analyzed: khaṇe ñāṇa visesam kilesa khaya visesam ca labhati iti attho
translated: The successive: the state of what is successive, what comes after what went before. The meaning is that from the time of the first undertaking he obtains a special kind of knowledge and a special kind of destruction of defilements in each moment.

original: Kammavipākakilesavaṭṭānaṃ mūlakāraṇattā ādito vuttattā ca avijjā paṭiccasamuppādassa🔽mūlaṃ. Tattha valliyā mūle diṭṭhe tato pabhuti valliyā haraṇaṃ viya paṭiccasamuppādassa
analyzed: kamma vipāka kilesa vaṭṭānam mūla kāraṇa ttā āditas vutta ttā ca avijjā paṭiccasamuppādassa  mūlam tattha valliyā mūle diṭṭhe tatas pabhuti valliyā haraṇam viya paṭiccasamuppādassa
translated: And because it is the root-cause of the kamma-resultant formations and of the defilements, and because it is stated first, ignorance is the root of dependent origination.

original: mūle diṭṭhe tato pabhuti paṭiccasamuppādadesanāti upamāsaṃsandanā na kātabbā. Na
analyzed: mūle diṭṭhe tatas pabhuti paṭiccasamuppāda desanā ati upamā saṃsandanā na kātabbā na
translated: Herein, it should not be construed that the teaching of dependent origination is like the pulling out of a creeper beginning with the root, since the creeper is seen when the root is seen.

original: hi bhagavato “idameva diṭṭhaṃ, itaraṃ adiṭṭha”nti vibhajanīyaṃ atthi sabbassa diṭṭhattā.🔽Mūlato pabhuti pana valliyā haraṇaṃ viya mūlato pabhuti paṭiccasamuppādadesanā katāti🔽idamettha sāmaññamadhippetaṃ, bodhaneyyajjhāsayavasena vā bodhetabbabhāvena mūlādidassanasāmaññañca yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: hi bhagavataḥ idam eva diṭṭham itaram a diṭṭham ti vibhajanīyam atthi sabbassa diṭṭha ttā  mūlataḥ pana valliyāḥ haraṇam viya mūlataḥ pabhuti paṭiccasamuppāda desanā katā ati  idam ettha sāmaññam adhippetam vā bodhetabba bhāvena mūla ādi dassana sāmaññañca yojetabbam
translated: For the Blessed One has no such distinction as “This is seen by me, that is not seen by me,” since all is seen by him.🔽But the teaching of dependent origination is like the pulling out of a creeper beginning with the root.

original: Tassāti –
analyzed: tassa iti
translated: So the similarity intended here is this: just as the creeper is pulled out beginning with the root, so too the teaching of dependent origination is given beginning with the root. Or else the similarity should be construed as follows: the root is the first of the creeper’s parts to appear, and so it is taught first; the root is the support for the creeper, and so it is taught first; the root is the cause for the production of the creeper, and so it is taught first; the root is the cause for the growth of the creeper, and so it is taught first; the root is the cause for the non-disappearance of the creeper, and so it is taught first.🔽So too, ignorance is the first of the states of dependent origination to appear, and so it is taught first; ignorance is the support for the states of dependent origination, and so it is taught first; ignorance is the cause for the production of the states of dependent origination, and so it is taught first; ignorance is the cause for the growth of the states of dependent origination, and so it is taught first; ignorance is the cause for the non-disappearance of the states of dependent origination, and so it is taught first.🔽“That prince, bhikkhus, having grown up, having reached maturity of faculties,

original: “Sa kho so, bhikkhave, kumāro vuddhimanvāya indriyānaṃ paripākamanvāya pañcahi kāmaguṇehi
analyzed: sa kho saḥ bhikkhave kumāraḥ vuddhim anvāya indriyānam paripākam anvāya pañcahi kāmaguṇehi
translated: with the five cords of sensual pleasure,

original: samappito…pe… rajanīyehi, so cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā piyarūpe rūpe sārajjati, apiyarūpe🔽rūpe byāpajjati, anupaṭṭhitakāyasatī ca viharati parittacetaso. So tañca cetovimuttiṃ🔽paññāvimuttiṃ yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti. Yatthassa te uppannā pāpakā akusalā dhammā🔽aparisesā nirujjhanti, so evaṃ anurodhavirodhaṃ samāpanno yaṃ kiñci vedanaṃ vedeti🔽sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā, so taṃ vedanaṃ abhinandati abhivadati ajjhosāya tiṭṭhatī”ti –🔽Evaṃ vuttassa. Evaṃ sotadvārādīsupi. Abhivadatoti “aho sukhaṃ, aho sukha”nti vacībhedakarappattāya
analyzed: rajanīyehi so cakkhunā rūpam disvā piya rūpe rūpe sārajjati a piya rūpe  rūpe byāpajjati an upaṭṭhita kāya satī ca viharati paritta cetasaḥ saḥ tam ca cetaḥ vimuttim  paññā vimuttim yathābhūtam na pajānāti yattha assa te uppannā pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ  aparisesāḥ nirujjhanti saḥ evam anurodha virodham samāpannaḥ yam kiñci vedanam vedeti  sukham vā dukkham vā adukkham asukham vā so tam vedanam abhinandati abhivadati ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati iti  evam vuttassa evam sota dvāra ādīsu pi abhivadato ti aho sukham aho sukham ti vacībheda kara ppattāya
translated: He is not fully restrained in the eye faculty. He sees a form with the eye and is lustful towards a form that is a basis for lust.🔽He dwells with a mind that is not fully focused internally, with an unpurified mind. He does not understand as it really is that liberation of mind, liberation by wisdom, wherein those arisen bad unwholesome states of his that have arisen cease without remainder.🔽Thus he enters into conformity and into contradiction. Whatever feeling he feels,🔽whether pleasant, painful, or neither-painful-nor-pleasant, he delights in that feeling, welcomes it, and remains holding to it. ”🔽When this was said, the Venerable Ananda said to the Blessed One:🔽“So it is, Blessed One! So it is, Sublime One! ”🔽The same in regard to the ear, etc.

original: balavataṇhāya “ahaṃ mamā”ti abhivadato. Tato balavatiyā mocetuṃ asakkuṇeyyabhāvena
analyzed: balava taṇhāya aham mama ati abhivadataḥ tatas balavatiyā a sakkuṇeyya bhāvena
translated: He is not fully aware of the deathless element that has arisen in himself. He is not fully aware of the deathless element that has arisen in himself. He is not fully aware of the deathless element that has arisen in himself. He is not fully aware of the deathless element that has arisen in himself. He is not fully aware of the deathless element that has arisen in himself. He is not fully aware of the deathless element that has arisen in himself. He is not fully aware of the deathless element that has arisen in himself. He is not fully aware of the deathless element that has arisen in himself. He is not fully aware of the deathless element that has arisen in himself. He is not fully aware of the deathless element that has arisen in himself. He is not fully aware of the deathless element that has arisen in himself. He is not fully aware of the deathless element that has arisen in himself. He is not fully aware of the deathless element that has arisen in himself. He is not fully aware of the deathless element that has arisen in himself. He is not fully aware of the deathless element that has arisen in himself. He is not fully aware of the deathless element that has arisen in himself. He is not fully aware of the deathless element that has arisen in himself. He is not fully aware of the deathless element that has arisen in himself. He is not fully aware of the deathless element that has arisen in himself. He is not fully aware of the deathless element that has arisen in himself. He is not fully aware of the deathless element that has arisen in himself. He is not fully aware of the deathless element that has arisen in himself. He is not fully aware of the deathless element that has arisen in himself. He is not fully aware of the deathless element that has arisen in himself. He is not fully aware of the deathless element that has arisen in himself. He is not fully aware of the deathless element that has arisen in himself. He is not fully aware of the deathless element that has arisen in himself. He is not fully aware of the deathless element that has arisen in himself.
