He is not fully aware of the deathless element that has arisen in himself. He is not fully aware of the deathless element that has arisen in himself. He is

original: ajjhosāya tiṭṭhato. Tatopi balavatī upādānabhūtā taṇhā nandī. Ettha ca abhinandanādinā
analyzed: ajjhosāya tiṭṭhataḥ tatas pi balavatī upādāna bhūtā taṇhā nandī ettha ca abhinandana ādinā
translated: and it persists in its attachment. And so craving, which is the underlying tendency, is stronger than the attachment. And here craving is stated by the words “delights in” and so on,

original: taṇhā vuttā, nandīvacanena tappaccayaṃ upādānaṃ catubbidhampi nanditātadavippayogatāhi
analyzed: taṇhā vuttā nandī vacanena tad paccayam upādānam catubbidham pi nandi tā tad a vippayoga tāhi
translated: and the fourfold attachment is stated by the words “finds delight in” and so on, because it is not separate from the delight and so on.

original: taṇhādiṭṭhābhinandanabhāvehi cāti veditabbaṃ. “Jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇa”ntiādikañca
analyzed: taṇhā diṭṭha abhinandana bhāvehi ca ati veditabbam jāti paccayā jarā maraṇa nti ādikam ca
translated: And the words “finds delight in” and so on should be understood as the states of delighting in craving, delighting in views, and delighting in the self.

original: tattheva mahātaṇhāsaṅkhayavimuttisutte vuttaṃ.🔽Vipākavaṭṭabhūte paṭisandhipavattiphassādayo kammasamuṭṭhānañca ojaṃ sandhāya “cattāro
analyzed: tattha iva mahā taṇhā saṅkhaya vimutti sutte vuttam  vipāka vaṭṭa bhūte paṭisandhi pavatti phassa ādayo kamma samuṭṭhānam ca ojam sandhāya cattāro
translated: And the words “With birth as condition, ageing, death” and so on are stated in the same sutta, the Mahātaṇhāsankhaya Sutta .

original: āhārā taṇhānidānā”tiādi vuttaṃ, vaṭṭūpatthambhakā pana itarepi āhārā taṇhāpabhave
analyzed: āhārā taṇhā nidānā tiādi vuttam vaṭṭu upatthambhakā pana itare pi āhārā taṇhā apabhave
translated: And the words “The four nutriments have craving as their source” and so on are stated with reference to the nutriment consisting of contact in rebirth-linking and the other phases of existence, and also to the nutriment consisting of mental volition, which is the outcome of kamma,

original: tasmiṃ avijjamāne na vijjantīti “taṇhānidānā”ti vattuṃ vaṭṭanti.
analyzed: tasmin a vijjamāne na vijjanti iti taṇhā nidānā ati vattum vaṭṭanti
translated: but the other nutriments, which are the consolidators of the round, are also rightly described as “having craving as their source,” since they do not occur if craving does not exist.

original: Tato tatoti catubbidhāsu desanāsu tato tato desanāto. Ñāyappaṭivedhāya saṃvattatīti
analyzed: tato tatoti catubbidhāsu desanāsu tatas tatas desanātaḥ ñāya ppaṭivedhāya saṃvattati iti
translated: From here and there: from here and there in the fourfold teaching. It conduces to the penetration of the right way.

original: ñāyoti maggo, soyeva vā paṭiccasamuppādo “ariyo cassa ñāyo paññāya sudiṭṭho hotī”ti🔽vacanato. Sayameva hi samantabhadrakattā tathā tathā paṭivijjhitabbattā tāya tāya
analyzed: ñāyaḥ ti maggo saḥ yā iva vā paṭiccasamuppādaḥ ariyaḥ ca ssa ñāyaḥ paññāya su diṭṭhaḥ hoti iti  vacanataḥ sayam eva hi samantabhadraka ttā tathā tathā paṭivijjhitabba ttā tāya tāya
translated: “Understanding” is the path, or else it is dependent origination itself, since it is said, “The noble understanding of dependent origination is well seen by him” .

original: desanāya attano paṭivedhāya saṃvattatīti. Samantabhadrakattaṃ desanāvilāsappatti
analyzed: desanāya paṭivedhāya saṃvattati iti samantabhadrakattam desanā vilāsa ppatti
translated: For it is he himself who is all-glorious, and it is he who penetrates in such and such a way, and it is he who is the cause of his own penetration of the teaching in such and such a way.🔽The all-gloriousness and the attainment of the beauty of the teaching are the same cause for all four teachings.

original: ca catunnampi desanānaṃ samānaṃ kāraṇanti visesakāraṇaṃ vattukāmo āha “visesato”ti.🔽Assa bhagavato desanā, assa vā paṭiccasamuppādassa desanāti yojetabbaṃ. Pavattikāraṇavibhāgo
analyzed: ca catunnam api desanānam samānam kāraṇam ti visesa kāraṇam vattu kāmaḥ āha visesataḥ ti  assa bhagavataḥ desanā assa vā paṭiccasamuppādassa desanā ti yojetabbam pavatti kāraṇa vibhāgaḥ
translated: Desiring to state the special cause, he said “in particular.”🔽The Blessed One’s teaching is “his” or dependent origination is “his.”

original: avijjādikova, kāraṇanti vā gahitānaṃ pakatiādīnaṃ avijjādīnañca akāraṇatā kāraṇatā
analyzed: vā akāraṇa tā kāraṇa tā
translated: The analysis of the cause of occurrence is the non-causality and causality of the inherent tendencies, etc., which are included among the causes such as ignorance, etc.

original: ca. Tattha sammūḷhā keci akāraṇaṃ “kāraṇa”nti gaṇhanti, keci na kiñci kāraṇaṃ bujjhantīti
analyzed: ca tattha sammūḷhā keci akāraṇam gaṇhanti keci na kiñci kāraṇam bujjhanti iti
translated: Herein, some, being confused, take what is not a cause to be a cause, while others do not understand any cause at all.

original: tesaṃ yathāsakehi anurūpehi kāraṇehi saṅkhārādipavattisandassanatthaṃ anulomadesanā
analyzed: tesam yathā sakehi anurūpehi kāraṇehi saṅkhāra ādi pavatti sandassana ttham anuloma desanā
translated: In order to show them the occurrence of formations, etc., by means of their respective appropriate causes, the forward order teaching is given.

original: pavattā, itarāsaṃ tadatthatāsambhavepi na tāsaṃ tadatthameva pavatti atthantarasabbhāvato.🔽Ayaṃ pana tadatthā evāti etissā tadatthatā vuttā. Pavattiādīnavapaṭicchādikā avijjā
analyzed: pavattā itarāsam tad attha tā sambhave pi na tāsam tad attham eva pavatti attha antara sabbhāvato  ayam pana tad atthā evā ti etissā tad attha tā vuttā pavatti ādīnava paṭicchādikā avijjā
translated: and the other three are so called because they occur with that meaning, though they do not have that meaning in themselves.🔽But this is called “having that meaning” because it has that meaning in itself. Ignorance is the beginning of the round of rebirths because it conceals the danger in the round.🔽The formations arise from that, and consciousness from the formations, and so on. The order in which the round of rebirths comes about is shown by this.

original: ādi, tato saṅkhārā uppajjanti tato viññāṇanti evaṃ pavattiyā uppattikkamasandassanatthañca.🔽Anuvilokayato yo sambodhito pubbabhāge taṃtaṃphalapaṭivedho pavatto, tadanusārena
analyzed: ādi tatas saṅkhārāḥ uppajjanti tatas viññāṇan ti evam pavattiyāḥ uppatti kkama sandassana ttham ca  anuvilokayataḥ yaḥ sambodhitaḥ pubba bhāge taṃ taṃ phala paṭivedho pavatto tad anusārena
translated: The order in which the round of rebirths is reversed is shown by the words “When he sees thus” and the rest.🔽The meaning is this. The Blessed One, who sees the world with his unobstructed knowledge, taught the dependent origination in forward order in order to show the arising of this or that fruit in the past, present, and future, in conformity with the past, present, and future occurrence of this or that cause.🔽And he taught it in reverse order in order to show the cessation of this or that fruit in the past, present, and future, in conformity with the past, present, and future cessation of this or that cause.

original: tadanugamena jarāmaraṇādikassa jātiādikāraṇaṃ yaṃ adhigataṃ, tassa sandassanatthaṃ
analyzed: tad anugamena jarā maraṇa ādikassa jāti ādi kāraṇam yaṃ adhigatam tassa sandassana attham
translated: For the Blessed One, who sees the world with his unobstructed knowledge, taught the dependent origination in forward order in order to show the arising of this or that fruit in the past, present, and future, in conformity with the past, present, and future occurrence of this or that cause.

original: assa paṭilomadesanā pavattā, anuvilokayato paṭilomadesanā pavattāti vā sambandho.
analyzed: assa paṭiloma desanā pavattā anuvilokayataḥ paṭiloma desanā pavattā ati vā sambandhaḥ
translated: And he taught it in reverse order in order to show the cessation of this or that fruit in the past, present, and future, in conformity with the past, present, and future cessation of this or that cause.

original: Desentopi hi bhagavā kicchāpannaṃ lokaṃ anuviloketvā pubbabhāga…pe… sandassanatthaṃ
analyzed: desentaḥ api hi bhagavā kicchā āpannam lokam anuviloketvā pubba bhāga pe sandassana attham
translated: For the Blessed One, who sees the world with his unobstructed knowledge, taught the dependent origination in forward order in order to show the arising of this or that fruit in the past, present, and future, in conformity with the past, present, and future occurrence of this or that cause.

original: desetīti. Āhārataṇhādayo paccuppannaddhā, saṅkhārāvijjā atītaddhāti iminā adhippāyenāha
analyzed: deseti iti āhāra taṇhā ādayo paccuppannaddhā saṅkhārā vijjāḥ atītaddhā iti iminā adhippāyena āha
translated: And he taught it in reverse order in order to show the cessation of this or that fruit in the past, present, and future, in conformity with the past, present, and future cessation of this or that cause.🔽The meaning is this. The Blessed One, who sees the world with his unobstructed knowledge, taught the dependent origination in forward order in order to show the arising of this or that fruit in the past, present, and future, in conformity with the past, present, and future occurrence of this or that cause.

original: “yāva atītaṃ addhānaṃ atiharitvā”ti, āhārā vā taṇhāya pabhāvetabbā anāgato addhā,🔽taṇhādayo paccuppanno, saṅkhārāvijjā atītoti. Paccakkhaṃ pana phalaṃ dassetvā taṃnidānadassanavasena
analyzed: yāva atītam addhānam atiharitvā ati āhārāḥ vā taṇhāya pabhāvetabbāḥ anāgataḥ addhā  taṇhā ādayo paccuppanno saṅkhārā vijjāḥ atīto ti paccakkham pana phalam dassetvā tad nidāna dassana vasena
translated: “As far back as the past” means that nutriment should be traced back to craving in the future,🔽craving, etc., in the present, and formations and ignorance in the past. But it is proper to show the result first and then to show the cause of the result by way of the succession of causes and effects.

original: phalakāraṇaparamparāya dassanaṃ yujjatīti āhārā purimataṇhāya uppāditā paccuppanno
analyzed: phala kāraṇa paramparāya dassanam yujjati iti āhārā purima taṇhāya uppāditā paccuppanno
translated: Thus nutriment is the present life produced by the past craving,

original: addhā, taṇhādayo atīto, saṅkhārāvijjā tatopi atītataro saṃsārassa anādibhāvadassanatthaṃ
analyzed: addhā taṇhā ādayaḥ atītaḥ saṅkhārā vijjā tatas pi atītataraḥ saṃsārassa anādi bhāva dassana ttham
translated: craving, etc., are the past life, and formations and ignorance are even more past than that. This is said in order to show that the round of rebirths has no beginning.

original: vuttoti yāva atītaṃ addhānanti yāva atītataraṃ addhānanti attho yutto.
analyzed: vutto ti yāva atītam addhānanti yāva atītataram addhānanti atthaḥ yutto
translated: Therefore the meaning of “as far back as the past” is “as far back as the more past.”

original: Āyatiṃ punabbhavābhinibbattiāhārakā vā cattāro āhārā –🔽“Āhāretīti ahaṃ na vadāmi, āhāretīti cāhaṃ vadeyyuṃ, tatrassa kallo pañho ‘ko nu
analyzed: āyatim punabbhava abhinibbatti āhārakāḥ vā cattāro āhārā  āhāra iti iti aham na vadāmi āhāra iti iti ca aham vadeyyum tatra assa kallaḥ pañho kaḥ nu
translated: Or alternatively, the four nutriments are the nutriments for the production of renewed existence in the future.

original: kho, bhante, āhāretī’ti. Evaṃ cāhaṃ na vadāmi, evaṃ pana avadantaṃ maṃ yo evaṃ puccheyya
analyzed: kho bhante āhāra iti iti evam ca aham na vadāmi evam pana a vadantam mama yaḥ evam puccheyya
translated: “I do not say that one who eats eats nutriment. If I said that one who eats eats nutriment, then it would be proper to ask me: ‘Who, venerable sir, is the one who eats nutriment?’ But since I do not say that one who eats eats nutriment, it is not proper to ask me:🔽‘Who, venerable sir, is the one who eats nutriment?’”

original: ‘kissa nu kho, bhante, viññāṇāhāro’ti. Esa kallo pañho, tatra kallaṃ veyyākaraṇaṃ,
analyzed: kissa nu kho bhante viññāṇa āhāraḥ ti esa kallaḥ pañhaḥ tatra kallam veyyākaraṇam
translated: ‘What, venerable sir, is the nutriment for consciousness?’ This is the right question, and the right answer is: ‘The nutriment for consciousness is volitional formations.’

original: viññāṇāhāro āyatiṃ punabbhavābhinibbattiyā”ti –
analyzed: viññāṇa āhāraḥ āyatim punabbhava abhinibbattiyā ati
translated: For this is said: ‘The nutriment for consciousness is the generation of future renewed existence’ .

original: Vacanato taṃsampayuttattā phassacetanānaṃ tappavattihetuttā ca kabaḷīkārāhārassa.
analyzed: vacanataḥ tad sampayutta ttā phassa cetanānam tad pavatti hetu ttā ca kabaḷīkāra āhārassa
translated: And because of the words ‘The nutriment for consciousness is volitional formations’ , the nutriment consisting of contact and the nutriment consisting of mental volition are included too, since they are associated with consciousness, and the nutriment consisting of material food is included too, since it is the cause for the occurrence of consciousness.

original: Tena hi upatthambhitarūpakāyassa, tañca icchantassa kammaviññāṇāyūhanaṃ hoti. Bhojanañhi
analyzed: tena hi upatthambhita rūpa kāyassa tat ca icchantassa kamma viññāṇā yūhanam hoti bhojanam hi
translated: So when the material body is consolidated, there is the arousing of kamma-born consciousness in one who desires it. For food

original: saddhādīnaṃ rāgādīnañca upanissayoti vuttanti. Tasmā “te kammavaṭṭasaṅgahitā āhārā🔽paccuppanno addhā”ti imasmiṃ pariyāye purimoyevattho yutto. Atītaddhuto pabhuti “iti
analyzed: saddhā ādīnam rāga ādīnam ca upanissayaḥ ti vuttan ti tasmā te kamma vaṭṭa saṅgahitāḥ āhārāḥ  paccuppannaḥ addhā iti imasmin pariyāye purimaḥ yevatthaḥ yuttaḥ iti
translated: is a condition for faith, etc., and for greed, etc., as a supporting object condition. So the nutriments included in the round of kamma are the nutriment that has been and is being.🔽In the case of the passage beginning, ‘Bhikkhus, in dependence upon the six bases for contact there arises contact ’ , the meaning intended is that given above, namely, that the nutriment that has been is the nutriment that is being.

original: kho, bhikkhave, avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārā”tiādinā atīte tato parañca hetuphalapaṭipāṭiṃ
analyzed: kho bhikkhave avijjā paccayā saṅkhāra ati ādinā atīte tatas parañca hetu phala paṭipāṭim
translated: For the purpose of showing the nutriment’s source, the exposition of the succession of cause and fruit in the past is given in the way beginning, ‘So, bhikkhus, in dependence upon ignorance there are formations’ .

original: paccakkhānaṃ āhārānaṃ nidānadassanavasena ārohitvā nivattanena vinā abujjhantānaṃ
analyzed: paccakkhānam āhārānam nidāna dassana vasena ārohitvā nivattanena vinā a bujjhantānam
translated: And the purpose of that is to show that the round of rebirths is ungrounded and bottomless. For those who do not understand the exposition of the nutriments will not understand the round of rebirths, which is ungrounded and bottomless, and so they will be unable to reach the end of suffering.

original: taṃsandassanatthaṃ sā ayaṃ desanā pavattāti attho. Anāgataddhuno sandassanatthanti
analyzed: tad sandassana ttham sā ayam desanā pavattā ati atthaḥ anāgata ddhuno sandassana ttham ti
translated: The meaning is that this teaching occurs for the purpose of showing that. For the purpose of showing the future state:

original: anāgataddhuno duppaṭivijjhantānaṃ apassantānaṃ paccakkhaṃ paccuppannaṃ hetuṃ dassetvā
analyzed: anāgata ddhunaḥ duppaṭivijjhantānam a passantānam paccakkham paccuppannam hetum dassetvā
translated: having shown the present cause as a fact to those who are unable to penetrate the future state and do not see it,

original: hetuphalaparamparāya tassa sandassanatthanti attho.
analyzed: hetu phala paramparāya tassa sandassana tthanti attho
translated: the meaning is that it occurs for the purpose of showing that by means of a succession of causes and effects.

original: Mūlakāraṇasaddaṃ apekkhitvā “na akāraṇa”nti napuṃsakaniddeso kato. Akāraṇaṃ yadi
analyzed: mūla kāraṇa saddam apekkhitvā na akāraṇam ti napuṃsaka niddeso kataḥ akāraṇam yadi
translated: The neuter form “akāraṇa” is used with reference to the word “mūlakāraṇa” . If there were no cause,

original: siyā, suttaṃ paṭibāhitaṃ siyāti dassento suttaṃ āharati. Vaṭṭakathāya sīsabhāvo vaṭṭahetuno
analyzed: siyā suttam paṭibāhitam siyā ti dassentaḥ suttam āharati vaṭṭa kathāya sīsa bhāvaḥ vaṭṭa hetuno
translated: the sutta would be contradicted. Showing this, he cites the sutta. The head of the round of rebirths is the cause of the round of rebirths,

original: kammassapi hetubhāvo. Tattha bhavataṇhāyapi hetubhūtā avijjā, tāya paṭicchāditādīnave
analyzed: kammassa api hetu bhāvaḥ tattha bhava taṇhāya api hetu bhūtā avijjā tāya paṭicchādita ādīnave
translated: and kamma is also a cause. Here ignorance, which is a cause of craving for becoming,

original: bhave taṇhuppattitoti avijjā visesena sīsabhūtāti “mūlakāraṇa”nti vuttā. Purimāya
analyzed: bhave taṇhā uppattitaḥ ti avijjā visesena sīsa bhūtā ati mūla kāraṇam ti vuttā purimāya
translated: is the cause of the arising of craving for becoming, which is concealed by ignorance, etc. Thus ignorance is called “the head” in particular because it is the root cause. If the former

original: koṭiyā apaññāyamānāya uppādavirahato niccataṃ gaṇheyyāti āha “evañcetaṃ, bhikkhave,
analyzed: koṭiyāḥ a paññāyamānāya uppāda virahataḥ niccatam gaṇheyya iti āha evam ca itam bhikkhave
translated: were not known, one would take it to be permanent because it has no origination. Therefore he said: “If, bhikkhus,

original: vuccatī”tiādi. Tena ito pubbe uppannapubbatā natthīti apaññāyanato purimakoṭiapaññāyanaṃ
analyzed: vuccati itiādi tena itas pubbe uppanna pubba tā natthi iti apaññāyanataḥ purima koṭi apaññāyanam
translated: “It is said” and so on. Therefore, since it is not known that it has arisen before this, the designation of a prior end is🔽

original: vuttanti imamatthaṃ dasseti.
analyzed: vuttan ti imam attham dasseti
translated: and so on. So he shows the meaning of the words “because it is not discerned” in the passage “because it is not discerned in the prior limit” .

original: Avijjātaṇhāhetukkamena phalesu vattabbesu “sugatiduggatigāmino”ti vacanaṃ saddalakkhaṇāvirodhanatthaṃ.
analyzed: avijjā taṇhā hetu kkamena phalesu vattabbesu sugati duggati gāminaḥ ti vacanam sadda lakkhaṇa avirodhana attham
translated: The words “who go to a good or a bad destination” are said in order to show the fruits of the causes of ignorance and craving.🔽For in a dvanda compound the first member is placed first.

original: Dvande hi pūjitassa pubbanipātoti. Savarā kira maṃsassa aṭṭhinā alagganatthaṃ punappunaṃ
analyzed: dvande hi pūjitassa pubba nipātaḥ ti savarā kira maṃsassa aṭṭhinā a laggana ttham punappunam
translated: It seems that the butchers, in order to make the meat firm on the bone, repeatedly

original: tāpetvā koṭṭetvā uṇhodakaṃ pāyetvā virittaṃ sūnaṃ aṭṭhito muttamaṃsaṃ gāviṃ mārenti.
analyzed: tāpetvā koṭṭetvā uṇha udakam pāyetvā virittam sūnam aṭṭhitas mutta maṃsam gāvim mārenti
translated: heat it and pound it and make it drink hot water and then kill the cow by pulling out the meat from the bone.

original: Tenāha “aggisantāpi”ccādi. Tattha yathā vajjhā gāvī ca avijjābhibhūtatāya yathāvuttaṃ
analyzed: tena āha aggi santāpicca ādi tattha yathā vajjhā gāvī ca avijjā abhibhūta tāya yathā vuttam
translated: Hence he said “by the heat of fire” , etc. Herein, just as the cow to be slaughtered, being overcome by ignorance, undertakes the drinking of hot water as described,

original: uṇhodakapānaṃ ārabhati, evaṃ puthujjano yathāvuttaṃ duggatigāmikammaṃ. Yathā pana
analyzed: uṇha udaka pānam ārabhati evam puthujjanaḥ yathāvuttam duggati gāmi kammam yathā pana
translated: so the worldling undertakes the kamma that leads to a bad destination as described. But just as

original: sā uṇhodakapāne ādīnavaṃ disvā taṇhāvasena sītudakapānaṃ ārabhati, evamayaṃ avijjāya
analyzed: sā uṇha udaka pāne ādīnavam disvā taṇhā vasena sītudaka pānam ārabhati evam ayam avijjāya
translated: that cow, seeing the danger in drinking hot water, undertakes the drinking of cold water through craving, so this worldling,🔽seeing the danger in ignorance and craving, undertakes the practice of virtue through non-delusion.

original: mandattā duggatigāmikamme ādīnavaṃ disvā taṇhāvasena sugatigāmikammaṃ ārabhati. Dukkhe
analyzed: manda ttā duggati gāmi kamme ādīnavam disvā taṇhā vasena sugati gāmi kammam ārabhati dukkhe
translated: and because of his dullness he sees no danger in the course that leads to the states of deprivation, so he undertakes the course that leads to the good destinations through craving.

original: hi avijjaṃ taṇhā anuvattati, sukhe taṇhaṃ avijjāti.
analyzed: hi avijjam taṇhā anuvattati sukhe taṇham avijjāti
translated: For ignorance follows after pain, and craving after pleasure.🔽“Thus” means because of being obstructed by ignorance and because of being bound up with craving.

original: Evanti avijjāya nivutattā taṇhāya saṃyuttattā ca. Ayaṃ kāyoti saviññāṇakakāyo khandhapañcakaṃ,
analyzed: evam ti avijjāya nivuta ttā taṇhāya saṃyutta ttā ca ayam kāyo ti sa viññāṇaka kāyaḥ khandha pañcakam
translated: “This body” is the five aggregates with consciousness,

original: “saḷāyatanapaccayā phasso”ti vacanato phassakāraṇañcetaṃ vuccatīti āyatanachakkaṃ
analyzed: saḷāyatana paccayā phasso ti vacanato phassa kāraṇam ca itam vuccati iti āyatana chakkam
translated: or the six bases, which are called the cause of contact because of the words, “With the sixfold base as condition, contact” .🔽“Arisen” means come into existence.

original: vā. Samudāgatoti uppanno. Bahiddhā ca nāmarūpanti bahiddhā saviññāṇakakāyo khandhapañcakaṃ,🔽saḷāyatanāni vā. Itthetanti itthaṃ etaṃ. Attano ca paresañca pañcakkhandhā dvādasāyatanāni🔽ca dvārārammaṇabhāvena vavatthitāni dvayanāmānīti attho. “Dvayaṃ paṭicca phassoti
analyzed: vā samudāgataḥ ti uppannaḥ bahiddhā ca nāma rūpan ti bahiddhā sa viññāṇaka kāyaḥ khandha pañcakam  vai itthā itanti ittham etam attano ca paresam ca pañca kkhandhāḥ dvādasa āyatanāni  ca dvāra ārammaṇa bhāvena vavatthitāni dvaya nāmāni iti atthaḥ dvayam paṭicca phasso ti
translated: “And the external sixfold base” is the five aggregates with consciousness, or the six bases, of another person.🔽“Thus” means in this way.🔽The five aggregates and the twelve bases of another person are distinguished as the two kinds called “doors” and “objects.”🔽“With the two as condition, contact” :

original: aññattha cakkhurūpādīni dvayāni paṭicca cakkhusamphassādayo vuttā, idha pana ajjhattikabāhirāni
analyzed: aññattha cakkhu rūpa ādīni dvayāni paṭicca cakkhu samphassa ādayaḥ vuttā idha pana ajjhattika bāhirāni
translated: elsewhere the eye, visible objects, etc., are called the two, and eye-contact, etc., are said to be with the two as condition. But here the internal and the external bases are called the two, and the six kinds of contact are said to be with the two as condition.

original: āyatanāni. Mahādvayaṃ nāma kireta”nti vuttaṃ. Ayamettha adhippāyo – aññattha “cakkhuñca🔽paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇaṃ, tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso”tiādinā “cakkhu ceva
analyzed: āyatanāni mahā dvayam nāma vuttam ayam ettha adhippāyaḥ aññattha cakkhuñca  paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhu viññāṇam tiṇṇam saṅgati phassa uti ādinā cakkhu ca eva
translated: “The great duality is said to be the bases.” The intention here is this: elsewhere it is said: “Eye-consciousness arises dependent on the eye and forms. The meeting of the three is contact” . Here it is said: “The eye and forms, bhikkhus, are one of the two. The arising of the eye-consciousness is the other. The meeting of the three is contact” .

original: rūpā ca…pe… mano ceva dhammā cā”ti vuttāni dvayāni paṭicca cakkhusamphassādayo vuttā,
analyzed: rūpā ca pe mano ca iva dhammā ca ati vuttāni dvayāni paṭicca cakkhu samphassa ādayaḥ vuttā
translated: The great duality is said to be this.” The intention here is this. Elsewhere, in the passage beginning, “Dependent on the eye and forms eye-consciousness arises. The meeting of the three is contact” , and continuing, “Dependent on the eye and forms … Dependent on the mind and mental phenomena mind-consciousness arises. The meeting of the three is contact” , the eye, etc., and forms, etc., are stated as the two conditions for the arising of eye-contact, etc.,

original: idha pana “ayañceva kāyo”ti cakkhādinissaye sesadhamme cakkhādinissite eva katvā🔽vuttaṃ, cakkhādikāyaṃ ekattena “ajjhattikāyatana”nti gahetvā “bahiddhā nāmarūpa”nti
analyzed: idha pana ayam ca iva kāyo ti cakkhu ādi nissaye sesa dhamme cakkhu ādi nissite eva katvā  vuttam cakkha ādi kāyam ekattena ajjhattika āyatanan ti gahetvā bahiddhā nāma rūpan ti
translated: and here the remaining dhammas, the eye’s condition, are stated as “this body” by including them in the eye, etc., which are dependent on the eye, etc.

original: vuttaṃ, rūpādiārammaṇaṃ ekatteneva bāhirāyatananti tāni ajjhattikabāhirāni āyatanāni🔽paṭicca phasso vutto, tasmā mahādvayaṃ nāmetanti. Evañca katvā “attano ca parassa
analyzed: vuttam rūpa ādi ārammaṇam ekattena iva bāhira āyatanam ti tāni ajjhattika bāhirāni āyatanāni  paṭicca phassaḥ vutto tasmā mahā dvayam nāma etat ti evam ca katvā attano ca parassa
translated: The eye, etc., are taken as “the internal sense bases” as a unity, and the object consisting of forms, etc., are stated as “external mentality-materiality” as a unity. Thus the internal and external sense bases are stated as the condition for contact.

original: ca pañcahi khandhehi chahāyatanehi cāpi ayamattho dīpetabbovā”ti vuttaṃ. “Ayaṃ kāyo”ti
analyzed: ca pañcahi khandhehi chahi āyatanehi ca api ayam attho dīpetabbaḥ uvā ati vuttam ayam kāyo ti
translated: Therefore it is said, “The great duality is said to be this.” And it is said: “This meaning should be illustrated by one’s own five aggregates and the other’s five aggregates, and by one’s own six bases and the other’s six bases.”🔽“This body” is the internal sense bases as a unity.

original: hi vuttāni sanissayāni cakkhādīni attano pañcakkhandhā, “bahiddhā nāmarūpa”nti vuttāni
analyzed: hi vuttāni sa nissayāni cakkha ādīni attanaḥ pañca kkhandhāḥ bahiddhā nāma rūpanti vuttāni
translated: The visible-data base, etc., which are said to be “externally” are those of others.

original: rūpādīni paresaṃ. Tathā ayaṃ kāyo attanova ajjhattikāni āyatanāni, bahiddhā nāmarūpaṃ🔽paresaṃ bāhirānīti. Aññathā ajjhattikāyatanamatte eva “ayaṃ kāyo”ti vutte na ajjhattikāyatanāneva
analyzed: rūpa ādīni paresam tathā ayam kāyaḥ attanā iva ajjhattikāni āyatanāni bahiddhā nāma rūpam  paresam bāhirāni iti aññathā ajjhattika āyatana matte eva ayam kāyaḥ iti vutte na
translated: Similarly, this body is one’s own internal bases, and the “mentality-materiality externally” is

original: attano pañcakkhandhā hontīti attano ca paresañca pañcakkhandhehi dīpanā na sambhaveyyāti.
analyzed: attano pañca kkhandhāḥ honti iti attano ca paresam ca pañca kkhandhehi dīpanā na sambhaveyya ati
translated: those of others, the external bases. Otherwise, if only the internal bases were referred to by the words “this body,” then one’s own five aggregates would not be included in the internal bases, and it would be impossible to illustrate both one’s own and others’ five aggregates.

original: Saḷevāyatanānīti saḷeva samphassakāraṇāni, yehi kāraṇabhūtehi āyatanehi uppannena
analyzed: saḷ eva āyatanāni iti samphassa kāraṇāni yehi kāraṇa bhūtehi āyatanehi uppannena
translated: The six bases for contact are the six causes of contact, by means of which contact arises

original: phassena phuṭṭho bālo sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.🔽Ādi-saddena “etesaṃ vā aññatarena avijjānīvaraṇassa, bhikkhave, paṇḍitassa taṇhāya
analyzed: phassena phuṭṭhaḥ bālaḥ sukha dukkham paṭisaṃvedeti  ādi saddena etesam vā aññatarena avijjā nīvaraṇassa bhikkhave paṇḍitassa taṇhāya
translated: through the bases that are the causes, and the fool experiences pleasure and pain.🔽The word “etc.” should be construed as follows: “Bhikkhus, when a wise man is hindered by ignorance and is bound by craving” , etc.

original: saṃyuttassā”tiādi yojetabbaṃ. Tasmiñhi sutte saṅkhāre avijjātaṇhānissite eva katvā
analyzed: saṃyuttassa atiādi yojetabbam tasmin hi sutte saṅkhāre avijjā taṇhā nissite eva katvā
translated: In that sutta the formations are shown as instigated by ignorance and craving.

original: kāyaggahaṇena viññāṇanāmarūpasaḷāyatanāni gahetvā etasmiñca kāye saḷāyatanānaṃ phassaṃ
analyzed: kāya ggahaṇena viññāṇa nāma rūpa saḷāyatanāni gahetvā etasmin ca kāye phassam
translated: and contact in the body, and he shows the specific conditionality of feeling by showing that it is dependent on contact.

original: taṃnissitameva katvā vedanāya visesapaccayabhāvaṃ dassentena bhagavatā bālapaṇḍitānaṃ
analyzed: tad nissitam eva katvā vedanāya visesa paccaya bhāvam dassentena bhagavatā bāla paṇḍitānam
translated: By this method the Exalted One shows the fool and the wise man,🔽and the dependent origination that has ignorance as its root and feeling as its terminus.

original: atītaddhāvijjātaṇhāmūlako vedanānto paṭiccasamuppādo dassito. Puna ca bālapaṇḍitānaṃ
analyzed: atīta ddhā vijjā taṇhā mūlako vedanā antaḥ paṭiccasamuppādaḥ dassito puna ca bāla paṇḍitānam
translated: Again, by showing the difference between the fool and the wise man,

original: visesaṃ dassentena –🔽“Yāya ca, bhikkhave, avijjāya nivutassa bālassa yāya ca taṇhāya saṃyuttassa ayaṃ
analyzed: visesam dassentena  yāya ca bhikkhave avijjāya nivutassa bālassa yāya ca taṇhāya saṃyuttassa ayaṃ
translated: he says:🔽“Bhikkhus, this body has arisen through a certain ignorance and a certain craving.

original: kāyo samudāgato, sā ceva avijjā bālassa appahīnā, sā ca taṇhā aparikkhīṇā. Taṃ kissa
analyzed: kāyaḥ samudāgato sā ca iva avijjā bālassa appahīnā sā ca taṇhā aparikkhīṇā tam kissa
translated: That ignorance has not been abandoned by the fool, and that craving has not been destroyed.

original: hetu? Na, bhikkhave, bālo acari brahmacariyaṃ sammā dukkhakkhayāya, tasmā bālo kāyassa
analyzed: hetu na bhikkhave bālaḥ acari brahmacariyam sammā dukkha kkhayāya tasmā bālaḥ kāyassa
translated: For what reason? Because the fool has not practiced the holy life for the complete destruction of suffering. Therefore, with the breakup of the body, after death, he is reborn in a bad destination,

original: bhedā kāyūpago hoti, so kāyūpago samāno na parimuccati jātiyā…pe… dukkhasmāti vadāmī”ti –
analyzed: bhedā kāya upago hoti saḥ kāya upago samānaḥ na parimuccati jātiyā āpe dukkhasma ati vadāmi iti
translated: in hell. Reborn in a bad destination, in hell, he does not escape from birth, aging, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, displeasure, and despair. He does not escape, I say, from suffering.”

original: Vedanāpabhavaṃ sāvijjaṃ taṇhaṃ dassetvā upādānabhave ca taṃnissite katvā “kāyūpago🔽hotī”tiādinā jātiādike dassentena paccuppannahetusamuṭṭhānato pabhuti ubhayamūlova
analyzed: vedanā apabhavam sāvijjam taṇham dassetvā upādāna bhave ca tad nissite katvā kāya upagaḥ  hoti itiādinā jāti ādike dassentena paccuppanna hetu samuṭṭhānato pabhuti ubhaya mūlaḥ uva
translated: Having shown craving with ignorance as its source and with feeling as its condition, and having shown clinging as its source and with that as its condition, he shows birth, etc., with the words “He becomes embodied in a body,” etc., thus showing the past and future by means of the present cause and origin.

original: paṭiccasamuppādo vutto, tabbipariyāyena ca paṇḍitassa paccuppannahetuparikkhayato🔽pabhuti ubhayamūlako paṭilomapaṭiccasamuppādoti.
analyzed: paṭiccasamuppādaḥ vuttaḥ tad vipariyāyena ca paṇḍitassa paccuppanna hetu parikkhayato  ubhaya mūlako paṭiloma paṭiccasamuppādo ti
translated: Having shown craving with ignorance as its source and with feeling as its condition, and having shown the source of clinging by making it dependent on that craving, he showed birth, etc., with the words “comes to birth in a womb” , etc., and so he stated dependent origination with a double root from the time of the arising of the present cause onwards. And the opposite of that is the reverse dependent origination with a double root, which the wise man should be made to see beginning with the exhaustion of the present cause.

original: Duggatigāmikammassa visesapaccayattā avijjā “avindiyaṃ vindatī”ti vuttā, tathā visesapaccayo🔽vindiyassa na hotīti “vindiyaṃ na vindatī’ti ca. Attani nissitānaṃ cakkhuviññāṇādīnaṃ
analyzed: duggati gāmi kammassa visesa paccaya ttā avijjā avindiyam vindati iti vuttā tathā visesa paccayo  vindiyassa na hoti iti vindiyam na vindati iti ca attani nissitānam cakkhu viññāṇa ādīnam
translated: Ignorance is called “unfounding that finds” because it is a special condition for kamma that leads to an unhappy destiny. And it is called “founding that does not find” because it is not a special condition for kamma that leads to a happy destiny.

original: pavattanaṃ uppādanaṃ āyatanaṃ. Sammohabhāveneva anabhisamayabhūtattā aviditaṃ aññātaṃ
analyzed: pavattanam uppādanam āyatanam sammoha bhāvena iva an abhisamaya bhūta ttā aviditam aññātam
translated: A sense base is a place for the occurrence, the arising, of eye-consciousness, etc., that are dependent on oneself. It makes them unknowable, uncomprehended, by mere delusion, because it is not a state of comprehension.

original: karoti. Antavirahite javāpetīti ca vaṇṇāgamavipariyāyavikāravināsadhātuatthavisesayogehi
analyzed: karoti anta virahite ca vaṇṇa āgama vipariyāya vikāra vināsa dhātu attha visesa yogehi
translated: It hurries them on to the endless, is what is said. And it is said to be a condition for the arising of the various kinds of materiality, etc., in the sense of the special meaning of the word “element” as “change,” “alteration,” and “disappearance” in the opposite sense to that of “appearance.”

original: pañcavidhassa niruttilakkhaṇassa vasena tīsupi padesu a-kāra vi-kāra ja-kāre gahetvā
analyzed: pañcavidhassa nirutti lakkhaṇassa vasena tīsu pi padesu akāra vikāra jakāre gahetvā
translated: The word “avijjā” is stated by taking the a-kāra, the vi-kāra, and the ja-kāra in the three parts,

original: aññesaṃ vaṇṇānaṃ lopaṃ katvā ja-kārassa ca dutiyassa āgamaṃ katvā “avijjā”ti vuttā.
analyzed: aññesam vaṇṇānam lopam katvā jakārassa ca dutiyassa āgamam katvā avijjā ati vuttā
translated: and by omitting the other phonemes and adding a second ja-kāra.

original: Byañjanatthaṃ dassetvā sabhāvatthaṃ dassetuṃ “apicā”tiādimāha. Cakkhuviññāṇādīnaṃ
analyzed: byañjana attham dassetvā sabhāva ttham dassetum api ca iti ādim āha cakkhu viññāṇa ādīnam
translated: Having shown the meaning of the phonemes, he says “Moreover” in order to show the meaning of the nature. The bases and objects of eye-consciousness, etc.,

original: vatthārammaṇāni “idaṃ vatthu, idamārammaṇa”nti avijjāya ñātuṃ na sakkāti avijjā tappaṭicchādikā🔽vuttā. Vatthārammaṇasabhāvacchādanato eva avijjādīnaṃ paṭiccasamuppādabhāvassa, jarāmaraṇādīnaṃ
analyzed: vattha ārammaṇāni idam vatthu idam ārammaṇan ti avijjāya ñātum na sakkā ati avijjā tad paṭicchādikā  vuttā vattha ārammaṇa sabhā vacchādanataḥ eva avijjā ādīnam paṭiccasamuppāda bhāvassa jarā maraṇa ādīnam
translated: cannot be known by ignorance as “This is the base, this is the object,” so ignorance is said to be their concealer.🔽Because it conceals the nature of the bases and objects, the concealment of dependent origination and of what is originated dependently should be understood as follows: because it conceals the fact that ignorance, etc., are dependent origination, and that aging-death, etc.,

original: paṭiccasamuppannabhāvassa ca chādanato paṭiccasamuppādapaṭiccasamuppannachādanaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: paṭicca samuppanna bhāvassa ca chādanataḥ paṭicca samuppāda paṭicca samuppanna chādanam veditabbam
translated: are originated dependently.

original: Saṅkhāra-saddaggahaṇena āgatā saṅkhārā saṅkhāra-saddena āgatasaṅkhārā. Yadipi avijjāpaccayā
analyzed: saṅkhāra sadda ggahaṇena āgatā saṅkhārā saṅkhāra saddena āgata saṅkhārā yadi api avijjā paccayā
translated: The formations that are included by the word “formations” are the formations that are included by the word “formations.” Although they are conditioned by ignorance,

original: saṅkhārāpi saṅkhāra-saddena āgatā, te pana imissā desanāya padhānāti visuṃ vuttā.
analyzed: saṅkhārā api saṅkhāra saddena āgatā te pana imissā desanāya padhānā ati visum vuttā
translated: Formations have also come in with the word “formations,” but they are mentioned separately here because they are the principal thing in this teaching.

original: Tasmā “duvidhā”ti ettha abhisaṅkharaṇakasaṅkhāraṃ saṅkhāra-saddenāgataṃ sandhāya🔽tattha vuttampi vajjetvā saṅkhārasaddena āgatasaṅkhārā yojetabbā. “Saṅkhāra-saddenāgatasaṅkhārā”ti
analyzed: tasmāt ettha abhisaṅkharaṇaka saṅkhāram saṅkhāra saddena āgatam sandhāya  tattha vuttam pi vajjetvā saṅkhāra saddena āgata saṅkhārā yojetabbā saṅkhāra saddena āgata saṅkhārā ati
translated: So in the passage “of two kinds” the “formations” that have come in with the word “formations” are the “formations consisting of determinations.”

original: vā samudāyo vutto, tadekadeso ca idha vaṇṇitabbabhāvena “avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārā”ti,
analyzed: vā samudāyaḥ vuttaḥ tad eka deso ca idha vaṇṇitabba bhāvena avijjā paccayā saṅkhārā ti
translated: But the “formations that have come in with the word ‘formations’” are a collection, and the “formations consisting of ignorance” are a part of that collection, and it is they that are to be expounded here.🔽So it should be understood that the twofoldness is stated in order to include all the formations that are to be expounded.

original: tasmā vaṇṇitabbasabbasaṅgahaṇavasena duvidhatā vuttāti veditabbā. Paṭhamaṃ nirujjhati
analyzed: tasmā vaṇṇitabba sabba saṅgahaṇa vasena duvidha tā vuttā iti veditabbā paṭhamam nirujjhati
translated: The first to cease

original: vacīsaṅkhārotiādinā vitakkavicāraassāsapassāsasaññāvedanāvacīsaṅkhārādayo vuttā,
analyzed: vacī saṅkhāraḥ ti ādinā vitakka vicāra assāsa passāsa saññā vedanā vacī saṅkhāra ādayaḥ vuttā
translated: The “verbal formations” and so on are stated in the passage beginning, “Thinking and exploring are a condition, as condition consisting of decisive support, for the in-breath and out-breath” ,

original: na avijjāsaṅkhāresu vuttā kāyasañcetanādayo.
analyzed: na avijjā saṅkhāresu vuttā kāya sañcetanā ādayaḥ
translated: and not the “bodily intimation” and so on stated in the passage beginning, “With ignorance as condition there are formations” .

original: Paritassatīti pipāsati. Bhavatīti upapattibhavaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ, bhāvayatīti kammabhavaṃ.
analyzed: paritassati iti pipāsati bhavati iti upapatti bhavam sandhāya vuttam bhāvayati iti kamma bhavam
translated: “Is anxious” : is thirsty. “Comes to be” is said with reference to rebirth-process becoming; “develops” is said with reference to kamma-process becoming.

original: Cuti khandhānaṃ maraṇanti “maranti etenā”ti vuttaṃ. “Dukkhā vedanā uppādadukkhā ṭhitidukkhā”ti🔽vacanato dvedhā khaṇati. Āyāsoti parissamo visādo. Kevala-saddo asammissavācako hoti
analyzed: cuti khandhānam maraṇanti maranti etena ati vuttam dukkhā vedanā uppāda dukkhā ṭhiti dukkhā  vacanataḥ dvedhā āyāsaḥ ti parissamaḥ visādaḥ kevala saddo a sammissa vācakaḥ hoti
translated: Because of the words, “Painful feeling is painful in arising and painful in presence” , it is twofold in instant and in continuity.

original: “kevalā sālayo”ti, niravasesavācako ca “kevalā aṅgamagadhā”ti, tasmā dvedhāpi atthaṃ
analyzed: kevalā ca kevalā tasmā dvedhā api attham
translated: The word “only” is used in the sense of “unmixed” as in the passage, “Only sāli rice” , and in the sense of “entire” as in the passage, “The entire Anga country” .

original: vadati. Tattha asammissassāti sukharahitassa. Na hi ettha kiñci uppādavayarahitaṃ atthīti.
analyzed: vadati tattha asammissassa ati sukha rahitassa na hi ettha kiñci uppāda vaya rahitam atthi iti
translated: So it has two meanings here. Herein, unmixed means devoid of pleasure, for there is nothing here devoid of arising and falling away.🔽It has the taste of deluding what is associated with it or a person,

original: Taṃsampayutte, puggalaṃ vā sammohayatīti sammohanarasā. Ārammaṇasabhāvassa chādanaṃ
analyzed: tad sampayutte puggalam vā sammohayati iti sammohana rasāḥ ārammaṇa sabhāvassa chādanam
translated: It has the manifestation of concealing by covering up the individual essence of an object.

original: hutvā gayhatīti chādanapaccupaṭṭhānā. “Āsavasamudayā avijjāsamudayo”ti vacanato āsavapadaṭṭhānā.
analyzed: hutvā gayhati iti chādana paccupaṭṭhānā āsava samudayā avijjā samudayo ti vacanataḥ āsava padaṭṭhānā
translated: It has the asavas as its proximate cause, according to the passage, “With the arising of the asavas there is the arising of ignorance” .

original: Paṭisandhijananatthaṃ āyūhanti byāpāraṃ karontīti āyūhanarasā, rāsikaraṇaṃ vā āyūhanaṃ.
analyzed: paṭisandhi janana attham āyūhanti byāpāram karonti iti āyūhana rasāḥ rāsi karaṇam vā āyūhanam
translated: It has the function of accumulating, that is, of making an accumulation, since it accumulates for the purpose of rebirth.

original: Nāmarūpassa purecārikabhāvena pavattatīti pubbaṅgamarasaṃ. Purimabhavena saddhiṃ🔽ghaṭanaṃ hutvā gayhatīti paṭisandhipaccupaṭṭhānaṃ. Viññāṇena saha sampayujjatīti🔽sampayogarasaṃ. Aññamaññaṃ sampayogābhāvato rūpaṃ vikiratīti vikiraṇarasaṃ. Evañca🔽katvā pisiyamānā taṇḍulādayo vikiranti cuṇṇī bhavantīti. Nāmassa kadāci kusalādibhāvo🔽ca atthīti tato visesanatthaṃ “abyākatapaccupaṭṭhāna”nti āha. “Acetanā abyākatā”ti🔽ettha viya anārammaṇatā vā abyākatatā daṭṭhabbā. Āyatanalakkhaṇanti ghaṭanalakkhaṇaṃ,
analyzed: nāma rūpassa purecārika bhāvena pavattati iti pubbaṅgama rasam purima bhavena saddhim  ghaṭanam hutvā gayhati iti paṭisandhi paccupaṭṭhānam viññāṇena saha sampayujjati iti  sampayoga rasam aññam aññam sampayoga abhāvataḥ rūpam vikirati iti vikiraṇa rasam evam ca  katvā pisiyamānā taṇḍula ādayaḥ vikiranti cuṇṇī bhavanti iti nāmassa kadāci kusala ādi bhāvaḥ  ca atthi iti tatas visesana attham abyākata paccupaṭṭhānan ti āha acetanā abyākatā ti  ettha viya anārammaṇa tā vā abyākata tā daṭṭhabbā āyatana lakkhaṇam ti ghaṭana lakkhaṇam
translated: It occurs as the forerunner of mentality-materiality, thus it has the function of a forerunner. It is apprehended as the conjunction with the previous becoming, thus it has the function of conjunction. It is associated with consciousness, thus it has the function of association. It scatters the materiality because of the absence of mutual association, thus it has the function of scattering. And in this way, when rice, etc., are being ground, they scatter and become fine. And since mentality sometimes has the nature of the wholesome, etc.,🔽the expression “with the inoperative as its object” is used in order to distinguish it. As in the case of the expression “inert and inoperative” , the meaning of “inoperative” should be understood here as the absence of an object. The characteristic of the sense bases is the characteristic of conjunction.

original: āyānaṃ tananalakkhaṇaṃ vā. Dassanādīnaṃ kāraṇabhāvo dassanādirasatā. Akusalavipākupekkhāya🔽aniṭṭhabhāvato dukkhena itarāya ca iṭṭhabhāvato sukhena saṅgahitattā “sukhadukkhapaccupaṭṭhānā”ti
analyzed: āyānam tanana lakkhaṇam vā dassana ādīnam kāraṇa bhāvaḥ dassana ādi rasa tā akusala vipāka upekkhāya 🔽aniṭṭha bhāvataḥ dukkhena itarāya ca iṭṭha bhāvataḥ sukhena saṅgahita ttā sukha dukkha paccupaṭṭhānā ati
translated: It occurs as the forerunner of mentality-materiality, thus it has the function of a forerunner. It is apprehended as being in conjunction with the prior existence, thus it has the function of conjunction. It is associated with consciousness, thus it has the function of association. It scatters materiality, thus it has the function of scattering. And in this way, when rice, etc., are being ground, they scatter and become fine. And since there is also a profitable, etc., state of mentality, he says, “Its mode of appearance is indeterminate,” in order to distinguish it. As in the case of the words, “The insentient is indeterminate” , so here too the indeterminateness should be understood as the absence of an object. The characteristic of the sense bases is the characteristic of the act of generation, or the characteristic of the generation of the sense bases. The function of seeing, etc., is the state of being the cause of seeing, etc. The appearance of the resultant equanimity that is unprofitable is as painful because of its unattractiveness, and as pleasant because of its attractiveness. Thus it is said that it has the appearance of pleasure and pain.

original: āha. Dukkhasamudayattā hetulakkhaṇā taṇhā. “Tatratatrābhinandinī”ti vacanato abhinandanarasā.
analyzed: āha dukkha samudaya ttā hetu lakkhaṇā taṇhā tatra tatra abhinandinī iti vacanataḥ abhinandana rasā
translated: Craving has the characteristic of being the source of suffering, since it is the source of suffering. Its function is to delight, since it is said, “Delighting and greedying for here and there” .

original: Cittassa, puggalassa vā rūpādīsu atittabhāvo hutvā gayhatīti atittabhāvapaccupaṭṭhānā.
analyzed: cittassa puggalassa vā rūpa ādīsu a titta bhāvaḥ hutvā gayhati iti a titta bhāva paccupaṭṭhānā
translated: It is manifested as over-indulgence, since it over-indulges in visible forms, etc., in the sense of exceeding the right measure in the mind or in a person.

original: Taṇhādaḷhattaṃ hutvā kāmupādānaṃ, sesāni diṭṭhi hutvā upaṭṭhahantīti taṇhādaḷhattadiṭṭhipaccupaṭṭhānā.
analyzed: taṇhā daḷhattam hutvā kāma upādānam sesāni diṭṭhi hutvā upaṭṭhahanti iti taṇhā daḷhatta diṭṭhi paccupaṭṭhānā
translated: It is manifested as the over-indulgence in craving and views, since craving is manifested as the over-indulgence in craving, and the other three are manifested as the over-indulgence in views.

original: Kammupapattibhavavasena bhavassa lakkhaṇādayo yojetabbā.🔽Ādi-saddena anubodhādibhāvaggahaṇaṃ. Dukkhādīsu aññāṇaṃ appaṭipatti, asubhādīsu subhādivipallāsā
analyzed: kamma upapatti bhava vasena bhavassa lakkhaṇa ādayaḥ yojetabbā  ādi saddena anubodha ādi bhāva ggahaṇam dukkha ādīsu aññāṇam appaṭipatti asubha ādīsu subha ādi vipallāsā
translated: The characteristic, etc., of becoming should be construed in the same way as those of suffering.

original: micchāpaṭipatti. Diṭṭhivippayuttā vā appaṭipatti, diṭṭhisampayuttā micchāpaṭipatti.
analyzed: micchā paṭipatti diṭṭhi vippayuttā vā appaṭipatti diṭṭhi sampayuttā micchā paṭipatti
translated: The word “etc.” includes the states of being understood, etc. Non-penetration of suffering, etc., is non-comprehension; non-practice of the unlovely, etc., is wrong practice. Or non-practice is non-comprehension of the unlovely, etc., and wrong practice is comprehension by wrong views.

original: Na avijjāya eva chadvārikatā chaḷārammaṇatā ca, atha kho aññesupi paṭiccasamuppādaṅgesu
analyzed: na avijjāya eva cha dvārika tā chaṭṭha ārammaṇa tā ca atha kho aññesu pi paṭiccasamuppāda aṅgesu
translated: The fourfold and sixfold classification is not only of ignorance, but also of the other factors of dependent origination.

original: arūpadhammānanti āha “sabbesupī”ti. Nobhayagocaranti manāyatanamāha. Na hi arūpadhammānaṃ
analyzed: arūpa dhammānam ti āha sabbesu pi iti na ubhaya gocaram iti mana āyatanam āha na hi arūpa dhammānam
translated: “Of all” means of all the factors of dependent origination. “Not the domain of both” refers to the mind base, for the formless states are not the domain of the eye and ear.

original: desavasena āsannatā dūratā ca atthi asaṇṭhānattā, tasmā manāyatanassa gocaro na manāyatanaṃ
analyzed: desa vasena āsanna tā dūra tā ca atthi asaṇṭhāna ttā tasmā mana āyatanassa gocaraḥ na mana āyatanam
translated: and there is nearness and farness by way of place, but there is no shape, therefore the object of the mind base is not the mind base.

original: sampatto asampatto vāti vuccatīti.
analyzed: sampattaḥ a sampattaḥ vā ati vuccati iti
translated: There is nearness and farness according to the place, but there is no shape, and so it is said that the object of the mind-base is not reached or is reached.🔽The meaning of the words “in the sense of the condition being fulfilled” should be understood in this way.

original: Sokādīnaṃ sabbhāvā aṅgabahuttappasaṅge “dvādasevā”ti aṅgānaṃ vavatthānaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: soka ādīnam sabbhāvāḥ aṅga bahutta ppasaṅge dvādasa iva āti aṅgānam vavatthānam veditabbam
translated: In the section on the many kinds of conditions, the delimitation of the factors should be understood thus: “Twelve factors.”

original: Na hi sokādayo aṅgabhāvena vuttā, phalena pana kāraṇaṃ avijjaṃ mūlaṅgaṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: na hi soka ādayaḥ aṅga bhāvena vuttā phalena pana kāraṇam avijjam mūlaṅgam dassetuṃ
translated: For sorrow, etc., are not mentioned as factors, but ignorance is mentioned as the root-factor in order to show the condition for the fruit.

original: te vuttāti. Jarāmaraṇabbhāhatassa hi bālassa te sambhavantīti sokādīnaṃ jarāmaraṇakāraṇatā🔽vuttā. “Sārīrikāya dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho”ti ca sutte jarāmaraṇanimittañca dukkhaṃ
analyzed: te vuttā ati jarā maraṇa bbhā hatassa hi bālassa te sambhavanti iti soka ādīnam jarā maraṇa kāraṇa tā  vuttā sārīrikāya dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭhā ti ca sutte jarā maraṇa nimittam ca dukkham
translated: For they arise in the fool who is struck down by aging and death. Thus the conditionality of sorrow, etc., by aging and death is stated.🔽And in the sutta “he is touched by bodily painful feeling” , suffering is included as the cause of sorrow, etc.,

original: saṅgahitanti taṃtaṃnimittānaṃ sādhakabhāvena vuttaṃ. Yasmā pana jarāmaraṇeneva sokādīnaṃ
analyzed: saṅgahitam iti sādhaka bhāvena vuttam yasmā pana jarā maraṇena iva soka ādīnam
translated: and it is stated as the condition for sorrow, etc., by the words “because of that.” But since sorrow, etc., are included in aging and death,

original: ekasaṅkhepo kato, tasmā tesaṃ jātipaccayatā yujjati. Jarāmaraṇapaccayabhāve hi avijjāya
analyzed: eka saṅkhepo kato tasmā tesam jāti paccaya tā yujjati jarā maraṇa paccaya bhāve hi avijjāya
translated: the conditionality of sorrow, etc., by birth is proper. For if ignorance were a condition for aging and death,

original: ekasaṅkhepo kātabbo siyā, jātipaccayā pana jarāmaraṇaṃ sokādayo ca sambhavantīti.
analyzed: eka saṅkhepaḥ kātabbo siyā jāti paccayā pana jarā maraṇam soka ādayo ca sambhavanti iti
translated: and it can be reduced to one, namely, birth, since aging-and-death, sorrow, etc., come about with birth as condition.

original: Tattha jarāmaraṇaṃ ekantikaṃ aṅgabhāveneva gahitaṃ, sokādayo pana rūpabhavādīsu abhāvato🔽anekantikā kevalaṃ pākaṭena phalena avijjānidassanatthaṃ gahitā. Tena anāgate jātiyā
analyzed: tattha jarā maraṇam ekantikam aṅga bhāvena iva gahitam soka ādayaḥ pana rūpa bhava ādīsu abhāvataḥ  anekantikā kevalam pākaṭena phalena avijjā nidassana attham gahitā tena anāgate jātiyā
translated: Herein, aging-and-death is single in the sense of being a part, while sorrow, etc., are multiple since they are not found in the case of materiality, becoming, etc.🔽They are included only as the obvious fruit in order to show ignorance. Thus it is shown that when there is future birth

original: sati tato parāya paṭisandhiyā hetuhetubhūtā avijjā dassitāti bhavacakkassa avicchedo
analyzed: sati tato parāya paṭisandhiyā hetu hetu bhūtā avijjā dassitā ati bhava cakkassa avicchedaḥ
translated: there is ignorance, which is the cause of the rebirth-linking in the next becoming, and so the continuity of the round of rebirths is shown.

original: dassito hotīti. Suttañca sokādīnaṃ avijjā kāraṇanti etassevatthassa sādhakaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ,
analyzed: dassitaḥ hoti iti suttam ca soka ādīnam avijjā kāraṇam ti etassa iva atthassa sādhakam daṭṭhabbaṃ
translated: And the sutta passage quoted should be taken as establishing that ignorance is the cause of sorrow, etc.,

original: na sokādīnaṃ bālassa jarāmaraṇanimittatāmattassa. “Assutavā puthujjano”ti hi vacanena
analyzed: na soka ādīnam bālassa jarā maraṇa nimitta tā mattassa assutavā puthujjanaḥ iti hi vacanena
translated: and not as establishing that sorrow, etc., are the suffering due to aging-and-death of the fool. For by the words “The uninstructed worldling”

original: avijjā sokādīnaṃ kāraṇanti dassitā, na ca jarāmaraṇanimittameva dukkhaṃ dukkhanti.🔽Uddesavāravaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽Avijjāpadaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: avijjā soka ādīnam kāraṇanti dassitā na ca jarā maraṇa nimittam eva dukkham dukkhanti 🔽uddesa vāra vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā 🔽avijjā pada niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: it is shown that ignorance is the cause of sorrow, etc., and not that suffering is only the suffering due to aging-and-death.

original: 226. “Avijjāpaccayā 92 saṅkhārā”ti hi vuttanti etena avijjāya visesanabhāvena saṅkhārānañca
analyzed: avijjā paccayā saṅkhārā ti hi vuttanti etena avijjāya visesana bhāvena
translated: “With ignorance as condition there are formations” : by this it is shown that formations are distinguished by ignorance as their condition.

original: padhānabhāvena vuttattā saṅkhārānaṃ niddisitabbabhāvassa kāraṇaṃ dasseti. Pitā kathīyati
analyzed: padhāna bhāvena vutta ttā saṅkhārānam niddisitabba bhāvassa kāraṇam dasseti pitā kathīyati
translated: “With the words ‘With ignorance as condition there are formations’ … he shows the reason why formations can be demonstrated, since ignorance is stated as a distinguishing factor and formations as the principal factor. A father is called ‘long’

original: “dīgho sāmo, mitto rasso, odāto datto”ti.🔽Rasitabbo paṭivijjhitabbo sabhāvo raso, attano raso saraso, yāthāvo saraso yāthāvasaraso,🔽so eva lakkhitabbattā lakkhaṇanti yāthāvasarasalakkhaṇaṃ. “Katamā ca, bhikkhave,
analyzed: dīghaḥ sāmaḥ mittaḥ rassaḥ o dātaḥ dattaḥ iti  rasitabbaḥ paṭivijjhitabbaḥ sabhāvaḥ rasaḥ attanaḥ rasaḥ sarasaḥ yāthāvaḥ sarasaḥ yāthāva sarasaḥ  saḥ eva lakkhitabba ttā lakkhaṇanti yāthāvasa rasa lakkhaṇam katamā ca bhikkhave
translated: and ‘short,’ ‘friend’ and ‘thin,’ ‘white’ and ‘given.’

original: avijjā? Dukkhe aññāṇa”ntiādinā sutte cattāreva vuttānīti “suttantikapariyāyenā”ti
analyzed: avijjā dukkhe aññāṇa nti ādinā sutte cattāreva vuttāni iti suttantika pariyāyena ati
translated: The meaning is the individual essence that is to be tasted, penetrated. The meaning of itself is the meaning of self-nature. The meaning of the way things are is the meaning of self-nature as it really is. The meaning of the way things are as they really are is the characteristic of the way things are as they really are. “And what is ignorance, bhikkhus? Not knowing suffering” . Since only four are stated in the sutta in this way, he says “by the method of the suttas.”

original: āha. Nikkhepakaṇḍe panātiādinā idha catūsu ṭhānesu kathitāya eva avijjāya nikkhepakaṇḍe
analyzed: āha nikkhepa kaṇḍe pana ati ādinā idha catūsu ṭhānesu kathitāya eva avijjāya nikkhepa kaṇḍe
translated: But in the section on the exposition, etc. Here, since ignorance is stated in four places, in the section on the exposition,

original: aṭṭhasu ṭhānesu kiccajātito pañcavīsatiyā padehi lakkhaṇato ca kathitattā tadatthasaṃvaṇṇanāvasena
analyzed: aṭṭhasu ṭhānesu kicca jātitaḥ pañcavīsatiyā padehi lakkhaṇato ca kathita ttā tad attha saṃvaṇṇanā vasena
translated: in the section on the analysis, in the section on the summary, and in the section on the question and answer, and since it is stated in eight places by way of function, in twenty-five terms by way of characteristic, and by way of the meaning of the characteristic,

original: vibhāvanaṃ karoti. Ahāpetvā vibhajitabbavibhajanañhi abhidhammapariyāyo.
analyzed: vibhāvanam karoti a hāpetvā vibhajitabba vibhajanam hi abhidhamma pariyāyaḥ
translated: He makes a division. For the division of what should be divided without bringing in is a method of exposition.

original: Jāyati etthāti jāti, uppattiṭṭhānaṃ. Yadipi nirodhamagge avijjā ārammaṇaṃ na karoti,
analyzed: jāyati ettha ati uppatti ṭṭhānam yadi api nirodha magge avijjā ārammaṇam na karoti
translated: Birth is the place of arising. Although ignorance does not take cessation and the path to cessation as its object,

original: te pana jānitukāmassa tappaṭicchādanavasena anirodhamaggesu nirodhamaggaggahaṇakaāraṇavasena
analyzed: te pana jānitu kāmassa tad paṭicchādana vasena anirodha maggesu nirodha magga ggahaṇaka āraṇa vasena
translated: nevertheless it occurs there in the sense of concealing that cessation and the path to cessation, and in the sense of being the cause of apprehending cessation and the path to cessation in the other two cessations.

original: ca pavattamānā tattha uppajjatīti vuccatīti tesampi avijjāya uppattiṭṭhānatā hoti,
analyzed: ca pavattamānā tattha uppajjati iti vuccati iti tesam pi avijjāya uppatti ṭṭhāna tā hoti
translated: So ignorance has the nature of a place of arising in these three cessations too,🔽as well as in the sense of being the object of the other three taints.

original: itaresaṃ ārammaṇabhāvena cāti. Saṅghikabaladevagoṇādīnaṃ saṅghāṭinaṅgalādīni viya
analyzed: itaresam ārammaṇa bhāvena ca ati saṅghika bala deva goṇa ādīnam saṅghāṭi naṅgala ādīni
translated: Like the ploughs and yoking-posts, etc., of the Sangha’s oxen, etc.,

original: aññasetādīnaṃ avijjāya dukkhādivisayānaṃ andhattakarānaṃ lobhādīnaṃ nivattako aññāṇādisabhāvo
analyzed: añña seta ādīnam avijjāya dukkha ādi visayānam lobha ādīnam nivattakaḥ aññāṇa ādi sabhāvaḥ
translated: the nature of ignorance, etc., is the opposite of the nature of the other three taints, which have the characteristic of blindness, etc., in regard to suffering, etc.,

original: lakkhaṇanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: lakkhaṇan ti daṭṭhabbam
translated: which are their objects.

original: Atthatthanti phalaphalaṃ. Āmeḍitavacanañhi sabbesaṃ atthānaṃ visuṃ visuṃ pākaṭakaraṇabhāvappakāsanatthaṃ.
analyzed: attha attham ti phala phalam āmeḍita vacanam hi sabbesam atthānam visum visum pākaṭa karaṇa bhāva ppakāsana tham
translated: The meaning of the meaning is the fruit of the fruit. For the word “meaning” is used in order to show that it makes each of the meanings evident in a special sense.

original: Attho eva vā attho atthatthoti atthassa aviparītatādassanatthaṃ atthenevatthaṃ visesayati.
analyzed: attho eva vā atthaḥ attha ttho ti atthassa aviparīta tā dassana ttham atthena iva attham visesayati
translated: Or else the meaning is the meaning of the meaning, in order to show that the meaning is not misapprehended. He distinguishes the meaning by the meaning itself.

original: Na hi ñāṇaṃ anatthaṃ atthoti gaṇhātīti. Evaṃ kāraṇakāraṇanti etthāpi daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽Taṃ ākāranti atthatthādiākāraṃ. Gahetvāti citte pavesetvā, cittena puggalena vā gahitaṃ
analyzed: na hi ñāṇam anattham gaṇhāti iti evam kāraṇa kāraṇam ti ettha api daṭṭhabbam  tam ākāram ti attha attha ādi ākāram gahetvā ti citte pavesetvā cittena puggalena vā gahitam
translated: For knowledge does not apprehend a non-meaning as a meaning. So too in the case of “cause of the cause.”🔽Having taken up the meaning of the meaning, etc., as the aspect: having taken it up into his mind, having made it apprehended by the mind or by himself as a person.

original: katvā. Paṭividdhassa puna avekkhaṇā paccavekkhaṇā. Duccintitacintitādilakkhaṇassa
analyzed: katvā paṭividdhassa puna avekkhaṇā paccavekkhaṇā duccintita cintita ādi lakkhaṇassa
translated: The reviewing of what has been penetrated is reviewing.

original: bālassa bhāvo bālyaṃ. Pajānātīti pakārehi jānāti. Balavamohanaṃ pamoho. Samantato mohanaṃ sammoho.
analyzed: bālassa bhāvaḥ bālyam pajānāti iti pakārehi jānāti balava mohanam pamohaḥ samantataḥ mohanam sammohaḥ
translated: The state of a fool characterized by bad thoughts, etc., is foolishness. He understands: he knows by means of the aspects. Delusion of strength is infatuation. Delusion all round is confusion.

original: Dukkhārammaṇatāti dukkhārammaṇatāya, yāya vā avijjāya chādentiyā dukkhārammaṇā taṃsampayuttadhammā,
analyzed: dukkha ārammaṇa tā ti dukkha ārammaṇa tāya yāya vā avijjāya chādentiyā dukkha ārammaṇā tad sampayutta dhammā
translated: Because of the painful feeling: because of the painful feeling, or because of the painful feeling-concomitant states that are concealed by ignorance,

original: sā tesaṃ bhāvoti dukkhārammaṇatā, ārammaṇameva vā ārammaṇatā, dukkhaṃ ārammaṇatā
analyzed: sā tesam bhāvaḥ ti dukkha ārammaṇa tā ārammaṇam eva vā ārammaṇa tā dukkham ārammaṇa tā
translated: that is their state, thus it is the painful feeling; or the object is the painful feeling,

original: etissāti dukkhārammaṇatā.
analyzed: etissa ati dukkha ārammaṇa tā
translated: thus it is the painful feeling.

original: Duddasattā gambhīrā na sabhāvato, tasmā tadārammaṇatā avijjā uppajjati, itaresaṃ
analyzed: duddasa ttā gambhīrā na sabhāvataḥ tasmā tad ārammaṇa tā avijjā uppajjati itaresam
translated: It is difficult to see, being deep, not obvious, and not in the domain of reasoning. Therefore ignorance arises in regard to it.

original: sabhāvato gambhīrattā tadārammaṇatā nuppajjatīti adhippāyo. Apica kho panāti maggassa
analyzed: sabhāvataḥ gambhīra ttā tad ārammaṇa tā nuppajjati iti adhippāyaḥ api ca kho pana ati maggassa
translated: It is hard to see because of its profundity in the true nature of things. Therefore ignorance arises in the form of misapprehension of it. But in the case of the other three truths, ignorance does not arise in the form of misapprehension because of their profundity in the true nature of things. This is the intention.

original: saṅkhatasabhāvattā tatopi nirodhassa gambhīratarataṃ dasseti.
analyzed: saṅkhata sabhāva ttā nirodhassa gambhīratara tam dasseti
translated: Moreover, the word “also” shows that cessation is more profound than the path, because the path has a compounded nature.

original: Avijjāpadaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: avijjā pada niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the description of ignorance is finished.

original: Saṅkhārapadaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: saṅkhāra pada niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: Description of the description of formations

original: Punātīti sodheti apuññaphalato dukkhasaṃkilesato ca, hitasukhajjhāsayena puññaṃ karotīti🔽taṃnipphādanena kārakassajjhāsayaṃ pūretīti puñño, pūrako pujjanibbattako ca niruttilakkhaṇena
analyzed: punāti iti sodheti apuñña phalataḥ dukkha saṃkilesataḥ ca hita sukha jjhāsayena puññam karoti iti  tad nipphādanena kārakassa ajjhāsayam pūreti iti puñño pūrako ca nirutti lakkhaṇena
translated: “He purifies” means he purifies by removing the fruit of demerit and the defilement of suffering. He does merit by way of the aspiration for welfare and happiness.🔽By producing that, he fulfills the aspiration of the doer. Therefore it is merit. It should be understood as “merit” by the characteristic of fulfilling and producing worship.

original: “puñño”ti veditabbo. Samādhipaccanīkānaṃ atidūratāya na iñjati na calatīti attho.
analyzed: puññaḥ ti veditabbaḥ samādhi paccanīkānam ati dūra tāya na iñjati na calati iti attho
translated: The meaning is that it does not tremble or waver because of the extreme distance from the opposites of concentration.

original: Kāyassāti dvārassa sāmibhāvena niddeso kato.
analyzed: kāyassa ati dvārassa sāmi bhāvena niddeso kato
translated: “Of the body” is a designation made by way of the body as the owner of the door.

original: Puññupaganti bhavasampattupagaṃ. Tatthāti vibhaṅgasutte. Tañhi padhānabhāvena gahitanti.
analyzed: puñña upaganti bhava sampatta upagam tattha ati vibhaṅga sutte tat hi padhāna bhāvena gahitanti
translated: “The meritorious” is the meritorious that goes to the attainment of existence. “There” is in the Vibhaṅga Sutta. For that is taken by way of its predominance.

original: Sammādiṭṭhisutte pana “tayome, āvuso, saṅkhārā”ti āgatanti. Sabbaññujinabhāsito pana
analyzed: sammādiṭṭhi sutte pana tayo me āvuso saṅkhārāti āgatanti sabbaññu jina bhāsito pana
translated: In the Sammāditthi Sutta, however, they are given as “These three formations” .

original: ayaṃ, na paccekajinabhāsito, imassatthassa dīpanatthaṃ etesaṃ suttānaṃ vasena te
analyzed: ayam na pacceka jina bhāsitaḥ imassa atthassa dīpana attham etesam suttānam vasena te
translated: This is the statement of the Omniscient One, not of a Paccekabuddha. In order to illustrate the meaning of this, they are taken in the way stated in these suttas.

original: gahitā. Kathaṃ panetena gahaṇenāyamattho dīpito hotīti taṃdassanatthamāha “abhidhammepi🔽hi suttepi ekasadisāva tanti niddiṭṭhā”ti. Sabbaññubhāsitoti pākaṭena suttantena
analyzed: gahitā katham pana itena gahaṇena ayam atthaḥ dīpitaḥ hoti iti tad dassana ttham āha abhidhamme pi  hi sutte pi eka sadisā ava tanti niddiṭṭhā ati sabbaññu bhāsito ti pākaṭena suttantena
translated: But how does the meaning become illustrated by this taking? In order to show this, he says: “In the Abhidhamma too,🔽and in the Suttas, they are shown to be the same” .

original: sadisattā ayampi sabbaññubhāsitoti ñāyatīti vuttaṃ hotīti.
analyzed: sadisa ttā ayam pi sabbaññu bhāsito ti ñāyati iti vuttam hoti iti
translated: “The statement of the Omniscient One” : because this is similar to the clear statement of the suttas, it is known that this is also the statement of the Omniscient One.

original: “Terasāpī”ti vuttaṃ, tattha ñāṇavippayuttānaṃ na bhāvanāmayatā pākaṭāti “yathā hī”tiādimāha.
analyzed: terasā api iti vuttam tattha ñāṇa vippayuttānam na bhāvanā maya tā pākaṭā ati yathā hi itiādim āha
translated: “Thirteen” is said. Therein, since the non-conjoined are not evident as being of the nature of development, he says “For example” .

original: Pathavī pathavītiādibhāvanā ca kasiṇaparikammakaraṇaṃ maṇḍalakaraṇañca bhāvanaṃ bhajāpenti.
analyzed: pathavī pathavī iti ādi bhāvanā ca kasiṇa parikamma karaṇam maṇḍala karaṇam ca bhāvanam
translated: And the development of the earth kasiṇa, etc., is the development of the preliminary work of the kasiṇa and the making of the kasiṇa disk.

original: Dānavasena pavattā cittacetasikā dhammā dānaṃ. Tattha byāpārabhūtā āyūhanacetanā
analyzed: dāna vasena pavattā citta cetasikāḥ dhammāḥ dānam tattha byāpāra bhūtā āyūhana cetanā
translated: The mental factors that occur by way of giving are giving. Therein, the volition of accumulation that has become the root of ill will

original: dānaṃ ārabbha dānaṃ adhikicca uppajjatīti vuccati, evaṃ itaresu. Somanassacittenāti
analyzed: dānam ārabbha dānam adhikicca uppajjati iti vuccati evam itaresu somanassa cittena ati
translated: and it is said that “the giving of gifts is a condition for the arising of the happiness of giving gifts.”

original: anumodanāpavattinidassanamattametaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Upekkhāsahagatenapi hi anussarati evāti.
analyzed: anumodanā apavatti nidassana mattam etam daṭṭhabbam upekkhā sahagatena api hi anussarati eva ati
translated: The words “with a mind of happiness” are said merely to show the occurrence of the rejoicing. For one rejoices with a mind accompanied by equanimity too.

original: Asarikkhakampi sarikkhakena catutthajjhānavipākena vehapphalādīsu vināpi asaññesu
analyzed: a sarikkhakam pi sarikkhakena catuttha jhāna vipākena vehapphala ādīsu vinā api asaññesu
translated: Even though it is not equal to the resultant fourth jhāna, it is equal to the resultant fourth jhāna of the Vehapphala and other Brahmas, and to the fine-material sphere jhāna of the immaterial-sphere deities.

original: kaṭattārūpaṃ. Rūpameva saphandanattā “saiñjana”nti vuttaṃ iñjanakaranīvaraṇādīnaṃ
analyzed: kaṭattā rūpam rūpam eva sa phandanattā sa eñjananti vuttam iñjana kara nīvaraṇa ādīnam
translated: The materiality of the fourth jhāna is called “with in-breath and out-breath” because it is associated with in-breath and out-breath.

original: avikkhambhanato, rūpataṇhāsaṅkhātassa iñjanakassa kāraṇattā vā. Teneva rūpārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: avikkhambhanato rūpa taṇhā saṅkhātassa iñjanakassa kāraṇa ttā vā tena iva rūpa ārammaṇam
translated: Because the hindrances, etc., are not suppressed in it, or because it is the cause of the in-breath and out-breath called materiality craving.

original: nimittārammaṇañca sabbampi catutthajjhānaṃ nippariyāyena “aniñjana”nti na vuccatīti.
analyzed: nimitta ārammaṇam ca sabbam pi catuttha jhānam nippariyāyena aniñjanan ti na vuccati iti
translated: Therefore the fourth jhāna with materiality as its object and with a sign as its object is not called “without in-breath and out-breath” in the ultimate sense.

original: Mahātulāya dhārayamāno nāḷiyā minamāno ca samudāyameva dhāreti minati ca, na ekekaṃ
analyzed: mahā tulāya dhārayamānaḥ nāḷiyā minamānaḥ ca samudāyam eva dhāra iti minati ca na ekekam
translated: When a man weighs or measures a collection of beans or a collection of rice in a basket, he weighs or measures the collection, not each individual bean or grain of rice.

original: guñjaṃ, ekekaṃ taṇḍulaṃ vā, evaṃ bhagavāpi aparimāṇā paṭhamakusalacetanāyo samudāyavaseneva
analyzed: guñjam ekekam taṇḍulam vā evam bhagavā api aparimāṇā samudāya vasena iva
translated: So too, the Blessed One, in the ultimate sense, does not say that the first wholesome volition is “without in-breath and out-breath” in the ultimate sense.

original: gahetvā ekajātikattā ekameva katvā dasseti. Evaṃ dutiyādayopīti.
analyzed: gahetvā eka jātika tā ekam eva katvā dasseti evam dutiya ādayaḥ api iti
translated: and having done so, he shows them as one by the unity of their species. So too with the second and the rest.

original: “Kāyadvāre pavattā”ti avatvā “ādānaggahaṇacopanaṃ pāpayamānā uppannā”tipi vattuṃ🔽vaṭṭatīti vacanavisesamattameva dasseti. Kāyadvāre pavatti eva hi ādānādipāpanāti.
analyzed: kāya dvāre pavattā ati avatvā ādāna ggahaṇa copanam pāpayamānā uppannā iti pi vattum  vaṭṭati iti vacana visesa mattam eva dasseti kāya dvāre pavatti eva hi ādāna ādi pāpanā ti
translated: Instead of saying “arisen in the mind door” he could have said “arisen in the mind door, taking up, grasping, and impelling the associated states” .🔽So he shows only a difference in the wording. For it is only in the mind door that there is taking up, etc.,

original: Purimena vā dvārassa upalakkhaṇabhāvo vutto, pacchimena cetanāya saviññattirūpasamuṭṭhāpanaṃ.
analyzed: purimena vā dvārassa upalakkhaṇa bhāvaḥ vutto pacchimena cetanāya sa viññatti rūpa samuṭṭhāpanam
translated: Or the former phrase shows the door as a characteristic of the consciousness, while the latter shows the instigation of the associated states by the volition.

original: Tattha ākaḍḍhitvā gahaṇaṃ ādānaṃ, sampayuttassa gahaṇaṃ gahaṇaṃ, phandanaṃ copanaṃ.
analyzed: tattha ākaḍḍhitvā gahaṇam ādānam sampayuttassa gahaṇam gahaṇam phandanam copanam
translated: Herein, taking up by drawing in is taking up; grasping is grasping the associated states; impelling is impelling the associated states.

original: Etthāti kāyavacīsaṅkhāraggahaṇe, kāyavacīsañcetanāgahaṇe vā. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ abhiññācetanā🔽na gahitā viññāṇassa paccayo na hotīti. Kasmā pana na hoti, nanu sāpi kusalā vipākadhammā
analyzed: ettha ati kāya vacī saṅkhāra ggahaṇe kāya vacī sañcetanā gahaṇe vā aṭṭhakathā ayam abhiññā cetanā  na gahitā viññāṇassa paccayaḥ na hoti iti kasmā pana na hoti nanu sā api kusalā vipāka dhammā
translated: Herein means in the taking up of the bodily and verbal formations, or in the taking up of the bodily and verbal inceptives. In the commentary the inceptive of direct-knowledge🔽is not taken, because it is not a condition for consciousness. But why is it not a condition? Is it not also profitable and a state of resultant nature?

original: cāti? Saccaṃ, anupacchinnataṇhāvijjāmāne pana santāne sabyāpārappavattiyā tassā kusalatā
analyzed: ca ati saccam anupacchinna taṇhā vijjāmāne pana santāne sa byāpāra ppavattiyā tassā kusala tā
translated: It is so, but in a continuity in which craving and ignorance are unbroken, it is unprofitable because it occurs with hate.

original: vipākadhammatā ca vuttā, na vipākuppādanena, sā pana vipākaṃ uppādayantī rūpāvacarameva
analyzed: vipāka dhamma tā ca vuttā na vipāka uppādanena sā pana vipākam uppādayantī rūpāvacaram eva
translated: and it is said to be a state of ripening, not that it produces ripening. But if it produced ripening, it would produce only that of the fine-material sphere,

original: uppādeyya. Na hi aññabhūmikaṃ kammaṃ aññabhūmikaṃ vipākaṃ uppādetīti. Attanā sadisārammaṇañca🔽tiṭṭhānikaṃ taṃ uppādeyya cittuppādakaṇḍe rūpāvacaravipākassa kammasadisārammaṇasseva
analyzed: uppādeyya na hi añña bhūmikam kammam añña bhūmikam vipākam uppādeti iti attanā sadisa ārammaṇam ca  tiṭṭhānikam tam uppādeyya citta uppāda kaṇḍe rūpāvacara vipākassa kamma sadisa ārammaṇassa iva
translated: for an action of one plane does not produce ripening of another plane. And it would produce an object similar to itself,

original: vuttattā, na ca rūpāvacaravipāko parittādiārammaṇo atthi, abhiññācetanā ca parittādiārammaṇāva
analyzed: vutta ttā na ca rūpāvacara vipāko paritta ādi ārammaṇaḥ atthi abhiññā cetanā ca paritta ādi ārammaṇā ava
translated: for it is said in the “Description of Consciousness” that the object of fine-material-sphere resultant consciousness is similar to that of the action that produces it. But there is no fine-material-sphere resultant consciousness that has a limited, etc., object. And the volition of direct-knowledge has a limited, etc., object.

original: hoti, tasmā vipākaṃ na uppādetīti viññāyati. Kasiṇesu ca uppāditassa catutthajjhānasamādhissa
analyzed: hoti tasmā vipākam na uppādeti iti viññāyati kasiṇesu ca uppāditassa catuttha jhāna samādhissa
translated: Therefore it is understood that it does not produce ripening. And the direct-knowledges are the fruit of the concentration arisen in the kasiṇas,

original: ānisaṃsabhūtā abhiññā. Yathāha “so evaṃ samāhite citte”tiādi. Tasmā samādhiphalasadisā
analyzed: ānisaṃsa bhūtā abhiññā yathā āha saḥ evam samāhite citta itiādi samādhi phala sadisā
translated: for it is said, “When his concentrated mind” , etc. So it is similar to the fruit of concentration. But it does not produce ripening,

original: sā, na ca phalaṃ detīti dānasīlānisaṃso tasmiṃ bhave paccayalābho viya sāpi vipākaṃ
analyzed: sā na ca phalam deti iti tasmin bhave paccaya lābhaḥ sā api vipākam
translated: just as the gain of requisites, etc., is the fruit of virtue and giving in that existence.

original: na uppādeti. Yathā ca abhiññācetanā, evaṃ uddhaccacetanāpi na hotīti idaṃ uddhaccasahagate
analyzed: na uppāde iti yathā ca abhiññā cetanā evam uddhacca cetanā api na hoti iti idam uddhacca sahagate
translated: and he does not generate it. And just as with the intention of direct-knowledge, so also with the intention of agitation.

original: dhamme visuṃ uddharitvā “tesaṃ vipāke ñāṇaṃ atthapaṭisambhidā”ti vuttattā vicāretabbaṃ.🔽Ayaṃ panettha amataggapathānugato vinicchayo – dassanabhāvanānaṃ abhāvepi yesaṃ puthujjanānaṃ
analyzed: dhamme visum uddharitvā tesam vipāke ñāṇam attha paṭisambhidā ti vutta ttā vicāretabbam  ayam pana ittha amata gga patha anugataḥ vinicchayaḥ dassana bhāvanānam abhāve pi yesam puthujjanānam
translated: This should be investigated in the way stated in the Paṭisambhidā, “Knowledge of the result of these is the discernment of meaning” .🔽But the following exposition is in accordance with the method of the Abhidhamma:

original: sekkhānañca dassanabhāvanāhi bhavitabbaṃ, tesaṃ taduppattikāle tehi pahātuṃ sakkuṇeyyā🔽akusalā “dassanena pahātabbā bhāvanāya pahātabbā”ti ca vuccanti, puthujjanānaṃ pana🔽bhāvanāya abhāvā bhāvanāya pahātabbacintā natthi. Tena tesaṃ pavattamānā te dassanena
analyzed: sekkhānam ca dassana bhāvanāhi bhavitabbam tesam tad uppatti kāle tehi pahātum sakkuṇeyyā  akusalāḥ dassanena pahātabbāḥ bhāvanāya pahātabbā ati ca vuccanti puthujjanānam pana  bhāvanāya abhāvāḥ bhāvanāya pahātabba cintā natthi tena tesam pavattamānā te dassanena
translated: Even though some ordinary men and some disciples in training do not have insight and development, still, when they arise in a future existence, they are able to abandon the unwholesome states that should be abandoned by insight and by development.🔽But the unwholesome states that arise in ordinary men who do not have development are not called “to be abandoned by development” because they cannot be abandoned by development.🔽Therefore, although they occur in ordinary men who cannot abandon them by insight, they are not called “to be abandoned by insight.”

original: pahātuṃ asakkuṇeyyāpi “bhāvanāya pahātabbā”ti na vuccanti. Yadi vucceyyuṃ, dassanena
analyzed: pahātum a sakkuṇeyyā api bhāvanāya pahātabbā ati na vuccanti yadi vucceyyum dassanena
translated: If they were called that, then the unwholesome states that occur in ordinary men who cannot abandon them by development would have to be called “to be abandoned by development.”

original: pahātabbā bhāvanāya pahātabbānaṃ kesañci keci kadāci ārammaṇārammaṇādhipatiupanissayapaccayehi🔽paccayo bhaveyyuṃ, na ca paṭṭhāne “dassanena pahātabbā bhāvanāya pahātabbānaṃ kesañci
analyzed: pahātabbāḥ bhāvanāya pahātabbānam kesañci keci kadāci ārammaṇa ārammaṇa adhipati upanissaya paccayehi  paccayaḥ bhaveyyum na ca paṭṭhāne dassanena pahātabbāḥ bhāvanāya pahātabbānam kesañci
translated: They might be conditions for some of those to be abandoned by development as object condition, object-domain condition, predominance condition, and proximity condition,

original: kenaci paccayena paccayo”ti vuttā. Sekkhānaṃ pana vijjamānā bhāvanāya pahātuṃ sakkuṇeyyā
analyzed: kenaci paccayena paccayaḥ ti vuttā sekkhānam pana vijjamānā bhāvanāya pahātum sakkuṇeyyā
translated: but they are not stated in the Paṭṭhāna thus: ‘Those to be abandoned by insight are a condition, by way of … condition, for some to be abandoned by development.’

original: bhāvanāya pahātabbā. Teneva sekkhānaṃ dassanena pahātabbā cattattā vantattā muttattā🔽pahīnattā paṭinissaṭṭhattā ukkheṭitattā samukkheṭitattā assāditabbā abhinanditabbā
analyzed: bhāvanāya pahātabbā tena iva sekkhānam dassanena pahātabbā catta ttā vanta ttā mutta ttā  pahīna ttā paṭinissaṭṭha ttā ukkheṭita ttā samukkheṭita ttā assāditabbā abhinanditabbā
translated: But those to be abandoned by development are found among the trainers, and they can be abandoned by development.🔽Therefore they are not to be abandoned by insight.🔽They are not to be relished, rejoiced in,

original: ca na honti, pahīnatāya eva somanassahetubhūtā avikkhepahetubhūtā ca na domanassaṃ
analyzed: ca na honti pahīna tāya eva somanassa hetu bhūtā avikkhepa hetu bhūtā ca na domanassam
translated: or delighted in because they have been abandoned, and they do not arouse sorrow and agitation because they have been abandoned.

original: uddhaccañca uppādentīti na te tesaṃ ārammaṇārammaṇādhipatibhāvaṃ pakatūpanissayabhāvañca
analyzed: uddhaccam ca uppādenti iti na te tesam ārammaṇa ārammaṇa adhipati bhāvam pakatūpanissaya bhāvañca
translated: They do not become object-domain condition, predominance condition, or natural condition for those to be abandoned by insight,

original: gacchanti. Na hi pahīne upanissāya ariyo rāgādikilese uppādeti.
analyzed: gacchanti na hi pahīne upanissāya ariyaḥ rāga ādi kilese uppādeti
translated: for the noble disciple does not arouse defilements such as lust by taking his stand on what has been abandoned.

original: Vuttañca “sotāpattimaggena ye kilesā pahīnā, te kilese na puneti na pacceti na paccāgacchati…pe…
analyzed: vuttam ca sotāpatti maggena ye kilesā pahīnā te kilese na puneti na pacceti na paccāgacchati pe
translated: And it is said: “The defilements that are abandoned by the path of stream-entry are not re-abandoned, not re-entered into, not re-approached …
