original: sahajātanissayapurejātaindriyādinā ekantena saḷāyatanassa pavattamānassa paccayabhāvaṃ🔽sandhāya vuttaṃ. Rūpāyatanādīnaṃ pana sahajātanissayānupālanabhāvo natthīti aggahaṇaṃ
analyzed: sahajāta nissaya purejāta aindriya ādinā ekantena saḷāyatanassa pavattamānassa paccaya bhāvam  sandhāya vuttam rūpa āyatana ādīnam pana sahajāta nissaya anupālana bhāvaḥ natthi iti aggahaṇam
translated: “As a rule” is said with reference to the fact that the sixfold base, as it occurs, is invariably a condition for the four great primaries, the sixfold base itself, and life, in the various ways of conascence, support, prenascence, faculty, etc.,🔽but that the base consisting of form, etc., are not conascent, supporting, or maintaining conditions for the sixfold base, and so they are not mentioned.

original: veditabbaṃ. Ārammaṇārammaṇapurejātādibhāvo ca tesaṃ na santatipariyāpannānameva,
analyzed: veditabbam ārammaṇa ārammaṇa purejāta ādi bhāvo ca tesam na santati pariyāpannānam eva
translated: But the fact that they are objects, object-predominants, prenascent conditions, etc., is only in the case of the continuity of the sixfold base,

original: na ca cakkhādīnaṃ viya ekappakārenevāti aniyamato paccayabhāvo. Niyamato…pe… jīvitindriyanti
analyzed: na ca cakkha ādīnam viya eka ppakārena iva ati aniyamato paccaya bhāvaḥ jīvitindriyanti
translated: not in the case of the eye, etc., and not in the way of a single condition. So their state as conditions is not invariable.🔽“As a rule, the life faculty is a condition, as the life faculty, for the four great primaries, for the sixfold base, and for contact, etc.”

original: evanti ettha evaṃ-saddena vā rūpāyatanādīnampi saṅgaho veditabbo. Chaṭṭhāyatanañca🔽saḷāyatanañca saḷāyatananti ettha yadipi chaṭṭhāyatanasaḷāyatana-saddānaṃ saddato
analyzed: evam ti ettha evaṃsaddena vā rūpa āyatana ādīnam pi saṅgahaḥ veditabbo chaṭṭha āyatanam ca  ettha yadi api chaṭṭha āyatana saḷāyatana saddānam
translated: Herein, the word “as a rule” should be understood to include the base consisting of form, etc., as well.🔽The sixth base and the sixfold base🔽Although the words “sixth base” and “sixfold base” are not synonymous in sound,

original: sarūpatā natthi, atthato pana saḷāyatanekadesova chaṭṭhāyatananti ekadesasarūpatā
analyzed: sarūpa tā natthi atthato pana saḷāyatana ekadesaḥ uva chaṭṭha āyatanam ti ekadesa sarūpa tā
translated: they are synonymous in meaning, for the sixth base is a part of the sixfold base.

original: atthīti ekadesasarūpekaseso katoti veditabbo. Atthatopi hi sarūpānaṃ ekadesasarūpekasesaṃ
analyzed: atthi iti eka desa sarūpa ikasesaḥ kataḥ ti veditabbaḥ atthataḥ pi hi sarūpānam eka desa sarūpa ikasesam
translated: and it should be understood that the remainder of the material sepагате is made by the word “also.” For they maintain that “crooked” and “bent” are a remainder of the material sepагате of the materials.

original: icchanti “vaṅko ca kuṭilo ca kuṭilā”ti, tasmā atthato ekadesasarūpānañca ekasesena bhavitabbanti.
analyzed: icchanti vaṅko ca kuṭilo ca kuṭilā ti tasmai atthataḥ eka desa sarūpānam ca ekasesena bhavitabbanti
translated: Therefore it must be a remainder of the material sepагате in the sense of a remainder of the materials.

original: Atha vā chaṭṭhāyatanañca manāyatanañca chaṭṭhāyatananti vā, manāyatananti vā, chaṭṭhāyatanañca
analyzed: atha vā chaṭṭhāyatanañca manāyatanañca chaṭṭhāyatananti vā manāyatananti vā chaṭṭhāyatanañca
translated: Or alternatively, the sixth sense base and the mind base are a remainder of the sixth sense base or of the mind base,

original: chaṭṭhāyatanañca chaṭṭhāyatananti vā, manāyatanañca manāyatanañca manāyatananti vā🔽ekasesaṃ katvā cakkhādīhi saha “saḷāyatana”nti vuttanti tameva ekasesaṃ nāmamattapaccayassa,🔽nāmarūpapaccayassa ca manāyatanassa vasena kataṃ atthato dassento āha “chaṭṭhāyatanañca
analyzed: chaṭṭhāyatanañca chaṭṭhāyatananti vā manāyatanañca manāyatanañca manāyatananti vā  ekasesam katvā cakkha ādīhi saha saḷāyatanam ti vuttanti tam eva ekasesam nāma matta paccayassa  nāma rūpa paccayassa ca manāyatanassa vasena katam atthataḥ dassentaḥ āha chaṭṭha āyatanam ca
translated: or the sixth sense base and the mind base are a remainder of the sixth sense base or of the mind base,🔽making a remainder by the method of one of the two, and together with the eye, etc., are called “sixfold base.” That very remainder is called “name” in the sense of a condition for the “mere name” and in the sense of the mind base, a condition for the “mentality-materiality.”

original: saḷāyatanañca saḷāyatananti evaṃ katekasesassā”ti. Yathāvuttopi hi ekaseso atthato
analyzed: evam kata ikasesassa ati yathā vuttaḥ api hi ekasesaḥ atthataḥ
translated: Showing this, he said: “The sixth sense base and the sixfold base are a remainder of the sixth sense base and of the sixfold base, respectively.”🔽For although the remainder is stated in the way just described, in fact it is

original: chaṭṭhāyatanañca saḷāyatanañcāti evaṃ kato nāma hotīti. Sabbattha ca ekasese kate
analyzed: chaṭṭha āyatanam ca saḷāyatanam ca ati evam kataḥ nāma hoti iti sabbattha ca ekasese kate
translated: and the sixth sense base and the sixfold base.🔽And in all these cases the singular is used in the expression of the remainder,

original: ekavacananiddeso katekasesānaṃ saḷāyatanādisaddavacanīyatāsāmaññavasena katoti daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: ekavacana niddeso kata ikasesānam saḷāyatana ādi sadda vacanīya tā sāmañña vasena kataḥ iti daṭṭhabbo
translated: which should be understood to be used in the sense of the similarity consisting in the fact that the words “sixfold base” and so on are the names for the remainder.

original: Abyākatavāre vakkhatīti kiñcāpi akusalavāre kusalavāre ca “nāmapaccayā chaṭṭhāyatana”nti🔽vuttaṃ, suttantabhājanīye pana vipākachaṭṭhāyatanameva gahitanti adhippāyena abyākatavārameva
analyzed: abyākata vāre vakkhati iti kiñcā api akusala vāre kusala vāre ca nāma paccayā chaṭṭha āyatanam ti  vuttam suttanta bhājanīye pana vipāka chaṭṭha āyatanam eva gahitan ti adhippāyena abyākata vāram eva
translated: “In the indeterminate section” means that although in the unprofitable and the profitable sections it is said, “With mind as condition, the sixth sense base,”🔽nevertheless, in the Suttantabhājanīya only the resultant sixth sense base is included. This is the intention.🔽And it should be understood that the indeterminate section is cited as the proof.

original: sādhakabhāvena udāhaṭanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Paccayanaye pana “chaṭṭhā hoti taṃ avakaṃsato”tiādinā
analyzed: sādhaka bhāvena daṭṭhabbam paccaya naye pana chaṭṭhā hoti tam avakaṃsato tiādinā
translated: But in the Dependent Origination method, the condition is stated thus, “The sixth is the remainder” ,

original: avipākassapi paccayo uddhaṭo, so niravasesaṃ vattukāmatāya uddhaṭoti veditabbo. Idha
analyzed: avipākassa api paccayaḥ uddhaṭaḥ saḥ niravasesam vattu kāma tāya uddhaṭaḥ ti veditabbaḥ idha
translated: and it is stated as the condition for the non-resultant as well. It should be understood that it is stated thus because it is intended to be stated without remainder.🔽Herein, “is included” means is included by the method of the remainder.

original: saṅgahitanti idha ekasesanayena saṅgahitaṃ, tattha abyākatavāre lokiyavipākabhājanīye
analyzed: saṅgahitanti idha eka sesa nayena saṅgahitam tattha abyākata vāre lokiya vipāka bhājanīye
translated: Therein, in the indeterminate section, in the Suttantabhājanīya,

original: vibhattanti veditabbanti adhippāyo.
analyzed: vibhattam ti veditabbam ti adhippāyaḥ
translated: it should be understood that it is distributed. This is the intention.

original: Neyyanti ñeyyaṃ. Ukkaṃsāvakaṃsoti ettha sattadhā paccayabhāvato ukkaṃso aṭṭhadhā
analyzed: neyyam ti ñeyyam ukkaṃsa avakaṃso ti ettha sattadhā paccaya bhāvataḥ ukkaṃso aṭṭhadhā
translated: “The highest and the lowest” : the highest is sevenfold by way of conditionality, the eightfold

original: paccayabhāvo, tato pana navadhā tato vā dasadhāti ayaṃ ukkaṃso, avakaṃso pana dasadhā
analyzed: paccaya bhāvo tatas pana navadhā tatas vā dasadhā ati ayam ukkaṃsaḥ avakaṃso pana dasadhā
translated: is the highest, the ninefold is the highest, the tenfold is the highest. The lowest is tenfold,

original: paccayabhāvato navadhā paccayabhāvo, tato aṭṭhadhā, tato sattadhāti evaṃ veditabbo,
analyzed: paccaya bhāvataḥ navadhā paccaya bhāvaḥ tatas aṭṭhadhā tatas sattadhā iti evam veditabbaḥ
translated: the ninefold is the lowest, the eightfold is the lowest, the sevenfold is the lowest.

original: na pana sattadhā paccayabhāvato eva dvepi ukkaṃsāvakaṃsā yojetabbā tato avakaṃsābhāvatoti.🔽Hadayavatthuno sahāyaṃ hutvāti etena arūpe viya asahāyaṃ nāmaṃ na hoti, hadayavatthu🔽ca nāmena saha chaṭṭhāyatanassa paccayo hotīti ettakameva dasseti, na pana yathā
analyzed: na pana sattadhā paccaya bhāvataḥ eva dve pi ukkaṃsa avakaṃsā yojetabbā tatas avakaṃsa abhāvato ti  hadayavatthuno sahāyam hutvā ati etena arūpe viya asahāyam nāmam na hoti hadayavatthu  ca nāmena saha chaṭṭha āyatanassa paccayaḥ hoti iti ettakam eva dasseti na pana yathā
translated: But the highest and the lowest should not be construed as two by way of the sevenfold conditionality, but by way of the lowest and highest conditionality.

original: hadayavatthu paccayo hoti, tathā nāmampīti ayamattho adhippeto. Vatthu hi vippayuttapaccayo
analyzed: hadaya vatthu paccayaḥ hoti tathā nāmam pi iti ayam atthaḥ adhippetaḥ vatthu hi vippayutta paccayo
translated: “Being a companion to the heart-basis” : this shows that the name is not without a companion, as is the immaterial, but that the heart-basis is a condition for the sixth base together with the name. But the meaning intended is not that the name is a condition in the same way that the heart-basis is a condition. For the basis is a dissociated condition,🔽but the name is not. And the name is a result condition, etc., but the basis is not.

original: hoti, na nāmaṃ, nāmañca vipākahetādipaccayo hoti, na vatthūti. Pavatte arūpadhammā
analyzed: hoti na nāmam nāmañca vipāka hetā ādi paccayaḥ hoti na vatthu uti pavatte arūpa dhammā
translated: The immaterial dhammas in the course of an existence

original: kammajarūpassa ṭhitippattasseva paccayā honti, na uppajjamānassāti vippayuttaatthiavigatā
analyzed: kamma ja rūpassa ṭhiti ppattassa iva paccayāḥ honti na uppajjamānassa ati vippayutta atthi avigatā
translated: They are conditions for materiality that has reached presence, not for that which is arising.

original: ca pacchājātavippayuttādayo eva cakkhādīnaṃ yojetabbā.🔽Avasesamanāyatanassāti ettha “pañcakkhandhabhave panā”ti etassa anuvattamānattā pañcavokārabhave
analyzed: ca pacchā jāta vippayutta ādayaḥ eva cakkha ādīnam yojetabbā  avasesa manāyatanassa ti ettha pañca kkhandha bhave pana ati etassa anuvatta māna ttā pañcavokāra bhave
translated: And the postnascence condition, etc., and the dissociate condition, etc., should be construed with the eye, etc., too.

original: eva pavattamānaṃ pañcaviññāṇehi avasesamanāyatanaṃ vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Nāmarūpassa
analyzed: eva pavattamānam pañca viññāṇehi avasesam anāyatanam vuttam ti daṭṭhabbam nāma rūpassa
translated: As to the remaining bases: since the words “in the five categories of becoming” follow on this, it should be understood that the remaining bases occurring only in the five-constituent becoming are referred to here.

original: sahajātādisādhāraṇapaccayabhāvo sampayuttādiasādhāraṇapaccayabhāvo ca yathāsambhavaṃ yojetabbo.
analyzed: sahajāta ādi sādhāraṇa paccaya bhāvo sampayutta ādi asādhāraṇa paccaya bhāvo ca yathāsambhavam yojetabbo
translated: The joint and the individual conditions of the remaining bases should be construed as appropriate.

original: Saḷāyatanapadaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
translated: The commentary on the section of the dependent origination dealing with the six bases is finished.

original: Phassapadaniddesavaṇṇanā🔽230. “Chaṭṭhāyatanapaccayā phasso”ti abhidhammabhājanīyapāḷi āruppaṃ sandhāya vuttāti
analyzed: chaṭṭha āyatana paccayā phassaḥ ti abhidhammabhājanīya pāḷi āruppam sandhāya vuttā ati
translated: The section of the dependent origination dealing with contact🔽The text of the Abhidhamma Commentary says, “With the sixth base as condition: contact,” referring to the immaterial states.

original: “chaṭṭhāyatanapaccayā phassoti pāḷianusārato”ti āha. Ajjhattanti sasantatipariyāpannameva
analyzed: chaṭṭha āyatana paccayā phasso ti pāḷi anusārato ti āha ajjhattam ti sa santati pariyāpannam eva
translated: So it is said, “According to the text, ‘With the sixth base as condition: contact’ refers to the immaterial states.”🔽Internal means included in one’s own continuum.

original: gaṇhāti. Tañhi sasantatipariyāpannakammanibbattaṃ tādisassa phassassa paccayo hoti,
analyzed: gaṇhāti tat hi sa santati pariyāpanna kamma nibbattam tādisassa phassassa paccayaḥ hoti
translated: for it is a condition for such contact as is generated by kamma that occurs in one’s own continuity.

original: rūpādīni pana bahiddhā anupādinnāni ca phassassa ārammaṇaṃ honti, na tāni cakkhādīni🔽viya sasantatipariyāpannakammakilesanimittapavattibhāvena phassassa paccayoti paṭhamācariyavāde
analyzed: rūpa ādīni pana bahiddhā anupādinnāni ca phassassa ārammaṇam honti na tāni cakkha ādīni  viya sa santati pariyāpanna kamma kilesa nimitta pavatti bhāvena phassassa paccayaḥ ti paṭhama ācariya vāde
translated: But visible data, etc., which are external and not clung to are the object condition for contact. They are not a condition in the way that the eye, etc., are,

original: na gahitāni, dutiyācariyavāde pana yathā tathā vā paccayabhāve sati na sakkā vajjetunti gahitānīti.🔽Yadi sabbāyatanehi eko phasso sambhaveyya, “saḷāyatanapaccayā phasso”ti ekassa vacanaṃ🔽yujjeyya. Athāpi ekamhā āyatanā sabbe phassā sambhaveyyuṃ, tathāpi sabbāyatanehi
analyzed: na gahitāni dutiya ācariya vāde pana yathā tathā vā paccaya bhāve sati na sakkā vajjetun ti gahitāni iti  yadi sabba āyatanehi ekaḥ phasso sambhaveyya saḷāyatana paccayā phasso ti ekassa vacanam  yujjeyya atha api ekamhā āyatanā sabbe phassā sambhaveyyum tathā api sabba āyatanehi
translated: that is, by way of acting as the physical basis for the occurrence of the kamma-resultant contact and by way of being the sign for the occurrence of the kamma-resultant contact generated by kamma in one’s own continuity. So they are not included in the first teacher’s statement. But in the second teacher’s statement they are included because there is no harm in their being a condition in some way or another.🔽If a single contact were to arise through all the bases, then the statement “With the sixfold base as condition, contact” would be appropriate as a single one.

original: sabbaphassasambhavato āyatanabhedena phassabhedo natthīti tadabhedavasena ekassa
analyzed: sabba phassa sambhavataḥ āyatana bhedena phassa bhedaḥ natthi iti tad abheda vasena ekassa
translated: But even if all contacts were to arise through a single base, still, since all contacts would arise through all the bases, there would be no distinction of contact according to the distinction of bases. So it would not be possible to state “With the sixfold base as condition, contact.”

original: vacanaṃ yujjeyya, tathā pana asambhavato na yuttanti codeti “na sabbāyatanehī”tiādinā.
analyzed: vacanam yujjeyya tathā pana asambhavataḥ na yuttanti codeti na sabba āyatanehi itiādinā
translated: He criticizes the other’s statement by saying “Nor with all bases” and so on, pointing out that the statement is not correct because it is impossible for all contacts to arise with all bases.

original: Aññassapi vā asambhavantassa vidhānassa bodhanatthameva “nāpi ekamhā āyatanā sabbe🔽phassā”ti vuttaṃ, “na sabbāyatanehi eko phasso sambhotī”ti idameva pana ekaphassavacanassa🔽ayuttadīpakaṃ kāraṇanti veditabbaṃ. Nidassanavasena vā etaṃ vuttaṃ, nāpi ekamhā āyatanā
analyzed: aññassa api vā a sambhavantassa vidhānassa bodhana ttham eva na api ekamhā āyatanā sabbe  phassā ti vuttam na sabba āyatanehi ekaḥ phasso sambhoti iti idam eva pana eka phassa vacanassa  ayutta dīpakam kāraṇan ti veditabbam nidassana vasena vā etam vuttam na api ekamhā āyatanā
translated: Or else the words “Nor with all bases” are stated only to show that there is no other way of construing the statement “Nor with one base all contacts” .🔽The words “Nor with one base all contacts” should be understood as the reason for pointing out that the statement “one contact” is not correct.🔽Or else this is said by way of illustration: “Nor with one base all contacts,” that is, “Nor with all bases one contact.”

original: sabbe phassā sambhonti, evaṃ na sabbāyatanehi eko phasso sambhoti, tasmā ekassa vacanaṃ
analyzed: sabbe phassā sambhonti evam na sabba āyatanehi ekaḥ phassaḥ sambhoti tasmai ekassa vacanam
translated: But the words “Nor with all bases one contact” are the reason for pointing out that the statement “one contact” is not correct.

original: ayuttanti. Parihāraṃ pana anekāyatanehi ekaphassassa sambhavatoti dassento “tatridaṃ
analyzed: ayuttam ti parihāram pana aneka āyatanehi eka phassassa sambhavato ti dassento tatridam
translated: But the answer is that it is possible for one contact to arise with many bases.

original: vissajjana”ntiādimāha. Ekopi anekāyatanappabhavo ekopanekāyatanappabhavo. Chadhāpaccayatte
analyzed: vissajjana nti ādim āha ekaḥ api aneka āyatana pabhavo chadhā paccayatte
translated: “Herein, the answer is this” : one contact has many bases, one contact has one or many bases.

original: pañcavibhāvayeti evaṃ sesesupi yojanā. Tathā cāti paccuppannāni rūpādīni paccuppannañca🔽dhammāyatanapariyāpannaṃ rūparūpaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Ārammaṇapaccayamattenāti taṃ
analyzed: pañca vibhāvaya iti evam sesesu pi yojanā tathā ca ati paccuppannāni rūpa ādīni paccuppannam ca  dhamma āyatana pariyāpannam rūpa rūpam sandhāya vuttam ārammaṇa paccaya mattena ati tam
translated: “Five ways” should be construed in the same way in the rest of the text.🔽And so too: the present materiality, etc., and the materiality included in the present sense-sphere element.

original: sabbaṃ apaccuppannaṃ aññañca dhammāyatanaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ.
analyzed: sabbam apaccuppannam aññam ca dhammāyatanam sandhāya vuttam
translated: “As condition by object condition only”: all that is past and the rest of the sense-sphere element.

original: Phassapadaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽Vedanāpadaniddesavaṇṇanā🔽231. “Sesāna”nti ettha sampaṭicchanassa cakkhusamphassādayo pañca yadipi anantarādīhipi🔽paccayā honti, anantarādīnaṃ pana upanissaye antogadhattā santīraṇatadārammaṇānañca
analyzed: phassa pada niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  vedanā pada niddesa vaṇṇanā  ettha sampaṭicchanassa cakkhu samphassa ādayaḥ pañca yadi pi anantara ādīhi pi  paccayāḥ honti anantara ādīnam pana upanissaye santīraṇa tad ārammaṇānam ca
translated: The description of the base of contact is ended.

original: sādhāraṇassa tassa vasena “ekadhā”ti vuttaṃ.🔽Tebhūmakavipākavedanānampi sahajātamanosamphassasaṅkhāto so phasso aṭṭhadhā paccayo
analyzed: sādhāraṇassa tassa vasena ekadhā iti vuttam  tebhūmaka vipāka vedanānam pi sahajāta manaḥ samphassa saṅkhāto so phassaḥ aṭṭhadhā paccayo
translated: As regards the words “the rest” , though the five beginning with eye contact are conditions by way of proximity, etc., as well, still, since proximity, etc., are included in decisive-support, and since the latter is common to both the determining and the adverting, it is said: “in one way.”🔽And it should be construed thus: “The resultant feeling of the three planes has that contact which is called mind-contact as condition in eight ways.”

original: hotīti yojetabbaṃ. Paccayaṃ anupādinnampi keci icchantīti “yā panā”tiādinā manodvārāvajjanaphassassa
analyzed: hoti iti yojetabbam paccayam an upādinnam pi keci icchanti iti yā pana ati ādinā manaḥ dvāra āvajjana phassassa
translated: Some maintain that the condition is not only that which is clung to, but also that which is not clung to. Therefore, in order to show the condition that is not clung to, the following is stated:

original: paccayabhāvo vutto, tañca mukhamattadassanatthaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Etena nayena sabbassa
analyzed: paccaya bhāvaḥ vuttaḥ tat ca mukha matta dassana attham daṭṭhabbam etena nayena sabbassa
translated: and the state of condition has been stated, and that should be seen as being for the purpose of showing the mere door.🔽

original: anantarassa anānantarassa ca phassassa tassā tassā vipākavedanāya upanissayatā yojetabbāti.
analyzed: anantarassa anānantarassa ca phassassa tassā tassā vipāka vedanāya upanissaya tā yojetabbā ati
translated: and the condition is stated. And that should be regarded as stated merely to show the face of the condition. In this way the conditionality of the resultant feeling in each instance should be construed as the support condition for the contact in each instance that is next to it and not next to it.

original: Vedanāpadaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: vedanā pada niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of the section on feeling is ended.

original: Taṇhāpadaniddesavaṇṇanā🔽232. Mamattenāti sampiyāyamānena, assādanataṇhāyāti vuttaṃ hoti. Tattha putto viya🔽vedanā daṭṭhabbā, khīrādayo viya vedanāya paccayabhūtā rūpādayo, khīrādidāyikā dhāti🔽viya rūpādichaḷārammaṇadāyakā cittakārādayo cha. Tattha vejjo rasāyanojāvasena tadupatthambhitajīvitavasena
analyzed: taṇhā pada niddesa vaṇṇanā  mamattena āti sampiyāyamānena assādana taṇhāya ati vuttam hoti tattha putto viya  vedanā daṭṭhabbā khīra ādayaḥ viya vedanāya paccaya bhūtāḥ rūpa ādayaḥ khīra ādi dāyikā  rūpa ādi chaṭṭha ārammaṇa dāyakā cittakāra ādayo cha tattha rasāyana ujā vasena tad upatthambhita jīvita vasena
translated: The description of the section on craving

original: ca dhammārammaṇassa dāyakoti daṭṭhabbo. Ārammaṇapaccayo uppajjamānassa ārammaṇamattameva
analyzed: ca dhamma ārammaṇassa dāyako ti daṭṭhabbaḥ ārammaṇa paccayaḥ uppajjamānassa ārammaṇa mattam eva
translated: is “in what is one’s own” , which is said with reference to craving for enjoyment in what is dear. Herein, feeling should be regarded as a son, and the material, etc., states that are conditions for feeling as milk, etc., and the mind’s reaction to the material, etc., as the nurse who gives the milk, etc. Herein, the physician should be regarded as the object of consciousness, which gives the milk, etc., by way of the nutritive essence of the nutriment consisting in consciousness, and by way of the life faculty maintained by that .

original: hoti, na upanissayo viya uppādakoti uppādakassa upanissayasseva vasena “ekadhāvā”ti
analyzed: hoti na upanissayaḥ viya uppādako ti uppādakassa upanissayassa iva vasena ekadhā avāti
translated: The object condition is merely the object of what arises; it is not a producer like the support condition. So it is said: “As one, by way of the support condition” .

original: vuttaṃ. Upanissayena vā ārammaṇūpanissayo saṅgahito, tena ca ārammaṇabhāvena taṃsabhāvo
analyzed: vuttam upanissayena vā ārammaṇa upanissayaḥ saṅgahitaḥ tena ca ārammaṇa bhāvena taṃsa bhāvaḥ
translated: It is said. Or it is included by decisive support, and by that it is of the same nature as object.

original: aññopi ārammaṇabhāvo dīpito hotīti upanissayavaseneva paccayabhāvo vuttoti veditabbo.
analyzed: aññaḥ api ārammaṇa bhāvaḥ dīpitaḥ hoti iti upanissaya vasena iva paccaya bhāvaḥ vuttaḥ ti veditabbaḥ
translated: and so on. Or else, the object-predominance is included in the decisive-support condition, and by that the state of being an object is shown, and the other state of being an object is also shown. So the state of being a condition should be understood as being only by way of the decisive-support condition.

original: Yasmā vātiādinā na kevalaṃ vipākasukhavedanā eva, tissopi pana vedanā vipākā visesena
analyzed: yasmā vāti ādinā na kevalam vipāka sukha vedanā eva tissaḥ api pana vedanāḥ vipākāḥ visesena
translated: By “because” and so on the Exalted One shows that not only the pleasant feeling that is a ripening but also the other two feelings are a decisive-support condition for craving, in a specific way,

original: taṇhāya upanissayapaccayo, avisesena itarā cāti dasseti. Upekkhā pana santattā, sukhamicceva🔽bhāsitāti tasmā sāpi bhiyyo icchanavasena taṇhāya upanissayoti adhippāyo. Upekkhā🔽pana akusalavipākabhūtā aniṭṭhattā dukkhe avarodhetabbā, itarā iṭṭhattā sukheti sā
analyzed: taṇhāya upanissaya paccayaḥ avisesena itarā ca ati dasseti upekkhā pana santattā sukham icca eva  bhāsitā ati tasmā sā api bhiyyas icchana vasena taṇhāya upanissayaḥ ti adhippāyaḥ upekkhā  pana akusala vipāka bhūtā aniṭṭha ttā dukkhe avarodhetabbā itarā iṭṭha ttā sukhā iti sā
translated: and in a general way for the other two. But equanimity is said to be pleasure because it is peaceful. Therefore, the intention is that it is also a decisive-support for craving because of the desire for more.🔽But equanimity that is a ripening of unwholesome action is to be included in pain because it is undesirable. The other two are to be included in pleasure because they are desirable. Therefore, it can be said that they are decisive-supports for craving as pain and pleasure.

original: dukkhaṃ viya sukhaṃ viya ca upanissayo hotīti sakkā vattunti. “Vedanāpaccayā taṇhā”ti
analyzed: dukkham viya sukham viya ca upanissayaḥ hoti iti sakkā vattunti vedanā paccayā taṇhā ati
translated: By the words “With feeling as condition there arises in him craving” ,

original: vacanena sabbassa vedanāvato paccayassa atthitāya taṇhuppattippasaṅge taṃnivāraṇatthamāha
analyzed: vacanena sabbassa vedanāvataḥ paccayassa atthitāya taṇhuppatti ppasaṅge tad nivāraṇa attham āha
translated: since the arising of craving is possible because of the existence of all conditions for feeling, the Exalted One says this in order to prevent that.

original: “vedanāpaccayā cāpī”tiādi.
analyzed: vedanā paccayā ca api itiādi
translated: “And feeling is a condition for craving,” and so on.

original: Nanu “anusayasahāyā vedanā taṇhāya paccayo hotī”ti vacanassa abhāvā atippasaṅganivattanaṃ
analyzed: nanu anusaya sahāyā vedanā taṇhāya paccayaḥ hoti iti vacanassa abhāvā atippasaṅga nivattanam
translated: But since there are no words to the effect that “feeling accompanied by inherent tendency is a condition for craving,” how can the avoidance of over-extension be

original: na sakkā kātunti? Na, vaṭṭakathāya pavattattā. Vaṭṭassa hi anusayavirahe abhāvato🔽anusayasahitāyeva paccayoti atthato vuttametaṃ hotīti. Atha vā “avijjāpaccayā”ti
analyzed: na sakkā kātunti na vaṭṭa kathāya pavatta ttā vaṭṭassa hi anusaya virahe abhāvato  anusaya sahitāya iva paccayaḥ ti atthataḥ vuttam etam hoti iti atha vā avijjā paccayā ti
translated: achieved? —Not so; because the wheel of becoming is in process. For since the wheel would not exist without the inherent tendencies, it is implied that🔽it is accompanied by inherent tendencies. Or alternatively, since the words🔽“With ignorance as condition there are formations” are repeated, it is evident

original: anuvattamānattā anusayasahitāva paccayoti viññāyati. “Vedanāpaccayā taṇhā”ti ca ettha
analyzed: anuvatta mānattā anusaya sahitā ava paccayaḥ ti viññāyati vedanā paccayā taṇhā ati ca ettha
translated: that the condition is accompanied by inherent tendencies. And in the passage🔽“With feeling as condition there is craving,” the rule is evident that craving

original: vedanāpaccayā eva taṇhā, na vedanāya vināti ayaṃ niyamo viññāyati, na vedanāpaccayā
analyzed: vedanā paccayā eva taṇhā na vedanāya vinā ati ayam niyamaḥ viññāyati na vedanā paccayā
translated: has only feeling as condition, not that craving is without feeling as condition.

original: taṇhā hoti evāti, tasmā atippasaṅgo natthi evāti.🔽Vusīmatoti vusitavato, vusitabrahmacariyavāsassāti attho. Vussatīti vā “vusī”ti maggo
analyzed: taṇhā hoti eva ati tasmā atippasaṅgaḥ natthi eva ati  vusīmataḥ ti vusitavataḥ vusita brahmacariya vāsassa ati atthaḥ vussati iti vā maggo
translated: Therefore there is no over-extension.🔽“Accomplished”: of one who has accomplished , i.e. of one who has🔽lived the life of spiritual practice. Or alternatively, the path is called “accomplished”🔽because it is “accomplished” , and he has that, thus he is “accomplished” . Or

original: vuccati, so etassa vuttho atthīti vusīmā. Aggaphalaṃ vā pariniṭṭhitavāsattā “vusī”ti
analyzed: vuccati saḥ etassa vutthaḥ atthi iti agga phalam vā pariniṭṭhita vāsattā vusīti
translated: the path is called “accomplished” because it is “accomplished” , i.e. because🔽the life of spiritual practice has been completed, and he has that, thus he is🔽“accomplished” .

original: vuccati, taṃ etassa atthīti vusīmā.
analyzed: vuccati tam etassa atthi iti vu sīmā
translated: it is said that he has a border, thus he is a borderer.

original: Taṇhāpadaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: taṇhā pada niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of the shackle of craving is ended.

original: Upādānapadaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: upādāna pada niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the shackle of assuming

original: 233. Sassato attāti idaṃ purimadiṭṭhiṃ upādiyamānaṃ uttaradiṭṭhiṃ nidassetuṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: sassataḥ attā iti idam purima diṭṭhim upādiyamānam uttara diṭṭhim nidassetum vuttam
translated: “The self is eternal” is said in order to show the later view that assumes the former view.

original: Yathā hi esā diṭṭhi daḷhīkaraṇavasena purimaṃ uttarā upādiyati, evaṃ “natthi dinna”ntiādikāpīti.
analyzed: yathā hi esā diṭṭhi daḷhīkaraṇa vasena purimam uttarā upādiyati evam natthi dinna nti ādikā api iti
translated: For just as this view assumes the former as the later in the sense of strengthening it, so too “There is nothing given” and so on.

original: Attaggahaṇaṃ pana attavādupādānanti na idaṃ diṭṭhupādānadassananti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Loko
analyzed: atta ggahaṇam pana attavāda upādānanti na idam diṭṭha upādāna dassanam ti daṭṭhabbam loko
translated: But the assumption of a self is the assuming of a view of self, and this should not be regarded as the shackle of views.

original: cāti vā attaggahaṇavinimuttaṃ gahaṇaṃ diṭṭhupādānabhūtaṃ idha purimadiṭṭhiuttaradiṭṭhivacanehi🔽vuttanti veditabbaṃ. “Dhammasaṅkhepavitthāre pana saṅkhepato taṇhādaḷhattaṃ, saṅkhepato
analyzed: ca ati vā atta ggahaṇa vinimuttam gahaṇam diṭṭha upādāna bhūtam idha purima diṭṭhi uttara diṭṭhi vacanehi  vuttam ti veditabbam dhamma saṅkhepa vitthāre pana saṅkhepataḥ taṇhā daḷha ttam saṅkhepataḥ
translated: Or the assumption that is free from the assumption of a self is the shackle of views, and it is said here by the words “the later view” and “the former view” respectively.🔽In the case of the brief and detailed exposition of ideas, the brief exposition is the strengthening of craving, and the brief exposition is merely the view, but the detailed exposition is the shackle of assuming a self and the shackle of craving.

original: diṭṭhimattameva, vitthārato panā”ti evaṃ dhammasaṅkhepavitthārato saṅkhepaṃ vitthārañca
analyzed: diṭṭhimattam eva vitthārato panāti evam dhamma saṅkhepa vitthārato saṅkhepam vitthāram ca
translated: Thus he discerns the brief and detailed exposition of ideas.

original: niddhāretīti. Dhammasaṅkhepavitthāreti niddhāraṇe bhummaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: niddhāreti iti dhamma saṅkhepa vitthārā iti niddhāraṇe bhummam daṭṭhabbam
translated: The words “the brief and detailed exposition of ideas” should be regarded as a locative absolute.

original: Pakatiaṇuādīnaṃ sassatagāhapubbaṅgamo, sarīrassa ucchedaggāhapubbaṅgamo ca tesaṃ🔽sāmibhūto koci sassato ucchijjamāno vā attā atthīti attaggāho kadāci hotīti “yebhuyyenā”ti
analyzed: pakati aṇu ādīnam sa sata gāha pubbaṅgamaḥ sarīrassa uccheda ggāha pubbaṅgamaḥ ca tesam  sāmi bhūtaḥ koci sassato ucchijjamānaḥ vā attā atthi iti attaggāhaḥ kadāci hoti iti yebhuyyena ati
translated: The grasping of a self is sometimes the grasping of a self that is permanent and is the forerunner of the eternalist view of the primary elements, etc., and sometimes the grasping of a self that is annihilated and is the forerunner of the annihilationist view of the body.🔽The statement “for the most part” is made because there is a self that is the owner of these two views, which is either permanent or annihilated.

original: vuttaṃ. Yebhuyyena paṭhamaṃ attavādupādānantiādinā vā sambandho.
analyzed: vuttam yebhuyyena paṭhamam vā sambandhaḥ
translated: Or else the statement “for the most part” is made in order to relate the passage to the statement “for the most part, first the grasping of the self and then the grasping of what belongs to the self.”

original: Yadipi bhavarāgajavanavīthi sabbapaṭhamaṃ pavattati gahitappaṭisandhikassa bhavanikantiyā
analyzed: yadi api bhava rāga javana vīthi sabba paṭhamam pavattati gahita paṭisandhikassa bhava nikantiyā
translated: Although the stream of impulsions accompanied by craving for existence occurs first, because the attachment to existence must occur in one who has already been reborn,

original: pavattitabbattā, so pana bhavarāgo taṇhādaḷhattaṃ na hotīti maññamāno na kāmupādānassa🔽paṭhamuppattimāha. Taṇhā kāmupādānanti pana vibhāgassa akaraṇe sabbāpi taṇhā kāmupādānanti,
analyzed: pavattitabba ttā so pana bhava rāgaḥ taṇhā daḷha ttam na hoti iti maññamānaḥ na kāma upādānassa  paṭhama uppattim āha taṇhā kāma upādānanti pana vibhāgassa akaraṇe sabbā api taṇhā kāma upādānanti
translated: this craving for existence is not considered to be strong craving, and so the arising of sensual desire is not mentioned first.🔽But if the distinction is not made, all craving is sensual desire,

original: karaṇepi kāmarāgato aññāpi taṇhā daḷhabhāvaṃ pattā kāmupādānanti tassa arahattamaggavajjhatā vuttā.
analyzed: karaṇe pi kāma rāgataḥ aññā api taṇhā daḷha bhāvam pattā kāma upādānam ti tassa arahatta magga vajjha tā vuttā
translated: and if the distinction is made, then sensual desire and any other craving that has become strong is sensual desire. The statement that it is abandoned by the path of arahantship is made because it is the object of the path of arahantship.

original: Uppattiṭṭhānabhūtā cittuppādā visayo. Pañcupādānakkhandhā ālayo, tattha ramatīti
analyzed: uppatti ṭṭhāna bhūtā cittuppādāḥ visayo pañca upādānakkhandhāḥ ālayo tattha ramati iti
translated: The objects are the consciousnesses that are the bases for its arising. The five aggregates subject to clinging are the abode, because one delights in them.

original: ālayarāmā, pajā. Teneva sā ālayarāmatā ca sakasantāne parasantāne ca pākaṭā hotīti.
analyzed: ālaya rāmā pajā tena iva sā ālaya rāma tā ca saka santāne para santāne ca pākaṭā hoti iti
translated: People delight in attachment. And so that delight in attachment becomes evident both in one’s own continuity and in that of others.

original: Upanissayavacanena ārammaṇānantarapakatūpanissayā vuttāti anantarapaccayādīnampi saṅgaho kato hoti.
analyzed: upanissaya vacanena ārammaṇa anantara pakatūpanissayā vuttā ati anantara paccaya ādīnam pi saṅgahaḥ kataḥ hoti
translated: By the word “predominance” the object, the proximate cause, and the natural decisive support are included.

original: Upādānapadaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: upādāna pada niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of the word “clinging” is ended.

original: Bhavapadaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: bhava pada niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: Description of the word “becoming”

original: 234. Phalavohārena kammabhavo bhavoti vuttoti upapattibhavanibbacanameva dvayassapi🔽sādhāraṇaṃ katvā vadanto āha “bhavatīti bhavo”ti. Bhavaṃ gacchatīti nipphādanaphalavasena
analyzed: phala vohārena kamma bhavaḥ bhavaḥ ti vuttaḥ ti upapatti bhava nibbacanam eva dvayassa api  sādhāraṇam katvā vadantaḥ āha bhavati iti bhavam gacchati iti nipphādana phala vasena
translated: Since kamma-process becoming is called “becoming” by way of its fruit, the expression of rebirth-process becoming is common to both.

original: attano pavattikāle bhavābhimukhaṃ hutvā pavattatīti attho, nibbattanameva vā ettha gamanaṃ adhippetaṃ.🔽Saññāvataṃ bhavo saññābhavoti ettha vantu-saddassa lopo daṭṭhabbo, tassa vā atthe
analyzed: attanaḥ pavatti kāle bhava abhimukham hutvā pavattati iti atthaḥ nibbattanam eva vā ettha gamanam adhippetam  saññāvatam bhavo saññābhavo ti ettha vantu saddassa lopo daṭṭhabbo tassa vā atthe
translated: So the commentator says, “It becomes , thus it is becoming” . It goes to becoming , thus it is becoming. The meaning is that it occurs at the time of its own occurrence facing becoming by way of the fruit of production. Or the meaning of “going” is intended here in the sense of rebirth.🔽In the case of the words “becoming with perception” , the word “with” should be regarded as elided, or the reading is “perceptive becoming” , with the meaning of “with” being expressed by the vowel “a” .

original: akāraṃ katvā “saññabhavo”tipi pāṭho. Vokirīyati pasārīyati vitthārīyatīti vokāro,
analyzed: akāram katvā pāṭhaḥ vokirīyati pasārīyati vitthārīyati iti vokāraḥ
translated: It is spread out , extended , expanded , thus it is a plane ;

original: vokiraṇaṃ vā vokāro, so ekasmiṃ pavattattā eko vokāroti vutto, padesapasaṭuppattīti attho.🔽Cetanāsampayuttā vā…pe… saṅgahitāti ācayagāmitāya kammasaṅkhātataṃ dassetvā kammabhave
analyzed: vokiraṇam vā vokāro saḥ ekasmin pavatta ttā ekaḥ vokāro ti vutto padesa pasaṭuppattī iti attho  cetanā sampayuttā vāpe saṅgahitā ti ācaya gāmi tāya kamma saṅkhāta tam dassetvā kamma bhave
translated: Or else the term is a derivation from the word for “breaking up” , and it is said to be “one” because it occurs in one , the meaning being that it is the source of a part of the perishing .🔽Or else it is included in the kamma-process, in the sense of being associated with the volition, etc., and so on up to:

original: saṅgahitabhāvaṃ pariyāyena vadati, nippariyāyena pana cetanāva kammabhavo. Vuttañhi🔽“kammabhavo tīhi khandhehi ekenāyatanena ekāya dhātuyā sampayutto, ekena khandhena
analyzed: saṅgahita bhāvam pariyāyena vadati nippariyāyena pana cetanā ava kamma bhavaḥ vuttam hi  kamma bhavaḥ tīhi khandhehi ekena āyatanena ekāya dhātuyā sampayuttaḥ ekena khandhena
translated: he shows that it is called kamma in the sense of “accumulating” , and then he states its inclusion in the kamma-process by a roundabout way. But in the direct way volition itself is the kamma-process. For this is said:

original: ekenāyatanena ekāya dhātuyā kehici sampayutto”ti. Upapattibhavo tīhipi tikehi vuttā🔽upapattikkhandhāva. Yathāha “upapattibhavo kāmabhavo saññābhavo pañcavokārabhavo🔽pañcahi khandhehi ekādasahāyatanehi sattarasahi dhātūhi saṅgahito”tiādi. Yadi hi
analyzed: ekena āyatanena ekāya dhātuyā kehici sampayuttaḥ ti upapatti bhavaḥ tīhi pi tikehi vuttā  upapatti kkhandhā ava yathā āha upapatti bhavo kāma bhavo saññā bhavo pañcavokāra bhavo  pañcahi khandhehi ekādasahi āyatanehi sattarasahi dhātūhi yadi hi
translated: “The kamma-process is associated with three aggregates, with one base, with one element, and it is associated with some of the bases and elements” . The process of rebirth-linking is the aggregates that occur in the three sections of the sutta.

original: anupādinnakānampi gahaṇaṃ siyā, “dvādasahāyatanehi aṭṭhārasahi dhātūhī”ti vattabbaṃ siyāti.
analyzed: anupādinnakānam pi gahaṇam siyā dvādasahi āyatanehi aṭṭhārasahi dhātūhi iti vattabbam siyāti
translated: For this is said: “The process of rebirth-linking is included in the sense-desire process, in the form process, in the five aggregates, in eleven bases, in seventeen elements” , and so on. For if it were to include what is not clung to, it would have to be said that it is included in twelve bases and in eighteen elements.

original: Saṅkhārabhavānaṃ dhammabhedato na saṅkhārā eva puna vuttāti “sātthakamevidaṃ punavacana”nti
analyzed: saṅkhāra bhavānam dhamma bhedataḥ na saṅkhārāḥ eva puna vuttā ati sātthakam eva idam punavacanan ti
translated: But it is not so because the formations are mentioned again in the sense of a part of becoming.🔽If it be said: “Is it not unreasonable to say that the repetition has a meaning since the formations are not mentioned again by way of a division of states of the becoming of formations?”

original: etaṃ na yuttanti ce? Na, bhavekadesabhāvena saṅkhārānaṃ bhavoti puna vuttattā. Parena🔽vā dhammavisesaṃ agaṇetvā punavacanaṃ coditanti codakābhilāsavasena “sātthakamevidaṃ
analyzed: etam na yuttam ti ce na bhava eka desa bhāvena puna vutta ttā parena  vā dhamma visesam a gaṇetvā punavacanam coditanti codaka abhilāsa vasena sātthakam eva idam
translated: —it may be replied: No, because the formations are mentioned again in the sense of a part of becoming.

original: punavacana”nti vuttaṃ.🔽Kāmabhavādinibbattanakassa kammassa kāmabhavādibhāvo phalavohārena aṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: punavacanam iti vuttam  kāma bhava ādi nibbattanakassa kammassa kāma bhava ādi bhāvo phala vohārena aṭṭhakathāyam
translated: Or else, the questioner, not counting the repetition as a division of states, asked the question, “Is it not unreasonable to say that the repetition has a meaning?” and the answerer, in order to show the questioner’s wish, said, “The repetition has a meaning.”🔽In the commentary the state of being of kamma that generates sense-desire becoming, etc., is stated by way of fruit-expression.

original: vutto. Antogadhe visuṃ agaṇetvā abbhantaragate eva katvā kāmabhavādike kammupapattibhavavasena🔽duguṇe katvā āha “cha bhavā”ti.
analyzed: vuttaḥ antogadhe visum a gaṇetvā abbhantara gate eva katvā kāma bhava ādike kamma upapatti bhava vasena  duguṇe katvā āha cha
translated: Without counting separately those included in the sense-desire becoming, etc., he said, “six kinds of becoming,” making them two by way of kamma-process becoming and rebirth-process becoming.

original: Avisesenāti upādānabhedaṃ akatvāti attho. Upādānabhedākaraṇeneva ca dvādasappabhedassa saṅgahavasena saṅgahato “cha bhavā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: avisesena ati upādāna bhedam a katvā iti atthaḥ upādāna bheda akaraṇena iva ca dvādasa ppabhedassa saṅgaha vasena saṅgahataḥ cha bhavā ti vuttam
translated: Without making a distinction of kinds of assuming means without making a distinction of kinds of assuming. And it is said, “six kinds of becoming” by way of inclusion, including the twelve kinds by way of inclusion without making a distinction of kinds of assuming.

original: Gosīlena kukkurasīlena ca samattena samādinnena gunnaṃ kukkurānañca sahabyatā vuttāti🔽sīlabbatupādānavato jhānabhāvanā na ijjhatīti maññamānā tena rūpārūpabhavā na hontīti
analyzed: go sīlena kukkura sīlena ca sa mattena samādinnena gunnam kukkura anam ca sahabya tā vuttā iti  sīlabba tupādānavataḥ jhāna bhāvanā na ijjhati iti maññamānā tena rūpa arūpa bhavāḥ na honti iti
translated: “By the practice of the virtue of the cow and the virtue of the dog, one is reborn in the company of cows and dogs” .🔽Some say that the development of jhāna is not successful in one who clings to virtue and vows, and so he does not attain the kinds of becoming associated with the fine-material and immaterial spheres.

original: keci vadanti, vakkhamānena pana pakārena paccayabhāvato “taṃ na gahetabba”nti āha.
analyzed: keci vadanti vakkhamānena pana pakārena paccaya bhāvataḥ tam na gahetabbanti āha
translated: But the meaning of the text is not to be taken in this way, according to the commentator, who says that the text should not be taken to mean that virtue and vows are conditions for rebirth in the fine-material and immaterial spheres.

original: Asuddhimagge ca suddhimaggaparāmasanaṃ sīlabbatupādānanti suddhimaggaparāmasanena
analyzed: a suddhi magge ca suddhi magga parāmasanam sīla bbata upādānam ti suddhi magga parāmasanena
translated: “Clinging to virtue and vows” is the misapprehension of a path to purity that is not the path to purity.🔽It is not proper that the development of the fine-material and immaterial jhānas should be due to misapprehension of a path to purity.🔽“Hearing of wrong conduct” is hearing of the conduct of the ancient kings of the Bharata dynasty, of the conduct of the hero Sītāharaṇa, of the conduct of Pasubandha, and so on.

original: rūpārūpāvacarajjhānānaṃ nibbattanaṃ na yujjatīti. Purāṇabhāratasītāharaṇapasubandhavidhiādisavanaṃ
analyzed: rūpa arūpāvacara jhānānam nibbattanam na yujjati iti
translated: The word “and” implies hearing of wrong conduct and wrong view.

original: asaddhammasavanaṃ. Ādi-saddena asappurisūpanissayaṃ pubbe ca akatapuññataṃ attamicchāpaṇidhitañca🔽saṅgaṇhāti. Tadantogadhā evāti tasmiṃ duccaritanibbatte sucaritanibbatte ca kāmabhave🔽antogadhā evāti attho.
analyzed: asat dhamma savanam ādi saddena asappurisa upanissayam pubbe ca a kata puñña tam atta micchā paṇidhi tam ca 🔽saṅgaṇhāti eva ati tasmin duccarita nibbatte su carita nibbatte ca kāma bhave 🔽antogadhāḥ eva ati
translated: “And” implies that the person who hears of wrong conduct and wrong view is one who has not previously made merit and who has a wrong aspiration.

original: Antogadhāti ca saññābhavapañcavokārabhavānaṃ ekadesena antogadhattā vuttaṃ. Na hi🔽te niravasesā kāmabhave antogadhāti. Sappabhedassāti sugatiduggatimanussādippabhedavato.🔽Kamena ca avatvā sīlabbatupādānassa ante bhavapaccayabhāvavacanaṃ attavādupādānaṃ
analyzed: antogadhā iti ca saññā bhava pañcavokāra bhavānam eka desena antogadha ttā vuttam na hi  te niravasesā kāma bhave sa pabhedassa ati sugati duggati manussa ādi ppabhedavato  kamena ca avatvā sīla bbata upādānassa ante bhava paccaya bhāva vacanam attavād upādānam
translated: For it is not included in its entirety.🔽“With its several kinds” means with its kinds as good destination, bad destination, human, and so on.

original: viya abhiṇhaṃ asamudācaraṇato attavādupādānanimittattā ca.
analyzed: a samudācaraṇataḥ attavāt upādāna nimitta ttā ca
translated: And although it is not stated in order, the statement of the condition consisting in becoming comes after the condition consisting in virtue and duty because the latter is the cause of the former,🔽and because the condition consisting in virtue and duty is the cause of the condition consisting in self-theory, since the latter is often found to occur in dependence on the former.

original: Hetupaccayappabhedehīti ettha maggapaccayo ca vattabbo. Diṭṭhupādānādīni hi maggapaccayā hontīti.
analyzed: hetu paccaya ppabhedehi iti ettha magga paccayaḥ ca vattabbaḥ diṭṭhupādāna ādīni hi magga paccayāḥ honti iti
translated: “With its several kinds of condition” means with its kinds of condition consisting in root cause, and so on. The path condition should be mentioned here too, since the conditions consisting in self-theory, etc., are path conditions.

original: Bhavapadaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: bhava pada niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of the word “becoming” is ended.

original: Jātijarāmaraṇādipadaniddesavaṇṇanā🔽235. Upapattibhavuppattiyeva jātīti āha “na upapattibhavo”ti. Jāyamānassa pana jāti
analyzed: jāti jarā maraṇa ādi pada niddesa vaṇṇanā  upapatti bhava uppattiyā iva jāti iti āha na upapatti bhavaḥ ti jāyamānassa pana jāti
translated: Description of the words birth, aging-and-death, etc.🔽“Birth” is the arising of the rebirth-process itself. That is why he said “not the rebirth-process.” But since the birth of what is being born is birth,🔽and since the rebirth-process would not be if birth were not, it can be said that the rebirth-process is a condition for birth.

original: jātīti upapattibhavopi asati abhāvā jātiyā paccayoti sakkā vattuṃ. Jāyamānarūpapadaṭṭhānatāpi
analyzed: jāti iti upapatti bhavaḥ api asati abhāvā jātiyā paccayaḥ ti sakkā vattum jāyamāna rūpa padaṭṭhāna tā api
translated: And the state of being the proximate cause of the materiality that is being born is also a condition for birth.

original: hi rūpajātiyā vuttā “upacitarūpapadaṭṭhāno upacayo, anuppabandharūpapadaṭṭhānā santatī”ti.🔽Khandhānaṃ jātānaṃ uññātatānuññātatāca hīnapaṇītatā. Ādi-saddena suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇādivisesaṃ
analyzed: hi rūpa jātiyā vuttā upacita rūpa padaṭṭhānaḥ upacayaḥ anuppabandha rūpa padaṭṭhānā santati iti  khandhānam jātānam uññāta tā anuññāta tā ca hīna paṇīta tā ādi saddena suvaṇṇa dubbaṇṇa ādi visesam
translated: for it is said of the kind of materiality called “arisen” that “growth is the condition for the material support of what is stored up, and continuity is the condition for the material support of what is not stored up” .

original: saṅgaṇhāti. Ajjhattasantānagatato aññassa visesakārakassa kāraṇassa abhāvā “ajjhattasantāne”ti āha.
analyzed: saṅgaṇhāti ajjhatta santāna gatataḥ aññassa visesa kārakassa kāraṇassa abhāvā ajjhatta santāne iti āha
translated: The “inferiority and superiority” of the aggregates that have arisen is their “unattractiveness and attractiveness.” The word “etc.” includes the distinction of “good colour and bad colour,” etc. He said “in one’s own and another’s continuity” because there is no other cause that makes the distinction in one’s own continuity.

original: Tena tenāti ñātibyasanādinā jarāmaraṇato aññena dukkhadhammena. Upanissayakoṭiyāti
analyzed: tena tena ati ñāti byasana ādinā jarā maraṇataḥ aññena dukkha dhammena upanissaya koṭiyā ati
translated: “By that and that” : by any other state of suffering than ageing and death, such as bereavement, etc. “At the end of conditionality” :

original: upanissayaṃsena, upanissayalesenāti attho. Yo hi paṭṭhāne anāgato sati bhāvā asati
analyzed: upanissaya ṃsena upanissaya lesena ati attho yaḥ hi paṭṭhāne anāgataḥ sati bhāvāḥ asati
translated: by the method of conditionality, is the meaning. For that which is future in function is a condition in the Suttas by way of presence and by way of absence.

original: ca abhāvā suttantikapariyāyena upanissayo, so “upanissayakoṭī”ti vuccati.
analyzed: ca abhāvā suttantika pariyāyena upanissayo so upanissaya koṭī iti vuccati
translated: That is called “at the end of conditionality.”

original: Jātijarāmaraṇādipadaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: jāti jarā maraṇa ādi pada niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the explanation of the terms “birth, ageing, and death” is ended.

original: Bhavacakkakathāvaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the Wheel of Becoming

original: 242. Samitanti saṅgataṃ, abbocchinnanti attho. Kāmayānassāti kāmayamānassa, kāmo yānaṃ etassāti vā kāmayāno, tassa kāmayānassa. Ruppatīti sokena ruppati.🔽Pariyuṭṭhānatāya tiṭṭhanasīlo pariyuṭṭhānaṭṭhāyī. “Pariyuṭṭhaṭṭhāyino”ti vā pāṭho,
analyzed: samitam ti saṅgatam abbocchinnam ti attho kāmayānassa ati kāmayamānassa kāmaḥ yānam etassa ati vā kāmayānaḥ tassa kāmayānassa ruppati iti sokena ruppati  pariyuṭṭhāna tāya tiṭṭhana sīlaḥ pariyuṭṭhāna ṭhāyī pariyuṭṭha ṭhāyinaḥ iti vā pāṭhaḥ
translated: “Joined” : conjoined, is the meaning. “Yearning” : one who is yearning, or one who has desire as his vehicle, is a “yearner” . “He suffers” : he suffers with grief.🔽“One who has the nature of standing by way of obsession” : one who has the nature of standing by way of obsession. The reading “pariyuṭṭhaṭṭhāyī” is also correct.

original: tattha pariyuṭṭhātīti pariyuṭṭhaṃ, diṭṭhipariyuṭṭhaṃ, tena tiṭṭhatīti pariyuṭṭhaṭṭhāyīti🔽attho daṭṭhabbo. Pañca pubbanimittānīti “mālā milāyanti, vatthāni kilissanti, kacchehi
analyzed: tattha pariyuṭṭhāti iti pariyuṭṭham diṭṭhi pariyuṭṭham tena tiṭṭhati iti pariyuṭṭha ṭhāyī iti  atthaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ pañca pubba nimittāni iti mālāḥ milāyanti vatthāni kilissanti kacchehi
translated: Herein, “he stands by way of obsession” is “pariyuṭṭhaṭṭhāyī” .

original: sedā muccanti, kāye vevaṇṇiyaṃ okkamati, devo devāsane nābhiramatī”ti vuttāni pañca
analyzed: sedāḥ muccanti kāye vevaṇṇiyam okkamati devaḥ devāsane na abhiramati iti vuttāni pañca
translated: The meaning should be regarded thus. “The five signs” : the five signs of death, called “the garlands fade, the clothes become soiled, sweat oozes from the armpits, the body assumes a different aspect, the deva no longer enjoys his deva-seat” .

original: maraṇapubbanimittānīti attho. Tāni hi disvā kammanibbattakkhandhasaṅkhāte upapattibhave
analyzed: maraṇa pubba nimittāni iti atthaḥ tāni hi disvā kamma nibbatta kkhandha saṅkhāte upapatti bhave
translated: The meaning is: the five signs of death.🔽For when he sees these, strong grief arises in the devas by the force of his craving for existence in the rebirth-process consisting of aggregates produced by kamma.

original: bhavachandabalena devānaṃ balavasoko uppajjatīti. Bāloti avidvā. Tena avijjāya kāraṇabhāvaṃ
analyzed: bhava chanda balena devānam balava sokaḥ uppajjati iti bālaḥ iti avidvā tena avijjāya kāraṇa bhāvam
translated: “The fool” : the undiscerning.

original: dasseti. Tividhanti tassāruppakathāsavanakammakāraṇādassanamaraṇakālakammopaṭṭhānanidānaṃ
analyzed: dasseti tividhanti
translated: and the three kinds of suffering are the suffering of seeing, the suffering of hearing, etc., the suffering of dying, and the suffering of the time of death.

original: sokādidukkhaṃ. Āsave sādhentīti āsave gamenti bodhentīti attho.
analyzed: soka ādi dukkham āsave sādhenti iti āsave gamenti bodhenti iti attho
translated: “They lead to cankers”: they cause cankers to come about; the meaning is, they cause cankers to be born.

original: Evaṃ satīti aviditāditāya anādibhāve sati. Ādimattakathanantiādi etassa atthīti ādimaṃ,
analyzed: evam sati iti avidita āditāya anādi bhāve sati etassa atthi iti ādimam
translated: “If this is so”: if it is so that it has no beginning. “The statement of a beginning”: the beginning is that which is at the beginning of this;

original: bhavacakkaṃ. Tassa bhāvo ādimattaṃ, tassa kathanaṃ ādimattakathanaṃ. Visesanivattiattho
analyzed: bhava cakkam tassa bhāvaḥ ādimattam tassa kathanam ādimatta kathanam visesa nivatti attho
translated: the round of rebirths is what is meant. The state of being that is the beginning is the beginningness. The statement of that is the statement of a beginning.

original: vā matta-saddo, sati anādibhāve avijjā ādimhi majjhe pariyosāne ca sabbattha siyāti
analyzed: vā matta saddaḥ sati anādi bhāve avijjā ādimhi majjhe pariyosāne ca sabbattha siyāti
translated: Or the word “matta” has the meaning of “special” or “particular.” If there is no beginning, then ignorance would be at the beginning, in the middle, and at the end, in all places.

original: ādimattāya avijjāya kathanaṃ virujjhatīti attho. Avijjāggahaṇenāti avijjāya uppādanena🔽kathanena, appahānena vā, attano santāne sannihitabhāvakaraṇenāti attho. Kammādīnīti
analyzed: ādimattāya avijjāya kathanam virujjhati iti atthaḥ avijjā ggahaṇena ati avijjāya uppādanena  kathanena appahānena vā attano santāne sannihita bhāva karaṇena ati attho kamma ādīni iti
translated: Therefore the statement of a beginning by way of ignorance is contradicted. The meaning is: by the statement of ignorance, by the production of ignorance,

original: kammavipākavaṭṭāni. Vaṭṭakāraṇabhāvena padhānattā “padhānadhammo”ti avijjā kathitā.
analyzed: kamma vipāka vaṭṭāni vaṭṭa kāraṇa bhāvena padhāna ttā padhāna dhammaḥ ti avijjā kathitā
translated: by the non-abandonment of ignorance, by the bringing about of its presence in one’s own continuum. “Kamma, etc.”: the rounds of kamma and result. Ignorance is called “the principal state” because it is pre-eminent as the cause of the round.

original: Vadatīti vado. Vedeti, vediyatīti vā vedeyyo, sukhādiṃ anubhavati, sabbavisaye vā
analyzed: vadati iti vadaḥ vedeti vediyati iti vā vedeyyaḥ sukha ādim anubhavati sabba visaye vā
translated: “It speaks” is “speech” . “It is felt” or “it is to be felt” is “what is to be felt” . It experiences pleasure, etc., or it knows all objects.

original: jānāti, “sukhito”tiādinā attanā parehi ca jānāti ñāyati cāti attho. Brahmādinā vā
analyzed: jānāti sukhita uti ādinā attanā parehi ca jānāti ñāyati ca ati atthaḥ brahma ādinā vā
translated: The meaning is that it is known by itself and by others as “happy,” etc. Or the meaning of “it” is the meaning of “and” .

original: attanā vāti vā-saddo ca-saddattho. Tenāha “kārakavedakarahita”nti ca-saddatthasamāsaṃ.
analyzed: attanā vā ati vāsaddaḥ tena āha kāraka vedaka rahitanti casaddattha samāsam
translated: Therefore he said “without an agent or a knower” , which is a compound of the meaning of “and.”

original: Dvādasavidhasuññatāsuññanti avijjādīnaṃ dvādasavidhānaṃ suññatāya suññaṃ, catubbidhampi
analyzed: dvādasavidha suñña tā suññanti avijja ādīnam dvādasavidhānam suñña tāya suññam catubbidham pi
translated: “Emptiness of the twelvefold” : empty of the twelvefold emptiness of ignorance, etc., or else, taking the fourfold emptiness as one,

original: vā suññataṃ ekaṃ katvā dvādasaṅgatāya dvādasavidhāti tāya dvādasavidhāya suññatāya suññanti attho.
analyzed: vā suññatam ekam katvā dvādasaṅgatāya tāya dvādasavidhāya suññatāya suññanti attho
translated: it is “twelvefold” because of its connection with the twelve . The meaning is: empty of that twelvefold emptiness.

original: Pubbantāharaṇatoti pubbantato paccuppannavipākassa āharaṇato paricchinnavedanāvasānaṃ
analyzed: pubbanta āharaṇato ti pubbantataḥ paccuppanna vipākassa āharaṇato paricchinna vedanā avasānam
translated: “Because it is brought from the past” : the meaning is that it is limited by feeling because it is brought from the past, from the beginningless past.

original: etaṃ bhavacakkanti attho. Bhavacakkekadesopi hi bhavacakkanti vuccati. Vedanā vā
analyzed: etam bhava cakkan ti atthaḥ bhava cakka ikadesaḥ api hi bhava cakkan ti vuccati vedanā vā
translated: For a part of the wheel of existence is also called “wheel of existence.” Or feeling

original: taṇhāsahāyāya avijjāya paccayo hotīti vedanāto avijjā, tato saṅkhārāti sambajjhanato
analyzed: taṇhā sahāyāya avijjāya paccayaḥ hoti iti vedanātaḥ avijjā tatas saṅkhārā ati sambajjhanato
translated: is “ignorance” because it is a condition for ignorance, which is accompanied by craving, and “formations” because it is mixed with ignorance.

original: vedanāvasānaṃ bhavacakkanti yuttametaṃ, evaṃ taṇhāmūlake ca yojetabbaṃ. Dvinnampi🔽hi aññamaññaṃ anuppaveso hotīti. Avijjā dhammasabhāvaṃ paṭicchādetvā viparītābhinivesaṃ
analyzed: vedanā avasānam bhava cakkanti yuttam etam evam taṇhā mūlake ca yojetabbam dvinnam pi  hi aññam aññam anuppavesaḥ hoti iti avijjā dhamma sabhāvam paṭicchādetvā viparīta abhinivesam
translated: For the two are mutually productive.

original: karontī diṭṭhicarite saṃsāre nayati, tesaṃ vā saṃsāraṃ saṅkhārādipavattiṃ nayati
analyzed: karontī diṭṭhi carite saṃsāre nayati tesam vā saṃsāram saṅkhāra ādi pavattim nayati
translated: Ignorance, by concealing the individual essences of states and causing the misinterpretations of views, leads those of view-action to the round of rebirths, or it leads the round of the occurrence of formations, etc.,🔽to occur, thus it is said to be “the leader in the round of rebirths.” The fruit of ripening is the fruit of ripening of the past kamma.

original: pavattetīti “saṃsāranāyikā”ti vuttā. Phaluppattiyāti kattuniddeso. Viññāṇādipaccuppannaphaluppatti
analyzed: pavatteti iti saṃsāra nāyikā ati vuttā phala uppattiyā ti kattu niddesaḥ viññāṇa ādi paccuppanna phala uppatti
translated: For the fruit of ripening consisting in consciousness, etc., is seen here, and the non-ceasing of the ignorance and formations that are the conditions for that fruit of ripening in past becoming is revealed.🔽Or alternatively, the first wheel of the round of rebirths is called “the leader in the round of rebirths” because it leads the second wheel of the round of rebirths to occur.🔽The fruit of ripening is the fruit of ripening of the present kamma.

original: hi idha diṭṭhā, adiṭṭhānañca purimabhave attano hetūnaṃ avijjāsaṅkhārānaṃ phalaṃ
analyzed: hi idha diṭṭhāḥ adiṭṭhānam ca purima bhave attanaḥ hetūnam avijjā saṅkhārānam phalam
translated: For the fruit of ripening consisting in consciousness, etc., is seen here, and the non-ceasing of the ignorance and formations that are the conditions for that fruit of ripening in past becoming is revealed.

original: ajanetvā anupacchijjanaṃ pakāseti. Atha vā purimabhavacakkaṃ dutiyena sambandhaṃ
analyzed: a janetvā an upacchijjanam pakāseti atha vā purima bhava cakkam dutiyena sambandham
translated: Or alternatively, the first wheel of the round of rebirths is called “the leader in the round of rebirths” because it leads the second wheel of the round of rebirths to occur.🔽The fruit of ripening is the fruit of ripening of the present kamma.

original: vuttanti vedanāsaṅkhātassa phalassa uppattiyā taṇhādīnaṃ hetūnaṃ anupacchedaṃ pakāseti,
analyzed: vuttam ti vedanā saṅkhātassa phalassa uppattiyā taṇhā ādīnam hetūnam anupacchedam pakāseti
translated: For the fruit of ripening consisting in consciousness, etc., is seen here, and the non-ceasing of the ignorance and formations that are the conditions for that fruit of ripening in past becoming is revealed.🔽Or alternatively, the first wheel of the round of rebirths is called “the leader in the round of rebirths” because it leads the second wheel of the round of rebirths to occur.

original: tasmā phaluppattiyā kāraṇabhūtāya paṭhamassa bhavacakkassa hetūnaṃ anupacchedappakāsanatoti
analyzed: tasmā phala uppattiyā kāraṇa bhūtāya paṭhamassa bhava cakkassa hetūnam an upaccheda pakāsanato ti
translated: The fruit of ripening is the fruit of ripening of the present kamma.🔽For the fruit of ripening consisting in consciousness, etc., is seen here, and the non-ceasing of the ignorance and formations that are the conditions for that fruit of ripening in past becoming is revealed.🔽Or alternatively, the first wheel of the round of rebirths is called “the leader in the round of rebirths” because it leads the second wheel of the round of rebirths to occur.🔽The fruit

original: attho. Saṅkhārādīnameva vā phalānaṃ uppattiyā avijjādīnaṃ hetūnaṃ phalaṃ ajanetvā
analyzed: saṅkhāra ādīnam eva vā phalānam uppattiyāḥ avijjā ādīnam hetūnam phalam a janetvā
translated: Or else, without knowing that ignorance, etc., are the causes of the arising of formations, etc.,

original: anupacchedameva, viññāṇādihetūnaṃ vā saṅkhārādīnaṃ anubandhanameva pakāseti paṭhamaṃ
analyzed: an upacchedam eva viññāṇa ādi hetūnam vā saṅkhāra ādīnam anubandhanam eva pakāseti paṭhamam
translated: he shows only the continuity of the succession, or the uninterrupted arising of the effects from the causes, or the uninterrupted arising of the causes in relation to the effects.🔽He shows the first cycle of existence, not the second, which has an end.

original: bhavacakkaṃ, na dutiyaṃ viya pariyosānampīti “phaluppattiyā hetūnaṃ anupacchedappakāsanato”ti🔽vuttaṃ. “Viññāṇapaccayā nāmarūpa”nti ettha aparipuṇṇāyatanakalalarūpaṃ vatvā tato
analyzed: bhava cakkam na dutiyam viya pariyosānam pi iti phala uppattiyāḥ hetūnam an upaccheda pakāsanato ti  vuttam viññāṇa paccayā nāma rūpan ti ettha a paripuṇṇa āyatana kalala rūpam vatvā tatas
translated: “Because it shows the continuity of the succession of causes and effects” means that he shows the continuity of the succession of causes and effects.🔽“Because it shows the successive arising” means that in the passage, “With consciousness as condition, mentality-materiality” , he first mentions the materiality of the kalala stage, which is incomplete in its sense faculties,

original: uddhaṃ “nāmarūpapaccayā saḷāyatana”nti saḷāyatanappavatti vuttāti āha “anupubbapavattidīpanato”ti.
analyzed: uddham nāma rūpa paccayā saḷāyatanan ti saḷāyatana ppavatti vuttā iti āha anupubba pavatti dīpanato ti
translated: and then he shows the arising of the six sense bases in the passage, “With mentality-materiality as condition, the six sense bases” .

original: “Bhavapaccayā jātī”ti ettha na āyatanānaṃ kamena uppatti vuttāti āha “sahuppattidīpanato”ti.
analyzed: bhava paccayā jāti iti ettha na āyatanānam kamena uppatti vuttā iti āha sahuppatti dīpanato ti
translated: “Because it shows the simultaneous arising” means that in the passage, “With birth as condition, aging and death” , he does not show the gradual arising of the sense bases.🔽The cycle of existence has three junctions beginning with the cause, etc.

original: Hetuādipubbakā tayo sandhī etassāti hetuphalahetupubbakatisandhi, bhavacakkaṃ. Hetuphalahetuphalavasena
analyzed: hetu ādi pubbakā tayo sandhī etassa ati hetu phala hetu pubbaka tisandhi bhava cakkam hetu phala hetu phala vasena
translated: The cycle of existence is threefold: beginning with the cause, beginning with the effect, and beginning with the cause and effect.

original: catuppabhedo aṅgānaṃ saṅgaho etassāti catubhedasaṅgahaṃ. Sarūpato avuttāpi tasmiṃ
analyzed: catu pabhedaḥ aṅgānam saṅgahaḥ etassa ati catu bheda saṅgaham sarūpataḥ a vuttā api tasmin
translated: The collection of the factors in four ways is the fourfold collection.

original: tasmiṃ saṅgahe ākirīyanti avijjāsaṅkhārādiggahaṇehi pakāsīyantīti ākārā, atītahetuādīnaṃ🔽vā pakārā ākārā. Kilesakammavipākā vipākakilesakammehi sambandhā hutvā punappunaṃ
analyzed: tasmin saṅgahe ākirīyanti avijjā saṅkhāra ādi gahaṇehi pakāsīyanti iti ākārāḥ atīta hetu ādīnam  vā pakārā ākārā kilesa kamma vipākā vipāka kilesa kammehi sambandhāḥ hutvā punappunam
translated: The aspects are so called because ignorance, formations, and so on are “strewn” in each collection, that is, are revealed by the inclusion of ignorance, formations, and so on.🔽Or the aspects are the modes of the past cause, etc.

original: parivattantīti tesu vaṭṭanāmaṃ āropetvā “tivaṭṭa”nti vuttaṃ, vaṭṭekadesattā vā “vaṭṭānī”ti vuttāni.
analyzed: parivattanti iti tesu vaṭṭa nāmam āropetvā ti vaṭṭanti vuttam vaṭṭa eka desa ttā vā vaṭṭāni iti vuttāni
translated: They are called “the three rounds” because they revolve again and again, being connected with defilement, action, and result, and result, defilement, and action. Or they are called “the three rounds” because they are parts of the round .

original: Sandhīnaṃ ādipariyosānavavatthitāti sandhīnaṃ pubbāparavavatthitāti attho.🔽“Yā kāci vā pana cetanā bhavo, cetanāsampayuttā āyūhanasaṅkhārā”ti idaṃ imissā dhammaṭṭhitiñāṇabhājanīye
analyzed: sandhīnam ādi pariyosāna vavatthitā ati sandhīnam pubba apara vavatthitā ati atthaḥ  yā kāci vā pana cetanā cetanā sampayuttā āyūhana saṅkhārā ati idam imissā dhamma ṭṭhiti ñāṇa bhājanīye
translated: The junctions are defined by a beginning and an end. The meaning is that the junctions are defined by a prior and a subsequent .🔽“Or any volition whatever is becoming; the formations that are accumulated are associated with volition” . This is said according to the text of the Paṭisambhidā, which is given in the Dhamma-satipatthāna . For there it is said: “Any volition whatever is becoming” .

original: vuttāya paṭisambhidāpāḷiyā vasena vuttaṃ. Ettha hi “cetanā bhavo”ti āgatāti. Bhavaniddese
analyzed: vuttāya paṭisambhidā pāḷiyā vasena vuttam ettha hi cetanā bhavaḥ ti āgatā ati bhava niddese
translated: In the Bhavaniddesa it is said:

original: pana “sātthato”ti ettha “cetanāva saṅkhārā, bhavo pana cetanāsampayuttāpī”ti vibhaṅgapāḷiyā
analyzed: pana sā atthato ti ettha cetanā ava saṅkhārāḥ cetanā sampayuttā api iti vibhaṅga pāḷiyā
translated: But in the case of the words “from the point of view of what is profitable” , it is shown in the Vibhaṅga text thus: “The formations are only volition, but becoming is associated with volition too” .

original: vasena dassitaṃ. “Tattha katamo puññābhisaṅkhāro? Kusalā cetanā kāmāvacarā”tiādinā🔽hi saṅkhārānaṃ cetanābhāvo vibhaṅgapāḷiyaṃ vuttoti. Tattha paṭisambhidāpāḷiyaṃ “cetanāsampayuttā
analyzed: vasena dassitam tattha katamo puñña abhisaṅkhāro kusalā cetanā kāmāvacarā iti ādinā  hi saṅkhārānam cetanā bhāvaḥ vibhaṅga pāḷiyam vuttaḥ ti tattha paṭisambhidā pāḷiyam cetanā sampayuttā
translated: For in the Vibhaṅga text the formations are stated to be volition thus: “Herein, what is the formation of merit? It is profitable volition belonging to the sense sphere” .

original: vipākadhammattā savipākena āyūhanasaṅkhātena saṅkhatābhisaṅkharaṇakiccena saṅkhārā”ti
analyzed: vipāka dhamma ttā sa vipākena āyūhana saṅkhātena saṅkhata abhisaṅkharaṇa kiccena
translated: There the formations are said in the Paṭisambhidā text to be “associated with volition” and to be “formed by accumulation” because they are states that have result by way of the function of forming what is formed by accumulation.

original: vuttā. Vibhaṅgapāḷiyaṃ “sabbampi bhavagāmikammaṃ kammabhavo”ti bhavassa paccayabhāvena
analyzed: vuttā vibhaṅga pāḷiyam sabbam pi bhava gāmi kammam kamma bhavaḥ ti bhavassa paccaya bhāvena
translated: In the Vibhaṅga text they are said to be “becoming” because they are a condition for becoming by the words “All kamma that leads to becoming is kamma-process becoming” ,

original: bhavagāmibhāvato kammasaṃsaṭṭhasahāyatāya kammabhāvato ca upapattibhavaṃ bhāventīti🔽bhavoti vuttā, upapattibhavabhāvanakiccaṃ pana cetanāya sātisayanti paṭisambhidāpāḷiyaṃ
analyzed: bhava gāmi bhāvataḥ kamma saṃsaṭṭha sahāya tāya kamma bhāvataḥ ca upapatti bhavam bhāventi iti 🔽bhavaḥ ti vuttā upapatti bhava bhāvana kiccam pana cetanāya paṭisambhidā pāḷiyam
translated: and because they “cause to become” rebirth-process becoming by the state of being kamma that is mixed up with kamma that leads to becoming and by the state of being a companion to it.🔽But the function of causing rebirth-process becoming to come to be is more outstanding in volition, so it is said in the Paṭisambhidā text.

original: cetanā “bhavo”ti vuttā, bhavābhisaṅkharaṇakiccaṃ cetanāya sātisayanti vibhaṅgapāḷiyaṃ
analyzed: cetanā bhavaḥ ti vuttā bhava abhisaṅkharaṇa kiccam cetanāya vibhaṅga pāḷiyam
translated: Volition is called “existence” in the Vibhaṅga text, which says: “What is existence? It is volition” .🔽And volition is called “formations” in the Vibhaṅga text, which says: “What are formations? They are the volition of one who is subject to the possibility of being reborn in a particular place of rebirth” .

original: “kusalā cetanā”tiādinā cetanā “saṅkhārā”ti vuttā, tasmā tena tena pariyāyena ubhayaṃ
analyzed: kusalā cetanā ati ādinā cetanā saṅkhārā ati vuttā tasmā tena tena pariyāyena ubhayam
translated: So both terms are applicable in both places.🔽There is no contradiction here.

original: ubhayattha vattuṃ yuttanti natthettha virodho. Gahaṇanti kāmupādānaṃ kiccenāha. Parāmasananti🔽itarāni. Āyūhanāvasāneti tīsupi atthavikappesu vuttassa āyūhanassa avasāne.
analyzed: ubhayattha vattum yuttam ti nattha ittha virodhaḥ gahaṇanti kāma upādānam kiccena āha parāmasananti  itarāni āyūhana avasāne ti tīsu pi attha vikappesu vuttassa āyūhanassa avasāne
translated: As regards the phrase “grasping by the act of grasping” , the grasping is the grasping of sense pleasures.🔽As regards the phrase “by assuming” , the other three kinds of grasping are meant.🔽As regards the phrase “at the end of the accumulation” , the accumulation spoken of in the three ways is meant.

original: Dvīsu atthavikappesu vutte āyūhanasaṅkhāre “tassa pubbabhāgā”ti āha, tatiye vutte🔽“taṃsampayuttā”ti. Daharassa cittappavatti bhavaṅgabahulā yebhuyyena bhavantarajanakakammāyūhanasamatthā
analyzed: dvīsu attha vikappesu vutte āyūhana saṅkhāre tassa pubba bhāgā ti āha tatiye vutte  tad sampayuttā ati daharassa citta ppavatti bhavaṅga bahulā yebhuyyena bhavantara janaka kamma āyūhana samatthā
translated: As regards the phrase “the prior part of that” , the formations of accumulation spoken of in the first two ways are meant.🔽As regards the phrase “associated with that” , the accumulation spoken of in the third way is meant.🔽The occurrence of consciousness in an infant is mostly bhavanga . It is not usually capable of accumulating kamma that will generate a new existence.

original: na hotīti “idha paripakkattā āyatanāna”nti vuttaṃ. Kammakaraṇakāle sammohoti etena
analyzed: na hoti iti idha paripakka ttā āyatanānam ti vuttam kamma karaṇa kāle sammoho ti etena
translated: That is why it is said, “because the bases are not yet mature” .

original: kammassa paccayabhūtaṃ sammohaṃ dasseti, na kammasampayuttameva.
analyzed: kammassa paccaya bhūtam sammoham dasseti na kamma sampayuttam eva
translated: The phrase “delusion at the time of performing kamma” shows the delusion that is a condition for kamma, not only that associated with kamma.

original: Kammāneva vipākaṃ sambharanti vaḍḍhentīti kammasambhārā, kammaṃ vā saṅkhārabhavā,
analyzed: kammān eva vipākam sambharanti vaḍḍhenti iti kamma sambhārā kammam vā saṅkhāra bhavā
translated: They are called “kamma-process-accumulations” because they accumulate and increase kamma’s result. Or kamma is the process of becoming consisting of formations.

original: tadupakārakāni avijjātaṇhupādānāni kammasambhārā, paṭisandhidāyako vā bhavo kammaṃ,🔽tadupakārakā yathāvuttaāyūhanasaṅkhārā avijjādayo ca kammasambhārāti kammañca kammasambhārā🔽ca kammasambhārāti ekasesaṃ katvā “kammasambhārā”ti āha. Dasa dhammā kammanti avijjādayopi
analyzed: tad upakārakāni avijjā taṇhā upādānāni kamma sambhārā paṭisandhi dāyakaḥ vā bhavaḥ kammam  tad upakārakāḥ yathā vutta āyūhana saṅkhārāḥ avijjā ādayaḥ ca kamma sambhārā ati kamman ca kamma sambhārā  ca kamma sambhārā ti ekasesam katvā kamma sambhārā ti āha dasa dhammā kammanti avijjā ādayaḥ api
translated: Ignorance, craving and clinging, which assist it, are the kamma-process-accumulations. Or becoming, which gives rebirth-linking, is kamma.🔽The other formations that assist it, namely ignorance, etc., are the kamma-process-accumulations. So kamma and the kamma-process- accumulations are called “kamma-process-accumulations” by ellipsis of the middle term.

original: kammasahāyatāya kammasarikkhakā tadupakārakā cāti “kamma”nti vuttā.🔽Saṅkhippanti ettha avijjādayo viññāṇādayo cāti saṅkhepo, kammaṃ vipāko ca. Kammaṃ
analyzed: kamma sahāya tāya kamma sarikkhakā tad upakārakā ca ati kammanti vuttā  ettha avijjā ādayaḥ viññāṇa ādayo ca ati saṅkhepo kammam vipāko ca kammaṃ
translated: The ten states called “kamma” are ignorance, etc., which are called “kamma” because they are similar to kamma and assist kamma by being its concomitants.

original: vipākoti evaṃ saṅkhipīyatīti vā saṅkhepo, avijjādayo viññāṇādayo ca. Saṅkhepabhāvasāmaññena
analyzed: evam evam saṅkhipīyati iti vā saṅkhepaḥ avijjā ādayaḥ viññāṇa ādayo ca saṅkhepa bhāva sāmaññena
translated: “Condensed” : here the “condensed” is ignorance, etc., and consciousness, etc. Kamma and result are condensed, or they are condensed in this way: “Kamma, result.”

original: pana ekavacanaṃ katanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Saṅkhepasaddo vā bhāgādhivacananti kammabhāgo kammasaṅkhepo.
analyzed: pana ekavacanam katam ti daṭṭhabbam saṅkhepa saddo vā bhāga adhivacananti kamma bhāgaḥ kamma saṅkhepo
translated: Or the word “condensed” is a collective term for the parts, so that “kamma-condensed” is the part consisting of kamma.

original: Evaṃ samuppannanti kammato vipāko. Tatthāpi avijjāto saṅkhārāti evaṃ samuppannaṃ,
analyzed: evam samuppannanti kammataḥ vipāko tattha api avijjātaḥ saṅkhārā ti evam samuppannam
translated: “Arisen thus” means “arisen as result from kamma.” Herein, “arisen thus” means “arisen thus from ignorance as formations,”

original: tisandhiādivasena vā samuppannaṃ idaṃ bhavacakkanti attho. Ittaranti gamanadhammaṃ,
analyzed: ti sandhi ādi vasena vā samuppannam idam bhava cakkan ti attho gamana dhammam
translated: or “arisen thus with three links, etc.,” and the meaning is that this is the wheel of becoming. “To be transcended” : subject to passing away,

original: vinassadhammanti attho. Tena uppādavayavantatādīpakena anicca-saddena vikārāpattidīpakena
analyzed: vinassa dhammanti atthaḥ tena uppāda vayavanta tā dīpakena anicca saddena vikāra āpatti dīpakena
translated: subject to destruction, is the meaning. By the word “impermanent,” which signifies origination and dissolution, etc.,

original: cala-saddena ca adīpitaṃ kālantaraṭṭhāyitāpaṭikkhepaṃ dīpeti, adhuvanti etena thirabhāvapaṭikkhepaṃ
analyzed: cala saddena ca a dīpitam kāla antara ṭṭhāyi tā paṭikkhepam dīpeti etena thira bhāva paṭikkhepam
translated: and by the word “unstable,” which signifies the state of change, he shows that it is denied that it endures for a second instant. By the word “not lasting” he shows that it is denied that it endures for a long time.

original: nissārataṃ. Hetū eva sambhārā hetusambhārā. “Ṭhānaso hetuso”ti ettha evaṃ vuttaṃ🔽vā ṭhānaṃ, aññampi tassa tassa sādhāraṇaṃ kāraṇaṃ sambhāro, asādhāraṇaṃ hetu. Evanti
analyzed: nissāratam hetū eva sambhārāḥ hetu sambhārāḥ ṭhānasaḥ hetuso ti ettha evam vuttam  vā ṭhānam aññam pi tassa tassa sādhāraṇam kāraṇam sambhāraḥ asādhāraṇam hetu evanti
translated: “Causes” are the conditions. “Conditions as cause” are the conditions that are causes. Herein, “conditions” are of two kinds, specific and general.🔽“Specific” is said of a condition that is specific to an action, such as the eye faculty for eye-consciousness. “General” is said of a condition that is common to many actions, such as light for eye-consciousness.🔽“Thus” means in this way.

original: evaṃ hetuto dhammamattasambhave hetunirodhā ca vaṭṭupacchede dhamme ca taṃnirodhāya
analyzed: evam hetutaḥ dhamma matta sambhave hetu nirodhā ca vaṭṭa upacchede dhamme ca tad nirodhāya
translated: The meaning is: when the mere states of dhammas have arisen thus from causes, and when the cessation of the causes is taught for the purpose of cutting off the round of existence, and when the states of dhammas are taught for the purpose of attaining that cessation,

original: desite satīti attho. Brahmacariyaṃ idha brahmacariyidha. Satte cāti ettha ca-saddo
analyzed: desite sati iti atthaḥ brahmacariyam satte ca ati ettha ca saddaḥ
translated: “The holy life” is the life of purity. “Here” is in this life. “Beings” : the word “ca”

original: evaṃ brahmacariyañca vijjati, sassatucchedā ca na hontīti samuccayattho. Evañhi hetuāyatte
analyzed: evam brahmacariyam ca vijjati ca na honti iti samuccaya tthaḥ evam hi hetu āyatte
translated: and so the life of purity is possible, and there is no eternalism or annihilationism. This is the meaning of the compound.🔽For when there is the mere occurrence of states, a being is not apprehended,

original: dhammamattasambhave satto nupalabbhati, tasmiñca upalabbhante sassato ucchedo vā
analyzed: dhamma matta sambhave sattaḥ na upalabbhati tasmin ca upalabbhante sassataḥ ucchedaḥ vā
translated: and if it were apprehended, it would be eternal or subject to annihilation.

original: siyā, nupalabbhante tasmiṃ nevucchedo na sassatanti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: siyā na upalabbhante tasmin na iva ucchedaḥ na vuttam hoti
translated: But when it is not apprehended, it is neither subject to annihilation nor eternal.🔽“From the origin of truth”: from the truth, or from the origin of truths.

original: Saccappabhavatoti saccato, saccānaṃ vā pabhavato. Kusalākusalaṃ kammanti vaṭṭakathāya
analyzed: sacca ppabhavato ti saccataḥ saccānam vā pabhavato kusala akusalam kammanti vaṭṭa kathāya
translated: Since it occurs in the exposition of the round, it is known as “subject to cankers.”

original: vattamānattā sāsavanti viññāyati. Avisesenāti cetanā cetanāsampayuttakāti visesaṃ
analyzed: vattamāna ttā sāsavanti viññāyati avisesena ati cetanā cetanā sampayuttakā ati visesam
translated: Without distinction: without making the distinction that it is volition and associated with volition.

original: akatvā sabbampi taṃ kusalākusalaṃ kammaṃ “samudayasacca”nti vuttanti attho. “Taṇhā🔽ca…pe… avasesā ca sāsavā kusalā dhammā”ti hi cetanācetanāsampayuttavisesaṃ akatvā
analyzed: a katvā sabbam pi tam kusala akusalam kammam samudaya saccan ti vuttanti atthaḥ taṇhā  cape avasesā ca sa āsavā kusalā dhammā ti hi cetanā cetanā sampayutta visesam a katvā
translated: The meaning is: all that profitable and unprofitable kamma is called “the truth of the origin.”

original: vuttanti, ariyasaccavisesaṃ vā akatvā samudayasaccanti vuttanti attho.
analyzed: vuttanti ariya sacca visesam vā a katvā samudaya saccan ti vuttanti attho
