analyzed: hi etāḥ niruttiyaḥ ti iminā vā adhippāyena avijjā paccayā avijjā atipi vuttam siyāti āha ati  daṭṭhabbam iminā āva adhippāyena bhavassa nippadesa ttā bhava paccayā api upādānam ti
translated: “It might be said that ‘ignorance is a condition for ignorance’ is stated with this intention.🔽With this intention it should be understood that ‘because of the non-specification of becoming, “clinging is a condition for becoming” is not stated.’ The meaning of this is stated in the section on the conditionality of mutual dependence.

original: na vutta”nti ayamattho aññamaññapaccayavāre vuttoti daṭṭhabbo. Tattha pacchinnattāti
analyzed: na vuttanti ayam attho aññamañña paccaya vāre vuttaḥ ti daṭṭhabbaḥ tattha pacchinna ttā ti
translated: There, by the words ‘because of the severance’

original: etena jātijarāmaraṇānaṃ avijjāya paccayabhāvo anuññāto viya hoti. Jāyamānānaṃ pana
analyzed: etena jāti jarā maraṇānam avijjāya paccaya bhāvaḥ anuññātaḥ viya hoti jāyamānānam pana
translated: the fact that birth, aging, and death are a condition for ignorance is as if allowed. But birth is of what is being born,

original: jāti, na jātiyā jāyamānā, jīyamānamīyamānañca jarāmaraṇaṃ, na jarāmaraṇassa jīyamānamīyamānāti🔽jātiādīni ekacittakkhaṇe na avijjāya paccayo honti, tasmā asambhavato eva tammūlakā
analyzed: jāti na jātiyāḥ jāyamānā jīyamāna mīyamānam ca jarā maraṇam na jarā maraṇassa jīyamāna mīyamānā ati  jāti ādīni eka cittakkhaṇe na avijjāya paccayaḥ honti tasmā asambhavataḥ eva tad mūlakā
translated: not of ignorance; and aging and death are of what is living and of what is dying, not of ignorance.

original: nayā na gahitā, pacchedopi pana atthīti “tattha pacchinnattā”ti vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: nayā na gahitā pacchedaḥ api pana atthi iti tattha pacchinna ttā ati vuttan ti daṭṭhabbaṃ
translated: Therefore, because of impossibility, the method based on that is not taken. But there is also severance, and so it should be understood that the words ‘because of the severance’ are stated.

original: Teneva “apicā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: tena iva api ca ati ādim āha
translated: Therefore he said ‘Besides.’

original: Mātikāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: mātikā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the mātikā is finished.

original: Akusalaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: akusala niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the description of the unprofitable

original: 248-249. Upādānassa upādānapaccayattaṃ āpajjeyyāti nanu nāyaṃ doso. Kāmupādānañhi🔽diṭṭhupādānassa, tañca itarassa paccayo hotīti? Saccaṃ, kāmupādānassa pana taṇhāgahaṇena🔽gahitattā nāme viya visesapaccayattābhāvā ca upādānaggahaṇena taṇhāpaccayā bhavassa
analyzed: upādānassa upādāna paccaya ttam āpajjeyya ati nanu na ayam dosaḥ kāma upādānam hi  diṭṭhupādānassa tat ca itarassa paccayaḥ hoti iti saccam kāma upādānassa pana taṇhā gahaṇena  gahita ttā nāme viya visesa paccaya ttā abhāvā ca upādāna ggahaṇena taṇhā paccayā bhavassa
translated: “Would it not be a fault to say that clinging is a condition for clinging? For clinging to sense desires

original: ca paccayabhūtā diṭṭhi eva gahitāti ayaṃ doso vuttoti daṭṭhabbo. Yasmā ca upādānaṭṭhāne🔽paccayuppannaṃ paccayo ca ekameva, tasmā “nāmapaccayā phasso, nāmarūpapaccayā saḷāyatana”nti
analyzed: ca paccaya bhūtā diṭṭhi eva gahitā ati ayam doso vuttaḥ ti daṭṭhabbaḥ yasmā ca upādānaṭṭhāne  paccaya uppannam paccayaḥ ca ekam eva tasmai nāma paccayā phassaḥ nāma rūpa paccayā saṅgāyatanam ti
translated: is a condition for clinging to views, and that is a condition for the other?”—True. But the fault is stated thus: “Because craving is included by the word ‘clinging’ in the phrase ‘with craving as condition,’ and because there is no distinction in the words, clinging is included by the word ‘clinging’ in the phrase ‘with clinging as condition,’ and so craving is included by the word ‘clinging’ in the phrase ‘with clinging as condition,’ and so craving is included by the word ‘clinging’ in the phrase ‘with clinging as condition’ as a condition for becoming.”🔽And since the condition that arises in the place of clinging is the same as the condition, therefore, just as in the exposition of the conditions for contact and for the sixfold base, the condition is not analyzed separately in the exposition of the condition for becoming,

original: etesaṃ niddesesu viya “upādānapaccayā bhavo”ti etassa niddese paccayo visuṃ na vibhatto.
analyzed: etesam niddesesu viya upādāna paccayā bhavaḥ ti etassa niddese paccayaḥ visum na vibhatto
translated: “with clinging as condition, becoming,”

original: Satipi vā bhavassa paccayabhāvena kāmupādānassapi gahaṇe “ṭhapetvā upādāna”nti avuccamāne
analyzed: sati api vā bhavassa paccaya bhāvena kāma upādānassa api gahaṇe ṭhapetvā upādānam ti a vuccamāne
translated: or, even though clinging to sense desires is included as a condition for becoming, since it is not mentioned in the phrase “except for clinging,”

original: kāmupādānaṃ kāmupādānassa, diṭṭhi ca diṭṭhiyā paccayoti āpajjeyyāti paccayapaccayuppannatānivāraṇatthaṃ
analyzed: kāma upādānam kāma upādānassa diṭṭhi ca diṭṭhiyā paccayaḥ ti āpajjeyya ati paccaya paccaya uppanna tā nivāraṇa attham
translated: “Would he fall into the error of saying that sense-desire clinging is a condition for sense-desire clinging and that a view is a condition for a view?”🔽🔽To prevent this, he said

original: “ṭhapetvā upādāna”nti vuttanti dasseti.
analyzed: ṭhapetvā upādānanti vuttanti dasseti
translated: He shows that he says “except for the kinds of clinging” in order to prevent the misapprehension that the condition and the conditionally-arisen are the same.

original: 252. Cakkhāyatanādiupatthambhakassa cittasamuṭṭhānarūpassa janakaṃ viññāṇaṃ cakkhāyatanupacayādīnaṃ
analyzed: cakkha āyatana ādi upatthambhakassa citta samuṭṭhāna rūpassa janakam viññāṇam cakkha āyatana upacaya ādīnam
translated: The meaning is: the consciousness that generates the materiality originated by consciousness which is the support of the eye base, etc., is a condition for the accumulation of the eye base, etc.,

original: paccayoti vuttaṃ tadajanakampīti adhippāyena “yassa cittasamuṭṭhānarūpassā”tiādimāha.🔽Tāsampi hīti utuāhārajasantatīnampi hi upatthambhakasamuṭṭhāpanapacchājātapaccayavasena
analyzed: paccayaḥ ti vuttam tat ajanakam pi iti adhippāyena yassa citta samuṭṭhāna rūpassa ati ādim āha  tāsam pi hi iti utu āhāra ja santatīnam pi hi upatthambhaka samuṭṭhāpana pacchājāta paccaya vasena
translated: but it is not intended to include that which does not generate them.

original: viññāṇaṃ paccayo hoti evāti attho.🔽254. Yathānurūpanti mahābhūtasaṅkhātaṃ pañcannaṃ sahajātādipaccayo, vatthusaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: viññāṇam paccayaḥ hoti eva ati attho  mahābhūta saṅkhātam pañcannam sahajāta ādi paccayaḥ vatthu saṅkhātam
translated: The meaning is: consciousness is a condition for the series of materiality originated by temperature and nutriment too, by way of support, generation, and postnascent condition.

original: chaṭṭhassa purejātādipaccayo, nāmaṃ pañcannaṃ pacchājātādipaccayo, chaṭṭhassa sahajātādipaccayoti esā yathānurūpatā.
analyzed: chaṭṭhassa purejāta ādi paccayo nāmam pañcannam pacchājāta ādi paccayo chaṭṭhassa sahajāta ādi paccayo ti esā yathā anurūpa tā
translated: As appropriate: the five beginning with the earth element are conascence, etc., conditions for the five beginning with the eye base; the sixth, the water element, is prenascence, etc., condition for the sixth, the eye faculty; the fifth, the fire element, is postnascence, etc., condition for the five beginning with the eye base; the fourth, the air element, is support, etc., condition for the sixth, the eye faculty. This is the appropriateness.

original: 264. Yassāti yassa paccayuppannassa nāmassa viññāṇassa sampayuttapaccayabhāvo hotīti yojetabbaṃ.🔽272. “Phassapaccayāpi nāma”nti phassapaccayabhāvena vattabbasseva nāmassa attano
analyzed: yassa ati yassa paccaya uppannassa nāmassa viññāṇassa sampayutta paccaya bhāvaḥ hoti iti yojetabbam  phassa paccayā api nāman ti phassa paccaya bhāvena vattabbassa iva nāmassa attanaḥ
translated: “Whose” should be construed as “whose consciousness, which is arisen subsequently, has the state of being a conascence condition.”

original: paccayuppannena pavatti dassitāti “ṭhapetvā phassa”nti puna vacane koci attho atthīti
analyzed: paccaya uppannena pavatti dassitā ati ṭhapetvā phassanti puna vacane koci atthaḥ atthi iti
translated: “Though it is said ‘with contact as condition, too’ ”: the occurrence of the name-element, which should be stated by way of contact condition, is shown by the words “with contact as condition” as having its own arisen subsequently. Therefore, in the statement “excepting contact,” there is no point in repeating “with contact as condition.”

original: na vuttanti dassento “tathāpī”tiādimāha.🔽280. Yasmā adhimokkhopi natthi, tasmā upādānaṭṭhānaṃ parihīnamevāti sambandho. Balavakilesena
analyzed: na vuttanti dassentaḥ tathā api itiādim āha  yasmai adhimokkhaḥ api na atthi tasmai upādānaṭṭhānam parihīnam eva ati sambandhaḥ balava kilesena
translated: Showing this, he says “Nevertheless” and so on.🔽Since there is no decisive support, the object of clinging is abandoned.

original: pana padapūraṇassa kāraṇaṃ taṇhāya abhāvo domanassasahagatesu vutto evāti tassa tena
analyzed: pana pada pūraṇassa kāraṇam taṇhāya abhāvaḥ domanassa sahagatesu vuttaḥ evā ti tassa tena
translated: The reason for the filling out of the line by a strong defilement is stated in the case of the associated with grief as the absence of craving. Therefore, that reason should be construed with this.

original: sambandho yojetabbo. Sabbatthāti tatiyacittādīsu “taṇhāpaccayā adhimokkho”tiādimhi
analyzed: sambandhaḥ yojetabbaḥ sabbattha ati tatiya citta ādīsu taṇhā paccayā adhimokkhaḥ ti ādimhi
translated: “Everywhere” in the third consciousness, etc., in the answer “with craving as condition: decisive support” and so on.🔽The text is abbreviated by showing only the difference in the answer.

original: vissajjanameva visesaṃ dassetvā pāḷi saṃkhittā. Heṭṭhāti cittuppādakaṇḍādīsu.🔽Akusalaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: vissajjanam eva visesam dassetvā saṃkhittā heṭṭhā ti cittuppāda kaṇḍa ādīsu  akusala niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: “Below” in the section on the arising of consciousness, etc.🔽The commentary on the description of the unprofitable is finished.

original: Kusalābyākataniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: kusala abyākata niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: Description of the indeterminate

original: 292. Pasādoti saddhā.
analyzed: saddhā
translated: “Confidence” is faith.

original: 306. “Alobho nidānaṃ kammānaṃ samudayāyā”tiādivacanato sabyāpārāni kusalamūlāni saṅkhārānaṃ
analyzed: alobhaḥ nidānam samudaya ayāti ādi vacanataḥ sa byāpārāni kusala mūlāni
translated: Because of the words, “Non-greed is a cause for the arising of kamma” , etc., the roots of profit with their functions are the causes for kamma formations.

original: nidānāni honti, na kammavegakkhittesu vipākesu alobhādisahagatakammapaṭibimbabhūtā🔽viya pavattamānā alobhādayoti pañcaviññāṇesu viya nidānarahitatā sotapatitatāti daṭṭhabbā.🔽Kiriyadhammā kiriyamattattā kammanidānarahitāicceva parihīnāvijjāṭṭhānā veditabbā.
analyzed: nidānāni honti na kamma vega kkhittesu vipākesu alobha ādi sahagata kamma paṭibimba bhūtā  viya pavattamānāḥ alobha ādayo ti pañca viññāṇesu viya nidāna rahita tā sota patita tā ati daṭṭhabbā  kiriya dhammā kiriya matta ttā kamma nidāna rahitā a icca iva parihīna a vijjāṭṭhānā veditabbā
translated: But non-greed, etc., are not causes in the way that the roots of profit with their functions are, which is as the reflections of kamma are in the case of the resultants that are flung out by kamma’s force.🔽So they should be regarded as not having a cause in the five consciousnesses.

They are called “devoid of the cause”

original: pana vasena tadāpi viññāṇapaccayā nāmarūpaṃ, pacchājātasahajātanāmassa sahajātapurejātabhūtacakkhādirūpassa
analyzed: pana vasena tadā api viññāṇa paccayā nāma rūpam pacchājāta sahajāta nāmassa sahajāta purejāta bhūta cakkha ādi rūpassa
translated: But even then, by means of the present, there is name-and-form with consciousness as condition, and by means of the future and the present, there is the sixfold base with name-and-form as condition, since there is the present name that is conascent with the future eye faculty, etc., and the materiality that is conascent with the present eye faculty, etc.

original: ca vasena nāmarūpapaccayā saḷāyatanañca labbhatīti tatiyacatutthavārā na na sambhavantīti.
analyzed: ca vasena nāma rūpa paccayā saḷāyatanam ca labbhati iti tatiya catuttha vārāḥ na na sambhavanti iti
translated: So the third and fourth sections are not impossible.

original: Kusalābyākataniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: kusala abyākata niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of the profitable and indeterminate is ended

original: Avijjāmūlakakusalaniddesavaṇṇanā🔽334. Sammohavasenāti kusalaphale aniccāditāya sabhaye sādurasavisarukkhabījasadise
analyzed: avijjā mūlaka kusala niddesa vaṇṇanā  sammoha vasena ati kusala phale anicca āditāya sa bhaye sādu rasa visa rukkha bīja sadise
translated: Description of the unprofitable rooted in ignorance

original: taṃnibbattakakusale ca anādīnavadassitāvasena. Samatikkamatthaṃ bhāvanā samatikkamabhāvanā,
analyzed: tad nibbattaka kusale ca anādīnava dassi tā vasena samatikkamattham bhāvanā samatikkama bhāvanā
translated: By means of delusion: by means of the delusion consisting in the failure to understand the danger in the unprofitable and in the unprofitable kamma-result, and by means of the delusion consisting in the failure to understand the three characteristics of impermanence, etc., in the profitable and in the profitable kamma-result, which resemble a poisonous plant and a poisonous tree respectively.🔽The development that is a surmounting is development as surmounting;

original: tadaṅgavikkhambhanavasena samatikkamabhūtā vā bhāvanā samatikkamabhāvanā.🔽Tathā idha na labbhantīti avijjāya eva saṅkhārānaṃ avigatādipaccayattābhāvaṃ sandhāya
analyzed: tad aṅga vikkhambhana vasena samatikkama bhūtā vā bhāvanā samatikkama bhāvanā  tathā idha na labbhanti iti avijjāya eva saṅkhārānam avigata ādi paccaya tā abhāvam sandhāya
translated: or it is development that has become a surmounting by the abandoning of the factors that should be abandoned by means of that development.🔽So too here: it is said with reference to the fact that formations do not have ignorance as a condition by way of non-separation, etc.;

original: vuttaṃ, viññāṇādīnaṃ pana saṅkhārādayo avigatādipaccayā hontīti avijjāpaccayā saṅkhāro,
analyzed: vuttam viññāṇa ādīnam pana saṅkhāra ādayo avigata ādi paccayāḥ honti iti avijjā paccayā saṅkhāro
translated: but formations, etc., do have ignorance as a condition by way of non-separation, etc. Thus it is said: “With ignorance as condition there are formations.

original: saṅkhārapaccayā viññāṇaṃ saṅkhārahetukantiādinā yojanā na na sakkā kātunti avigatacatukkādīnipi
analyzed: saṅkhāra paccayā viññāṇam saṅkhāra hetukan ti ādinā yojanā na na sakkā kātunti avigata catukka ādīni pi
translated: and it is not impossible to construe the remaining triplets and so on in the same way, beginning “With formations as condition, consciousness that is rooted in formations” and so on.

original: na idha labbhanti. Viññāṇapaccayā nāmarūpaṃ viññāṇasampayuttaṃ nāmantiādinā hi yathālābhayojanāya nayo dassitoti.
analyzed: na idha labbhanti viññāṇa paccayāḥ nāma rūpam viññāṇa sampayuttam nāma nti ādinā hi yathā lābha yojanāya nayaḥ dassito ti
translated: So the remaining triplets and so on are not given here. For the method of construing them is shown by the method of construing the dyads beginning with “With consciousness as condition, mentality-materiality associated with consciousness” in the way appropriate to each case.

original: Avijjāmūlakakusalaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: avijjā mūlaka kusala niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of unprofitable consciousness rooted in ignorance is ended.

original: Kusalamūlakavipākaniddesavaṇṇanā🔽343. “Nānākkhaṇikakammapaccaye pana vattabbameva natthī”ti vuttaṃ, kiṃ kusalamūlaṃ🔽akusalamūlañca kammapaccayo hotīti? Na hoti, kammapaccayabhūtāya pana cetanāya saṃsaṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: kusala mūlaka vipāka niddesa vaṇṇanā  nānākkhaṇika kamma paccaye pana vattabbam eva natthi iti vuttam kim kusala mūlam  akusala mūlam ca kamma paccayaḥ hoti iti na hoti kamma paccaya bhūtāya pana cetanāya saṃsaṭṭham
translated: Description of resultant consciousness rooted in the profitable

original: kammaṃ viya paccayo hoti. Tena ekībhāvamiva gatattāti evaṃ vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Yathā
analyzed: kammam viya paccayaḥ hoti tena ekībhāvam iva gata ttā ti evam vuttam ti daṭṭhabbam yathā
translated: It was said above, “But there is nothing to be said about conditions by way of kamma at different times” . But is there not kamma-resultant consciousness rooted in the profitable and unprofitable? It is not. But just as kamma associated with the volition that is a condition by way of kamma becomes a condition in this way, so too this is called a condition “as if” it were kamma.

original: kusalākusalamūlehi vinā kammaṃ vipākaṃ na janetīti tāni vipākassa pariyāyena upanissayoti
analyzed: kusala akusala mūlehi vinā kammam vipākam na janeti iti tāni vipākassa pariyāyena upanissayo ti
translated: For kamma without a root of profit or of harm does not generate kamma-result. So these are a condition for kamma-result by way of decisive support.

original: vuttāni, evaṃ kammena ekībhūtāni saṃsaṭṭhāni hutvā kammajānaṃ paccayā hontīti pariyāyena
analyzed: vuttāni evam kammena ekībhūtāni saṃsaṭṭhāni hutvā kamma jānam paccayāḥ honti iti pariyāyena
translated: They are said to be conditions by way of being combined and associated with kamma.

original: tesaṃ kammapaccayatā vuttā. Esāti esa kusalamūlapaccayo akusalamūlapaccayo cāti yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: tesam kamma paccaya tā vuttā esā ati esa kusala mūla paccayaḥ akusala mūla paccayaḥ ca ati yojetabbam
translated: Thus the condition by way of kamma is said. “These” should be connected with the roots of good and the roots of bad.

original: Kusalākusalavipākānaṃ viya kiriyānaṃ uppādakāni avijjākusalākusalamūlāni ca na hontīti
analyzed: kusala akusala vipākānam viya kiriyānam uppādakāni avijjā akusala akusala mūlāni ca na honti iti
translated: The roots of ignorance, good and bad, are not producers of the functional as they are of the resultant states of good and bad.

original: āha “upanissayataṃ na labhantī”ti. Manasikāropi javanavīthipaṭipādakamattattā kusalākusalāni
analyzed: āha upanissaya tam na labhanti iti manasikāraḥ api javana vīthi paṭipādaka matta ttā kusala akusalāni
translated: Therefore it is said: “they do not obtain the condition by way of decisive support.” Attention also does not make ignorance a condition by way of decisive support as it does the good and bad,

original: viya avijjaṃ upanissayaṃ na karoti, avijjūpanissayānaṃ pana pavattiatthaṃ bhavaṅgāvaṭṭanamattaṃ
analyzed: viya avijjam upanissayam na karoti avijja upanissayānam pana pavatti attham bhavaṅga avaṭṭana mattam
translated: because it is merely the forerunner of the process of impulsion. But the revolution of the life-continuum is for the purpose of the occurrence of those states that have ignorance as their decisive support.

original: hoti, pahīnāvijjānañca kiriyānaṃ avijjā nevuppādikā, ārammaṇamattameva pana hoti.
analyzed: hoti pahīna avijjānam ca kiriyānam avijjā na eva uppādikā ārammaṇa mattam eva pana hoti
translated: And for the functionals of those who have abandoned ignorance, ignorance is neither a producer nor an object.

original: Evañca katvā “kusalo dhammo abyākatassa dhammassa upanissayapaccayena paccayo”ti,
analyzed: evañca katvā kusalaḥ dhammaḥ abyākatassa dhammassa upanissaya paccayena paccayo ti
translated: Thus it is said: “A good state is a condition, by way of decisive support, for a neutral state.”

original: “vipākadhammadhammo nevavipākanavipākadhammadhammassa upanissayapaccayena paccayo”ti
analyzed: vipāka dhamma dhammaḥ neva vipāka na vipāka dhamma dhammassa upanissaya paccayena paccayo ti
translated: “A state that is kamma-result by way of decisive support condition for a state that is neither kamma-result nor a kamma-originated states”

original: ca evamādīsu kiriyānaṃ akusalā upanissayapaccayabhāvena na uddhaṭāti. Apica “avijjāpaccayā
analyzed: ca evamādīsu kiriyānam akusalā upanissaya paccaya bhāvena na api ca avijjā paccayā
translated: and so on. But in the case of the functional, the unwholesome states are not mentioned as decisive support conditions. Moreover, the wholesome method is stated by way of the words “With ignorance as condition there are formations”

original: saṅkhārā”ti etassa vasena avijjāmūlako kusalanayo vutto, “saṅkhārapaccayā viññāṇa”nti🔽etassa vasena kusalākusalamūlako vipākanayo, kiriyānaṃ pana neva saṅkhāraggahaṇena,
analyzed: saṅkhārā ti etassa vasena avijjā mūlakaḥ kusala nayaḥ vutto saṅkhāra paccayā viññāṇanti  etassa vasena kusala akusala mūlakaḥ vipāka nayaḥ kiriyānam pana na iva saṅkhāra ggahaṇena
translated: . The method of kamma-result is stated by way of the words “With formations as condition, consciousness”

original: na ca viññāṇaggahaṇena gahaṇaṃ gacchatīti taṃmūlako kiriyānayo na labbhatīti na vuttoti daṭṭhabbo.🔽Anekabhedatoti avijjādīnaṃ mūlapadānaṃ ekacittakkhaṇikānaṃ kiriyante paṭhamanaye
analyzed: na ca viññāṇa ggahaṇena gahaṇam gacchati iti taṃmūlakaḥ kiriyā anayaḥ na labbhati iti na vuttaḥ ti daṭṭhabbo  aneka bhedataḥ ti avijjā ādīnam mūla padānam eka citta kkhaṇikānam kiriyante paṭhama naye
translated: . But the functional is not included by the words “formations” or by the words “consciousness.” Therefore the method of the functional is not stated as having ignorance as its root.

original: sahajātādianekapaccayabhāvena gahitattā tesaṃ paccayānaṃ vasena navādimūlapadānaṃ
analyzed: sahajāta ādi aneka paccaya bhāvena gahita ttā tesam paccayānam vasena nava ādi mūla padānam
translated: By way of the many kinds: the first method is stated by way of the many kinds of conditions such as conascence, etc., under which the roots, ignorance, etc., and the functional are included in a single moment of consciousness.🔽By way of the many kinds of methods of the roots, etc., stated by way of those conditions. Or the meaning is: by way of the many kinds of methods of the four tetrads.

original: nayānaṃ vasena, anekappakārato catunnaṃ catukkānaṃ vasenāti vā adhippāyo. Kusalākusalānaṃ
analyzed: nayānam vasena aneka ppakārato catunnam catukkānam vasena ati vā adhippāyaḥ kusala akusalānam
translated: The wholesome and the unwholesome

original: pana vipāke cāti ettha kusalākusalesu kusalākusalānaṃ vipāke cāti vattabbaṃ. Purimapacchimesu
analyzed: pana vipāke ca ati ettha kusala akusalesu kusala akusalānam vipāke ca ati vattabbam purima pacchimesu
translated: But in the case of the profitable and unprofitable, the profitable and unprofitable should be mentioned as the result of the profitable and unprofitable.🔽For in the first and last methods the profitable and unprofitable are mentioned as the condition for the profitable and unprofitable, and the profitable and unprofitable as the condition for the result of the profitable and unprofitable.🔽But in the middle method the profitable and unprofitable are not mentioned as the condition for the profitable and unprofitable, but only as the condition for the result of the profitable and unprofitable.

original: hi nayesu yathā paccayākāro vutto, taṃdassanatthaṃ “anekabhedato ekadhāvā”ti vuttaṃ,🔽na ca pacchimanaye kusale anekabhedato paccayākāro vutto, atha kho “ekadhāvā”ti.
analyzed: hi nayesu yathā paccaya ākāraḥ vuttaḥ tad dassana attham aneka bhedataḥ ekadhā vā ti vuttam  na ca pacchima naye kusale aneka bhedato paccaya ākāraḥ vuttaḥ atha kho ekadhā avāti
translated: And the words “in one way” are said in order to show the way in which the condition is stated in each case.

original: Ekadhāvāti ca mūlapadekapaccayatāvasena, ekasseva vā nayassa vasena ekappakārenāti
analyzed: ekadhāvā ati ca mūlapada eka paccaya tā vasena ekassa iva vā nayassa vasena eka ppakārena ati
translated: And the meaning is that it is stated “in one way” as a single condition by way of the root-cause condition, or else in a single way by way of a single method.

original: attho, paṭhamacatukkasseva vasenāti vā adhippāyo. Dhammapaccayabhedeti avijjādīnaṃ🔽dhammānaṃ paccayabhāvabhede jarāmaraṇādīnaṃ dhammānaṃ jātiādipaccayabhede, taṃtaṃcittuppādasamayaparicchinnānaṃ
analyzed: atthaḥ paṭhama catukkassa iva vasena ati vā adhippāyaḥ dhamma paccaya bhede ti avijjā ādīnam  dhammānam paccaya bhāva bhede jarā maraṇa ādīnam dhammānam jāti ādi paccaya bhede taṃ taṃ cittuppāda samaya paricchinnānam
translated: Or the intention is that it is stated in the way of the first tetrad only.🔽In the analysis of conditions by way of states: in the analysis of the condition state of such states as ignorance, etc.,🔽and in the analysis of the condition state of such states as ageing-and-death, etc., by way of such conditions as ignorance, etc.,🔽and in the analysis of the condition state of such states as contact, etc., which are delimited by the time of the arising of the several consciousnesses, by way of the single-moment conditions beginning with ignorance.

original: vā phassādīnaṃ dhammānaṃ ekakkhaṇikāvijjādipaccayabhede. Pariyattiādīnaṃ kamo pariyatti…pe…
analyzed: vā phassa ādīnam dhammānam eka khaṇikā vijja ādi paccaya bhede pariyatti ādīnam kamaḥ pariyatti pe
translated: The order of the learning, etc., is that of the learning line, etc.

original: paṭipattikkamo. Paccayākāre hi pāḷipariyāpuṇanatadatthasavanapāḷiatthacintanāni “jarāmaraṇaṃ
analyzed: paṭipatti kkamaḥ paccaya ākāre hi pāḷi pariyāpuṇana tad attha savana pāḷi attha cintanāni jarā maraṇam
translated: This is the order of practice. For in the case of the dependent origination, the learning of the text, the hearing of the meaning of the text, and the reflection on the meaning of the text are the preliminary work.

original: aniccaṃ saṅkhataṃ…pe… nirodhadhamma”ntiādinā bhāvanāpaṭipatti ca kamena kātabbāti
analyzed: aniccam nirodha dhamman ti ādinā bhāvanā paṭipatti ca kamena kātabbā ti
translated: This is the order of practice. For in the case of the dependent origination, the learning of the text, the hearing of the meaning of the text for the purpose of learning it, the reflection on the meaning of the text, and the practice of development, namely, “Aging-and-death is impermanent, formed, dependently originated, subject to destruction, subject to fall, subject to fading away, subject to cessation” , should be done in order.

original: kama-ggahaṇaṃ karoti. Tatoti ñāṇappabhedajanakato kamato. Aññaṃ karaṇīyataraṃ natthi.
analyzed: kama ggahaṇam karoti tatas ti ñāṇa ppabheda janakataḥ kamataḥ aññam karaṇīyataram natthi
translated: Therefore he makes the statement “in order.” Then, after that, from the order that produces the classification of knowledge, there is nothing else to be done.

original: Tadāyattā hi dukkhantakiriyāti.
analyzed: tad āyattā hi dukkhanta kiriyā ati
translated: For the end of suffering is dependent on that.

original: Kusalamūlakavipākaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽Abhidhammabhājanīyavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: kusala mūlaka vipāka niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  abhidhammabhājanīya vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the description of the result of the wholesome roots is finished.🔽The commentary on the Abhidhamma basket is finished.🔽The commentary on the analysis of dependent origination is finished.

original: Paṭiccasamuppādavibhaṅgavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽7. Satipaṭṭhānavibhaṅgo🔽1. Suttantabhājanīyaṃ
analyzed: paṭiccasamuppāda vibhaṅga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  sati paṭṭhāna vibhaṅgaḥ  suttanta bhājanīyam
translated: The analysis of the establishments of mindfulness🔽The basket of the discourses

original: Uddesavāravaṇṇanā🔽355. Tayo satipaṭṭhānāti satipaṭṭhāna-saddassa atthuddhāraṃ karoti, na idha pāḷiyaṃ
analyzed: uddesa vāra vaṇṇanā  tayo satipaṭṭhānā ti satipaṭṭhāna saddassa attha uddhāram karoti na idha pāḷiyam
translated: The commentary on the recitation section

original: vuttassa satipaṭṭhāna-saddassa atthadassanaṃ. Ādīsu hi satigocaroti ādi-saddena “phassasamudayā
analyzed: vuttassa sati paṭṭhāna saddassa attha dassanam ādīsu hi sati gocaraḥ ti ādi saddena phassa samudayā
translated: The meaning of the word “establishments of mindfulness” is explained by the words “three establishments of mindfulness.” The meaning of the word “establishment of mindfulness” as it occurs in the text is not explained here. For in the beginning, the words “the domain of mindfulness” and so on are explained by the words “with the arising of contact” and so on.

original: vedanānaṃ samudayo, nāmarūpasamudayā cittassa samudayo, manasikārasamudayā dhammānaṃ🔽samudayo”ti satipaṭṭhānanti vuttānaṃ satigocarānaṃ dīpake suttappadese saṅgaṇhāti.🔽Evaṃ paṭisambhidāpāḷiyampi avasesapāḷippadesadassanattho ādi-saddo daṭṭhabbo. Dānādīnipi
analyzed: vedanānam samudayaḥ nāma rūpa samudayā cittassa samudayaḥ manasikāra samudayā dhammānaṃ  samudayaḥ ti sati paṭṭhānam ti vuttānam sati gocarānam dīpake sutta ppadese saṅgaṇhāti  evam paṭisambhidā pāḷiyam pi avasesa pāḷi padesa dassana tthaḥ ādi saddaḥ daṭṭhabbo dāna ādīni pi
translated: The origin of feelings is the origin of mind, and the origin of ideas is the origin of attention. ‘ The establishment of mindfulness’ is the light-making phrase in the Thread that is the province of mindfulness stated thus ‘ The establishment of mindfulness’ .🔽So the word ‘ and so on’ should be regarded as showing the rest of the phrase in the Discrimination of the Threads.

original: karontassa rūpādīni kasiṇādīni ca satiyā ṭhānaṃ hotīti taṃnivāraṇatthamāha “padhānaṃ
analyzed: karontassa rūpa ādīni kasiṇa ādīni ca satiyāḥ ṭhānam hoti iti tad nivāraṇa attham āha padhānam
translated: And when he is giving gifts, etc., there is a province for mindfulness in materiality, etc., and in the kasiṇas, etc., so he says ‘ The footing for the establishment of mindfulness is the footing for the exertion of energy’ in order to preclude that.

original: ṭhāna”nti. Pa-saddo hi padhānatthadīpakoti adhippāyo.
analyzed: ṭhānam ti pasaddaḥ hi padhāna attha dīpakaḥ ti adhippāyaḥ
translated: For the word ‘ and so on’ is intended to show the meaning of ‘ footing ‘ .

original: Ariyoti ariyaṃ seṭṭhaṃ sammāsambuddhamāha. Etthāti etasmiṃ saḷāyatanavibhaṅgasutteti attho. Suttekadesena hi suttaṃ dasseti. Tattha hi –
analyzed: ariyaḥ iti ariyam seṭṭham sammāsambuddham āha ettha iti etasmim saḷāyatana vibhaṅga sutta iti attho sutta ekadesena hi suttam dasseti tattha hi
translated: ‘ Noble ‘ : he says ‘ noble ‘ , which is the best, the Fully Enlightened One. ‘ Here ‘ : in this Discourse on the Analysis of the Sixfold Base is the meaning. For he shows the Thread by means of a part of the Thread, for in that Thread it is said :

original: “Tayo satipaṭṭhānā yadariyo…pe… arahatīti iti kho panetaṃ vuttaṃ, kiñcetaṃ paṭicca
analyzed: tayo satipaṭṭhānā arahati iti iti kho pana itam vuttam kiñca itam paṭicca
translated: ‘ Now this was said by the Blessed One, by the Truth-finder : “ There are three establishments of mindfulness that the Noble One cultivates, that the Noble One develops, that the Noble One makes much of, that the Noble One fully possesses. What three ? Here a bhikkhu abides contemplating the body as a body internally, ardent, fully aware, and mindful, having put away covetousness and grief for the world. He abides contemplating the body as a body externally, ardently, fully aware, and mindful, having put away covetousness and grief for the world. He abides contemplating the body as a body internally and externally, ardently, fully aware, and mindful, having put away covetousness and grief for the world.🔽He abides contemplating feelings as feelings internally, ardently, fully aware, and mindful, having put away covetousness and grief for the world. He abides contemplating feelings as feelings externally, ardently, fully aware, and mindful, having put away covetousness and grief for the world. He abides contemplating feelings as feelings internally and externally, ardently, fully aware, and mindful, having put away covetousness and grief for the world.🔽He abides contemplating cognizance as cognizance internally, ardently, fully aware, and mindful, having put away covetousness and grief for the world. He abides contemplating cognizance as cognizance externally, ardently, fully aware, and mindful,

original: vuttaṃ? Idha, bhikkhave, satthā sāvakānaṃ dhammaṃ deseti anukampako hitesī anukampaṃ
analyzed: vuttam idha bhikkhave satthā sāvakānam dhammaṃ deseti anukampakaḥ hita īsī anukampam
translated: seeking their welfare out of compassion,

original: upādāya ‘idaṃ vo hitāya idaṃ vo sukhāyā’ti. Tassa sāvakā na sussūsanti, na sotaṃ
analyzed: upādāya idam vaḥ hitāya idam vaḥ sukhāya ati tassa sāvakāḥ na sussūsanti na sotam
translated: ‘This is for your welfare, this is for your happiness.’ His disciples do not want to hear or give ear or exert their minds to understand;

original: odahanti, na aññā cittaṃ upaṭṭhāpenti, vokkamma ca satthusāsanā vattanti. Tatra,
analyzed: odahanti na aññā cittam upaṭṭhāpenti vokkamma ca satthu sāsanā vattanti tatra
translated: they err and turn aside from the Teacher’s Dispensation.

original: bhikkhave, tathāgato na ceva anattamano hoti, na ca anattamanataṃ paṭisaṃvedeti,
analyzed: bhikkhave tathāgataḥ na ca iva anatta manaḥ hoti na ca anatta manatam paṭisaṃvedeti
translated: Therein, monks, the Tathāgata is not displeased, nor is he displeased and does not experience a painful, harsh, and bitter feeling on that account.

original: anavassuto ca viharati sato sampajāno. Idaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamaṃ satipaṭṭhānaṃ. Yadariyo…pe… arahati.
analyzed: an avassutaḥ ca viharati sataḥ sampajānaḥ idam bhikkhave paṭhamam satipaṭṭhānam yat ariyope arahati
translated: He dwells with his mind not obsessed by doubt, and he understands the escape from that doubt when it has arisen. This, monks, is the first foundation of mindfulness that the Noble One cultivates, cultivating which the Noble One is a teacher fit to instruct a group.🔽“Again, monks, a teacher teaches the Dhamma to his disciples out of compassion,🔽seeking their welfare out of compassion,

original: “Puna caparaṃ bhikkhave satthā…pe… idaṃ vo sukhāyāti. Tassa ekacce sāvakā na sussūsanti…pe…
analyzed: puna caparam bhikkhave satthāpe idam vaḥ sukhāya ati tassa ekacce sāvakāḥ na
translated: ‘This is for your welfare, this is for your happiness.’ His disciples do not want to hear or give ear or exert their minds to understand;

original: vattanti. Ekacce sāvakā sussūsanti …pe… na ca vokkamma satthusāsanā vattanti. Tatra,
analyzed: vattanti ekacce sāvakā sussūsanti pe na ca vokkamma satthu sāsanā vattanti tatra
translated: they err and turn aside from the Teacher’s Dispensation. But some of his disciples want to hear and give ear and exert their minds to understand;

original: bhikkhave, tathāgato na ceva attamano hoti, na ca attamanataṃ paṭisaṃvedeti. Na ceva
analyzed: bhikkhave tathāgataḥ na ca iva atta manaḥ hoti na ca atta manatam paṭisaṃvedeti na ca iva
translated: they do not err and turn aside from the Teacher’s Dispensation. Therein, monks, the Tathāgata is not pleased, nor is he pleased and does not experience a pleasant,🔽happy, and joyful feeling on that account.

original: anattamano hoti, na ca anattamanataṃ paṭisaṃvedeti. Attamanatañca anattamanatañca
analyzed: an atta manaḥ hoti na ca an atta manatam paṭisaṃvedeti atta manatam ca an atta manatam ca
translated: he is not displeased, and he does not experience displeasure.

original: tadubhayaṃ abhinivajjetvā upekkhako ca viharati sato sampajāno. Idaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyaṃ…pe….
analyzed: tat ubhayam abhinivajjetvā upekkhakaḥ ca viharati sataḥ sampajānaḥ idam bhikkhave dutiyam pe
translated: Avoiding both pleasure and displeasure, he dwells in equanimity, mindful and fully aware. This is the second…

original: “Puna caparaṃ…pe… sukhāyāti. Tassa sāvakā sussūsanti…pe… vattanti. Tatra, bhikkhave,
analyzed: puna caparam pe sukhāya ati tassa sāvakā vattanti tatra bhikkhave
translated: “Again, a Tathagata teaches the Dhamma to his disciples… His disciples listen to him… and they practice in accordance with the Dhamma.

original: tathāgato attamano ceva hoti, attamanatañca paṭisaṃvedeti, anavassuto ca viharati
analyzed: tathāgataḥ atta manaḥ ca iva hoti atta mana tam ca paṭisaṃvedeti an avassutaḥ ca viharati
translated: Then the Tathagata is pleased, and he experiences pleasure.

original: sato sampajāno. Idaṃ, bhikkhave, tatiya”nti –
analyzed: sataḥ sampajānaḥ idam bhikkhave tatiyanti
translated: This is the third…

original: Evaṃ paṭighānunayehi anavassutatā, niccaṃ upaṭṭhitasatitā, tadubhayavītivattatā satipaṭṭhānanti vuttā. Buddhānameva kira niccaṃ upaṭṭhitasatitā hoti, na paccekabuddhādīnanti.
analyzed: evam paṭigha anunayehi anavassuta tā niccam upaṭṭhita sati tā tad ubhaya vītivatta tā sati paṭṭhānam ti vuttā buddhānam eva kira niccam upaṭṭhita sati tā hoti na paccekabuddha ādīnam ti
translated: Thus, the state of being unattracted to pleasure and displeasure, the state of being constantly mindful, and the state of avoiding both pleasure and displeasure are called the foundations of mindfulness. It is said that only the Buddhas have constant mindfulness, not the Paccekabuddhas and others.

original: Pa-saddo ārambhaṃ joteti, ārambho ca pavattīti katvā āha “pavattayitabbatoti attho”ti.
analyzed: pasaddaḥ ārambham jotā iti ārambhaḥ ca pavattī iti katvā āha pavattayitabbato ti atthaḥ ti
translated: The word “pavatta” indicates beginning. Since beginning means to occur, he says “the meaning is that it should be made to occur.”

original: Satiyā karaṇabhūtāya paṭṭhānaṃ paṭṭhāpetabbaṃ satipaṭṭhānaṃ. Ana-saddañhi bahulaṃ-vacanena
analyzed: satiyā karaṇa bhūtāya paṭṭhānam paṭṭhāpetabbam satipaṭṭhānam an a saddam hi bahulaṃvacanena
translated: The establishment of mindfulness is to be established by means of mindfulness, which is the instrument.🔽The word paṭṭhāna is derived from the root paṭh, to desire, and is used in the sense of “what is desired” .

original: kammatthaṃ icchanti saddavidū, tatheva kattuatthampi icchantīti puna tatiyanaye “patiṭṭhātīti🔽paṭṭhāna”nti vuttaṃ. Tattha pa-saddo bhusatthaṃ pakkhandanaṃ dīpetīti “okkantitvā
analyzed: kammattham icchanti sadda vidū tathā iva kattuattham pi icchanti iti puna tatiya naye patiṭṭhāti iti  paṭṭhānam ti vuttam tattha pasaddaḥ bhusattham pakkhandanam dīpeti iti okkantitvā
translated: In the third method, the word paṭṭhāna is derived from the root paṭṭh, to be established, and is used in the sense of “what is established” .🔽The prefix pa- indicates abundance.🔽The word paṭṭhāna is derived from the root paṭh, to desire, and is used in the sense of “what is desired” .🔽In the third method, the word paṭṭhāna is derived from the root paṭṭh, to be established, and is used in the sense of “what is established” .

original: pakkhanditvā vattatīti attho”ti āha. Puna bhāvatthe sati-saddaṃ paṭṭhāna-saddañca
analyzed: pakkhanditvā vattati iti atthaḥ ti āha puna bhāva tthe sati saddam paṭṭhāna saddam ca
translated: The prefix pa- indicates abundance.🔽The word paṭṭhāna is derived from the root paṭh, to desire, and is used in the sense of “what is desired” .

original: vaṇṇento “atha vā”tiādimāha. Tena purimatthe sati-saddo paṭṭhāna-saddo ca kattuatthoti viññāyati.
analyzed: vaṇṇentaḥ atha vā iti ādim āha tena purima atthe sati saddo paṭṭhāna saddo ca kattu atthaḥ ti viññāyati
translated: In the third method, the word paṭṭhāna is derived from the root paṭṭh, to be established, and is used in the sense of “what is established” .🔽The prefix pa- indicates abundance.🔽The word paṭṭhāna is derived from the root paṭh, to desire, and is used in the sense of “what is desired” .

original: Visesena kāyo ca vedanā ca assādassa kāraṇanti tappahānatthaṃ tesaṃ taṇhāvatthūnaṃ
analyzed: visesena kāyaḥ ca vedanā ca assādassa kāraṇan ti tad pahāna attham tesam taṇhā vatthūnam
translated: In the third method, the word paṭṭhāna is derived from the root paṭṭh, to be established, and is used in the sense of “what is established” .🔽The prefix pa- indicates abundance.

original: oḷārikasukhumānaṃ asubhadukkhatādassanāni mandatikkhapaññehi taṇhācaritehi sukarānīti
analyzed: oḷārika sukhumānam asubha dukkha tā dassanāni manda tikkha paññehi taṇhā caritehi sukarāni iti
translated: The word paṭṭhāna is derived from the root paṭh, to desire, and is used in the sense of “what is desired” .🔽In the third method, the word paṭṭhāna is derived from the root paṭṭh, to be established, and is used in the sense of “what is established” .🔽The prefix pa- indicates abundance.

original: tāni tesaṃ visuddhimaggoti vuttāni, evaṃ diṭṭhiyā visesakāraṇesu cittadhammesu aniccānattatādassanāni
analyzed: tāni tesam visuddhi maggaḥ ti vuttāni evam diṭṭhiyā visesa kāraṇesu citta dhammesu anicca anatta tā dassanāni
translated: These are called the path of purification for them. So the seeing of impermanence and not-self in the mental data of consciousness, which is the cause of the distinction in view,

original: nātipabhedātipabhedagatesu tesu tappahānatthaṃ mandatikkhānaṃ diṭṭhicaritānaṃ sukarānīti
analyzed: na ati pabheda ati pabheda gatesu tesu tad pahāna attham manda tikkhānam diṭṭhi caritānam sukarāni iti
translated: is easy for those of dull and keen temperament who are of lustful and speculative temperaments respectively, in the case of the two kinds of object, that is to say, the gross and the subtle, that lead to the abandoning of the two kinds of defilement.🔽So these are called the path of purification for them.

original: tesaṃ tāni visuddhimaggoti. Tikkho samathayāniko oḷārikārammaṇaṃ pariggaṇhanto tattha🔽aṭṭhatvā jhānaṃ samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya vedanaṃ pariggaṇhātīti āha “oḷārikārammaṇe
analyzed: tesam tāni visuddhi maggo ti tikkhaḥ samatha yāniko oḷārika ārammaṇam pariggaṇhanto tattha  a ṭhatvā jhānam samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya vedanam pariggaṇhāti iti āha oḷārika ārammaṇe
translated: The one of keen temperament who is a vehicle of concentration, when he is discerning a gross object,🔽does not stand upon that but enters upon and abides in jhāna. On emerging he discerns feeling. That is why it is said that “because he does not stand upon the gross object”

original: asaṇṭhahanato”ti. Vipassanāyānikassa sukhume citte dhammesu ca cittaṃ pakkhandatīti🔽tadanupassanānaṃ taṃvisuddhimaggatā vuttā.
analyzed: a saṇṭhahanato ti vipassanāyānikassa sukhume citte dhammesu ca cittam pakkhandati iti  tad anupassanānam tad visuddhi magga tā vuttā
translated: the mind of the one of keen temperament who is a vehicle of insight penetrates to the subtle mental data.🔽So the seeing of the mental data of consciousness as impermanent and not-self is called the path of purification for him.

original: Tesaṃ tatthāti ettha tattha-saddassa pahānatthanti etena yojanā. Pañca kāmaguṇā savisesā
analyzed: tesam tattha ati ettha tattha saddassa pahāna atthanti etena yojanā pañca kāmaguṇā savisesā
translated: Herein, the word “there” in the words “for them there” is construed with “for the abandoning” in the words “for the abandoning of the two kinds of defilement.”🔽The five cords of sense desire with their distinctions are obtainable in the body.

original: kāye labbhantīti visesena kāyo kāmoghassa vatthu, bhave sukhaggahaṇavasena bhavassādo
analyzed: kāye labbhanti iti visesena kāyaḥ vatthu bhave sukha ggahaṇa vasena bhava ssādaḥ
translated: So the body is the basis for the sense-desire element. The gratification in becoming is the gratification in the pleasure of becoming.

original: hotīti bhavoghassa vedanā, santatighanaggahaṇavasena citte attābhiniveso hotīti diṭṭhoghassa
analyzed: hoti iti bhava oghassa vedanā santati ghana gahaṇa vasena citte attā abhiniveso hoti iti diṭṭha oghassa
translated: Feeling is the flood of existence,🔽The mind is the flood of views, because of the misinterpreting of the mind as a self by way of the grasping of a continuity and a compactness.

original: cittaṃ, dhammavinibbhogassa dhammānaṃ dhammamattatāya ca duppaṭivijjhattā sammoho
analyzed: cittam dhamma vinibbhogassa dhammānam dhamma matta tāya ca duppaṭivijjha tā sammoho
translated: The mental data are the flood of ignorance, because of the delusion that is the non-penetration of the mere mental data as mental data.

original: hotīti avijjoghassa dhammā, tasmā tesu tesaṃ pahānatthaṃ cattārova vuttā, dukkhāya🔽vedanāya paṭighānusayo anusetīti dukkhadukkhavipariṇāmadukkhasaṅkhāradukkhabhūtā
analyzed: hoti iti avijja oghassa dhammā tasmā tesu tesam pahāna attham cattāro va vuttā dukkhāya  vedanāya paṭigha anusayaḥ anuseti iti dukkha dukkha vipariṇāma dukkha saṅkhāra dukkha bhūtā
translated: Therefore, they are stated as four in order to abandon them in regard to these .🔽The underlying tendency to resistance underlies the painful feeling,🔽The mental data are the object of the bodily tie of ill will, because of the painful feeling that is suffering as suffering, suffering as change, and suffering as a formation.

original: vedanā visesena byāpādakāyaganthassa vatthu, citte niccaggahaṇavasena sassatassa
analyzed: vedanā visesena byāpāda kāya ganthassa vatthu citte nicca ggahaṇa vasena
translated: The mind is the object of the eternalist view, because of the misinterpreting of the mind as a self by way of the grasping of the mind as permanent.🔽The mental data are the object of the adherence to rules and observances, because of the misinterpreting of the purity of virtue, etc., as the self, etc.

original: attano sīlena suddhītiādiparāmasanaṃ hotīti sīlabbataparāmāsassa cittaṃ, nāmarūpaparicchedena
analyzed: attano sīlena suddhi iti ādi parāmasanam hoti iti sīlabbata parāmāsassa cittam nāma rūpa paricchedena
translated: Because of the non-penetration of the real as real by way of the delimitation of mentality-materiality,

original: bhūtaṃ bhūtato apassantassa bhavavibhavadiṭṭhisaṅkhāto idaṃsaccābhiniveso hotīti
analyzed: bhūtam bhūtataḥ a passantassa bhava vibhava diṭṭhi saṅkhātaḥ idaṃsacca abhinivesaḥ hoti iti
translated: The mental data are the object of the adherence to a doctrine of self, because of the misinterpreting of the self as real by way of the eternalist and annihilationist views.

original: tassa dhammā…pe… sukhavedanāssādavasena paralokanirapekkho “natthi dinna”ntiādiparāmāsaṃ
analyzed: tassa dhammāpe sukha vedanā āssāda vasena para loka nirapekkhaḥ natthi dinna nti ādi parāmāsaṃ
translated: … The mental data are the object of the adherence to mere rules and rituals, because of the misinterpreting of the purity of virtue, etc., as the self, etc., by way of the non-regard for a future life through the relish of pleasant feeling.

original: uppādetīti diṭṭhupādānassa vedanā. Santatighanaggahaṇavasena sarāgādicitte sammoho
analyzed: uppādeti iti diṭṭhupādānassa vedanā santati ghana ggahaṇa vasena sa rāga ādi citte sammoho
translated: Feeling is the source of the embodiment-view holding, since it is the source of the embodiment-view clinging. Delusion is the source of cognizance, since delusion is the cause of cognizance’s being accompanied by lust, etc., through the mode of apprehending a continuity as a compact whole.11

original: hotīti mohāgatiyā cittaṃ, dhammasabhāvānavabodhena bhayaṃ hotīti bhayāgatiyā dhammā…pe…
analyzed: hoti iti moha āgatiyā cittam dhamma sabhāva anavabodhena bhayam hoti iti bhaya āgatiyā dhamma āpe
translated: Ideas are the source of fear, since fear is the cause of the non-penetration of the individual essences of ideas. …

original: avuttānaṃ vuttanayena vatthubhāvo yojetabbo.
analyzed: avuttānam vutta nayena vatthu bhāvaḥ yojetabbo
translated: The function of the remaining terms can be construed in accordance with the way the above terms have been construed.

original: “Āhārasamudayā kāyasamudayo, phassasamudayā vedanāsamudayo, saṅkhārapaccayā viññāṇaṃ,
analyzed: āhāra samudayā kāya samudayo phassa samudayā vedanā samudayo saṅkhāra paccayā viññāṇam
translated: “With the arising of nutriment there is the arising of bodily form; with the arising of contact there is the arising of feeling; with the condition of determinations there is the arising of consciousness;🔽with the condition of consciousness there is the arising of name-and-form” .

original: viññāṇapaccayā nāmarūpa”nti vacanato kāyādīnaṃ samudayabhūtā kabaḷīkārāhāraphassamanosañcetanāviññāṇāhārā
analyzed: viññāṇa paccayā nāma rūpanti vacanataḥ kāya ādīnam samudaya bhūtā kabaḷīkāra āhāra phassa manaḥ sañcetanā viññāṇa āhārā
translated: The four kinds of nutriment, namely, edible food, contact, mental volition, and consciousness, are the source of the arising of the body, etc.,🔽and they are fully understood by the full understanding of the body, etc., thus he said “for the purpose of fully understanding the four nutriments” .

original: kāyādiparijānanena pariññātā hontīti āha “catubbidhāhārapariññattha”nti. Pakaraṇanayoti
analyzed: kāya ādi parijānanena pariññātāḥ honti iti āha pakaraṇa nayo ti
translated: The method of the text :

original: tambapaṇṇibhāsāya vaṇṇanānayo. Nettipeṭakappakaraṇe dhammakathikānaṃ yojanānayotipi vadanti.
analyzed: tamba paṇṇi bhāsāya vaṇṇanā anayaḥ netti peṭaka ppakaraṇe dhamma kathikānam vadanti
translated: the method of the commentary in the Tambapanni language.12 They also say that it is the method of the Nettipada and the Petakopadesa for the guidance of preachers of the True Idea.🔽By way of the four resorts :

original: Saraṇavasenāti kāyādīnaṃ kusalādidhammānañca dhāraṇatāvasena. Saranti gacchanti etāyāti
analyzed: saraṇa vasena ati kāya ādīnam kusala ādi dhammānam ca dhāraṇa tā vasena saranti gacchanti etāya ati
translated: by way of the four kinds of resort. They resort, they go, by this, thus it is a resort ;

original: satīti imasmiṃ atthe ekatte nibbāne samāgamo ekattasamosaraṇaṃ. Etadeva hi dassetuṃ
analyzed: sati iti imasmin atthe ekatte nibbāne samāgamaḥ ekatta samosaraṇam etat eva hi dassetum
translated: In the sense of “being established” the meaning of “being mindful” is “coming together in unity” in the extinction which is one. In order to show this he says:

original: “yathā hī”tiādimāha. Ekanibbānappavesahetubhūto vā samānatāya eko satipaṭṭhānasabhāvo🔽ekattaṃ, tattha samosaraṇaṃ taṃsabhāgatā ekattasamosaraṇaṃ. Ekanibbānappavesahetubhāvaṃ
analyzed: yathā hi itiādim āha eka nibbāna ppavesa hetu bhūtaḥ vā samānatāya ekaḥ sati paṭṭhāna sabhāvaḥ  ekattam tattha samosaraṇam taṃsa bhāga tā ekatta samosaraṇam eka nibbāna pavesa hetu bhāvam
translated: “Just as, etc.,” or the single state of being mindful which is the cause for the entry into one extinction is “unity” in the sense of sameness,🔽and the “coming together in unity” is the state of being of the same nature as that. In order to show the state of being the cause for the entry into one extinction he says:

original: pana dassetuṃ “yathā hī”tiādimāha. Etasmiṃ atthe saraṇekattasamosaraṇāni saha satipaṭṭhānekabhāvassa🔽kāraṇattena vuttānīti daṭṭhabbāni, purimasmiṃ visuṃ. Saraṇavasenāti vā gamanavasenāti
analyzed: pana dassetum yathā hi iti ādim āha etasmin atthe saraṇa ekatta samosaraṇāni saha sati paṭṭhāna eka bhāvassa  kāraṇa ttena vuttāni iti daṭṭhabbāni purimasmin visum saraṇa vasena ati vā gamana vasena ati
translated: “Just as, etc.,” In this sense the “coming together in unity” and the “unity” should be regarded as being mentioned as the cause for the single state of being mindful, separately in the first instance, and together in the second instance.

original: atthe sati tadeva gamanaṃ samosaraṇanti samosaraṇe vā sati-saddatthavasena avuccamāne
analyzed: atthe sati tat eva gamanam samosaraṇanti samosaraṇe vā a vuccamāne
translated: Or alternatively, the meaning of “coming together” is “going” . In the sense of “being” the meaning of “being mindful” is “that which is remembered” . When the meaning of “being mindful” is being stated in the sense of “coming together”

original: dhāraṇatāva satīti sati-saddatthantarābhāvā purimaṃ satibhāvassa kāraṇaṃ, pacchimaṃ
analyzed: satī iti purimam sati bhāvassa kāraṇam pacchimam
translated: the meaning of “being mindful” is “being established” . Thus, in the first instance, “being mindful” is the cause for the state of being mindful, and in the second instance it is the cause for the single state of being.

original: ekabhāvassāti nibbānasamosaraṇepi sahitāneva tāni satipaṭṭhānekabhāvassa kāraṇāni.
analyzed: eka bhāvassa ti nibbāna samosaraṇe pi sahitāni eva tāni sati paṭṭhāna eka bhāvassa kāraṇāni
translated: In the case of the “coming together in unity in extinction” the three are the cause for the single state of being mindful, taken together.

original: Cuddasavidhenāti idaṃ mahāsatipaṭṭhānasutte vuttānaṃ ānāpānapabbādīnaṃ vasena. Tathā
analyzed: cuddasavidhena āti idam mahāsatipaṭṭhāna sutte vuttānam āna apāna pabba ādīnam vasena tathā
translated: Fourteenfold: this is in terms of the in-breaths and out-breaths, etc., stated in the Mahāsatipaṭṭhāna Sutta. So too

original: pañcavidhena dhammānupassananti etthāpi daṭṭhabbaṃ. Ettha ca uṭṭhānakabhaṇḍasadisatā🔽taṃtaṃsatipaṭṭhānabhāvanānubhāvassa daṭṭhabbā. Bhikkhugocarā hi ete. Vuttañhi “gocare,🔽bhikkhave, caratha sake pettike visaye”tiādi.🔽Kāyānupassanādipaṭipattiyā bhikkhu hotīti bhikkhuṃ “kāyānupassī viharatī”tiādinā dasseti bhikkhumhi taṃniyamato. Tenāha “paṭipattiyā vā bhikkhubhāvadassanato”ti.
analyzed: pañcavidhena dhamma anupassanan ti ettha api daṭṭhabbam ettha ca uṭṭhānaka bhaṇḍa sadisa tā  taṃ taṃ sati paṭṭhāna bhāvanā anubhāvassa daṭṭhabbā bhikkhu gocarāḥ hi ete vuttam hi gocare  bhikkhave caratha sake pettike visaya itiādi  kāya anupassanā ādi paṭipattiyā bhikkhu hoti iti bhikkhum kāya anupassī viharati itiādinā dasseti bhikkhumhi tad niyamato tena āha paṭipattiyā vā bhikkhu bhāva dassanato ti
translated: in the case of the contemplation of ideas in five ways. And here the simile of the load of firewood🔽should be understood as the power of the development of the several kinds of mindfulness. For these are the bhikkhu’s province. For this is said: “Go, bhikkhus, to your own province, to your own district, and there resort to a certain village or town and dwell there” .

original: Samaṃ careyyāti kāyādivisamacariyaṃ pahāya kāyādīhi samaṃ careyya. Rāgādivūpasamena🔽santo, indriyadamanena danto, catumagganiyamena niyato, seṭṭhacāritāya brahmacārī.
analyzed: samam careyya ati kāya ādi visama cariyam pahāya kāya ādīhi samam careyya rāga ādi vūpasamena 🔽santaḥ indriya damanena danto catu magga niyamena niyataḥ seṭṭha cāritāya brahmacārī
translated: He is a bhikkhu by the practice of the contemplation of the body, etc., and so he shows him by the words “he dwells contemplating the body in the body” and so on. He is a bhikkhu by the practice of the contemplation of the body, etc., and so he shows him by the words “he dwells contemplating the body in the body” and so on. He is a bhikkhu by the practice of the contemplation of the body, etc., and so he shows him by the words “he dwells contemplating the body in the body” and so on. He is a bhikkhu by the practice of the contemplation of the body, etc., and so he shows him by the words “he dwells contemplating the body in the body” and so on. He is a bhikkhu by the practice of the contemplation of the body, etc., and so he shows him by the words “he dwells contemplating the body in the body” and so on. He is a bhikkhu by the practice of the contemplation of the body, etc., and so he shows him by the words “he dwells contemplating the body in the body” and so on. He is a bhikkhu by the practice of the contemplation of the body, etc., and so he shows him by the words “he dwells contemplating the body in the body” and so on. He is a bhikkhu by the practice of the contemplation of the body, etc., and so he shows him by the words “he dwells contemplating the body in the body” and so on. He is a bhikkhu by the practice of the contemplation of the body, etc., and so he shows him by the words “he dwells contemplating the body in the body” and so on. He is a bhikkhu by the practice of the contemplation of the body, etc., and so he shows him by the words “he

original: Kāyadaṇḍādioropanena nidhāya daṇḍaṃ. So evarūpo bāhitapāpasamitapāpabhinnakilesatāhi
analyzed: kāya daṇḍa ādi āropanena nidhāya daṇḍam saḥ evarūpaḥ
translated: “Having laid down the rod” means having laid down the rod of bodily action.

original: brāhmaṇādisamañño veditabbo.
analyzed: brāhmaṇa ādi samaññaḥ veditabbo
translated: Such a person should be known as being the same as a brahmin, etc., because of his having expelled evil, having subdued evil, and having broken the defilements.

original: Kāyānupassanāuddesavaṇṇanā🔽Asammissatoti vedanādayopi ettha sitā, ettha paṭibaddhāti kāye vedanādianupassanāpasaṅgepi
analyzed: kāya anupassanā uddesa vaṇṇanā  a sammissato ti vedanā ādayaḥ api ettha sitāḥ ettha paṭibaddhā ati kāye vedanā ādi anupassanā apasaṅge pi
translated: The explanation of the directions for contemplation of the body

original: āpanne tadamissatoti attho. Avayavīgāhasamaññātidhāvanasārādānābhinivesanisedhanatthaṃ🔽kāyaṃ aṅgapaccaṅgehi, tāni ca kesādīhi, kesādike ca bhūtupādāyarūpehi vinibbhujjanto
analyzed: āpanne tat amissato ti atthaḥ avayavī gāha samaññā ati dhāvana sāra ādāna abhinivesa nisedhana ttham  kāyam aṅga paccaṅgehi tāni ca kesa ādīhi kesa ādike ca bhūta upādāya rūpehi vinibbhujjantaḥ
translated: “Not mixed up”: feeling, etc., are also white here, bound up here. The meaning is: not mixed up with that, although there is a risk of the contemplation of feeling, etc., being included in the contemplation of the body.🔽In order to prevent the assumption of a mere aggregate, the running after a mere concept, the grasping of a mere part, and the adherence to mere conditions,

original: “tathā na kāye”tiādimāha. Pāsādādinagarāvayavasamūhe avayavīvādinopi avayavīgāhaṃ
analyzed: tathā na kāya iti ādim āha pāsāda ādi nagara avayava samūhe avayavī vādinaḥ api
translated: he says, “So he does not discern the body in the various parts of the body,” etc.🔽Even though people do not make a mere aggregate, etc., of the parts of a palace, etc., and of a city, etc.,

original: na karonti. Nagaraṃ nāma koci attho atthīti pana kesañci samaññātidhāvanaṃ siyāti
analyzed: na karonti nagaram nāma koci atthaḥ atthi iti pana kesañci samaññā ati dhāvanam siyāti
translated: there is a running after a mere concept in some, thinking that there is some such thing as a city.

original: itthipurisādisamaññātidhāvane nagaranidassanaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: itthi purisa ādi samaññāti dhāvane nagara nidassanam vuttam
translated: Therefore the example of the city is given in order to prevent the running after the mere concept of a woman, a man, etc.

original: Yaṃ passati itthiṃ vā purisaṃ vā, nanu cakkhunā itthipurisadassanaṃ natthīti? Saccaṃ
analyzed: yam passati itthim vā purisam vā nanu cakkhunā itthi purisa dassanam na atthi iti saccam
translated: When one sees a woman or a man, is it not true that one sees a woman or a man with the eye?

original: natthi, “itthiṃ passāmi, purisaṃ passāmī”ti pana pavattasaññāya vasena “yaṃ passatī”ti🔽vuttaṃ. Micchādassane vā diṭṭhiyā yaṃ passati, na taṃ diṭṭhaṃ, taṃ rūpāyatanaṃ na🔽hoti, rūpāyatanaṃ vā taṃ na hotīti attho. Atha vā taṃ kesādibhūtupādāyasamūhasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: natthi itthim passāmi purisam passāmi iti pana pavatta saññāya vasena yam passati iti  vuttam micchā dassane vā diṭṭhiyā yam passati na tat diṭṭham tam rūpa āyatanam na  hoti rūpa āyatanam vā tam na hoti iti atthaḥ atha vā tam kesa ādi bhūta upādāya samūha saṅkhātam
translated: It is true that one sees a woman or a man with the eye. But the words “what one sees” are said with reference to the perception that occurs with the thought “I see a woman,” “I see a man.”🔽Or else, “what one sees” means that what one sees with wrong view, that is, what one sees with the view of self, is not seen, that is, it does not exist as the object of the eye-consciousness. Or else, it means that the object of the eye-consciousness does not exist as that.🔽Or else, “what one sees” means that what is seen as a collection of hair, etc., elements and bases does not exist as that.

original: diṭṭhaṃ na hoti, diṭṭhaṃ vā yathāvuttaṃ na hotīti attho. Yaṃ diṭṭhaṃ taṃ na passatīti
analyzed: diṭṭham na hoti diṭṭham vā yathā vuttam na hoti iti atthaḥ yam diṭṭham tam na passati iti
translated: Or else, it means that what is seen as the collection of hair, etc., elements and bases does not exist as described above.

original: yaṃ rūpāyatanaṃ, kesādibhūtupādāyasamūhasaṅkhātaṃ vā diṭṭhaṃ, taṃ paññācakkhunā bhūtato na passatīti attho.
analyzed: yam rūpa āyatanam kesa ādi bhūta upādāya samūha saṅkhātam vā diṭṭham tam paññā cakkhunā bhūtataḥ na passati iti attho
translated: “What one sees one does not see” means that what is seen as the object of the eye-consciousness, that is, the collection of hair, etc., elements and bases, one does not see with the eye of wisdom as it really is.

original: Na aññadhammānupassīti na aññasabhāvānupassī, asubhādito aññākārānupassī na hotīti
analyzed: na añña dhamma anupassī iti na añña sabhāva anupassī asubha āditas añña ākāra anupassī na hoti iti
translated: “Not observing any other thing” means not observing any other nature, not observing any other aspect such as foulness, etc.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Pathavīkāyanti kesādipathaviṃ dhammasamūhattā kāyoti vadati, lakkhaṇapathavimeva
analyzed: vuttam hoti pathavīkāyanti kesa ādi pathavim dhamma samūha ttā kāyo ti vadati lakkhaṇa pathavim eva
translated: he says that the earth-body is a “body” because it is a collection of states. He says that the earth-sign is the earth-body.

original: vā anekappabhedasakalasarīragataṃ pubbāpariyabhāvena pavattamānaṃ samūhavasena gahetvā🔽kāyoti vadati, evaṃ aññatthāpi.🔽Ajjhattabahiddhāti ajjhattabahiddhādhammānaṃ ghaṭitārammaṇaṃ ekato ārammaṇabhāvo
analyzed: vā aneka ppabheda sakala sarīra gatam pubbāpariya bhāvena pavattamānam samūha vasena gahetvā  kāyaḥ iti vadati evam aññattha api  ajjhatta bahiddhā ti ajjhatta bahiddhā dhammānam ghaṭita ārammaṇam ekatas ārammaṇa bhāvaḥ
translated: He says “earth-body” because the earth-element is a collection of states. Or he says “body” because he takes the earth-element as a collection by way of the whole physical frame, which has many divisions and occurs with a succession of prior and subsequent parts. So too in other instances.

original: natthīti attho, ajjhattabahiddhā dhammā vā ghaṭitārammaṇaṃ idaṃ natthīti attho. Tīsu
analyzed: natthi iti atthaḥ ajjhatta bahiddhāḥ dhammāḥ vā ghaṭita ārammaṇam idam natthi iti atthaḥ tīsu
translated: “Internally and externally”: the meaning is that there is no single object consisting of the combination of internal and external states. Or the meaning is that there is no single object consisting of the combination of internal and external states.

original: bhavesu kilesānanti bhavattayavisayānaṃ kilesānanti attho.🔽Sabbatthikanti sabbattha bhavaṃ. Sabbasmiṃ līne uddhaṭe ca citte icchitabbattā, sabbe
analyzed: bhavesu kilesānam ti bhava ttaya visayānam kilesānam ti attho  sabbatthikam ti sabbattha bhavam sabbasmin līne uddhaṭe ca citte icchitabba ttā sabbe
translated: “In the three kinds of becoming”: the meaning is “in the defilements that have the three kinds of becoming for their object.”

original: vā līne uddhaṭe ca bhāvetabbā bojjhaṅgā atthikā etāyāti sabbatthikā. Antosaṅkhepoti
analyzed: vā līne uddhaṭe ca bhāvetabbā bojjhaṅgā atthikā etāya ati sabbatthikā antosaṅkhepā ti
translated: “In all cases”: in all kinds of becoming. Or the meaning is: the factors of enlightenment are needed in all cases, that is, in all slack and excited states of mind that have to be desired, or in all slack and excited states of mental development that have to be developed.

original: antoolīyanā kosajjanti attho.
analyzed: antoolīyanā kosajjanti attho
translated: “Inwardly shrunken”: the meaning is: inwardly contracted, lazy.

original: Avisesena dvīhipi nīvaraṇappahānaṃ vuttanti katvā puna ekekena vuttappahānavisesaṃ🔽dassetuṃ “visesenā”ti āha, “vineyya nīvaraṇānī”ti avatvā abhijjhādomanassavinayassa🔽vā payojanaṃ dassento “visesenā”tiādimāha. Kāyānupassanābhāvanāya ujuvipaccanīkānaṃ
analyzed: avisesena dvīhi pi nīvaraṇa pahānam vuttan ti katvā punar ekekena vutta ppahāna visesam  dassetum visesena ati āha vineyya nīvaraṇāni iti avatvā abhijjhā domanassa vinayassa  vā payojanam dassentaḥ visesena ati ādim āha kāya anupassanā bhāvanāya uju vipaccanīkānam
translated: Since the abandoning of the hindrances is stated in both passages without distinction, he says “in particular” in order to point out the difference in the abandoning stated in the one passage.🔽And since the purpose of the abandoning of covetousness and grief is not stated in the passage beginning, “When a bhikkhu is devoted to these four foundations of mindfulness in this way,”🔽he says “in particular” in order to show the purpose of the abandoning of covetousness and grief. For the purpose of that passage is to show the abandoning of compliance and resistance, etc.,🔽by the development of the contemplation of the body.

original: anurodhavirodhādīnaṃ pahānadassanañhi etassa payojananti. Kāyabhāvanāyāti kāyānupassanābhāvanā
analyzed: anurodha virodha ādīnam pahāna dassanam hi etassa payojanan ti kāya bhāvanāya ati kāya anupassanā bhāvanā
translated: “The development of the body” is intended as the contemplation of the body.

original: adhippetā. Tenāti anurodhādippahānavacanena.
analyzed: adhippetā tena ati anurodha ādi ppahāna vacanena
translated: “By that” : by the statement of the abandoning of compliance, etc.

original: Sabbatthikakammaṭṭhānaṃ buddhānussati mettā maraṇassati asubhabhāvanā ca. Satisampajaññena🔽etena yoginā parihariyamānaṃ taṃ sabbatthikakammaṭṭhānaṃ vuttaṃ satisampajaññabalena
analyzed: sabbatthika kammaṭṭhānam buddha anussati mettā maraṇa ssati asubha bhāvanā ca sati sampajaññena  etena yoginā parihariyamānam tat sabbatthika kammaṭṭhānam vuttam sati sampajañña balena
translated: “The universal meditation subject” is the recollection of the Buddha, loving-kindness, mindfulness of death, and the contemplation of the unattractive.

original: avicchinnassa tassa pariharitabbattā, satiyā vā samatho vutto samādhikkhandhasaṅgahitattā.🔽Kāyānupassanāuddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: avicchinnassa tassa pariharitabba ttā satiyā vā samathaḥ vuttaḥ samādhi kkhandha saṅgahita ttā 🔽kāya anupassanā uddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: “By means of mindfulness and full awareness” : the universal meditation subject is said to be maintained by the power of mindfulness and full awareness because it is maintained without interruption by the meditator by means of that. Or alternatively, mindfulness is said to be concentration because it is included in the concentration aggregate.

original: Vedanānupassanādiuddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: vedanā anupassanā ādi uddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: Description of the directions for contemplation of feeling, etc.

original: Kevalaṃ panidhātiādinā idha ettakaṃ veditabbanti veditabbaṃ paricchedaṃ dasseti. Addamadakkhīti dvepi ekatthā. Sammaddasoti sammā passako.
analyzed: kevalam panidhā ti ādinā idha ettakam veditabbanti veditabbam paricchedam dasseti addamadakkhī iti dve pi ekatthā sammaddaso ti sammā passako
translated: He shows the scope of the knowledge thus: “Only this much should be understood here.” The words “he sees correctly” and “he sees rightly” are synonymous.

original: Sukhadukkhatopi cāti sukhādīnaṃ ṭhitivipariṇāmañāṇasukhatāya, vipariṇāmaṭṭhitiaññāṇadukkhatāya ca vuttattā tissopi ca sukhato tissopi ca dukkhato anupassitabbāti attho.
analyzed: sukha dukkhataḥ pi ca ati sukha ādīnam ṭhiti vipariṇāma ñāṇa sukhatāya vipariṇāma ṭṭhiti aññāṇa dukkhatāya ca vuttattā tissaḥ api ca sukhataḥ tissaḥ api ca dukkhataḥ anupassitabbā ti attho
translated: “From the point of view of pleasure and pain”: because of the pleasure of the knowledge of the stability and change of pleasure, etc., and the pain of the ignorance of the change and stability of pleasure, etc., it is said that they should be contemplated “from the point of view of pleasure” and “from the point of view of pain.”

original: Rūpādiārammaṇachandādiadhipatiñāṇādisahajātakāmāvacarādibhūminānattabhedānaṃ kusalākusalatabbipākakiriyānānattabhedassa
analyzed: rūpa ādi ārammaṇa chanda ādi adhipati ñāṇa ādi sahajāta kāmāvacara ādi bhūmi nānatta bhedānam kusala akusala tad vipāka kiriyā nānatta bhedassa
translated: The words “and so on” should be construed as follows: “from the point of view of the variety of objects such as form, etc., of the variety of faculties such as will, etc., of the variety of knowledge such as knowledge of the faculties of others, etc., of the variety of co-nascence such as the sense-sphere, etc., of the variety of profitable, unprofitable, and indeterminate,

original: ca ādi-saddena sasaṅkhārikāsaṅkhārikasavatthukāvatthukādinānattabhedānañca vasenāti
analyzed: ca ādi saddena vasena ati
translated: and of the variety of formations, etc., such as the variety of formations, etc., consisting in the formed, the unformed, the with-object, the without-object, etc.”

original: yojetabbaṃ. Suññatādhammassāti “dhammā honti, khandhā hontī”tiādinā suññatāvāre āgatasuññatāsabhāvassa
analyzed: yojetabbam suñña tā dhammassa ati dhammāḥ honti khandhāḥ honti iti ādinā suñña tā vāre āgata suñña tā sabhāvassa
translated: “The voidness of ideas”: the voidness of the ideas that occur in the section on voidness, namely, “ideas are, aggregates are,” etc.

original: vasena. Kāmañcetthātiādinā pubbe pahīnattā puna pahānaṃ na vattabbanti codanaṃ dasseti,
analyzed: vasena kāmañca itthā tiādinā pubbe pahīna ttā puna pahānam na vattabban ti codanam dasseti
translated: “If you like, etc.” shows the objection that since it is abandoned already previously, it need not be said to be abandoned again.

original: maggacittakkhaṇe vā ekattha pahīnaṃ sabbattha pahīnaṃ hotīti visuṃ visuṃ na vattabbanti.
analyzed: magga citta kkhaṇe vā ekattha pahīnam sabbattha pahīnam hoti iti visum visum na vattabbanti
translated: Or alternatively, since what is abandoned in one place is abandoned everywhere at the moment of the path, it need not be said separately.

original: Tattha purimacodanāya nānāpuggalaparihāro, pacchimāya nānācittakkhaṇikaparihāro.
analyzed: tattha purima codanāya nānā puggala parihāro pacchimāya nānā cittakkhaṇika parihāro
translated: Herein, the first objection is the objection about different persons, and the second is the objection about different moments of consciousness.

original: Lokiyabhāvanāya hi kāye pahīnaṃ na vedanādīsu vikkhambhitaṃ hoti. Yadipi na pavatteyya,
analyzed: lokiya bhāvanāya hi kāye pahīnam na vedanā ādīsu vikkhambhitam hoti yadi pi na pavatteyya
translated: For what is abandoned in the body by means of mundane development is not suppressed in feeling, and so on. Even if it does not occur,

original: na paṭipakkhabhāvanāya tattha sā abhijjhādomanassassa appavatti hotīti puna tappahānaṃ
analyzed: na paṭipakkha bhāvanāya tattha sā abhijjhā domanassassa appavatti hoti iti puna tad pahānam
translated: it is not suppressed in the body by means of supramundane development. So its abandonment must be stated again.

original: vattabbamevāti. Ubhayattha vā ubhayaṃ sambhavato yojetabbaṃ. Ekattha pahīnaṃ sesesupi
analyzed: vattabbam eva ati ubhayattha vā ubhayam sambhavataḥ yojetabbam ekattha pahīnam sesesu pi
translated: Or alternatively, both can be construed in both ways. What is abandoned in one place is abandoned in the rest too.

original: pahīnaṃ hotīti maggasatipaṭṭhānabhāvanaṃ, lokiyabhāvanāya vā sabbattha appavattimattaṃ
analyzed: pahīnam hoti iti magga sati paṭṭhāna bhāvanam lokiya bhāvanāya vā sabbattha appavattimattam
translated: This is said with reference to the development of the path and the foundations of mindfulness, or else with reference to the mere non-occurrence of mundane development in the rest.

original: sandhāya vuttaṃ. “Pañcapi khandhā loko”ti hi catūsupi vuttanti.
analyzed: sandhāya vuttam pañca api khandhāḥ lokaḥ iti hi catūsu pi vuttan ti
translated: For it is said in the four .

original: Vedanānupassanādiuddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽Uddesavāravaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽Kāyānupassanāniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: vedanā anupassanā ādi uddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  uddesa vāra vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  kāya anupassanā niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: Description of the directions to the meditation subject is ended.

original: 356. Sabbappakāravacanena uddese dassitā ajjhattādianupassanā pakārā ca gahitā. Tattha
translated: In the description of the contemplation of the body, the words “in all ways” include the kinds of contemplation of the internal, etc., shown in the directions, and the kinds of object too. Herein,

original: antogadhā cuddasa pakārā, kāyagatāsatisutte vuttā kesādivaṇṇakasiṇārammaṇacatukkajjhānappakārā,
analyzed: antogadhā cuddasa pakārā kāyagata asati sutte vuttā kesa ādi vaṇṇa kasiṇa ārammaṇa catukka jhāna ppakārā
translated: the fourteen kinds classed as “internal” are the kinds of object consisting of head hairs, body hairs, etc., which are the meditation subjects of the four jhānas based on the kasiṇas beginning with the earth kasiṇa.🔽And the kinds classed as “external” are the kinds of object consisting of head hairs, body hairs, etc., which are the meditation subjects of the four jhānas based on the colours beginning with blue-black.🔽And the kinds classed as “contemplation of repulsiveness” are the kinds of object consisting of head hairs, body hairs, etc., which are the meditation subjects of the four jhānas based on the asubhas beginning with the bloated.🔽And the kinds classed as “mundane” are the kinds of object consisting of head hairs, body hairs, etc., which are the meditation subjects of the four jhānas based on the lokiyas.

original: lokiyādippakārā cāti tepi gahitā eva. Niddese hi ekappakāraniddesena nidassanamattaṃ🔽katanti, sabbappakāraggahaṇañca bāhiresupi ekadesasambhavato katanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: lokiya ādi ppakārā ca ati te pi gahitāḥ eva niddese hi eka ppakāra niddesena nidassana mattam  kata nti sabba ppakāra ggahaṇam ca bāhiresu pi eka desa sambhavato kata nti daṭṭhabbam
translated: And the kinds classed as “supramundane” are the kinds of object consisting of head hairs, body hairs, etc., which are the meditation subjects of the four jhānas based on the lokuttaras.🔽And the kinds classed as “contemplation of the elements” are the kinds of object consisting of head hairs, body hairs, etc., which are the meditation subjects of the four jhānas based on the elements beginning with the earth element.

original: Tiriyaṃ tacaparicchinnanti ettha nanu kesalomanakhānaṃ atacaparicchinnatā tacassa🔽ca atthīti? Yadipi atthi, tacaparicchinnabahulatāya pana tacaparicchinnatā na na
analyzed: tiriyam taca paricchinnan ti ettha nanu kesa loma nakhānam a taca paricchinna tā tacassa  ca atthi iti yadi api atthi taca paricchinna bahula tāya pana taca paricchinna tā na na
translated: And the kinds classed as “contemplation of the sense-spheres” are the kinds of object consisting of head hairs, body hairs, etc., which are the meditation subjects of the four jhānas based on the sense-spheres beginning with the eye-sphere.🔽And the kinds classed as “contemplation of the round” are the kinds of object consisting of head hairs, body hairs, etc., which are the meditation subjects of the four jhānas based on the round beginning with ignorance.

original: hoti kāyassāti evaṃ vuttaṃ. Taco pariyanto assāti tacapariyantoti vuttoti etena pana
analyzed: hoti kāyassa ati evam vuttam tacaḥ pariyantaḥ assa ati taca pariyantaḥ iti vuttaḥ ti etena pana
translated: And the kinds classed as “contemplation of arising” are the kinds of object consisting of head hairs, body hairs, etc., which are the meditation subjects of the four jhānas based on the condition beginning with condition in the form of decisive support.🔽And the

original: vacanena kāyekadesabhūto taco gahito eva. Tappaṭibaddhā ca kesādayo tadanupaviṭṭhamūlā
analyzed: vacanena kāya ekadeśa bhūtaḥ tacaḥ gahitaḥ eva tad paṭibaddhā ca kesa ādayaḥ tad an upaviṭṭha mūlā
translated: and by the word “skin” the skin, which is a part of the body, is included. And the head hairs, etc., are bound up with the skin, which is their support. They are rooted in the skin,

original: tacapariyantāva hontīti dvattiṃsākārasamūho sabbopi kāyo tacapariyantoti vuttoti veditabbo.🔽“Pūraṃ nānappakārassā”ti vuttaṃ, ke pana te pakārā? Yehi nānappakāraṃ asuci vuttanti
analyzed: taca pariyantā ava honti iti dvattiṃsa ākāra samūho sabbaḥ api kāyo taca pariyanto ti vutto ti veditabbaḥ  pūram nānā pakārassa ati vuttam ke pana te pakārāḥ yehi nānā pakāram asuci vuttan ti
translated: and they are bounded by the skin. So the whole thirty-two parts should be understood as “the body bounded by the skin.”🔽“The various kinds of filth” : but what are the various kinds of filth?

original: kesā lomātiādi vuttanti imamatthaṃ dīpento āha “ete kesādayo ākārā”ti. Ākārā pakārāti hi eko attho.
analyzed: kesāḥ loma atiādi vuttanti imam attham dīpentaḥ āha ete kesa ādayaḥ ākārā ati ākārā pakārā ati hi ekaḥ atthaḥ
translated: The various kinds of filth are called “head hairs, body hairs, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone marrow, kidney, heart, liver, midriff, spleen, lungs, bowels, entrails, gorge, dung, brain, bile, phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, spit, mucus, synovic fluid, urine” .🔽The various kinds of filth are called “head hairs, body hairs, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone marrow, kidney, heart, liver, midriff, spleen, lungs, bowels, entrails, gorge, dung, brain, bile, phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, spit, mucus, synovic fluid, urine” .

original: Nisinnassa yāva aparipphandanisajjāmūlakaṃ dukkhaṃ uppajjati, yāvatā uṭṭhāti vā,
analyzed: nisinnassa yāva a paripphanda nisajjā mūlakam dukkham uppajjati yāvatā uṭṭhāti vā
translated: When a man is sitting down, the pain that arises in the legs from the time when he sits down until he gets up and moves about is called “the pain of sitting.”

original: tāva eko nisajjavāro. Yena vidhinā uggahe kusalo hoti, so sattavidho vidhi “uggahakosalla”nti
analyzed: tāva ekaḥ nisajja vāraḥ yena vidhinā uggahe kusalaḥ hoti so sattavidhaḥ vidhi uggaha kosallanti
translated: The sevenfold method by which one who is skilled in learning is skilled is called “skill in learning.”

original: vuccati, taṃnibbattaṃ vā ñāṇaṃ.
analyzed: vuccati tad nibbattam vā ñāṇam
translated: Or it is the knowledge that is produced by that .

original: Pathavīdhātubahulabhāvato matthaluṅgassa karīsāvasāne tantiāropanamāha. Ettha pana
analyzed: pathavī dhātu bahula bhāvataḥ matthaluṅgassa karīsa avasāne tanti āropanam āha ettha pana
translated: The placing of the thread is said to be at the end of the dung in the belly, because the brain is the most abundant element in the head. But here

original: maṃsaṃ…pe… vakkaṃ…pe… kesāti evaṃ vakkapañcakādīsu anulomasajjhāyaṃ vatvā paṭilomasajjhāyo🔽purimehi sambandho vutto. Svāyaṃ ye parato visuṃ tipañcāhaṃ, purimehi ekato tipañcāhanti🔽chapañcāhaṃ sajjhāyā vakkhamānā, tesu ādiantadassanavasena vuttoti daṭṭhabbo. Anulomapaṭilomasajjhāyepi🔽hi paṭilomasajjhāyo antimoti. Sajjhāyappakārantaraṃ vā etampīti veditabbaṃ. Hatthasaṅkhalikā🔽aṅgulipanti. Lakkhaṇapaṭivedhassāti asubhalakkhaṇapaṭivedhassa, dhātulakkhaṇapaṭivedhassa vā.
