original: (1.) Ekakaniddesavaṇṇanā
translated: 1. Description of the “one-unit” section

original: 843-844. Atthi paṭiccaṃ nāmāti yathā “cakkhuñca paṭiccā”tiādīsu nissayādipaccayabhāvena🔽paṭiccāti vuttaṃ, na tathā idha khattiyādijātīnaṃ paramatthato avijjamānānaṃ nissayādipaccayattassa
analyzed: atthi paṭiccam nāma ati yathā cakkhum ca paṭicca ati ādīsu nissaya ādi paccaya bhāvena  paṭicca iti vuttam na tathā idha khattiya ādi jātīnam paramatthataḥ avijjamānānam nissaya ādi paccayattassa
translated: “With a condition”: just as “with eye and visible data” is said with the meaning of support condition, etc.,🔽so here it is not said with the meaning of support condition, etc., because the clans such as the Khattiyas do not exist in the ultimate sense.

original: abhāvā. Yesu pana khandhesu santesu khattiyādisammuti hoti, tesaṃ abbocchinnatāva
analyzed: abhāvā yesu pana khandhesu santesu khattiya ādi sammuti hoti tesam
translated: But the fact that the aggregates in the presence of which the designation “Khattiya” occurs are not cut off is

original: khattiyādijātiyā atthitā, sā idha paṭicca-saddena vibhāvitāti attho. Ekissā seṇiyāti
analyzed: khattiya ādi jātiyāḥ atthi tā sā idha paṭicca saddena vibhāvitā ati attho ekissā seṇiyā ti
translated: the existence of the clan “Khattiya,” and that is what is intended here by the word “with a condition.”

original: asambhinnāyāti attho.🔽Pañhavissajjanādikiriyāsu purato karaṇaṃ purekkhāro. Nikkheparāsīti nidhānarāsi.
analyzed: a sambhinnāya ati atthaḥ  pañha vissajjana ādi kiriyāsu puratas karaṇam purekkhāraḥ nikkhepa rāsi iti nidhāna rāsi
translated: “One family” means “not mixed.”🔽“Foremost” is the placing in front in the answering of questions, etc. “Heap of what is laid down” is a heap of what is stored.

original: Patthaṭākittinoti vitthiṇṇākittino. Rattaññumadoti purāṇaññutāmadoti vadanti. Cirarattijātena,
analyzed: patthaṭākittino ti vitthiṇṇākittinaḥ rattaññu mado ti purāṇaññu tā mado ti vadanti cira ratti jātena
translated: “Widely renowned” means “renowned far and wide.” “Drunk with long-standing conceit” is said to be “drunk with conceit about long-standing knowledge.”

original: cirarattipabbajitena vā jānitabbassa, rattīnameva vā jānanamado. Upaṭṭhāpakamānoti
analyzed: cira ratti pabbajitena vā jānitabbassa rattīnam eva vā jānana madaḥ upaṭṭhāpaka mānaḥ ti
translated: or it is the pride in knowing what should be known by one gone forth for a long time, or it is the mere pride in knowing the nights. The pride of being a servant is

original: āṇākaraṇamāno. Āṇākaraṇañhi vicāraṇaṃ idha “yaso”ti vuttanti. Parimaṇḍalattabhāvanissito
analyzed: āṇākaraṇa mānaḥ āṇākaraṇam hi vicāraṇam idha vuttanti parimaṇḍalatta bhāva nissito
translated: the pride in obeying orders. For obeying orders is called “glory” here. The pride of being a great man is

original: māno pariṇāhamado. Sarīrasampattipāripūriyā mado pāripūrimado.
analyzed: māno pariṇāha madaḥ sarīra sampatti pāripūriyā mado pāripūri madaḥ
translated: the pride based on the development of a great man’s qualities. The pride of being full is the pride in being complete through the excellence of the body.

original: 845. Vatthunā vināpi vattabbatāya avatthukaṃ, na vatthuno abhāvā.
analyzed: vatthunā vinā api vattabbatāya avatthukam na vatthunaḥ abhāvā
translated: . It is groundless in that it is to be spoken of without a ground, not in that the ground does not exist.

original: 846. Cittassa vossajjananti cittassa satito muccanaṃ, kāyaduccaritādīsu pakkhandanaṃ
analyzed: cittassa vossajjananti cittassa satitaḥ muccanam kāya duccarita ādīsu pakkhandanam
translated: . The giving up of cognizance is the letting go of cognizance through mindfulness, or the giving up in the sense of plunging into bodily misconduct, etc.

original: vā vossaggo. Patiṭṭhābhāvoti kusalakaraṇe aṭṭhānaṃ, anuṭṭhānanti attho. Pamādasaṅkhātassa
analyzed: vā vossaggaḥ patiṭṭhā bhāvo ti kusala karaṇe aṭṭhānam anuṭṭhānam ti attho pamāda saṅkhātassa
translated: . The absence of a footing is the absence of a place for the profitable, the meaning being the absence of effort. The giving up of cognizance in the sense of negligence

original: atthassa kāyaduccarite cittassa vossaggo pāṇātipāte micchādiṭṭhiyaṃ kodhe upanāheti
analyzed: atthassa kāya duccarite cittassa vossaggo pāṇātipāte micchādiṭṭhiyam kodhe upanāheti
translated: in bodily misconduct, etc., is the giving up in killing breathing things, in wrong view, in hate, etc.

original: evamādiko pariyāyo apariyanto, tadatthatappariyāyappakāsako vossagganissaggādiko
analyzed: evamādiko pariyāyaḥ a pariyantaḥ tad attha tad pariyāya ppakāsako vossagga nissagga ādiko
translated: This method, which is called “giving up,” etc., is unlimited, and it reveals the unlimited meaning of the words.

original: byañjanapariyāyo cāti sabbaṃ taṃ saṅkhipitvā evarūpoti idaṃ ākāranidassanaṃ sabbapariyāyassa
analyzed: byañjana pariyāyaḥ ca ati sabbam tam saṅkhipitvā evarūpaḥ ti idam ākāra nidassanam sabba pariyāyassa
translated: and the phrasing is a roundabout way of saying it. All that can be summarized as follows: “Such and such” is a description of the mode.

original: vattuṃ asakkuṇeyyattā katanti dassento āha “pariyantābhāvato”ti. Vissaṭṭhākāroti
analyzed: vattum asakkuṇeyya ttā katanti dassentaḥ āha pariyanta abhāvato ti vissaṭṭha ākārā iti
translated: Because it is impossible to state all the roundabout ways, he says “because of the absence of a limit.”

original: satiyā paccanīkabhūte cattāro khandhe dasseti.
analyzed: satiyā paccanīka bhūte cattāro khandhe dasseti
translated: The mode of spreading out is shown by the four aggregates, which are the opposites of mindfulness.🔽They say that the stiffness of mind is the same as the mind that occurs in that way, or it should be regarded as a special kind of conceit.

original: 847. Cittassa thaddhatā tathāpavattacittamevāti vadanti, mānaviseso vā daṭṭhabbo. Upasaṅkamane vanditabbaṃ hotīti pariyanteneva carati.
analyzed: cittassa thaddha tā tathā pavatta cittam eva ati vadanti māna visesaḥ vā daṭṭhabbo upasaṅkamane vanditabbam hoti iti pariyantena iva carati
translated: When he goes to meet him, he should pay homage. He goes about with a limit.

original: 848. “Āpattiṃ āpannosī”ti vutte “āvuso, tvaṃ āpannosī”tiādinā tena vuttaṃ tasseva🔽upari khipanavasena “paṭippharitvā”ti vadanti. “Tasmiṃ nāma dalidde, akusale vā idaṃ
analyzed: āpattim āpannā asi iti vutte āvuso tvam āpannā asi iti ādinā tena vuttam tassa eva  upari khipana vasena paṭippharitvā iti vadanti tasmin nāma dalidde akusale vā idam
translated: When it is said, “You have fallen into an offense,” he says, “Friend, you have fallen into an offense,” and so on.

original: karonte ahaṃ kasmā na karomī”ti evaṃ idha paṭippharaṇaṃ yuttaṃ. Karaṇassa uttarakiriyā
analyzed: karonte aham kasmai na karomi iti evam idha paṭippharaṇam yuttam karaṇassa uttara kiriyā
translated: By throwing it back on him, they say, he “reverses it.” It is appropriate to reverse it in this way: “When he is so poor, or when he is doing this unwholesomely, why shouldn’t I do it?” The action that is the outcome of the action is the outcome of the action.

original: karaṇuttariyaṃ. Akusalapakkho esāti sārambhoti adhippāyo.
analyzed: karaṇa uttariyam akusala pakkhaḥ esā ati sa ārambhā ti adhippāyo
translated: The unprofitable side is what is meant by “with resistance.”

original: 849. Aticca icchatīti aticciccho, tassa bhāvo aticcicchatāti vattabbe cci-kāralopaṃ
analyzed: aticcaḥ icchati iti aticcicchaḥ tassa bhāvaḥ vattabbe ccikāra lopam
translated: He wishes beyond : he is one who wishes beyond , thus he is aticchati . The state of that is aticchatā . But in order to make it aticchatā by the elision of the cci-ka-ra-vowel sign,

original: katvā “aticchatā”ti vuttaṃ. Atricchatāti ca sā eva vuccatīti. Tatrāpi neruttikavidhānena
analyzed: katvā vuttam atricchatā iti ca sā eva vuccati iti tatra api neruttika vidhānena
translated: it is said to be aticchatā . And that is called aticchā too. And there too the derivation of the word should be understood according to the method of the Neruktikas.

original: padasiddhi veditabbā. Yathāladdhaṃ vā atikkamitvā atra atra icchanaṃ atricchatā,
analyzed: pada siddhi veditabbā yathā laddham vā atikkamitvā atra atra icchanam atricchatā
translated: Or alternatively, aticchatā is the wishing beyond , the wishing here and there after getting what has been got.

original: sā eva ra-kārassa ta-kāraṃ katvā “aticchatā”ti vuttā.
analyzed: sā eva rakārassa takāram katvā aticchatā iti vuttā
translated: That is said to be aticchatā by making the ra-sign of the ra in aticchati into a ta-sign.🔽He wishes beyond , thus he is an aticchati . Or he wishes here and there, thus he is an aticchati .

original: Atricchanti aticchaṃ, atra vā icchanto. Kena? Atilobhena atilobhamicchāsaṅkhātena
analyzed: atricchanti aticcham atra vai ati lobhena ati lobham icchā saṅkhātena
translated: By what? By excessive greed, by excessive greed called wishing.

original: atilobhamadena ca. Attano hitaṃ attāti vuttaṃ. Hāyati jīrati, ādiṇṇo vā attā, patto
analyzed: ati lobha madena ca attanaḥ hitam attā ati vuttam hāyati jīrati ādiṇṇaḥ vā attā patto
translated: And by excessive greed-intoxication. His own good is called his self . He is diminished , he is worn away, or his self is taken away, or his self is reached,

original: vā attā, naṃ jīrati candakinnariṃ patthayitvā asitābhūdeviyā vihīno viya.
analyzed: vā attā nam jīrati candakinnarim patthayitvā asitābhūdeviyā vihīnaḥ
translated: and he is worn away, like the moon after it has reached the Kinnari of the dawn, or like the god Asita after he had lost the goddess of the earth.

original: Icchāhatassāti icchāya upaddutassa, mudditassa vā.
analyzed: icchā hatassa ati icchāya upaddutassa mudditassa vā
translated: He is ruined by wishing : he is afflicted by wishing, or he is oppressed by wishing.

original: Atihīḷayānoti avamaññamāno. Malakanti evaṃnāmakaṃ janapadaṃ, abbhokāsaṃ vā. Kodaṇḍakenāti kudaṇḍakena rassadaṇḍakena. Gaddulenāti ca vadanti. Ruhiramakkhitaṅgoti ruhirasinnagatto.
analyzed: ati hīḷayānaḥ iti avamaññamānaḥ malakam ti evaṃnāmakam janapadam abbhokāsam vā kodaṇḍakena ati kudaṇḍakena rassadaṇḍakena gaddulena ati ca vadanti ruhira makkhitaṅgo ti ruhira sinna gatto
translated: “Too much contempt”: disrespecting. “Malaka”: a country by that name, or the open air. “With a cudgel”: with a cudgel, a short stick. “Gaddulena” is also said. “Smeared with blood”: covered with blood.

original: 850. Jānantasseva bhiyyo bhiyyo codento viya sambhāvetukāmo hoti. Paccayeti upādānādipaccaye.
analyzed: jānantassa iva bhiyyas bhiyyas codentaḥ viya sambhāvetu kāmaḥ hoti paccaye iti upādāna ādi paccaye
translated: He wants to honour him as if he were accusing him more and more, though he knows. “Conditions”: conditions such as clinging.

original: 851. Ye patirūpena vañcenti, te gaṇṭhikā, durācārena vā gaṇṭhibhūtā. Gaṇṭhikaputtā
analyzed: ye pati rūpena vañcenti te gaṇṭhikāḥ durācārena vā gaṇṭhi bhūtāḥ gaṇṭhika puttā
translated: Those who deceive by means of a likeness are “snares,” or they are snares by means of bad conduct. “Sons of snares”

original: nāma gaṇṭhikā eva honti, tena saddhivihārikā gaṇṭhikabhāvena “thero…pe… dīghacaṅkame🔽viharatī”ti vadanti.🔽Vaṭṭati bhanteti ayampi eko pakāro, lābhinā eva pana sakkā ñātunti attano samāpattilābhitaṃ
analyzed: nāma gaṇṭhikāḥ eva honti tena saddhivihārikāḥ gaṇṭhika bhāvena therope dīghacaṅkame  viharati iti vadanti  vaṭṭati bhante ti ayam pi ekaḥ pakāraḥ lābhinā eva pana sakkā ñātun ti attanaḥ samāpatti lābhitam
translated: are just snares. Because of the state of being a snare, his pupils say: “The elder … walks on a long walk.”

original: sūcetīti attho. Pañcattayaṃ nāma uparipaṇṇāsake dutiyasuttaṃ. Tassa gambhīrattā vadati
analyzed: sūcā iti iti attho pañcattayam nāma upari paṇṇāsake dutiya suttam tassa gambhīra ttā vadati
translated: “It is allowable, venerable sir”: this is another way. But only one who is successful can know. The meaning is that he indicates his own attainment of concentration. “The five groups of five”: the second sutta in the “Over Fifty” . Because of its profundity, he says:

original: “pañcattayaṃ olokentassā”ti.
analyzed: pañcattayam olokentassa āti
translated: “Looking at the five groups of five.”

original: 852. Siṅganti siṅgāraṃ. Tañhi kusalassa vijjhanato samāsevitatāya sīse parikkhataṃ sunikhataṃ visāṇaṃ viya, thirattā ca siṅgaṃ viyāti siṅgaṃ, taṃ panatthato rāgo.🔽853. Temanakaraṇatthe tintiṇa-saddo daṭṭhabbo. Khīyananti ca yena lobhena paraṃ mamanti
analyzed: siṅganti siṅgāram tat hi kusalassa samāsevita tāya sīse parikkhatam su nikhatam visāṇam viya thira ttā ca siṅgam viyāti siṅgam tam pana atthataḥ rāgaḥ  temana karaṇa atthe tintiṇa saddo daṭṭhabbo ca yena lobhena param mamanti
translated: “Horn” is passion. For that is called “horn” because it is pierced by what is profitable, because it is well-shaped and well-formed in the head, like a horn, and because it is firm like a horn. But in the sense of the word it is greed.🔽The word “grass” should be taken in the sense of “grass-making” . And the word “weariness” is said of the greed by which one is worn out,

original: vadantaṃ khīyati, so vutto. Khīyanaṃ bhaṇḍananti ca vadanti. Tintiṇanti vā loluppamicceva
analyzed: vadantam khīyati saḥ vuttaḥ khīyanam bhaṇḍananti ca vadanti tintiṇanti vā loluppam icca eva
translated: saying “It is mine” to another’s property. And they say that “weariness” is “quarrel” . Or the word “grass” is said of greed itself,

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Saññā-saddo hi eso loluppavācakoti.🔽854. Ūruppamāṇāpīti etena mahantaghanabhāvena apūtitaṃ dasseti. Athavātiādinā cīvaramaṇḍanādīnaṃ
analyzed: vuttam hoti saññā saddo hi eso loluppa vācakaḥ ti  ūru pamāṇā api iti etena mahanta ghana bhāvena apūti tam dasseti athavā ati ādinā cīvara maṇḍana ādīnam
translated: for this word “grass” is a term for greed.🔽“Even though it is the size of a mere thumb”: he shows that it is not filled with a great mass. Or “even though” , etc., shows the distinctions of adorning the robe, etc.,

original: visesanāni “imassa vā pūtikāyassa bāhirānaṃ vā parikkhārānaṃ maṇḍanā”tiādīnīti dasseti.
analyzed: visesanāni imassa vā pūti kāyassa bāhirānam vā parikkhārānam maṇḍana ati ādīni iti dasseti
translated: as “adorning of this putrid body or of the external requisites” , and so on.

original: Cīvarena hi maṇḍanā cīvaramaṇḍanā, cīvarassa vā maṇḍanā cīvaramaṇḍanā, evaṃ pattamaṇḍanā
analyzed: cīvarena hi maṇḍanā cīvara maṇḍanā cīvarassa vā maṇḍanā cīvara maṇḍanā evam patta maṇḍanā
translated: For “adorning with a robe” is either adorning a robe or adorning with a robe. So too with the bowl.

original: senāsanamaṇḍanā cāti adhippāyo. Ūnaṭṭhānapūraṇaṃ chavirāgasusaṇṭhānādikaraṇañca cīvarādīsu
analyzed: senāsana maṇḍanā ca ati adhippāyaḥ ūna ṭṭhāna pūraṇam chavi rāga su saṇṭhāna ādi karaṇam ca cīvara ādīsu
translated: The meaning is that he is not intent on adorning his resting place, etc., and on filling up the gaps, and on making his robes, etc., attractive by removing discoloured patches, etc.🔽This should be applied as appropriate to the body too.

original: kāye ca yathāyogaṃ yojetabbaṃ. Tadahujātadārako viya hotīti dārakacāpalyaṃ na muñcatīti attho.
analyzed: kāye ca yathāyogam yojetabbam tad ahu jāta dārakaḥ viya hoti iti dāraka cāpalyam na muñcati iti attho
translated: The meaning is that he does not let go of the childishness of a newly born infant.

original: 855. Sadisā anurūpā bhatti sabhāgo, na sabhāgo asabhāgo, mānathaddhatā, virodho vā. Tenassa mātādīsu vattanaṃ asabhāgavuttitā. Evaṃvidhānaṃ mānādhikānaṃ akusalānamidaṃ nāmaṃ.
analyzed: sadisāḥ anurūpāḥ sabhāgaḥ na sabhāgaḥ asabhāgaḥ māna thaddha tā virodhaḥ vā tena assa mātā ādīsu vattanam asabhāga vutti tā evaṃvidhānam māna adhikānam akusalānam idam nāmam
translated: A suitable, appropriate, or equal portion is a share; an unequal portion is not a share. Arrogance is haughtiness or opposition. Therefore his behaviour towards his mother, etc., is called “unshared behaviour.” This is the name for such kinds of unwholesome states that are based on conceit.

original: 856. Paritassitāti saṅkampanā, ukkaṇṭhitassa vā tassa tassa taṇhāyanā.
analyzed: paritassitā ati saṅkampanā ukkaṇṭhitassa vā tassa tassa taṇhāyanā
translated: Anxiety is agitation or the craving of one who is discontented.

original: 857. Kusalakaraṇe kāyassa avipphārikatā līnatā jātiālasyaṃ, na rogautubhojanādīhi🔽kāyagelaññaṃ tandī nāma, atha kho pakatiālasyanti attho. Kāyālasiyanti nāmakāyassa
analyzed: kusala karaṇe kāyassa a vipphārika tā līna tā jāti ālasyam na roga autubhojana ādīhi  kāyagelaññam tandī nāma atha kho pakati ālasyanti attho kāyālasiyanti nāma kāyassa
translated: Laziness is the unserviceability of the body for making a wholesome effort. It is sluggishness, natural idleness.

original: ālasiyaṃ, tadeva rūpakāyassāpīti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: ālasiyam tat eva rūpa kāyassa api iti daṭṭhabbam
translated: The laziness of the body is the laziness of the bodily formation. It should be regarded as the laziness of the material body too.

original: 858. Accasanādīhi uppannadhātukkhobhanimittaṃ ālasiyaṃ vijambhitā.
analyzed: accasana ādīhi uppanna dhātu kkhobha nimittam ālasiyam vijambhi tā
translated: Yawning is the laziness that arises from the humours being disturbed by overeating, etc.

original: 859. Bhattanimittena uppannaṃ ālasyaṃ bhattasammado.
analyzed: bhatta nimittena uppannam ālasyam bhatta sammadaḥ
translated: Laziness arisen with the sign of a meal is “laziness after a meal.”

original: 860. Imehi panāti cittassa akalyatādīhi. Sabbattha kilesavasenāti thinamiddhakāraṇānaṃ rāgādīnaṃ vasenāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: imehi pana ati cittassa akalya tā ādīhi sabbattha kilesa vasena ati thinam iddha kāraṇānam rāga ādīnam vasena ati daṭṭhabbam
translated: “By all these” means by the unfitness of the mind, etc. “By defilement” should be understood as by greed, etc., which are the causes of stiffness and torpor.

original: 861. Sammāājīvato apeto katoti apakato. So ājīvupaddavena upaddutoti katvā āha “upaddutassāti attho”ti.
analyzed: sammāājīvataḥ apetaḥ katoti apakato so ājīva upaddavena upaddutoti katvā āha upaddutassa ati attho ti
translated: “Distressed” means “distressed by the calamity of livelihood.”

original: Tividhampi taṃ tattha āgataṃ tassa nissayabhūtāya imāya pāḷiyā dassetunti evamattho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: tividham pi tam tattha āgatam tassa nissaya bhūtāya imāya pāḷiyā dassetun ti evamatthaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: The meaning should be understood as follows: the three kinds of distress that are given there are shown by this text, which is the basis for them.

original: Pāpaṇikānīti āpaṇato chaḍḍitāni. Nantakānīti antarahitāni, cīrāni vā. Gilānassa paccayabhūtā
analyzed: pāpaṇikāni iti āpaṇataḥ chaḍḍitāni nantakāni iti anta rahitāni cīrāni vā gilānassa paccaya bhūtā
translated: “Goods for sale” are goods thrown out from a shop. “Cast off” means lost or cast off robes.

original: bhesajjasaṅkhātā jīvitaparikkhārā gilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhārā. Pūtimuttanti purāṇassa
analyzed: bhesajja saṅkhātāḥ jīvita parikkhārāḥ gilāna paccaya bhesajja parikkhārā pūti muttanti purāṇassa
translated: “Medicines for the sick” are requisites for living, that is, medicines,

original: apurāṇassa ca sabbassa gomuttassetaṃ nāmaṃ. Pūtibhāvena chaḍḍitosadhantipi keci.
analyzed: apurāṇassa ca sabbassa gomuttassa etam nāmam pūti bhāvena keci
translated: which are a condition for the sick. “Rotten urine” is the name for all urine, whether old or not,🔽whether of a cow or not. Some say it is medicine thrown out because of its bad smell.

original: Agabbhikā ekadvārā dīghasālā kira uddaṇḍo. Kucchitarajabhūtāya pāpicchatāya niratthakakāyavacīvipphandaniggahaṇaṃ🔽korajaṃ, taṃ etassa atthīti korajiko, ativiya korajiko korajikakorajiko. Atiparisaṅkitoti
analyzed: agabbhikā eka dvārā dīghasālā kira uddaṇḍo kucchita raja bhūtāya pāpa icchatāya niratthaka kāya vacī vipphanda niggahaṇam  korajam tam etassa atthi iti korajikaḥ ativiya korajikaḥ korajika korajikaḥ atiparisaṅkitaḥ iti
translated: He is a “crook” because he is crooked like a crook. He is a “crook-crook” because he is a crook to an extreme degree. Some say that he is “much suspected.”

original: keci. Mukhasambhāvitoti korajikakorajikādibhāvena pavattavacanehi attano mukhamattena
analyzed: keci korajika korajika ādi bhāvena pavatta vacanehi attanaḥ mukha mattena
translated: He is “honoured by the mouth” because he is honoured by others with words such as “You are a crook, a crook,” etc., which are uttered by the mouth alone.

original: aññehi sambhāvito. So evarūpo evarūpatāya eva attānaṃ paraṃ viya katvā “ayaṃ samaṇo”tiādiṃ katheti.
analyzed: aññehi sambhāvito saḥ evarūpaḥ evarūpa tāya eva attānam param viya katvā ayam samaṇa uti ādim kathā iti
translated: Such a one, by reason of his being such, makes himself like another and speaks thus: “This recluse … ”

original: Paṇidhāyāti “arahāti maṃ jānantū”ti cittaṃ ṭhapetvā, patthetvā vā. Āpāthakajjhāyīti manussānaṃ āpāthaṭṭhāne samādhiṃ samāpanno viya nisīdanto āpāthake janassa pākaṭaṭṭhāne jhāyī.
analyzed: paṇidhāya ati arahā ati mama jānantu uti cittam ṭhapetvā patthetvā vā āpāthaka jjhāyī ti manussānam āpātha ṭṭhāne samādhim samāpannaḥ viya nisīdantaḥ āpāthake janassa pākaṭa ṭṭhāne jhāyī
translated: “Having resolved”: having set his mind on the thought “Let them know me for an Arahant,” or having aspired to it. “Meditating in the hearing”: sitting down as if he had attained concentration in the hearing of men, meditating in the hearing of people who are in the hearing.

original: Aññaṃ viya katvā attano samīpe bhaṇanaṃ sāmantajappitaṃ. Ākārassa rassattaṃ katvā
analyzed: aññam viya katvā attano samīpe bhaṇanam sāmanta jappitam ākārassa rassattam katvā
translated: He speaks in the presence of others as if he were speaking to himself. He makes the form of his voice low

original: “aṭhapanā”ti vuttaṃ. Kuhanaṃ kuho, tassa ayanā pavatti kuhāyanā, kuhassa vā puggalassa
analyzed: aṭhapanā iti vuttam kuhanam kuhaḥ tassa ayanā pavatti kuhāyanā kuhassa vā puggalassa
translated: “Deception” is what is meant. The state of that is deceptiveness.

original: ayanā gatikiriyā kuhāyanā.
analyzed: ayanā gati kiriyā kuhāyanā
translated: Or the state of that person’s going, his activity, is deceptiveness.🔽“Asked” : asked “Who is Tissa? Who is honoured by the king?”

original: 862. Puṭṭhassāti “ko tisso, ko rājapūjito”ti puṭṭhassa. Nahanāti bandhanā pariveṭhanā.
analyzed: puṭṭhassa ati kaḥ tisso kaḥ rāja pūjito ti puṭṭhassa nahanā ati bandhanā pariveṭhanā
translated: “Hint” : a bond, a roundabout expression.

original: 863. Nimittena caranto jīvanto nimittakārako nemittiko, tassa bhāvo nemittikatā.🔽Attano icchāya pakāsanaṃ obhāso. Ko pana soti? “Ajja bhikkhūnaṃ paccayā dullabhā
analyzed: nimittena carantaḥ jīvantaḥ nimitta kārako nemittikaḥ tassa bhāvaḥ nemittika tā  attanaḥ icchāya pakāsanam obhāsaḥ kaḥ pana so ti ajja bhikkhūnam paccayā dullabhā
translated: “Sign” : one who lives by signs, a fortune-teller, is a nemittika; the state of that is nemittikatā.🔽“Light” : self-advertisement. But what is that? It is talk about requisites such as this: “Today requisites are hard to get for bhikkhus.”

original: jātā”tiādikā paccayapaṭisaṃyuttakathā. Icchitavatthussa samīpe kathanaṃ sāmantajappā.
analyzed: jāta ati ādikā paccaya paṭisaṃyutta kathā icchita vatthussa samīpe kathanam sāmantajappā
translated: And talk about a thing that is wanted in the vicinity of the thing wanted is hinting.

original: 864. Bahi chaḍḍanaṃ ukkhepanā. Parapiṭṭhimaṃsakhādanasīlo parapiṭṭhimaṃsiko, tassa bhāvo parapiṭṭhimaṃsikatā.
analyzed: bahi chaḍḍanam ukkhepanā para piṭṭhi maṃsa khādana sīlo para piṭṭhi maṃsikaḥ tassa bhāvaḥ para piṭṭhi maṃsika tā
translated: “Throwing out” : casting out. One who has the habit of eating the flesh of others’ backs is a parapiṭṭhimaṃsiko; the state of that is parapiṭṭhimaṃsikatā.

original: 865. Nikattuṃ appena lābhena bahukaṃ vañcetvā gahetuṃ icchanaṃ nijigīsanaṃ, tassa bhāvo nijigīsanatā. Tasseva icchanassa pavattiākāro, taṃsahajātaṃ vā gavesanakammaṃ.
analyzed: nikattum appena lābhena bahukam vañcetvā gahetum icchanam nijigīsanam tassa bhāvaḥ nijigīsana tā tassa iva icchanassa pavatti ākāraḥ tad sahajātam vā gavesana kammaṃ
translated: The desire to take possession of much by deceiving with a little gain is the wish to be pre-eminent; the state of that is the wish to be pre-eminent. Or the mode of occurrence of the one who wishes is that, or the act of seeking that is conascent with it.

original: 866. Vaṇṇasampannaṃ pokkharaṃ vaṇṇapokkharanti uttarapadalopo pubbapadassa daṭṭhabbo,
analyzed: vaṇṇa sampannam pokkharam vaṇṇa pokkharanti uttara pada lopaḥ pubba padassa daṭṭhabbo
translated: The word “pokkhara” is a word for a pond, and “vaṇṇapokkhara” is the elision of the middle term in the expression “vaṇṇasampannaṃ pokkharaṃ vaṇṇapokkhara” .🔽Or “vaṇṇapokkharatā” is the fulfilment of beauty.

original: vaṇṇapāripūrī vā vaṇṇapokkharatā. “Atthajāpikā”ti ettha viya japa-saddo uppattivācakoti āha “pavattetī”ti.
analyzed: vaṇṇa pāripūrī vā vaṇṇa pokkhara tā attha jāpikā ti ettha viya japa saddo uppatti vācakaḥ ti āha pavatteti iti
translated: The word “jappa” is a word for occurrence, as in the passage “Atthajāpikā” , he said.

original: 867. Seyyasadisamānā unnativasena pavattāti ubhayatthāpi “mānaṃ jappetī”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: seyya sadisa mānā unnati vasena pavattā ati ubhayattha api mānam jappeti iti vuttam
translated: It occurs by way of the elevation that is like a high bed, thus it is said that “it makes conceit occur” in both instances.

original: 868. Hīnamāno pana onativasena pavattito kevalena mānasaddena niddesaṃ nārahatīti taṃniddese “omānaṃ jappetī”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: hīna mānaḥ pana onati vasena pavattitaḥ kevalena māna saddena niddesam na ārahati iti tad niddese omānam jappeti iti vuttam
translated: But the low form of conceit does not deserve to be demonstrated by the word “conceit” alone since it occurs by way of depression, thus in its demonstration it is said that “it makes lowliness occur” .

original: 872. Rājabhogena raṭṭhabhuñjanako rājanissito raṭṭhiyo.
analyzed: rāja bhogena raṭṭha bhuñjanakaḥ rāja nissitaḥ raṭṭhiyaḥ
translated: The king’s subjects are the people of the realm who enjoy the king’s wealth.

original: 879. Puggalaṃ anāmasitvāti yathā seyyassa seyyamānādiniddesesu “parehi seyyaṃ attānaṃ
analyzed: puggalam an āmasitvā ti yathā seyyassa seyyamāna ādi niddesesu parehi seyyam attānam
translated: Without specifying the person, as in the case of the demonstrations of “conceit about being superior” , etc., in the passage “He thinks ‘I am superior’ or ‘I am equal’ or ‘I am inferior’ to someone who is superior, or … who is equal, or … who is inferior” ,

original: dahatī”ti seyyādipuggalo mānuppādako āmaṭṭho, evametassa seyyamānabhāvepi mānuppādakapuggalavisesaṃ
analyzed: dahati iti seyya ādi puggalaḥ māna uppādakaḥ āmaṭṭhaḥ evam etassa seyyamāna bhāve pi māna uppādaka puggala visesam
translated: “He burns” : the person who is better, etc., is not one who causes pride. The meaning is that, although he is in the state of being better, etc., he does not cause pride in another by not mentioning the distinction of the person who is better, etc.

original: anāmasitvā “pare atimaññati”cceva vuttanti attho. Pare atikkamitvā maññanañhi yassa kassaci atimānoti.
analyzed: an āmasitvā pare vuttanti attho pare atikkamitvā yassa kassaci
translated: “He looks down upon others” : the meaning is that he looks down upon others by surpassing them.

original: 880. Purimamānassa uparimāno mānātimāno, ati-saddo upari-saddassa atthaṃ vadatīti daṭṭhabbo. Purimamānaṃ vā atikkanto māno mānātimāno.
analyzed: purima mānassa upari mānaḥ māna atimānaḥ atisaddaḥ upari saddassa attham vadati iti daṭṭhabbo purima mānam vā atikkantaḥ mānaḥ māna atimānaḥ
translated: “Pride-in-surpassing” : the pride of surpassing the pride of the first kind is “pride-in-surpassing” . The word “ati” should be regarded as having the meaning of the word “upari” . Or alternatively, the pride that has gone beyond the first kind of pride is “pride-in-surpassing” .

original: 881. Pakkhijātīsu vāyaso anto lāmakoti katvā “kākajāti viyā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: pakkhi jātīsu vāyasaḥ antar lāmakaḥ ti katvā kāka jāti viya iti vuttam
translated: “Among birds the crow is reckoned as the worst” : the crow is reckoned as the worst among birds because it is contemptible.

original: 882. Thero kira dosacarito ahosi, tasmā āditova “tumhe akhīṇāsavā”ti avatvā upāyena kathesīti vadanti, dosacaritattā vā khippaṃ tatiyapadavāre virāgaṃ uppādesīti adhippāyo.
analyzed: thero kira dosa caritaḥ ahosi tasmai āditas va tumhe akhīṇa āsavā ti avatvā upāyena kathesi iti vadanti dosa carita ttā vā khippam tatiya padavāre virāgam uppādesi iti adhippāyaḥ
translated: “The elder was of a quarrelsome disposition” : the elder was of a bad disposition, they say. Therefore, from the very beginning, instead of saying “You have not destroyed the cankers,” he spoke by way of a simile. Or alternatively, the intention is that because he was of a bad disposition, he quickly aroused dispassion in the third line of the verse.

original: 883. Mānaṃ anugatacchandoti mānasampayuttachando, mānasabhāvaṃ anugato mānacchando vā.
analyzed: mānam anugata chandaḥ iti māna sampayutta chandaḥ mānasa bhāvam anugataḥ māna chandaḥ vā
translated: “Desire that follows pride” : desire associated with pride, or desire that follows the state of being proud.

original: 884. “Vilambana”nti ca itthipurisasammānanādikiriyādivilambanapaṭisaṃyuttaṃ kattabbaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tattha yuttamuttasiliṭṭhaṃ paṭibhānaṃ vilambanapaṭibhānaṃ.
analyzed: vilambanam ti ca itthi purisa sammānana ādi kiriyā ādi vilambana paṭisaṃyuttam kattabbam daṭṭhabbam tattha yuttam utta siliṭṭham paṭibhānam vilambana paṭibhānam
translated: “Delay” is connected with the kind of action that consists in the delay of such things as the paying of attention to women and men, etc., and that is to be seen as what should be done. Herein, the expression “delay” is a figure of speech consisting in the ascription of a cause to the effect.

original: 887. Amaravādapaṭisaṃyutto vitakko, attano amaraṇatthāya devabhāvatthāya vā vitakko amaravitakko.
analyzed: amara vāda paṭisaṃyuttaḥ vitakkaḥ attanaḥ amaraṇa tthāya deva bhāva tthāya vā vitakkaḥ amaravitakko
translated: “Immortality thinking” is thinking for the purpose of one’s own immortality or for the purpose of the state of a god.

original: 888. Paresu anuddayā rāgavasena anuddayakaraṇaṃ etassāti parānuddayo, tassa bhāvo
analyzed: paresu anuddayā rāga vasena anuddaya karaṇam etassa ati para anuddayaḥ tassa bhāvo
translated: “Absence of resentment” is the state of absence of resentment in others.

original: parānuddayatā, paresu vā anuddayasseva sahananditādikassa bhāvo parānuddayatā, tādiso
analyzed: para anuddaya tā paresu vā anuddayassa iva saha nandita ādikassa bhāvaḥ para anuddaya tā tādisaḥ
translated: Or the state of absence of resentment is the state of delighting with others in their absence of resentment, etc.

original: rāgo. Tatthāti parānuddayatāya saṃsaṭṭhavihārena dassitāyāti attho yujjati.
analyzed: rāgaḥ tattha ati para anuddaya tāya saṃsaṭṭha vihārena dassitāya ati atthaḥ yujjati
translated: Such is lust. Herein, the meaning of “here” is “in the absence of resentment,” which is shown by the expression “living in association.”

original: 890. Anavaññattiṃ patthento anavaññattatthameva kāmaguṇe ca patthetīti āha “pañcakāma…pe… nissito hutvā”ti.
analyzed: anavaññattim patthentaḥ anavaññatta ttham eva kāma guṇe ca pattheti iti āha pañca kāmape nissitaḥ hutvā iti
translated: “He is intent upon the five cords of sense desire” is said because he is intent upon the five cords of sense desire and upon the very non-disdain that is the purpose of non-disdain.

original: Ekakaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: ekaka niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the exposition of the single terms is ended.

original: (2.) Dukaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: duka niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the double terms

original: 891. Upanayhatīti bandhati. A-kāro anantaratthavācako, mariyādavācakassa vā ākārassa🔽rassattaṃ katvā “aṭṭhapanā”ti vuttanti “anantaraṭṭhapanā”tiādimāha. Tattha paṭhamuppannassa
analyzed: upanayhati iti bandhati akāraḥ anantarattha vācakaḥ mariyāda vācakassa vā ākārassa  katvā aṭṭhapanā iti vuttanti anantaraṭṭhapanā iti ādim āha tattha paṭhama uppannassa
translated: ‘He ties’ means he binds. The letter a is a term for the immediately following meaning. Or else, the letter a is a term for the letter ākāra, which is long. So ‘aṭṭhapanā’ is said. ‘The immediately following cessation’ is what is meant. Herein, the first-arisen

original: pavattākāro mariyādā, taṃ anatikkamitvā tasseva daḷhīkaraṇavasena ṭhapanā mariyādaṭṭhapanā.
analyzed: pavatta ākāraḥ mariyādā tam an atikkamitvā tassa iva daḷhīkaraṇa vasena ṭhapanā mariyādaṭṭhapanā
translated: “He ties” means he binds. The letter a is a term for the immediately following. Or else, having made the letter a, which is a term for a limit, long, he says “attapanā” . Herein, the mode of occurrence that arises first is the limit. The fixing by way of not exceeding that and by way of strengthening it is “limit-fixing.”

original: Pakatiṭṭhapanāmattameva, visesanarahitāti attho.🔽892. Niṭṭhuriyaṃ kheḷapātanaṃ, niṭṭhuriyaṃ viya niṭṭhuriyaṃ. Dassetvāti dantehi chinditvā.
analyzed: pakati ṭṭhapanā mattam eva visesana rahitā ti attho  niṭṭhuriyam kheḷa pātanam niṭṭhuriyam viya niṭṭhuriyam dassetvā iti dantehi chinditvā
translated: It is just the fixing of the normal state; the meaning is, it is without distinction.🔽“Spitting” is the letting fall of spittle. Like spitting, thus it is “as if spitting.” “Having shown” means having cut with the teeth.

original: Tena pana dassanaṃ paḷāsoti dasseti. Paḷāsassa āyanāti yugaggāhappavatti. Samabhāvadahanaṃ
analyzed: tena pana dassanam paḷāsaḥ oti dasseti paḷāsassa yuga ggāha ppavatti sama bhāva dahanam
translated: But he shows that the seeing is the contempt. The coming of the contempt is the occurrence of the yoke-bearing. The burning of the even state

original: jayo, tassa āharaṇato āhāro. Dhuraṃ na detīti pāmokkhaṃ na deti.
analyzed: jayaḥ tassa āharaṇataḥ āhāraḥ dhuram na deti iti pāmokkham na deti
translated: is victory. Because of bringing that about, it is “nourishment.” “He does not give the yoke” means he does not give the leadership.

original: 894. Kāyena cetiyaṅgaṇādivattaṃ karoti “evaṃ vattasampanno saddho kathaṃ kāyaduccaritādīni
analyzed: kāyena cetiya ṅgaṇa ādi vattam karoti evam vatta sampannaḥ saddho katham kāya duccarita ādīni
translated: “If with the body” means if he does the duties in the shrine enclosure, etc., thinking “Endowed with conduct in this way, the faithful one, how can he do bodily misconduct, etc.,

original: karissatī”ti paresaṃ ñāpanatthaṃ. Aticcāti accayaṃ katvā. Āsarantīti āgacchanti,
analyzed: karissati iti paresam ñāpana attham aticca ati accayam katvā āsaranti iti āgacchanti
translated: “He will do so” is for the purpose of informing others. “Having transgressed” means having committed a transgression. “They come” means they occur again in concealment.

original: puna paṭicchādane pavattantīti attho. Konāmevaṃ karotīti vocchindanacchādanā vā vocchādanā.
analyzed: puna paṭicchādane pavattanti iti vocchindana chādanā vā vocchādanā
translated: The meaning is: they occur again in concealment. “Who does this?” means one who conceals by cutting off and concealing.

original: Na sammā bhāsitāti yo na sammā bhāsati, so saṭhoti dasseti. Kucchi vā piṭṭhi vā jānituṃ🔽na sakkāti asantaguṇasambhāvaneneva cittānurūpakiriyāvirahato “evaṃcitto evaṃkiriyo”ti
analyzed: na sammā bhāsitā ati yaḥ na sammā bhāsati so saṭho ti dasseti kucchi vā piṭṭhi vā jānituṃ  na sakkā ati asanta guṇa sambhāvanena iva citta anurūpa kiriyā virahataḥ evam cittaḥ evaṃkiriyaḥ iti
translated: “He does not speak rightly” shows that one who does not speak rightly is a deceiver. “One cannot know whether it is his belly or his back”🔽means that because of the mere assumption of good qualities, one cannot know whether “he has such a mind and such an action”

original: jānituṃ na sakkāti attho.
analyzed: jānitum na sakkā iti atthaḥ
translated: because of the absence of action in accordance with the mind. This is the meaning.

original: Ajo eva ajāmigo. Nelakoti taruṇavaccho. Yathā so yakkho tādisaṃ rūpaṃ dassetvā “ajā”ti
analyzed: ajaḥ eva ajāmigaḥ na ilakoti taruṇa vacchaḥ yathā saḥ yakkhaḥ tādisam rūpam dassetvā ajāti
translated: A goat is a goat animal. A calf is a young bull. Just as that yakkha, having shown such a form, eats those who come thinking “it is a goat,”

original: saññāya āgatāgate khādati, evamayampi taṃtaṃsadisaguṇasambhāvanena te te vañceti.
analyzed: saññāyaḥ āgata āgate khādati evam ayam pi taṃ taṃsa disa guṇa sambhāvanena te te vañca iti
translated: in the same way, by the mere assumption of such and such good qualities, he deceives those and those.

original: Tenetaṃ sāṭheyyaṃ māyāto balavatarā vañcanāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Teneva “parikkhattatā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: tena itam sāṭheyyam māyātaḥ balavatarā vañcanā ti daṭṭhabbam tena iva parikkhatta tā ti vuttam
translated: Therefore, this deceit should be seen as more powerful than illusion. Therefore, it is said “to be circumscribed.”

original: 908. Sakkāyadiṭṭhādīnaṃ abhāvepi yaṃ saṃyojanaṃ hoti, taṃ bahiddhā saṃyojanato bahiddhāsaṃyojanassa puggalassa visesanabhūtaṃ bahiddhāsaṃyojanaṃ nāma.
analyzed: sakkāya diṭṭha ādīnam abhāve pi yam saṃyojanam hoti tam bahiddhā saṃyojanataḥ bahiddhā saṃyojanassa puggalassa visesana bhūtam bahiddhāsaṃyojanam nāma
translated: Although there is no personality view, etc., still there is a fetter, and that is called a fetter outside the round because it is a distinction of the kind of person fettered outside the round.

original: Dukaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: duka niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of the dyads is ended

original: (3.) Tikaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: tika niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: . Description of the triads

original: 909. Akusalamūlāneva vaṭṭamūlānīti tehi kathitehi vaṭṭamūlasamudācāro kathito hotīti āha “tīhi…pe… kathito”ti.🔽919. Sassato lokotiādidassanameva brahmacariyaṃ mokkhasampāpakaṃ uttamacariyanti🔽diṭṭhigatikehi sammatanti āha “diṭṭhigatikasammatassā”ti. Rūpārūpāvacaravipākesu🔽sātisayo bhavarāgoti adhippāyena vuttaṃ “mahābrahmāna”nti.
analyzed: akusala mūlāni eva vaṭṭa mūlāni iti tehi kathitehi vaṭṭa mūla samudācāraḥ kathitaḥ hoti iti āha tīhipe kathitaḥ iti  sassataḥ loka uti ādi dassanam eva brahmacariyam mokkha sampāpakam uttama cariyan ti  diṭṭhi gatikehi sammatanti āha diṭṭhi gatika sammatassa ati rūpa arūpa avacara vipākesu  sa atisayaḥ bhava rāgaḥ ti adhippāyena vuttam mahābrahmānanti
translated: . The root of the round is the three unprofitable roots. When these are stated, the manifestation of the round is stated too, thus he said “With the three unprofitable roots, etc.”

original: 920. Kathaṃvidhanti kenākārena saṇṭhitanti atthoti katvā āha “ākārasaṇṭhāna”nti. Mānaṭhapanāti seyyādivasena mānena ṭhapanā, mānasaṅkhātā vā ṭhapanā.
analyzed: kathaṃvidhanti kena ākārena saṇṭhitanti attho ti katvā āha ākāra saṇṭhānanti māna ṭhapanā ati seyyā ādi vasena mānena ṭhapanā māna saṅkhātā vā ṭhapanā
translated: . The life of one who holds the view that the world is eternal, etc., is the supreme life, and the life of one who holds the view that the world is not eternal, etc., is the supreme life, and the life of one who holds the view that the world is finite, etc., is the supreme life, and the life of one who holds the view that the world is infinite, etc., is the supreme life, and the life of one who holds the view that the soul and the body are the same, etc., is the supreme life, and the life of one who holds the view that the soul is one thing and the body another, etc., is the supreme life, and the life of one who holds the view that the Tathāgata exists after death, etc., is the supreme life, and the life of one who holds the view that the Tathāgata does not exist after death, etc., is the supreme life, and the life of one who holds the view that the Tathāgata both exists and does not exist after death, etc., is the supreme life, and the life of one who holds the view that the Tathāgata neither exists nor does not exist after death, etc., is the supreme life, and the life of one who holds the view that the world is not a tangle, etc., is the supreme life, and the life of one who holds the view that the world is a tangle, etc., is the supreme life, and the life of one who holds the view that the world is not a tangle, etc., is the supreme life, and the life of one who holds the view that the world is not a tangle, etc., is the supreme life, and the life of one who holds the view that the world is not a tangle, etc., is the supreme life, and the life of one who holds the view that the world is not a tangle, etc., is the supreme life, and the life of one who holds the view that the world is

original: 921. Cetaso utrāso domanassaṃ, doso vā, taṃsampayuttā vā cetanādayo.🔽922. Desanāsukhatāyāti tiṇṇaṃ addhānaṃ vasena vicikicchāya desanā sukhā “kaṅkhati
analyzed: cetasaḥ domanassam dosaḥ vā tad sampayuttāḥ vā cetanā ādayaḥ  desanā sukhatāya ati tiṇṇam addhānam vasena vicikicchāya desanā sukhā kaṅkhati
translated: Fear, sorrow, hate, and the volition associated with them, etc., are the mental states.

original: vicikicchatī”ti, na pana tathā mohenāti adhippāyo. Vaṇṇādibhedaṃ sutvāti keci kira🔽vadanti “khattiyajīvo paṇḍuvaṇṇo. Kasmā? So hi pubbaṇhe ramati, pubbaṇhe ca chāyā
analyzed: vicikicchati iti na pana tathā mohena ati adhippāyaḥ vaṇṇa ādi bhedam sutvā iti keci kira  vadanti khattiya jīvaḥ paṇḍu vaṇṇaḥ kasmā saḥ hi pubbaṇhe ramati pubbaṇhe ca chāyā
translated: The intention is this: “It is easy to teach perplexity by means of the three divisions of time, since it is said, ‘He is perplexed, he is doubtful about the past, the future, and the present’ . But it is not so easy to teach delusion, which is without divisions of time.”

original: paṇḍuvaṇṇā. Brāhmaṇavessasuddajīvā odātapītakāḷavaṇṇā. Te hi majjhanhasāyanharattīsu🔽odātapītakāḷachāyā kāḷatamakālesu ramantī”ti tesaṃ vaṇṇabhedaṃ, “byāpī parimaṇḍalo”tiādinā
analyzed: paṇḍu vaṇṇāḥ brāhmaṇa vessa suddajīvāḥ odāta pīta kāḷa vaṇṇā te hi majjhan ha sāyan harattīsu  ramanti iti tesam vaṇṇa bhedam byāpī parimaṇḍala uti ādinā
translated: Some say that they heard it said that the life of a noble is pale-coloured. Why? Because he delights in the morning, and the morning is pale-coloured with the light. The life of a brahmin, a merchant, and a worker is white, yellow, and black respectively. Because they delight in the middle of the day, in the evening, and at night, and because the shadows are white, yellow, and black in the middle of the day, in the evening, and at night, and because the darkness is black at the times of the new and full moon.

original: kathentānaṃ saṇṭhānabhedañca sutvā.
analyzed: kathentānam saṇṭhāna bhedam ca sutvā
translated: They heard it said that there is a difference of colour in them, and they heard it said that there is a difference of shape in them, since it is said, “He is compact and round” , etc.

original: 923. Purisapuggaloti padadvayaṃ ekapadaṃ katvā jānantānaṃ vasenāyaṃ sammutikathā
analyzed: purisa puggalaḥ ti pada dvayam eka padam katvā jānantānam vasena ayam sammuti kathā
translated: This conventional expression is used by those who know how to take the two words “man” and “person” as one word.

original: pavattā, padantarameva vā idaṃ puggalavācakanti dassento “ayaṃ panā”tiādimāha. Atha
analyzed: pavattā pada antaram eva vā idam puggala vācakanti dassentaḥ ayam pana ati ādim āha atha
translated: Or else, showing that this is a mere word for a person, he said, “This, however, is said” , etc.

original: vā purisoti vutto ca puggalo eva, na purisindriyayuttovāti dassanatthampi “purisapuggalo”ti
analyzed: vā purisaḥ ti vutto ca puggalaḥ eva na purisa indriya yuttaḥ vā ati dassana ttham pi purisa puggalaḥ ti
translated: and the person is called a man, not one who possesses the male faculty.

original: vuttanti veditabbaṃ. Aṭṭhasu ābādhesūti pittasemhavātasamuṭṭhānautuvipariṇāmajaopakkamikavisamaparihārajasannipātajakammasamuṭṭhānesu.
analyzed: vuttanti veditabbam aṭṭhasu ābādhesu ti pitta semha vāta samuṭṭhāna otu vipariṇāma ja opakkamika visama parihāra ja sannipāta ja kamma samuṭṭhānesu
translated: The eight kinds of sickness are those originating from bile, from phlegm, from wind, from the variation of the seasons, from conduct, from accumulated action, from a combination of these, and from supernormal power.

original: Pubbe katanti purāṇatarakammaṃ icchantīti upapajjavedanīyañca kira paṭikkhipanti.🔽Āṇattimūlakena vāti yopi āṇāpetvā vadhabandhādidukkhaṃ uppādeti, tampi taṃmūlakaṃ
analyzed: pubbe katanti purāṇatara kammam icchanti iti upapajja vedanīyam ca kira paṭikkhipanti  āṇatti mūlakena vāti yaḥ api āṇāpetvā vadha bandha ādi dukkham uppādeti tam pi taṃmūlakam
translated: They want to say that it is kamma done in the past: they deny that it is kamma to be experienced in the next rebirth.

original: na hoti, issaranimmānamūlamevāti adhippāyo.🔽924. Mohassa anudahanaṃ dāhakāraṇatāya vuttaṃ, sabhāvatopi pana asampaṭivedho sampaṭivedhasukhassa🔽paccanīkabhūto dukkho evāti anudahanatā veditabbā. Evañca katvā “upekkhā vedanā ñāṇasukhā
analyzed: na hoti issara nimmāna mūlam eva ati adhippāyaḥ  mohassa anudahanam dāha kāraṇa tāya vuttam sabhāvataḥ pi pana asampaṭivedhaḥ sampaṭivedha sukhassa  paccanīka bhūtaḥ dukkhaḥ evā ti anudahana tā veditabbā evam ca katvā upekkhā vedanā ñāṇa sukhā
translated: The meaning is that it is not rooted in the king’s command, but in the creation of a ruler.🔽Delusion is called “not burning” because it is the cause of burning. But it should be understood that it is not burning because it is the opposite of the bliss of penetration, and it is suffering.

original: aññāṇadukkhā”ti vuttā.
analyzed: aññāṇa dukkhā ti vuttā
translated: And in this way it is said: “Equanimity is bliss when known, Suffering when not known.”

original: 926. Puthunimittārammaṇesūti subhanimittādivasena puthunimittasabhāvesu ārammaṇesu,🔽puthusabhāvesu vā subhanimittādiārammaṇesu. Kosajjapamādaniddesānaṃ samānattepi avipphārikatāsaṅkhātā
analyzed: puthu nimitta ārammaṇesu iti subha nimitta ādi vasena puthu nimitta sabhāvesu ārammaṇesu  puthusa bhāvesu vā subha nimitta ādi ārammaṇesu kosajja pamāda niddesānam samāna tte pi a vipphārika tā a saṅkhātā
translated: In the various signs as object: in the various kinds of object consisting of the sign of the beautiful, and so on.🔽Or in the various kinds of object consisting of the sign of the beautiful, and so on, which have various individual essences.

original: līnavuttitā kosajjaṃ, sativossaggasaṅkhātaṃ pamajjanaṃ pamādoti ayaṃ visesoti.🔽931. Sagaruvāsanti saottappavāsamāha, sajeṭṭhakavāsanti sahirivāsaṃ. Anādiyanā anaddā
analyzed: līna vutti tā kosajjam sati vossagga saṅkhātam pamajjanam pamādaḥ ti ayam visesaḥ ti  sagaru vāsanti saottappa vāsam āha sajeṭṭhaka vāsanti sahiri vāsam anādiyanā anaddā
translated: Although the descriptions of idleness and negligence are the same, nevertheless idleness is the state of contraction called “non-expansion” and negligence is the state of forgetfulness called “forgetting the advice.”🔽“Dwelling in fear” is dwelling in fear of the dangers of the defilements and of the dangers of kamma.🔽“Dwelling in the elder’s place” is dwelling in the place of the elder.🔽“Not receiving” is not taking up the advice. The meaning is: not making it one’s mental object.

original: ovādaaggahaṇaṃ, acittīkāroti attho. Sukkhakaṭṭhassa viya anallatā, amudutā vā anaddā.
analyzed: ovāda aggahaṇam acittīkāro ti attho sukkha kaṭṭhassa viya analla tā amudu tā vā anaddā
translated: “Not being pliable” is the state of being unpliable like dry wood.

original: Asīlyanti asukhasīlatā amudutā eva.
analyzed: a sīlyanti a sukha sīlatāḥ a mudu tāḥ eva
translated: “Not being easy to correct” is the state of being unpliable.

original: 934. Upārambho dosasampayuttacittuppādo siyā.
analyzed: upārambhaḥ dosa sampayutta cittuppādaḥ siyā
translated: “Resentment” is the arising of consciousness associated with hate.🔽“He makes” is used in the sense of placing, as in “He makes a stone” .

original: 936. “Idha pāsāṇaṃ karotī”tiādinā ṭhapanatthepi karoti-saddo yujjatīti āha “karotīti
analyzed: idha pāsāṇam karoti iti ādinā ṭhapana atthe pi karoti saddaḥ yujjati iti āha karoti iti
translated: This is why it is said, “He makes = he places” .

original: ṭhapetī”ti. Ettha cāyaṃ āvajjanā akusalānaṃ āsannakāraṇattā khuddakavatthūsu vuttāti
analyzed: ṭhapeti iti ettha ca ayam āvajjanā akusalānam āsanna kāraṇa ttā khuddaka vatthūsu vuttā ati
translated: And here this adverting is mentioned in the case of the minor defilements because it is a proximate cause of the unprofitable.

original: veditabbā, tadanukūlakiccattā vā.
analyzed: veditabbā tad anukūla kiccattā vā
translated: or it should be understood as the state of being in conformity with that.

original: Tikaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: tika niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the exposition of the three kinds of craving is ended.

original: (4.) Catukkaniddesavaṇṇanā
translated: Exposition of the four kinds of craving

original: 939. Itīti nidassane nipātoti evaṃ-saddena samānatthoti dasseti. Bhavābhavahetūtipīti🔽ettha bhavanti jāyanti etenāti bhavo, sappiādibhesajjaṃ. Bhavo eva paṇītataro abhivuddho🔽abhavo. Bhāvanārāmatāariyavaṃsappaheyyattā vā purimataṇhāttayavajjā sabbā taṇhā “bhavābhavahetu
analyzed: iti iti nidassane nipāto ti evaṃsaddena samānatthaḥ ti dasseti bhava abhava hetu utipi iti  ettha bhavanti jāyanti etena ati bhavaḥ sappi ādi bhesajjam bhavaḥ eva paṇītataraḥ abhivuddhaḥ  abhavaḥ vā purima taṇhā attaya vajjā sabbā taṇhā bhava abhava hetu
translated: It thus: the particle thus shows that it has the same meaning as the word evaṃ . The cause of being and non-being: being is what is, what is born, like medicine of ghee, etc.;🔽the cause of being is the craving for being. Non-being is the cause of non-being. Or alternatively, the cause of being is the craving for the five kinds of sensual desires, and the cause of non-being is the craving for the kinds of becoming beginning with the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception.

original: uppajjatī”ti vuttāti veditabbā.
analyzed: uppajjati iti vuttā iti veditabbā
translated: Because of the delight in being, or because of the blameworthiness of the noble lineage, or because of the avoidance of the three kinds of craving mentioned above, all craving should be understood as said to arise “with the cause of being and non-being.”

original: Etāyāti chandādiagatiyā. Na gacchantīti na pavattanti, taṃ taṃ kiriyaṃ na karontīti attho. Imināti chandādinā agatigamanena. Chandādīsu yena ninno, tena gamanaṃ yathāninnagamanaṃ.
analyzed: etāya ati chanda ādi agatiyā na gacchanti iti na pavattanti tam tam kiriyam na karonti iti atthaḥ iminā ati chanda ādinā agati gamanena chanda ādīsu yena ninnaḥ tena gamanam yathā ninna gamanam
translated: Do not go: do not occur; the meaning is, they do not perform this or that function. By this: by the going by way of the destination of will, etc. Going according to the inclination is the going in the direction of the inclination.

original: “Rājā”tiādinā rājādinimitto viya ūmiādinimitto cittutrāso ūmiādibhayaṃ, “ūmibhayanti
analyzed: rāja ati ādinā rāja ādi nimittaḥ cittu trāsaḥ ūmi ādi bhayam
translated: The fear of waves, etc., is the mental fear of the sign of waves, etc., as if it were a king, etc. The fear of waves is the fear of waves, etc.

original: kho, bhikkhave, kodhupāyāsassetaṃ adhivacana”ntiādivacanato kodhupāyāsaodarikattapañcakāmaguṇamātugāmā
analyzed: kho bhikkhave kodhupāyāsassa etam adhivacanan ti ādi vacanataḥ kodhupāyāsa odarikatta pañca kāmaguṇa mātugāmā
translated: “Bhikkhus, this is a designation for anger and enmity” .

original: vā. Tattha pañcakāmaguṇamātugāmaggahaṇena tannissitachandarāgaggahaṇaṃ veditabbaṃ,
analyzed: vā tattha pañca kāmaguṇa mātu gāma ggahaṇena tad nissita chanda rāga ggahaṇam veditabbam
translated: The five strands of sensual desire and women are the source of anger and enmity. Herein, the five strands of sensual desire and women should be understood to include the will and lust for them.🔽And anger and enmity are greed.

original: odarikattañca lobhova. Ukkhepanīyādikammaṃ vinayadaṇḍaṃ.🔽“Atha kho timbaruko paribbājako yena bhagavā…pe… etadavoca ‘kiṃ nu kho, bho gotama,
analyzed: odarika ttam ca ukkhepanīya ādi kammam vinaya daṇḍam  atha kho timbarukaḥ paribbājakaḥ yena bhagavā āpe etat avoca kim nu kho bho gotama
translated: The disciplinary penalty is the legal question.

original: sayaṃkataṃ sukhadukkha’nti? Mā hevaṃ timbarukāti bhagavā avocā”tiādinā nidānavagge
analyzed: sayaṃkatam sukha dukkham ti mā ha ivam timbaruka ati bhagavā avoca ati ādinā nidāna vagge
translated: “Then the wanderer Timbaruka went to the Blessed One… and said: ‘Now then, Master Gotama, is pleasure and pain created by oneself? ‘ ‘Timbaruka, do not say so’ ,” etc.,

original: āgatattā “timbarukadiṭṭhī”ti vuttā.
analyzed: āgata ttā timbaruka diṭṭhī iti vuttā
translated: which is given in the Nidāna Vagga .

original: Catukkaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: catukka niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the tetrad is ended.

original: (5.) Pañcakaniddesavaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the pentad

original: 940. Āgantuṃ pana na dentīti āgamanassa paccayā na hontīti attho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: āgantum pana na denti iti āgamanassa paccayāḥ na honti iti atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: But they do not allow him to come in: the meaning is that the conditions for his coming in are not present.

original: 941. Avadehanatoti pūraṇena maṃsūpacayahetutāya ca upacayanato. Gimhakāle bhuñjitvā
analyzed: pūraṇena maṃsu upacaya hetutāya ca upacayanataḥ gimha kāle bhuñjitvā
translated: Because of the denial: because of the denial by Pūraṇa and because of the accumulation of flesh as a cause. Having eaten in the hot season

original: sayantassa sukhaṃ hotīti taṃ utusukhaṃ “seyyasukha”nti vuttaṃ, sayaniriyāpathasukhanti
analyzed: sayantassa sukham hoti iti tam utu sukham seyya sukhan ti vuttam saya niriyāpatha sukhan ti
translated: “Pleasure in lying down” is the pleasure of the weather, which is called “pleasure of lying down” because it is a condition for lying down. The meaning is pleasure of posture.

original: attho. Vatanti dhutaṅgāni. Tapoti khandhakavattāni, vīriyaṃ vā. Sīlaggahaṇena khandhakavattamethunaviratīnaṃ🔽gahitattā tapabrahmacariyaggahaṇaṃ na kattabbanti ce? Na, aññasīlato visesetvā tapabrahmacariyānaṃ
analyzed: attho vatanti dhutaṅgāni tapoti khandhaka vattāni vīriyam vā sīla ggahaṇena khandhaka vatta methuna viratīnam  gahita ttā tapa brahmacariya ggahaṇam na kattabbanti ce na añña sīlataḥ visesetvā tapa brahmacariyānam
translated: “Austerities” are the ascetic practices. “Vows” are the chapter on the rules of training, or energy.🔽If it be said that the austerities and the holy life should not be mentioned because the chapter on the rules of training and the avoidance of sexual intercourse are included by the mention of virtue,

original: devattakāraṇattaggahaṇassa dassanato, bāhirānañcassa vinibandhassa pavattidassanato
analyzed: devatta kāraṇatta ggahaṇassa dassanataḥ bāhira anañcassa vinibandhassa pavatti dassanataḥ
translated: then that is not so, because the austerities and the holy life are shown to be the cause of rebirth in the world of deities by mentioning them separately from virtue, etc.,

original: vā. Tesañhi avihiṃsādigovatādidukkarakārikāmethunaviratiyo yathākkamaṃ sīlādīni,🔽tāni ca te devanikāyaṃ paṇidhāya carantīti. Aññathā ca saddhāruciādīhi “yato kho
analyzed: vā tesam hi avihiṃsā ādi govata ādi dukkara kārikā methuna viratiyaḥ yathākkamam sīla ādīni  tāni ca te devanikāyam paṇidhāya caranti iti aññathā ca saddhā ruci ādīhi yatas kho
translated: or because the external bond is shown to be operative. For the avoidance of sexual intercourse and the performance of the difficult practices such as the vow of silence, etc., are respectively virtue, etc.,

original: bho ayaṃ attā rūpī cātumahābhūtiko mātāpettikasambhavo kāyassa bhedā ucchijjatī”tiādinā vikappetvā.
analyzed: bho ayam attā rūpī cātumahābhūtikaḥ mātā pettika sambhavo kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati iti ādinā vikappetvā
translated: and they practise them with the aspiration to a particular order of deities. Otherwise, by means of faith, desire, etc., they speculate thus: “When this self, good sirs, is material, consisting of the four great primaries, born of mother and father, with food as its origin, perishes with the breakup of the body, is destroyed and does not exist after death” , etc.

original: 942. Byasanesu ñātibhogarogabyasanaggahaṇena taṃnimittā sokādayo gahitāti daṭṭhabbā.🔽Dassanasavanesu paṭikūlatā dassanasavanapaṭikūlatā. Ettha ca ādīnavehi pañcahi tesaṃ🔽kāraṇabhūtā akkhantiyeva bhinditvā kathitāti veditabbā, akkhantimūlakā vā appiyatādihetubhūtā
analyzed: byasanesu ñāti bhoga roga byasana ggahaṇena tad nimittā soka ādayaḥ gahitā ati daṭṭhabbā  dassana savanesu paṭikūla tā dassana savana paṭikūla tā ettha ca ādīnavehi pañcahi tesam  kāraṇa bhūtā akkhantiyā iva bhinditvā kathitā ati veditabbā akkhanti mūlakā vā appiya tā ādi hetu bhūtā
translated: The grief, etc., that have them for their cause are included by the mention of “misfortunes” in the text, which refers to the misfortune of relatives, property, and sickness.

original: dukkaṭadubbhāsitatādidosā.🔽Micchājīvanimittaṃ maraṇakāle uppannabhayaṃ “ājīvakabhaya”nti vuttaṃ. “Ājīvikābhaya”nti
analyzed: dukkaṭa dubbhāsita tā ādi dosā  micchājīva nimittam maraṇa kāle uppanna bhayam ājīvaka bhayanti vuttam ājīvikā bhayanti
translated: The unattractiveness of what is seen and heard is the unattractiveness of what is seen and heard. And here the five beginning with grief should be understood as stated by analysis of the mere lack of confidence that is the cause of those five, or else as the faults of bad conduct, bad speech, etc., which are the causes of the unloved, etc.

original: pana pāṭhe paccayānuppattiṃ passato ājīvikanimitto cittutrāsoti attho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: pana pāṭhe paccaya anuppattim passato ājīvika nimittaḥ cittu trāsaḥ ti atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: The fear that arises at the time of death owing to wrong livelihood is called “fear of the next world.” But in the reading “fear of want,” the meaning should be regarded as the mental fear in one who sees no means of support owing to the lack of livelihood.

original: Kittisaddo silokanti tappaṭipakkhā asilokaṃ akitti. Tenāha “garahabhaya”nti.
analyzed: kitti saddaḥ si lokam ti tad paṭipakkhā a si lokam tena āha gara habhayan ti
translated: Bad report is the opposite of good report, that is, disrepute. Hence it is said, “fear of blame.”

original: 943. Uppilāvitanti udaggatāsaṅkhāto avūpasamabhāvo, avūpasamahetubhūto vā pītiyā ākāro.
analyzed: udagga tā saṅkhātaḥ avūpasama bhāvaḥ avūpasama hetu bhūtaḥ vā pītiyāḥ ākāraḥ
translated: Agitation is the state of non-tranquility called “arousing” , or else it is the mode of joy that is the cause of non-tranquility.

original: Pañcakaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
translated: The commentary on the description of the pentad is finished.

original: (6.) Chakkaniddesavaṇṇanā
translated: Description of the sextet

original: 944. “Kodhano hoti upanāhī”tiādinā kodhādihetukā upanāhādayo kodhādīnaṃ sahāyakāraṇabhāvena
analyzed: kodhanaḥ upanāhi iti ādinā kodha ādi hetukāḥ upanāha ādayaḥ sahāya kāraṇa bhāvena
translated: “He is angry and revengeful” : the revengefulness, etc., which have anger, etc., as their cause are stated in the suttas as the conditions for anger, etc., by way of companionship.

original: suttante vuttāti kodhādayo eva vivādamūlāni, tenettha te eva vuttā. Sandiṭṭhiparāmasitā
analyzed: suttante vuttā iti kodha ādayaḥ eva vivāda mūlāni tena ittha te eva vuttā sandiṭṭhi parāmasitā
translated: Therefore only anger, etc., are stated here as the roots of disputes.

original: attano diṭṭhiyaṃ abhiniviṭṭhatā.
analyzed: attanaḥ diṭṭhiyam abhiniviṭṭha tā
translated: Clinging to false view: being attached to one’s own view.🔽Lack of confidence: being without teachers who are sources of confidence.

original: 945. Appatissayoti patissayabhūtehi garūhi virahito. Appamādalakkhaṇanti satiavippavāsaṃ kusalānuyogasātaccaṃ vā.🔽Yuttapayuttatāti tanninnatāvasena suṭṭhu yuttatā. Gaṇasaṅgaṇikā kilesavasena pavattā
analyzed: appatissayaḥ ti patissaya bhūtehi garūhi virahitaḥ appamāda lakkhaṇam ti sati avippavāsam kusala anuyoga sātaccam vā  yutta payutta tā ati tad ninna tā vasena suṭṭhu yutta tā gaṇa saṅgaṇikā kilesa vasena pavattā
translated: The characteristic of heedfulness: the non-abandonment of mindfulness or the persistence in the practice of the wholesome.🔽Being occupied and engaged: being well occupied and engaged in the sense of being devoted to it.🔽The company of many is the company of many that occurs by way of defilement.

original: saṅgaṇikā. Itthipaṭisaṃyuttakathāsavane itthisaddasavane ca assādo savanasaṃsaggo.
analyzed: saṅgaṇikā itthi paṭisaṃyutta kathā savane itthi sadda savane ca assādaḥ savana saṃsaggo
translated: The listening to and hearing of talk connected with women is the association of listening.

original: Itthiyā kassaci dānaggahaṇassādo paribhogasaṃsaggo.
analyzed: itthiyā kassaci paribhoga saṃsaggo
translated: The association of enjoyment is the enjoyment of giving something to some woman or of enjoying her.

original: 946. Somanassena saddhiṃ upavicarantīti somanassupavicārāti akusalasomanassasahagatā
analyzed: somanassena saddhim upavicaranti iti somanassa upavicārā ati akusala somanassa sahagatā
translated: The mental concomitants that occur together with joy are called “the concomitants of joy.”

original: rūpavicārādayo idhādhippetāti veditabbā, tathā upekkhupavicārā ca. Taṃsampayutto🔽vāti etena vicāraggahaṇena vitakkopi gahitoti vitakkappavattanena “upavitakketī”ti
analyzed: rūpa vicāra ādayaḥ idha adhippetā ti veditabbā tathā upekkhu pavicārā ca tad sampayutto  vā ti etena vicāra ggahaṇena vitakkaḥ api gahitaḥ ti vitakka ppavattanena upavitakketi iti
translated: and the kinds of thinking about visible forms, etc., should be understood as intended here, and also the kinds of thinking about equanimity.🔽“Or associated with it” : by the mention of thinking, applied-thinking is also included.

original: idampi vuttaṃ hotīti dasseti.
analyzed: idam api vuttam hoti iti dasseti
translated: So it is shown that by the occurrence of applied-thinking, “he thinks” is also said.

original: 947. Aññāṇasampayuttāti vicikicchuddhaccasahagatacittesu upekkhā mohoti vadanti, lobhasampayuttupekkhāpi pana gehassitā na na hoti.
analyzed: aññāṇa sampayuttā ati vicikicchu ddhacca sahagata cittesu upekkhā moho ti vadanti lobha sampayutta upekkhā api pana geha ssitā na na hoti
translated: “Associated with unknowing” : they say that in the kinds of consciousness associated with doubt and agitation there is delusion, which is equanimity. But that does not preclude the equanimity associated with greed.

original: 948. Adhiccasamuppanniko “adhicca samuppanno attā uppanno bhavissatī”ti gaṇhanto
analyzed: adhiccasamuppannikaḥ adhicca samuppannaḥ attā uppanno bhavissati iti gaṇhantaḥ
translated: “The theorist of fortuitous origination” : one who holds the view that the self is fortuitously originated, arisen by chance, without cause or condition,

original: sassatadiṭṭhiko hotīti evarūpassa diṭṭhi viyāti dassento “adhiccasamuppannikassevā”ti
analyzed: sassata diṭṭhikaḥ hoti iti evarūpassa diṭṭhi viya ati dassento adhiccasamuppannikassa iva āti
translated: is a theorist of eternalism. Showing that such a view is of the nature of eternalism, he said, “The theorist of fortuitous origination.”

original: āha. Na so jātoti ettha “jātū”ti ayaṃ nipāto u-kārassa o-kāraṃ katvā jātoti vutto,
analyzed: āha na saḥ jātaḥ iti ettha jātu uti ayam nipātaḥ ukārassa okāram katvā jātaḥ iti vutto
translated: “He has not been born” : here the indeclinable jatu is stated as jāto by changing the u to o.

original: tena vā samānatthaṃ nipātantaraṃ etaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Sabbāsavadiṭṭhīti sabbāsavapariyāyena āgatā diṭṭhi.
analyzed: tena vā samāna attham nipāta antaram etam daṭṭhabbam sabba āsava diṭṭhi iti sabba āsava pariyāyena āgatā diṭṭhi
translated: Or it should be regarded as a synonym of the same meaning as the indeclinable. “Any view whatever” : a view stated in any way by the theorists of fortuitous origination, etc.

original: Chakkaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: chakka niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the exposition of the six is finished.

original: (7.) Sattakaniddesavaṇṇanā
translated: Exposition of the seven

original: 951. Dvāsaṭṭhiyā diṭṭhīsu sattakassa aññassa abhāvā satta ucchedavādā eva idha tathā avatvā “satta diṭṭhī”ti vuttā.
analyzed: dvāsaṭṭhiyā diṭṭhīsu sattakassa aññassa abhāvā satta uccheda vādā eva idha tathā avatvā satta diṭṭhī iti vuttā
translated: Since there is no other seven in the sixty-two views, only the seven annihilationist views are referred to here as “seven views” without specifying them.

original: Sattakaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: sattaka niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the exposition of the seven is finished.

original: (8.) Aṭṭhakaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: aṭṭhaka niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: Exposition of the eight

original: 952. “Kammaṃ kho me kattabbaṃ bhavissatī”tiādinā osīdanākārena pavattacittuppādā
analyzed: kammam kho me kattabbam bhavissati itiādinā osīdana ākārena pavatta cittuppādā
translated: The thoughts that occur in the mode of sinking with the words “I shall have to work” and so on are

original: kosajjakāraṇāni, kosajjameva vā kosajjantarakāraṇatāya kosajjakāraṇānīti daṭṭhabbāni.
analyzed: kosajja kāraṇāni kosajjam eva vā kosajja antara kāraṇatāya kosajja kāraṇāni iti daṭṭhabbāni
translated: the reasons for laziness. Or else laziness itself should be regarded as the reasons for laziness because it is the cause of the reasons for laziness.

original: Māsācitaṃ maññeti ettha ācita-saddo tinta-saddassa, maññe-saddo ca viya-saddassa
analyzed: māsa ācitam maññā iti ettha ācita saddo tinta saddassa maññesaddo ca viya saddassa
translated: In the passage “he thinks it is smeared with month-old urine” the word ācita has the meaning of the word tinta, and the word maññati has the meaning of the word viya.

original: atthaṃ vadatīti adhippāyena “tintamāso viyā”ti ayamattho vibhāvito, māsacayo viyāti vā attho.
analyzed: attham vadati iti adhippāyena tinta māsaḥ viyā ti ayam atthaḥ vibhāvitaḥ māsa cayaḥ viyā ti vā atthaḥ
translated: The meaning is worked out thus: “it is as if it were smeared with month-old urine,” or the meaning is: “it is as if it were a month-old accumulation.”

original: 957. Pharatīti phusati, ghaṭṭetīti attho. Aññena kāraṇenāti “ajja tayā vikāle bhuttaṃ,
analyzed: pharati iti phusati ghaṭṭeti iti atthaḥ aññena kāraṇena ati ajja tayā vikāle bhuttam
translated: It touches, is the meaning of it breaks up. It comes into contact with, is the meaning of it breaks up. With another reason: “Today you ate at the wrong time,

original: tena tvaṃ āpattiṃ āpannosī”ti vutto “hiyyo mayā kāle bhuttaṃ, tenāhaṃ anāpanno”tiādinā🔽aññena ayuttena kāraṇena aññaṃ yuttaṃ kāraṇaṃ paṭicchādetīti attho. Pucchitatthato
analyzed: tena tvam āpattim āpannaḥ asi iti vuttaḥ hiyyas mayā kāle bhuttam tena aham anāpannaḥ iti ādinā  aññena ayuttena kāraṇena aññam yuttam kāraṇam paṭicchādeti iti atthaḥ pucchita tthato
translated: “You have fallen into an offence,” he replies, “Yesterday I ate at the right time, therefore I have not fallen into an offence,” and so on.🔽The meaning is that he conceals one reason with another reason which is not appropriate.🔽The meaning of the question is that he should not be led away by talk in such a way that he does not come to the point.🔽The meaning of the question is that he should not be led away by talk in such a way that he does not come to the point.

original: bahiddhā yathā taṃ na allīyati, tathā kathāya apanayanaṃ vikkhipanaṃ bahiddhā apanāmanā.🔽958. Asaññīvādāti puggalehi diṭṭhiyo dasseti. Yehi vā abhinivesehi asaññī attānaṃ vadanti, te asaññīvādā. Arūpasamāpattinimittanti ākāsādiṃ.
analyzed: bahiddhā yathā tam na allīyati tathā kathāya apanayanam vikkhipanam bahiddhā apanāmanā  asaññīvādā ti puggalehi diṭṭhiyaḥ dasseti yehi vā abhinivesehi asaññī attānam vadanti te asaññīvādāḥ arūpa samāpatti nimittam ti ākāsa ādim
translated: The meaning of the question is that he should not be led away by talk in such a way that he does not come to the point.🔽The meaning of the question is that he should not be led away by talk in such a way that he does not come to the point.🔽The meaning of the question is that he should not be led away by talk in such a way that he does not come to the point.🔽The meaning of the question is that he should not be led away by talk in such a way that he does not come to the point.🔽The meaning of the question is that he should not be led away by talk in such a way that he does not come to the point.🔽The meaning of the question is that he should not be led away by talk in such a way that he does not come to the point.🔽The meaning of the question is that he should not be led away by talk in such a way that he does not come to the point.

original: Aṭṭhakaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽(9.) Navakaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: aṭṭhaka niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The meaning of the question is that he should not be led away by talk in such a way that he does not come to the point.🔽The meaning of the question is that he should not be led away by talk in such a way that he does not come to the point.

original: 960. Dasamassa avuttattā “sattesu uppattivaseneva kathitānī”ti vuttaṃ.
translated: The meaning of the question is that he should not be led away by talk in such a way that he does not come to the point.🔽The meaning of the question is that he should not be led away by talk in such a way that he does not come to the point.🔽The meaning of the question is that he should not be led away by talk in such a way that he does not come to the point.🔽The meaning of the question is that he should not be led away by talk in such a way that he does not come to the point.

original: 963. Sukhavinicchayanti sevitabbāsevitabbasukhasanniṭṭhānanti attho. Ajjhattaṃ sukhanti sevitabbaṃ nekkhammasukhaṃ. Vinicchayāti dve vinicchayāti idaṃ –
analyzed: sukha vinicchayanti sevitabba asevitabba sukha sanniṭṭhānanti atthaḥ ajjhattam sukhanti sevitabbam nekkhamma sukham vinicchayā ati dve vinicchayā ati idam
translated: The meaning of the question is that he should not be led away by talk in such a way that he does not come to

original: “Sātaṃ asātanti yamāhu loke,
analyzed: sātam yam āhuḥ loke
translated: “In the world they call pleasure pain,

original: Tamūpanissāya pahoti chando;
analyzed: tam ūpanissāya pahoti chandaḥ
translated: And from that pleasure comes desire.

original: Rūpesu disvā vibhavaṃ bhavañca,
analyzed: rūpesu disvā vibhavam bhavañca
translated: Seeing in forms both ending and no-ending,

original: Vinicchayaṃ kubbati jantu loke”ti. –🔽Etassa niddese vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vinicchayam kubbati  etassa niddese vuttam
translated: A man in the world makes his choice. ”🔽This is said in the description of desire.

original: Idha vinicchayoti vuttoti imissā vibhaṅgapāḷiyā yo chandarāgassa paccayasabhāvena🔽vinicchaya-saddena vutto, sakkapañhepi chandassa nidānabhāvena vitakka-saddena so
analyzed: idha vinicchayaḥ ti vutto ti imissā vibhaṅga pāḷiyā yaḥ chanda rāgassa paccaya sabhāvena  vinicchaya saddena vuttaḥ sakka pañhe pi chandassa nidāna bhāvena vitakka saddena so
translated: Here the word “choice” is used in the sense of a condition for desire.🔽In the Sakkapañha Sutta the same thing is called “thought” in the sense of a source of desire.

original: eva āgatoti evaṃ vitakkassa vinicchayabhāvaṃ tasseva idha gahitatañca dasseti. Balavasanniṭṭhānanti
analyzed: eva āgataḥ ti evam vitakkassa vinicchaya bhāvam tassa iva idha gahita tat ca dasseti balava sanniṭṭhānam ti
translated: So this shows that thought is choice and that it is included here.

original: balavatiyā taṇhāya ārammaṇassa niṭṭhapetvā gahaṇaṃ.🔽964. Satipi aññesañca saṅkhatabhāve ahanti asmīti ca sātisayā mānassa saṅkhatatāti
analyzed: balavatiyā taṇhāya ārammaṇassa niṭṭhapetvā gahaṇaṃ  sati pi aññesam ca saṅkhata bhāve ahanti asmi iti ca sa atisayā mānassa saṅkhata tā ati
translated: “Determination by strength” is the grasping of an object by strong craving.🔽Although other things are also formed, still the conceit “I am” is more formed than they are,🔽because it is more outstanding. So “formed” is said of the conceit “I am.”

original: katvā “saṅkhata”nti māno vutto. Seyyādivasena “ahamasmī”ti attano saṅkharaṇaṃ vā
analyzed: katvā saṅkhatanti māno vutto seyyā ādi vasena aham asmi iti attano saṅkharaṇam vā
translated: Or the conceit “I am” is said to be formed because it is the formation of oneself as “I am” in such and such a way.

original: saṅkhataṃ. Ettha “bhavissantī”tiādikā pavatti taṇhādiṭṭhīnaṃ visesavatīti tāsampi
analyzed: ettha bhavissanti iti ādikā pavatti taṇhā diṭṭhīnam visesavatī iti tāsam pi
translated: “Will be” and so on is the occurrence of craving and views with a distinction.

original: iñjitādibhāvo vutto.
analyzed: iñjita ādi bhāvaḥ vutto
translated: So their trembling and so on is stated.

original: Navakaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: navaka niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the exposition of the nine kinds of unprofitable consciousness is ended.

original: (10.) Dasakaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dasaka niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: Exposition of the ten kinds of consciousness🔽The “wrong reflection” is the wrong reflection that conceals the wrongness of the reflection.🔽The “wrong reflection” is the wrong reflection that conceals the wrongness of the reflection.🔽The “wrong reflection” is the wrong reflection that conceals the wrongness of the reflection.🔽The “wrong reflection” is the wrong reflection that conceals the wrongness of the reflection.

original: 970. Jālakkhipasaṃvidhānādikusalatāsaṅkappanaṃ upāyacintā, tassā micchābhāvapaṭicchādanabhāvena
analyzed: jāla kkhipa saṃvidhāna ādi kusala tā saṅkappanam upāya cintā tassāḥ micchā bhāva paṭicchādana bhāvena
translated: The “wrong reflection” is the wrong reflection that conceals the wrongness of the reflection.🔽The “wrong reflection” is the wrong reflection that conceals the wrongness of the reflection.🔽The “wrong reflection” is the wrong reflection that conceals the wrongness of the reflection.🔽The “wrong reflection” is the wrong reflection that conceals the wrongness of the reflection.🔽The “wrong reflection” is the wrong reflection that conceals the wrongness of the reflection.🔽The “wrong reflection” is the wrong reflection that conceals the wrongness of the reflection.🔽The “wrong reflection” is the wrong reflection that conceals the wrongness of the reflection.🔽The “wrong reflection” is the wrong reflection that conceals the wrongness of the reflection.🔽The “wrong reflection” is the wrong reflection that conceals the wrongness of the reflection.

original: pavatto tadākāro moho upāyacintāvasena uppannoti daṭṭhabbo. Yathākate pana pāpe anādīnavadassanavasena
analyzed: pavattaḥ tad ākāraḥ mohaḥ upāya cintā vasena uppanno ti daṭṭhabbo yathā kate pana pāpe anādīnava dassana vasena
translated: The “wrong reflection” is the wrong reflection that conceals the wrongness of the reflection.🔽The “wrong reflection” is the wrong reflection that conceals the wrongness of the reflection.🔽The “wrong reflection” is the wrong reflection that conceals the wrongness of the reflection.

original: pavattā saññā, saṅkappo vā paccavekkhaṇā, tassāpi micchābhāvapaṭicchādakaṃ tadākāraṃ,
analyzed: pavattā saññā saṅkappaḥ vā paccavekkhaṇā tassa api micchā bhāva paṭicchādakam tad ākāram
translated: The “wrong reflection” is the wrong reflection that conceals the wrongness of the reflection.🔽The “wrong reflection” is the wrong reflection that conceals the wrongness of the reflection.🔽The “wrong reflection” is the wrong reflection that conceals the wrongness of the reflection.🔽The “wrong reflection” is the wrong reflection that conceals the wrongness of the reflection.

original: anādīnavadassanaṃ vā paccavekkhaṇākārena uppanno mohoti. Vimuttasaññitāti adhimānasampayuttaṃ,
analyzed: anādīnava dassanam vā paccavekkhaṇa ākārena uppannaḥ mohaḥ ti vimutta saññi tā ati adhimāna sampayuttam
translated: The “wrong reflection” is the wrong reflection that conceals the wrongness of the reflection.🔽The “wrong reflection” is the wrong reflection that conceals the wrongness of the reflection.

original: titthiyānaṃ vā attano diṭṭhiyā vimuttatāsañjānanaṃ. “Vimuttomhī”ti evaṃ pavatto akusalacittuppādo
analyzed: titthiyānam vā attanaḥ diṭṭhiyāḥ vimutta tā sañjānanam vimuttaḥ aham iti evam pavattaḥ akusala cittuppādo
translated: The “wrong reflection” is the wrong reflection that conceals the wrongness of the reflection.

original: micchāvimuttīti keci vadanti. Phalaṃ viya vimuttanti gahite pana diṭṭhisampayuttacitte
analyzed: micchā vimutti iti keci vadanti phalam viya vimuttanti gahite pana diṭṭhi sampayutta citte
translated: Some say that wrong view is wrong knowledge and wrong concentration is wrong deliverance. But when it is taken that deliverance is like a fruit, then wrong knowledge is wrong view in the consciousness associated with wrong view,

original: diṭṭhi micchāñāṇaṃ, samādhi ca micchāvimuttīti yuttaṃ siyā.
analyzed: diṭṭhi micchāñāṇam samādhi ca micchā vimutti iti yuttam siyā
translated: and wrong deliverance is wrong concentration.

original: Dasakaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dasaka niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the section of ten is finished.

original: Taṇhāvicaritaniddesavaṇṇanā🔽973. Samūhagāhatoti taṇhāmānadiṭṭhīnaṃ sādhāraṇaggahaṇatoti vadanti. “Itthaṃ evaṃ
analyzed: taṇhāvicarita niddesa vaṇṇanā  samūha gāhato ti taṇhā māna diṭṭhīnam sādhāraṇa ggahaṇato ti vadanti ittham evam
translated: The exposition of the description of the kinds of craving🔽is finished.🔽They say that the “generalized apprehension” is the common apprehension of craving, conceit, and views. But the “generalized apprehension” should be regarded as the apprehension without making any distinction such as “in this way, in this manner,

original: aññathā”ti pana visesaṃ akatvā gahaṇaṃ samūhagāhoti daṭṭhabbo. Aññaṃ ākāranti parasantānagataṃ🔽ākāraṃ. Atthīti sadā saṃvijjatīti attho. Sīdatīti vinassati. Saṃsayaparivitakkavasenāti
analyzed: aññathā ti pana visesam a katvā gahaṇam samūha gāho ti daṭṭhabbo aññam ākāram ti para santāna gatam  ākāram atthi iti sadā saṃvijjati iti attho sīdati iti vinassati saṃsaya parivitakka vasena ati
translated: in another way.” The “mode of another” is a mode belonging to another continuity.

original: “kiṃ nu kho ahaṃ siyaṃ, na siya”nti evaṃ parivitakkavasena. Patthanākappanavasenāti
analyzed: kim nu kho aham siyam na siyanti evam parivitakka vasena patthanā kappana vasena ati
translated: “There is” means “it exists always.” The meaning is: it exists. “It perishes” means it is destroyed. “By means of doubt and reflection” means by means of the reflection “What shall I be? Shall I be?”

original: “api nāma sādhu panāhaṃ siya”nti evaṃ patthanāya kappanavasena.
analyzed: api nāma sādhu pana aham evam patthanāya kappana vasena
translated: “By means of aspiration and resolve” means by means of the aspiration “Perhaps I shall be good.”
