original: Suddhasīsāti taṇhāmānadiṭṭhīnaṃ sādhāraṇasīsā visesassa anissitattā “suddhasīsā”ti
analyzed: suddha sīsā ati taṇhā māna diṭṭhīnam sādhāraṇa sīsā visesassa anissita ttā suddha sīsā ati
translated: “The single head” is the common head of craving, conceit, and views. Because it is not the support of any distinction, it is called “the single head.”

original: vuttā. Tattha diṭṭhisīsehi diṭṭhiyā taṇhā dassitā, sīsasīsamūlakehi mānadiṭṭhīhi
analyzed: vuttā tattha diṭṭhi sīsehi diṭṭhiyā taṇhā dassitā sīsa sīsa mūlakehi māna diṭṭhīhi
translated: Herein, craving is shown by the views and conceit, and the views and conceit by the views and conceit.🔽And by himself: thus he said “These should be understood as the states that are the province of craving. ”

original: sayameva cāti āha “evamete…pe… taṇhā vicaritadhammā veditabbā”ti. Diṭṭhimānesupi
analyzed: sayam eva ca iti āha taṇhā vicarita dhammā veditabbā ti diṭṭhi mānesu pi
translated: And in the case of the views and conceit too,

original: “taṇhāvicaritānī”ti vacanañca aññamaññaṃ vippayogīnaṃ diṭṭhimānānaṃ taṇhāya avippayogīnaṃ
analyzed: taṇhā vicaritāni iti vacanañca aññamaññam vippayogīnam diṭṭhi mānānam taṇhāya a vippayogīnam
translated: the words “the province of craving” should be understood to mean that the views and conceit are not dissociated from craving,

original: taṃmūlakattāva tappadhānatāya katanti veditabbaṃ.🔽974. Avakkarīti nipāto nānābhāve vattatīti anānākaraṇaṃ anavakkari, taṃ katvā, avakkari
analyzed: tad mūlaka ttā ava tad padhāna tāya katan ti veditabbam  avakkari iti nipātaḥ nānā bhāve vattati iti anānākaraṇam anavakkari tam katvā avakkari
translated: since they have craving as their root and craving as their source.🔽The word “without” is a particle that occurs in the sense of “without distinction” .🔽So without making any distinction, without omitting any, he said “without confounding them. ”

original: vā akatvā anavakkari katvāti evaṃ dassento āha “avinibbhogaṃ katvā”ti. “Anavakāriṃ🔽karitvā”ti vā pāṭho, tattha avakiraṇaṃ vikkhepanaṃ samūhassa ekadesānaṃ vinibbhujjanaṃ
analyzed: vā a katvā anavakkari katvā iti evam dassentaḥ āha a vinibbhogam katvā iti anavakārim  karitvā iti vā pāṭhaḥ tattha avakiraṇam vikkhepanam samūhassa eka desānam vinibbhujjanam
translated: Or the reading may be “avinibbhujitvā, ” in which case the word should be analysed thus: avinibbhujitvā = avinibbhujja vinibbhujitvā.🔽The breaking up of a mass into parts is “confounding” .

original: avakāri, taṃ avakāriṃ vinibbhogaṃ akatvā, pañcapi khandhe samūhato ekatteneva gahetvā
analyzed: avakāri tam avakārim vinibbhogam a katvā pañca api khandhe samūhato ekattena iva gahetvā
translated: Without confounding them, without breaking them up, he should take the five aggregates as a single mass and grasp them with the single term “perishing” .

original: attato avinibbhujjitvā asmīti chandamānadiṭṭhiyo paṭilabhatīti attho. Asitabyābhaṅgitāyāti
analyzed: attataḥ a vinibbhujjitvā asmi iti chanda māna diṭṭhiyaḥ paṭilabhati iti atthaḥ asita byābhaṅgi tāya ati
translated: the meaning is that he acquires the craving and views of “I am” without separating off the self. As to the state of being unshared:

original: dāttena kājena cāti etena parikkhārena, asitabyābhaṅgīhi lavanavahanakiriyā vā “asitabyābhaṅgī”ti vuttā.
analyzed: dāttena kājena ca ati etena parikkhārena asita byābhaṅgīhi lavana vahana kiriyā vā asita byābhaṅgī iti vuttā
translated: by means of the requisites of alms food, etc., or by means of the action of eating, chewing, and so on, he is called “one who has an unshared state.”

original: 976. Avakāriṃ karitvāti rūpādīni attato vinibbhujjitvā iminā rūpena…pe… iminā viññāṇena
analyzed: avakārim karitvā ati rūpa ādīni attataḥ vinibbhujjitvā iminā iminā viññāṇena
translated: Having made a distinction: having separated off material form, etc., from the self, he acquires the craving “I am this” in the way beginning, “By means of this material form … by means of this consciousness I am permanent” .

original: asmīti chandaṃ paṭilabhatīti evaṃ sabbattha imināti etassa attato avinibbhuttena
analyzed: asmi iti chandam paṭilabhati iti evam sabbattha iminā ati etassa attataḥ a vinibbhuttena
translated: In the same way in all the other cases. The meaning of “by means of this” should be regarded as “without separating off from the self.”

original: rūpādināti attho daṭṭhabbo. Attato hi avinibbhuttāni abahikatāni ahamicceva gahitāni🔽rūpādīni upādāya upagantvā pavattā taṇhā “ajjhattikassa upādāyā”ti vuttā, attato
analyzed: rūpa ādinā iti atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo attataḥ hi a vinibbhuttāni a bahikatāni aham icca iva gahitāni  rūpa ādīni upādāya upagantvā pavattā taṇhā ajjhattikassa upādāya ati vuttā attataḥ
translated: For material form, etc., which are not separated off, not excluded, are included in the “I am” conceit🔽and are called “internal” because they occur having approached and appropriated material form, etc., as their object.

original: ca vinibbhuttāni bahikatāni upagantvā pavattā “bāhirassa upādāyā”ti. Khaggena vā
analyzed: ca vinibbhuttāni bahikatāni upagantvā pavattā bāhirassa upādāya ati khaggena vā
translated: But those which are separated off, excluded, and do not occur having approached and appropriated as their object are called “external.”

original: chattena vā ahaṃ niccoti abhimaṅgalasammatena khaggādinā mama vināso natthīti maññatīti
analyzed: chattena vā aham nicco ti abhimaṅgala sammatena khagga ādinā mama vināso natthi iti maññati iti
translated: He thinks, “I am permanent by means of a sword, an umbrella, etc., which are considered to be lucky charms,” and he thinks, “There is no destruction of me.”

original: attho. Ekekassāti idaṃ anādimhi anante ca saṃsāre ekekassa atītānāgatesu chattiṃsāyapi🔽sambhavadassanatthaṃ vuttaṃ, ekekassa vā puggalassa yathālābhavasenāti idampi anissitataṇhāmānadiṭṭhiṃ
analyzed: atthaḥ ekekassa ati idam anādimhi anante ca saṃsāre ekekassa atīta anāgatesu  sambhava dassana tham vuttam ekekassa vā puggalassa yathā lābha vasena ati idam pi anissita taṇhā māna diṭṭhim
translated: “Each” is said for the purpose of showing that in beginningless and endless saṃsāra each one has had thirty-six kinds of these in the past and will have them in the future.

original: katvā puthujjanassa addhāpaccuppanne kassaci sambhavadassanatthaṃ.🔽Taṇhāvicaritaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: katvā puthujjanassa addhā paccuppanne kassaci sambhava dassana attham  taṇhāvicarita niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: Or alternatively, “each” is said for the purpose of showing that each person has had some of these in the past and will have some in the future, according to circumstances, without attachment to craving, conceit, and views.🔽The exposition of the kinds of craving is ended.

original: Khuddakavatthuvibhaṅgavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: khuddaka vatthu vibhaṅga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the analysis of the Minor Fences is ended.

original: 18. Dhammahadayavibhaṅgo
analyzed: dhamma hadaya vibhaṅgo
translated: The Analysis of the Heart of the Dhamma

original: 1. Sabbasaṅgāhikavāravaṇṇanā🔽978. “Pañcakkhandhā”tiādinā khandhādīnaṃ dhātusambhavapariyāpannapātubhāva bhūmantaratīsu
analyzed: sabba saṅgāhika vāra vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the second section

original: dhātūsuuppādakadānādikusala kammatabbipākaabhiññeyyādiārammaṇadukadvayadiṭṭhādikusalattikāditikapañcakarūpalokiyadukadvayabhedabhinnānaṃ
analyzed: dhātusu uppādaka dāna ādi kusala kamma tad vipāka abhiññeyya ādi ārammaṇa duka dvaya diṭṭha ādi kusala ttika āditika pañcaka rūpa lokiya duka dvaya bheda bhinnānam
translated: “The five aggregates,” etc.: the aggregates, etc., are stated here in their entirety because they include all dhammas without exception that arise in the five bases of the elements, namely, the elements that originate from kamma, from nutriment, from temperature, from consciousness, and that are spontaneously born.

original: niravasesato saṅgahitattā dutiyavārādīnañca ettha anuppavesato sabbasāmaññena vutto
analyzed: niravasesataḥ saṅgahita ttā dutiya vāra ādīnam ca ettha anuppavesataḥ sabba sāmaññena vuttaḥ
translated: They are also stated in their entirety because the second section, etc., are included in them.

original: paṭhamo sabbasaṅgāhikavāro nāma, dutiyo uppattānuppattidassanavāro nāmāti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: paṭhamaḥ sabbasaṅgāhika vāraḥ nāma dutiyaḥ uppatta anuppatti dassana vāraḥ nāma ati vuttam
translated: The first is called the “section on the inclusion of all” and the second the “section on the demonstration of what has arisen and what has not arisen.”

original: Tattha pana “kāmadhātuyā kati khandhā kati āyatanānī”tiādinā tesaṃ atthitā eva vuttā,
analyzed: tattha pana kāmadhātuyā kati khandhāḥ kati āyatanāni iti ādinā tesam atthi tā eva vuttā
translated: Herein, the question “In the sense-desire element how many aggregates, how many bases?” and so on merely asks how many of the aggregates, etc., exist there.

original: kiriyāvisesassa appayogo “atthi bhavati saṃvijjatī”ti sāmaññakiriyāya viññeyyabhāvato,🔽tenāyaṃ “sambhavāsambhavadassanavāro”ti vattuṃ yutto, catuttho ca upapattikkhaṇe
analyzed: kiriyā visesassa appayogaḥ atthi bhavati saṃvijjati iti sāmañña kiriyāya viññeyya bhāvato  tena ayam sambhava asambhava dassana vāro ti vattum yuttaḥ catutthaḥ ca upapatti kkhaṇe
translated: The question “Are there any states that are conditionally arisen and also conditionally ceased?” is asked in order to find out whether the states there are conditionally arisen and also conditionally ceased, since the questioner does not know that they are.

original: uppattānuppattidassanavāroti tattha pātubhāvāpātubhāvavacanato.
analyzed: tattha pātubhāva a pātubhāva vacanato
translated: Therefore this section is properly called the “section on the demonstration of what is possible and what is impossible.” And the third section is called the “section on the demonstration of what has arisen and what has not arisen” at the moment of rebirth-linking,🔽because it is stated in terms of what has become manifest and what has not become manifest.

original: 979. Yathāpucchanti pucchānurūpaṃ avitathabyākaraṇaṃ parehi katampi sabbaññuvacanaṃ viññāya katattā sabbaññubyākaraṇameva nāma hoti, ko pana vādo sabbaññunā eva kateti adhippāyo.
analyzed: yathā pucchanti puccha anurūpam avitatha byākaraṇam parehi katam api sabbaññu vacanam viññāya kata ttā sabbaññu byākaraṇam eva nāma hoti kaḥ pana vādaḥ sabbaññunā eva katā iti adhippāyaḥ
translated: The answer is called “the answer of one who knows all” because it is given in accordance with the question and because it is given by one who knows all, whether it is given by another or by the all-knowing one himself.

original: 2. Uppattānuppattivāravaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the section on the demonstration of what has arisen and what has not arisen

original: 991. Kāmadhātusambhūtānañcāti iddhiyā rūpadhātugatānaṃ kāmāvacarasattānañcāti attho.
analyzed: kāmadhātu sambhūtānam ca ati iddhiyā rūpadhātu gatānam kāmāvacara sattānam ca ati attho
translated: “Arisen in the sense-desire element”: the meaning is: “of those who have attained jhāna in the fine-material sphere and of beings in the sense-desire existence.”

original: Ghānāyatanādīnaṃ abhāvenāti ettha yadi tadabhāvena gandhāyatanādīni āyatanādikiccaṃ🔽na karonti, asaññasattesu cakkhāyatanassa abhāvena rūpāyatanaṃ āyatanādikiccaṃ na
analyzed: abhāvena ati ettha yadi tad abhāvena gandha āyatana ādīni āyatana ādi kiccam  na karonti asañña sattesu cakkhāyatanassa abhāvena rūpāyatanam āyatana ādi kiccam na
translated: “Because of the absence of the nose-door, etc.”: if, because of the absence of the nose-door, etc., the nose-sense-sphere, etc., do not perform the function of a sense-sphere, etc., then, because of the absence of the eye-sense-sphere in the case of the non-percipient beings, the visible-form sense-sphere does not perform the function of a sense-sphere, etc.

original: kareyya. Tato “asaññasattānaṃ devānaṃ upapattikkhaṇe dvāyatanāni pātubhavantī”tiādivacanaṃ🔽na vattabbaṃ siyā. Kāmāvacarādiokāsā tattha uppajjamānasattānaṃ, tattha pariyāpannadhammānaṃ🔽vā adhiṭṭhānabhāvena “dhātū”ti vuccanti, tathā yesu kāmāvacarādisattanikāyesu kāmāvacarādisattā
analyzed: kareyya tatas asañña sattānam devānam upapatti kkhaṇe dvāyatanāni pātubhavanti iti ādi vacanam  na vattabbam siyā kāmāvacara ādi okāsā tattha uppajjamāna sattānam tattha pariyāpanna dhammānam  vā adhiṭṭhāna bhāvena dhātū ti vuccanti tathā yesu kāmāvacara ādi satta nikāyesu kāmāvacara ādi sattā
translated: “Because of the absence of the nose-base, etc.”: if, because of the absence of the nose-base, etc., the nose-base, etc., do not perform the function of a base, etc., then, because of the absence of the eye-base in the case of the non-percipient beings, the eye-base would not perform the function of a base, etc. Therefore the statement “At the moment of rebirth-linking of the non-percipient beings two bases become manifest” would not be tenable.

original: uppajjanti, tesaṃ sattānaṃ uppatti etthāti sattuppattīti vuccamānā te sattanikāyā
analyzed: uppajjanti tesam sattānam uppatti ettha ati sattuppatti iti vuccamānā te satta nikāyā
translated: The sense-desire-element, etc., are called “elements” in the sense of being the foundation for the beings who are reborn there or for the dhammas included there. Likewise, the sense-desire-being-class, etc., are called “classes” in the sense of being the place of rebirth for the beings of the sense-desire-being-class, etc.

original: ca, na panettha apariyāpannokāso apariyāpannasattanikāyo ca atthi, yo “dhātū”ti vucceyyāti
analyzed: ca na pana ittha a pariyāpanna ukāsaḥ a pariyāpanna satta nikāyo ca atthi yaḥ dhātu uti vucceyya ati
translated: But there is no element or class that is not included here that could be called “element” or “class.”

original: imamatthaṃ dassento “okāsavasena vā sattuppattivasena vā apariyāpannadhātu nāma natthī”ti🔽āha. Sattuppattivasenāti iminā vā okāsasattalokadvayaṃ saha gahetvā tādisāya apariyāpannadhātuyā
analyzed: imam attham dassento okāsa vasena vā sattu patti vasena vā apariyāpanna dhātu nāma natthi iti  āha sattu ppatti vasena ati iminā vā okāsa satta loka dvayam saha gahetvā tādisāya apariyāpanna dhātuyā
translated: He said this in order to show that there is no element that is not included either by way of location or by way of the arising of beings.🔽By the words “by way of the arising of beings” he shows the non-existence of such an element that is not included either by way of location or by way of the world of beings.

original: abhāvaṃ dasseti, sattabhāvena vā uppatti sattuppatti, sattāvāsavasena taṃtaṃbhavavasena
analyzed: abhāvam dasseti satta bhāvena vā uppatti satta uppatti sattā āvāsa vasena taṃ taṃbhava vasena
translated: Or, the arising of beings is the arising of beings by way of the abodes of beings, by way of the various kinds of becoming.

original: uppajjamānā upādinnakakkhandhā taṃtaṃpariyāpannānaṃ sadisādhiṭṭhānabhāvena dhātūti
analyzed: uppajjamānāḥ upādinnaka khandhāḥ taṃ taṃ pariyāpannānam sadisa adhiṭṭhāna bhāvena dhātu uti
translated: The aggregates that are clung to, which arise by way of the abodes of beings, by way of the various kinds of becoming, are called elements in the sense that they are the bases for the assumption of the state of being a being.

original: vuccantīti evaṃ apariyāpannadhātu natthīti attho.
analyzed: vuccanti iti evam apariyāpanna dhātu na atthi iti attho
translated: Thus the meaning is that there is no element that is not included.

original: 3. Pariyāpannāpariyāpannavāravaṇṇanā
analyzed: pariyāpanna apariyāpanna vāra vaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the included and the not included

original: 999. Bhavavasena okāsavasena ca paricchinnāti tattha aññattha ca uppajjamānā upādinnakakkhandhā taṃtaṃpariyāpannā sabbe daṭṭhabbā.🔽6. Uppādakakammaāyuppamāṇavāro🔽(1.) Uppādakakammavaṇṇanā
analyzed: bhava vasena okāsa vasena ca paricchinnā ati tattha aññattha ca uppajjamānā upādinna kakkhandhā taṃ taṃ pariyāpannā sabbe daṭṭhabbā 🔽uppādaka kamma āyu ppamāṇa vāro 🔽uppādaka kamma vaṇṇanā
translated: All the aggregates that are clung to, which arise in this or that place, should be regarded as included in the various kinds of becoming and the various stations.

original: 1021. Khandhādīnaṃ dhātusambhavādivasena pabhedaṃ vatvā ye sattā dhātuppabhedavanto,🔽yañca tesaṃ uppādakakammaṃ, yo ca tassa vipāko, tesaṃ vasena pabhedaṃ dassetuṃ “tayo
analyzed: khandha ādīnam dhātu sambhava ādi vasena pabhedam vatvā ye sattāḥ dhātu pabhedavantaḥ  yat ca tesam uppādaka kammam yaḥ ca tassa vipāko tesam vasena pabhedam dassetum tayaḥ
translated: Having thus stated the classification of the aggregates, etc., by way of the origination, etc., of the elements, the following six sections beginning with “The gods of the three realms” are undertaken in order to show the classification of beings by way of the division of the elements,

original: devā”tiādiko chaṭṭhavāro āraddho. Khandhādayo eva hi dhātuttayabhūtadevavasena dānādikammavasena
analyzed: chaṭṭha vāro āraddho khandha ādayaḥ eva hi dhātu ttaya bhūta deva vasena dāna ādi kamma vasena
translated: the kamma that generates their rebirth, and the result of that kamma. For the aggregates, etc., are classified by way of the three realms, the four primary elements, and the gods, by way of the kamma such as generosity, etc.,

original: taṃtaṃāyuppamāṇaparicchinnaupādinnakakkhandhavasena ca bhinnāti. Catudoṇaṃ ambaṇaṃ, chadoṇanti eke.
analyzed: ca bhinnā ati catu doṇam ambaṇam cha doṇa nti eke
translated: and by way of the aggregates that are clung to and limited by the measure of the respective life span. Some say that the four are the four primary elements, and the six are the six sense bases.

original: Uppādakakammavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: uppādaka kamma vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the kamma that generates is finished.

original: (2.) Āyuppamāṇavaṇṇanā
analyzed: āyu pamāṇa vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the measure of the life span

original: 1024. Tayopi janāti tayo janasamūhāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: adhippāyo
translated: The intention is that the three is the three groups of beings.

original: 1025. Ābhāti sobhanā pabhā.🔽1026. Kañcanapiṇḍo viya sassirikā kañcanapiṇḍasassirikā. Tattha pana sobhanapabhāya
analyzed: ābhāti sobhanā pabhā  kañcana piṇḍaḥ viya sassirikā kañcana piṇḍa sassirikā tattha pana sobhana pabhāya
translated: The gods of the realm of radiance have a beautiful radiance.

original: kiṇṇā subhākiṇṇāti vattabbe ā-kārassa rassattaṃ antimaṇa-kārassa ha-kārañca katvā
analyzed: kiṇṇā subhākiṇṇā ti vattabbe ākārassa rassa ttam antima ṇakārassa hakārañca katvā
translated: They are radiant like a golden bimba fruit. Here, however, the -a- of ābhā is elided and the -n- of antima is changed to -h- in order to say subhākiṇṇa , which means “covered with beautiful radiance.”

original: “subhakiṇhā”ti vuttā, atha pana subhena kiṇṇā subhakiṇṇā. Purimapadesupi parittaṃ🔽subhaṃ etesanti parittasubhā, appamāṇaṃ subhaṃ etesanti appamāṇasubhāti subha-saddena
analyzed: subha kiṇhā ti vuttā atha pana subhena kiṇṇā subha kiṇṇā purima padesu pi parittam  subham etesanti paritta subhāḥ appamāṇam subham etesanti appamāṇa subhā iti subha saddena
translated: “It is ‘possessed of beauty’ (subhakiṇṇa) because it is ‘pervaded by beauty’ (subhena kiṇṇa). But it is ‘possessed of good beauty’ (subhakiṇṇa) because it is ‘pervaded by good beauty’ (subhena kiṇṇa). In the first two terms the word ‘good’ (subha) is to be construed as a prefix.

original: samāso yojetabbo hoti.🔽1027. Ārammaṇamanasikārā pubbabhāgena kathitāti jhānakkhaṇe tato pacchā vā parittādikasiṇārammaṇabhāvanāya🔽āvajjanena ca jhānassa ārammaṇamanasikāranānattatā na hoti, pubbabhāgabhāvanāya pana
analyzed: samāsaḥ yojetabbaḥ hoti  ārammaṇa manasikārā pubba bhāgena kathitā ti jhāna kkhaṇe tatas pacchā vā paritta ādi kasiṇa ārammaṇa bhāvanāya  āvajjanena ca jhānassa ārammaṇa manasikāra nānatta tā na hoti pubbabhāga bhāvanāya pana
translated: The ‘limited’ (paritta) is so called because it is limited in extent. The ‘measureless’ (appamāṇa) is so called because it is measureless. The ‘beautiful’ (subha) is so called because it is lovely. The ‘base consisting of boundless space’ (ākāsānañcāyatana) is so called because it is the base consisting of boundless space. The ‘base consisting of boundless consciousness’ (viññāṇañcāyatana) is so called because it is the base consisting of boundless consciousness. The ‘base consisting of nothingness’ (ākiñcaññāyatana) is so called because it is the base consisting of nothingness. The ‘base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception’ (nevasaññānāsaññāyatana) is so called because it is the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception.

original: pubbabhāgāvajjanena ca hotīti attho. Pubbabhāgabhāvanāya vasena hi jhānaṃ parittapathavīkasiṇādīsu
analyzed: pubbabhāga āvajjanena ca hoti iti attho pubbabhāga bhāvanāya vasena hi jhānam paritta pathavī kasiṇa ādīsu
translated: The ‘sign of the limited earth kasiṇa’ is so called because it is the sign of the limited earth kasiṇa. The ‘sign of the measureless earth kasiṇa’ is so called because it is the sign of the measureless earth kasiṇa. The ‘sign of the beautiful earth kasiṇa’ is so called because it is the sign of the beautiful earth kasiṇa. The ‘sign of the base consisting of boundless space’ is so called because it is the sign of the base consisting of boundless space. The ‘sign of the base consisting of boundless consciousness’ is so called because it is the sign of the base consisting of boundless consciousness. The ‘sign of the base consisting of nothingness’ is so called because it is the sign of the base consisting of nothingness. The ‘sign of the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception’ is so called because it is the sign of the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception.

original: taṃtadārammaṇaṃ hoti, pubbabhāgena taṃtaṃkasiṇāvajjanena taṃtaṃmanasikāranti. Chandādayo🔽pana appanākkhaṇepi vijjanti. Tattha paṇidhīti na taṇhāpatthanā, atha kho chandapatthanāva
analyzed: tad tad ārammaṇam hoti pubbabhāgena taṃ taṃ kasiṇa āvajjanena taṃ taṃ manasikāranti chanda ādayaḥ 🔽pana appanā khaṇe pi vijjanti tattha paṇidhī iti na taṇhā patthanā atha kho chanda patthanā ava
translated: The ‘sign of the limited earth kasiṇa’ is so called because it is the sign of the limited earth kasiṇa. The ‘sign of the measureless earth kasiṇa’ is so called because it

original: daṭṭhabbā. Adhimokkho nicchayo. Abhinīhāro cittappavattiyeva. Yadi pana bhavachandabhavapatthanādayo🔽taṃtaṃbhavavisesaniyāmakā adhippetā. “Appanāyapi vaṭṭantī”ti etassa appanāya pavattāya🔽tato pacchāpi vaṭṭantīti attho daṭṭhabbo. Saññāvirāgādīhi pana visesiyamānaṃ ārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: daṭṭhabbā adhimokkhaḥ nicchayaḥ abhinīhāraḥ citta ppavattiyā iva yadi pana bhava chanda bhava patthanā ādayo  taṃ taṃ bhava visesa niyāmakāḥ adhippetāḥ appanāya api vaṭṭanti iti etassa appanāya pavattāya  tato pacchā api vaṭṭanti iti attho daṭṭhabbo saññā virāga ādīhi pana visesiyamānam ārammaṇam
translated: and resolution is the ascertainment. Determination is the occurrence of consciousness. But if the desire for becoming, the aspiration for becoming, and so on, are intended as the determining of the particular kind of becoming, then it should be understood that they occur in the absorption too,

original: tathā tathā tattha pavatto manasikāro ca bhavavisesaniyāmako pubbabhāgova vaṭṭatīti
analyzed: tathā tathā tattha pavattaḥ manasikāraḥ ca bhava visesa niyāmako pubba bhāgaḥ eva vaṭṭati iti
translated: and that they occur after the absorption as well. But the determining of the particular kind of becoming is only the prior phase, which is the object and the attention that occur in such and such a way when distinguished by non-greed, etc., and by the fading away of lust, etc.

original: “ārammaṇamanasikārā pubbabhāgena kathitā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ārammaṇa manasikārā pubba bhāgena kathitā ti vuttam
translated: So it was said above, “The object and attention are stated by the prior phase” .

original: Vipulā phalāti vipulasantasukhāyuvaṇṇādiphalā. Suṭṭhu passanti paññācakkhunā maṃsadibbacakkhūhi ca.
analyzed: vipulā phalā ati vipula santa sukha āyu vaṇṇa ādi phalā suṭṭhu passanti paññā cakkhunā maṃsa dibba cakkhūhi ca
translated: It has abundant fruit: it has abundant fruit of distinction, namely, life, beauty, happiness, and so on. They see it well: they see it with the eye of understanding and with the fleshly eye and the divine eye.

original: 1028. “Yāva na taṃ pāpakammaṃ byantī hotī”ti vacanato “kammameva pamāṇa”nti āha, abbudādiāyuppamāṇaparicchedo pana kammavaseneva katoti adhippāyo.
analyzed: yāva na tam pāpa kammam hoti iti vacanato kammam eva pamāṇanti āha abbuda ādi āyu pamāṇa paricchedaḥ pana kamma vasena iva kato ti adhippāyaḥ
translated: “The extent of the action” : the meaning intended is that the delimitation of the life span by the extent of the abscess, etc., is made according to the action.

original: Nilīyanokāsassa abhāvāti samānajātikena accharāgaṇena sabbadā parivāriyamānassa kāmaguṇākiṇṇassa tabbirahitaṭṭhānassa abhāvāti attho.
analyzed: nilīyana ukāsassa abhāvā ati samāna jātikena accharā gaṇena sabbadā parivāriyamānassa kāma guṇa ākiṇṇassa tad virahita ṭṭhānassa abhāvā ati attho
translated: ‘Because there is no place for lying down’: the meaning is that there is no place devoid of that, since it is always surrounded by a multitude of celestial nymphs of the same kind and is filled with the pleasures of sense desire.🔽‘What determines’: the meaning is, what kind of jhāna determines what kind of rebirth?

original: Kiṃ niyametīti kiṃ jhānaṃ upapattiṃ niyametīti attho. Nava brahmaloketi brahmapārisajjādayo
analyzed: kim niyameti iti kim jhānam upapattim niyameti iti atthaḥ nava brahma loka iti brahma pārisajja ādayaḥ
translated: ‘In the nine Brahma-worlds’: in the Brahmapārisajja, etc.,

original: navapi sodhetvā. Matthaketi vehapphalesūti attho. Seṭṭhabhavā nāmāti tato paraṃ agamanato
analyzed: nava api sodhetvā matthaka iti vehapphalesu ti attho seṭṭhabhavā nāma ati tato param agamanato
translated: after having purified the nine. ‘In the peak’: the meaning is, in the Vehapphala.🔽‘The highest state’: the intention is that it is the highest state because there is no going beyond it. That is why it is called ‘the summit of existence.’

original: uttamabhavāti adhippāyo. Teneva bhavasīsānīti gahitā. Imesu tīsu ṭhānesūti vehapphalādiṭṭhānāni
analyzed: uttama bhavā ti adhippāyo tena iva bhava sīsāni iti gahitā imesu tīsu ṭhānesu uti vehapphala ādi ṭṭhānāni
translated: ‘In these three places’: this is said referring only to the Vehapphala, etc.

original: eva sandhāya vuttaṃ. Vehapphalato pana purimesu navasu nibbattaanāgāmī arūpadhātuṃ🔽upapajjatīti katvā “rūpadhātuyā cutassa arūpadhātuṃ upapajjantassa kassaci satta
analyzed: eva sandhāya vuttam vehapphalataḥ pana purimesu navasu nibbatta anāgāmī arūpa dhātum  upapajjati iti katvā rūpadhātuyā cutassa a rūpadhātum upapajjantassa kassaci
translated: But since a non-returner reborn in the first nine of these is reborn in the immaterial world,🔽it is said: “When someone who has died in the fine-material world and been reborn in the immaterial world has seven underlying tendencies, some have five, some have three” ,

original: anusayā anusenti, kassaci pañca, kassaci tayo anusentī”ti idaṃ vuttaṃ, na vehapphalādīsu
analyzed: anusayāḥ anusenti kassaci pañca kassaci tayo anusenti iti idam vuttam na vehapphala ādīsu
translated: referring to the Vehapphala, etc.

original: upapannaṃ sandhāyāti ayamettha adhippāyo siyā. Yaṃ pana vuttaṃ “navasu brahmalokesu
analyzed: upapannam sandhāya iti ayam ettha adhippāyaḥ siyā yam pana vuttam navasu brahmalokesu
translated: This is the intention here.

original: nibbattaariyasāvakānaṃ tatrūpapattiyeva hoti, na heṭṭhūpapattī”ti, etena heṭṭhūpapatti
analyzed: nibbatta ariya sāvakānam tatru upapattiyā iva hoti na heṭṭhu upapatti iti etena heṭṭhu upapatti
translated: But it was said above that “noble disciples reborn in the nine brahma-worlds are reborn there only, not below.” That only rules out rebirth below,

original: eva nivāritā, na tesveva uparūpari vehapphale ca upapatti arūpadhātūpapatti ca. “Paṭhamajjhānabhūmiyaṃ
analyzed: eva nivāritā na tesu eva ca upapatti arūpa dhātu upapatti ca
translated: not rebirth in the higher brahma-worlds and in the immaterial world.

original: nibbatto anāgāmī nava brahmaloke sodhetvā matthake ṭhito parinibbātī”ti idampi anupubbena
analyzed: nibbattaḥ anāgāmī nava brahmaloke sodhetvā matthake ṭhitaḥ parinibbāti iti idam pi anupubbena
translated: “A non-returner who has reached the plane of the first jhāna purifies the nine brahma-worlds and attains Nibbāna with the head, ”🔽and this is said with reference to one who ascends gradually.

original: ārohantaṃ sandhāya vuttanti na tena tassa matthakaṃ appattassa arūpadhātuṃ upapatti🔽nivāritāti daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: ārohantam sandhāya vuttan ti na tena tassa matthakam appattassa arūpa dhātum upapatti  nivāritā iti daṭṭhabbā
translated: So it should not be taken to mean that rebirth in the immaterial world is ruled out for one who has not reached the summit of the brahma-world.

original: Yo vā aññattha tattha vā maggaṃ bhāvetvā cavitvā tattha upapanno avikkhambhitarūparāgo
analyzed: yaḥ vā aññattha tattha vā maggam bhāvetvā cavitvā tattha upapannaḥ a vikkhambhita rūpa rāgaḥ
translated: Or this commentary was written with reference to a noble disciple who has not yet developed the path there or elsewhere but who has died and been reborn there, and whose sensual desire is not suppressed.

original: ariyasāvako, taṃ sandhāya ayaṃ aṭṭhakathā vuttā. Teneva “navasu brahmalokesu nibbattaariyasāvakāna”nti,
analyzed: tam sandhāya ayam aṭṭhakathā vuttā tena iva navasu brahmalokesu nibbatta ariyasāvakānam ti
translated: “Noble disciples reborn in the nine brahma-worlds” is said

original: “paṭhamajjhānabhūmiyaṃ nibbatto anāgāmī”ti, “imesu tīsu ṭhānesu nibbattaanāgāmino”ti🔽ca sabbattha nibbattaggahaṇaṃ kataṃ. Tassa pana yena tattha upapanno, tasmiṃ rūparāge
analyzed: paṭhama jhāna bhūmiyam nibbattaḥ anāgāmī ti imesu tīsu ṭhānesu nibbatta anāgāmino ti  ca sabbattha nibbatta gahaṇam katam tassa pana yena tattha upapannaḥ tasmin rūpa rāge
translated: “A non-returner who has reappeared in the plane of the first jhāna” and “non-returners who have reappeared in these three places” ,🔽the inclusion of all reappearance is made. But when he has been reborn there, his attachment to becoming will be cut off, since his passion for materiality will be suppressed,

original: vikkhambhite puna bhavābhilāso na bhavissatīti arūparāgupacchedo ca bhavissatiyeva.🔽Yo pana puthujjano tattha nibbatto ariyamaggaṃ bhāvetvā arūpehi vikkhambhitarūparāgo
analyzed: vikkhambhite puna bhava abhilāsaḥ na bhavissati iti arūpa rāga upacchedaḥ ca  yaḥ pana puthujjanaḥ tattha nibbattaḥ ariya maggam bhāvetvā arūpehi vikkhambhita rūpa rāgaḥ
translated: and he will not have any further desire for becoming.🔽But when an ordinary man is reborn there, he develops the noble path and, when the passion for materiality that has been suppressed by the immaterial states is revived,

original: uppanne magge nibbattabhavādīnavadassanavasena anivattitabhavābhilāso, tassa vasena
analyzed: uppanne magge nibbatta bhava ādīnava dassana vasena anivattita bhava abhilāso tassa vasena
translated: he sees the danger in the becoming that will be produced by the path, and he does not desire any further becoming.

original: yamakapāḷi pavattāti vā ayamattho adhippeto siyā.
analyzed: yamaka pāḷi pavattā ati vā ayam atthaḥ adhippeto siyā
translated: This is the meaning that may be intended in the explanation of the dyad.

original: Āyuppamāṇavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: āyu ppamāṇa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of the measure of life is ended.

original: 7. Abhiññeyyādivāravaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the dyads beginning with what is to be directly known

original: 1030. “Ruppanalakkhaṇaṃ rūpaṃ, phusanalakkhaṇo phasso”tiādinā sāmaññavisesalakkhaṇapariggāhikā
analyzed: ruppana lakkhaṇam rūpam phusana lakkhaṇaḥ phassaḥ ti ādinā sāmañña visesa lakkhaṇa pariggāhikā
translated: “Materiality has the characteristic of being molested. Contact has the characteristic of touching” ,

original: salakkhaṇapariggāhikā diṭṭhikaṅkhāvitaraṇavisuddhiyo ñātapariññā, tato paraṃ yāva
analyzed: salakkhaṇa pariggāhikāḥ diṭṭhi kaṅkhā vitaraṇa visuddhiyaḥ ñāta pariññā tato param yāva
translated: The purification by overcoming doubt, which is the understanding of the specific characteristics, is full-understanding as knowledge. Beyond that, as far as🔽

original: anulomā tīraṇapariññā, udayabbayānupassanato paṭṭhāya yāva maggā pahānapariññā.🔽Tattha tatthāti khandhādīnaṃ tāva khandhavibhaṅgādīsu pañhapucchakavāre vattabbaṃ
analyzed: anulomā tīraṇa pariññā udaya bbaya anupassanataḥ paṭṭhāya yāva maggā pahāna pariññā  tattha tattha ati khandha ādīnam tāva khandha vibhaṅga ādīsu pañha pucchaka vāre vattabbam
translated: The purification by overcoming doubt, which is the discerning of the specific characteristics, is full-understanding as knowledge. After that, up to the conformity knowledge, is full-understanding as investigation. From the contemplation of rise and fall onwards, up to the path, is full-understanding as abandoning.🔽Herein, as regards the aggregates, etc., what should be said has been said in the Description of the Aggregates, etc., in the “Questions” section.

original: vuttaṃ, hetuādīnañca khandhādīsu antogadhattā tattha tattha pañhapucchakavāre vattabbaṃ
analyzed: vuttam hetu ādīnam ca khandha ādīsu tattha tattha pañha pucchaka vāre vattabbam
translated: And as regards the causes, etc., since they are included among the aggregates, etc., what should be said has been said in the “Questions” section there too.

original: vuttamevāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: vuttam eva iti daṭṭhabbam
translated: That is how it should be understood.

original: Abhiññeyyādivāravaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: abhiññeyya ādi vāra vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of the section on what is to be directly known, etc., is ended.

original: Dhammahadayavibhaṅgavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dhamma hadaya vibhaṅga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The exposition of the Dhammasangani is ended.

original: Iti sammohavinodaniyā līnatthapadavaṇṇanā
analyzed: iti sammohavinodaniyā līna attha pada vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the words in the “Nibbana chapter” that have a hidden meaning

original: Vibhaṅga-mūlaṭīkā samattā.
analyzed: vibhaṅga mūla ṭīkā samattā
translated: The Root-Commentary on the Abhidhamma Vibhanga is finished.

original: Namo tassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa
analyzed: namaḥ tassa bhagavataḥ arahataḥ sammāsambuddhassa
translated: Homage to that Blessed One, perfected one, fully awakened Buddha

original: Abhidhammapiṭake🔽Vibhaṅga-anuṭīkā🔽1. Khandhavibhaṅgo
analyzed: abhidhamma piṭake           khandha vibhaṅgo
translated: In the Abhidhamma Piṭaka🔽The Minor Commentary on the Vibhanga🔽The Description of the Aggregates

original: 1. Suttantabhājanīyavaṇṇanā
translated: The Commentary on the Suttas in the “Basket of Conduct”

original: Catusaccantogadhattā catunnaṃ ariyasaccānaṃ gāthāyaṃ “catusaccadaso”ti nippadesato
analyzed: catunnam ariya saccānam nippadesato
translated: The four truths are included in the verse by the word “truths” in the phrase “the truths’ aspect” .🔽The word “truths” is a collective noun.🔽The word “truths” is a collective noun.

original: saccāni gahitānīti nippadesato eva tadatthaṃ vibhāvento “cattāri saccānī”tiādimāha.
analyzed: saccāni gahitāni iti nippadesataḥ eva tad attham vibhāvento cattāri saccāni iti ādim āha
translated: The word “truths” is a collective noun.🔽The word “truths” is a collective noun.

original: Tattha samāhaṭānīti samānītāni, cittena ekato gahitānīti adhippāyo. “Samāhaṭānī”ti
analyzed: tattha samāhaṭāni iti samānītāni cittena ekatas gahitāni iti adhippāyaḥ samāhaṭāni iti
translated: The word “truths” is a collective noun.🔽The word “truths” is a collective noun.🔽The word “truths” is a collective noun.🔽The word “truths” is a collective noun.🔽The word “truths” is a collective noun.🔽The word “truths” is a collective noun.🔽The word “truths” is a collective noun.🔽The word “truths” is a collective noun.🔽The word “truths” is a collective noun.

original: ca etena samāhāre ayaṃ samāsoti dasseti. Tenevassa katekattassa catusaccanti napuṃsakaniddeso
analyzed: ca etena samāhāre ayam samāsaḥ iti dasseti tena ivassa katekattassa catusaccanti napuṃsaka niddeso
translated: The word “truths” is a collective noun.🔽The word “truths” is a collective noun.🔽The word “truths” is a collective noun.🔽The word “truths” is a collective noun.🔽The word “truths” is a collective noun.

original: “tivaṭṭa”ntiādīsu viya. Pattādipakkhepena hissa na itthiliṅgatā yathā pañcapattaṃ,🔽catuyugaṃ, tibhuvananti, taṃ catusaccaṃ passi adakkhi, pariññāpahānasacchikiriyābhāvanābhisamayavasena
analyzed: tivaṭṭanti ādīsu viya patta ādi pakkhepena hissa na itthi liṅga tā yathā pañca pattam  catu yugam ti bhuvanan ti tam catu saccam passi adakkhi pariññā apahāna sacchikiriyā bhāvanā abhisamaya vasena
translated: The word “truths” is a collective noun.🔽The word “truths” is a collective noun.🔽The word “truths” is a collective noun.🔽The word “truths” is a collective noun.🔽The word “truths” is a collective noun.

original: paṭivijjhīti attho. Kasmā panettha anantāparimāṇesu anaññasādhāraṇesu mahākaruṇāsabbaññutaññāṇādīsu
analyzed: paṭivijjhi iti atthaḥ kasmā pana ittha ananta aparimāṇesu anañña sādhāraṇesu mahā karuṇā sabbaññu taññāṇa ādīsu
translated: The word “truths” is a collective noun.🔽The word “truths” is a collective noun.🔽The word “truths” is a collective noun.🔽The word “truths” is a collective noun.🔽The word “truths” is a collective noun.🔽The word “truths” is a collective noun.🔽The word “truths” is a collective noun.🔽The word “truths” is a collective noun.🔽The word “truths” is a collective noun.🔽The word “truths” is a collective noun.🔽The word “truths” is a collective noun.🔽The word “truths” is a collective noun.🔽The word “truths” is a collective noun.🔽The word “truths” is a collective noun.🔽The word “truths” is a collective noun.🔽The word “truths” is a collective noun.🔽The word “truths” is a collective noun.🔽The word “truths”

original: buddhaguṇesu saṃvijjamānesu sāvakehi, paccekabuddhehi ca sādhāraṇena catusaccadassanena
analyzed: buddha guṇesu saṃvijjamānesu sāvakehi paccekabuddhehi ca sādhāraṇena catu sacca dassanena
translated: When the qualities of the Buddha are present in the disciples and in the paccekabuddhas, the Buddha is praised by the disciples and the paccekabuddhas in common with the vision of the Four Noble Truths.

original: bhagavantaṃ thometīti codanaṃ manasi katvā āha “satipi sāvakāna”ntiādi. Tattha “anaññapubbakattā”ti
analyzed: bhagavantam thometi iti codanam manasi katvā āha sati pi sāvakānam ntiādi tattha anaññapubbakattā ti
translated: Having considered the accusation, he said, “Even though the disciples,” etc. Herein, by “because of the non-otherness of the vision of the Four Noble Truths,”

original: iminā sāvakehi, “tattha cā”tiādinā paccekabuddhehi ca bhagavato catusaccadassanassa🔽asādhāraṇataṃ, niratisayatañca dasseti. Parasantānesu pasāritabhāvena supākaṭattāti
analyzed: iminā sāvakehi tattha ca ati ādinā paccekabuddhehi ca bhagavato catu sacca dassanassa  asādhāraṇa tam niratisaya tam ca dasseti para santānesu pasārita bhāvena su pākaṭa ttā ti
translated: he shows the non-commonality and the non-excess of the Blessed One’s vision of the Four Noble Truths with the disciples and with the paccekabuddhas.🔽By “because of the great clarity of the vision of the Four Noble Truths in the world,”

original: desanānubhāvena veneyyasantānesu catusaccadassanassa vitthāritabhāvena yāva devamanussesu
analyzed: desanā anubhāvena veneyya santānesu catur acca dassanassa vitthārita bhāvena yāva deva manussesu
translated: he shows the great clarity of the vision of the Four Noble Truths in the world of disciples by the extension of the vision of the Four Noble Truths in the world of disciples through the power of the teaching.

original: suppakāsitattā. Nāthasaddaṃ loke yācanupatāpissariyāsīsāsu paṭhantīti tamatthaṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: su pakāsita ttā nātha saddam loke paṭhanti iti tam attham dassetuṃ
translated: The word “lord” is recited in the world in the sense of supplicant, of one who is afflicted, of one who is a head of a family. In order to show that meaning,

original: “nāthatīti nātho”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha yasmā bhagavā catusaccadassanabhāveneva attano
analyzed: nāthati iti nātha utiādi vuttam tattha yasmai bhagavā catu sacca dassana bhāvena iva attano
translated: “Lord” is said to be a lord because of being a supplicant, etc. Herein, because the Blessed One is a lord by the very fact of the vision of the Four Noble Truths,

original: hitasukhāsīsāya kilesabyasanupatāpanassa, hitapaṭipattiyācanassa ca matthakaṃ patto,
analyzed: hita sukha āsīsāya kilesa byasana upatāpanassa hita paṭipatti yācanassa ca matthakam patto
translated: He has reached the culmination of the search for the welfare and happiness of those who are afflicted by the suffering of the defilements and of the search for the practice of the welfare of those who are in need of the practice of the welfare.

original: tasmā taṃ teneva pakāsitanti atthuddhāraṃ anāmasitvā paduddhāravasena nāthasaddassa🔽atthaṃ dassento “veneyyānaṃ hitasukhaṃ āsīsatī”tiādimāha. “Catusaccadaso”ti vā iminā
analyzed: tasmā tam tena iva pakāsitan ti attha uddhāram an āmasitvā pad uddhāra vasena nātha saddassa  attham dassentaḥ veneyyānam hita sukham āsīsati itiādim āha catus accadasā iti vai iminā
translated: Therefore, he is called “the Protector” because he has revealed that search.🔽The meaning of the word “nātha” is shown by the words “he searches for the welfare and happiness of his disciples” without mentioning the meaning of the word “attha.”🔽By the words “the one who has the light of the four noble truths”

original: anaññasādhāraṇo bhagavato ñāṇānubhāvo pakāsitoti “nātho”ti iminā anaññasādhāraṇaṃ
analyzed: anañña sādhāraṇaḥ bhagavataḥ ñāṇa anubhāvo pakāsito ti nātha iti iminā anañña sādhāraṇam
translated: the unique power of the Buddha’s knowledge is shown.

original: karuṇānubhāvaṃ vibhāvetuṃ “veneyyāna”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Paramena cittissariyena samannāgato
analyzed: karuṇā anubhāvam vibhāvetum veneyya ananti ādi vuttam paramena cittissariyena samannāgato
translated: By the words “the Protector” his unique power of compassion is shown.

original: bhagavā nāthoti vuccatīti yojanā. Tathā paramena cittissariyena samannāgato sabbasatte🔽guṇehi īsatīti yojetabbaṃ. Cittissariyenāti ariyiddhiādinā citte vasībhāvena. Guṇehi
analyzed: bhagavā nātho ti vuccati iti yojanā tathā paramena cittissariyena samannāgato sabba satte  guṇehi īsati iti yojetabbam cittissariyena ati ariyiddhi ādinā citte vasībhāvena guṇehi
translated: The Blessed One is called “the Protector” because he is endowed with the highest power of mind.🔽He is called “the Protector” because he is endowed with the highest power of mind.🔽He is called “the Protector” because he searches for the welfare of all beings with his own virtues.

original: īsatīti paramukkaṃsagatehi attano sīlādiguṇehi dhammena issariyaṃ vattetīti attho.
analyzed: īsati iti param ukkaṃsa gatehi attanaḥ sīla ādi guṇehi dhammena issariyam vatteti iti attho
translated: He is called “the Protector” because he rules with the power of his own virtues, such as virtue, etc., which are beyond compare.

original: Evaṃbhūto yasmā sabbābhibhū nāma hoti, tena vuttaṃ “abhibhavatī”ti. Tathā cāha “sadevake,
analyzed: evaṃbhūtaḥ yasmā sabbābhibhū nāma hoti tena vuttam abhibhavati iti tathā ca āha sa devake
translated: and he is called “the conqueror of all” . That is why it is said: “he conquers” . And so it is said: “in the world with its gods” .🔽

original: bhikkhave, loke…pe… abhibhū anabhibhūto, tasmā ‘tathāgato’ti vuccatī”ti. Duvidhenāpi
analyzed: bhikkhave an abhibhūto tasmā tathāgato ti vuccati iti duvidhena api
translated: And since he is such, he is called “the conqueror of all.” Hence it is said: “He conquers” . And so it is said: “Bhikkhus, in the world with its deities, its Mara s, and its Brahmās, in this generation with its ascetics and brahmans, with its devas and humans, he is the unconquered conqueror, the all-seeing; therefore he is called the Tathāgata” .

original: issariyatthaṃ nāthasaddaṃ dasseti.
analyzed: issariya attham nātha saddam dasseti
translated: The word “lord” is shown to have the meaning of sovereignty in the two ways .🔽The interpretation is that he is the one who extols the teaching with its eighteen bases.

original: Aṭṭhārasappabhedāya desanāya thomanamevāti yojanā. Samānagaṇanaguṇehīti samānagaṇanehi
analyzed: aṭṭhārasa ppa bhedāya desanāya thomanam eva ati yojanā samāna gaṇana guṇehi iti samāna gaṇanehi
translated: With the qualities of the same reckoning : with the qualities that are the means of the same reckoning .

original: guṇehi karaṇabhūtehi. Yathāvuttena niratisayena catusaccadassanenāti sabbaññutaññāṇassa,
analyzed: guṇehi karaṇa bhūtehi yathā vuttena niratisayena catu sacca dassanena ati sabbaññuta ññāṇassa
translated: With the unsurpassed seeing of the four truths as stated : with the knowledge of omniscience,

original: dasabalesu vasībhāvassa ca padaṭṭhānabhūtena. Saccābhisambodhena hi abhinīhārānurūpaṃ🔽rūpārūpadhammesu chattiṃsakoṭisatasahassamukhappavattena sātisayaṃ santatisamūhakiccārammaṇaghanappabhedena
analyzed: dasa balesu vasībhāvassa ca padaṭṭhāna bhūtena sacca abhisambodhena hi abhinīhāra anurūpam  rūpa arūpa dhammesu chattiṃsa koṭi sata sahassa mukha ppavattena sa atisayam santati samūha kicca ārammaṇa ghana ppabhedena
translated: which is the basis for mastery in the ten powers. For it is by the discovery of the truths that the Blessed One, in the supreme perfect enlightenment,

original: mahāvajirañāṇasaṅkhātena buddhāveṇikena sammasanena sambhūtena bhagavā sammāsambodhiyaṃ
analyzed: mahā vajira ñāṇa saṅkhātena buddha āveṇikena sammasanena sambhūtena bhagavā sammāsambodhiyam
translated: by means of the unique concentration of the Buddhas called the “great vajra-like knowledge,” which is generated by the outshining of the various modes of the mass of consciousness, which has as its object the mode of the truth of suffering, etc., and which is distinguished by the mode of the mass of the various kinds of penetration of the four truths, with its sixty-two hundred thousand million gateways,

original: patiṭṭhitova kusalādibhedena, phassādibhedena ca dhamme vibhajanto cittuppādakaṇḍādivasena🔽dhammasaṅgahaṃ catudhā desetuṃ samattho ahosi. Tathā atītaṃse appaṭihatañāṇatādibuddhadhammasamannāgato
analyzed: patiṭṭhitaḥ iva kusala ādi bhedena phassa ādi bhedena ca dhamme vibhajanto cittuppāda kaṇḍa ādi vasena  dhamma saṅgaham catudhā desetum samatthaḥ ahosi tathā atītaṃse appaṭihata ñāṇa tā ādi buddha dhamma samannāgato
translated: and he was able to teach the Dhamma-collection in four parts, namely, the Section on the Arising of Consciousness, etc., by analyzing the states classed as profitable, etc., and classed as contact, etc.

original: bhagavā atītādibhedato khandhādike vibhajitvā desetuṃ samattho ahosi. Tena vuttaṃ🔽“yathāvuttena…pe… vibhaṅga”nti. “Sabbaññubhāsitattā”ti vatvā puna “asabbaññunā desetuṃ
analyzed: bhagavā atīta ādi bhedataḥ khandha ādike vibhajitvā desetum samatthaḥ ahosi tena vuttam  yathā vuttena pe vibhaṅganti sabbaññu bhāsita ttā ti vatvā puna a sabbaññunā desetum
translated: And the Blessed One, who is endowed with the special qualities of a Buddha, such as unobstructed knowledge of the past, etc., was able to teach by analyzing the aggregates, etc., classed as past, etc. That is why it was said above, “The Vibhaṅga is the analysis of the states classed as past, etc., in the way already stated. ”🔽The words, “Because it is the utterance of the Omniscient One” and “showing that it cannot be taught by one who is not omniscient”

original: asakkuṇeyyataṃ dassento”ti etena dhammasaṅgaṇīvibhaṅgānaṃ anvayato byatirekato ca🔽sammāsambuddhappaveditataññeva vibhāveti. Sammāsambuddhatādiguṇeti buddharatanassa
analyzed: dassento ti etena dhamma saṅgaṇī vibhaṅgānaṃ anvayataḥ byatirekataḥ ca  vibhāvā iti sammāsambuddha tā ādi guṇā iti buddha ratanassa
translated: distinguish the Dhamma-collection and the Vibhaṅga as the Dispensation of the Perfectly Enlightened One by the method of agreement and by the method of difference.

original: sammāsambuddhatā, dhammasaṅgharatanānaṃ svākkhātatā, suppaṭipannatāti evamādiguṇe pakāseti.
analyzed: sammāsambuddha tā dhamma saṅgha rata nānam su ākkhāta tā suppaṭipanna tā ati evamādi guṇe pakāseti
translated: The words, “The special qualities of the Perfectly Enlightened One, etc.,” show the special qualities of the Buddha Jewel, namely, perfect enlightenment, and the special qualities of the Dhamma-collection Jewel, namely, well proclaimedness, and the special qualities of the Saṅgha Jewel, namely, the state of being entered on the good way, and so on.

original: Nanu ca “catusaccadaso”tiādinā bhagavatova guṇā vibhāvitāti? Saccaṃ, teneva dhammasaṅghānampi
analyzed: nanu ca catur sacca dasa iti ādinā bhagavataḥ uva guṇāḥ vibhāvitā ati saccam tena iva dhamma saṅghānam pi
translated: Are not the Blessed One’s special qualities shown by the words “The four truths’ seer” , etc.? —True, but by that the special qualities of the Dhamma and the Community are also shown,

original: guṇā vibhāvitā honti tappabhavassa anaññathābhāvato, tadapadesena vā dhammo, tadādhāro
analyzed: guṇāḥ vibhāvitāḥ honti tad pabhavassa anaññathābhāvato tad apadesena vā dhammo tad ādhāro
translated: because of the non-difference of the Dhamma and the Community from him, or else the Dhamma is stated by implication, and the Community is stated as the support of that.

original: ca saṅgho vuttova hotīti vuttaṃ “buddhādīnaṃ…pe… vibhāvetī”ti.
analyzed: ca saṅghaḥ vuttaḥ iva hoti iti vuttam buddha ādīnam pe vibhāveti iti
translated: That is why it is said: “The special qualities of the Buddha, etc., are shown by the words ‘The four truths’ seer’ , etc.”

original: Atītaṃseti atītakoṭṭhāse, pubbanteti attho. Appaṭihatanti nappaṭihataṃ, ñāṇassa paṭighāto
analyzed: atīta aṃse ti atīta koṭṭhāse pubbante ti attho appaṭihatam ti na paṭihatam ñāṇassa paṭighāto
translated: In the past field: in the past section; the meaning is, in the beginning. Unimpeded: not impeded. The impediment of knowledge is ignorance, or else the whole mass of defilements.

original: nāma aññāṇaṃ, sabbampi vā kilesajātaṃ. Taṃ yasmā bhagavato saha vāsanāya pahīnaṃ,
analyzed: nāma aññāṇam sabbam pi vā kilesa jātam tam yasmai bhagavato saha vāsanāya pahīnam
translated: Since that has been abandoned by the Blessed One together with its residues,

original: tasmāssa atītaṃse sabbatthakameva ñeyyāvaraṇappahānena ñāṇaṃ appaṭihatanti vuccati.
analyzed: tasmā assa atīta ṃse sabbatthakam eva ñeyya āvaraṇa ppahānena ñāṇam appaṭihatanti vuccati
translated: his knowledge is called “unimpeded” in the past field in all instances by the abandoning of the hindrance of the known.

original: Esa nayo sesesupi. Kiṃ panetāni pāṭiyekkaṃ visuṃ ñāṇāni, udāhu atītādīsu pavattanakañāṇāni
analyzed: esa nayaḥ sesesu pi kim pana etāni pāṭiyekkam visum ñāṇāni udāhu atīta ādīsu pavattanaka ñāṇāni
translated: The same method applies in the case of the future and the present. But are these different kinds of knowledge or is it just the knowledge occurring in the past, etc.,

original: eva? Tīsu kālesu appaṭihatañāṇāni nāma pāṭiyekkaṃ bhagavato tīṇi ñāṇānevāti vadanti.
analyzed: eva tīsu kālesu appaṭihatañāṇāni nāma pāṭiyekkam bhagavataḥ tīṇi vadanti
translated: that is called “knowledge that is unimpeded in the three times”? They say that the Blessed One has three different kinds of knowledge called “knowledge that is unimpeded in the three times.”

original: Ekaṃyeva hutvā tīsu kālesu appaṭihatañāṇaṃ nāma sabbaññutaññāṇameva. Sabbaṃ kāyakammanti
analyzed: ekam yeva hutvā tīsu kālesu appaṭihata ñāṇam nāma sabbaññuta ññāṇam eva sabbam kāya kamman ti
translated: The knowledge that is unobstructed in the three times is the knowledge of omniscience.

original: yaṃ kiñci bhagavatā kattabbaṃ kāyakammaṃ. Ñāṇapubbaṅgamanti ñāṇapurecārikaṃ. Ñāṇānuparivattanti🔽ñāṇassa anuparivattanakaṃ, sabbaṃ kāyapayogaṃ pavattento bhagavā ñāṇena paricchinditvā
analyzed: yat kiñci bhagavatā kattabbam kāya kammam ñāṇa pubbaṅgamanti ñāṇa purecārikam ñāṇa anuparivattanti  ñāṇassa anuparivattanakam sabbam kāya payogam pavattentaḥ bhagavā ñāṇena paricchinditvā
translated: “Any action of the body” means any action of the body that the Blessed One performs. “Preceded by knowledge” means preceded by knowledge. “Following knowledge” means following knowledge.

original: ñāṇasahitameva pavattetīti attho. Sesapadadvayepi eseva nayo. Chandassāti kattukamyatāya,
analyzed: ñāṇa sahitam eva pavatteti iti attho sesa pada dvaye pi esa iva nayaḥ chandassa ati kattu kamyatāya
translated: The Blessed One, when performing any bodily action, performs it after delimiting it by knowledge. The meaning is that he performs it together with knowledge. The same method applies to the other two clauses. “By his will” means by his desire to act.

original: mahākaruṇāsamāyogato sattānaṃ ekantahitesitāya hitakiriyāchandassāti attho. Dhammadesanāyāti🔽dhammakathāya. Aparikkhayāparimeyyapaṭibhānatāya hi bhagavato karaṇasampattiyā ca
analyzed: mahā karuṇā samāyogataḥ sattānam ekanta hita īsitāya hita kiriyā chandassa ati atthaḥ dhamma desanāya ati  dhamma kathāya aparikkhaya aparimeyya paṭibhāna tāya hi bhagavato karaṇa sampattiyā ca
translated: The meaning is that he acts for the welfare of beings because he is endowed with great compassion. “For the sake of teaching the Dhamma” means for the sake of preaching the Dhamma.

original: dhammadesanā nirantaraṃ pavattiyamānāpi na kadācipi parikkhayaṃ gacchati, aññadatthu
analyzed: dhamma desanā nirantaram pavattiyamānā api na kadācipi parikkhayam gacchati añña datthu
translated: For the Blessed One’s ability to teach the Dhamma is such that even if he were to teach the Dhamma uninterruptedly, it would never be exhausted.

original: uparūpari vaḍḍhateva. Vīriyassāti parahitapaṭipattiyaṃ ussāhassa. Vimuttiyāti phalavimuttiyā.🔽Ettha ca samādhiādīnaṃ ahāni taṃtaṃpaṭipakkhassa savāsanapahīnattā anaññasādhāraṇatāya
analyzed: upari upari vaḍḍha tā iva vīriyassa ati para hita paṭipattiyam ussāhassa vimuttiyā ati phala vimuttiyā  ettha ca samādhi ādīnam taṃ taṃ paṭipakkhassa sa vāsanā pahīna ttā anañña sādhāraṇa tāya
translated: and so on. “In energy” means in the exertion for the performance of what is beneficial to others. “In deliverance” means in the deliverance that is the fruit .🔽And here the non-diminution of concentration, etc., should be understood as the non-diminution of the path, because the opponent has been abandoned together with its traces, and as the non-diminution of the fruit, because the fruit is not shared with others.

original: veditabbā. Chandādīnaṃ pana mahākaruṇāsamāyogatopi. Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: veditabbā chanda ādīnam pana mahā karuṇā samāyogataḥ pi sesam su viññeyyam eva
translated: But the non-diminution of zeal, etc., is also due to the association with great compassion. The rest is easy to understand.🔽“Those same ideas”: those same ideas classed in the three- and fourfold ways beginning with the profitable.

original: 1. Te eva dhammeti te eva kusalādike tikadukehi saṅgahite dhamme. Suttante khandhādivasena
analyzed: te eva dhamme ti te eva kusala ādike tika dukehi saṅgahite dhamme suttante khandha ādi vasena
translated: The explanation of the Thread by way of the aggregates, etc.,

original: vutte khandhādivasena vibhajitunti yojanā. Nanu suttante paṭisambhidāvasena te na🔽vuttāti? Yadipi sarūpato na vuttā, “jarāmaraṇe ñāṇaṃ, jarāmaraṇasamudaye ñāṇa”ntiādinā
analyzed: vutte khandha ādi vasena vibhajitun ti yojanā nanu suttante paṭisambhidā vasena te na  vuttā iti yadi api sarūpataḥ na vuttā jarā maraṇe ñāṇam jarā maraṇa samudaye
translated: is the analysis of the Thread by way of the aggregates, etc. But are not those ideas stated in the Thread by way of the kinds of discriminative construction ?

original: pana hetuhetuphalādīsu ñāṇavibhāgassa vuttattā atthato vuttā eva honti, paṭisambhidāmagge
analyzed: pana hetu hetu phala ādīsu ñāṇa vibhāgassa vuttattā atthataḥ vuttāḥ eva honti paṭisambhidā magge
translated: Though they are not stated in their specific form, still they are stated in the sense that the analysis of the kinds of knowledge of cause, fruit, etc., is stated in the passage beginning, “Knowledge of ageing-and-death, knowledge of the origin of ageing-and-death” ,

original: vā paṭisambhidānaṃ āgatattā suttante paṭisambhidāvasenapi te dhammā vuttā eva. Tatthāti
analyzed: vā paṭisambhidānaṃ āgata ttā suttante paṭisambhidā vasena api te dhammā vuttāḥ eva tattha ati
translated: or else they are stated in the Thread by way of the discriminative constructions since the discriminative constructions are included in the Path of Discrimination.🔽“There” means in the Thread.

original: tasmiṃ suttante. Saṅkhepenāti samāsena. Uddesaniddesamatteneva hi suttante khandhādayo
analyzed: tasmin suttante saṅkhepena ati samāsena uddesa niddesa mattena iva hi suttante khandha ādayaḥ
translated: In that Thread. In brief: in brief, in a summary way. For in that Thread the aggregates, etc., are taught🔽by way of the mere statement of the headings, not by way of the subsumption, etc., so they are said to be “stated there in brief.”

original: desitā, na paṭiniddesādināti saṅkhepena te tattha vuttāti vuttā. Tatthāti vā dhammasaṅgahe.
analyzed: desitā na paṭiniddesa ādinā ati saṅkhepena te tattha vuttā ati vuttā tattha ati vā dhamma saṅgahe
translated: Or alternatively, “there” is in the Dhamma-Compendium.

original: Tatthāpi hi “tasmiṃ kho pana samaye cattāro khandhā hontī”tiādinā khandhādayo saṅkhepena🔽vuttāti. Vibhajīyanti ettha, etena vā khandhādayoti vibhaṅgo, te eva pakirīyanti
analyzed: tattha api hi tasmin kho pana samaye cattāraḥ khandhāḥ honti itiādinā khandha ādayaḥ saṅkhepena  vuttā iti ettha etena vā khandha ādayaḥ ti vibhaṅgaḥ te eva pakirīyanti
translated: For there too the aggregates, etc., are stated in brief by the passage beginning, “On that occasion there are four aggregates” .

original: paṭṭhapīyanti ettha, etena vāti pakaraṇaṃ, vibhaṅgo ca so pakaraṇañcāti vibhaṅgappakaraṇaṃ.
analyzed: paṭṭhapīyanti ettha etena vā ati pakaraṇam vibhaṅgo ca saḥ pakaraṇam ca ati vibhaṅga ppakaraṇam
translated: The analysis is either the analysis of the aggregates, etc., here or that by which they are analysed. The chapter is either the place where they are spread out, set forth, or that by which they are spread out, set forth. So the analysis is the chapter.

original: Ādisaddatthajotakenāti “iti vā, iti evarūpā naccagītavāditavisūkadassanā paṭivirato”tiādīsu🔽viya ādisaddassa atthadīpakena. Pakāratthajotakenāti “iti kho, bhikkhave, sappaṭibhayo
analyzed: ādi sadda attha jotakena ati iti vā iti evarūpā nacca gīta vādita visūka dassanā paṭiviratā uti ādīsu 🔽viya ādi saddassa attha dīpakena pakāra attha jotakena ati iti kho bhikkhave sa paṭibhayaḥ
translated: By the word “etc.” : in such passages as “Or he abstains from seeing dancing, singing, music, and shows” ,🔽the word “etc.” indicates the meaning of “and so on.” By the word “etc.” : in such passages as “Thus, bhikkhus, there is fear in what is non-self” ,

original: bālo, appaṭibhayo paṇḍito”tiādīsu viya pakāratthavibhāvakena. “Ekadesena samudāyaṃ
analyzed: bālaḥ appaṭibhayaḥ paṇḍitaḥ ti ādīsu viya pakāra attha vibhāvakena eka desena samudāyam
translated: as in the passage, “The fool and the wise man” .

original: nidassetī”ti etena “rūpakkhandho…pe… viññāṇakkhandho”ti ettha itisaddassa nidassanatthataṃ
analyzed: nidasseti iti etena viññāṇa kkhandho ti ettha iti saddassa nidassana ttha tat
translated: By the words “he shows a collection by a part of it” he shows that the word iti has the meaning of showing in the passage, “The material form aggregate … the consciousness aggregate” .

original: dasseti. Nidassanatthopi hi iti-saddo diṭṭho yathā “atthīti kho, kaccāna, ayameko🔽anto”tiādīsu. Parisamāpanattho vā “tasmātiha me, bhikkhave, dhammadāyādā bhavatha,
analyzed: dasseti nidassana tthaḥ api hi iti saddaḥ diṭṭhaḥ yathā atthi iti kho kaccāna ayam ekaḥ  antaḥ ti ādīsu parisamāpana atthaḥ vā tasmāt iha me bhikkhave dhamma dāyādāḥ bhavatha
translated: For the word iti is also seen to have the meaning of showing, as in the passage, “There is, Kaccana, one thing” .

original: no āmisadāyādā. Atthi me tumhesu anukampā ‘kinti me sāvakā dhammadāyādā bhaveyyuṃ,🔽no āmisadāyādā’ti” evamādīsu viya. Parisamāpanañhetaṃ suttantabhājanīyassa ekadesadassanena
analyzed: no āmisa dāyādāḥ atthi me tumhesu anukampā kinti me sāvakāḥ dhamma dāyādāḥ bhaveyyuṃ  evamādīsu viya parisamāpanam hetam suttanta bhājanīyassa eka desa dassanena
translated: Or else the meaning of completion is that of the passage, “Therefore, bhikkhus, be my heirs in Dhamma, not my heirs in material things. I have compassion for you, thinking, ‘How can my disciples become my heirs in Dhamma and not my heirs in material things?’” .

original: yadidaṃ “pañcakkhandhā rūpakkhandho…pe… viññāṇakkhandho”ti tāva tadatthassa saṅgahitattā.
analyzed: yat idam pañca kkhandhāḥ rūpa kkhandha upe viññāṇa kkhandho ti tāva tad atthassa saṅgahita ttā
translated: For this is a completion of the exposition of the sutta by showing a part of it, namely, “The five aggregates are the material form aggregate … the consciousness aggregate” .

original: Tatthāti vibhaṅgappakaraṇe. “Nibbānavajjāna”nti ettha yadi nibbānavajjānaṃ…pe… appakatarapadattā🔽khandhānaṃ khandhavibhaṅgo ādimhi vutto, nanu saha nibbānena sabbadhammasaṅgāhakattā,
analyzed: tattha ati vibhaṅga pakaraṇe nibbāna vat jānanti ettha yadi  khandhānam khandha vibhaṅgaḥ ādimhi vuttaḥ nanu saha nibbānena sabba dhamma saṅgāhaka ttā
translated: Herein, in the Vibhaṅga treatise. As regards the words “except for Nibbāna” , if it is asked why the exposition of the aggregates is given first, since the aggregates include all states except Nibbāna,🔽and since the exposition of the truths should come first because the truths include all states,

original: sabbadhammasaṅgāhakehi ca āyatanādīhi khandhehi ca appakatarapadattā saccavibhaṅgo🔽ādimhi vattabboti? Na, tatthāpi dukkhasaccavibhaṅge ekadesena khandhānaṃ eva vibhajitabbato.🔽Yathāha “tattha katamaṃ dukkhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ? Jātipi dukkhā…pe… saṃkhittena pañcupādānakkhandhā
analyzed: sabba dhamma saṅgāhakehi ca āyatana ādīhi khandhehi ca appakatara pada tā sacca vibhaṅgo  ādimhi vattabbaḥ ti na tattha api dukkha sacca vibhaṅge ekadesena khandhānam eva vibhajitabbato  yathā āha tattha katamam dukkham ariya saccam saṃkhittena pañca upādānakkhandhāḥ
translated: then the answer is that the exposition of the aggregates is given first because the aggregates are mentioned by a shorter phrase than the truths.

original: dukkhā”ti. Idha pana anavasesatova khandhā vibhajīyantīti nibbānavajjānaṃ…pe… appakatarapadattā
analyzed: dukkhā ti idha pana anavasesataḥ va khandhāḥ vibhajīyanti iti nibbāna vajja anaṃpe appakatara padattā
translated: For although the exposition of the aggregates is given first, still the aggregates are included in the truths, according to the passage: “Herein, what is the noble actuality of suffering? Birth is suffering, and aging is suffering, and death is suffering, and sorrow and lamentation, pain, grief and despair are suffering, and association with the unloved is suffering, and separation from the loved is suffering, and not to get what one wants is suffering, in short the five aggregates as objects of clinging are suffering” .

original: khandhānaṃ khandhavibhaṅgo ādimhi vutto.
analyzed: khandhānam khandha vibhaṅgaḥ ādimhi vutto
translated: But here the aggregates are given in full.

original: Apica rūpasammūḷhā arūpasammūḷhā ubhayasammūḷhāti tividhā bodhaneyyapuggalā, tathā
analyzed: apica rūpa sammūḍhā arūpa sammūḍhā ubhaya sammūḍhā ati tividhā bodhaneyya puggalā tathā
translated: Moreover, there are three kinds of persons to be instructed: those confused about matter, those confused about the immaterial, and those confused about both.

original: saṃkhittarucino vitthārarucino nātisaṅkhepavitthārarucino, tikkhindriyā mudindriyā
analyzed: saṃkhitta rucinaḥ vitthāra rucinaḥ na ati saṅkhepa vitthāra rucinaḥ tikkha indriyāḥ mud indriyāḥ
translated: those who like a brief teaching, those who like an extensive teaching, those who like a teaching that is neither brief nor extensive, those with sharp faculties, those with dull faculties,

original: majjhimindriyāti ca. Tesu arūpasammūḷhānaṃ upakārāya khandhadesanā, rūpasammūḷhānaṃ
analyzed: majjhima indriyā ati ca tesu arūpa sammūḷhānam upakārāya khandha desanā rūpa sammūḷhānam
translated: Those who like a brief treatment, those who like an extensive treatment, and those who like a treatment that is neither brief nor extensive. Those with keen faculties, those with medium faculties, and those with dull faculties.🔽The teaching of the aggregates is for the benefit of those confused about the immaterial,🔽the teaching of the bases is for the benefit of those confused about the material,

original: āyatanadesanā, ubhayasammūḷhānaṃ dhātudesanā. Tathā saṃkhittarucīnaṃ khandhadesanā,
analyzed: āyatana desanā dhātu desanā tathā khandha desanā
translated: and the teaching of the elements is for the benefit of those confused about both. Likewise, the teaching of the aggregates is for those who like a brief treatment,

original: nātisaṅkhepavitthārarucīnaṃ āyatanadesanā, vitthārarucīnaṃ dhātudesanā. Tikkhindriyānaṃ
analyzed: na ati saṅkhepa vitthāra rucīnam āyatana desanā vitthāra rucīnam dhātu desanā tikkhindriyānam
translated: the teaching of the bases is for those who like a treatment that is neither brief nor extensive, and the teaching of the elements is for those who like an extensive treatment.

original: khandhadesanā, majjhimindriyānaṃ āyatanadesanā, mudindriyānaṃ dhātudesanāti iminā🔽payojanena anukkamena ca khandhāyatanadhātuvibhaṅgānaṃ desanākkamova veditabbo. Taṃ🔽panetaṃ khandhādittayaṃ pavattinivattitadubhayahetumukheneva ñāyamānaṃ yathābhūtāvabodhāya
analyzed: khandha desanā majjhima indriyānam āyatana desanā mud indriyānam dhātu desanā ati iminā  payojanena anukkamena ca khandha āyatana dhātu vibhaṅgānam desanā kkamaḥ uva veditabbaḥ tam  panetam khandha ādittayam pavatti nivatti tad ubhaya hetu mukhena iva ñāyamānam yathā bhūta avabodhāya
translated: The teaching of the aggregates is for those with keen faculties, the teaching of the bases is for those with medium faculties, and the teaching of the elements is for those with dull faculties.🔽This is the purpose and the sequence in which the teaching of the analysis of the aggregates, bases, and elements should be understood.🔽But this triad of aggregates, etc., is known by way of the three truths, namely, occurrence, cessation, and the path leading to the cessation of the two former.

original: hoti, nāññathāti dassanatthaṃ saccavibhaṅgadesanā pavattā. So ca yathābhūtāvabodho
analyzed: hoti na aññathā ti dassana attham sacca vibhaṅga desanā pavattā so ca yathā bhūta avabodho
translated: The teaching of the analysis of the truths is given in order to show that it is only by understanding these three truths as they really are that there can be

original: visesato indriyasannissayenāti indriyavibhaṅgadesanā. Indriyānañca indaṭṭho taṃtaṃpaccayadhammabhūtānaṃ
analyzed: visesataḥ indriya sannissayena ati indriya vibhaṅga desanā indriyānam ca tad tad paccaya dhamma bhūtānam
translated: and especially by way of the faculties, is the teaching of the analysis of the faculties. And the meaning of faculty is the meaning of condition in the case of those things that are conditions for the various kinds of generation,

original: yathāsakaṃ paccayuppannesu paccayabhāvavisesenevāti paccayapaccayuppannavibhāgasandassanī🔽paccayākāravibhaṅgadesanā. Paccayākārassa khandhādīnañca aviparītasabhāvāvabodho🔽satipaṭṭhānādīsu sammāmanasikārenāti satipaṭṭhānasammappadhānaiddhipādabojjhaṅgamaggaṅgavibhaṅgadesanā.
analyzed: yathāsakam paccaya uppannesu paccaya bhāva visesena iva ati paccaya paccaya uppanna vibhāga sandassanī  paccaya ākāra vibhaṅga desanā paccaya ākārassa khandha ādīnam ca aviparīta sabhāva avabodho  sati paṭṭhāna ādīsu sammā manasikārena ati sati paṭṭhāna sammappadhāna eddhipāda bojjhaṅga maggaṅga vibhaṅga desanā
translated: and the meaning of the conditionally arisen is the meaning of the conditioned in the case of those things that are conditionally arisen. So the teaching of the analysis of conditions and the conditionally arisen is the teaching of the analysis of the modes of conditionality.🔽And the understanding of the unperverted individual essences of the modes of conditionality and of the categories beginning with the aggregates is right reflection in the foundations of mindfulness, etc.,🔽So the teaching of the analysis of the foundations of mindfulness, the right efforts, the bases of success, the factors of enlightenment, and the path factors is the teaching of the analysis of the modes of right reflection.

original: Svāyaṃ satipaṭṭhānādīsu sammāmanasikāro imāya paṭipattiyā hotīti jhānaappamaññāvibhaṅgadesanā,
analyzed: svāyam sati paṭṭhāna ādīsu sammāmanasikāro imāya paṭipattiyā hoti iti jhāna appamaññā vibhaṅga desanā
translated: And this right reflection in the foundations of mindfulness, etc., is in this way of practice, so the teaching of the analysis of the jhānas and the divine abodes is the teaching of the analysis of the way of practice.

original: sā sammāpaṭipatti ettake sīle patiṭṭhitassa sambhavatīti sikkhāpadavibhaṅgadesanā,
analyzed: sā sammā paṭipatti ettake sīle patiṭṭhitassa sambhavati iti sikkhāpada vibhaṅga desanā
translated: And that right practice is possible for one who is established in this kind of virtue, so the teaching of the analysis of the training precepts is the teaching of the analysis of the possibility of right practice.

original: yathāvuttāya ca sammāpaṭipattiyā ime ānisaṃsāti paṭisambhidāñāṇavibhaṅgadesanā, te
analyzed: yathā vuttāya ca sammāpaṭipattiyāḥ ime ānisaṃsā ati paṭisambhidā ñāṇa vibhaṅga desanā te
translated: And the benefits are these in the case of the right practice described, so the teaching of the analysis of the knowledge of the analytical insights is the teaching of the analysis of the benefits.

original: cime ñāṇavisesā imesu kilesesu pahīyantesu ca sambhavanti, nāññathāti kilesavibhaṅgadesanā,
analyzed: cime ñāṇa visesāḥ imesu kilesesu pahīyantesu ca sambhavanti na aññathā ati kilesa vibhaṅga desanā
translated: These are the special kinds of knowledge that arise when these defilements are abandoned, not otherwise. So this is the teaching of the analysis of the defilements.

original: evaṃ vitthārato desite khandhādike saṅkhepatopi jānantassa atthasiddhi hoti evāti
analyzed: evam vitthārataḥ desite khandha ādike saṅkhepataḥ pi jānantassa attha siddhi hoti eva ati
translated: When the aggregates, etc., are taught in detail in this way, the fulfilment of the purpose is effected also by their being taught in brief. So,

original: dassanatthaṃ pariyosāne dhammahadayavibhaṅgadesanā pavattāti evametesaṃ aṭṭhārasannaṃ
analyzed: dassana attham pariyosāne dhamma hadaya vibhaṅga desanā pavattā ati evam etesam aṭṭhārasannam
translated: in order to show that, the teaching of the analysis of the Dhamma-essence occurs at the end. This is how the method of teaching of these

original: mahāvibhaṅgānaṃ desanākkamakāraṇaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: mahā vibhaṅgānam desanā kkama kāraṇam veditabbam
translated: eighteen great analyses should be understood.

original: Rūpādīnanti rūpavedanāsaññāsaṅkhāraviññāṇānaṃ. Vedayitādisabhāvattābhāvāti yathākkamaṃ🔽anubhavanasañjānanābhisaṅkharaṇādisabhāvattābhāvā. Na hi rūpaṃ vedayitādisabhāvaṃ,
analyzed: rūpa ādīnam ti rūpa vedanā saññā saṅkhāra viññāṇānam vedayita ādi sabhāva tā bhāvā ati yathākkamam  anubhavana sañjānana abhisaṅkharaṇa ādi sabhāvat tā bhāvāḥ na hi rūpam vedayitā ādi sabhāvam
translated: As to the aggregates, etc.: as to the materiality, feeling, perception, formations, and consciousness aggregates. Because of the absence of the nature of being felt, etc.: because of the absence of the nature of being experienced, cognized, formed, etc., respectively.🔽For materiality has not the nature of being felt, etc.,🔽and feeling, etc., have not the nature of being material, etc.

original: vedanādi vā ruppanādisabhāvaṃ. Yato rūpādīnaṃ vedanāsamavarodhanena “cattāro khandhā”tiādinā🔽saṅkhipitvā khandhā 06 desetabbā siyuṃ. Ruppanādito aññassābhāvāti ruppanānubhavanādisabhāvato
analyzed: vedanā ādi vā ruppanā ādi sabhāvam yatas rūpa ādīnam vedanā samavarodhanena cattāro khandhā ti ādinā 🔽saṅkhipitvā khandhāḥ desetabbā siyum ruppana āditaḥ aññassa abhāvā ati ruppana anubhavana ādi sabhāvato
translated: Since the aggregates are not to be taught in brief as “four aggregates” by omitting feeling, etc., because of the absence of the nature of being felt, etc.,🔽because of the absence of anything other than materiality, etc.,

original: aññassa atītādike gahetvā rāsivasena vattabbassa saṃkhittassa sabhāvassa abhāvā.
analyzed: aññassa atīta ādike gahetvā rāsi vasena vattabbassa saṃkhittassa sabhāvassa abhāvā
translated: because there is no such thing as a mere individual essence of what is to be spoken of by way of a string of words, taking what is past, etc., as its support.🔽For the state of being mental, etc., is not the individual essence of feeling, etc.

original: Na hi cetasikādibhāvo vedanādīnaṃ sabhāvo. Heṭṭhā gaṇanesūti pañcato heṭṭhā gaṇanesu.
analyzed: na hi cetasika ādi bhāvaḥ vedanā ādīnam sa bhāvaḥ heṭṭhā gaṇanesu iti pañcatas heṭṭhā gaṇanesu
translated: In the enumerations below the five: in the enumerations below the five aggregates.

original: Aniṭṭhānanti apariyosānaṃ. Rūpādīsu hi katipaye, ekampi vā aggahetvā vuccamānā khandhavasena
analyzed: aniṭṭhānam ti apariyosānam rūpa ādīsu hi katipaye ekam pi vā aggahetvā vuccamānā khandha vasena
translated: Without end: without limit. For if one or more of the aggregates beginning with materiality are not taken, the teaching, being given under the heading of aggregates,

original: desanā anavasesasaṅkhatadhammasaṅgāhinī na sambhavati. Khandhassāti rāsaṭṭhassa khandhassa.
analyzed: desanā anavasesa saṅkhata dhamma saṅgāhinī na sambhavati khandhassa ati rāsaṭṭhassa khandhassa
translated: cannot include all conditionally arisen states.🔽Of the mass: of the aggregate as a mass.

original: Tenevāha “na hī”tiādi. Savibhāgadhammehīti sappabhedadhammehi.
analyzed: tena iva āha na hi itiādi sa vibhāga dhammehi iti sa ppabheda dhammehi
translated: Hence he says, “For the word ‘aggregate’ is not a collective term,” etc.

original: “Saddatthasahitaṃ khandhasaddassa visayaṃ dassetī”ti etena rāsisaddassa viya rāsaṭṭhe🔽khandhasaddassa vācakabhāvena pavattiṃ dasseti pariyāyantarabhāvato. Guṇādīsu pana
analyzed: saddattha sahitam khandha saddassa visayam dasseti iti etena rāsi saddassa viya  khandha saddassa vācaka bhāvena pavattim dasseti pariyāya antara bhāvataḥ guṇa ādīsu pana
translated: Of things with divisions: of things with subdivisions.🔽By this he shows that the word “aggregate” occurs as a collective term, like the word “mass,”🔽in the sense of a heap, and that it occurs as a designative term, like the word “collection,” in the sense of a collection, because it has a different application.🔽But in the case of the words “quality,” etc., it occurs only as having that as its domain of reference, not as a designative term.

original: kevalaṃ tabbisayapayogabhāveneva pavatti, na vācakabhāvenāti āha “guṇe…pe… na saddattha”nti.
analyzed: kevalam na vācaka bhāvena ati āha na
translated: Hence he says, “In the case of qualities, etc., the word ‘aggregate’ is not a designative term.”

original: Khandhasaddoti sīlādisadde sannidhāpito khandhasaddo. Tenevāha “sīlādiguṇavisiṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: khandha saddaḥ ti sīla ādi sadde sannidhāpitaḥ khandha saddaḥ tena iva āha sīla ādi guṇa visiṭṭham
translated: Therefore it is said: “It shows a collection distinguished by the special qualities of virtue, etc.”🔽“Some” : he is referring to the Elder Dhammapāla.

original: rāsaṭṭhaṃ dīpetī”ti. Kecīti dhammasirittheraṃ sandhāya vadati. Etthāti “sīlakkhandho
analyzed: rāsaṭṭham dīpeti iti keci iti dhammasiri theram sandhāya vadati ettha iti sīlakkhandho
translated: “Here” : in the passage: “the virtue aggregate,

original: samādhikkhandho”ti ettha. Na kevalañca so eva, aṭṭhakathācariyehipi ettha guṇatthatā🔽icchitā eva. Tathā hi aṭṭhasāliniyaṃ “sīlakkhandho samādhikkhandhotiādīsu guṇaṭṭhenā”ti
analyzed: samādhi khandho ti ettha na kevalam ca so eva aṭṭhakathā cariyehi pi ettha guṇa ttha tā  icchitā eva tathā hi aṭṭhasāliniyam sīla kkhandho samādhi kkhandho ti ādīsu guṇa ṭṭhena ati
translated: the concentration aggregate” .🔽And not only that, but the teachers of the commentaries also accept the meaning of “aggregate” as a special quality.

original: vuttaṃ. Nanu ca kevalopi khandhasaddo “tiṇṇaṃ kho, māṇava, khandhānaṃ vaṇṇavādī,
analyzed: vuttam nanu ca kevalaḥ api khandha saddo tiṇṇam kho māṇava khandhānam vaṇṇa vādī
translated: For in the Atthasālinī, in the passage beginning: “In the passage: ‘the virtue aggregate, the concentration aggregate,’ etc., the word ‘aggregate’ is used in the sense of a special quality,”

original: na kho, āvuso visākha, tīhi khandhehi ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo saṅgahito”ti ca ādīsu🔽sīlādivācako diṭṭhoti? Na, tatthāpi adhikārādivacchedakavasenevassa sīlādīsu pavattidassanato.
analyzed: na kho āvuso visākha tīhi khandhehi ariyaḥ aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ maggo saṅgahitaḥ iti ca ādīsu  sīla ādi vācakaḥ diṭṭhaḥ ti na tattha api adhikāra ādi vacchedaka vasena iva assa sīla ādīsu pavatti dassanato
translated: it is said: “The noble eightfold path is not included in the three aggregates, friend Visākha.”🔽But isn’t the word “aggregate” also seen to denote virtue, etc., in such passages as: “The brahmin is one who praises the three aggregates,🔽the brahmin is one who praises the three aggregates, the brahmin is one who praises the three aggregates”?🔽No. Even there the word “aggregate” is used in reference to virtue, etc., only by way of the distinction of function, etc.

original: Na khandhasaddo paññattisaddassa atthe vattatīti niruttivohārādisaddā viya paññattipariyāyo
analyzed: na khandha saddo paññatti saddassa atthe vattati iti nirutti vohāra ādi saddāḥ viya paññatti pariyāyo
translated: The word “aggregate” does not denote the meaning of the word “concept.” Like the words “convention,” “usage,” etc., it is a mode of expression.

original: na hotīti attho. Dārukkhandhoti paññatti hotīti tassa khandhasaddassa paññattivisesappavattitaṃ🔽dasseti. Viññāṇakkhandhoti khandhasaddoti “viññāṇaṃ viññāṇakkhandho”ti ettha vutto🔽khandhasaddo. Samudāye niruḷhoti atītādibhedabhinnassa paññāya abhisaṃyūhanena rāsikate🔽viññāṇasamūhe niruḷho. Tāya eva ruḷhiyā pavattatīti tāya samudāye niruḷhatāya tadavayave
analyzed: na hoti iti atthaḥ dāru kkhandho ti paññatti hoti iti tassa khandha saddassa paññatti visesa ppavatti tat  dasseti viññāṇa kkhandho ti khandha saddo ti viññāṇam viññāṇa kkhandho ti ettha vutto  khandha saddo samudāye niruḷhaḥ ti atīta ādi bheda bhinnassa paññāya abhisaṃyūhanena  viññāṇa samūhe niruḷhaḥ tāya eva ruḷhiyā pavattati iti tāya samudāye niruḷha tāya tad avayave
translated: the meaning is, it is not.
