The word “aggregate” is used figuratively in the sense of a collection, as in the expression “a forest of trees” .🔽The word “aggregate” in the passage “the consciousness aggregate” is the word “aggregate” .🔽It is used figuratively in the sense of a collection, in the sense of a mass of consciousnesses distinguished by pastness, etc., by being brought together under the concept “consciousness.”🔽It occurs by that very usage, by that very figurative use in the sense of a collection. It occurs in the individual members of the collection,

original: ekasmimpi viññāṇe pavattatīti. Ettha ca ñāṇasampayutte niruḷho kosallasambhūtaṭṭhena🔽kusalabhāvo viya ñāṇavippayutte viññāṇasamudāye niruḷho tadekadesepi ruḷhiyā pavattatīti🔽veditabbaṃ. Atha vā kiñci nimittaṃ gahetvā satipi aññasmiṃ tannimittayutte kismiñcideva
analyzed: ekasmim pi viññāṇe pavattati iti ettha ca ñāṇa sampayutte niruḷhaḥ kosalla sambhūta ṭṭhena 🔽kusala bhāvaḥ viya ñāṇa vippayutte viññāṇa samudāye niruḷho tad eka dese pi ruḷhiyā pavattati iti 🔽veditabbam atha vā kiñci nimittam gahetvā satipi aññasmin tad nimitta yutte kismiṃcid eva
translated: The meaning is that it is not. The word “aggregate” in the phrase “the aggregate of consciousness” is a word that is used in the sense of a collection. It is used in the sense of a collection in the way that the word “bundle” is used in the sense of a collection of sticks. It is used in the sense of a collection in the way that the word “bundle” is used in the sense of a collection of sticks. It is used in the sense of a collection in the way that the word “bundle” is used in the sense of a collection of sticks. The word “

original: visaye sammutiyā cirakālatāvasena nimittavirahepi pavatti ruḷhi nāma, yathā mahiyaṃ
analyzed: visaye sammutiyā cira kāla tā vasena nimitta virahe pi pavatti ruḷhi nāma yathā mahiyam
translated: The occurrence of a usage even in the absence of a reason for it by virtue of the length of time during which it has been current in a given area is what is called “established usage,” as in the case of the word mahiyaṃ.

original: setīti mahiṃso, gacchantīti gāvoti, evaṃ khandhasaddassāpi ruḷhibhāvo veditabbo.
analyzed: seti iti mahiṃsaḥ gacchanti iti gāvaḥ ti evam khandha saddassa api ruḷhi bhāvaḥ veditabbo
translated: The occurrence of the term “aggregate” even in the absence of a reason for it, by virtue of the long-standing usage of the term in reference to the objective fields, is called “conventional usage,” as in the case of the words “mahiṃsa” and “gāvo.”🔽The conventional usage of the term “aggregate” should be understood in the same way.

original: Rāsito guṇatoti sabbattha bhummatthe vā nissakkavacanaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Niyametvāti vavatthapetvā.
analyzed: rāsitaḥ guṇato ti sabbattha bhummatthe vā nissakka vacanam daṭṭhabbam niyametvā iti vavatthapetvā
translated: “As a collection and as a quality” should be understood as a locative of place. “Having defined” means having delimited.

original: Piṇḍaṭṭhoti saṅghātattho. Tasmāti yasmā pañceva khandhā vuttā, koṭṭhāsaṭṭhe ca khandhaṭṭhe
analyzed: piṇḍa ṭṭho ti saṅghāta attho tasmā iti yasmā pañca iva khandhāḥ vuttā koṭṭhāsa aṭṭhe ca khandha aṭṭhe
translated: “The meaning of a heap” is the meaning of a collection. Therefore, since only five aggregates are mentioned, and since the meaning of an aggregate is the meaning of a heap,

original: nibbānassa vasena chaṭṭhenāpi khandhena bhavitabbaṃ, tasmā khandhaṭṭho nāma rāsaṭṭhoti
analyzed: nibbānassa vasena chaṭṭhena api khandhena bhavitabbam tasmā khandhaṭṭhaḥ nāma rāsaṭṭhaḥ ti
translated: the sixth aggregate must be the Nibbāna element. Therefore, the meaning of an aggregate is the meaning of a collection.

original: yuttaṃ. “Yesaṃ vā atītādivasena bhedo atthī”tiādinā atītādivibhāgabhinnesu ruppanādisabhāvadhammesu
analyzed: yuttam yesam vā atīta ādi vasena bhedaḥ atthi iti ādinā atīta ādi vibhāga bhinnesu ruppana ādi sabhāva dhammesu
translated: “Or else, those that are distinguished by way of the past, etc.” The aggregates are distinguished by way of the past, etc., in the sense of the states of materiality, etc., that occur in the past, etc.

original: visuṃ visuṃ koṭṭhāsabhāvena gayhamānesu tabbibhāgarahitassa ekassa nibbānassa rāsaṭṭhatā
analyzed: visum visum koṭṭhāsa bhāvena gayhamānesu tad vibhāga rahitassa ekassa nibbānassa rāsaṭṭha tā
translated: The Nibbāna element, which is devoid of that distinction, is a collection of the aggregates.

original: viya koṭṭhāsaṭṭhatāpi na sambhavatīti dasseti. Etena paññattiyāpi khandhesu aggahaṇe
analyzed: viya koṭṭhāsaṭṭha tā api na sambhavati iti dasseti etena paññattiyā api khandhesu aggahaṇe
translated: and so the state of being a part is not possible.🔽By this he shows that the aggregates are not mentioned in the description of the world of beings.

original: kāraṇaṃ vuttanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: kāraṇam vuttan ti veditabbam
translated: and so the division into six sections is impossible. By this it should be understood that the reason for not including the concepts in the aggregates is stated.

original: Kasmā panettha phassādike viya saṅkhārakkhandhe anavarodhetvā vedanāsaññā visuṃ khandhabhāvena
analyzed: kasmā pana ittha phassa ādike viya saṅkhāra kkhandhe an avarodhetvā vedanā saññā visum khandha bhāvena
translated: Why are feeling and perception included as separate aggregates here, without being subsumed under the formations aggregate like contact, etc.?

original: gahitāti? Vivādamūlatādivisesadassanatthaṃ. Gahaṭṭhānañhi vivādakāraṇaṃ kāmajjhosānaṃ.🔽Vuttañcetaṃ “puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, kāmahetu kāmanidānaṃ kāmādhikaraṇaṃ kāmānameva
analyzed: gahitā ti vivāda mūla tā ādi visesa dassana attham gaha ṭṭhānam hi vivāda kāraṇam kāma ajjhosānam  vuttam ca itam puna ca param bhikkhave kāma hetu kāma nidānam kāma adhikaraṇam kāmānam eva
translated: In order to show the difference in their being the roots of dispute, etc. For the cause of dispute is the pursuit of sense desires.

original: hetu mātāpi puttena vivadati, puttopi mātarā vivadatī”tiādi. Pabbajitānaṃ diṭṭhābhiniveso.
analyzed: hetu mātā api puttena vivadati puttaḥ api mātarā vivadati itiādi pabbajitānam diṭṭha abhiniveso
translated: And this is said: “Again, bhikkhus, it is for the sake of sensual pleasures, for the sake of desires, because of desires, that a mother and father are disputed about by their children” , and so on.🔽And the adherence to views of those who have gone forth is the cause of dispute.

original: Vuttampi cetaṃ “ye diṭṭhimuggayha vivādayanti, ‘idameva sacca’nti ca vādayantī”tiādi.
analyzed: vuttam pi ca itam ye diṭṭhim uggayha vivādayanti idam eva saccanti ca vādayanti itiādi
translated: And this is said: “Those who dispute, taking up views, saying ‘Only this is the truth’ ” , and so on.

original: Tesu kāmajjhosānaṃ vedanassādena hoti, diṭṭhābhiniveso saññāvipallāsena. Saññāvipallāsena
analyzed: tesu kāma ajjhosānam vedanā ssādena hoti diṭṭha abhinivesaḥ saññā vipallāsena saññā vipallāsena
translated: Among these, the pursuit of sense desires is due to the gratification of feeling, and the adherence to views is due to the perversion of perception.

original: hi cittavipallāso, cittavipallāsena diṭṭhimānataṇhāpapañcānaṃ vipallāsoti. Tathā🔽vedanānugiddho vipallatthasañño ca saṃsarati. Vedanānugiddhassa hi vedanāpaccayā
analyzed: hi citta vipallāso citta vipallāsena vipallāso ti tathā  vedanā anugiddhaḥ vipallattha sañño ca saṃsarati vedanā anugiddhassa hi vedanā paccayā
translated: For the perversion of view and the perversions of craving and conceit are due to the perversion of consciousness.

original: taṇhā siddhā hoti, tato ca taṇhāpaccayā upādānanti āvaṭṭati bhavacakkaṃ. Vipallatthasaññissa
analyzed: taṇhā siddhā hoti tatas ca taṇhā paccayā upādānam ti āvaṭṭati bhava cakkam vipallattha saññissa
translated: And he who is infatuated with feeling and has perverted perception wanders in the cycle of rebirths. For when one is infatuated with feeling, craving is established in him with feeling as its condition, and from that craving, assuming is established with craving as its condition. Thus the wheel of becoming revolves.

original: ca “saññānidānā hi papañcasaṅkhā”ti vacanato diṭṭhimānataṇhāpapañcānaṃ anupacchedato🔽saṃsārassa anupacchedova. Iti vivādakāraṇānaṃ kāmajjhosānadiṭṭhābhinivesānaṃ kāraṇabhāvo🔽saṃsārahetubhāvoti imassa vivādamūlatādivisesassa dassanatthaṃ saṅkhārakkhandhe anavarodhetvā
analyzed: ca saññā nidānāḥ hi papañca saṅkhā ati vacanataḥ diṭṭhi māna taṇhā papañcānam an upacchedato  iti vivāda kāraṇānam kāma ajjhosāna diṭṭha abhinivesānam kāraṇa bhāvaḥ  saṃsāra hetu bhāvaḥ ti imassa vivāda mūla tā ādi visesassa dassana ttham saṅkhāra kkhandhe an avarodhetvā
translated: And for one who has perverted perception, the perversions of view, craving, and conceit are not severed, since it is said: “With perception as condition, the manifoldness of conceptualization” .🔽Thus the cycle of rebirths is not severed.

original: vedanāsaññā visuṃ khandhabhāvena gahitāti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: vedanā saññā visum khandha bhāvena gahitā ati veditabbam
translated: So in order to show the distinction that the perversions of view, craving, and conceit are the cause of the reasons for dispute, namely, sensual lust, etc., and are the root of dispute, etc., the aggregates of feeling and perception are taken separately as aggregates without being included in the formations aggregate.

original: Okāsesūti vibhajanakiriyāya pavattiṭṭhānabhāvato atītādayo okāsāti vuttā. Itisaddenāti
analyzed: okāsesu iti vibhajana kiriyāya pavatti ṭṭhāna bhāvataḥ atīta ādayaḥ okāsa ati vuttāḥ iti saddena ati
translated: In the passages: “In the seen there is only the seen” , etc., the past, etc., are called “passages” because they are the bases for the act of discerning.

original: “upādāyarūpa”nti evaṃ aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttaitisaddena. Nidassanatthenāti udāharaṇatthena.
analyzed: upādāya rūpan ti evam aṭṭhakathā ayam vutta eti saddena nidassana atthena ati udāharaṇa atthena
translated: “As an instance”: as an example.

original: Sabboti sakalo ekādasasu okāsesu vibhatto vibhajananayo. Idañca vibhajananti “cattāro
analyzed: sabbaḥ ti sakalaḥ ekādasasu okāsesu vibhattaḥ vibhajana nayaḥ idam ca vibhajananti cattāro
translated: “The whole”: the entire method of analysis in the eleven instances.

original: ca mahābhūtā…pe… upādāyarūpa”nti evaṃ vibhattaṃ idañca vibhajanaṃ. Oḷārikādīsūti
analyzed: ca evam vibhattam idam ca vibhajanam oḷārikā ādīsu iti
translated: And this analysis: the analysis stated thus, “The four great entities … and the matter derived by clinging.”🔽“In the gross, etc.,” etc.: in the gross, the subtle, the inferior, the superior, the far, and the near.

original: oḷārikasukhumahīnapaṇītadūrasantikesu. Cakkhāyatanantiādivibhajanañcāti “cakkhāyatanaṃ…pe…
analyzed: oḷārika sukhuma hīna paṇīta dūra santikesu cakkhu āyatana nti ādi vibhajanam ca ati
translated: And the analysis stated thus, “The eye base …

original: phoṭṭhabbāyatanaṃ itthindriyaṃ…pe… kabaḷīkāro āhāro rūpā saddā gandhā rasā phoṭṭhabbāti
analyzed: phoṭṭhabba āyatanam itthi indriyam pe kabaḷīkāraḥ āhāraḥ rūpā saddā gandhā rasā phoṭṭhabbā ti
translated: the tangible-object base … the femininity faculty … the nutriment physical food … visible form, sound, odour, taste, and tangible object”🔽should be applied as appropriate in the eleven instances.

original: evaṃ pavattaṃ vibhajanañca. Yathāsambhavanti yathārahaṃ. Ekādasasu okāsesu yaṃ yattha🔽vibhajanaṃ yuttaṃ, taṃ tattha yojetabbaṃ. Evaṃ vedanākkhandhādīsupīti yathā rūpakkhandhe
analyzed: evam pavattam vibhajanam ca yathāsambhavanti yathāraham ekādasasu okāsesu yam yattha  vibhajanam yuttam tat tattha yojetabbam evam vedanā kkhandha ādīsu pi iti yathā rūpa kkhandhe
translated: In the eleven instances, the analysis should be applied in each case as appropriate.🔽So too with the feeling aggregate, etc.

original: yathāsambhavaṃ ekādasasu okāsesu vibhajanaṃ yojetabbanti vuttaṃ, evaṃ vedanākkhandhādīsupi
analyzed: yathāsambhavam ekādasasu okāsesu vibhajanam yojetabban ti vuttam evam vedanā khandha ādīsu pi
translated: As it was said that the analysis should be applied in the eleven instances as appropriate in the case of the material form aggregate, so too it should be applied in the case of the feeling aggregate, etc.,

original: yathāsambhavaṃ ekādasasu okāsesu vibhajanaṃ yojetabbanti attho.
analyzed: yathāsambhavam ekādasasu okāsesu vibhajanam yojetabbanti attho
translated: The meaning is that the analysis should be applied in the eleven instances as they occur.

original: Tattha vedanākkhandho tāva purime okāsapañcake sukhādivedanāttikavasena vibhatto,
analyzed: tattha vedanā khandho tāva purime okāsa pañcake sukha ādi vedanā ttika vasena vibhatto
translated: Herein, firstly, the feeling aggregate is analyzed in the first five instances by way of the three kinds of feeling beginning with pleasant feeling;🔽in the other instances by way of the three kinds of profitable feeling, the three kinds of feeling, the two kinds of feeling associated with the formed and formless worlds, and the two kinds of feeling associated with what is subject and not subject to cankers.

original: itarasmiṃ kusalattikavedanāttikasamāpannadukasāsavadukavasena. Saññākkhandho pana
analyzed: itarasmin kusala ttika vedanā ttika samāpanna duka sāsava duka vasena saññā kkhandhaḥ pana
translated: The perception aggregate is analyzed

original: purime okāsapañcake chaphassadvāravasena, itarasmiṃ oḷārikaduke paṭighasamphassadukavasena
analyzed: purime okāsa pañcake cha phassa dvāra vasena itarasmim oḷārika duke paṭigha samphassa duka vasena
translated: in the first five instances by way of the six bases of contact, and in the other instances by way of the two kinds of gross feeling, the two kinds of feeling associated with resistance,

original: ceva yathāvuttakusalattikādivasena ca vibhatto. Sesesu kusalattikādivaseneva. Tathā
analyzed: ca iva yathā vutta kusala ttika ādi vasena ca vibhatto sesesu kusala ttika ādi vasena iva tathā
translated: and by way of the three kinds of profitable feeling, etc., as stated. In the rest it is analyzed by way of the three kinds of profitable feeling, etc., only. So too

original: saṅkhārakkhandho. Paṭighasamphassaduko panettha nattheva. Cetanāya eva cettha niddeso
analyzed: saṅkhāra kkhandho paṭigha samphassa duko pana ittha nattha iva cetanāya eva ca ittha niddeso
translated: the formations aggregate. But the two kinds of feeling associated with resistance are not found here. The definition is given only by way of volition

original: saṅkhārakkhandhadhammānaṃ cetanāppadhānabhāvadassanatthaṃ. Tathā hi sā “saṅkhārakkhandho”ti
analyzed: saṅkhāra kkhandha dhammānam cetanā appadhāna bhāva dassana ttham tathā hi sā saṅkhāra kkhandho ti
translated: in order to show that the mental formations aggregate is dominated by volition. For it is said: “The mental formations aggregate is volition” .

original: vuttā. Tatthāti tasmiṃ viññāṇakkhandhassa vibhajane paṭiniddese. Taṃ pana dvayanti
analyzed: vuttā tattha ati tasmin viññāṇa kkhandhassa vibhajane paṭiniddese tam pana
translated: Therein: in the analysis, the definition, of the consciousness aggregate. That is twofold:

original: manodhātumanoviññāṇadhātudvayaṃ. Yañhi sattaviññāṇadhātudesanāyaṃ “manodhātu, manoviññāṇadhātū”ti
analyzed: manaḥ dhātu manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu dvayam yat hi satta viññāṇa dhātu desanā ayam manaḥ dhātu manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu uti
translated: The two, the mind element and the mind-consciousness element. For in the teaching of the seven consciousness elements, the mind element and the mind-consciousness element are given as follows:

original: dvayaṃ desitaṃ, taṃ chaviññāṇakāyadesanāyaṃ “manoviññāṇa”ntveva vuccatīti.
analyzed: dvayam desitam tam cha viññāṇa kāya desanā ayam manaḥ viññāṇam tu eva vuccati iti
translated: The two, the mind element and the mind-consciousness element. For the two, the mind element and the mind-consciousness element, which are taught in this Thread as the seven consciousness elements, are called “mind-consciousness” in the teaching of the six bodies of consciousness.

original: Pāḷinayenāti khandhavibhaṅgapāḷinayena. Aññena pakārenāti dhammasaṅgahe, tadaṭṭhakathāyañca āgatena pakārantarena.
analyzed: pāḷi nayena ati khandha vibhaṅga pāḷi nayena aññena pakārena ati dhamma saṅgahe tad aṭṭhakathāyan ca āgatena pakāra antarena
translated: By the phrasing of the text: by the phrasing of the text in the Description of the Categories. By another method: by the method stated in the Schedule of Ideas and in the Commentary on that.

original: 1. Rūpakkhandhaniddesavaṇṇanā🔽2. “Kiñcī”ti padaṃ “ekacca”nti iminā samānatthanti āha “kiñcīti pakārantarabhedaṃ🔽āmasitvā aniyamanidassana”nti. Ubhayenāti pakārabhedaṃ anāmasitvā āmasitvā ca aniyamadassanavasena
analyzed: rūpa kkhandha niddesa vaṇṇanā  kiñci iti padam ekaccanti iminā samāna tthanti āha kiñci iti pakāra antara bhedam  ubhayena ati pakāra bhedam an āmasitvā āmasitvā ca aniyama dassana vasena
translated: Description of the Materiality Category🔽The word “any” is synonymous with “some” , he says. “ By the word ‘any’ he shows non-restriction, taking cognizance of the distinction of another method” .🔽By both: by the two words “any” and “whatever” in the sense of showing non-restriction, without taking cognizance of the distinction of another method and also taking cognizance of it.

original: pavattena “yaṃ kiñcī”ti padadvayena. Adhippetatthanti rūpaṃ. Aticcāti atikkamitvā.
analyzed: pavattena yam kiñci iti pada dvayena rūpam aticca ati atikkamitvā
translated: The intended meaning: materiality. Beyond: having surpassed.

original: Pavattitoti pavattanato. Niyamanatthanti nivattanatthaṃ.
analyzed: pavattitaḥ ti pavattanataḥ niyamana attham ti nivattana attham
translated: By occurrence: by occurrence. For the sake of restriction: for the sake of restriction.

original: “Kiñcā”ti ettha kiṃ-saddo pucchāyaṃ hetuatthadīpako, karaṇe cetaṃ paccattavacanaṃ,
analyzed: kiñca iti ettha kiṃsaddo pucchā ayam hetu attha dīpako karaṇe ca itam paccattavacanam
translated: “What is that?” Here the word “what” in the sense of “why” is an indicator of cause, and this is a reflexive pronoun in the instrumental case.

original: ca-saddo vacanālaṅkāroti āha “kena kāraṇena vadethā”ti. Dutiyavikappe pana vuttanayeneva
analyzed: casaddaḥ vacana alaṅkāraḥ iti āha kena kāraṇena vadetha ati dutiya vikappe pana vutta nayena iva
translated: The word “ca” is an ornament of speech. Therefore he said: “For what reason do you say?” But in the second analysis, in the same way as stated,

original: kāraṇatthe pavattaṃ kiṃ-saddaṃ “vadethā”ti kiriyāpadasambandhanena upayogavasena
analyzed: kāraṇa atthe pavattam kiṃsaddam vadetha iti kiriyā pada sambandhanena upayoga vasena
translated: he changes the word “what” which occurs in the sense of cause, by the method of utility in connection with the verbal noun “say”,

original: pariṇāmetvā vadati “taṃ kāraṇaṃ vadethā”ti.🔽Purimasantānassa bhedanti purimasantānassa vināsaṃ, vināsāpadesena cettha santāne
analyzed: vadati tam kāraṇam vadetha iti  purima santānassa purima santānassa vināsam vināsa apadesena ca ittha santāne
translated: and says: “Say that reason.”

original: visadisuppādameva dasseti. Tenevāha “visadisasantānuppattidassanato”ti. Nanu ca arūpadhammānampi
analyzed: visadisa uppādam eva dasseti tena iva āha visadisa santa anuppatti dassanato ti nanu ca arūpa dhammānam pi
translated: The destruction of the previous continuum: the destruction of the previous continuum, the disappearance of the previous continuum. Here, by the expression “disappearance”, he shows the arising of something different in the continuum. Therefore he said: “Because it shows the arising of a different continuum.” But is there not the arising of something different in the case of immaterial dhammas

original: virodhipaccayasamavāye visadisuppatti atthīti? Saccaṃ atthi, sā pana na pākaṭatarā,
analyzed: virodhi paccaya samavāye atthi iti saccam atthi sā pana na pākaṭatarā
translated: when there is the concurrence of opposing conditions? It is true that there is, but that is not so obvious,

original: pākaṭatarā ca idhādhippetā. Tenevāha “sītādisannipāte”ti. Tathā cāha bhagavā “sītenapi
analyzed: pākaṭatarā ca idha adhippetā tena iva āha sītā ādi sannipāta iti tathā ca āha bhagavā sītena api
translated: and what is obvious is intended here. Therefore he said: “When there is the concurrence of cold, etc.” And the Blessed One said: “When there is the concurrence of cold and heat, of hunger and thirst, of flies and mosquitoes, of the wind and the sun, of creeping things and serpents, the body is affected with suffering.

original: ruppati, uṇhenapi ruppatī”tiādi. Idāni bheda-saddo ujukameva vikārāpattiṃ vadatīti
analyzed: ruppati uṇhena api ruppati itiādi idāni bheda saddaḥ ujukam eva vikāra āpattim vadati iti
translated: and it is heated by heat.” Now, the word “change” denotes only the occurrence of a modification.

original: dassento “bhedo cā”tiādimāha. Visadisarūpuppattiyeva, na uppannassa aññathābhāvoti🔽adhippāyo. Tena kāpiliyaṃ pariṇāmavādaṃ paṭikkhipati. Yadi purimasantānato bhedo🔽visadisuppatti ruppanaṃ, evaṃ sante lakkhaṇassa atippasaṅgo siyāti codanaṃ manasi
analyzed: dassentaḥ bhedaḥ ca atiādim āha visadisa rūpa uppattiyā iva na uppannassa aññathābhāvaḥ ti  adhippāyaḥ tena kāpiliyam pariṇāma vādam paṭikkhipati yadi purima santānataḥ bhedaḥ  visadisuppatti ruppanam evam sante lakkhaṇassa atippasaṅgaḥ siyā ti codanam manasi
translated: To show this he says “and change” . The intention is that there is only the occurrence of a different visible form, not the alteration of what has already occurred.🔽Thus he rejects the theory of the Kāpilas that there is transformation . If change is the occurrence of a different visible form, the alteration of what has already occurred, then the characteristic of alteration is too wide.

original: katvā āha “arūpakkhandhāna”ntiādi. Ettha sītādīhīti ādi-saddena yathā uṇhajighacchādayo
analyzed: katvā āha ettha sīta ādīhi iti ādi saddena yathā uṇha jighaccha ādayaḥ
translated: Having considered this objection, he says “of the immaterial aggregates” , etc. Here, by the word “and so on” , the inclusion of heat, hunger, etc., is to be understood in the same way as cold, etc., are included.

original: saṅgayhanti, evaṃ āhārādīnampi saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo. Yenāti yena sītādīhi samāgamena.
analyzed: evam āhāra ādīnam pi saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ yena ati yena sītā ādīhi samāgamena
translated: Likewise the inclusion of nutriment, etc., should be understood. By the word “by” , the meaning of “by the contact of” is to be understood.

original: Tatthāti tesu rūpadhammesu. Āhārādikassa vā ṭhitippattassāti sambandho. Yathā rūpadhammānaṃ
analyzed: tattha ati tesu rūpa dhammesu āhāra ādikassa vā ṭhiti pattassa ati sambandhaḥ yathā rūpa dhammānam
translated: In the phrase “in those” , the meaning of “in those visible forms” is to be understood. Or the construction may be: “of the nutriment, etc., that has reached presence.”

original: ṭhitikkhaṇe sītādīhi samāgamo hoti, evaṃ arūpakkhandhānaṃ aññehi samāgamo natthi
analyzed: ṭhiti kkhaṇe sītā ādīhi samāgamaḥ hoti evam arūpa kkhandhānam aññehi samāgamaḥ natthi
translated: Just as there is contact with cold, etc., at the moment of presence of visible forms, so there is no contact with others in the case of the immaterial aggregates.

original: atilahuparivattito, tasmā arūpadhammā rūpadhammānaṃ viya pākaṭassa vikārassa abhāvato
analyzed: ati lahu parivattitaḥ tasmai arūpa dhammāḥ rūpa dhammānam viya pākaṭassa vikārassa abhāvato
translated: because they are not easily affected by change,

original: “ruppantī”ti, “ruppanalakkhaṇā”ti ca na vuccantīti sambandho. “Ruppatī”ti padassa
analyzed: ruppanti iti ruppana lakkhaṇā ati ca na vuccanti iti sambandhaḥ ruppati iti padassa
translated: therefore they are not called “ruppa” or “having the characteristic of ruppana” because they do not have the obvious change of the material dhammas.

original: kattukammasādhanānaṃ vasena atthaṃ dassetuṃ aṭṭhakathāyaṃ “kuppati ghaṭṭīyati pīḷīyati
analyzed: kattu kamma sādhanānam vasena attham dassetum aṭṭhakathāyam kuppati ghaṭṭīyati pīḷīyati
translated: In order to show the meaning of the word “ruppati” by way of the accomplishment of the doing and the doing itself, it is said in the Commentary: “It is broken, it is struck, it is pressed,

original: bhijjatī”ti vuttanti tadatthaṃ vivaranto “kuppatīti etenā”tiādimāha. Kopādikiriyāti
analyzed: bhijjati iti vuttanti tad attham vivarantaḥ kuppati iti etena atiādim āha kopa ādi kiriyā iti
translated: it is split.” Explaining that meaning, he says: “By ‘it is broken’ and so on.” The doing of breaking and so on,

original: kopasaṅghaṭṭanapīḷanakiriyā. Kopa-saddo cettha khobhapariyāyo veditabbo. Kattubhūto
analyzed: kopa saṅghaṭṭana pīḷana kiriyā kopa saddo ca ittha khobha pariyāyaḥ veditabbo kattu bhūto
translated: the doing of breaking, striking, and pressing. The word “kopa” should be understood here as synonymous with “khobhana.” The meaning,

original: kammabhūto ca atthoti kattukammasādhanānaṃ vasena vuccamāno bhūtupādāyarūpasaṅkhāto🔽attho. Kammakattutthena bhijjati-saddenāti yadā kammakattuttho ruppati-saddo, tadā
analyzed: kamma bhūtaḥ ca atthaḥ ti kattu kamma sādhanānam vasena vuccamānaḥ bhūta upādāya rūpa saṅkhātaḥ  atthaḥ kamma kattutthena bhijjati saddena ati yadā kamma kattutthaḥ tadā
translated: which is called “materiality consisting of the four great essentials and the materiality derived from the four great essentials,” is said by way of the accomplishment of the doing and the doing itself.🔽When the word “ruppati” is in the sense of the doing, then the word “bhijjati” should be understood to have the same meaning.

original: bhijjati-saddopi tadattho eva veditabboti attho. Tattha yadā kammatthe “ruppatī”ti
analyzed: bhijjati saddaḥ api tad atthaḥ eva veditabbaḥ iti attho tattha yadā kammatthe ruppati iti
translated: There, when “ruppati” is in the sense of the doing,

original: padaṃ, tadā “sītenā”tiādīsu kattuatthe karaṇavacanaṃ. Yadā pana “ruppatī”ti padaṃ
analyzed: padam tadā sītena ati ādīsu kattu atthe karaṇa vacanam yadā pana ruppati iti padam
translated: When the word “is heated” is used in the sense of an agent, then the instrumental case is used in the sense of an instrument in such passages as “by cold.”

original: kattuatthe kammakattuatthe vā, tadā hetumhi karaṇavacanaṃ veditabbaṃ. “Yaṃ pana ruppatī”tiādinā
analyzed: kattu atthe kamma kattu atthe vā tadā hetumhi karaṇa vacanam veditabbam yam pana ruppati iti ādinā
translated: But when the word “is heated” is used in the sense of an agent or in the sense of an object of an agent, then the instrumental case should be understood in the sense of a reason. In the passage beginning “But what is heated … ”

original: “kuppatī”tiādīnaṃ kattukammatthānampi atthavacanānaṃ vacane kāraṇaṃ dasseti. Yadipi
analyzed: kuppati iti ādīnam kattu kammatthānam pi attha vacanānam vacane kāraṇam dasseti yadi pi
translated: he shows the reason for using the words “is heated” and so on, which have the sense of an object of an agent, in the sense of an object.🔽Although the word “meaning” is a synonym for an individual essence in such passages as “the meaning of affliction” ,

original: attha-saddo “pīḷanaṭṭho”tiādīsu sabhāvapariyāyopi hoti, “kenaṭṭhenā”ti panettha abhidheyyapariyāyo
analyzed: attha saddo pīḷana ṭṭho ti ādīsu sabhāva pariyāyaḥ api hoti kenaṭṭhena ati pana ittha abhidheyya pariyāyaḥ
translated: here the intended meaning is a synonym for a name.

original: adhippetoti āha “kenaṭṭhenāti pucchāsabhāgavasena ruppanaṭṭhenā”ti, ruppanasaddābhidheyyabhāvenāti
analyzed: adhippetaḥ iti āha kena aṭṭhena āti pucchā sabhāga vasena ruppana ṭṭhena āti ruppana sadda abhidheyya bhāvena ati
translated: Therefore he says, “By what meaning? By the meaning of being heated, as if it were a question.” The meaning is: by the fact of being the name of the word “being heated.”🔽Therefore he says, “It is not only the meaning of the word that is being heated.”

original: attho. Tenevāha “na kevalaṃ saddatthoyeva ruppana”nti. Tassa atthassāti tassa bhūtupādāyappabhedassa
analyzed: tena iva āha na kevalam tassa atthassa ati tassa bhūta upādāya ppabhedassa
translated: The meaning of that is the meaning of the individual essence of the primary elements and the derivatives.

original: sabhāvadhammassa. Ruppanalakkhaṇañca nāmetaṃ aniccatādi viya kakkhaḷattādito aññanti
analyzed: sabhāva dhammassa ruppana lakkhaṇam ca nāma etam anicca tā ādi viya kakkhaḷa ttā āditaḥ
translated: And this is characterized by being heated, like impermanence and so on, and is different from hardness and so on.

original: na gahetabbaṃ. Paññattiviseso hi tanti, kakkhaḷattādīnaṃyeva pana arūpadhammavidhuro
analyzed: na gahetabbam paññatti visesaḥ hi tanti kakkhaḷa tta ādīnam yeva pana arūpa dhamma vidhuraḥ
translated: It should not be taken. For the difference in the definition is only a difference in the mode of occurrence of the material states consisting of hardness, etc.,

original: sabhāvavisesoti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: sabhāva visesaḥ ti veditabbam
translated: which is called a difference in individual essence.

original: Mucchāpattiyāti mucchāya mohassa āpajjanena. Kappasaṇṭhānaṃ udakanti kappasaṇṭhāpakamahāmeghavuṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: mucchā āpattiyā ti mucchāya mohassa āpajjanena kappa saṇṭhānam udakanti kappa saṇṭhāpaka mahā megha vuṭṭham
translated: By the occurrence of delusion: by the arising of delusion, of confusion. The water that is the receptacle of the earth: the water that is the great receptacle of the earth, which is the source of the great cloud.

original: udakaṃ. Tathāti tappakāratāya khārabhāve sati udakena kappavuṭṭhānakāle viya pathavī🔽vilīyeyya. Lokantariyasattānaṃ pana pāpakammabalena akhārepi khāre viya sarīrassa🔽vilīyanā veditabbā. Tenevāti saussadanissayanirayassa vuttattā eva. Na hi avīcimhi
analyzed: udakam tathā iti tad pakāra tāya khāra bhāve sati udakena kappa vuṭṭhāna kāle pathavī  vilīyeyya lokantariya sattānam pana pāpa kamma balena a khāre pi khāre viya sarīrassa  vilīyanā veditabbā tena iva ati saussada nissaya nirayassa vuttattā eva na hi avīcimhi
translated: If the earth were to have the nature of hardness, etc., as it does at the present time, it would melt away like water at the time of the great dissolution.🔽But the melting away of the bodies of the beings in the nether world should be understood to be due to the power of their evil kamma, as if it were due to the contact of fire.

original: pañcavidhabandhanādikammakāraṇaṃ karonti.
analyzed: pañcavidha bandhana ādi kamma kāraṇam karonti
translated: Therefore: because the hell of the burning embers was mentioned. For in the Avīci hell they do not perform the fivefold act of binding, etc.

original: 3. Pakaraṇappattaṃ rūpaṃ pakkhipitvā mātikā ṭhapitāti ānetvā sambandho. Mahābhūtu…pe…
analyzed: pakaraṇa pattam rūpam pakkhipitvā mātikā ṭhapitā ati ānetvā sambandhaḥ mahābhūta upe
translated: The order of the material states is given in the text by the words “the great primaries, etc.”

original: āpajjati tappakārabhāvena atītaṃse gaṇanaṃ gatanti vuttattāti adhippāyo. “Na hī”tiādinā
analyzed: āpajjati tad pakāra bhāvena atīta aṃse gaṇanam gatanti vutta ttā ti adhippāyaḥ na hi iti ādinā
translated: The intention is this: “For it is said that the past is reckoned by the mode of hardness, etc.”

original: dhammantaranivattanatthatā pakārantaranivattanatthatā ca bhūtupādāyagahaṇassa natthīti
analyzed: dhamma antara nivattana tā pakāra antara nivattana tā ca bhūta upādāya gahaṇassa natthi iti
translated: and the meaning of the inclusion of the primaries and the derived matter is shown to be not the meaning of the inclusion of other states and of other aggregates.

original: dasseti. Taṃdassaneti gaṇanantaradassane. Taṃsabhāvattāti bhūtupādāyasabhāvattā.
analyzed: dasseti tat dassanā iti gaṇa nantara dassane bhūta upādāya sabhāvattā
translated: In the words “in the demonstration of the counting” the demonstration is the showing. In the words “in the same individual essence” the individual essence is the individual nature.

original: “Na cā”tiādinā bhūtupādāyasabhāvo atītaṃsagaṇitatāya taṃsabhāvassapi aññathā gaṇitattā,🔽ataṃsabhāvassa ca tathā gaṇitattā akāraṇanti dasseti. “Ajjhatta…pe… labbhatī”ti etena
analyzed: na ca ati ādinā bhūta upādāyasa bhāvaḥ atī taṃsa gaṇita tāya taṃsa bhāvassa api aññathā gaṇita ttā  ataṃsa bhāvassa ca tathā gaṇita ttā akāraṇanti dasseti ajjhatta pe labbhati iti etena
translated: In the words “and it is not” he shows that the individual nature of the primaries and the derived matter is not the reason because it is counted in the past aggregate, and because the non-individual nature is counted in the same way.

original: dutiyanaye na kevalaṃ yathāvuttova doso, atha kho abyāpitopi dosoti dasseti. Tadetaṃ
analyzed: dutiya naye na kevalam yathā vuttaḥ uva doso atha kho abyāpitaḥ api doso ti dasseti tat etam
translated: In the words “is found in the internal” he shows that in the second method not only is there the fault stated in the first method, but also the fault of non-pervasion.

original: pana akāraṇaṃ kāraṇabhāvasseva anadhippetattā. Na hettha bhūtupādāyarūpabhāvo atītaṃse🔽gaṇanassa kāraṇanti adhippetaṃ, yato yathāvuttadosāpatti siyā.
analyzed: pana akāraṇam kāraṇa bhāvassa iva an adhippeta ttā na ha ittha bhūta upādāya rūpa bhāvaḥ  gaṇanassa kāraṇanti adhippetam yatas yathāvutta dosa āpatti siyā
translated: But this is not a reason because the state of being a primary or a derived materiality is not intended as the reason for the counting in the past aggregate.

original: “Kintī”ti ettha “ki”nti pubbe yaṃ “rūpa”nti sāmaññato gahitaṃ, tassa sarūpapucchā.
analyzed: kinti iti ettha kinti pubbe yam rūpanti sāmaññataḥ gahitam tassa sarūpa pucchā
translated: In the words “What then?” the “what” is a question about the matter that was stated in the first method in the general sense as “matter.”

original: Iti-saddo nidassanattho, na kāraṇattho. Tenassa yaṃ rūpaṃ atītaṃ niruddhaṃ…pe… atītaṃsena
analyzed: iti saddaḥ nidassana atthaḥ na kāraṇa atthaḥ tena assa yat rūpam atītam atīta sena
translated: The word “so” has the meaning of “thus” and not the meaning of “because.” Therefore, “the form that is past, ceased, changed” is the meaning of “the form that is past.”🔽🔽

original: saṅgahitaṃ atītakoṭṭhāse gaṇanaṃ gataṃ, taṃ kinti ce? “Cattāro ca…pe… rūpa”nti bhūtupādāyavibhāgadassanamukhena
analyzed: saṅgahitam atīta koṭṭhāse gaṇanam gatam tam kinti ce cattāro bhūta upādāya vibhāga dassana mukhena
translated: The word “iti” is for the purpose of showing, not for the purpose of giving a reason. Therefore, what is the form that is past, ceased, … and is included in the past section and counted in the past? “Four great elements and the form derived from the great elements.”

original: visesaṃ nidasseti. Yattakā hi idha visesā niddiṭṭhā cakkhāyatanādayo, tesamidaṃ nidassananti.
analyzed: visesam nidasseti yattakāḥ hi idha visesāḥ niddiṭṭhā cakkha āyatana ādayo tesam idam nidassananti
translated: By the method of showing the analysis of the primary elements and the derived form, he shows the distinction. For whatever distinctions are shown here, such as the eye base, etc., this is their showing.

original: Na cettha purimanayato aviseso. Tattha hi rūpassa bhūtupādāyatāmattasabhāvadassanatā🔽vuttā. Tenāha aṭṭhakathāyaṃ “atītarūpampi bhūtāni cevā”tiādi. Idha pana bhūtupādāyena
analyzed: na ca ittha purima nayataḥ avisesaḥ tattha hi rūpassa bhūta upādāyatā matta sabhāva dassana tā  vuttā tena āha aṭṭhakathā ayam atīta rūpam pi bhūtāni ca iva atiādi idha pana bhūta upādāyena
translated: But there is no difference here from the previous method. For there it was said that the nature of form is merely the primary elements and the derived form.

original: nidassanabhūtena rūpassa sabbavisesavibhāvanatā dassitā. Evañca katvā abyāpitadosopi
analyzed: nidassana bhūtena rūpassa sabba visesa vibhāvana tā dassitā evam ca katvā abyāpita dosaḥ api
translated: Therefore it is said in the commentary: “Past form is the primary elements and the derived form, etc.” But here, by the showing of the primary elements and the derived form, the distinction of all form is shown. And when it is done in this way,

original: cettha anokāsova, yaṃ rūpaṃ ajjhattaṃ…pe… upādinnaṃ, kinti? Cattāro ca…pe… rūpanti
analyzed: yam rūpam upādinnam kinti cattāro
translated: the fault of incompleteness is also impossible here. What is the form that is internal, … and clung to? “Four great elements and the form derived from the great elements.”

original: tadaññavisesanidassanassa adhippetattā. Tathā cāha “evaṃ sabbattha attho veditabbo”ti.
analyzed: tad añña visesa nidassanassa adhippeta ttā tathā ca āha evam sabbattha atthaḥ veditabbaḥ iti
translated: because it is intended to show the difference from the other two. And he says, “The meaning should be understood in this way in all cases.”🔽“By way of teaching in terms of synonyms”: a synonym is a synonym in the sense of a “reverser” , a “turner around” .

original: Pariyāyadesanattāti sabhāvato pariyāyanaṃ parivattanaṃ pariyāyo, ujukaṃ appavattīti
analyzed: pariyāya desanattā ati sabhāvato pariyāyanam parivattanam pariyāyaḥ ujukam appavatti iti
translated: The meaning is that it does not turn around in a straight line.

original: attho. Pariyāyena, pariyāyabhūtā vā desanā etthāti pariyāyadesanaṃ, suttantaṃ. Suttantañhi
analyzed: attho pariyāyena pariyāya bhūtā vā desanā ettha ati pariyāya desanam suttantam suttantam hi
translated: Or the teaching in terms of synonyms is the sutta, since the teaching in terms of synonyms is found here.

original: veneyyajjhāsayavasena desetabbadhamme lesato labbhamānabhāvakathanaṃ, na ujunippadesabhāvakathananti
analyzed: veneyya ajjhāsaya vasena desetabba dhamme lesataḥ labbhamāna bhāva kathanam na uju nippadesa bhāva kathanam ti
translated: For the sutta is a teaching of the way things are found in the sense of the inclinations of those requiring training, not a teaching of the way things are in the sense of the straight meaning.

original: pariyāyadesanaṃ nāma. Teneva taṃ “yathānulomasāsana”nti vuccati. Abhidhammo pana
analyzed: pariyāya desanam nāma tena iva tam yathā anuloma sāsanam ti vuccati abhidhammaḥ pana
translated: Therefore it is called “the teaching in accordance with what is the case” . But the Abhidhamma is a teaching of the way things are in the sense of the straight meaning.🔽Therefore it is called “the teaching in accordance with the True Idea” .

original: desetabbadhamme ujunippadesakathananti nippariyāyadesanaṃ nāma, yato “yathādhammasāsana”nti🔽vuccati. Nicchayena desoti vavatthānato kathanaṃ. Tathā bhaddekarattasuttādīsu viya
analyzed: desetabba dhamme uju nippadesa kathanan ti nippariyāya desanam nāma yatas yathā dhamma sāsanam ti 🔽vuccati nicchayena deso ti vavatthānato kathanam tathā bhaddekaratta sutta ādīsu viya
translated: “By way of teaching in the sense of a definition”: a definition is a teaching by way of a delimitation.

original: atītādibhāvo atītānāgatapaccuppannabhāvo addhāvasena idhāpi khandhavibhaṅge suttantabhājanīyattā
analyzed: atīta ādi bhāvaḥ atīta anāgata paccuppanna bhāvaḥ addhā vasena idha api khandha vibhaṅge suttanta bhājanīya ttā
translated: The past, etc., state is the past, future, and present state. It should be demonstrated here too in the way already stated in the Description of the Aggregates.

original: niddisitabbo siyāti yojanā.
analyzed: niddisitabbaḥ siyā ti yojanā
translated: The meaning is that it should be demonstrated by way of the time periods.🔽“Assembled”: come together. “By continuity”: by the succession of earlier and later.

original: Sannipatitanti samāgataṃ. Santānavasenāti pubbāparavasena. Pubbenāparassa samappamāṇatāya
analyzed: sannipatitam ti samāgatam santāna vasena ati pubba apara vasena pubbena aparassa sama ppamāṇa tāya
translated: It is “not less” and “not more” because the later is the same size as the earlier.

original: anūnaṃ anadhikaṃ, tato eva ekākāraṃ. Pavattikālavasena vā anūnaṃ anadhikaṃ, samānasabhāvatāya🔽ekākāraṃ. Tena visabhāgautunā anantaritataṃ dasseti. Evaṃ āhārepīti ettha visabhāgāhārena🔽anantarito anekavāraṃ anekadivasampi bhutto sabhāgekāhāraṃ nāma. “Tato pubbe visabhāgautuāhārasamuṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: anūnam anadhikam tatas eva eka ākāram pavatti kāla vasena vā anūnam anadhikam samāna sabhāvatāya  eka ākāram tena dasseti evam āhāre pi iti ettha visabhāga āhārena  anantaritaḥ aneka vāram aneka divasam pi bhutto sabhāga ekāhāram nāma tatas pubbe visabhāga otu āhāra samuṭṭhānam
translated: And it is “of one kind” because it is of the same nature. Or alternatively, it is “not less” and “not more” by way of the time of occurrence; and it is “of one kind” because it is of the same nature.🔽This shows that it is not interrupted by dissimilar kinds of nutriment.🔽The same method applies to nutriment derived from gross or fine food.🔽“Not interrupted by dissimilar kinds of nutriment” means that it is not interrupted by nutriment derived from gross or fine food. It is “derived from nutriment” many times, even for many days.🔽“The past is that arisen in the past and disappeared; the future is that which has not yet arisen but will arise in the future without interruption by states of dissimilar type. The present is that arisen and not yet disappeared without interruption by states of dissimilar type.”

original: atītaṃ, pacchā anāgata”nti hi vuttanti. “Ekāhārasamuṭṭhāna”nti pana vuttattā ekasseva
analyzed: atītam pacchā anāgatanti hi vuttanti eka āhāra samuṭṭhānanti pana vuttattā ekassa eva
translated: Others say that the method of explanation by way of one nutriment is more appropriate because it is said, “Derived from one nutriment.”

original: āhārassa yojanā yuttarūpāti apare. Pañcadvāravasenāti ettha pañcadvārāvajjanato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: āhārassa yojanā yutta rūpā ati apare pañca dvāra vasena ati ettha pañca dvāra āvajjanato paṭṭhāya
translated: “By way of the five doors”: beginning with the adverting to the five doors.

original: yāva tadārammaṇaṃ, yāva javanaṃ, yāva vā voṭṭhabbanaṃ, tāva pavattā cittasantati
analyzed: yāva tad ārammaṇam yāva javanam yāva vā voṭṭhabbanam tāva pavattā citta santati
translated: and the process of consciousness goes on for as long as the object impinges, for as long as the impulsion lasts, for as long as the process of consciousness lasts,

original: ekavīthi. Ekajavanasamuṭṭhānanti ekajavanavārasamuṭṭhānaṃ. Ettha ca samayaṃ anāmasitvāva
analyzed: eka vīthi eka javana samuṭṭhānanti eka javana vāra samuṭṭhānam ettha ca samayam
translated: that is called a single cognitive series. And the expression “arisen with a single impulsion” means arisen with a single impulsion-moment. And here the past, etc., should be taken by classing together the process and the series without distinguishing them,

original: santativasena, santatiñca anāmasitvāva samayavasena atītādivibhāgo gahetabbo.
analyzed: santati vasena santatim ca samaya vasena atīta ādi vibhāgaḥ gahetabbaḥ
translated: and by classing together the moment and the series without distinguishing them.

original: Tesanti hetupaccayānaṃ. Kalāpassāti rūpakalāpassa. Kammānantarādīti kammādi, anantarādīti🔽paccekaṃ ādi-saddo yojetabbo. Tattha paṭhamena ādisaddena upanissayapaccayassa āhārādino
analyzed: tesan ti hetu paccayānam kalāpassa ati rūpa kalāpassa kamma anantara ādi iti kamma ādi anantara ādi iti  paccekam ādi saddaḥ yojetabbaḥ tattha paṭhamena ādi saddena upanissaya paccayassa āhāra ādino
translated: “Their” : of the causes and conditions. “The aggregate” : the materiality aggregate. “Kamma-resultant, etc.” : kamma-resultant, etc., and immediately-preceded, etc.🔽The word “etc.” should be construed with each of the two terms. Herein, the first “etc.” includes the decisive-support condition, the nutriment condition, etc.,

original: ca dutiyena samanantarānantarūpanissayādino saṅgaho veditabbo. Cittuppādassa cettha
analyzed: ca dutiyena samanantara ananta rūpa nissaya ādino saṅgahaḥ veditabbo cittuppādassa ca ittha
translated: and the second “etc.” includes the immediately-preceded condition, the prenascence condition, etc. And the generation of consciousness should be construed as kamma-resultant, etc., by way of the conditions that are immediately-preceded, etc.,

original: kammānantarādipaccayavasena, itarassa kammādivaseneva janakabhāve yojanā daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: kamma anantara ādi paccaya vasena itarassa kamma ādi vasena iva janaka bhāve yojanā daṭṭhabbā
translated: and the generation of the other by way of the conditions that are kamma-resultant, etc.🔽And the generation of consciousness should be construed as prenascent, etc., by way of the prenascence condition, etc.,

original: Tathā cittuppādassa purejātavasena, itarassa pacchājātavasena, ubhayesampi sahajātavasena
analyzed: tathā cittuppādassa purejāta vasena itarassa pacchājāta vasena ubhayesam pi sahajāta vasena
translated: and the generation of the other by way of the postnascence condition, etc., and both should be construed by way of the conascence condition, etc.

original: upatthambhanaṃ veditabbaṃ. Tenevāha “yathāsambhavaṃ yojetabba”nti. Uppādakkhaṇeti🔽hetukiccakkhaṇe. Hetukiccaṃ nāma tassa tassa uppādetabbassa uppattikaraṇaṃ, tañca
analyzed: upatthambhanam veditabbam tena iva āha yathāsambhavam yojetabbanti uppāda khaṇa iti  hetu kicca khaṇe hetu kiccam nāma tassa tassa uppādetabbassa uppatti karaṇam tat ca
translated: and the support should be understood. Hence it was said above: “They should be construed as appropriate.”🔽At the moment of arising:

original: tasmiṃ khaṇe uppannaphalattā tato paraṃ kattabbābhāvato niṭṭhitañcāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: tasmin khaṇe uppanna phala ttā tatas param kattabba abhāvataḥ niṭṭhitam ca ati daṭṭhabbam
translated: at the moment of the function of the cause. The function of the cause is the causing of the arising of what is to arise. And that should be regarded as finished because the result has arisen in that moment and there is nothing more to be done after that.

original: Itaraṃ pana tīsupi khaṇesu paccayakiccaṃ daṭṭhabbanti yojanā.
analyzed: itaram pana tīsu pi khaṇesu paccaya kiccam daṭṭhabbanti yojanā
translated: But the function of conditions should be regarded as occurring in all three moments.

original: 6. Aniṭṭhanāmanivattanassāti aniṭṭhanāmanivattiyā akāraṇabhāvadassanena iṭṭhanāmalābhāpanassa akāraṇabhāvaṃ dasseti.
analyzed: aniṭṭha nāma nivattanassa ati aniṭṭha nāma nivattiyāḥ akāraṇa bhāva dassanena iṭṭha nāma lābhāpanassa akāraṇa bhāvam dasseti
translated: “The non-occurrence of the non-desired” : by showing that the non-occurrence of the non-desired is not the cause, he shows that the occurrence of the desired is not the cause.

original: Devamanussasampattibhaveti sampattiyutte sampanne devamanussabhave. Samiddhasobhanatāti
analyzed: deva manussa sampatti bhaveti sampatti yutte sampanne deva manussa bhave samiddha sobhana tā ati
translated: “In the existence of the divine and human kinds of excellence” : in the existence of the divine and human kinds of excellence that are associated with excellence, that are perfect. “The beauty of prosperity” :

original: abhivuddhasobhanatā. Tato evāti sampattivirahato eva, asampannattā evāti attho. Tesaṃyeva
analyzed: abhivuddha sobhana tā tatas eva ati sampatti virahataḥ eva asampanna ttā eva ati attho tesaṃ yeva
translated: the beauty of abundance. “For that very reason” : for the very reason that there is no excellence, for the very reason that there is no perfection.

original: hatthiādīnaṃ sukhassa hetubhāvaṃ na gacchanti sāraṇādivasena dukkhapaccayattā. Tesanti
analyzed: hatthi ādīnam sukhassa hetu bhāvam na gacchanti sāraṇā ādi vasena dukkha paccaya ttā tesan ti
translated: They do not become the cause of the happiness of those same elephants, etc., because they are a condition for suffering, as nutriment, etc., are.

original: hatthirūpādīnaṃ. “Tassa tassevā”tiādinā yathāvuttamatthaṃ vivarati. Akusalena attanā🔽katena nibbattaṃ dukkhassa paccayo hotīti yojanā. Tasmāti yasmā kammaṃ yasmiṃ santāne🔽nibbattaṃ, tattheva sukhadukkhānaṃ paccayo hoti, na aññattha, tasmā. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ🔽panāti ekaccamatadassanaṃ. Tattha “aniṭṭhaṃ nāma natthī”ti yasmā paṭisedhadvayena
analyzed: hatthi rūpa ādīnam tassa tassa iva ati ādinā yathāvuttam attham vivarati akusalena attanā  katena nibbattam dukkhassa paccayaḥ hoti iti yojanā tasmā iti yasmā kammam yasmin santāne  nibbattam tattha iva sukha dukkhānam paccayaḥ hoti na aññattha tasmā aṭṭhakathāyam  pana ati ekacca mata dassanam tattha aniṭṭham nāma natthi iti yasmā paṭisedha dvayena
translated: of the elephant-form, etc. “Because of that, etc.”: he explains the meaning stated. The construction is: “The suffering produced by the unwholesome action done by oneself becomes a condition.” “Because of that”: since the kamma that is produced in a certain continuity becomes a condition for pleasure and pain in that very place, not elsewhere, therefore. “In the commentary”: this is a certain opinion. Therein, “There is nothing unpleasant”: since there is no unpleasant feeling, therefore, “there is no unpleasant object.”

original: kusalakammajassa iṭṭhabhāvo niyato, tasmā “kusalakammajameva iṭṭha”nti evaṃ aniyametvā🔽“kusalakammajaṃ iṭṭhamevā”ti evamettha niyamo gahetabboti dassento “akusalakammajampī”tiādimāha.
analyzed: kusala kamma jassa iṭṭha bhāvaḥ niyataḥ tasmā kusala kamma jam eva iṭṭhanti evam a niyametvā  kusala kamma jam iṭṭham eva ti evam ettha niyamaḥ gahetabbo ti dassentaḥ akusala kamma jam pi iti ādim āha
translated: of the form of an elephant, etc. “Because of that, etc.”: he explains the meaning stated above. The construction is: “The suffering that is produced by the unwholesome kamma done by oneself becomes a condition for that.” “Because of that”: because kamma, when produced in a certain continuity, becomes a condition for pleasure and pain in that very continuity, not elsewhere. “In the commentary”: in the Paṭisambhidā. “There is nothing unpleasurable”: since the pleasantness of what is produced by wholesome kamma is certain by virtue of the twofold negation , the restriction should be understood thus: “What is produced by wholesome kamma is only pleasant,” not as follows: “What is produced by wholesome kamma is only pleasant, and what is produced by unwholesome kamma is only unpleasant.”

original: Kinti akusalakammajaṃ sobhanaṃ, yaṃ paresaṃ iṭṭhaṃ nāma siyā? Yadi duggatiyaṃ kesañci
analyzed: kinti akusala kamma jam sobhanam yam paresam iṭṭham nāma siyā yadi duggatiyam kesañci
translated: How can what is produced by unwholesome kamma be beautiful, which might be pleasant to others? If, in the unhappy destinies,

original: tiracchānānaṃ saṇṭhānādisampatti sugatiyaṃ sattānaṃ akusalanissandena virūparūpatā
analyzed: tiracchānānam saṇṭhāna ādi sampatti sugatiyam sattānam akusala nissandena virūpa rūpa tā
translated: the excellence of the bodily form, etc., of some animals is the result of wholesome kamma, then the ugliness of beings in the happy destinies must be the result of unwholesome kamma.

original: viya kusalanissandena, kathaṃ tassā akusalakammajatā. Atha pana yaṃ kesañci amanāpampi
analyzed: viya kusala nissandena katham tassāḥ akusala kamma ja tā atha pana yam kesañci amanāpam pi
translated: and how is it born of unprofitable kamma? But it is said with reference to visible data that are disagreeable to some,

original: samānaṃ rūpaṃ manāpaṃ hutvā upaṭṭhāti, taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ, evampi yathā kesañci🔽tiracchānādīnaṃ kusalakammajaṃ manussādirūpaṃ amanāpato upaṭṭhahantampi kusalavipākasseva🔽ārammaṇabhāvato atthato iṭṭhameva nāma hoti, evaṃ akusalakammajaṃ kesañci manāpaṃ
analyzed: samānam rūpam manāpam hutvā upaṭṭhāti tam sandhāya vuttam evam pi yathā kesañci  tiracchāna ādīnam kusala kamma jam manussa ādi rūpam amanāpataḥ upaṭṭhahantam pi kusala vipākassa iva  ārammaṇa bhāvataḥ atthataḥ iṭṭham eva nāma hoti evam akusala kamma jam kesañci manāpam
translated: but appear as agreeable. And so too, in the way already stated,🔽visible data born of profitable kamma, though they appear as disagreeable to some animals, etc., are in fact agreeable because they are objects of profitable kamma.

original: hutvā upaṭṭhahantampi akusalavipākasseva ārammaṇabhāvato atthato aniṭṭhameva nāma🔽hoti, evañcetaṃ sampaṭicchitabbaṃ. Aññathā “aṭṭhānametaṃ anavakāso, yaṃ kāyaduccaritassa
analyzed: hutvā upaṭṭhahantam pi akusala vipākassa iva ārammaṇa bhāvataḥ atthataḥ aniṭṭham eva nāma  hoti evañca itam sampaṭicchitabbam aññathā aṭṭhānam etam anavakāsaḥ yam kāya duccaritassa
translated: And so too, in the way already stated, visible data born of unprofitable kamma, though they appear as agreeable to some, are in fact disagreeable because they are objects of unprofitable kamma.🔽This is how it should be understood. Otherwise there would be contradiction of the passage in the Description of the Mean, “It is impossible, it cannot happen that a desirable, agreeable result of bodily good conduct can be expected” , and so on.

original: iṭṭho kanto manāpo vipāko uppajjeyyā”tiādiaṭṭhānapāḷiyā virodho siyā. Tenevāha “kusalakammajassa
analyzed: iṭṭhaḥ kantaḥ manāpaḥ vipākaḥ uppajjeyya ati ādi aṭṭhāna pāḷiyā virodho siyā tena iva āha kusala kamma jassa
translated: That is why he said, “But in the case of what is born of profitable kamma” , and so on.🔽“All” refers to one’s own and to others’.

original: panā”tiādi. Sabbesanti attano, paresañca. Iṭṭhassa abhāvo vattabboti yathā “kusalakammajaṃ
analyzed: pana atiādi sabbesanti attanaḥ paresam ca iṭṭhassa abhāvaḥ vattabbo ti yathā kusala kamma jam
translated: “The absence of what is desirable should be stated” .

original: aniṭṭhaṃ nāma natthī”ti vuttaṃ, evaṃ kiñcāpi “akusalakammajaṃ iṭṭhaṃ nāma natthī”ti
analyzed: aniṭṭham nāma natthi iti vuttam evam kiñcā api akusala kamma jam iṭṭham nāma natthi iti
translated: “There is nothing undesirable” is said. Although it is not said in the commentary, “There is nothing desirable that is born of unwholesome kamma,”

original: aṭṭhakathāyaṃ na vuttaṃ, tena pana nayadassanena akusalakammajassa abhāvo vutto eva
analyzed: aṭṭhakathāyam na vuttam tena pana naya dassanena akusala kamma jassa abhāvaḥ vuttaḥ eva
translated: by this method it is said that there is none.

original: hotīti so saṃvaṇṇanāvasena niddhāretvā vattabboti adhippāyo. Etena kusalakammajameva
analyzed: hoti iti saḥ saṃvaṇṇanā vasena niddhāretvā vattabbaḥ ti adhippāyaḥ etena kusala kamma jam eva
translated: Therefore the meaning should be extracted by way of the commentary. The intention is this: by this he shows that the desirable is only that born of wholesome kamma.

original: iṭṭhanti purimapadāvadhāraṇassa gahetabbataṃ dasseti.🔽Idāni “hatthiādīnampī”tiādinā tamevatthaṃ vivarati. Kusalavipākassāti etthāpi kusalavipākasseva🔽ārammaṇanti attho. Manussānanti ca nidassanamattaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Itaresampi ca akusalakammajaṃ
analyzed: iṭṭha nti purima pada avadhāraṇassa gahetabba tam dasseti  idāni hatthi ādīnam pi iti ādinā tam eva attham vivarati kusala vipākassa ati ettha api kusala vipākassa iva  ārammaṇanti atthaḥ manussānam ti ca nidassana mattam daṭṭhabbam itaresam pi ca akusala kamma jam
translated: “By the word ‘only’ in the first line” shows that the word “only” in the first line should be taken.

original: akusalavipākasseva, kusalakammajañca kusalavipākasseva ārammaṇanti dassitovāyaṃ nayoti.
analyzed: akusala vipākassa iva kusala kamma jañca kusala vipākassa iva ārammaṇanti dassitaḥ uva ayam nayoti
translated: Now, by “of elephants, etc., too” he explains that same meaning. “Of the result of wholesome kamma” also means “of the object of the result of wholesome kamma.” And “of human beings” should be regarded as an illustration only. And the method is shown thus: of the result of unwholesome kamma is the object of the result of unwholesome kamma, and of the result of wholesome kamma is the object of the result of wholesome kamma.

original: Kasmā pana iṭṭhāniṭṭhamissite vatthumhi manāpatāva saṇṭhātīti āha “iṭṭhārammaṇena…pe…
analyzed: kasmā pana iṭṭha aniṭṭha missite vatthumhi manāpatā ava saṇṭhāti iti āha
translated: Why does it occur only in the desirable in the case of objects that are mixed with the desirable and the undesirable? He says: “Because of the object that is desirable” …

original: sakkā vattu”nti. Suṭṭhu vuttanti “iṭṭhāniṭṭhaṃ ekantato vipākeneva paricchijjatī”ti
analyzed: sakkā vattunti suṭṭhu vuttam ti iṭṭha aniṭṭham ekantataḥ vipākena iva paricchijjati iti
translated: “It is right to say so.”

original: vadantehi iṭṭhāniṭṭhārammaṇavavatthānaṃ sammadeva vuttaṃ. Taṃ anugantvāti vipākavasena
analyzed: vadantehi iṭṭha aniṭṭha ārammaṇa vavatthānam sammat eva vuttam tam anugantvā iti vipāka vasena
translated: Those who say, “The desirable and undesirable are delimited by the result alone,” have rightly said that the desirable and undesirable are delimited by the object.🔽“Following that” means following the delimitation of the desirable and undesirable by way of the result.

original: iṭṭhāniṭṭhārammaṇavavatthānaṃ anugantvā. Sabbatthāti sugatiduggatīsu, sabbesu vā ārammaṇesu.
analyzed: iṭṭha aniṭṭha ārammaṇa vavatthānam anugantvā sabbattha ati sugati duggatīsu sabbesu vā ārammaṇesu
translated: “Everywhere” means in good and bad destinations, or in all objects.

original: “Aniṭṭhā”ti vacaneneva tesaṃ iṭṭhatā nivattitāti āha “sadisatā ca rūpādibhāvoyevā”ti.
analyzed: aniṭṭhā iti vacanena iva tesam iṭṭha tā nivatti tā iti āha sadisa tā ca rūpa ādi bhāvoyā iva ati
translated: “By the word ‘undesirable’ the desirable is excluded,” he says. “The state of being visible, etc., is the same in both.”🔽The desirable visible-data, etc., are called “sense objects” in the sutta.

original: Iṭṭhāneva rūpādīni kāmaguṇāti sutte vuttānīti mittapaṭipakkho amitto viya iṭṭhapaṭipakkhā
analyzed: rūpa ādīni kāma guṇā ti sutte vuttāni iti mitta paṭipakkhaḥ amittaḥ viya iṭṭha paṭipakkhā
translated: “The undesirable is intended as the opposite of the desirable,🔽like an enemy who is the opposite of a friend.”

original: aniṭṭhāti adhippetāti vuttaṃ “aniṭṭhāti…pe… vohāro viyā”ti. Sabbāni vāti ettha “piyarūpaṃ🔽sātarūpa”nti vacanato kathaṃ aniṭṭhānaṃ rūpādīnaṃ kāmaguṇabhāvāpattīti ce? Tesampi
analyzed: aniṭṭhā ati adhippetā ti vuttam aniṭṭhā atipe vohāraḥ viyā ti sabbāni vā ti ettha piya rūpam  vacanato katham aniṭṭhānam rūpa ādīnam kāma guṇa bhāva āpatti iti ce tesam pi
translated: “All” means all the visible-data, etc., that are objects of the six kinds of consciousness.🔽“But how can the visible-data, etc., which are undesirable, become sense objects?”🔽Because the desirable is intended in the sense of being dear and delightful.

original: vipallāsavasena taṇhāvatthubhāvato piyarūpabhāvassa adhippetattā. Yadi evaṃ kathaṃ
analyzed: vipallāsa vasena taṇhā vatthu bhāvataḥ piya rūpa bhāvassa adhippeta ttā yadi evam katham
translated: “If that is so, then how can the desirable become sense objects?”

original: “cakkhuviññeyyāni rūpāni iṭṭhānī”tiādisuttapadaṃ nīyatīti āha “atisayenā”tiādi.
analyzed: cakkhu viññeyyāni rūpāni iṭṭhāni iti ādi sutta padam nīyati iti āha atisayena atiādi
translated: “The passage in the sutta, ‘visible forms cognizable by the eye that are wished for, desired, agreeable, pleasing, connected with worldly baits,’ is brought in” .

original: Indriyabaddharūpavasena pāḷiyaṃ hīnadukaniddeso pavattoti dassetuṃ “dvīsupi hīnapaṇītapadesū”tiādimāha.
analyzed: indriya baddha rūpa vasena pāḷiyam hīna duka niddeso pavatto ti dassetum dvīsu pi hīna paṇīta padesu iti ādim āha
translated: “In the two passages about inferior and superior visible forms” : the inferior and superior visible forms are stated in the text by way of the visible forms bound up with the faculties.

original: Avayavayoge sāmivacanaṃ, na kattarīti adhippāyo. “Tesaṃ tesaṃ sattāna”nti indriyabaddharūpe
analyzed: avayava yoge sāmi vacanam na kattari iti adhippāyaḥ tesam tesam indriya baddha rūpe
translated: The intention is that the word “their” is used in the sense of a part of a whole, not in the sense of an agent.

original: niddiṭṭhe kasmā kammajavasena attho vutto, na catusantativasenāti āha “sattasantāna…pe…
analyzed: niddiṭṭhe kasmā kamma ja vasena atthaḥ vuttaḥ na catu santati vasena āti āha satta santānape
translated: “When the visible forms bound up with the faculties are indicated” : why is the meaning stated by way of the kamma-born, not by way of the fourfold origination?

original: vutta”nti. Padhānattā hi kammajavasena atthaṃ vatvā sesesu “evaṃ utusamuṭṭhānādīsupī”ti
analyzed: vuttam ti padhāna ttā hi kamma ja vasena attham vatvā sesesu evam utu samuṭṭhāna ādīsu pi iti
translated: “The meaning is stated by way of the kamma-born” : the commentary gives the additional statement “in the same way, in the case of the temperature-born, etc., too” .🔽“In the meaning of ‘by those and those’ ” : the word “their” is taken in the sense of an agent.

original: aṭṭhakathāyaṃ atideso kato. “Tehi tehīti etasmiṃ atthe”ti iminā “tesaṃ tesa”nti kattari
analyzed: aṭṭhakathā ayam atideso kato tehi tehi iti etasmin atthe iti iminā tesam tesanti kattari
translated: “In that case, the meaning of ‘by those and those’ is the meaning of ‘in those and those’ ” : he shows the advantage of the word “their” being used in the sense of an objective genitive.

original: sāmivacanaṃ āsaṅkati. Tathā sati visaye vā sāmivacane laddhaguṇaṃ dasseti “na kammajavasenevā”tiādinā,
analyzed: sāmi vacanam tathā sati visaye vā sāmi vacane laddha guṇam dasseti na kamma ja vasena iva ati ādinā
translated: The word “only” shows that the meaning is not stated by way of the kamma-born.

original: kammajaggahaṇañcettha upalakkhaṇaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: kamma ja ggahaṇam ca ittha upalakkhaṇam daṭṭhabbam
translated: The word “kamma-born” should be regarded as a mere example.

original: Mariyādābhūtanti uttamamariyādābhūtaṃ. Tenevāha “yassa yeva manāpā, tassa teva paramā”ti. Tesanti kāmaguṇānaṃ. Sabhāvatoti lakkhaṇato.🔽“Ekasmiṃyeva assādanakujjhanato”tiādinā “yasmā teyeva rūpādayo eko assādetī”tiādikaṃ
analyzed: mariyādā bhūtanti uttama mariyādā bhūtam tena iva āha yassa yā iva manāpā tassa tā iva paramā ti tesanti kāma guṇānam sabhāvataḥ ti lakkhaṇato  ekasmin yeva rūpa ādayaḥ ekaḥ assādeti iti ādikam
translated: In their true nature: in their characteristics.🔽“Because one delights in and is irritated by the same things” , etc., is the explanation of the sutta passage beginning, “Because they delight in the same things” .

original: suttantavivaraṇaṃ iṭṭhāniṭṭhabhāve hetubhāvena vuttanti dasseti. Iṭṭhāniṭṭhaggahaṇaṃ
analyzed: suttanta vivaraṇam iṭṭha aniṭṭha bhāve hetu bhāvena vutta nti dasseti iṭṭha aniṭṭha ggahaṇam
translated: The words “delight in” and “are irritated by” are stated as the cause for the perception of what is desirable and undesirable.

original: hotīti nibbāne viya aniṭṭhaggahaṇaṃ saññāvipallāsena aññesupi ārammaṇesu iṭṭhāniṭṭhābhiniveso hotīti adhippāyo.
analyzed: hoti iti nibbāne viya aniṭṭha ggahaṇam saññā vipallāsena aññesu pi ārammaṇesu iṭṭha aniṭṭha abhinivesaḥ hoti iti adhippāyaḥ
translated: The intention is that, just as there is the perception of what is undesirable in Nibbāna, so too there is the misapprehension of what is desirable and undesirable in other objects through the perversion of perception.

original: Vibhāgo nāma asaṅkaro, vitthāro cāti “vibhatta”nti padassa “vavatthitaṃ, pakāsita”nti🔽ca atthamāha. Aññesanti atiaḍḍhadaliddānaṃ. Idaṃ iṭṭhaṃ, aniṭṭhañca hotīti ettha
analyzed: vibhāgaḥ nāma asaṅkaraḥ vitthāro ca ati vibhattam nti padassa vavatthitam pakāsitam  ca attham āha aññesanti idam iṭṭham aniṭṭham ca hoti iti ettha
translated: The word vibhatta is explained as meaning “defined” and “revealed” .🔽Others: those who are more than half-blind.

original: ca-saddena aniṭṭhaṃ, iṭṭhañca hotīti ayampi attho vuttoti veditabbaṃ. Aniṭṭhaṃ iṭṭhanti
analyzed: ca saddena aniṭṭham iṭṭham ca hoti iti ayam pi atthaḥ vuttaḥ ti veditabbam aniṭṭham iṭṭham ti
translated: The word ca in the phrase “what is desirable and undesirable” should be understood to imply also the phrase “what is undesirable and desirable.”

original: iṭṭhassa “aniṭṭha”nti, aniṭṭhassa “iṭṭha”nti gahaṇe yathāsaṅkhyaṃ yojanā. Indriyavikārāpattiādināti
analyzed: iṭṭhassa an iṭṭhanti an iṭṭhassa iṭṭhanti gahaṇe yathāsaṅkhyam yojanā indriya vikāra āpatti ādinā ati
translated: In the case of what is desirable, what is undesirable is taken as desirable, and in the case of what is undesirable, what is desirable is taken as undesirable. The words “and so on” include the alteration of faculties and the rest.

original: ettha ādi-saddena pubbābhisaṅkhārādiṃ saṅgaṇhāti. Puretaraṃ pavattacittābhisaṅkhāravasenāpi
analyzed: ettha ādi saddena pubba abhisaṅkhāra ādim saṅgaṇhāti puretaram pavatta citta abhisaṅkhāra vasena api
translated: For by the alteration of the mind’s formation that occurs earlier,

original: hi vināva saññāvipallāsaṃ iṭṭhaṃ “aniṭṭha”nti, aniṭṭhañca “iṭṭha”nti gayhatīti.🔽Tena vipākenāti tena kusalākusalavipākena. Ārammaṇassa iṭṭhāniṭṭhatanti yattha taṃ
analyzed: hi vinā āva saññā vipallāsam iṭṭham an iṭṭhanti an iṭṭham ca iṭṭhanti gayhati iti  tena vipākena ati tena kusala akusala vipākena ārammaṇassa iṭṭha aniṭṭha tat ti yattha taṃ
translated: what is desirable is taken as undesirable and what is undesirable as desirable, even without the perversion of perception.

original: uppajjati, tassa buddharūpādikassa gūthādikassa ca ārammaṇassa yathākkamaṃ iṭṭhataṃ
analyzed: uppajjati tassa buddha rūpa ādikassa gūtha ādikassa ca ārammaṇassa yathākkamam
translated: “By its ripening”: by the ripening of that profitable or unprofitable action. “The desirability and undesirability of the object”: this shows the desirability of the object consisting of the Enlightened One’s material body, etc., and the undesirability of the object consisting of excrement, etc., in the place where they occur.

original: aniṭṭhatañca nidasseti. Vijjamānepi saññāvipallāse ārammaṇena vipākaniyamadassananti🔽iṭṭhārammaṇe kusalavipākova uppajjati, aniṭṭhārammaṇe akusalavipākovāti evaṃ ārammaṇena
analyzed: aniṭṭha tañca nidasseti vijjamāne pi saññā vipallāse ārammaṇena vipāka niyama dassanam ti  iṭṭha ārammaṇe kusala vipākaḥ uva uppajjati aniṭṭha ārammaṇe akusala vipākaḥ uva ati evam ārammaṇena
translated: And it shows the control of ripening by the object even when there is the perversion of perception.🔽For profitable ripening occurs with a desirable object, and unprofitable ripening with an undesirable object. This is the “control of ripening by the object.”

original: vipākaniyamadassanaṃ. Ārammaṇaniyamadassanatthanti yaṃ kusalavipākassa ārammaṇaṃ,
analyzed: vipāka niyama dassanam ārammaṇa niyama dassana ttham ti yam kusala vipākassa ārammaṇam
translated: “For the purpose of showing the control of the object”: the object of profitable ripening is

original: taṃ iṭṭhaṃ nāma. Yaṃ akusalavipākassa ārammaṇaṃ, taṃ aniṭṭhaṃ nāmāti dassanatthaṃ.
analyzed: tat iṭṭham nāma yam akusala vipākassa ārammaṇam tat aniṭṭham nāma ati dassana ttham
translated: and that is called desirable. The purpose of the statement is to show that what is the object of unprofitable kamma-result is undesirable.

original: Ārammaṇena niyāmito hi vipāko attano upakārakassa ārammaṇassa niyāmako hotīti.🔽Dvārantare dukkhassa paccayabhūtassa ārammaṇassa dvārantare sukhavipākuppādanato,
analyzed: ārammaṇena niyāmitaḥ hi vipākaḥ attanaḥ upakārakassa ārammaṇassa niyāmakaḥ hoti iti  dvāra antare dukkhassa paccaya bhūtassa ārammaṇassa dvāra antare sukha vipāka uppādanato
translated: For kamma-result is governed by its object, and it governs the object that is helpful to it.🔽Because it produces a pleasant kamma-result in a door different from that of the object that is a condition for pain,

original: dvārantare sukhassa paccayabhūtassa ārammaṇassa dvārantare dukkhavipākuppādanato
analyzed: dvāra antare sukhassa paccaya bhūtassa ārammaṇassa dvāra antare dukkha vipāka uppādanato
translated: and because it produces an unpleasant kamma-result in a door different from that of the object that is a condition for pleasure,

original: vipākena ārammaṇaniyamadassanena vipākavasena iṭṭhāniṭṭhatā dassitāti yojanā.
analyzed: vipākena ārammaṇa niyama dassanena vipāka vasena iṭṭha aniṭṭha tā dassitā ati yojanā
translated: the desirable and undesirable should be understood as kamma-result by showing the governance of the object by the kamma-result.

original: 7. Duppariggahaṭṭhena kāraṇabhūtena lakkhaṇassa indriyādisabhāvassa duppaṭivijjhatā,
analyzed: duppariggaha ṭṭhena kāraṇa bhūtena lakkhaṇassa indriya ādi sabhāvassa duppaṭivijjha tā
translated: The difficulty of penetration of the characteristic, which is the cause in the sense of the most important factor, is due to the difficulty of apprehending the visible-data base.

original: evaṃ supariggahaṭṭhena lakkhaṇasuppaṭivijjhatā veditabbā. “Dūre”ti avuttassāti lakkhaṇato
analyzed: evam su pariggaha aṭṭhena lakkhaṇa su paṭivijjha tā veditabbā dūrā iti avuttassa ati lakkhaṇato
translated: The ease of penetration of the characteristic should be understood in the opposite sense as the ease of apprehending the visible-data base.🔽“Not stated as far as” : not stated as far as the characteristic.

original: “dūre”ti akathitassa. Vuttampīti lakkhaṇato “dūre”ti vuttampi sukhumarūpaṃ.
analyzed: dūre ti a kathitassa vuttam pi iti lakkhaṇato dūre iti vuttam pi sukhuma rūpam
translated: “Stated” : stated as far as the characteristic.

original: “Bhindamāno”ti sambhindamānoti vuttaṃ hotīti āha “missakaṃ karonto”ti. Yasmā pana
analyzed: bhindamānaḥ ti sambhindamānaḥ iti vuttam hoti iti āha missakam karonto ti yasmā pana
translated: “Breaking up” is said to be “mixing up.” Therefore he says, “making a mixture.”

original: bhedanaṃ vibhāgakaraṇampi hoti, tasmā dutiyavikappe “bhindamāno”ti padassa “visuṃ🔽karonto”ti atthamāha. Tatiyavikappe pana bhindamānoti vināsentoti attho. Tenāha “santikabhāvaṃ🔽bhinditvā dūrabhāvaṃ, dūrabhāvañca bhinditvā santikabhāvaṃ karonto”ti. Na hi sakkā
analyzed: bhedanam vibhāga karaṇam pi hoti tasmā dutiya vikappe bhindamānaḥ iti padassa visum  karontaḥ iti attham āha tatiya vikappe pana bhindamāno ti vināsentaḥ iti attho tena āha santika bhāvam  bhinditvā dūra bhāvam dūra bhāvam ca bhinditvā santika bhāvam karontaḥ iti na hi sakkā
translated: But since breaking up is also making a division, therefore in the second interpretation he says that the meaning of “breaking up” is “making separate.”🔽But in the third interpretation the meaning of “breaking up” is “destroying.” Therefore he says: “having broken up the state of nearness and made it distant, and having broken up the state of distance and made it near.”

original: santikassa tabbhāvaṃ avināsetvā dūrabhāvaṃ kātuṃ, tathā itarassāpi. Santikabhāvakaraṇena🔽na bhindati na vināseti, na ca okāsadūrato lakkhaṇato dūraṃ visuṃ karaṇena bhindati
analyzed: santikassa tad bhāvam a vināsetvā dūra bhāvam kātum tathā itarassa api santika bhāva karaṇena  na bhindati na vināseti na ca okāsa dūrataḥ lakkhaṇataḥ dūram visum karaṇena bhindati
translated: For it is not possible to make what is near distant without destroying its state of nearness, and vice versa.🔽By making near he does not break up or destroy; and by making separate he does not break up or divide what is distant in spatial extension from him or distant in kind.

original: vibhāgaṃ karoti, nāpi okāsadūrena lakkhaṇato dūraṃ vomissakakaraṇena bhindati sambhindatīti
analyzed: vibhāgam karoti na api okāsa dūrena lakkhaṇataḥ dūram vomissaka karaṇena bhindati sambhindati iti
translated: Nor does he break up or mix up what is distant in kind by making a mixture.

original: yojanā. “Tidhā attho daṭṭhabbo”ti saṅkhepena vuttamatthaṃ “na hī”tiādinā vivarati.
analyzed: yojanā tidhā attho daṭṭhabbo ti saṅkhepena vuttam attham na hi iti ādinā vivarati
translated: The meaning should be seen in three ways. Having stated the meaning briefly, he explains it in detail with the words “For it is not possible.”

original: Visuṃ karoti, vomissakaṃ karotīti karoti-saddaṃ ānetvā sambandho. “Etthāpī”tiādinā🔽yathā “okāsato dūrameva bhindatī”ti ettha okāsato dūrassa okāsato santikabhāvakaraṇaṃ🔽adhippetanti vināsanaṃ bhedanaṃ, evaṃ “na lakkhaṇato dūraṃ bhindatī”ti etthāpi lakkhaṇato
analyzed: visum karoti vomissakam karoti iti karoti saddam ānetvā sambandhaḥ ettha api iti ādinā  yathā okāsataḥ dūram eva bhindati iti ettha okāsataḥ dūrassa okāsataḥ santika bhāva karaṇam  adhippetam ti vināsanam bhedanam evam na lakkhaṇataḥ dūram bhindati iti ettha api lakkhaṇato
translated: He splits it up, he makes it different, he makes it diverse: the word “makes” is to be supplied.

original: dūrassa lakkhaṇato santikabhāvākaraṇaṃ abhedanaṃ avināsananti imamatthaṃ dasseti.🔽Vomissakakaraṇavibhāgakaraṇatthataṃ sandhāyāha “bhindamānoti ettha ca aññathā bhedanaṃ
analyzed: dūrassa lakkhaṇato santika bhāva akaraṇam abhedanam avināsanam ti imam attham dasseti  sandhāya āha bhindamānaḥ iti ettha ca aññathā bhedanam
translated: In the same way, in the passage “It does not split up what is far by way of characteristic” , what is meant is that it does not make what is far by way of plane near by way of characteristic, that is, it does not destroy it, it does not split it up.🔽He splits up: and here the splitting up is said in one way,

original: vutta”nti. Pacchimanaye vināsanatthameva sandhāya “bhedanaṃ idha ca aññathā vutta”nti avoca.
analyzed: vuttanti pacchima naye vināsana attham eva sandhāya bhedanam idha ca aññathā vuttan ti avoca
translated: and the splitting up here is said in another way.

original: Rūpakkhandhaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: rūpa kkhandha niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Description of the Materiality Aggregate is ended.

original: 2. Vedanākkhandhaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: vedanā khandha niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Feeling Aggregate

original: 8. Cakkhādayo pasādāti oḷārikattabhāvapariyāpannā cakkhusotaghānajivhāpasādā, manomayattabhāvapariyāpannā
analyzed: cakkha ādayaḥ pasādā ti oḷārika tta bhāva pariyāpannā cakkhu sota ghāna jivhā pasādā manaḥ maya tta bhāva pariyāpannā
translated: The eye, etc., that are included among the faculties are the eye, ear, nose, tongue, and body that are included among the great primaries.

original: cakkhusotappasādā ca. Kāyavohāraṃ arahantīti kāyantogadhattā kāyekadesattā ca kāyoti🔽vattabbataṃ arahanti. Kāyoti hi attabhāvopi vuccati “sakkāyadiṭṭhī”tiādīsu, karajakāyopi
analyzed: cakkhu sota ppasādā ca kāya vohāram arahanti iti kāya antogadhattā kāya ika desa ttā ca  vattabba tam arahanti kāyaḥ iti hi atta bhāvaḥ api vuccati sakkāya diṭṭhi iti ādīsu karaja kāyaḥ api
translated: and the eye, ear, and body sensitive matter. “They are fit to be called ‘body’ ”: they are fit to be called “body” because they are a collection of bodies and because they are a part of the body.🔽For “body” is said of the individual essence in such passages as “personality view” , and it is said of the physical body in such passages as “he creates another body by this one” .

original: “so imamhā kāyā aññaṃ kāyaṃ abhinimminātī”tiādīsu. Tabbatthukāti cakkhādinissitā
analyzed: saḥ imamhā kāyā aññam kāyam abhinimmināti itiādīsu tabbatthukā ati cakkha ādi nissitā
translated: “They have that as their object”: they are dependent on the eye, etc.,

original: kāyikāti pariyāyena vuttā, nippariyāyena pana cetasikāva. Yathāha “yaṃ tasmiṃ samaye🔽tajjācakkhuviññāṇadhātusamphassajaṃ cetasikaṃ neva sātaṃ nāsātaṃ cetosamphassajaṃ🔽adukkhamasukhaṃ vedayita”ntiādi. “Na hi cakkhādayo kāyappasādā hontī”ti iminā kāyapasādanissitā
analyzed: kāyikā ati pariyāyena vuttā nippariyāyena pana yathā āha yam tasmin samaye  tajjā cakkhu viññāṇa dhātu samphassa jam cetasikam na iva sātam na asātam cetaḥ samphassa jam  adukkham asukham vedayita ntiādi na hi cakkha ādayo kāya ppasādāḥ honti iti iminā kāya pasāda nissitā
translated: and are called “bodily” in a secondary sense. But in the primary sense they are mental. As it is said:🔽“At that time there is in him contact, bodily pleasure and pain, and the mental state born of that contact, neither painful nor pleasant, which is accompanied by equanimity” .🔽By the words “The eye, etc., are not bodily sensitive matter” he shows that the feeling dependent on bodily sensitive matter is bodily in the primary sense.

original: vedanā nippariyāyena kāyikāti dasseti. Kāyikacetasikādibhāvenāti ādi-saddena kusalākusalābyākatādibhāvā
analyzed: vedanā nippariyāyena kāyikā ati dassa iti kāyika cetasika ādi bhāvena ati ādi saddena kusala akusala abyākata ādi bhāvā
translated: “As bodily, mental, etc.”: the word “etc.” includes the categories of wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate.

original: saṅgayhanti. Tenāti sukhādivedanekadesassa addhāsamayavasena atītādibhāvābhāvena.🔽Keci panettha “heṭṭhā dassitanayattā pākaṭattā addhāvasena, ekamuhuttādipubbaṇhādīsu
analyzed: tena ati sukha ādi vedanā eka desassa addhā samaya vasena atīta ādi bhāva abhāvena  keci pana ittha heṭṭhā dassita naya ttā pākaṭa ttā addhā vasena eka muhutta ādi pubbaṇha ādīsu
translated: “By means of the time division of the life-continuum and the time division of the moment” : by means of the pastness, etc., of the various kinds of pleasant feeling, etc., according to the division of the life-continuum and the division of the moment.

original: utuādinā rūpassa viya vedanāya vibhāgo na gayhatīti samayavasena ca atītādibhedo🔽na dassito”ti vadanti. Santānavasena pavattānampi vedanānaṃ cittena samūhato gahetabbataṃ
analyzed: utu ādinā rūpassa viya vedanāya vibhāgaḥ na samaya vasena ca atīta ādi bhedaḥ  na dassito ti vadanti santāna vasena pavattānam pi vedanānam cittena samūhataḥ gahetabba tam
translated: But some say that the division according to the time division of the moment is not given here because it is obvious from the method shown above, and that the division according to the time division of the life-continuum is not given because the classification of feeling according to season, etc., is not recognized in the way that that of materiality is.

original: sandhāyāha “vedanāsamudāyo”ti. Tehīti addhāsamayavasena atītādibhāvehi. Etthāti etasmiṃ
analyzed: sandhāya āha tehi iti addhā samaya vasena atīta ādi bhāvehi ettha iti etasmin
translated: But the “aggregate of feeling” is said in order to include in the definition the feelings that occur in a continuity, since they can be apprehended only by being taken together with consciousness.🔽“By means of those” : by means of the pastness, etc., according to the time division of the life-continuum and the time division of the moment.🔽“Here” : in this Vibhaṅga.

original: vibhaṅge. Teti “vedanekadesā”ti vuttā kāyikacetasikādibhāvena bhinnā sukhādivedanāvisesā.
analyzed: vibhaṅge tā iti vedanā eka desā ati vuttā kāyika cetasika ādi bhāvena bhinnā sukha ādi vedanā visesā
translated: “Those” : the various kinds of pleasant feeling, etc., distinguished according to the division into bodily and mental, etc., which are called “the various kinds of feeling.”

original: Yadi vedanekadesā ettha gahitā, khaṇaparicchinnāva te gahetabbā, na santatiparicchinnāti
analyzed: yadi vedanā eka desāḥ ettha gahitā khaṇa paricchinnā ava te gahetabbā na santati paricchinnā ati
translated: If the various kinds of feeling are included here, they must be apprehended as defined by the moment, not as defined by the continuity.

original: āha “ekasantatiyaṃ panā”tiādi. Tesūti sukhādibhedesu. Bhedoti viseso. Tassāti sukhādivisesassa.
analyzed: āha eka santatiyam pana ātiādi tesu iti sukha ādi bhedesu bhedaḥ iti visesaḥ tassa ti sukha ādi visesassa
translated: He says “But in a single continuity” and so on. As to these: as to the kinds classed as pleasant, and so on. Difference: distinction. As to that: as to the distinction of pleasant, and so on.

original: Yathā cettha, evaṃ “taṃsahitataduppādakā”ti etthāpi taṃ-saddena sukhādiviseso paccāmaṭṭhoti
