analyzed: yathā ca ittha evam tad sahita tad uppādakā iti ettha api tad saddena sukha ādi viseso paccāmaṭṭhaḥ ti
translated: And just as here, so also in the phrase “accompanied by that and originated by that” the word that should be construed as referring back to the distinction of pleasant, and so on.

original: veditabbo. Santati paricchedikā bhavituṃ arahatīti sambandho. Santatikhaṇavaseneva
analyzed: veditabbaḥ santati paricchedikā bhavitum arahati iti sambandhaḥ santati khaṇa vasena iva
translated: The construction is: “it is proper to delimit by means of a continuity.” The intention is that the delimitation is stated by means of a continuity and a moment,

original: paricchedo vutto, na addhāsamayavasenāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: paricchedaḥ vuttaḥ na addhā samaya vasena ati adhippāyaḥ
translated: not by means of a period of time.

original: “Pubbantāparantamajjhagatā”ti niṭṭhitahetukiccā aniṭṭhitapaccayakiccāti vuttā, taṃ
analyzed: pubba anta apara anta majjha gatā ti niṭṭhita hetu kiccā aniṭṭhita paccaya kiccā ti vuttā tam
translated: “Past, future, and present” are said to be the states of the function of cause that is finished and the states of the function of condition that is unfinished.

original: pana atikkantahetupaccayakiccanti evaṃ vuttassa nayassa upalakkhaṇanti āha “pubbantāparantamajjhagatāti🔽etena hetupaccayakiccavasena vuttanayaṃ dassetī”ti. Ettha kusalākusalakiriyavedanānaṃ
analyzed: pana atikkanta hetu paccaya kiccanti evam vuttassa nayassa upalakkhaṇanti āha pubba anta apara anta majjha gatā ti  etena hetu paccaya kicca vasena vutta nayam dasseti iti ettha kusala akusala kiriya vedanānam
translated: But the intention is that the past, future, and present are a mere indication of the method stated as the function of cause and condition.

original: rūpassa viya, vipākānaṃ viya ca ayaṃ nāma janakahetūti nippariyāyena na sakkā vattuṃ,
analyzed: rūpassa viya vipākānam viya ca ayam nāma janaka hetu uti nippariyāyena na sakkā vattum
translated: Herein, it is not possible to say categorically “This is the productive cause of profitable and unprofitable kamma-resultant consciousness and of materiality, as it is of kamma-resultant consciousness” and “This is the productive cause of materiality, as it is of kamma-resultant consciousness.”

original: pariyāyena pana anantarapaccayabhūto hetūti vattabbo.
analyzed: pariyāyena pana anantara paccaya bhūtaḥ hetu iti vattabbo
translated: But it can be said that it is a cause in the sense of an immediately preceding condition.🔽The function of burning is the function of scorching.

original: 11. Santāpanakiccanti pariḍahanakiccaṃ. Jātiādisaṅkaranti jātisabhāvapuggalalokiyalokuttarato
analyzed: santāpana kiccanti pariḍahana kiccam jāti ādi saṅkaranti jāti sabhāva puggala lokiya lokuttarato
translated: Without confusion of kinds, of generation, of individual essence, of person, of world, of supramundane,🔽without confusion, without jumbling, of kinds such as these.🔽Of the same kind: of one kind.

original: saṅkaraṃ sambhedaṃ akatvā. Samānajātiyanti ekajātiyaṃ. Sukhato tajjātiyā adukkhamasukhā🔽paṇītāti yojetabbāti sambandho. Samānabhedeti bhūmantarādisamānavibhāge. Upabrūhitānaṃ
analyzed: saṅkaram sambhedam a katvā samāna jātiyanti eka jātiyam sukhataḥ tad jātiyāḥ adukkha asukhāḥ  paṇītā iti sambandhaḥ samāna bhedā iti bhūmantara ādi samāna vibhāge
translated: From the pleasant: from the kind that is neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant.🔽Excellent: the construction is “excellent by reason of that kind.”🔽Of the same mode: of the same mode of progress, and so on.🔽Of the elements that are assisted: of the material phenomena that are excellent by the production of superior materiality.

original: dhātūnanti uḷārarūpasamuṭṭhāpanena paṇītānaṃ rūpadhammānaṃ. Vibādhitānanti nippīḷitānaṃ🔽milāpitānaṃ. Ubhayanti sukhādidvayaṃ. Ettha ca khobhanā, āluḷanā ca kāyikasukhassa
analyzed: dhātūnam nti uḷāra rūpa samuṭṭhāpanena paṇītānam rūpa dhammānam vibādhitānam ati nippīḍitānam  sukha ādi dvayam ettha ca khobhanā āluḷanā ca kāyika sukhassa
translated: Of the elements that are opposed: of those that are oppressed,🔽of those that are withered.🔽Both: the two, namely, the pleasant and the unpleasant. And here the inflating and the swelling should be understood as bodily pleasure;

original: vasena veditabbā. Abhisandanā jhānasukhassa. Madayanā kāmasukhassa. Tathā chādanā.
analyzed: vasena veditabbā abhisandanā jhāna sukhassa madayanā kāma sukhassa tathā chādanā
translated: the embellishing as the pleasure of jhāna; the intoxicating as sensual pleasure; and so too the concealing.

original: Āsiñcanā sabbassa. Chādanā āsiñcanā vā sabbassa vasena veditabbā.
analyzed: āsiñcanā sabbassa chādanā āsiñcanā vā sabbassa vasena veditabbā
translated: The sprinkling is all. The concealing and the sprinkling should be understood as all.

original: Sabhāvādibhedena cāti sabhāvapuggalalokiyādibhedena ca. Ekantapaṇīte lokuttare hīnapaṇītānaṃ
analyzed: sabhāva ādi bhedena ca ati sabhāva puggala lokiya ādi bhedena ca ekanta paṇīte lokuttare
translated: And by the difference of their individual essences, etc., means by the difference of their individual essences, of their persons, of their worldliness, and so on.🔽🔽The supramundane, which is exclusively exalted, is divided into inferior and superior.

original: paṭipadānaṃ vasena hīnapaṇītatā. Ekantahīne akusale chandādivasena hīnapaṇītatā,
analyzed: paṭipadānam vasena hīna paṇīta tā ekanta hīne akusale chanda ādi vasena hīna paṇīta tā
translated: And by the difference of their individual essences, etc., means by the difference of their individual essences, of their persons, of their worldliness, and so on. The inferiority and superiority of the unprofitable, etc., should be understood as follows. The inferiority and superiority of the supramundane, which is absolutely superior, are due to the inferior and superior ways of progress. The inferiority and superiority of the unprofitable, which is absolutely inferior, are due to the inferior and superior desires, etc.,

original: oḷārikasukhumatā ca. Tathā hi vuttaṃ aṭṭhakathāyaṃ “yā oḷārikā, sā hīnā. Yā sukhumā,
analyzed: oḷārika sukhuma tā ca tathā hi vuttam aṭṭhakathāyam yā oḷārikā sā hīnā yā sukhumā
translated: and to grossness and subtlety. For this is said in the commentary: “That which is gross is inferior; that which is subtle is superior.”🔽The grossness and subtlety of the unprofitable, etc., is said according to the grossness and subtlety of the particular defilements, such as hate, etc., that are associated with them.

original: sā paṇītā”ti. Akusalādīsu dosasahagatādiantarabhedavasena upādāyupādāya oḷārikasukhumatā🔽taṃtaṃvāpanavasena vuccati, na kusalākusalādivasenāti āha “taṃtaṃvāpanavasena kathanepi
analyzed: sā paṇītā ati akusala ādīsu dosa sahagata ādi antara bheda vasena upādāya upādāya oḷārika sukhuma tā  taṃ taṃ vāpana vasena vuccati na kusala akusala ādi vasena ati āha taṃ taṃ vāpana vasena kathane pi
translated: And it is said according to the grossness and subtlety of the particular defilements that are the cause for the occurrence of the unprofitable, etc.,🔽and not according to the unprofitable, etc., themselves. That is why it is said: “There is no reversal in the explanation according to the particular defilements that are the cause for the occurrence of the unprofitable, etc.”🔽“Because of the abundance of hate” means because of the abundance of defilements.

original: parivattanaṃ natthī”ti. Dosussannatāyāti kilesādhikatāya. Tathāti dosussannatāya.
analyzed: parivattanam natthi iti dosussannatāya ati kilesa adhikatāya tathā ati dosussannatāya
translated: “In the same way” means because of the abundance of hate.🔽But how is there an abundance of defilements in the profitable?

original: Kathaṃ pana kusalesu dosussannatā? Upanissayavasena, kilesādhikehi santāne pavattamānā
analyzed: katham pana kusalesu dosa ussanna tā upanissaya vasena kilesa adhikehi santāne pavattamānā
translated: It is because of the abundance of defilements in the associated states that occur in the life-continuum.

original: kusalā dhammā kilesehi sambādhappattiyā tiṇādīhi sambādhappattāni viya sassāni vipulaphalauḷāraphalā
analyzed: kusalāḥ dhammā kilesehi sambādha pattiyā tiṇa ādīhi sambādha ppattāni viya sassāni vipula phala oḷāra phalā
translated: and the profitable ideas are like crops that have been invaded by weeds such as grass, etc., and so they do not come to abundant fruit and abundant yield.

original: na hontīti. Tathāti mandadosatāya. Kusalānaṃ mandadosatāpi vuttanayānusārena veditabbā.🔽Oḷārikasukhumanikantīti ettha antogadhavisesaṃ nikantiyā oḷārikasukhumatāsāmaññaṃ
analyzed: na honti iti tathā ati manda dosa tāya kusalānam manda dosa tā api vutta naya anusārena veditabbā  oḷārika sukhuma nikantī iti ettha antogadha visesam nikantiyāḥ oḷārika sukhuma tā sāmaññam
translated: “ So too” : because of the mildness of the defilements. The mildness of the defilements of the profitable should be understood in the way already stated.🔽“ Gross, subtle, and middling” : the gross, subtle, and middling of the gross, subtle, and middling of the middling, and the gross, subtle, and middling of the subtle.

original: vuttaṃ. Yathā hettha oḷārikasāmaññena oḷārikoḷārikataroḷārikatamā nikantiyo gayhanti,🔽tathā sukhumasukhumatarasukhumatamā sukhumatāsāmaññena gayhantīti. Sukhumatamanikantivatthunti
analyzed: vuttam yathā ha ittha oḷārika sāmaññena oḷārika uḷārikatara uḷārikatamāḥ nikantiyaḥ gayhanti  tathā sukhuma sukhumatara sukhumatamā sukhuma tā sāmaññena gayhanti iti
translated: Herein, the gross, subtle, and middling of the gross are the gross, subtler, and subtlest of the gross.🔽And so too in the case of the middling and the subtle.

original: cettha yāva bhavaggaṃ vipassanāñāṇañca veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: ca ittha yāva bha vaggam vipassanā ñāṇañca veditabbam
translated: “ The basis for the subtlest middling attachment” : insight knowledge should be understood as far as the peak of existence.

original: 13. Yadi siyāti yadi asampayogo visaṃsaṭṭho siyā.
analyzed: yadi siyā iti yadi a sampayogaḥ visaṃsaṭṭhaḥ siyā
translated: “ If it were” : if non-conascence were disjunction.

original: Santikato akusalatoti akusalabhāvena santikato lobhasahagatādiakusalavedayitato.
analyzed: santikataḥ akusala to ti akusala bhāvena santikataḥ lobha sahagata ādi akusala vedayitato
translated: “ From the unprofitable, from the far” : from the unprofitable state, from the unprofitable feeling accompanied by greed, etc.

original: Akusalāti dosasahagatādiakusalavedanā dūreti yathā uddharīyati. Tato dūrato kusalatoti
analyzed: akusalā ati dosa sahagata ādi akusala vedanā dūrā iti yathā tatas dūratas
translated: “Unprofitable” is the unprofitable feeling accompanied by hate, and so on. “Far” is far from the profitable. “From that” is from the unprofitable.

original: tato akusalato dūrato kāmāvacarādikusalavedayitato kusalā kāmāvacarādikusalavedanā.
analyzed: tatas akusalataḥ dūratas kāmāvacara ādi kusala vedayitataḥ kusalā kāmāvacara ādi kusala vedanā
translated: “Unprofitable” is the unprofitable feeling accompanied by hate, etc., which is “far” in the way stated. “From that” means from the unprofitable. “Nearer than that to the profitable” is the profitable feeling of the sense sphere, etc., which is “nearer” than the unprofitable.

original: “Na sakkā”ti vuttaṃ uddharituṃ asakkuṇeyyataṃ “tathā hi satī”tiādinā vivarati. Tasmāti
analyzed: na sakkā iti vuttam uddharitum tathā hi sati iti ādinā vivarati tasmā iti
translated: “It cannot be done” : the impossibility of doing it is made clear by the words “because it is so.” “Therefore” means

original: yasmā dūrato santikuddharaṇaṃ vuttanayena santikato santikuddharaṇameva hoti, tathā🔽sati atthaviseso na hoti, upādāyupādāya dūrasantikatā idha vuccati. Tasmā santikato
analyzed: yasmai dūratas santika uddharaṇam vutta nayena santikataḥ santika uddharaṇam eva hoti tathā  sati attha visesaḥ na hoti upādāya upādāya dūra santika tā idha vuccati tasmā santikato
translated: because the removal of the near from the far is in the way stated, the removal of the near from the near is the same as the removal of the far from the far.

original: santikuddharaṇañca na sakkā kātuṃ atthavisesābhāvato, anadhippetattā cāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: santika uddharaṇam ca na sakkā kātum attha visesa abhāvataḥ anadhippeta ttā ca ati adhippāyaḥ
translated: “In that case there is no difference in meaning” : the difference in meaning is not in the sense of the far and the near, but in the sense of the far and the far, and the near and the near. Therefore the removal of the near from the near cannot be done because there is no difference in meaning, and because it is not intended.

original: Nanu ca atisayavacanicchāvasena attheva atthavisesoti codanaṃ manasi katvā āha “dūradūrataratāya
analyzed: nanu ca ati saya vacanicchā vasena atthā iva attha visesaḥ ti codanam manasi katvā āha dūra dūrataratāya
translated: “But is there not a difference in meaning because of the intention to speak of a distinction?” Anticipating this objection, he says, “Because of the farness and the fartherness,” etc.

original: viya santikasantikataratāya ca anadhippetattā”ti. Yāti akusalavedanā. Tatoti kusalavedayitato.🔽Idha vuttassa dūrassāti imasmiṃ vedanākkhandhavibhaṅge “akusalā vedanā kusalābyākatāhi🔽vedanāhi dūre”tiādinā vuttassa dūrassa. Dūrato accantavisabhāgattāti yato yaṃ “dūre”ti🔽vuttaṃ, tato accantavisadisattā tassa vasena dūre santikaṃ natthīti na sakkā dūrato
analyzed: ca santika santikatara tāya ca an adhippeta ttā ati yā ati akusala vedanā kusala vedayitato  idha vuttassa dūrassa ati imasmin vedanā khandha vibhaṅge akusalā vedanā  vedanā hi dūrā iti ādinā vuttassa dūrassa dūratas accanta visabhāga ttā ati yatas yam dūrā iti  vuttam tatas accanta visadisa ttā tassa vasena dūre santikam natthi iti na sakkā dūratas
translated: and because of the nearness of the near and the remoteness of the remote, it is not stated.🔽Yā means unwholesome feeling. Tato means from wholesome feeling.🔽Dūrattā means from what is stated here. In this analysis of the feeling aggregate, unwholesome feeling is stated as remote from wholesome and indeterminate feelings,🔽and so on. Dūrato accantavisabhāgattā means because of the utter dissimilarity of what is stated as remote.🔽Because of that, there is no nearness or remoteness in terms of that. Therefore, it is not possible to say that there is nearness or remoteness🔽

original: santikaṃ uddharituṃ. Ayañhettha adhippāyo – heṭṭhā yā vedanā yāya vedanāya dūreti🔽vuttā, sā eva tassā kenacipi pariyāyena santiketi na uddharitabbāti. Santiketi vuttavedanaṃyeva🔽sandhāya vadati. Bhinneti lobhasahagatādivasena vibhatte. Tatthevāti “santike”ti🔽vuttaatthe eva. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – “akusalā vedanā akusalāya vedanāya santike”ti
analyzed: santikam uddharitum ayam ha itthā adhippāyaḥ heṭṭhā yā vedanā yāya vedanāya dūrā iti 🔽vuttā sā eva tassā kenacipi pariyāyena santikā iti na uddharitabbā ati santikā iti vutta vedanaṃyā eva 🔽sandhāya vadati bhinnā iti lobha sahagata ādi vasena vibhatte tattha iva ati santikā iti 🔽vutta atthe eva idam vuttam hoti akusalā vedanā akusalāya vedanāya santikā iti
translated: and because of the remoteness of the unwholesome from the wholesome, and because of the remoteness of the unwholesome from the indeterminate, and because of the remoteness of the original: evaṃ vuttaakusalāya vedanāyameva lobhasahagatādivasena vibhattāya dūrabhāvopi labbhati. Evaṃ sesesupīti.
analyzed: evam vutta akusalāya lobha sahagata ādi vasena vibhattāya dūra bhāvaḥ pi labbhati evam sesesu pi iti
translated: If nearness and farness are possible in the way stated, then it should be possible to remove what is far by making it near,

original: Yadi santikato dūraṃ labbhati, yadaggena dūraṃ labbhati, tadaggena dūrato santikaṃ🔽uddhariyeyyāti codanaṃ manasi katvā āha “upādāyupādāya dūrato ca santikaṃ na sakkā🔽uddharitu”ntiādi. Tassattho – yaṃ santikato dūraṃ labbhati, yadipi taṃ visabhāgaṭṭhena
analyzed: yadi santikataḥ dūram labbhati yad aggena dūram labbhati tad aggena dūratas santikam  uddhariyeyya iti codanam manasi katvā āha upādāya upādāya dūratas ca santikam na sakkā  uddharitum tiādi tassa atthaḥ yam santikataḥ dūram labbhati yadi api tam visabhā gaṭṭhena
translated: and what is near by making it far.

original: labbhati, tathāpi yaṃ tattha santikaṃ labbhati, taṃ sabhāgaṭṭheneva labbhatīti santikatova
analyzed: labbhati tathā api yam tattha santikam labbhati tam sabhā gaṭṭhena iva labbhati iti santikatas vā
translated: The answer to this is: “Far and near cannot be removed by making them far and near respectively.” The meaning is this. Although what is far is obtained as such in the sense of being unlike what is near, nevertheless what is near is obtained there too in the sense of being like it. So it is not possible to remove what is near by making it far.

original: santikaṃ uddhaṭaṃ siyāti. Tasmāti yasmā visabhāgaṭṭhena dūratā, sabhāgaṭṭhena ca🔽santikatā icchitā, tasmā. Lobhasahagatāya dosasahagatā visabhāgatāya dūre samānā
analyzed: santikam uddhaṭam siyāti tasmā iti visabhāgaṭṭhena dūra tā sabhāgaṭṭhena ca  santika tā icchitā tasmai lobha sahagatāya dosa sahagatā visabhāgatāya dūre samānā
translated: Therefore, since farness is held to be in the sense of unlike and nearness in the sense of like,🔽how can what is far by being unlike, that is, by being associated with hate, be near by being like, that is, by being associated with greed? This is the intention.

original: kathaṃ santike bhaveyyāti adhippāyo. Nanu tāsaṃ akusalasabhāgatā labbhatevāti tattha
analyzed: katham santike bhaveyya ati adhippāyaḥ nanu tāsam akusala sabhā ga tā labbhateva āti tattha
translated: But is not unwholesomeness obtained in them?

original: uttaramāha “visabhāgatā”tiādi. Tattha bhedaṃ aggahetvā na pavattatīti bhedaṃ visesaṃ
analyzed: uttaram āha visa bhāga tā ati ādi tattha bhedam aggahetvā na pavattati iti bhedam visesam
translated: Therein, it does not occur without taking a difference, i.e., it occurs only after taking a difference, a distinction,🔽a dissimilarity.

original: asadisataṃ gahetvā eva pavattati visabhāgatā. Dūratāyāti idhādhippetāya dūratāya
analyzed: a sadisa tam gahetvā eva pavattati visabhāga tā dūra tāya ati idha adhippetāya dūra tāya
translated: By remoteness: by the remoteness intended here.

original: sabhāgassa abyāpakattā dūrato santikuddharaṇaṃ na sakkā kātuṃ. Sati hi sabhāgabyāpakatte
analyzed: sabhāgassa a byāpaka ttā dūratas santikuddharaṇam na sakkā kātum sati hi sabhāga byāpaka tte
translated: Because of the non-pervasiveness of the similar, it is not possible to remove nearness from remoteness. For if there were pervasiveness of the similar,🔽it would be possible to remove nearness from remoteness. This is the intention.

original: siyā santikatāti dūrato santikuddharaṇaṃ sakkā kātunti adhippāyo. “Na hī”tiādinā
analyzed: siyā santika tā iti dūratas santika uddharaṇam sakkā kātunti adhippāyaḥ na hi iti ādinā
translated: By “not so,” etc.,🔽he makes that very meaning clear.🔽By similarity: by community.

original: tamevatthaṃ pākaṭaṃ karoti. Sabhāgatāti sāmaññaṃ. Bhedanti visesaṃ. Antogadhaṃ katvāvāti🔽abhibyāpetvāva. Visabhāgabyāpakattā santikatāyāti idhādhippetavisabhāgaṃ byāpetvā
analyzed: tam evattham pākaṭam karoti sabhāgatā ati sāmaññam visesam antogadham katvā avāti  abhibyāpetvā ava visabhāga byāpaka ttā santika tāya ati idha adhippeta visabhāgam byāpetvā
translated: By difference: by distinction.🔽By including: by manifesting.

original: pavattanato heṭṭhā vuttasantikatāya santikato dūruddharaṇaṃ sakkā kātuṃ. Tamevatthaṃ
analyzed: pavattanataḥ heṭṭhā vutta santika tāya santikataḥ dūr uddharaṇam sakkā kātum tam evattham
translated: Because of the pervasiveness of the dissimilar, it is possible to remove nearness from remoteness by nearness, which is stated below, because it occurs after manifesting the dissimilar intended here.

original: “akusalatā hī”tiādinā pākaṭaṃ karoti.🔽Vedanākkhandhaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: akusala tā hi iti ādinā pākaṭam karoti  vedanā khandha niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: He makes that very meaning clear by “not so,” etc.🔽The commentary on the description of the feeling aggregate is finished.

original: 3. Saññākkhandhaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: saññā khandha niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: Description of the perception aggregate

original: 17. Tassāpīti saññāyapi. Tabbatthukattāti cakkhuvatthukattā. Paṭighaviññeyyoti yathāvuttapaṭighato
analyzed: tassa api iti tad vatthuka ttā ti cakkhu vatthuka ttā paṭigha viññeyyaḥ ti yathā vutta paṭighato
translated: ‘Of that perception too’ means of the perception of visible data. ‘Because of the same basis’: because of the same physical basis as the eye. ‘To be cognized by the opponent’:

original: vijānitabbo paṭighavasena gahetabbo. Uttarapadalopaṃ katvāti purimapade uttarapadalopaṃ katvā.🔽Viññeyyabhāve, na uppattiyanti adhippāyo. Vacananti saddo, nāmanti attho. Vacanādhīnāti🔽gahetabbataṃ pati saddādhīnā, nāmāyattagahaṇāti attho. Yadettha vattabbaṃ, taṃ nāmarūpaduke🔽vuttameva. Adhivacanaṃ paññattipakāsakaṃ ñāpakaṃ etesaṃ atthīti adhivacanā yathā
analyzed: vijānitabbaḥ paṭigha vasena gahetabbaḥ uttara pada lopam katvā ati purima pade uttara pada lopam katvā  viññeyya bhāve na uppattiyanti adhippāyaḥ vacananti saddo nāmanti atthaḥ vacana adhīnā ti  sadda adhīnā nāma āyatta gahaṇā ti atthaḥ yat ettha vattabbam tam nāma rūpa duke  vuttam eva adhivacanam paññatti pakāsakam ñāpakam etesam atthi iti adhivacanāḥ yathā
translated: ‘Of that perception too’: of the perception of the eye-base too. ‘Because of the same meaning’: because of the same meaning as the eye-base. ‘To be cognized by the resistance’: to be cognized by the resistance as stated, to be grasped by way of resistance. ‘By ellipsis of the second member’: by ellipsis of the second member in the first member.🔽The meaning is: in the state of being cognizable, not in the state of arising. ‘Word’ is sound. ‘Name’ is meaning. ‘Dependent on the word’: dependent on the sound in the state of being grasped. The meaning is: the grasping is dependent on the name. What is to be said here has been said already in the section on mentality-materiality.

original: arisasoti. Tatojoti adhivacanasaṅkhātato arūpakkhandhato jāto. Arūpakkhandhapariyāpannattā
analyzed: arisasaḥ ti adhivacana saṅkhātataḥ arūpa kkhandhataḥ jātaḥ arūpa kkhandha pariyāpanna ttā
translated: ‘Designation’ is that which reveals, which makes known, the ‘designations’ . The meaning is: as ‘poison’ . ‘Derived from that’: derived from the immaterial aggregate called ‘designation.’ Because it is included in the immaterial aggregate,

original: phassepi yathāvutto attho sambhavatīti dassetuṃ “samphassoyeva vā”tiādimāha. Na kevalaṃ
analyzed: phasse api yathā vuttaḥ attho sambhavati iti dassetum samphassaḥ yā iva vāti ādim āha na kevalam
translated: the meaning stated in the case of the eye-base is applicable here too. To show this, the Exalted One says: ‘Or it is only contact.’

original: manodvārikaphasse eva, atha kho pañcadvārikaphassepi “viññeyyabhāve vacanaṃ adhikicca🔽pavattā adhivacanā”tiādivuttappakāro attho sambhavati. Itīti tasmā. Tena pariyāyenāti🔽manosamphassajapariyāyena. Tatojāpīti pañcadvārikaphassajātāpi. Aññappakārāsambhavatoti
analyzed: manaḥ dvārika phasse eva atha kho pañca dvārika phasse pi viññeyya bhāve vacanam  pavattā adhivacana ati ādi vutta ppakāraḥ attho sambhavati iti iti tasmā tena pariyāyena ati  manaḥ samphassa ja pariyāyena tatojā api iti pañca dvārika phassa jātā api añña ppakāra asambhavato ti
translated: But in the case of the five-door impact, the meaning stated thus: “The expression ‘cognizable’ is used by way of the fact that it is what is cognized” is applicable.

original: paṭighasamphassajapariyāyassa asambhavato. Āveṇikaṃ paṭighasamphassajatā. Pakārantaraṃ🔽adhivacanasamphassajatā.🔽Yadi evanti yadi pañcadvārikaphassehi uppannasaññā pariyāyato nippariyāyato ca “adhivacanasamphassajā”ti
analyzed: paṭigha samphassa ja pariyāyassa asambhavataḥ āveṇikam paṭigha samphassa ja tā pakāra antaram  adhivacana samphas saja tā  yadi evam ti yadi pañca dvārika phassehi uppanna saññā pariyāyataḥ nippariyāyataḥ ca adhivacana samphassa jāti
translated: ‘In that way’: therefore. ‘By that method’: by the method of mind-contact. ‘Born of that’: born of the five-door impact. ‘Because there is no other way’: because there is no other way of construing the expression ‘born of resistance.’ ‘The unique’: the born-of-resistance that is not shared by the other. ‘Another kind’: the born-of-contact that is different.

original: vuccanti, evaṃ cattāropi arūpino khandhā evaṃ vattuṃ yuttā. Evaṃ sante saññāva kasmā
analyzed: vuccanti evam cattāraḥ api arūpino khandhāḥ evam vattum yuttāḥ evam sante saññā ava kasmā
translated: ‘If that is so’: if the perception arisen through the five-door impact is called ‘born of contact’ both by way of the method and by way of the unique, then the four immaterial aggregates are also suitable to be called thus. If that is so, why is only perception called ‘born of contact’?

original: “adhivacanasamphassajā”ti vuttāti āha “tiṇṇaṃ khandhāna”ntiādi. Tattha tiṇṇaṃ khandhānanti
analyzed: adhivacana samphassa jāti vuttā ti āha tiṇṇam khandhānam tiādi tattha tiṇṇam khandhānam ti
translated: ‘Because of the three aggregates’ and so on. Herein, ‘because of the three aggregates’ means because of the three aggregates of feeling, perception, and formations.

original: vedanāsaṅkhāraviññāṇakkhandhānaṃ. Atthavasenāti “vacanaṃ adhikicca pavattā adhivacanā”tiādinā
analyzed: vedanā saṅkhāra viññāṇa kkhandhānam attha vasena ati vacanam adhikicca pavattā adhivacana ati ādinā
translated: and of the other three aggregates. By way of meaning: by way of the meaning stated thus: “Words that occur by way of predominance of statement are terms-of-reference” ,

original: vuttaatthavasena anvatthatāvasena. Attano pattampi nāmanti “adhivacanasamphassajā”ti🔽evaṃ attano anuppattampi nāmaṃ. Dhammābhilāpoti sabhāvanirutti. Pubbe catunnaṃ arūpakkhandhānaṃ
analyzed: vutta attha vasena anvattha tā vasena attano pattam pi adhivacana samphassa jāti  evam attanaḥ an uppattam pi nāmam dhamma abhilāpo ti sa bhāva nirutti pubbe catunnam arūpa kkhandhānam
translated: and by way of the meaning of the words “terms-of-reference” . By way of its own occurrence: by way of what occurs as its own occurrence, namely, “born of contact accompanied by terms-of-reference” .🔽The expression of dhammas: the expression of individual essences. Of the four immaterial aggregates

original: sādhāraṇopi adhivacanasamphassajavohāro ruḷhivasena saññāya eva pavattoti vatvā idāni
analyzed: sādhāraṇaḥ api adhivacana samphassa ja vohāraḥ ruḷhi vasena saññāya eva pavatto ti vatvā idāni
translated: previously: previously to the time of the arising of the expression of dhammas. The expression of dhammas is common to all four immaterial aggregates. But the expression “born of contact accompanied by terms-of-reference” occurs only by way of perception.

original: so tadaññārūpakkhandhasādhāraṇo saññāya nivesitoti dassetuṃ “atha vā”tiādimāha. Rajjitvā🔽olokanādīsūti ettha ādi-saddena kujjhitvā olokanādi viya rajjitvā savanādipi saṅgayhatīti
analyzed: so tad aññā rūpa kkhandha sādhāraṇaḥ saññāya nivesito ti dassetum atha vā ati ādim āha rajjitvā  olokana ādīsu iti ettha ādi saddena kujjhitvā olokana ādi rajjitvā savana ādi pi saṅgayhati iti
translated: Now, in order to show that that expression, which is common to the four immaterial aggregates, is assigned to perception, he said, “Or alternatively” , etc. Having been excited🔽and having looked, etc.: the word “etc.” should be understood to include having been angered and having looked, etc., and having been excited and having heard, etc.,

original: veditabbaṃ, tathāsotāvadhānādinopi rattatādivijānananimittatāsambhavato. Cakkhusamphassajāsaññāya
analyzed: veditabbam tathā sotāvadhāna ādinaḥ api ratta tā ādi vijānana nimitta tā sambhavataḥ cakkhu samphassa ja asaññāya
translated: because the expression “born of contact accompanied by terms-of-reference” is common to both the looking, etc., and the hearing, etc., and because the state of knowing the excited state, etc., is possible in the case of listening, etc., as well. Perception born of eye-contact

original: pana pākaṭabhāvaṃ nidassanavasena dassetuṃ “olokanaṃ cakkhuviññāṇavisayasamāgame”tiādimāha.
analyzed: pana pākaṭa bhāvam nidassana vasena dassetum olokanam cakkhu viññāṇa visaya samāgama iti ādim āha
translated: But in order to show the state of manifestation he says, “The seeing is the meeting of the eye with the object.”

original: Olokanassa apākaṭabhāve rattatādivijānanaṃ na hoti, pākaṭabhāve ca hotīti āha “pasādavatthukā🔽evā”ti. “Aññaṃ cintenta”nti yaṃ pubbe tena kathitaṃ, kāyena vā pakāsitaṃ, tato aññaṃ
analyzed: olokanassa apākaṭa bhāve ratta tā ādi vijānanam na hoti pākaṭa bhāve ca hoti iti āha pasāda vatthukā  eva ati aññam cintentanti yam pubbe tena kathitam kāyena vā pakāsitam tatas aññam
translated: When the seeing is not manifest, there is no cognizing of the object, etc., but when it is manifest there is. That is why he says “It is only the condition for the arising of the consciousness that has the clarity as its object.”

original: kiñci atthaṃ cintentaṃ. Tenevāha “ñāta”nti.
analyzed: kiñci attham cintentam tena iva āha ñāta nti
translated: “Thinking of something else” is what was said above, which is made clear by the body, and thinking of something else than that. That is why he says “known.”

original: Saññākkhandhaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: saññā kkhandha niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of the perception aggregate is ended.

original: 4. Saṅkhārakkhandhaniddesavaṇṇanā🔽20. “Heṭṭhimakoṭiyāti etthā”ti idaṃ paṭhamaṃ “heṭṭhimakoṭiyā”ti vacanaṃ sandhāya🔽vuttaṃ. Tassa hi bhummavasena attho gahetabbo. Tenāha “tattha hi padhānaṃ dassita”nti.
analyzed: saṅkhāra khandha niddesa vaṇṇanā  heṭṭhima koṭiyā ti ettha ati idam paṭhamam heṭṭhima koṭiyā iti vacanam sandhāya  vuttam tassa hi bhumma vasena atthaḥ gahetabbo tena āha tattha hi padhānam dassitan ti
translated: The description of the formations aggregate🔽Herein, “in the first place” is said with reference to the first occurrence of the word “end” .🔽For its meaning should be taken as locative. That is why he says “for the exertion is shown there.”

original: Heṭṭhimakoṭiyāva padhānaṃ dassitanti imamatthaṃ gahetvā “yadi eva”ntiādinā codeti.
analyzed: heṭṭhima koṭiyā va padhānam dassitam ti imam attham gahetvā yadi eva nti ādinā codeti
translated: Taking the meaning of the first occurrence of the word “end” as “the exertion is shown at the end,” he objects in the passage beginning, “If that is so.”

original: Itaro “heṭṭhimakoṭiyā padhānameva dassita”nti evamettha niyamo gahetabboti dassento🔽“uparimakoṭigatabhāvenā”tiādinā taṃ pariharati. Padhānasseva dassanaṃ. Padhāne hi
analyzed: itaraḥ heṭṭhima koṭiyā padhānam eva dassitanti evam ettha niyamaḥ gahetabbo ti dassento  uparima koṭi gata bhāvena ati ādinā tam pariharati padhānassa iva dassanam padhāne hi
translated: The other party says: “Only the lower end is shown.” The intention of the author of the commentary is to show that the restriction should be understood thus.🔽He answers: “By the fact that the lower end is shown, etc.” The meaning is: by the fact that the lower end is shown, the upper end is also shown.

original: dassite appadhānampi atthato dassitameva hotīti. Tenāha aṭṭhakathāyaṃ “taṃsampayuttasaṅkhārā
analyzed: dassite appadhānam pi atthataḥ dassitam eva hoti iti tena āha aṭṭhakathā ayam tad sampayutta saṅkhārā
translated: For when the lower end is shown, the upper end is shown too. Therefore it is said in the commentary: “The formations associated with it are also included when it is included.”

original: pana tāya gahitāya gahitāva hontī”ti. Yaṃ heṭṭhimakoṭiyaṃ labbhati, taṃ uparimakoṭiyampi
analyzed: pana tāya gahitāya gahitāḥ ava honti iti yam heṭṭhima koṭiyam labbhati tam uparima koṭiyam pi
translated: What is found at the lower end is also found at the upper end. Therefore it is said: “The lower end is all-pervading.”

original: labbhati evāti āha “heṭṭhimakoṭi hi sabbabyāpikā”ti. Dutiye karaṇaniddesataṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: labbhati evā ti āha heṭṭhima koṭi hi sabba byāpikā iti dutiye karaṇa niddesa tam dassetuṃ
translated: In the second case, the word “comes” is used to show the instrumental case.

original: “āgatāti sambandho”ti āha. Āgamanakiriyā hi heṭṭhimakoṭiyā karaṇabhāvena tattha vuttāti.
analyzed: āgatā iti sambandhaḥ iti āha āgamana kiriyā hi heṭṭhima koṭiyā karaṇa bhāvena tattha vuttā ti
translated: For the action of coming is mentioned there in the instrumental case.

original: Yathā ca āgamanakiriyāya, evaṃ vacanakiriyāyapi heṭṭhimakoṭiyā karaṇabhāvo sambhavatīti
analyzed: yathā ca āgamana kiriyāya evam vacana kiriyāya api heṭṭhima koṭiyā karaṇa bhāvaḥ sambhavati iti
translated: And just as the action of coming, so also the action of speaking is possible in the instrumental case.

original: dassetuṃ “purimepi vā”tiādimāha. “Ekūnapaññāsappabhede”ti idaṃ lokiyacittuppāde pāḷiāgatānaṃ🔽saṅkhārakkhandhadhammānaṃ uparimakoṭiṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Yevāpanakadhammehi saddhiṃ🔽uparimakoṭiyā gayhamānāya “tepaññāsā”ti vattabbaṃ siyā, lokuttaracittuppādavasena
analyzed: dassetum purime api vā tiādim āha ekūna paññāsa pabhede ti idam lokiya cittuppāde  saṅkhāra kkhandha dhammānam uparima koṭim sandhāya vuttam yevāpanaka dhammehi saddhim  uparima koṭiyā gayhamānāya te paññāsā ati vattabbam siyā lokuttara cittuppāda vasena
translated: In order to show this, he says, “Or else, in the forty-nine classes of consciousness,” etc. “In the forty-nine classes of consciousness” is said with reference to the highest number of formations belonging to the classes of mundane consciousness mentioned in the texts.🔽If the highest number were taken together with the formations belonging to the unwholesome consciousness,🔽it would be necessary to say “fifty.”🔽

original: pana “sattapaññāsā”ti.
analyzed: pana satta paññāsā ati
translated: In order to show this, he says, “Or else, in the forty-nine kinds of consciousness,” etc. The words “in the forty-nine kinds of consciousness” are said with reference to the highest number of formations belonging to the classes of states given in the texts as occurring in the kinds of mundane consciousness. If the highest number were taken together with the states belonging to the classes of states not given in the texts, the number would be fifty. But with the kinds of supramundane consciousness the number is fifty-seven.

original: Saṅkhārakkhandhaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: saṅkhāra khandha niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The exposition of the formations aggregate is ended.

original: Pakiṇṇakakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: pakiṇṇaka kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the miscellaneous section

original: Samuggama-padassa tatvato pariyāyato ca atthaṃ dasseti “sañjātiyaṃ ādiuppattiya”nti.🔽Bhedato pana samāyoge uggamananti. Tattha kena samāyoge, kuto, kathañca uggamananti
analyzed: samuggama padassa ca attham dasseti sañjātiyam ādi uppattiyanti  bhedato pana samāyoge uggamananti tattha kena samāyoge kutas kathañca uggamananti
translated: The meaning of the word samuggama is shown in the words “in the sense of arising, origination, coming-to-be” in the sense of the ultimate and the conventional. But in the sense of the ultimate it is the arising of the aggregates in the sense of the coming together of the aggregates.🔽The meaning of the word samuggama in the sense of the conventional is shown in the words “in the sense of arising, origination, coming-to-be” in the sense of the coming together of the aggregates.🔽The meaning of the word samuggama in the sense of the conventional is shown in the words “in the sense of arising, origination, coming-to-be” in the sense of the coming together of the aggregates.🔽The meaning of the word samuggama in the sense of the conventional is shown in the words “in the sense of arising, origination, coming-to-be” in the sense of the coming together of the aggregates.🔽The meaning of the word samuggama in the sense of the conventional is shown in the words “in the sense of arising, origination, coming-to-be” in the sense of the coming together of the aggregates.🔽The meaning of the word samuggama in the sense of the conventional is shown in the words “in the sense of arising, origination, coming-to-be” in the sense of the coming together of the aggregates.

original: vicāraṇāyaṃ āha “taṃtaṃpaccayasamāyoge”tiādi. Tatthevāti pañcavokārabhave eva. Tattha🔽hi pañcakkhandhā paripuṇṇā samuggacchanti. Yathādhigatānaṃ adhigatappakārānaṃ, paṭisandhikānanti
analyzed: āha tat tat paccaya samāyoga itiādi tattha iva ati pañcavokāra bhave eva tattha 🔽hi pañca khandhā paripuṇṇā samuggacchanti yathā adhigatānam adhigata ppakārānam paṭisandhikānam ti
translated: The meaning of the word samuggama in the sense of the conventional is shown in the words “in the sense of arising, origination, coming-to-be” in the sense of the coming together of the aggregates.🔽The meaning of the word samuggama in the sense of the conventional is shown in the words “in the sense of arising, origination, coming-to-be” in the

original: attho. Opapātikasamuggameneva cettha saṃsedajasamuggamopi gahitoti daṭṭhabbo pañcakkhandhapariyāpannānaṃ
analyzed: atthaḥ opapātika samuggamena iva ca ittha saṃseda ja samuggamaḥ api gahito ti daṭṭhabbo pañca kkhandha pariyāpannānam
translated: and meaning. And the egg-born should be understood to be included by the “born by apparition” kind, since those who are capable of arising then arise in the five-constituent kind.

original: tadā uppajjanārahānaṃ uppajjanato. Tattha saṃsedajā uppajjitvā vaḍḍhanti, itare na
analyzed: tadā uppajjana arahānam uppajjanataḥ tattha saṃseda jāḥ uppajjitvā vaḍḍhanti itare na
translated: Herein, the egg-born grow after arising, but not the rest.

original: vaḍḍhantīti idametesaṃ nānākaraṇaṃ. Sukhumajātiyalomā eva kira keci eḷakā himavante🔽vijjanti, tesaṃ lomaṃ sandhāya “jātimantaeḷakaloma”nti vuttaṃ atisukhumattā tesaṃ🔽lomānaṃ. Keci pana “ajapākatikeḷakādīhi saṅkararahitānaṃ tesaṃ eḷakavisesānaṃ nibbatteḷakassa
analyzed: vaḍḍhanti iti idam etesam nānākaraṇam eva kira keci eḷakāḥ himavante  vijjanti tesam lomam sandhāya vuttam ati sukhuma ttā tesam  lomānam keci pana aja pākatika iḷaka ādīhi saṅkara rahitānam tesam eḷaka visesānam nibbatta iḷakassa
translated: This is the difference between them. It seems that there are certain goats in the Himalayas whose hair is so fine that it is called “wool of the Himalayan goat” .🔽But others say that it is the wool of a special kind of goat that is born in the Himalayas, which is unmixed with that of the ajapāka, the keḷaka, and so on, and that it is the wool of the goat born at that time.

original: lomaṃ jātiuṇṇā, tampi taṅkhaṇanibbattassā”ti vadanti. Gabbhaṃ phāletvā gahitassāti
analyzed: lomam jāti uṇṇā tam pi taṅkhaṇa nibbattassa ati vadanti gabbham phāletvā gahitassa ati
translated: Others say it is the wool of the goat taken while still in the womb.

original: apare. Evaṃsaṇṭhānanti jātiuṇṇaṃsuno paggharitvā agge ṭhitatelabindusaṇṭhānaṃ. Vaṇṇappaṭibhāgoti
analyzed: apare evaṃsaṇṭhānam ti jāti uṇṇa ṃsuno paggharitvā agge ṭhita tela bindu saṇṭhānam vaṇṇa ppaṭibhāgaḥ ti
translated: Such is its shape: it is the shape of a drop of oil standing on the tip of a blade of grass after the rest has been wiped off.

original: rūpapaṭicchanno saṇṭhānapaṭicchanno ca.
analyzed: rūpa paṭicchannaḥ saṇṭhāna paṭicchannaḥ ca
translated: Its colour and appearance: it is covered by skin and it has an appearance.

original: Santatimūlānīti tasmiṃ bhave rūpasantatiyā mūlabhūtāni. Anekindriyasamāhārabhāvatoti yathārahaṃ cakkhādianekindriyasaṅghātabhāvato. Padhānaṅganti uttamaṅgaṃ siro.
analyzed: santati mūlāni iti tasmin bhave rūpa santatiyāḥ mūla bhūtāni aneka indriya samāhāra bhāvataḥ ti yathāraham cakkha ādi aneka indriya saṅghāta bhāvataḥ uttama aṅgam siro
translated: “Roots of continuity” are what are rooted in the material continuity in that becoming. “Because of the combination of many faculties” means because of the combination of many faculties such as the eye, etc., as appropriate. “The head is the most important part” means the most important part.

original: Na tassa tassa khandhassa paripuṇṇataṃ, taṃtaṃkhandhekadesasseva vuttattāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: na tassa tassa khandhassa paripuṇṇa tat tad tad khandha ekadesassa iva vutta ttā ti adhippāyo
translated: The intention is that it is not the fullness of each of the aggregates that is referred to, but only a part of each aggregate.

original: Kāmāvacarānanti kāmāvacarasattānaṃ. Parihīnāyatanassāti parihīnassa cakkhādiāyatanassa🔽vasena. Tattha duggatiyaṃ andhassa cakkhudasakavasena, badhirassa sotadasakavasena,
analyzed: kāmāvacara ānanti kāmāvacara sattānam parihīna āyatanassa ati parihīnassa cakkhu ādi āyatanassa  vasena tattha duggatiyam andhassa cakkhu dasaka vasena badhirassa sota dasaka vasena
translated: “Of beings in the sense-sphere” means of beings in the sense-sphere existence. “Because of the loss of a sense-sphere” means because of the loss of an eye-sphere, etc.🔽There, in the lower realms, the loss of continuity of the head should be understood in the case of the blind by way of the eye, in the case of the deaf by way of the ear,

original: andhabadhirassa ubhayavasena santatisīsahāni veditabbā. Napuṃsakassa pana bhāvahāni
analyzed: andha badhirassa ubhaya vasena santati sīsa hāni veditabbā napuṃsakassa pana bhāva hāni
translated: and in the case of the blind and deaf by way of both. But the loss of the state of being a neuter is

original: vuttā eva. Tathā andhabadhirāghānakassa cakkhusotaghānavasena. Taṃ pana dhammahadayavibhaṅgapāḷiyā
analyzed: vuttāḥ eva tathā andha badhira āghānakassa cakkhu sota ghāna vasena tam pana dhamma hadaya vibhaṅga pāḷiyā
translated: already mentioned. Likewise, in the case of the blind, deaf, and mute, it is by way of the eye, ear, and nose. But that contradicts the text of the Dhamm- hadayavibhanga,

original: virujjhati. Taṃ parato āvi bhavissati. Rūpāvacarānaṃ pana cakkhusotavatthujīvitavasena
analyzed: virujjhati tam paratas bhavissati rūpāvacarānam pana cakkhu sota vatthu jīvita vasena
translated: which will be explained later. But in the case of beings in the fine-material sphere, it is by way of the eye, ear, and life faculty.

original: cattāri santatisīsānīti itaresaṃ vasena santatisīsahāni veditabbā.
analyzed: cattāri santati sīsāni iti itaresam vasena santati sīsahāni veditabbā
translated: The four are the “roots of continuity” in the sense of the other three.🔽“The five aggregates” : the five aggregates of the past, future, and present.

original: Tesanti pañcannaṃ khandhānaṃ. Vatthubhāvenāti vicāraṇāya adhiṭṭhānabhāvena. Paṭisandhiyaṃ
analyzed: tesanti pañcannam khandhānam vatthu bhāvena ati vicāraṇāya adhiṭṭhāna bhāvena paṭisandhiyam
translated: “As the basis” : as the foundation for the act of reflection.

original: uppannā pavattā pañcakkhandhāti paṭisandhikkhaṇe pavattikkhaṇe ca pañcakkhandhe dasseti.
analyzed: uppannā pavattā pañca kkhandhā ti paṭisandhi khaṇe pavatti khaṇe ca pañca kkhandhe dasseti
translated: “The five aggregates arisen in the rebirth-linking and the five aggregates arisen in the process of existence” : he shows the five aggregates at the moment of rebirth-linking and the five aggregates at the moment of the process of existence.🔽“The designation of the plane” : the designation of the plane is “in the five aggregates.”

original: Bhummaniddesoti “pañcasu khandhesū”ti ayaṃ bhummaniddeso. Aññathāti niddhāraṇe anadhippete.
analyzed: bhumma niddeso ti pañcasu khandhesu uti ayam bhumma niddesaḥ aññathā ati niddhāraṇe anadhippete
translated: “Otherwise” : without the specification.

original: “Bhāvenabhāvalakkhaṇatthe”ti idaṃ visayādiatthānaṃ idhāsambhavato vuttaṃ. Ubhayanti
analyzed: bhāvena bhāva lakkhaṇa tthā iti idam visaya ādi atthānam idha asambhavataḥ vuttam ubhayam ti
translated: “In the sense of the characteristic of non-existence and existence” : this is said because the other meanings of the word bhāva, such as object, etc., are not applicable here.🔽“Both” : materiality and immateriality.

original: rūpārūpaṃ. Rūpārūpasantatinti rūpasamuṭṭhāpakaṃ rūpasantatiṃ arūpasantatiñca. “Vatthu🔽uppādakkhaṇe dubbalaṃ hotī”ti idaṃ na paṭisandhikkhaṇaṃ eva, nāpi vatthurūpaṃ eva
analyzed: rūpa arūpam rūpa arūpa santatim ti rūpa samuṭṭhāpakam rūpa santatim arūpa santatim ca vatthu  uppāda khaṇe dubbalam hoti iti idam na paṭisandhi khaṇam eva na api vatthu rūpam eva
translated: “The continuity of materiality and the continuity of the immaterial” : the continuity of materiality that produces materiality and the continuity of the immaterial.🔽“The basis is weak at the moment of arising” : he says this in order to show that this is not said only in regard to the moment of rebirth-linking or to materiality as basis.

original: sandhāya vuttanti dassento āha “sabbarūpānaṃ uppādakkhaṇe dubbalataṃ sandhāya vutta”nti.
analyzed: sandhāya vuttanti dassentaḥ āha sabba rūpānam uppāda kkhaṇe dubbala tam sandhāya vuttanti
translated: “The weakness of all materiality at the moment of arising is meant.”

original: “Tadā hī”tiādi yathāvuttassa atthassa kāraṇavacanaṃ. Tattha tanti rūpaṃ. “Kammakkhittattā”ti
analyzed: tadā hi itiādi yathā vuttassa atthassa kāraṇa vacanam tattha tanti rūpam
translated: “Then” , etc., is a statement of the reason for the meaning stated thus. Herein, “that” is materiality. “Because it is hurled by kamma” :

original: idaṃ na kammajatāmattaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ, atha kho kammajassa paṭhamuppattiyaṃ apatiṭṭhitataṃ
analyzed: idam na kamma ja tā mattam sandhāya vuttam atha kho kamma jassa paṭhama uppattiyam apatiṭṭhita taṃ
translated: this is not said with reference to mere kamma-bornness, but rather with reference to the non-establishment of the first arising of what is kamma-born.

original: sandhāyāti dassento “satipī”tiādimāha. Tato paranti tato paṭisandhito paraṃ. Sadisasantāne
analyzed: sandhāya iti dassentaḥ sati pi itiādim āha tatas paranti tatas paṭisandhitaḥ param sadisa santāne
translated: Showing this, he says, “Even though” , etc. “Thereafter” : after rebirth-linking. In a homogeneous continuity

original: yathā patiṭṭhitaṃ, na tathā visadisasantāneti āha “samānasantatiya”nti.
analyzed: yathā patiṭṭhitam na tathā visadisa santānā iti āha samāna santatiyanti
translated: it is not established in the same way as in a heterogeneous continuity. That is why he says “in a homogeneous continuity” .

original: Aṅgabhāvanti kāraṇabhāvaṃ. Tenevāha “sahāyabhāva”nti. Tesaṃ dhammānanti yehi saddhiṃ
analyzed: aṅga bhāvanti kāraṇa bhāvam tena iva āha sahāya bhāvanti tesam yehi saddhim
translated: “As a condition” : as a cause. Hence he says “as a companion” . “Those states” : those that arise

original: uppannaṃ, tesaṃ paṭisandhiyaṃ cittacetasikadhammānaṃ. Tadāti ṭhitikkhaṇe bhaṅgakkhaṇe
analyzed: uppannam tesam paṭisandhiyam citta cetasika dhammānam tadā ti ṭhiti khaṇe bhaṅga kkhaṇe
translated: together with it. “Those states of consciousness and its concomitants at rebirth-linking” : the states of consciousness and its concomitants at the moment of rebirth-linking. “Then” : at the moment of presence and at the moment of dissolution

original: ca rūpuppādanameva natthi. Anantarādipaccayalābhena uppādakkhaṇe eva cittassa balavabhāvo,
analyzed: ca rūpa uppādanam eva natthi anantara ādi paccaya lābhena uppāda kkhaṇe eva cittassa balava bhāvaḥ
translated: there is no production of materiality at all. At the moment of arising, which is the acquisition of the conditionality of the proximate cause, etc., consciousness is strong,

original: na itaratra. Tenāha “yadā ca rūpuppādanaṃ, tadā uppādakkhaṇe”ti.
analyzed: na itaratra tena āha yadā ca rūpa uppādanam tadā uppāda khaṇa iti
translated: not elsewhere. Hence he says, “When there is production of materiality, then at the moment of arising” .

original: Yehākārehīti āhārindriyapaccayādiākārehi. Yathāsambhavaṃ paccayā hontīti phassādayo🔽āhārādivasena yathārahaṃ paccayā honti. Vuttañhetaṃ paṭṭhāne “paṭisandhikkhaṇe vipākābyākatā
analyzed: yehi ākārehi iti āhāra indriya paccaya ādi ākārehi yathāsambhavam paccayāḥ honti iti phassa ādayaḥ  āhāra ādi vasena yathāraham paccayāḥ honti vuttam ha etam paṭṭhāne paṭisandhi khaṇe
translated: By what mode? By the mode of nutriment, faculty, condition, etc. They are conditions in whatever way is appropriate.

original: āhārā sampayuttakānaṃ khandhānaṃ, kaṭattā ca rūpānaṃ āhārapaccayena paccayo”tiādi.
analyzed: āhārā sampayuttakānam khandhānam kaṭattā ca rūpānam āhāra paccayena paccayaḥ tiādi
translated: For it is said in the Paṭṭhāna: “At the moment of rebirth-linking, the resultant indeterminate nutriments are a condition, as nutriment condition, for the associated aggregates and for the kinds of materiality originated by kamma” (Patth I 1).

original: Cuticittena saddhiṃ uppajjamānaṃ, cuticittena vā kāraṇabhūtena uppajjamānaṃ. Tato
analyzed: cuti cittena saddhim uppajjamānam cuti cittena vā kāraṇa bhūtena uppajjamānam tatas
translated: “Arisen together with the death consciousness” means arisen together with the death consciousness, or arisen by way of the death consciousness as a cause.

original: purimatarehi uppajjamānaṃ viyāti yathā cuticittato āsannehi purimatarehi uppajjamānaṃ
analyzed: purimatarehi uppajjamānam viyāti yathā cuti cittataḥ āsannehi purimatarehi uppajjamānam
translated: “Like that arisen earlier” means like that arisen earlier, as in the case of the materiality arisen earlier to the death consciousness.

original: rūpaṃ bhavantare na uppajjati, evaṃ cuticittena uppajjamānampi anupacchinnepi vaṭṭamūleti
analyzed: rūpam bhava antare na uppajjati evam cuti cittena uppajjamānam api anupacchinne pi vaṭṭa mūla iti
translated: Just as the materiality arisen earlier to the death consciousness does not arise in the next becoming, so also that arisen together with the death consciousness.

original: akāraṇaṃ vaṭṭamūlāvūpasamo cuticittassa rūpuppādaneti dasseti.
analyzed: akāraṇam cuti cittassa rūpa uppādanā iti dasseti
translated: The meaning is that the cessation of the root of the round is not a condition for the arising of materiality in the next becoming, even though the round is not cut off.

original: Arūpassāti āruppassa.
analyzed: arūpassa ati āruppassa
translated: “Of the immaterial” means of the immaterial state.

original: Utunāti paṭisandhicittassa ṭhitikkhaṇe uppannena utunā. Samuṭṭhite rūpeti paṭisandhicittassa
analyzed: utunā ati paṭisandhi cittassa ṭhiti kkhaṇe uppannena utunā samuṭṭhite rūpe iti paṭisandhi cittassa
translated: “By temperature” means by temperature arisen at the moment of the life-continuum consciousness. “Materiality originated” means materiality originated by the life-continuum consciousness.

original: bhaṅgakkhaṇe rūpe samuṭṭhite paṭisandhianantaraṃ paṭhamabhavaṅgacittaṃ rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti.
analyzed: bhaṅga kkhaṇe rūpe samuṭṭhite paṭisandhi anantaram paṭhama bhavaṅga cittam rūpam samuṭṭhāpeti
translated: At the moment of dissolution, when materiality has arisen, the first life-continuum consciousness that arises next to the rebirth-linking consciousness causes the materiality to arise.

original: Uppādanirodhakkhaṇāti yathāvuttesu soḷasasu cittesu ādicittassa uppādakkhaṇo, soḷasamacittassa
analyzed: uppāda nirodha khaṇā ti yathā vuttesu soḷasasu cittesu ādi cittassa uppāda kkhaṇo soḷasama cittassa
translated: The moment of arising and the moment of dissolution: they say that the moment of arising of the first of the sixteen kinds of consciousness is the moment of dissolution of the sixteenth.

original: nirodhakkhaṇo cāti vadanti, rūpasseva pana uppādanirodhakkhaṇā veditabbā.🔽Dharamānakkhaṇe evāti tassa utuno vijjamānakkhaṇe eva yadi gahitā, “soḷasacittakkhaṇāyukaṃ
analyzed: nirodha khaṇo ca ati vadanti rūpassa iva pana uppāda nirodha kkhaṇā veditabbā  dharamāna khaṇe eva ati tassa utunaḥ vijjamāna kkhaṇe eva yadi gahitā soḷasa cittakkhaṇa āyukam
translated: But the moment of arising and the moment of dissolution should be understood as applying to materiality only.🔽At the moment of presence: if the moment of presence of that materiality is taken as the moment of presence of the temperature, then it is said that the materiality lasts for sixteen moments of consciousness.

original: rūpa”nti vuttaṃ hoti soḷasaheva cittehi tassa dharamānatāya paricchinnattā. Uppādakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: rūpanti vuttam hoti soḷasahā iva cittehi tassa dharamāna tāya paricchinna ttā uppāda kkhaṇam
translated: For it is delimited by the sixteen kinds of consciousness that are present during that time.

original: aggahetvāti utuno dharamānakkhaṇe uppādakkhaṇaṃ aggahetvā nirodhakkhaṇo atha gahito,
analyzed: aggahetvā ti utunaḥ dharamāna khaṇe uppāda kkhaṇam aggahetvā nirodha kkhaṇaḥ atha gahitaḥ
translated: Without taking the moment of arising: if the moment of dissolution is taken without taking the moment of arising of the materiality at the moment of its presence,

original: “sattarasacittakkhaṇāyukaṃ rūpa”nti vuttaṃ hoti uppādakkhaṇasahitena ca ekassa cittakkhaṇassa
analyzed: satta rasa cittakkhaṇa āyukam rūpanti vuttam hoti uppāda kkhaṇa sahitena ca ekassa cittakkhaṇassa
translated: then it is said that the materiality lasts for seventeen moments of consciousness. And the moment of arising of the materiality is included in the moment of presence of the temperature.

original: gahitattā. “Adhikasoḷasacittakkhaṇāyuka”nti vuttaṃ hoti nirodhakkhaṇassa bahikatattā.
analyzed: gahita ttā adhika soḷasa cittakkhaṇa āyukanti vuttam hoti nirodha kkhaṇassa
translated: because it is included. What is meant is that it has a life of sixteen or more thought-moments, excluding the moment of cessation.

original: Evaṃ uppādanirodhakkhaṇesu gahitesu aggahitesu ca soḷasasattarasacittakkhaṇāyukatā,🔽tato adhikacittakkhaṇāyukatā ca siyāti dassetvā idāni tattha ṭhitapakkhaṃ dassento
analyzed: evam uppāda nirodha khaṇesu gahitesu aggahitesu ca soḷasa satta rasa cittakkhaṇa āyuka tā  tatas adhika citta khaṇa āyuka tā ca siyā ti dassetvā idāni tattha ṭhita pakkham dassento
translated: So when the moments of arising and cessation are included and not included, it has a life of seventeen or sixteen thought-moments,

original: “yasmā panā”tiādimāha. Tattha tassa dharamānakkhaṇe uppannesūti tassa utuno dharamānakkhaṇe
analyzed: yasmā pana ati ādim āha tattha tassa dharamāna kkhaṇe uppannesu iti tassa utuno dharamāna kkhaṇe
translated: and more than that. Having shown this, he now said “But since” in order to show the side on which he stands. Herein, in the moments of its presence, when they have arisen: in the moments of the presence of that season,🔽when the sixteen kinds of consciousness have arisen, since the rebirth-linking is included,

original: uppannesu soḷasasu cittesu paṭisandhipi yasmā gahitā, tasmā utuno uppādakkhaṇo dharamānakkhaṇe
analyzed: uppannesu soḷasasu cittesu yasmai gahitā tasmai utuno uppāda kkhaṇaḥ dharamāna kkhaṇe
translated: therefore the moment of arising of the season is included in the moment of its presence.

original: gahitoti nirodhakkhaṇe aggahite “rūpe dharanteyeva soḷasa cittāni uppajjitvā nirujjhanti,
analyzed: gahitoti nirodha kkhaṇe aggahite rūpe soḷasa cittāni uppajjitvā nirujjhanti
translated: When the moment of cessation is not included, “sixteen kinds of consciousness arise and cease in the presence of materiality,

original: taṃ pana sattarasamena cittena saddhiṃ nirujjhatī”ti evaṃ aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vakkhamānā
analyzed: tam pana sattarasamena cittena saddhim nirujjhati iti evam aṭṭhakathā ayam vakkhamānā
translated: but that ceases together with the seventeenth kind of consciousness.” So it will be said in the commentary.

original: adhikasoḷasacittakkhaṇāyukatā adhippetā. Gahite vā nirodhakkhaṇe soḷasacittakkhaṇāyukatā🔽adhippetāti sambandho. Ettha ca “adhikasoḷasacittakkhaṇāyukatā”ti idaṃ paṭisandhicittassa
analyzed: adhika soḷasa cittakkhaṇa āyuka tā adhippetā gahite vā nirodha kkhaṇe soḷasa cittakkhaṇa āyuka tā  adhippetā iti sambandhaḥ ettha ca adhika soḷasa cittakkhaṇa āyuka tā ti idam paṭisandhi cittassa
translated: What is intended is that it lasts for more than sixteen thought-moments. Or else the meaning can be construed as follows: “What is intended is that it lasts for sixteen thought-moments at the moment of cessation when it is apprehended.”🔽And here the words “lasts for more than sixteen thought-moments” are said taking the moment of arising of the rebirth-linking consciousness.

original: uppādakkhaṇo gahitoti katvā vuttaṃ. Yasmā pana paṭiccasamuppādavibhaṅgavaṇṇanāyaṃ🔽“dve bhavaṅgāni, āvajjanaṃ, dassanaṃ, sampaṭicchanaṃ, santīraṇaṃ, voṭṭhabbanaṃ, pañca
analyzed: uppāda khaṇaḥ gahito ti katvā vuttam yasmā pana paṭiccasamuppāda vibhaṅga vaṇṇanā ayam  dve bhavaṅgāni āvajjanam dassanam sampaṭicchanam santīraṇam voṭṭhabbanam pañca
translated: But since in the description of dependent origination it is said:

original: javanāni, dve tadārammaṇāni, ekaṃ cuticittanti pañcadasa cittakkhaṇā atītā honti,🔽athāvasesaekacittakkhaṇāyuke”ti, tathā tadārammaṇapariyosānāni, “ekaṃ cuticittaṃ,
analyzed: javanāni dve tad ārammaṇāni ekam cuti cittanti pañcadasa cittakkhaṇāḥ atītāḥ honti  atha avasesa eka citta kkhaṇa āyukā iti tathā tad ārammaṇa pariyosānāni ekam cuti cittam
translated: “Two life-continua, adverting, seeing, receiving, investigating, determining, five impulsions, two registration conscious- nesses, and one death consciousness—fifteen thought-moments have passed,🔽and then the rest in one thought-moment,”

original: tadavasāne tasmiññeva ekacittakkhaṇaṭṭhitike ārammaṇe paṭisandhicittaṃ uppajjatī”ti
analyzed: tad avasāne tasmin ñeva eka citta khaṇa ṭṭhitike ārammaṇe paṭisandhi cittam uppajjati iti
translated: and since it is said that the death consciousness is the last of the registrations, and that the rebirth-linking consciousness arises in the same object-field as the death consciousness, which lasts for only one thought-moment,

original: ca vakkhati. Tasmā rūpassa soḷasacittakkhaṇāyukatāyapi atthasiddhi hotiyeva. Tenāha
analyzed: ca vakkhati tasmā rūpassa attha siddhi tena āha
translated: the meaning of the words “lasts for more than sixteen thought-moments” is established even if matter lasts for sixteen thought-moments. Therefore it is said:

original: “soḷasacittakkhaṇāyukatā adhippetā”ti. Tathāpi uppajjitvā bhavaṅgacalanassa paccayo
analyzed: soḷasa cittakkhaṇa āyuka tā adhippetā ati tathā api uppajjitvā bhavaṅga calanassa paccayo
translated: “What is intended is that it lasts for sixteen thought-moments.” Still, it is a condition for the disturbance of the life-continuum after it has arisen,

original: hoti, na uppajjamānamevāti sattarasacittakkhaṇāyukatā veditabbā.🔽Ojāya sabhāvasukhumatā upādārūpabhāvato. Ettha ca mātarā ajjhohaṭā ojā bāhirabbhañjanaṃ🔽viya gabbhamallinā tasmiṃ santāne ojaṭṭhamakarūpuppattiyā paccayo hoti. Āhārasamuṭṭhānarūpapaveṇiyā
analyzed: hoti na uppajjamānam eva ati satta rasa cittakkhaṇa āyuka tā veditabbā  ojāya sabhāva sukhumatā upādā rūpa bhāvataḥ ettha ca mātarā ajjhohaṭā ojā bāhis abbhañjanam  viya gabbha mallinā tasmin santāne ojaṭṭhamaka rūpa uppattiyā paccayaḥ hoti āhāra samuṭṭhāna rūpa paveṇiyā
translated: but it is not a condition while it is arising. So it should be understood that it lasts for seventeen thought-moments.🔽It is subtle by nature as nutriment, and it is derived matter. And here the nutriment that is ingested by the mother is a condition for the arising of the nutriment-derived materiality in that continuity, as does the nutriment-derived materiality in the stream of the external food.🔽But the nutriment in the rest of the continuity produces materiality by means of the nutriment in the womb, as does the nutriment-derived materiality in the stream of the external nutriment.

original: ojāya viya sesatisantatiojāya rūpuppādananti udariye ojā rūpaṃ na samuṭṭhāpeti utusamuṭṭhānabhāvato,
analyzed: ojāya udariye ojā rūpam na samuṭṭhāpeti utu samuṭṭhāna bhāvato
translated: The nutriment in the womb does not produce materiality, because it is materiality originated by temperature,

original: upādinnakaṭṭhāne eva pana samuṭṭhāpeti, rasaharaṇīhi gantvā kāyānusaṭanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: upādinnaka ṭṭhāne eva pana samuṭṭhāpeti rasaharaṇīhi gantvā veditabbam
translated: but it should be understood that it produces materiality in the place occupied by the appropriated materiality, having gone there by way of the channels that convey nutriment.

original: Cittañcevāti ettha ca-saddena paṭiyogīnaṃ kammameva samuccinoti, na cittena sampayuttadhammeti
analyzed: cittam ca iva āti ettha ca saddena paṭiyogīnam kammam eva samuccinoti na cittena sampayutta dhamma iti
translated: And by the word “and” in the words “And the consciousness” , the counter-correlate is included, namely, kamma only, not the states associated with consciousness.

original: katvā āha “cittassa pubbaṅgamatāya vutta”nti. “Cittuppādaṃ gaṇhāti ‘cittaṃ uppannaṃ🔽hotī’tiādīsu viya, na kammacetanaṃ viya ekadhammamevā”ti vutte “yathā cittasamuṭṭhānarūpassa
analyzed: katvā āha cittassa pubbaṅgama tāya vuttanti cittuppādam gaṇhāti cittam uppannam  hoti itiādīsu viya na kamma cetanam viya eka dhammam eva ati vutte yathā citta samuṭṭhāna rūpassa
translated: and he said: “It is said because of the pre-eminent position of consciousness.” “It is the arising of consciousness that is meant, as in the passage ‘When consciousness has arisen in a being’ , not a single state of consciousness as in the passage ‘With consciousness as condition, mentality-materiality’ . ” “But then the meaning of the words ‘With mentality-materiality as condition, the sixfold base’ is contradicted, since the sixfold base is included in mentality-materiality.”

original: hetuādayo cittasampayuttadhammāpi samuṭṭhāpakāva, evaṃ kammasamuṭṭhānarūpassa kammasampayuttāpī”ti
analyzed: hetu ādayo citta sampayutta dhammā api evam kamma samuṭṭhāna rūpassa kamma sampayuttā api iti
translated: and he says, “It is said because of the pre-eminent position of consciousness.” “It is the arising of consciousness that is meant, not a single state called ‘consciousness,’ as in the passage, ‘When consciousness has arisen …’ ” “Just as the states associated with consciousness are the instigators of the kinds of materiality originated by consciousness, so too are the states associated with kamma the instigators of the kinds of materiality originated by kamma.”

original: codanaṃ samuṭṭhāpetvā tassa parihāraṃ vattuṃ “kammasamuṭṭhānañcā”tiādimāha.🔽Rūpassāti rūpakkhaṇassa, rūpassa vā addhuno. Nayadassanamattaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ paṭisandhikkhaṇe
analyzed: codanam samuṭṭhāpetvā tassa parihāram vattum kamma samuṭṭhānam ca ati ādim āha  rūpassa ati rūpa kkhaṇassa rūpassa vā addhunaḥ naya dassana mattam daṭṭhabbam paṭisandhi kkhaṇe
translated: Having raised this objection, he says, “And the kinds of materiality originated by kamma” in order to answer it.

original: eva rūpārūpadhammānaṃ ekakkhaṇe pātubhāvoti imassa atthassa anadhippetattā. Tenevāha
analyzed: eva rūpa arūpa dhammānam eka kkhaṇe pātubhāvaḥ ti imassa atthassa an adhippeta ttā tena iva āha
translated: “Rūpassa” means “of the materiality-moment” or “of the materiality-phase.” It should be regarded as mere indication, because the meaning “the manifestation of material and immaterial states in a single moment at the moment of rebirth-linking” is not intended. That is why he says,

original: “tato parampi rūpārūpānaṃ sahuppattisabbhāvato”ti. Yathā ca “paṭisandhikkhaṇe evā”ti
analyzed: tatas param pi rūpa arūpānam sahuppatti sabbhāvato ti yathā ca paṭisandhi khaṇe evā ti
translated: “because of the fact that materiality and mentality arise together afterwards too.”

original: niyamo na gahetabbo, evaṃ “ekakkhaṇe eva pātubhāvo”tipi niyamo na gahetabboti dassento
analyzed: niyamaḥ na gahetabbo evam eka khaṇe eva pātubhāvaḥ ti pi niyamaḥ na gahetabbaḥ ti dassento
translated: And just as the restriction “at the moment of rebirth-linking alone” cannot be accepted, so too the restriction “in a single moment alone” cannot be accepted. Showing this, he says,

original: “na paneta”ntiādimāha. Taṃdīpanatthamevāti asamānakālatādīpanatthameva, na sahuppādadīpanatthaṃ.
analyzed: na pana itara iti ādim āha tat dīpana attham eva āti asamāna kāla tā dīpana attham eva na sahuppāda dīpana attham
translated: The meaning of the words “only” and “just” is that the words “at the same time” and “simultaneously” are used only to show that the two things are not of different times, not to show that they arise together.

original: Addhānaparicchedakathā hi ayanti.
analyzed: hi ayanti
translated: The discussion of the delimitation of time is finished.

original: Yadi evanti yathā phalapattāni, evaṃ rūpārūpadhammā yadi dandhalahuparivattino. Asamānaddhattāti🔽atulyakālattā. Nicchiddesūti nibbivaresu. Tena nirantarappavattiṃ eva vibhāveti.
analyzed: yadi evanti yathā phala pattāni evam rūpa arūpa dhammāḥ yadi dandha lahu parivattinaḥ  atulya kāla ttā nicchiddesu iti nibbivaresu tena nirantara ppavattim eva vibhāveti
translated: If that is so, then material and immaterial states would be slow and quick in their occurrence like the leaves of the cotton and palm trees.🔽They are not of the same time,🔽because they are not of the same moment.

original: Ayanti addhānaparicchedakathā. Cittajarūpādīnaṃ na tathā nirantarabhāvena pavatti,🔽yathā kammajarūpānanti āha “kammajarūpappavattiṃ sandhāyā”ti. Kammajarūpānaṃ vā itaresaṃ
analyzed: citta ja rūpa ādīnam na tathā nirantara bhāvena  yathā āha kamma ja rūpa ppavattim sandhāya ati kamma ja rūpānam vā itaresam
translated: In the uninterrupted occurrence of material instances, etc.,🔽the word “occurrence” is used in the sense of the principal,🔽because material instances, etc., do not occur uninterruptedly in the way that material instances produced by kamma do.

original: mūlabhāvato padhānanti “kammajarūpappavattiṃ sandhāyā”ti vuttaṃ. Acittuppādakattā
analyzed: mūla bhāvataḥ padhānan ti kamma ja rūpa ppavattim sandhāya iti vuttam acittuppādaka ttā
translated: Or the word “occurrence” is used in the sense of the principal because material instances produced by kamma are the principal among the material instances, etc.,

original: abyābajjhatāya nirodhasamāpattiyā nibbānapaṭibhāgatā veditabbā. Pade padaṃ akkamitvāti
analyzed: a byābajjha tāya nirodha samāpattiyāḥ nibbāna paṭibhāga tā veditabbā pade padam akkamitvā iti
translated: because the attainment of cessation is similar to Nibbāna in being free from disturbance.

original: lakuṇḍakapādatāya attano akkantapadasamīpe padaṃ nikkhipitvā. Yo hi sīghapadavikkamo
analyzed: lakuṇḍaka pāda tāya attanaḥ akkanta pada samīpe padam nikkhipitvā yaḥ hi sīgha pada vikkamaḥ
translated: For the one who has a quick gait,🔽the one with a hare’s gait, is intended here.

original: lakuṇḍakapādo, so idhādhippetoti āha “lahuṃ lahuṃ akkamitvāti attho”ti. Saheva nirujjhantīti
analyzed: lakuṇḍaka pādo saḥ idha adhippeto ti āha lahum lahum akkamitvā ati saha iva nirujjhanti iti
translated: That is why it is said: “The meaning is: quickly, quickly, he places his foot down.”🔽Together with its cessation:

original: rūpaṃ kammajamidhādhippetanti katvā vuttaṃ. Utujaṃ pana cutito uddhampi pavattati🔽eva. Pubbe vuttanti “rūpassa sattarasacittakkhaṇā, arūpassa tato ekabhāgo”ti evaṃ
analyzed: rūpam kamma jam idha adhippetanti katvā vuttam utu jam pana cutitaḥ uddham pi pavattati  eva pubbe vuttanti rūpassa satta rasa cittakkhaṇāḥ arūpassa tatas eka bhāgaḥ ti evam
translated: because materiality is intended here as kamma-born. But the materiality born of temperature continues even after death.

original: vuttaṃ addhānappakāraṃ.🔽Ekuppādatoti samānuppādato. Samānattho hi ayaṃ eka-saddo. Eko daṭṭhabbākāroti eko
analyzed: vuttam addhānappakāram  eka uppādataḥ ti samāna uppādataḥ samāna atthaḥ hi ayam eka saddaḥ ekaḥ daṭṭhabba ākāraḥ ti ekaḥ
translated: Previously stated: the method of reckoning stated thus:🔽“Materiality, seventeen mind-moments; immateriality, one part of that” .🔽From a single arising: from a single occurrence. For the word eka has the meaning of sama .

original: ñātapariññāya passitabbākāro. Evañhi soḷasākārā siyuṃ, itarathā vīsati, tato adhikā
analyzed: ñāta pariññāya passitabba ākāraḥ evañhi soḷasa ākārā siyuṃ itarathā vīsati tatas adhikā
translated: One mode of seeing: one mode of seeing by way of the full-understanding by seeing .🔽For if it were otherwise, there would be twenty modes, or more than twenty modes.

original: vā ete ākārā bhaveyyuṃ. Tassāti pacchimakammajassa. Heṭṭhā soḷasaketi pariyosānasoḷasakassa
analyzed: vā ete ākārāḥ bhaveyyum tassa ati pacchima kamma jassa heṭṭhā soḷasakā iti pariyosāna soḷasakassa
translated: That: the last kamma-born materiality.🔽In the sixteen below: in the final sixteen.

original: anantarātītasoḷasake. Pacchimassāti tattha pacchimacittassa. Nānānirodhabhāvaṃ viya🔽ekuppādabhāvampi pacchimakammajassa ṭhapane kāraṇaṃ anicchanto “yadi panā”ti sāsaṅkaṃ
analyzed: anantara atīta soḷasake pacchimassa ati tattha pacchima cittassa nānā nirodha bhāvam viya  eka uppāda bhāvam pi pacchima kamma jassa ṭhapane kāraṇam an icchantaḥ yadi panāti sa āsaṅkam
translated: in the sixteen moments that have just passed. ‘Of the last’: of the last consciousness. ‘As if it had the state of a separate cessation’:

original: vadati. “Sabbampī”tiādinā tattha atippasaṅgaṃ dasseti. Vajjetabbaṃ nānuppādaṃ ekanirodhaṃ.
analyzed: vadati sabbam pi itiādinā tattha atippasaṅgam dasseti vajjetabbam na anuppādam eka nirodham
translated: ‘But if’ he says this with doubt, not wanting to give a reason for the placing of the last kamma-born materiality as having a single arising. ‘All’ and so on shows the over-extension of the doubt. ‘It should be rejected’ because of the non-arising of a single cessation.

original: Gahetabbaṃ ekuppādanānānirodhaṃ. Ubhayampi tadā natthi anuppajjanato. Tenevāha “kammajarūpassa🔽anuppattito”ti. Tato pubbeti pacchimakammajarūpuppajjanato oraṃ. Aññassāti yassa🔽cittassa uppādakkhaṇe uppannaṃ, tato aññassa cittassa. Ṭhitikkhaṇe uppannassa ekuppādatā,
analyzed: gahetabbam eka uppāda nānā nirodham ubhayam pi tadā natthi anuppajjanato tena iva āha kamma ja rūpassa  anuppattito ti tatas pubbā iti pacchima kamma ja rūpa uppajjanato aññassa iti yassa  cittassa uppāda kkhaṇe uppannam tatas aññassa cittassa ṭhiti kkhaṇe uppannassa ekuppāda tā
translated: ‘It should be accepted’ because of the single arising and separate cessation. ‘Both are not’ because of non-arising. Hence he said ‘because of the non-arising of kamma-born materiality.’

original: bhaṅgakkhaṇe uppannassa nānānirodhatā ca natthīti āha “ṭhitibhaṅgakkhaṇesu uppannarūpāni
analyzed: bhaṅga kkhaṇe uppannassa nānā nirodha tā ca natthi iti āha ṭhiti bhaṅga kkhaṇesu uppanna rūpāni
translated: ‘Before that’: before the arising of the last kamma-born materiality. ‘Of another’: of materiality arisen at the moment of arising of a consciousness other than that. ‘At the moment of presence’ and ‘at the moment of dissolution’ there is no single arising and separate cessation. Hence he said ‘materiality arisen at the moments of presence and dissolution’

original: vajjetvā”ti. Tenāti rūpena. “Saṅkhalikassa viya sambandho”ti etena avicchinnasambandho
analyzed: vajjetvā ati tena ati rūpena saṅkhalikassa viya sambandho ti etena avicchinna sambandhaḥ
translated: “By that” means by that material form. By the words “like the links of a chain” he shows that what is meant here by “series” is a continuous connection.

original: idha “paveṇī”ti adhippetoti dasseti. Aññathāti vicchijjamānampi gahetvā “paveṇī”ti
analyzed: idha paveṇī iti adhippeto ti dasseti aññathā ati vicchijjamānam pi gahetvā paveṇī iti
translated: Otherwise, if what is meant by “series” were taken to be a connection that is interrupted,🔽then it would be necessary to say that there are forty-nine kamma-originated material dhammas.

original: vuccamāne. Na hi rūpadhammānaṃ arūpadhammānaṃ viya anantarapaccayabhāvo atthīti rūpadhammānaṃ
analyzed: vuccamāne na hi rūpa dhammānam arūpa dhammānam viya anantara paccaya bhāvaḥ atthi iti rūpa dhammānam
translated: For there is no such thing as the condition being immediately prior for material dhammas as it is for immaterial dhammas.

original: bhaṅgakkhaṇe uppannarūpadhamme aggahetvā “aṭṭhacattālīsā”ti vuttaṃ. Tesaṃ pana gahaṇe
analyzed: bhaṅga kkhaṇe uppanna rūpa dhamme aggahetvā aṭṭha cattālīsā ti vuttam tesam pana gahaṇe
translated: Therefore, without taking the material dhammas that arise at the moment of dissolution, it is said that there are forty-eight.

original: ekūnapaññāsāva siyāti āha “ekūnapaññāsakammajiyavacanaṃ kattabbaṃ siyā”ti.
analyzed: siyā ti āha ekūnapaññāsa kammajiya vacanam kattabbam siyā ti
translated: But if they were taken, it would be necessary to say that there are forty-nine.

original: Sudīpanattāti sukhadīpanattā, nayadassanabhāvena vā suṭṭhu dīpanattā. Tenevāha “etena🔽hi nayenā”tiādi. Tattha tanti rūpaṃ. Tenāti rūpena. Ubhayatthāti pacchimakammajarūpappavattiyaṃ,
analyzed: su dīpana ttā ati sukha dīpana ttā naya dassana bhāvena vā suṭṭhu dīpana ttā tena iva āha etena  hi nayena atiādi tattha rūpam tena ati rūpena ubhayattha ati pacchima kamma ja rūpa ppavattiyam
translated: “Easy to demonstrate”: easy to show, or because of the way in which they are shown. Therefore he says, “For in this way … ”

original: tato pubbe ca. Aññassāti ekassa cittassa ṭhitikkhaṇe uppajjitvā tato aññassa cittassa.
analyzed: tatas pubbe ca aññassa ati ekassa cittassa ṭhiti kkhaṇe uppajjitvā tatas aññassa cittassa
translated: Herein, “that” = material form. “By that” = by the material form. “In both cases” = in the occurrence of the kamma-born material dhammas that follow, and before that. “Of another” = arisen in the moment of the persistence of one consciousness, and then of another.

original: Tassāti rūpassa. Ettha ca pacchimakammajarūpappavattiyaṃ nirujjhanakanti vuttaṃ tato
analyzed: tassa iti rūpassa ettha ca pacchima kamma ja rūpa ppavattiyam nirujjhanakanti vuttam tatas
translated: ‘Its’ is the materiality. And here the ‘cessation’ is said of the occurrence of the last-born materiality in the rebirth-linking.

original: puretarappavattaṃ rūpaṃ veditabbaṃ. Catusantatikarūpenātiādi yathāvuttasaṅgahagamanadassanaṃ.🔽Etthāti etasmiṃ nānuppādekanirodhatādīpane. Ṭhitikkhaṇeti arūpassa rūpassa ca ṭhitikkhaṇe
analyzed: puretara ppavattam rūpam veditabbam catu santatika rūpena atiādi yathāvutta saṅgaha gamana dassanam  ettha ati etasmin na anuppāda eka nirodha tā dīpane ṭhiti khaṇe ti arūpassa rūpassa ca ṭhiti khaṇe
translated: ‘Its’ means the materiality’s. And here the materiality that has occurred earlier should be understood as the materiality that is ceasing in the last consciousness of the Arahant. ‘With the fourfold materiality’ and so on is said to show the inclusion of what has been stated.

original: uppannassa rūpassa ca arūpassa ca dassitattā. Adassitassāti yathā eva ettha, evaṃ
analyzed: uppannassa rūpassa ca arūpassa ca dassita ttā a dassitassa ati yathā eva ettha evam
translated: ‘Here’ means in the demonstration of non-occurrence and non-cessation. ‘At the moment of presence’ is said because materiality and immateriality that have arisen at the moment of presence are shown.

original: tattha vibhajitvā adassitassa. Kasmā panettha pacchimakammajena dīpanāyaṃ samatiṃsakammajarūpaggahaṇaṃ🔽katanti āha “samatiṃsa…pe… yojita”nti. Tato kammato jātā taṃkammajā, tesu. Saṅkharotīti🔽saṅkhāro, jīvitañca taṃ saṅkhāro cāti jīvitasaṅkhāro, āyu. Jīvitena saṅkharīyantīti
analyzed: tattha vibhajitvā a dassitassa kasmā pana ittha pacchima kamma jena dīpana ayam sama tiṃsa kamma ja rūpa ggahaṇam  katanti āha sama tiṃsape yojitanti tatas kammataḥ jātā taṃkamma jā tesu saṅkharoti iti  saṅkhāraḥ jīvitam ca tam ca ati jīvita saṅkhāraḥ āyu jīvitena saṅkharīyanti iti
translated: ‘Not shown’ means that it is not shown by analysis there as it is here. But why is the inclusion of the materiality of the thirty-two aspects made in the demonstration of the last-born materiality here?

original: jīvitasaṅkhārā, usmādayo.
analyzed: jīvita saṅkhārāḥ usma ādayaḥ
translated: He said, ‘The thirty-two … are included’ and so on. ‘Born of that kamma’ is born of that kamma. ‘Among those’ means among those four kinds of kamma-born materiality. ‘It is formed’ is saṅkhāra. ‘And that is life’ is jīvita-saṅkhāra. ‘Life’ is jīvita. ‘They are formed by life’ is jīvita-saṅkhārā. ‘Heat’ and so on are jīvita-saṅkhārā.

original: Aññassa uppādakkhaṇeti yassa cittassa uppādakkhaṇe uppannaṃ rūpaṃ aññassa tato sattarasamassa
analyzed: aññassa uppāda kkhaṇe ti yassa cittassa uppāda kkhaṇe uppannam rūpam aññassa tatas sattarasamassa
translated: At the moment of arising of another, etc.: the materiality arisen at the moment of arising of a certain consciousness is at the moment of arising of another, that is, at the moment of arising of the seventeenth consciousness arisen next to it,

original: uppādakkhaṇe, ṭhitikkhaṇe uppannaṃ aññassa ṭhitikkhaṇeti sambandho. “Vuttanti adhippāyo”ti🔽idaṃ pāḷiyā virujjhantampi aṭṭhakathāyaṃ āgatabhāvadassanatthaṃ vuttanti ayamettha
analyzed: uppāda kkhaṇe ṭhiti kkhaṇe uppannam aññassa ṭhiti kkhaṇe iti sambandhaḥ vuttam ti adhippāyaḥ ti  idam pāḷiyā virujjhantam pi aṭṭhakathā ayam āgata bhāva dassana attham vuttanti ayam ettha
translated: at the moment of presence of another, that is, at the moment of presence of the seventeenth consciousness arisen next to it. “The intention is this” is said

original: adhippāyoti attho. Kasmāti cittasamuṭṭhānarūpaṃ sandhāya pāḷi pavattā, aṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ ti attho kasmā iti citta samuṭṭhāna rūpam sandhāya pāḷi pavattā aṭṭhakathā ayam
translated: because it is contrary to the text, in order to show that it is stated in the commentary. The meaning is this: “The intention is this.” “Why?” is said because the text occurs with reference to materiality originated by consciousness, but in the commentary

original: pana kammajarūpanti sā tāya kena kāraṇena virujjhatīti āha “catu…pe… bhavitabbattā”ti,🔽nipphannassāti adhippāyo. Tenāha aṭṭhakathāyaṃ “yo cāyaṃ cittasamuṭṭhānassa…pe… kammādisamuṭṭhānassāpi
analyzed: pana sā tāya kena kāraṇena virujjhati iti āha catupe bhavitabbattā ti  nipphannassa ti adhippāyaḥ tena āha aṭṭhakathā ayam yaḥ ca ayam kamma ādi samuṭṭhānassa api
translated: it is called “kamma-born materiality.” So why is it contrary to the commentary? “Because it would be necessary to say ‘four’ and so on” is said.🔽The intention is this: “The materiality originated by consciousness is kamma-born, etc.,”🔽and so he says this. Therefore it is said in the commentary, “And this is the rule for the moment in the case of what is originated by consciousness, etc.,

original: ayameva khaṇaniyamo”ti. Etehīti yathānīto yamakapāṭho, “kāyasaṅkhāro cittasamuṭṭhāno”tiādiko
analyzed: ayam eva khaṇa niyamaḥ ti etehi iti yathānītaḥ yamaka pāṭho kāya saṅkhāro citta samuṭṭhānaḥ ti ādiko
translated: as well as in the case of what is originated by kamma, etc.” “By these” is said because the twin text as it stands is quoted, beginning, “Bodily formation originated by consciousness” .

original: aṭṭhakathāpadesoti etehi. Natthiyeva ekuppādaekanirodhadīpanatoti adhippāyo. Tena
analyzed: aṭṭhakathā padeso ti etehi natthi yeva eka uppāda eka nirodha dīpanato ti adhippāyo tena
translated: ‘In the Commentaries’ means in these . The intention is that there is no such thing as a single arising and a single cessation.

original: hi vuttaṃ “yena cittena saddhiṃ uppajjati, tato paṭṭhāya sattarasamena saddhiṃ nirujjhatī”tiādi.
analyzed: hi vuttam yena cittena saddhim uppajjati tatas paṭṭhāya sattarasamena saddhim nirujjhati itiādi
translated: Because it is said: ‘It arises together with the consciousness and it ceases together with the seventeenth .’
