translated: so here too the eye-element, etc., should be expounded by way of the method of teaching in the Suttas.🔽Herein, there is no other method of teaching the aggregates, etc., in the Suttas apart from the method of teaching in the Abhidhamma, which is the most comprehensive.

original: natthīti te rūpakkhandhādivaseneva suttantabhājanīye desitā, dhātūnaṃ pana so atthīti🔽te tiṇṇaṃ dhātuchakkānaṃ vasena idha desitāti dassento āha “suttantesveva…pe… vibhattanti
analyzed: natthi iti te rūpa kkhandha ādi vasena iva suttanta bhājanīye desitā dhātūnam pana so atthi iti  te tiṇṇam dhātu chakkānam vasena idha desitā iti dassentaḥ āha
translated: Therefore they are taught in the Vibhanga, etc., by way of the aggregates, etc., alone. But there is such a method of teaching the elements.🔽Therefore, showing that they are taught here by way of the three element-sets, he said, “In the Suttas … they should be understood to be expounded by way of the three element-sets.”

original: veditabba”nti. Tenāha aṭṭhakathāyaṃ “sabbā dhātuyo chahi chahi dhātūhi saṅkhipitvā”ti.
analyzed: veditabbam ti tena āha aṭṭhakathā ayam sabbāḥ dhātuyaḥ chahi chahi dhātūhi saṅkhipitvā iti
translated: Hence it is said in the commentary: “All the elements are included in the six elements.”

original: Kathaṃ pana chasu chasu dhātūsu aṭṭhārasannaṃ dhātūnaṃ samavarodhoti? Sabhāvanissayadvārārammaṇasampayogasāmaññato.
analyzed: katham pana chasu chasu dhātūsu aṭṭhārasannam dhātūnam samavarodhaḥ ti sa bhāva nissaya dvāra ārammaṇa sampayoga sāmaññato
translated: But how is there inclusion of the eighteen elements in the six elements? —By community of nature, support, door, and object, and by association.

original: Tattha paṭhamachakke tāva pathavītejovāyodhātuyo sabhāvato phoṭṭhabbadhātu. Āpodhātuākāsadhātuyo
analyzed: tattha paṭhama chakke tāva pathavī tejaḥ vāyo dhātuyo sabhāvato phoṭṭhabba dhātu āpo dhātu ākāsa dhātuyo
translated: Herein, in the first dyad, the earth, fire, and air elements are the tangible-data element by their nature. The water element and the space element

original: dhammadhātuekadeso. Viññāṇadhātu sattaviññāṇadhātuyo. Catudhātuggahaṇena cettha tadāyattavuttikā
analyzed: dhammadhātu eka desaḥ viññāṇa dhātu satta viññāṇa dhātuyo catu dhātu ggahaṇena ca ittha tad āyatta vuttikā
translated: are a part of the mental-data element. The consciousness element is the seven consciousness elements. And when the four elements are taken, the remaining material elements are included by their being the support,

original: nissayāpadesena, viññāṇadhātuyā dvārārammaṇabhāvena vā avasiṭṭhā rūpadhātuyo samavaruddhā,
analyzed: nissaya apadesena viññāṇa dhātuyā dvāra ārammaṇa bhāvena vā avasiṭṭhāḥ rūpa dhātuyo samavaruddhāḥ
translated: as the physical basis, of the water element, or by their being the door and object of the consciousness element.

original: viññāṇadhātuggahaṇena taṃsampayogato dhammadhātuekadesoti evaṃ sabbadhātusamavarodho
analyzed: viññāṇa dhātu ggahaṇena tad sampayogataḥ dhammadhātu eka deso ti evam sabba dhātu samavarodho
translated: And when the consciousness element is taken, a part of the mental-data element is included by its being associated with the seven consciousness elements. This is how the inclusion of all the elements should be understood.

original: daṭṭhabbo. Dutiye chapi dhātuyo sabhāvato, dhammāyatanekadeso, taṃsampayogato sattaviññāṇadhātuyo,
analyzed: daṭṭhabbaḥ dutiye cha pi dhātuyo sabhāvataḥ dhamma āyatana eka deso tad sampayogato satta viññāṇa dhātuyo
translated: In the second dyad, the six elements are a part of the mental-data base by their nature. The seven consciousness elements are a part of the mental-data base by their association with it.

original: yathārahaṃ tesaṃ nissayadvārārammaṇabhāvato avasiṭṭhadhātuyo samavaruddhā. Tatiyachakkepi
analyzed: yathāraham tesam nissaya dvāra ārammaṇa bhāvataḥ avasiṭṭha dhātuyaḥ samavaruddhā tatiya chakke pi
translated: And the remaining elements are included by their being respectively the support, door, and object of those elements as appropriate. In the third dyad,

original: eseva nayo. Evamettha chasu chasu dhātūsu aṭṭhārasannaṃ dhātūnaṃ samavarodho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ evam ettha chasu chasu dhātūsu aṭṭhārasannam dhātūnam samavarodhaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: So too with the rest. This is how the inclusion of the eighteen elements should be understood in the six elements.

original: Tena vuttaṃ “sabbā dhātuyo chahi chahi dhātūhi saṅkhipitvā”ti.
analyzed: tena vuttam sabbāḥ dhātuyaḥ chahi chahi dhātūhi saṅkhipitvā ati
translated: Hence it was said above: “All the elements are included in sixes” .🔽“Empty”: empty of self. “The mere elements”: the mere individual essences.

original: Suññoti attasuñño, tena sasabhāvatāya ca idha dhātuvohāroti āha “suññe sabhāvamatte
analyzed: suñño ti atta suñño tena sa sabhāva tāya ca idha dhātu vohāro ti āha suññe sa bhāva matte
translated: “The term ‘element’ is established”: the word “element” is established.🔽“Space is merely the mere absence of obstruction”: space is merely the mere absence of the physical .🔽“The mere absence of compactness”: the mere absence of the physical .🔽“The mere absence of the physical”: the mere absence of the physical .

original: niruḷho dhātusaddo”ti. Taṃtaṃbhūtavivittatā rūpapariyantova ākāsoti yehi vivitto,🔽yesañca paricchedo, tehi asamphuṭṭhatā tesaṃ byāpakabhāve sati na hotīti āha “catūhi
analyzed: niruḷhaḥ dhātu saddo ti taṃ taṃ bhūta vivitta tā ākāsaḥ ti yehi vivittaḥ  yesam ca paricchedaḥ tehi a samphuṭṭha tā tesam byāpaka bhāve sati na hoti iti āha catūhi
translated: “The mere absence of the physical”: the mere absence of the physical .🔽“The mere absence of the physical”: the mere absence of the physical .🔽“The mere absence of the physical”: the mere absence of the physical .🔽“The mere absence of the physical”: the mere absence of the physical .🔽“The mere absence of the physical”: the mere absence of the physical .🔽“The mere absence of the physical”: the mere absence of the physical .🔽“The mere absence of the physical”: the mere absence of the physical .🔽“The mere absence of the physical”: the mere absence of the physical .🔽“The mere absence of the physical”: the mere absence of the physical .🔽“The mere absence of the physical”: the mere absence of the physical .

original: mahābhūtehi abyāpitabhāvo”ti. Paricchinnavuttīni hi bhūtānīti.
analyzed: mahābhūtehi paricchinna vuttīni hi bhūtāni iti
translated: “The mere absence of the physical”: the mere absence of the physical .🔽“The mere absence of the physical”: the mere absence of the physical .🔽“The mere absence of the physical”: the mere absence of the physical .🔽“The mere absence of the physical”: the mere absence of the physical .🔽“The mere absence of the physical”: the mere absence of the physical .🔽“The mere absence of the physical”: the mere absence of the physical .🔽“The mere absence of the physical”: the mere absence of the physical .🔽“The mere absence of the physical”: the mere absence of the physical .🔽“The mere absence of the physical”: the mere absence of the physical .🔽“The mere absence of the physical”: the mere absence of the physical .🔽“The mere absence of the physical”: the mere absence of the physical .🔽“The mere absence of the physical”: the mere absence of the physical .🔽“The mere absence of the physical”: the mere absence of the physical .

original: 173. Avayavavinimutto samudāyo nāma koci natthīti purimatthaṃ asambhāvento “dve eva vā”tiādinā samudāyena vinā dutiyatthamāha. Paccattaṃ attani jātatanti pāṭipuggalikataṃ.
analyzed: avayava vinimutto samudāyaḥ nāma koci natthi iti purima attham asambhāventaḥ dve eva vāti ādinā samudāyena vinā dutiya attham āha paccattam attani jāta tanti pāṭipuggalika tam
translated: “The mere absence of the physical”: the mere absence of the physical

original: Pāṭiyekko koṭṭhāsoti vā lomādiitarakoṭṭhāsehi asammisso visuṃ eko pathavīkoṭṭhāsoti attho.
analyzed: pāṭiyekkaḥ koṭṭhāso ti vā loma ādi itara koṭṭhāsehi asammissaḥ visum ekaḥ pathavī koṭṭhāso ti attho
translated: Or ‘a separate part’ means a single part of earth, not mixed up with the other parts beginning with hair.

original: Payoganti bhāvanāpayogaṃ. Vīriyanti bhāvanānipphādakaṃ ussāhaṃ. Āyūhananti tādisaṃ cetanaṃ.
analyzed: bhāvanā apayogam bhāvanā nipphādakam ussāham āyūhananti tādisam cetanam
translated: ‘Application’ is the application of development. ‘Energy’ is the endeavour that produces development. ‘Accumulation’ is the volition of that kind.

original: Dhātupaṭikkūlavaṇṇamanasikārānanti dhātumanasikārapaṭikkūlamanasikāravaṇṇamanasikārānaṃ.
analyzed: dhātu paṭikkūla vaṇṇa manasikāra ananti dhātu manasikāra paṭikkūla manasikāra vaṇṇa manasikāra ananti
translated: ‘Contemplation of the sign of the elements, of what is loathed, and of the colour’: of the contemplation of the elements, of the contemplation of what is loathed, and of the contemplation of the colour.

original: Abyāpāratāyāti “ahametaṃ nipphādemi, mama esā nipphādanā”ti cetanārahitatāya. Karontīti
analyzed: abyāpāra tāya ati aham etam nipphādemi mama esā nipphādanā ati cetanā rahita tāya karonti iti
translated: ‘Absence of ill will’: absence of volition in the form of ‘I produce this, this is produced by me’.

original: ābhogapaccavekkhaṇāni uppādenti.🔽Lakkhaṇavasenāti sabhāvavasena. So pana yasmā pathavīdhātuyā kakkhaḷakharatā hotīti āha “kakkhaḷaṃ kharigatantiādivacanaṃ sandhāya vutta”nti.
analyzed: ābhoga paccavekkhaṇāni uppādenti  lakkhaṇa vasena āti sabhāva vasena saḥ pana yasmā pathavī dhātuyā kakkhaḷa khara tā hoti iti āha kakkhaḷam khari gata nti ādi vacanam sandhāya vuttan ti
translated: ‘They make’: they arouse the prior and subsequent contemplations.🔽‘By its characteristic’: by its individual essence. But since hardness and roughness are the individual essence of the earth element, he says, ‘The words “hardness, roughness” are stated with reference to the statement’.

original: Vekantakaṃ nāma sabbalohacchedanasamatthaṃ lohaṃ. Tathā hi taṃ vikantati chindatīti
analyzed: vekantakam nāma sabba loha chedana samattham loham tathā hi tam vikantati chindati iti
translated: ‘A sharp-edged axe’ is an axe that can cut through any kind of wood. For it cuts, it penetrates,

original: vikantaṃ, vikantameva vekantakanti vuccati. Lohasadisanti lohākāraṃ lohamalaṃ viya
analyzed: vikantam vikantam eva vekantakanti vuccati loha sadisanti loha ākāram loha malam viya
translated: and what is called “broken” is what is called “broken” . “Like iron” : it is like the shape of iron, like the rust of iron.

original: ghanasahitaṃ hutvā tiṭṭhati. Tāpetvā tāḷitaṃ pana chinnaṃ chinnaṃ hutvā visarati,
analyzed: ghana sahitam hutvā tiṭṭhati tāpetvā tāḷitam pana chinnam chinnam hutvā visarati
translated: It remains together with the mass of iron. But when it is heated and struck, it is split up and falls away,

original: mudu maṭṭhaṃ kammaniyaṃ vā na hoti, tena “lohavijātī”ti vuccatīti. Tiputambādīhīti
analyzed: mudu maṭṭham kammaniyam vā na hoti tena loha vijātī iti vuccati iti tipu tamba ādīhi iti
translated: and it is not soft, smooth, and pliable. Therefore it is called “of a different nature from iron.” “In bronze, etc.” :

original: tiputambe missetvā kataṃ kaṃsalohaṃ, sīsatambe missetvā kataṃ vaṭṭalohaṃ, jasadatambe🔽missetvā kataṃ ārakūṭaṃ. Yaṃ pana kevalaṃ jasadadhātuviniggataṃ, yaṃ “pittala”ntipi
analyzed: tipu tambe missetvā katam kaṃsaloham sīsa tambe missetvā katam vaṭṭa loham jasada tambe  katam ārakūṭam yam pana kevalam jasada dhātu viniggatam yam
translated: Bronze is made by mixing tin with copper. Bell-metal is made by mixing lead with copper. Brass is made by mixing zinc with copper.

original: vadanti, taṃ idha nādhippetaṃ, yathāvuttamissakameva pana gahetvā “kittima”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vadanti tam idha na adhippetam yathā vutta missakam eva pana gahetvā kittimanti vuttam
translated: But what is called “brass” is not intended here. Only the mixture mentioned is taken and called “crystal.”

original: Nidassanamattanti muttānaṃ jātito anekabhedattā vuttaṃ. Tathā hi hatthikumbhaṃ varāhadāṭhaṃ
analyzed: nidassanam attanti jātitaḥ aneka bheda ttā vuttam tathā hi hatthi kumbham varāha dāṭham
translated: “Merely an indication”: this is said because there are many kinds of crystals according to their species. For there are eight kinds of crystals: elephant’s frontal globe, boar’s tusk,

original: bhujaṅgasīsaṃ valāhakūṭaṃ veṇupabbaṃ macchasiro saṅkho sippīti aṭṭha muttāyoniyo.
analyzed: bhujaṅgasīsam valāhakūṭam veṇupabbam macchasiraḥ saṅkhaḥ sippī iti aṭṭha muttāyoniyaḥ
translated: snake’s head, rain cloud, bamboo’s tip, fish’s head, conch, and shell.

original: Tattha hatthikumbhajā pītavaṇṇā pabhāhīnā. Varāhadāṭhajā varāhadāṭhavaṇṇāva. Bhujaṅgasīsajā🔽nīlādivaṇṇā suvisuddhā, vaṭṭalā ca. Valāhakajā bhāsurā dubbibhāgarūpā rattibhāge
analyzed: tattha hatthi kumbha jā pīta vaṇṇā pabhā hīnā varāha dāṭha jā varāha dāṭha vaṇṇā ava bhujaṅga sīsa jā  nīla ādi vaṇṇā su visuddhā vaṭṭalā ca valāhaka jā bhāsurā dubbibhāga rūpā ratti bhāge
translated: Herein, those born from an elephant’s frontal globe are yellow-coloured and lacking in sheen. Those born from a boar’s tusk are the colour of a boar’s tusk. Those born from a snake’s head

original: andhakāraṃ vidhamantā tiṭṭhanti, devūpabhogā eva honti. Veṇupabbajā kāraphalasamānavaṇṇā,
analyzed: andhakāram vidhamantā tiṭṭhanti deva upabhogāḥ eva honti veṇu pabbajāḥ kāra phala samāna vaṇṇā
translated: are blue-coloured, very pure, and round. Those born from a thunder- bolt are dazzling, and they have an ugly shape. At night they stand dispelling the darkness, and they are only for the use of the gods. Those born from bamboo are the colour of a kāra fruit,

original: na bhāsurā, te ca veḷavo amanussagocare eva padese jāyanti. Macchasīsajā pāṭhīnapiṭṭhisamānavaṇṇā,
analyzed: na bhāsurā te ca veḷavaḥ amanussa gocare eva padese jāyanti maccha sīsa jā pāṭhīna piṭṭhi samāna vaṇṇā
translated: but they are not dazzling. And those bamboos grow only in places that are not frequented by human beings. Those born from a fish’s head are the colour of a spotted deer’s back,

original: vaṭṭalā, laghavo ca honti pabhāvihīnā, te ca macchā samuddamajjheyeva jāyanti. Saṅkhajā
analyzed: vaṭṭalāḥ laghavaḥ ca honti pabhā vihīnā te ca macchā samudda majjheyā iva jāyanti saṅkhajā
translated: are round, and are light, and they are lacking in sheen. And those fish grow only in the middle of the ocean. Those born from a shell

original: saṅkhoracchavivaṇṇā, kolappamāṇāpi honti pabhāvihīnāva. Sippijā pana pabhāvisesayuttāva
analyzed: honti pabhā vihīnā ava sippi jā pana pabhā visesa yuttā ava
translated: are the colour of a conch trumpet, and they are the size of a kola fruit, and they are lacking in sheen. But those born from a bird’s feather are endowed with a special sheen.

original: honti nānāsaṇṭhānā. Evaṃ jātito aṭṭhavidhāsu muttāsu yā macchasaṅkhasippijā, tā sāmuddikā.
analyzed: honti nānā saṇṭhānāḥ evam jātitaḥ aṭṭhavidhāsu muttāsu yā maccha saṅkha sippi jā tā sāmuddikā
translated: They are of various shapes. Of the eight kinds of pearl thus classified, those born from a fish, a shell, and a bird’s feather are sea-pearls.

original: Bhujaṅgajāpi kāci sāmuddikāti vadanti, itarā asāmuddikā. Tena vuttaṃ “sāmuddikamuttāti
analyzed: bhujaṅga jā api kāci sāmuddikā iti vadanti itarā a sāmuddikā tena vuttam sāmuddika muttā iti
translated: Some are sea-born and some are not, they say. The former are sea-born, the latter are not. Hence it was said above, “Sea-born gems are pearls” .

original: nidassanamattametaṃ, sabbāpi pana muttā muttā evā”ti. Bahulato vā aṭṭhakathāyaṃ etaṃ
analyzed: nidassana mattam etam sabbā api pana muttāḥ muttāḥ evā iti bahulataḥ vā aṭṭhakathā ayam etam
translated: This is stated by way of illustration only; for all gems are pearls. Or else it is said in the Commentary

original: vuttaṃ “muttāti sāmuddikamuttā”ti. Bahulañhi loke sāmuddikāva muttā dissanti. Tatthāpi
analyzed: vuttam muttā ati sāmuddika muttā ati bahulam hi loke sāmuddikāḥ ava muttāḥ dissanti tattha api
translated: in the way stated above because of the abundance of sea-born gems. For in the world it is only sea-born gems that are generally seen. But even there

original: sippijāva, itarā kadāci kācīti.
analyzed: itarā kadāci kāci iti
translated: some are the product of skill, while others are not.

original: 174. Idha natthi niyamo kevalaṃ dravabhāvasseva adhippetattā.
analyzed: idha na atthi niyamaḥ kevalam drava bhāvassa iva adhippeta ttā
translated: Here there is no restriction. Only the state of being a substance is intended.

original: 175. Nisitabhāvenāti santāpanādivasappavattena tikhiṇabhāvena. Usmākārañhi nisānaṃ🔽idha nisitabhāvo. Pākatikoti sābhāviko kāyusmāti adhippeto. Sadāti sabbakālaṃ yāva
analyzed: nisita bhāvena ati santāpana divasa pavattena tikhiṇa bhāvena usmākāram hi nisānam  idha nisita bhāvaḥ pākatikaḥ iti sābhāviko adhippeto sadā ti sabbakālam yāva
translated: By their sharpness: by their sharpness due to their ability to burn, etc., for sharpness here is the ability to burn.🔽Natural: natural heat of the body is intended. Constant: it occurs as long as the life faculty does.

original: jīvitindriyaṃ pavattati. Petaggi nijjhāmataṇhikapetaggi. Idhāti bāhiratejodhātukathāyaṃ.
analyzed: jīvita indriyam pavattati petaggi nijjhāma taṇhika petaggi
translated: In the case of the fire-born: in the case of the fire-born gem. Here: in the discussion of the external fire element.

original: 176. Vāyanaṃ bījanaṃ, taṃ pana thāmasā pavattīti āha “savegagamanavasenā”ti. Samudīraṇaṃ allaparisosanaṃ, bhūtasaṅghātassa desantaruppattihetubhāvo vā.
analyzed: vāyanam bījanam tam pana thāmasā pavatti iti āha sa vega gamana vasena ati samudīraṇam alla parisosanam bhūta saṅghātassa desa antara uppatti hetu bhāvaḥ vā
translated: The meaning of “moving” is “causing to go,” and that occurs by means of speed, thus he said “by means of rapid motion.” “Shaking” is drying up by shaking. Or it is the cause for the arising of the elements in another place.

original: 177. Bhitticchiddādivasena labbhamānaṃ ajaṭākāsaṃ nissāyeva paricchedākāsassa parikammakaraṇanti āha “ajaṭākāsassa ca kathitata”nti.
analyzed: bhitti chidda ādi vasena labbhamānam ajaṭā ākāsam nissāya iva pariccheda ākāsassa parikamma karaṇan ti āha ajaṭā kāsassa ca kathita tanti
translated: The surrounding space is made ready by means of the space in the openings of the door and window, etc., thus he said “and the space in the openings.”

original: 179. Sukhadukkhaphoṭṭhabbasamuṭṭhāpanapaccayabhāvenāti iṭṭhāniṭṭhaphoṭṭhabbānaṃ nibbattakabhūtena
analyzed: sukha dukkha phoṭṭhabba samuṭṭhāpana paccaya bhāvena ati iṭṭha aniṭṭha phoṭṭhabbānam nibbattaka bhūtena
translated: By means of the condition for arousing pleasure and pain: by means of the condition for arousing desirable and undesirable tangible objects.

original: paccayabhāvena. Kassa pana so paccayabhāvoti āha “sarīraṭṭhakautussā”ti. Paccayabhāvenāti
analyzed: paccaya bhāvena kassa pana so paccaya bhāvoti āha sarīraṭṭha kautussā ati paccaya bhāvena ati
translated: But whose condition is it? He said “of the bodily intimation.”

original: ca hetumhi karaṇavacanaṃ. Tena hi kāraṇabhūtena sukhadukkhaphoṭṭhabbānaṃ yathāvuttasamatthatā
analyzed: ca hetumhi karaṇa vacanam tena hi kāraṇa bhūtena sukha dukkha phoṭṭhabbānam yathā vutta samattha tā
translated: “By means of the condition” is a locative in the sense of instrument. For it is by means of that condition that the desirable and undesirable tangible objects have the aforesaid capacity.

original: hotīti. “Tathevā”ti iminā “yathābalaṃ sarīrekadesasakalasarīra”nti idaṃ anukaḍḍhati.
analyzed: hoti iti tathā iva ati iminā yathābalam idam anukaḍḍhati
translated: By “so too” he includes “according to strength, in a part of the body or in the whole body.”

original: Evanti attano phalūpacārasiddhena pharaṇappakārena. Etesanti sukhādīnaṃ. “Oḷārikappavatti
analyzed: evam ti attanaḥ phala upacāra siddhena pharaṇa ppakārena etesanti sukha ādīnam oḷārika ppavatti
translated: “Thus”: by the mode of occurrence of the pleasure, etc., which is established by the occurrence of its own fruit. “Of these”: of the pleasure, etc.

original: eva vā pharaṇa”nti iminā nirupacāraṃ etesaṃ pharaṇaṭṭhaṃ dasseti. Ubhayavatoti sukhadukkhavato,
analyzed: eva vā pharaṇam ti iminā nirupacāram etesam pharaṇa ṭṭham dasseti ubhayavataḥ ti sukha dukkhavato
translated: “Or occurrence is the gross process of these” : by this he shows the mode of occurrence of these without the occurrence of its own fruit.

original: somanassadomanassavato ca, pharaṇāpharaṇaṭṭhānavato vā.
analyzed: somanassa domanassavataḥ ca pharaṇa a pharaṇa ṭṭhānavataḥ vā
translated: “Of both kinds”: of the kind of pleasure and of the kind of pain, or of the kind of joy and of the kind of grief.

original: 181. Ettha vuttaṃ saṅkappanti etasmiṃ “saṅkappo kāmo”tiādike niddesapadese vuttaṃ
analyzed: ettha vuttam saṅkappanti etasmin saṅkappo kāmo ti ādike niddesa padese vuttam
translated: “The thought stated here” : the thought stated in the passage of the sutta that begins, “Thought is will” .

original: saṅkappaṃ. Tattha hi kilesakāmova “saṅkapparāgo purisassa kāmo”tiādīsu viya. Vatthukāmassa🔽tathā tathā saṅkappanato parikappanato “saṅkappo”ti vutto, na vitakkoti ayamettha
analyzed: saṅkappam tattha hi kilesa kāmaḥ iva saṅkappa rāgaḥ purisassa kāmaḥ ti ādīsu viya vatthu kāmassa  tathā tathā saṅkappanato parikappanato saṅkappo ti vuttaḥ na ayam ettha
translated: For in that passage the defilement of lust is called “will” , as in such passages as “The will of a man for a woman is his lust for her” .🔽The object of lust is called “will” because it is willed in such and such a way, because it is imagined, not because it is mere applied thought. This is the meaning stated here.

original: attho vutto. Ṭīkāyaṃ pana vitakkavasena atthaṃ dassetuṃ “sopi hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tatrāpi🔽purimo evattho adhippetoti ce, sampiṇḍanattho pi-saddo niratthako siyā, “kilesasanthavasambhavato”ti
analyzed: atthaḥ vuttaḥ ṭīkāyam pana vitakka vasena attham dassetum saḥ api hi itiādi vuttam tatra api 🔽purimaḥ eva tthaḥ adhippetaḥ iti ce sampiṇḍana atthaḥ pi saddaḥ niratthakaḥ siyā kilesa santhava sambhavato ti
translated: But in the commentary the meaning is stated by way of applied thought. If it be asked: “But is not the meaning intended here the same as that stated in the commentary?” , the word “also” would be meaningless, since the defilement of lust is possible.

original: ca na vattabbaṃ siyā, parato ca “byāpādavacanena byāpādavitakkaṃ dassetī”ti vakkhati.
analyzed: ca na vattabbam siyā paratas ca byāpāda vacanena byāpāda vitakkam dasseti iti vakkhati
translated: and it should not be said that it is. And it is said that by the word ‘ill will’ he shows the thought of ill will.

original: Kilesakāmo vibhatto kilesasampayuttattāti adhippāyo. Kāmapaṭibaddhāti ettha kāma-saddena
analyzed: kilesa kāmaḥ vibhattaḥ kilesa sampayutta ttā ti adhippāyo kāma paṭibaddhā ti ettha kāma saddena
translated: The intention is that sense desire as defilement is distinguished by being associated with defilement. ‘Bound up with sense desires’: here the word ‘sense desires’

original: vatthukāmāpi saṅgahitāti daṭṭhabbā.🔽182. Ubhayattha uppannoti sattesu, saṅkhāresūti ubhayattha uppanno, sattākāro, saṅkhārākāroti
analyzed: vatthu kāmā api saṅgahitā iti daṭṭhabbā  ubhayattha uppanno ti sattesu saṅkhāresu iti ubhayattha uppanno satta ākāro saṅkhāra ākāro iti
translated: should be regarded as including sense desires as object.

original: vā ārammaṇassa ubhayākāraggahaṇavasena uppanno. Kammapathaviseso, kammapathavināsako🔽ca kammapathabhedoti dassetuṃ “abhijjhāsaṃyogenā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tathā vihiṃsāya vihiṃsāvitakkaṃ
analyzed: vā ārammaṇassa ubhaya ākāra ggahaṇa vasena uppannaḥ kamma patha visesaḥ kamma patha vināsako  ca kamma patha bhedaḥ ti dassetum abhijjhā saṃyogena atiādi vuttam tathā vihiṃsāya vihiṃsā vitakkam
translated: ‘Arisen in both’: arisen in both beings and formations. Or it is arisen by the apprehension of the twofold aspect of the object, the aspect of beings and the aspect of formations.

original: dassetīti yojanā. Vihiṃsāyāti ca vihiṃsāvacanenāti attho. Yathāsambhavaṃ pāṇātipātādivasenāti
analyzed: dasseti iti yojanā vihiṃsāya ati ca vihiṃsā vacanena ati atthaḥ yathāsambhavam pāṇa atipāta ādi vasena ati
translated: In order to show that it is a special kind of course of action and a distinction in the course of action that is a destroyer of the course of action, it is said, ‘by the fetter of covetousness’ and so on. And the construction is: ‘by the word “ill will” he shows the thought of ill will.’🔽‘By ill will’ means by the word ‘ill will.’ ‘According to the circumstances’ means according to killing breathing things, etc.

original: ādi-saddena adinnādānamusāvādapesuññapharusavācāsamphappalāpe saṅgaṇhāti. Sabba…pe…
analyzed: ādi saddena adinna ādāna musāvāda pesuñña pharusa vācā samphappalāpe saṅgaṇhāti
translated: The word ‘etc.’ includes taking what is not given, false speech, malicious speech, gossip, and covetousness.

original: saṅgāhakehi kāmanekkhammadhātūhi. Dve dveti byāpādavihiṃsādhātuyo, abyāpādaavihiṃsādhātuyo🔽ca. “Etthāti panā”tiādinā saṃkilesavodānānaṃ saṅkarabhāvassa aniṭṭhāpajjanassa ca
analyzed: saṅgāhakehi kāma nekkhamma dhātūhi dve dve iti byāpāda vihiṃsā dhātuyaḥ a byāpāda avihiṃsā dhātuyaḥ  ca ettha iti pana ati ādinā saṃkilesa vodānānam saṅkara bhāvassa aniṭṭha āpajjanassa ca
translated: by the two kinds of craving, by the two kinds of views, and by the two kinds of ignorance. “Two by two”: the two kinds of hate and the two kinds of violence, and the two kinds of non-hate and the two kinds of non-violence.

original: dassanena purimaṃyeva atthaṃ byatirekamukhena sampādeti.
analyzed: dassanena purimaṃyā eva attham byatireka mukhena sampādeti
translated: “But here” , etc., he concludes the former meaning by the method of excess, showing that the defilements and the purification are mixed up and that the undesirable result is produced.

original: Suttantabhājanīyavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: suttantabhājanīya vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the sutta-nipāta is ended.

original: 2. Abhidhammabhājanīyavaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Abhidhamma-nipāta

original: 183. Āveṇikattho atisayattho ca visesasaddo hotīti tadubhayaṃ dassetuṃ “puggalantarāsādhāraṇaṃ,
analyzed: āveṇika atthaḥ atisaya ttho ca visesa saddo hoti iti tat ubhayam dassetum puggala antara asādhāraṇam
translated: The word “special” has the meaning of “unique” and the meaning of “excessive.” In order to show both of these meanings, it is said, “unique to a person,

original: nīlādisabbarūpasādhāraṇañcā”ti vuttaṃ. Asādhāraṇakāraṇenāpi hi niddeso hoti yathā
analyzed: nīla ādi sabba rūpa sādhāraṇam ca ati vuttam asādhāraṇa kāraṇena api hi niddesaḥ hoti yathā
translated: and common to all visible data such as blue, etc.” For description is also by way of a unique reason, as in the case of

original: “bherisaddo, yavaṅkuro”ti. Atisayakāraṇenapi yathā “atītānāgatapaccuppannānaṃ kammasamādānānaṃ
analyzed: bheri saddaḥ atisaya kāraṇena api yathā atīta anāgata paccuppannānam kamma samādānānam
translated: “the sound of the drum” and “the sprout of the yava grain.” It is also by way of an excessive reason, as in the case of

original: ṭhānaso hetuso vipākaṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānātī”ti. Dhātuattho evāti “dhātu”iti imassa
analyzed: ṭhānasaḥ hetusaḥ vipākam yathābhūtam pajānāti iti dhātu atthaḥ eva ati dhātu iti imassa
translated: “the Tathāgata understands as they really are the various elements of the world” . The meaning of “element” is just this: “element”

original: dhātusaddasseva attho. Dhātuvacanīyo hi attho upasaggena jotīyati.🔽Purimena asadiso vidhānadhāraṇatthānaṃ pākaṭo bhedoti. Visabhāgalakkhaṇā visadisasabhāvā avayavā bhāgā, tesu.
analyzed: dhātu saddassa iva atthaḥ dhātu vacanīyaḥ hi atthaḥ upasaggena jotīyati  purimena asadisaḥ vidhāna dhāraṇa tthānam pākaṭaḥ bhedaḥ ti visabhāga lakkhaṇāḥ visadisa sabhāvāḥ avayavāḥ bhāgā tesu
translated: The meaning of the word element is the same as that of the word dhātu. For the meaning of the word dhātu is made clear by the prefix upa.🔽The difference between the two is obvious in the case of the injunction and the retention of the meaning.

original: Yathāsambhavanti kiriyāmanodhātu upanissayakoṭiyā, vipākamanodhātu vipākamanoviññāṇassa
analyzed: yathā sambhavanti kiriyā manaḥ dhātu upanissaya koṭiyā vipāka manaḥ dhātu vipāka manaḥ viññāṇassa
translated: In the case of the mental-data element, the resultant mental-data element is a condition by way of decisive support for resultant mind-consciousness element,

original: anantarādināpi, itarassa sabbāpi upanissayakoṭiyāva. Dhammadhātu pana vedanādikā
analyzed: anantara ādinā api itarassa sabbā api upanissaya koṭiyā āva dhammadhātu pana vedanā ādikā
translated: and by way of proximity, etc., too, and the other is so only by way of decisive support. But the mental-data element consisting of the aggregates of feeling, etc.,

original: sahajātā sahajātādinā, asahajātā anantarādinā, upanissayena ārammaṇādinā ca manoviññāṇassa
analyzed: sahajātā sahajāta ādinā asahajātā anantara ādinā upanissayena ārammaṇa ādinā ca manaḥ viññāṇassa
translated: is a condition by way of conascence, etc., for the conascent mind-consciousness element, and by way of proximity, etc., for the non-conascent, and by way of decisive support, etc., for the mind-consciousness element that has a different object.

original: paccayoti evaṃ manodhātudhammadhātūnaṃ manoviññāṇassa hetubhāvo yathāsambhavaṃ yojetabbo.
analyzed: paccayaḥ ti evam manaḥ dhātu dhammadhātūnam manaḥ viññāṇassa hetu bhāvaḥ yathāsambhavam yojetabbaḥ
translated: So the state of being a condition by way of cause of mind-consciousness element should be construed in each instance for the mind element and the mental-data element.

original: Dvārabhūtamanopi sutte “manodhātū”ti vuccatīti āha “dvārabhūtamanovasena vā”ti. Tassā
analyzed: dvāra bhūta manaḥ pi sutte manaḥ dhātu uti vuccati iti āha dvāra bhūta manaḥ vasena vāti tassā
translated: And the door-like mind is called “mind element” in the texts. That is why he says “Or as the door-like mind.”

original: manodhātuyā manoviññāṇassa hetubhāvo yathāsambhavaṃ yojetabboti sambandho.
analyzed: manaḥ dhātuyāḥ manaḥ viññāṇassa hetu bhāvaḥ yathāsambhavam yojetabbaḥ iti sambandho
translated: So the state of being a condition by way of cause of mind-consciousness element should be construed in each instance for that mind element.

original: Purimanayenāti visesanaṃ dutiyanayassa hīnattikavaseneva vibhattattā. Nānādhātūnañca cakkhudhātuādīnanti sambandho.
analyzed: purima nayena ati visesanam dutiya nayassa hīna ttika vasena iva vibhatta ttā nānā dhātūnam ca cakkhu dhātu ādīnam ti sambandhaḥ
translated: The word “respectively” is a specification of the second method, since it is treated in the way of the inferior-superior method. The compound “the various elements, the eye element, etc.” is to be resolved as “the various elements and the eye element, etc.”

original: Na hi dve manoviññāṇadhātuyo santi aṭṭhārasadhātuvibhāgadassaneti adhippāyo. Khandhāyatanadhātindriyānaṃyeva
analyzed: na hi dve manaḥ viññāṇa dhātuyo santi aṭṭhārasa dhātu vibhāga dassane iti adhippāyaḥ
translated: The intention is that there are not two mind-consciousness elements, since the eighteen elements are shown in the exposition of the elements.

original: vasena saṅkhepādivibhāgadassanaṃ tesaṃ bahulaṃ pariññeyyadhammasaṅgaṇhanato. Saccadesanā
analyzed: vasena saṅkhepa ādi vibhāga dassanam tesam bahulam pariññeyya dhamma saṅgaṇhanato sacca desanā
translated: The exposition of the aggregates, bases, elements, and faculties is given in brief, etc., because they are the most frequently discerned phenomena.

original: pana atisaṃkhittabhāvatoyevettha bahikatā.
analyzed: pana bahika tā
translated: The exposition of the truths is omitted here because it is too brief.

original: Nijjīvassātiādi visesato sattasuññatādīpanatthā dhātudesanāti katvā vuttaṃ. Purimanayo🔽aññesampi kamavuttīnaṃ dhātūnaṃ sambhavatīti adhippāyena vuttoti “manodhātuyeva vā”tiādinā
analyzed: nijjīvassa iti ādi visesataḥ satta suñña tā dīpana tthā dhātu desanā iti katvā vuttam purima nayo  aññesam pi kama vuttīnam dhātūnam sambhavati iti adhippāyena vuttaḥ ti manaḥ dhātuyā iva vā āti ādinā
translated: The exposition of the elements is given in order to show the emptiness of beings, etc., in particular. The first method is stated🔽with the intention that it is applicable to other elements that are the basis of the round of existence. The second method is stated with the words “Or the mind element alone, etc.”

original: dutiyanayo vutto. Tattha avijjamānepi purecarānucarabhāveti purecarānucarābhisandhiyā
analyzed: dutiya nayaḥ vutto tattha a vijjamāne pi purecara anucara bhāve ti purecara anucara abhisandhiyā
translated: There, although there is no precedence and subsequence, the intention is that of precedence and subsequence.

original: abhāvepi kevalaṃ anantarapubbakālaanantarāparakālatāya manodhātu purecarānucarā viya daṭṭhabbāti vuttā.🔽“Aññaṃ aggahetvā pavattituṃ asamatthatāyā”ti etena viññāṇassa ekantasārammaṇatādassanena
analyzed: abhāve api kevalam anantara pubba kāla anantara apara kāla tāya manaḥ dhātu purecara anucarā viya daṭṭhabbā iti vuttā  aññam aggahetvā pavattitum asamattha tāya ati etena viññāṇassa ekanta sārammaṇa tā dassanena
translated: It is said that the mind element is like the prenascent and postnascent states of the mind faculty, though there is no such thing as prenascence and postnascence, because it is immediately prior and immediately subsequent to the mind faculty.

original: “ārammaṇena vinā sayameva nīlādiābhāsaṃ cittaṃ pavattatī”ti evaṃ pavattitaṃ viññāṇavādaṃ paṭisedheti.
analyzed: ārammaṇena vinā sayam eva nīla ādi ābhāsam cittam pavattati iti evam pavattitam viññāṇa vādam paṭisedheti
translated: By the words “because it cannot occur without taking something else as its object” he rejects the theory of consciousness put forward thus, “Consciousness occurs with the appearance of blue, etc., by itself without an object” , showing that consciousness has a specific object.

original: 184. Ekanānāsantānagatānanti ekasantānagatānaṃ abhinnasantānagatānaṃ dvārānaṃ, nānāsantānagatānaṃ
analyzed: eka nānā santāna gatānanti eka santāna gatānan abhinna santāna gatānan dvārānan nānā santāna gatānan
translated: “Occurring in the same and in different continuities” : the meaning is that the doors occur in the same continuity , in an unbroken continuity, and the objects occur in different continuities,

original: bhinnasantānagatānaṃ ārammaṇānanti yojanā. Ekanānājātikattāti cakkhādiekekajātikattā
analyzed: bhinna santāna gatānam ārammaṇānam ti yojanā eka nānā jātika ttā ti cakkha ādi eka eka jātika ttā
translated: in a broken continuity. “Occurring in the same and in different kinds” : the meaning is that the doors occur in the same kind , in the one kind beginning with the eye,

original: dvārānaṃ, nīlādianekajātikattā ārammaṇānaṃ.🔽Cakkhādi ekampi viññāṇassa paccayo hoti, rūpādi pana anekameva saṃhatanti imassa
analyzed: dvārānaṃ nīla ādi aneka jātika ttā ārammaṇānaṃ  cakkha ādi ekam pi viññāṇassa paccayaḥ hoti rūpa ādi pana anekam eva saṃhatanti imassa
translated: and the objects occur in different kinds, in the many kinds beginning with blue.🔽The distinction in the words “eye,” “visible-form,” etc., is made in order to show this particular meaning: the eye, etc., are conditions for consciousness as a single thing, but visible form, etc., are conditions as a plurality.

original: vā atthavisesassa dassanatthaṃ cakkhurūpādīsu vacanabhedo kato. Kiṃ pana kāraṇaṃ
analyzed: vā attha visesassa dassana ttham cakkhu rūpa ādīsu vacana bhedaḥ kataḥ kim pana kāraṇam
translated: Or alternatively, the distinction in the words “eye,” “visible-form,” etc., is made in order to show this particular meaning: the eye, etc., are conditions for consciousness as a single thing, but visible form, etc., are conditions as a plurality, being a composite.

original: cakkhādi ekampi viññāṇassa paccayo hoti, rūpādi pana anekamevāti? Paccayabhāvavisesato.
analyzed: cakkha ādi ekam pi viññāṇassa paccayaḥ hoti rūpa ādi pana anekam eva ati paccaya bhāva visesato
translated: Does the eye, etc., become a condition for consciousness in one way only, and visible data, etc., in many ways?

original: Cakkhu hi cakkhuviññāṇassa nissayapurejātaindriyavippayuttapaccayehi paccayo hontaṃ
analyzed: cakkhu hi cakkhu viññāṇassa nissaya purejāta aindriya vippayutta paccayehi paccayaḥ hontam
translated: The eye is a condition for eye-consciousness in four ways, as proximity, contiguity, predominance, and support condition.

original: atthibhāveneva hoti tasmiṃ sati tassa bhāvato, asati abhāvato, yato taṃ atthiavigatapaccayehissa
analyzed: atthi bhāvena iva hoti tasmin sati tassa bhāvataḥ asati abhāvataḥ yatas tam atthi avigata paccayehissa
translated: It is a condition in the sense of presence, because it is only when it is present that the latter is present, and because it is not when it is absent.🔽And it is a condition in the sense of non-disappearance, because it does not disappear as long as that does not disappear.

original: paccayo hotīti vuccatīti. Taṃnissayatā cassa na ekadesena allīyanavasena icchitabbā
analyzed: paccayaḥ hoti iti vuccati iti tad nissaya tā ca ssa na ekadesena allīyana vasena icchitabbā
translated: And its state of being a support should not be understood as the state of being a support for something that leans on it,

original: arūpabhāvato, atha kho garurājādīsu sissarājapurisādīnaṃ viya tappaṭibaddhavuttitāya.
analyzed: arūpa bhāvataḥ atha kho garu rāja ādīsu sissa rāja purisa ādīnam viya tad paṭibaddha vutti tāya
translated: because it is immaterial; but rather as the state of being a support for the occurrence of that consciousness, like the state of being a support for the king’s chief minister, etc.,🔽The other conditions should be understood according to their respective characteristics.

original: Itare ca paccayā tena tena visesena veditabbā. Svāyaṃ paccayabhāvo na ekasmiṃ na
analyzed: itare ca paccayā tena tena visesena veditabbā su ayam paccaya bhāvaḥ na ekasmim na
translated: And this state of being a condition does not occur in one only,

original: sambhavatīti ekampi cakkhu cakkhuviññāṇassa paccayo hotīti dassetuṃ pāḷiyaṃ “cakkhuñca
analyzed: sambhavati iti ekam pi cakkhu cakkhu viññāṇassa paccayaḥ hoti iti dassetum pāḷiyam cakkhuñca
translated: so the singular number in the phrase “The eye is a condition” should be understood as stated in the text in order to show that the eye is a condition for eye-consciousness in one way only,

original: paṭiccā”ti ekavacananiddeso kato.
analyzed: paṭicca ati ekavacana niddeso kato
translated: as presence condition.

original: Rūpaṃ pana yadipi cakkhu viya purejātaatthiavigatapaccayehi paccayo hoti puretaraṃ
analyzed: rūpam pana yadi api cakkhu viya purejāta atthi avigata paccayehi paccayaḥ hoti puretaram
translated: But materiality is a condition for the eye, etc., as conascence, mutuality, support, association, presence, non-disappearance conditions, and it is a condition for the eye-consciousness element, etc., as prenascence, postnascence, support, presence, non-disappearance conditions.

original: uppannaṃ hutvā vijjamānakkhaṇeyeva upakārakattā, tathāpi anekameva saṃhataṃ hutvā🔽paccayo hoti ārammaṇabhāvato. Yañhi paccayadhammaṃ sabhāvabhūtaṃ, parikappitākāramattaṃ
analyzed: uppannam hutvā vijjamāna kkhaṇeya iva upakāraka ttā tathā api anekam eva saṃhatam hutvā  paccayaḥ hoti ārammaṇa bhāvataḥ yat hi paccaya dhammam sabhāva bhūtam parikappita ākāra mattam
translated: But though materiality is a condition for eye-consciousness, etc., as conascence, mutuality, support, presence, non- disappearance, and postnascence conditions, still it is only as object condition that it is a condition for the consciousness that arises next to that, since it is helpful at the very moment of its presence.🔽But though it is only as object condition that it is a condition for that, still it is only a single materiality that is a condition for the many, for the many occur in dependence on it.🔽For the consciousness that occurs distinguishing the materiality as its condition, whether it be in its individual essence or in the aspect of a concept, is a condition for the many, though they are not its effects.

original: vā viññāṇaṃ vibhāventaṃ pavattati, tadaññesañca satipi paccayabhāve so tassa sārammaṇasabhāvato🔽yaṃ kiñci anālambitvā pavattituṃ asamatthassa olubbha pavattikāraṇatāya ālambanīyato
analyzed: vā viññāṇam vibhāventam pavattati tad aññesam ca sati pi paccaya bhāve saḥ tassa sa ārammaṇa sabhāvato  yam kiñci an ālambitvā pavattitum asamatthassa olubbha pavatti kāraṇa tāya ālambanīyato
translated: And though the other conditions are conditions for that consciousness, still it is only the object that is so called because it is the cause of its occurrence by penetrating it.🔽For it is impossible for any consciousness to occur without taking an object.

original: ārammaṇaṃ nāma. Tassa yasmā yathā yathā sabhāvūpaladdhi viññāṇassa ārammaṇapaccayalābho,
analyzed: ārammaṇam nāma tassa yasmai yathā yathā sabhāva upaladdhi viññāṇassa ārammaṇa paccaya lābho
translated: And the more the individual essence of the materiality is apprehended, the more the consciousness gets the opportunity to arise as object condition.

original: tasmā cakkhuviññāṇaṃ rūpaṃ ārabbha pavattamānaṃ tassa sabhāvaṃ vibhāventameva pavattati.
analyzed: tasmā cakkhu viññāṇam rūpam ārabbha pavattamānam tassa sabhāvam vibhāventam eva pavattati
translated: So eye-consciousness, which occurs making the materiality its object, occurs only by distinguishing its individual essence.

original: Sā cassa indriyādhīnavuttikassa ārammaṇasabhāvūpaladdhi na ekadvikalāpagatavaṇṇavaseneva
analyzed: sā ca ssa indriya adhīna vuttikassa ārammaṇa sabhā vūpaladdhi na eka dvi kalā apagata vaṇṇa vasena iva
translated: And the apprehension of the individual essence of the object in one who has faculties that are subject to alteration is not by means of a colour that is devoid of one or other of the two, namely, singularity or plurality.

original: hoti, nāpi katipayakalāpavaṇṇavasena, atha kho ābhogānurūpaṃ āpāthagatavaṇṇavasenāti🔽anekameva rūpaṃ saṃhaccakāritāya viññāṇassa paccayo hotīti dassento bhagavā “rūpe
analyzed: hoti na api katipaya kalāpa vaṇṇa vasena atha kho ābhoga anurūpam āpāthagata vaṇṇa vasena ati  anekam eva rūpam saṃhacca kāritāya viññāṇassa paccayaḥ hoti iti dassentaḥ bhagavā rūpe
translated: And the apprehension of the individual essence of the object of the consciousness that occurs under the domination of the faculties is not by means of a colour devoid of the one or the other of the two, nor by means of a colour consisting of a number of components, but rather by means of a colour that has come into the focus of attention in accordance with the degree of attention given to the object.

original: cā”ti bahuvacanena niddisi.🔽Yaṃ pana “rūpāyatanaṃ cakkhuviññāṇadhātuyā, taṃsampayuttakānañca dhammānaṃ ārammaṇapaccayena🔽paccayo”ti vuttaṃ, taṃ kathanti? Tampi yādisaṃ rūpāyatanaṃ cakkhuviññāṇassa ārammaṇapaccayo,🔽tādisameva sandhāya vuttaṃ. Kīdisaṃ pana tanti? Samuditanti pākaṭoyamattho. Evañca
analyzed: ca ati bahuvacanena nid disi  yam pana rūpa āyatanam cakkhu viññāṇa dhātuyā tad sampayuttakānaṃ ca dhammānam ārammaṇa paccayena  paccayaḥ ti vuttam tam katham ti tam pi yādisam rūpa āyatanam cakkhu viññāṇassa ārammaṇa paccayo  tādisam eva sandhāya vuttam kīdisam pana tat ti samuditam ti pākaṭaḥ ayam atthaḥ evam ca
translated: Thus, showing that many kinds of materiality are a condition for consciousness by acting as its consolidating cause, the Blessed One described it with the plural form “material dhammas” .🔽But what is said in the Abhidhamma text, “The visible-data base is a condition, as object condition, for eye-consciousness element and for the states associated therewith” , how is that to be understood? That too is said with reference to the kind of visible-data base that is a condition by object for eye-consciousness.

original: katvā yadeke vadanti “āyatanasallakkhaṇavasena cakkhuviññāṇādayo sallakkhaṇārammaṇā,
analyzed: katvā yat eke vadanti āyatana sat lakkhaṇa vasena cakkhu viññāṇa ādayo sat lakkhaṇa ārammaṇā
translated: But what kind is that? The meaning is, “The obvious one.” And when it is put like this, then it is in agreement with what some say, namely, that eye-consciousness, etc., have as their object the visible-data base, etc., as delimited by the defining of the sense bases .

original: na dabyasallakkhaṇavasenā”ti, taṃ yuttameva hoti. Na cettha samudāyārammaṇatā āsaṅkitabbā🔽samudāyābhogasseva abhāvato, samuditā pana vaṇṇadhammā ārammaṇapaccayā honti. Kathaṃ🔽pana paccekaṃ asamatthā samuditā ārammaṇā honti, na hi paccekaṃ daṭṭhuṃ asakkontā
analyzed: na dabya sat lakkhaṇa vasena ati tam yuttam eva hoti na ca ittha samudāya ārammaṇa tā āsaṅkitabbā  samudāya ābhogassa iva abhāvato samuditā pana vaṇṇa dhammā ārammaṇa paccayāḥ honti kathaṃ  pana paccekam asamatthā samuditāḥ ārammaṇāḥ honti na hi paccekam daṭṭhum a sakkontā
translated: And here the condition by way of object should not be supposed to be a condition by way of a single aggregate as object,🔽because there is no such thing as a single aggregate as object. But the visible-data objects that are combined are a condition by way of object condition.

original: andhā samuditā passantīti? Nayidamekantikaṃ visuṃ asamatthānaṃ sivikāvahanādīsu samatthatāya🔽dassanato. Kesādīnañca yasmiṃ ṭhāne ṭhitānaṃ paccekaṃ vaṇṇaṃ gahetuṃ na sakkā, tasmiṃyeva
analyzed: andhā samuditā passanti iti na yidam ekantikam visum a samatthānam sivikā vahana ādīsu samattha tāya  dassanataḥ kesa ādīnam ca yasmim ṭhāne ṭhitānam paccekam vaṇṇam gahetum na sakkā tasmiṃ yeva
translated: But how can they be a condition by way of object when they are incapable of being objects severally? For just as the blind men in the parable were incapable of apprehending an elephant severally, so too, when they are combined, they are incapable of being seen.🔽This is not conclusive. For it is seen that what is incapable of being done severally is done when combined, as in the case of the carrying of the palanquin by the four men.

original: ṭhāne samuditānaṃ taṃ gahetuṃ sakkāti bhiyyopi tesaṃ saṃhaccakāritā paribyattā. Etena
analyzed: ṭhāne tam gahetum sakkā ati bhiyyas pi tesam saṃhacca kāritā paribyattāḥ etena
translated: And the combining of the hairs, etc., is still more evident in the case of the place where they are, since the colour there cannot be apprehended if the hairs, etc., are not apprehended.

original: kiṃ cakkhuviññāṇassa paramāṇurūpaṃ ārammaṇaṃ, udāhu taṃsamudāyotiādikā codanā paṭikkhittā
analyzed: kim cakkhu viññāṇassa paramāṇu rūpam ārammaṇam udāhu tad samudāyaḥ ti ādikā codanā paṭikkhittā
translated: And by this it should be understood that the objection that the ultimate units of matter are the object of eye-consciousness, or that the combination of them is, is refuted.

original: veditabbā. “Sotañca paṭicca sadde cā”tiādīsupi ayameva nayo.
analyzed: veditabbā sotañca paṭicca sadde ayam eva nayaḥ
translated: The same method applies in the case of the passage: “With the ear as condition and sounds” , and so on.

original: Evampi attho labbhatīti “manodhātuyāpī”ti pi-saddena na kevalaṃ javanapariyosānā
analyzed: evam pi atthaḥ labbhati iti manaḥ dhātuyā api iti pi saddena na kevalam javana pariyosānā
translated: So the meaning is possible.

original: manoviññāṇadhātuyeva sampiṇḍīyati, atha kho tadārammaṇabhavaṅgasaṅkhātāpi sampiṇḍīyatīti
analyzed: manaḥ viññāṇa dhātuyā iva sampiṇḍīyati atha kho tad ārammaṇa bhavaṅga saṅkhātā api sampiṇḍīyati iti
translated: The word “also” in the words “in the mind element too” does not imply that only the resultant mind-consciousness element is included, but that the life-continuum, which is of the same object, is also included.

original: evampi attho labbhati, sambhavatīti attho. Evaṃ satīti evaṃ aññamanodhātuppavattiyā
analyzed: evam pi atthaḥ labbhati sambhavati iti atthaḥ evam sati iti evam añña manaḥ dhātu ppavattiyā
translated: So the meaning is possible, is what is meant.

original: oraṃ pavattacittānaṃ manoviññāṇadhātutādassane sati. Satipi manaso sambhūtabhāve
analyzed: pavatta cittānam manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu tā dassane sati sati api manaso sambhūta bhāve
translated: When that is so, then, when the mind-consciousness element is shown as the first of the kinds of consciousness occurring before the occurrence of another mind element,🔽although there is a state of being produced from the mind,

original: manodhātuyā manoviññāṇadhātubhāvappasaṅgo na hotiyeva taṃsabhāvasseva manoviññāṇadhātubhāvena
analyzed: manaḥ dhātuyāḥ manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu bhāva ppasaṅgaḥ na taṃsa bhāvassa iva manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu bhāvena
translated: there is no implication that the mind element is the mind-consciousness element, because the mind-consciousness element is shown as having that same state.

original: niddiṭṭhattā. Idāni tamevatthaṃ “pañcaviññāṇadhātumanodhātū”tiādinā pākaṭataraṃ karoti.
analyzed: niddiṭṭha ttā idāni tam evattham pañca viññāṇa dhātu manaḥ dhātu uti ādinā pākaṭataram karoti
translated: Now he makes the meaning clear by the words “The five-door and mind-consciousness elements” and so on.

original: Tabbidhurasabhāvenāti pañcaviññāṇadhātūhi visadisasabhāvena. Uppattiṭṭhānena cāti
analyzed: tad bidhu rasa bhāvena ati pañca viññāṇa dhātūhi visadisa sabhāvena uppatti ṭṭhānena ca ati
translated: By the difference in their individual essences: by the difference in their individual essences from the five-door-consciousness element.🔽By the difference in their physical bases: by the difference in their physical bases, which are the eye, etc., and are delimited by the eye-consciousness element, and so on.

original: manodhātukiriyamanoviññāṇadhātuādīhi paricchinnena uppajjanaṭṭhānena ca. Idāni ekattaggahaṇaṃ
analyzed: manaḥ dhātu kiriya manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu ādīhi paricchinnena uppajjana ṭṭhānena ca idāni ekatta gahaṇam
translated: Now, the inclusion of the mind element and the mind-consciousness element under the heading of “one kind”

original: vināpi yathāvuttassa atthassa sambhavaṃ dassetuṃ “anupanītepī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: vinā api yathā vuttassa atthassa sambhavam dassetum anupanīte pi itiādi vuttam tattha
translated: The words “even though not brought to mind” are stated in order to show that the meaning stated above can be understood even without the words.🔽By way of similarity: by way of likeness.🔽That: the consciousness arisen next to the life-continuum.

original: sāmaññavasenāti sadisatāvasena. Tassāti bhavaṅgānantaraṃ uppannacittassa. Amanoviññāṇadhātubhāvāsiddhitoti🔽manodhātubhāvāsiddhito. Na hi “manoviññāṇadhātuyāpi uppajjitvā niruddhasamanantaraṃ
analyzed: sāmañña vasena āti sadisa tā vasena tassa iti bhavaṅga anantaram uppanna cittassa a manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu bhāva asiddhito ti  manaḥ dhātu bhāva asiddhitaḥ na hi manaḥ viññāṇa dhātuyā api uppajjitvā niruddha samanantaram
translated: Because the state of mind-consciousness element is not established:

original: uppajjati cittaṃ…pe… tajjā manoviññāṇadhātū”ti idaṃ vacanaṃ bhavaṅgānantaraṃ uppannacittassa
analyzed: uppajjati tad jāḥ manaḥ viññāṇa dhātū ti idam vacanam bhavaṅga anantaram uppanna cittassa
translated: because the state of mind element is not established. For this statement: “Immediately after mind-consciousness element has ceased, consciousness arises … that is accompanied by equanimity” does not establish the state of mind element for the consciousness arisen next to the life-continuum.

original: manodhātubhāvaṃ sādheti. Siddhe hi manodhātubhāve taṃ tassa nivattakaṃ siyāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: manaḥ dhātu bhāvam sādheti siddhe hi manaḥ dhātu bhāve tam tassa nivattakam siyā ti adhippāyaḥ
translated: The intention is this: for if the state of mind element were established, then that statement would be a reason for it.

original: Manoviññāṇadhātuyā pana uppannassa cittassa manoviññāṇadhātubhāvadīpakaṃ vacanaṃ
analyzed: manaḥ viññāṇa dhātuyā pana uppannassa cittassa manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu bhāva dīpakam vacanam
translated: But the statement that illuminates the state of mind-consciousness element for the consciousness arisen next to mind-consciousness element

original: tādisāya manodhātuyāpi manoviññāṇadhātubhāvameva dīpeyyāti kathaṃ tassā nivattakaṃ
analyzed: tādisāya manaḥ dhātuyā api manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu bhāvam eva dīpeyya ati katham tassāḥ nivattakam
translated: would illuminate the state of mind-consciousness element for such a mind element as well. So how could it be a reason for it?

original: siyāti āha “na hi yaṃ codīyati, tadeva parihārāya hotī”ti.
analyzed: āha na hi yam codīyati tat eva parihārāya hoti iti
translated: Therefore he says: “For what is questioned is not the same as what is the answer.”

original: Yadi evaṃ pañcadvārāvajjanassa manoviññāṇadhātubhāvāpatti evāti codanaṃ manasi katvā
analyzed: yadi evam manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu bhāva āpatti eva ati codanam manasi katvā
translated: If that is so, then the adverting of the five doors must be the mind element, the mind base, and the mind faculty, too?

original: āha “manodhātuyāpī”tiādi. Pañcaviññāṇehi manodhātūhi ca visiṭṭho sabhāvo pañcaviññāṇa…pe…🔽sabhāvo, tassa vasena. Cutipaṭisandhibhavaṅgānanti tadārammaṇampi bhavaṅgantogadhaṃ
analyzed: āha manaḥ dhātuyā api itiādi pañca viññāṇehi manaḥ dhātūhi ca visiṭṭhaḥ sabhāvaḥ pañca viññāṇa pe  sabhāvo tassa vasena tad ārammaṇam pi
translated: The answer is: “In the mind element too” . The individual essence that is distinguished from the five consciousnesses and the mind element is the mind base, the mind faculty, and the consciousness aggregate.🔽The meaning is: in the sense of that individual essence. “Death, rebirth-linking, and life-continuum” : the object of the adverting is also included in the life-continuum.

original: katvā vuttaṃ. Javanāvasānānīti vā javanārammaṇattā tadārammaṇampi gahitaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: katvā vuttam javana avasānāni iti vā javana ārammaṇa ttā tad ārammaṇam pi gahitam daṭṭhabbam
translated: Or the meaning is: because it is the object of impulsion, the object of adverting is also included in the life-continuum.

original: Tenevāha “chadvārikacittehi vā”tiādi.
analyzed: tena iva āha cha dvārika cittehi vāti ādi
translated: That is why he says “or in the six consciousnesses.”

original: Visuṃ kātuṃ yuttanti āvajjanampi yadipi rūpādivisayaṃ hoti, javanaṃ viya ārammaṇarasānubhavanaṃ🔽pana na hotīti edise ṭhāne visuṃ kātabbameva. Mano cāti ca-saddo “manañca paṭiccā”tiādīsu
analyzed: visum kātum yuttanti āvajjanam pi yadi api rūpa ādi visayam hoti javanam viya ārammaṇa rasa anubhavanam  pana na hoti iti edise ṭhāne visum kātabbam eva manaḥ ca ati ca saddaḥ manam ca paṭicca ati ādīsu
translated: Although the object of adverting is visible data, etc., like the object of impulsion, it is not the experience of the taste of the object.🔽It should be treated separately in such instances.🔽The meaning of the word “and” in the phrase “mind and mental factors” is not the meaning of combination, as in the phrase “mind and bodily form” ,

original: viya na sampiṇḍanattho, atha kho byatirekattho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: viya na sampiṇḍana tthaḥ atha kho byatireka atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: but rather the meaning of excess, as in the phrase “mind and mental factors” .

original: Abhidhammabhājanīyavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: abhidhammabhājanīya vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the section of the Abhidhamma is ended.

original: 3. Pañhapucchakavaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the questions and answers

original: Heṭṭhā vuttanayattāti dhammadhātumanoviññāṇadhātūnaṃ “pañcapaṇṇāsa kāmāvacaradhamme
analyzed: heṭṭhā vutta naya ttā ati dhammadhātu manaḥ viññāṇa dhātūnam pañcapaṇṇāsa kāmāvacara dhamme
translated: ‘In the way stated above’ means that the fifty-five states of the sense sphere,🔽

original: ārabbha rajjantassā”tiādinā parittārammaṇādibhāve dassiyamāne “cittuppādarūpavasena
analyzed: ārabbha rajjantassa ati ādinā paritta ārammaṇa ādi bhāve dassiyamāne cittuppāda rūpa vasena
translated: “In the way stated above” means that when the states of the fine-material sphere are shown to be the object of the mind element and mind-consciousness element, it is done by way of the fifty-five fine-material-sphere states,

original: taṃ taṃ samudāyaṃ ekekaṃ dhammaṃ katvā”tiādinā tadatthassa khandhavibhaṅgavaṇṇanādīsu vuttanayattā.
analyzed: tam tam samudāyam ekekam dhammam katvā iti ādinā tad atthassa khandha vibhaṅga vaṇṇanā ādīsu vutta naya ttā
translated: and when the formless-sphere states are shown to be their object, it is done by way of the formless-sphere states.

original: Pañhapucchakavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: pañha pucchaka vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the questions is ended.

original: Dhātuvibhaṅgavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dhātu vibhaṅga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the exposition of the elements is ended.

original: 4. Saccavibhaṅgo
analyzed: sacca vibhaṅgaḥ
translated: The Exposition of the Truths

original: 1. Suttantabhājanīyavaṇṇanā
translated: The Commentary on the Suttas as Requisites

original: Uddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: uddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: The Commentary on the Enumeration

original: 189. Saccavinimuttaṃ natthi pavattinivattitadubhayahetusandassanavasena pavattanato.
analyzed: sacca vinimuttam natthi pavatti nivatti tad ubhaya hetu sandassana vasena pavattanato
translated: Because it shows the occurrence, the cessation, and the cause of both, there is no occurrence apart from the truths.

original: Saccesu kamatīti saccesu visayabhūtesu pavattati. Desetabbatthavisayā hi desanāti.
analyzed: saccesu kamati iti saccesu visaya bhūtesu pavattati desetabba attha visayā hi desanā ati
translated: It occurs in the truths: it occurs in the truths that are its domain. For the teaching is the domain of the object to be taught.

original: Etesu kamatīti etesu ariyasaccesu pariññādikiccasādhanavasena pavattati. “Sīlasamādhipaññāsaṅkhāta”nti
analyzed: etesu kamati iti etesu ariya saccesu pariññā ādi kicca sādhana vasena pavattati sīla samādhi paññā saṅkhātanti
translated: It occurs in these: it occurs in these noble truths by accomplishing the functions of full understanding, etc. “Consisting in virtue, concentration, and wisdom” .

original: vuttaṃ atthasabhāvaṃ kamanakiriyāya kattubhāvena gahitanti pākaṭataraṃ katvā dassetuṃ🔽“kiṃ kamatī”ti pucchati. Tabbohārenāti tadupacārena. Etena nippariyāyena atthasabhāvaṃ
analyzed: vuttam attha sabhāvam kamana kiriyāya kattu bhāvena gahitan ti pākaṭataram katvā dassetum  kim kamati iti pucchati tad bohārena ati tad upacārena etena nippariyāyena attha sabhāvam
translated: In order to show the meaning of the word “nature” by making it more evident, he asks, “What does it do?”

original: sāsanaṃ, pariyāyena vacanasabhāvanti dasseti.🔽Taṃsabhāvāti dukkhādisabhāvā. Amusāsabhāvāti bādhanādibhāvena bhūtasabhāvā. Aññākārarahitāti
analyzed: sāsanam pariyāyena vacana sabhāvanti dasseti  tad sabhāvā ati dukkha ādi sabhāvā amusā sabhāvā amusā sabhāvā ati bādhanā ādi bhāvena bhūta sabhāvā añña ākāra rahitā ati
translated: The phrase “by the method of that” refers to the method of the word “nature.” He shows that the Dispensation is the nature of meaning by the method of the ultimate, and that it is the nature of words by the method of the conventional.🔽The phrase “the nature of that” refers to the nature of suffering, etc. The phrase “the nature of what is not a false teaching” refers to the nature of what is true by way of being oppressive, etc. The phrase “devoid of any other mode” refers to the absence of any mode other than that of non-oppression, etc.

original: abādhanādiākāravivittā. Dvidhāti dukkhadukkhatātannimittatāhi. Rāgādikilesapariḷāho🔽kilesadāho. Santānassa avipphārikatākaraṇaṃ puggalahiṃsanaṃ. Attano eva tikhiṇabhāvoti
analyzed: a bādhanā ādi ākāra vivittā dvidhā ati dukkha dukkha tā tad nimitta tāhi rāga ādi kilesa pariḷāhaḥ  kilesa dāho santānassa a vipphārika tā karaṇam puggala hiṃsanam attanaḥ eva tikhiṇa bhāvaḥ ti
translated: The phrase “in two ways” refers to the two modes of suffering and the cause of suffering. The phrase “the burning of defilements” refers to the burning of lust, etc.

original: saṅkhatadhammassa attano sabhāveneva rujāvahatikkhabhāvo. Sarasenevāti sabhāveneva.
analyzed: saṅkhata dhammassa attanaḥ sabhāvena iva rujā vaha tikkhabhāvo sarasena iva ati sabhāvena iva
translated: The phrase “the burning of defilements” refers to the burning of lust, etc. The phrase “the harmfulness of individuals” refers to the prevention of the non-diffusion of the continuum. The phrase “the sharpness of one’s own” refers to the sharpness of the conditioned thing by way of its own nature, as it causes pain.

original: Sampiṇḍakassa samudayassa, kilesasantāparahitassa maggassa, avipariṇāmassa nirodhassa
analyzed: sampiṇḍakassa samudayassa kilesa santāpa rahitassa maggassa avipariṇāmassa nirodhassa
translated: The phrase “as if by a saw” refers to the sharpness of the conditioned thing by way of its own nature. The phrase “the arising of the mass” refers to the arising of the mass of defilements. The phrase “the path devoid of the burning of defilements” refers to the path devoid of the burning of defilements. The phrase “the non-change of cessation” refers to the cessation that is not subject to change.

original: dassanena yathāsaṅkhyaṃ dukkhassa saṅkhatasantāpavipariṇāmaṭṭhā āvi bhavantīti āha🔽“itare yathākkamaṃ samudayamagganirodhadassanehi āvibhavanākārā”ti. Byāpetvāti bhavādīsu
analyzed: dassanena yathāsaṅkhyam dukkhassa saṅkhata santāpa vipariṇāma ṭṭhā āvi bhavanti iti āha  itare yathākkamam samudaya magga nirodha dassanehi āvi bhavana ākārā ati byāpetvā ati bhava ādīsu
translated: The three characteristics of the formed, namely, pain, change, and the fact that there is no self, become evident respectively through the seeing of suffering, its origin, and its cessation.🔽The other three characteristics become evident respectively through the seeing of the origin, the path, and cessation.

original: nānārammaṇesu ca visaṭā hutvā. Anekatthattā dhātūnaṃ “ūhanaṃ rāsikaraṇa”nti vatvā🔽puna tadatthaṃ vivarati “dukkhanibbattana”nti. Ekavokārabhavepi hi rāsibhūtameva
analyzed: nānā ārammaṇesu ca visaṭāḥ hutvā aneka attha tā dhātūnam ūhanam rāsikaraṇam ti vatvā  puna tad attham vivarati eka vokāra bhave pi hi rāsi bhūtam eva
translated: “Spreading out” means that they spread out over the various objects such as existence, etc., and over the various objects of consciousness.

original: dukkhaṃ nibbattati anekadhammasamūhato, pageva catupañcavokārabhavesu. Ettha ca byāpanatthaṃ
analyzed: dukkham nibbattati aneka dhamma samūhataḥ pagā iva catu pañca vokāra bhavesu ettha ca byāpana attham
translated: Having said that “spreading out” means “heaping up,” he explains the meaning again: “producing suffering.” For suffering is produced as a heap even in a single-constituent existence, to say nothing of a five-constituent existence.

original: ākāraṃ, tassa ca ya-kārāgamaṃ katvā sampiṇḍanatthaṃ āyūhananti padaṃ veditabbaṃ.🔽Nidadātīti dukkhassa ekantakāraṇattā taṃ nidassentaṃ viya janetīti dassento “idaṃ
analyzed: ākāram tassa ca yakāra āgamam katvā sampiṇḍana attham āyūhananti padam veditabbam  nidadāti iti dukkhassa ekanta kāraṇa ttā tam nidassentam viya janeti iti dassentaḥ idam
translated: And here the word “spreading out” should be understood as “heaping up” in the sense of “spreading out.”

original: taṃ dukkha”ntiādimāha. Dukkha…pe… āvi bhavati rogadassanena viya roganidānaṃ. Saṃyoga…pe…
analyzed: tam dukkham ti ādim āha dukkha pe āvi bhavati roga dassanena viya roga nidānam saṃyoga pe
translated: “Indicating” means that it generates suffering as if it were indicating it, since it is the sole cause of suffering. Showing this, he says: “This is that suffering.” … becomes evident through the seeing of suffering, etc., as the cause of a disease becomes evident through the seeing of the disease.

original: dassanehīti saṃyogaṭṭho visaṃyogasabhāvassa nirodhassa, palibodhaṭṭho niyyānasabhāvassa
analyzed: dassanehi iti saṃyoga ṭṭhaḥ visaṃyoga sabhāvassa nirodhassa palibodha ṭṭhaḥ niyyāna sabhāvassa
translated: “Seeing” is the meaning of “in the case of” the cessation that has the nature of disjunction from the state of bondage, and of the path that has the nature of escape from the state of obstruction.

original: maggassa dassanena āvi bhavatīti attho. Teti saṃyogapalibodhaṭṭhā.
analyzed: maggassa dassanena āvi bhavati iti saṃyoga palibodha ṭṭhā
translated: The meaning is that the state of disjunction and the state of escape become evident through seeing. “These” : the state of bondage and the state of obstruction.

original: Etthāti etasmiṃ ārammaṇabhūte sati. Samudayato viveko vivekaṭṭho. Nirodho ca taṇhākkhayabhāvato
analyzed: ettha ati etasmin ārammaṇa bhūte sati samudayataḥ vivekaḥ viveka ṭṭhaḥ nirodho ca taṇhā kkhaya bhāvato
translated: “Here” : in the case of the object of clinging. The state of seclusion is the meaning of “seclusion” from origination. And cessation is secluded from origination because it is the state of destruction of craving.

original: samudayato vivitto, tasmā avivekabhūtassa samudayassa dassanena nirodhassa vivekaṭṭho
analyzed: samudayataḥ vivittaḥ tasmai aviveka bhūtassa samudayassa dassanena nirodhassa viveka ṭṭho
translated: Therefore the state of seclusion of cessation becomes evident through seeing origination, which is not secluded from cessation.

original: āvi bhavati, nibbānādhigamahetubhūtassāpi maggassa sappaccayatāya saṅkhatabhāvaṃ🔽passato appaccayassa nirodhassa asaṅkhataṭṭho āvi bhavati, tathā maraṇadhammatāya
analyzed: āvi bhavati nibbāna adhigama hetu bhūtassa api maggassa sappaccaya tāya saṅkhata bhāvam  passataḥ appaccayassa nirodhassa asaṅkhata ṭṭho āvi bhavati tathā maraṇa dhamma tāya
translated: The state of the unconditioned of cessation becomes evident through seeing the conditioned state of the path, which has a condition, as the cause for the attainment of Nibbāna.

original: dukkhaṃ vinassantaṃ passato amaraṇadhammassa nirodhassa amataṭṭho āvi bhavatīti imamatthaṃ
analyzed: dukkham vinassantam passataḥ amaraṇa dhammassa nirodhassa amata ṭṭhaḥ āvi bhavati iti imam attham
translated: Likewise, the state of the deathless of cessation becomes evident through seeing suffering, which has the nature of death, as subject to destruction and not having the nature of the deathless.

original: dasseti “vivekā”tiādinā. Itare samudayanirodhadukkhadassanehīti ettha samudayadassanena
analyzed: dasseti viveka ati ādinā itare samudaya nirodha dukkha dassanehi iti ettha samudaya dassanena
translated: He shows this meaning with the words “seclusion” and so on. “In the case of” the seeing of origination, cessation, and suffering.

original: “nāyaṃ hetu nibbānādhigamāya, ayaṃ pana hetū”ti hetuṭṭho āvi bhavati. Tathā paramagambhīrassa
analyzed: na ayam hetu nibbāna adhigamāya ayam pana hetu uti hetuṭṭhaḥ bhavati tathā parama gambhīrassa
translated: “This is not the cause for the attainment of Nibbāna, but this is the cause,” the meaning of cause becomes evident.🔽Likewise, by the seeing of cessation, which is supremely profound,

original: nipuṇatarassa duddasassa nirodhassa dassanena dassanaṭṭho sukhumarūpadassanena cakkhuno🔽viya, dukkhadassanena pana anekarogāturakapaṇajanadassanena issarajanassa uḷārabhāvo
analyzed: nipuṇatarassa duddasassa nirodhassa dassanena dassana ṭṭho sukhuma rūpa dassanena cakkhuno  viya dukkha dassanena pana aneka roga ātura kapaṇa jana dassanena issara janassa uḷāra bhāvo
translated: subtle, and hard to see, the meaning of seeing becomes evident, like the eye’s seeing of subtle visible forms.

original: viya maggassa ādhipateyyaṭṭho āvi bhavati.
analyzed: viya maggassa ādhipateyya ṭṭhaḥ bhavati
translated: But by the seeing of suffering, the meaning of predominance of the path becomes evident, like the greatness of a king by his seeing of a multitude of sick people and beggars.

original: Te panete hetuṭṭhādike sarūpato dassetuṃ “tattha palibodhupacchedavasenā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: te pana ete hetu ṭṭhā ādike sarūpataḥ dassetum tattha palibodha upaccheda vasena atiādi vuttam
translated: But in order to show the meaning of cause, etc., in their specific nature, it is said: “Therein, by the severance of impediments,” and so on.

original: Tattha palibodhupacchedavasenāti samudayappahānavasena. “Maggādhipatino dhammā”ti🔽vacanatoti yasmā satipi jhānādīnaṃ ārammaṇādhipatibhāve “jhānādhipatino dhammā”ti
analyzed: tattha palibodha upaccheda vasena ati samudaya ppahāna vasena magga adhipatino dhammā ti  vacanato ti yasmā sati pi jhāna ādīnam ārammaṇa adhipati bhāve jhāna adhipatino dhammā ti
translated: Therein, by the severance of impediments: by the abandoning of origination.🔽Because of the words “The states that are the overlords of the path”🔽. Although the jhānas, etc., are overlords in the sense of object, still they are not called “the states that are the overlords of the jhānas,” etc.,

original: evamādi na vuttaṃ, “maggādhipatino dhammā” icceva pana vuttaṃ. Tasmā sātisayo maggaṅgadhammānaṃ
analyzed: evamādi na vuttam magga adhipatinaḥ dhammāḥ icca iva pana vuttam tasmā sa atisayaḥ maggaṅga dhammānam
translated: but rather “the states that are the overlords of the path.” Therefore the states that are path factors

original: ārammaṇādhipatibhāvo. Tenāha “visesato vā ārammaṇādhipatibhūtā maggaṅgadhammā hontī”ti.🔽So tesaṃ ākāroti yo maggaṅgānaṃ garuṃ katvā paccavekkhaṇavasena pavattadhammānaṃ
analyzed: tena āha visesataḥ vā ārammaṇa ādhipati bhūtāḥ maggaṅga dhammāḥ honti iti  so tesam ākāro ti yaḥ maggaṅgānam garum katvā paccavekkhaṇa vasena pavatta dhammānam
translated: and the state of object-predominance. Hence he said: “Or alternatively, the states of the path are object-predominance in the sense of being the object of the reviewing that occurs by giving prominence to the states of the path.”🔽That is their mode, which is called the conditionality as object-predominance of the states of the path.

original: ārammaṇādhipatipaccayatāsaṅkhāto ākāro, so maggassa ādhipateyyaṭṭho. Purimo pana🔽ādhipateyyaṭṭho sahajātādhipativasena vutto. Abhisametabbaṭṭhoti yathāvuttapīḷanādiatthameva
analyzed: ārammaṇa adhipati paccaya tā saṅkhāto ākāro so maggassa ādhipateyya ṭṭho purimaḥ pana  ādhipateyya ṭṭhaḥ sahajāta adhipati vasena vuttaḥ abhisametabba ṭṭhaḥ ti yathā vutta pīḷana ādi attham eva
translated: The former meaning of predominance, however, is stated in terms of conascence-predominance.🔽The meaning of what is to be penetrated is stated by combining the three meanings of what is to be penetrated, namely, the meaning of affliction, etc., already mentioned, because of the necessity for the penetration of the path in the sense of the abandoning of the defilements that are to be abandoned by that path.

original: paṭivijjhitabbatāya ekajjhaṃ katvā vadati. Tena abhisamayasaddaṃ kammatthaṃ dasseti.🔽Abhisamayassāti ñāṇassa. Pavattiākāroti parijānanādivisesākāro. So hi maggakkhaṇe
analyzed: paṭivijjhitabba tāya ekajjham katvā vadati tena abhisamaya saddam kammattham dasseti  abhisamayassa ati ñāṇassa pavatti ākāro ti parijānana ādi visesa ākāro so hi magga kkhaṇe
translated: Thus he shows the verbal root in the word abhisamaya .

original: asammohato siddho, pacchā paccavekkhaṇādinā pākaṭo hoti. Ākāropi ñāṇena araṇīyato
analyzed: asammohataḥ siddho pacchā paccavekkhaṇa ādinā pākaṭaḥ hoti ākāraḥ api ñāṇena araṇīyato
translated: The mode of occurrence of the knowledge is the mode of occurrence of the distinction consisting in the full-understanding, etc., for that is established at the moment of the path by the non-delusion of the knowledge of the way, and afterwards it becomes evident by reviewing, etc.🔽And since the mode is called the meaning because it is to be penetrated by the knowledge, the third method is shown.

original: atthoti vuccatīti katvā tatiyanayo dassito. Pīḷanādinā dassito visayavibhāgenapi
analyzed: attho ti vuccati iti katvā tatiya nayaḥ dassitaḥ pīḷana ādinā dassitaḥ visaya vibhāgena api
translated: The meaning of the distinction of the object is shown by the meaning of affliction, etc.

original: visayivibhāgo hoti yathā “rūpasaññā, saddasaññā”ti.🔽Kucchitaṃ khanti garahitaṃ hutvā asāraṃ. “Samāgamo”tiādinā anvayato byatirekato ca🔽saṃ-saddassa saṃyogatthajotakattamāha. “Uppannaṃ udita”ntiādīsu kevalassa panna-saddassa,
analyzed: visayi vibhāgaḥ hoti yathā rūpa saññā sadda saññā ti  hutvā asāram anvayataḥ ca  saṃsaddassa saṃyoga attha jotaka ttam āha uppannam uditam ti ādīsu kevalassa panna saddassa
translated: There is a division of the domain, as in “perception of visible form, perception of sound.”🔽The word “conjoined” is used in the sense of “conjoined with” in the phrase “conjoined with the six bases.”🔽The word “arisen” is used in the sense of “originated” in the phrase “arisen, originated.”🔽The word “originated” is used in the sense of “originated” in the phrase “originated, arisen.”

original: ita-saddassa ca payoge uppattiatthassa anupalabbhanato, u-saddassa ca payoge upalabbhanato
analyzed: ita saddassa ca payoge uppatti atthassa an upalabbhanato u saddassa ca payoge upalabbhanato
translated: The word “arisen” is used in the sense of “originated” in the phrase “arisen, originated.”🔽The word “originated” is used in the sense of “originated” in the phrase “originated, arisen.”

original: so uppattiatthaṃ dīpetīti āha “evaṃ uppannaṃ uditanti etthāpī”ti. Visuṃ payujjamānāti
analyzed: saḥ uppatti attham dīpeti iti āha evam uppannam uditam ti ettha api iti visum payujjamānā ati
translated: The word “arisen” is used in the sense of “originated” in the phrase “arisen, originated.”🔽The word “originated” is used in the sense of “originated” in the phrase “originated, arisen.”🔽The word “arisen” is used in the sense of “originated” in the phrase “arisen, originated.”🔽The word “originated” is used in the sense of “originated” in the phrase “originated, arisen.”🔽The word “arisen” is used in the sense of “originated” in the phrase “arisen, originated.”🔽The word “originated” is used in the sense of “originated” in the phrase “originated, arisen.”🔽The word “arisen” is used in the sense of “originated” in the phrase “arisen, originated.”🔽The word “originated” is used in the sense of “originated” in the phrase “originated, arisen.”

original: āgama-ita-padehi vinā payujjamānā. Sadhātukanti antonītena dhātunā sadhātukaṃ. Teneva
analyzed: vinā antonītena dhātunā sa dhātukam tena iva
translated: The word “arisen” is used in the sense of “originated” in the phrase “arisen, originated.”🔽The word “originated” is used in the sense of “originated” in the phrase “originated, arisen.”

original: te “upasaggā”ti ca vuttā.
analyzed: te upasaggā iti ca vuttā
translated: The word “arisen” is used in the sense of “originated” in the phrase “arisen, originated.”🔽The word “originated” is used in the sense of “originated” in the phrase “originated, arisen.”

original: Dukkhavivekabhāvanti dukkhavivittataṃ. Nivattiyāti nibbānassa. Nivattetvāti anuppādasaddena🔽visesanavasena nivattetvā. Nirodhapaccayatā nirodhassa maggassa ārammaṇapaccayatā.
analyzed: dukkha viveka bhāvanti dukkha vivitta tam nivattiyā āti nibbānassa nivattetvā ati anuppāda saddena 🔽visesana vasena nivattetvā nirodha paccaya tā nirodhassa maggassa ārammaṇa paccaya tā
translated: The word “arisen” is used in the sense of “originated” in the phrase “arisen, originated.”🔽The word “originated” is used in the sense of “originated” in the phrase “

original: Puggalasacchikiriyādhammabhāvehīti puggaladhammabhāvena sacchikaraṇadhammabhāvena🔽ca. Phalanti ariyaphalaṃ. Tassāti niṭṭhānabhūtāya phalasaṅkhātāya dukkhanirodhappattiyā
analyzed: puggala sacchikiriyā dhamma bhāvehi iti puggala dhamma bhāvena sacchikaraṇa dhamma bhāvena  ca phalanti ariya phalam tassa ti niṭṭhāna bhūtāya phala saṅkhātāya dukkha nirodha ppattiyā
translated: “By the person’s realization and by the state of being a Dhamma”: by the person’s realization and by the state of being a Dhamma.

original: abhisamayabhūtāya dukkhanirodhappattiyā paṭipadatā daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: abhisamaya bhūtāya dukkha nirodha ppattiyā paṭipada tā daṭṭhabbā
translated: “It bears the noble fruit”: the attainment of the cessation of suffering called “fruit” should be regarded as the path, since it is the culmination of the path, and the attainment of the cessation of suffering should be regarded as the path, since it is the culmination of the path, and the attainment of the cessation of suffering should be regarded as the path, since it is the culmination of the path.🔽“At the time of penetration”: at the time of the penetration of the four truths.

original: Paṭivijjhanakāle nippariyāyena buddhādisamaññāti āha “paṭividdhakāle pavatta”nti. Tato evāti tena pakāsitattā eva.
analyzed: paṭivijjhana kāle nippariyāyena buddha ādi samaññā iti āha paṭividdha kāle pavattanti tatas eva ati tena pakāsita ttā eva
translated: “Because it is shown by that”: because it is shown by the path.

original: Tannimittabhāvoti jātiādi viya adhiṭṭhānabhāvena dukkhassa kāraṇabhāvo, na samudayasaccaṃ
analyzed: tad nimitta bhāvaḥ ti jāti ādi viya adhiṭṭhāna bhāvena dukkhassa kāraṇa bhāvaḥ na samudaya saccam
translated: “The state of being its sign”: the state of being the cause of suffering, like birth, etc., by way of being its basis, not the state of being its origin by way of arising.🔽“The state of being oppressed by arising and falling away”: the suffering of formations.

original: viya pabhavabhāvena. Udayabbayapīḷitabhāvo saṅkhāradukkhatā. Pavattanamevāti pavatti
analyzed: viya pabhava bhāvena udaya bbaya pīḷita bhāvaḥ saṅkhāra dukkha tā pavattanam evā ati pavatti
translated: “Merely occurrence”: occurrence itself.🔽“The function of the taste”: he shows that the taste has the meaning of function.

original: eva. Kiccaṃ rasoti rasassa kiccatthataṃ dasseti. Pavattinivattīsūti niddhāraṇe bhummaṃ.
analyzed: eva kiccam rasaḥ ti rasassa kiccatthatam dasseti pavatti nivattīsu iti niddhāraṇe bhummam
translated: “The occurrence and turning away”: the locative case.

original: Avikāratā vikārābhāvo niccatā.
analyzed: avikāra tā vikāra abhāvaḥ nicca tā
translated: “The state of being unalterable”: the state of being without alteration.

original: Marīcimāyāattānanti marīciyā māyāya attano ca ariyañāṇassāti ariyānaṃ ñāṇassa. Tena
analyzed: marīci māyā attānam ca ariya ñāṇassa ati ariyānam ñāṇassa tena
translated: ‘By the knowledge of noble ones and by his own knowledge of the similes of magic and illusion’: by the knowledge of noble ones and by his own knowledge of the similes of a magic trick and an illusion. Thereby

original: ariyānaṃ maggañāṇānusārena pavattanakañāṇampi saṅgahitaṃ hoti. Tenāha “avitathagāhakassā”tiādi.🔽Tesanti paṭivedhapaccavekkhaṇañāṇānaṃ. Tattha paṭivedhañāṇassa paṭivijjhitabbatā
analyzed: ariyānam magga ñāṇa anusārena pavattanaka ñāṇam pi saṅgahitam hoti tena āha avitatha gāhakassa atiādi  tesan ti paṭivedha paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇānam tattha paṭivedha ñāṇassa paṭivijjhitabba tā
translated: the knowledge that occurs in conformity with the path knowledge of noble ones is also included. Hence it was said: ‘By the knowledge that does not misapprehend.’🔽‘Theirs’: of the knowledge of penetration and of reviewing. Herein, the state of being penetrated

original: gocarabhāvo, itarassa ārammaṇabhāvo. Paṭivijjhitabbatā, ārammaṇabhāvo vā paṭivedhañāṇassa
analyzed: gocara bhāvaḥ itarassa ārammaṇa bhāvaḥ paṭivijjhitabba tā ārammaṇa bhāvaḥ vā paṭivedha ñāṇassa
