translated: is the province of the knowledge of penetration, and the state of being the object is that of the other. The state of being penetrated or the state of being the object is the province of the knowledge of penetration,

original: gocarabhāvo, itarassa ārammaṇabhāvova.🔽Bādhakappabhavabhāvenāti bādhakassa uppādakabhāvena visuṃ gahitattā na taṇhā bādhakabhāvena
analyzed: gocara bhāvo itarassa ārammaṇa bhāvaḥ uva  bādhaka ppabhava bhāvena ati bādhakassa uppādaka bhāvena visum gahita ttā na taṇhā bādhaka bhāvena
translated: and the state of being the object is that of the other.🔽‘By the state of being the cause of arising and of occurrence’: craving is not included by the state of being the cause of arising, because that is separately stated by the state of being the cause of arising. It is stated in order to show the unconfused cause of occurrence. And when it is stated thus,

original: gahitā pavattipavattihetūnaṃ asaṅkaravasena bodhanato. Evañca katvā abhidhammabhājanīyepi
analyzed: gahitā pavatti pavatti hetūnam asaṅkara vasena bodhanataḥ evam ca katvā abhidhamma bhājanīye pi
translated: this explanation of the meaning is appropriate in the Abhidhamma too.

original: ayamatthavaṇṇanā yujjateva. Yadipi evaṃ “dukkhameva bādhaka”nti niyamānupapatti,
analyzed: ayam attha vaṇṇanā yujjatā iva yadi api evam dukkham eva bādhakan ti niyama anupapatti
translated: Even though it is so, there is no logical possibility of the statement ‘Only suffering is that which is to be penetrated’ being correct.

original: samudayabhāvappasaṅgo cāti codanaṃ sandhāyāha “jātiādīnaṃ viya vā”tiādi. Bādhakattassa🔽bādhakatte ca niyamoti āha “dvidhāpi bādhakatthāvadhāraṇenā”ti. Yathā hi bādhakattassa
analyzed: samudaya bhāva ppasaṅgaḥ ca ati codanam sandhāya āha jāti ādīnam viya vāti ādi bādhaka ttassa  bādhaka tte ca niyamaḥ iti āha dvidhā api bādhaka attha avadhāraṇena ati yathā hi bādhaka ttassa
translated: and the possibility of the state of origination. He says “or like birth, etc.,” referring to the objection.🔽And the restriction to the meaning of “oppression”

original: dukkhe niyatatā, evaṃ dukkhassa ca bādhakatte niyatatāti. Suttantabhājanīye taṇhāya
analyzed: dukkhe niyatatā evam dukkhassa ca bādhaka tte niyatatā ati suttanta bhājanīye taṇhāya
translated: and the restriction to the meaning of “oppression” is also twofold. Just as the state of suffering is restricted to the meaning of “oppression,” so too the state of origination is restricted to the meaning of “possibility.”

original: eva samudayabhāvassa dassitattā taṇhāvasena niyamaṃ dassento “na taṇhāya vinā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: eva samudaya bhāvassa dassita ttā taṇhā vasena niyamam dassentaḥ na taṇhāya vinā iti ādim āha
translated: Since the state of origination is shown in the sutta as craving, he says “without craving” in order to show the restriction to craving.🔽The commentary on the sutta is this.

original: Suttantabhājanīyavaṇṇanā hesāti. “Kusalehi vinā”tiādinā dukkhahetutāya taṇhāya padhānabhāvamāha.
analyzed: suttanta bhājanīya vaṇṇanā hesā ati kusalehi vinā iti ādinā dukkha hetu tāya taṇhāya padhāna bhāvam āha
translated: He says “without the wholesome” in order to show the pre-eminent role of craving as the cause of suffering.

original: Tathā hi sā kammavicittatāya hetubhāvaṃ gacchantī visesena kammassa sahakārikāraṇaṃ
analyzed: tathā hi sā kamma vicitta tāya hetu bhāvam gacchantī visesena kammassa sahakāri kāraṇam
translated: For it is craving that becomes the cause of suffering through the variety of kamma. It is a co-operating condition of kamma in particular.

original: hotīti. Dvidhāpi niyamenāti maggova niyyānaṃ, niyyānameva ca maggoti dvippakārena niyamena.
analyzed: hoti iti dvidhā api niyamena ati maggo uva niyyānam niyyānam eva ca maggo ti dvippakārena niyamena
translated: The restriction is twofold. The path is the outlet, and the outlet is the path. The restriction is twofold in this way.

original: Vacīsaccaṃ saccavācā, taṃsamuṭṭhāpikā cetanā cāti āha “viratisacceti musāvādaviratiya”nti.
analyzed: vacī saccam sacca vācā taṃ samuṭṭhāpikā cetanā ca ati āha virati saccā iti musāvāda viratiyanti
translated: and verbal rectitude is the truth of verbal action and the volition that originates it.

original: Keci pana “viratisaccaṃ samādānaviratī”ti vadanti, tesampi na samādānamattaṃ viratisaccaṃ,
analyzed: keci pana virati saccam samādāna virati iti vadanti tesam pi na samādāna mattam virati saccam
translated: But some say that the truth of rectitude is the abstinence from what is not to be done. But for them too the truth of rectitude is not mere abstinence,

original: atha kho samādānāvisaṃvādanaṃ. Taṃ pana paṭiññāsaccattā musāvādaviratiyeva hoti.
analyzed: atha kho samādāna avisaṃvādanam tam pana paṭiññā saccattā musāvāda viratiyā iva hoti
translated: but rather the non-deception consisting in the abstinence. But that is the abstinence from false speech since it is the truth of promise.

original: Tenāha “na hi aññaviratīsu saccasaddo niruḷho”ti. Satipi dukkhasamudayāvabodhe yāvadeva
analyzed: tena āha na hi añña viratīsu sacca saddo niruḷhaḥ ti sati pi dukkha samudaya avabodhe yāvat eva
translated: Therefore it is said: “For the word ‘truth’ is not current in the other abstinences.”🔽Although there is understanding of suffering and its origin, the development of understanding is only for the purpose of attaining cessation and the path.

original: nirodhamaggādhigamatthā paññābhāvanāti pacchimadvayasseva saccatthaṃ sātisayaṃ, tadadhigamassa
analyzed: nirodha magga adhigama atthā paññā bhāvanā ti pacchima dvayassa iva saccattham sa atisayam tad adhigamassa
translated: Therefore the meaning of truth is especially pertinent to the last two. And the reason for the non-dispute about their attainment

original: ca avivādahetukaṃ sutte vibhāvitaṃ dassento “tassa panā”tiādimāha.🔽Ṭhānaṃ natthīti attano vādapatiṭṭhāpanakāraṇaṃ natthīti attho. Attabhāvapaṭilābheneva
analyzed: ca avivāda hetukam sutte vibhāvitam dassentaḥ tassa pana ati ādim āha  ṭhānam natthi iti attanaḥ vāda patiṭṭhāpana kāraṇam natthi iti attho atta bhāva paṭilābhena iva
translated: is shown in the sutta by the words “There is no ground for it.” The meaning is: there is no reason for establishing one’s own doctrine.🔽For the acquisition of the aggregates and the manifestation of birth, etc., of beings occurs only with the acquisition of an individual existence.

original: sattānaṃ jātiādīnaṃ patti sammukhībhāvo ca jāyatīti āha “sampattatā, paccakkhatā
analyzed: sattānam jāti ādīnam patti sammukhībhāvaḥ ca jāyati iti āha sampatta tā paccakkha tā
translated: Therefore it is said: “The attainment of the aggregates and the manifestation of birth, etc., of beings occurs only with the acquisition of an individual existence. Therefore it is said: ‘The attainment of the aggregates and the manifestation of birth, etc., of beings occurs only with the acquisition of an individual existence. Therefore it is said: ‘The attainment of the aggregates and the manifestation of birth, etc., of beings occurs only with the acquisition of an individual existence. Therefore it is said: ‘The attainment of the aggregates and the manifestation of birth, etc., of beings occurs only with the acquisition of an individual existence. Therefore it is said: ‘The attainment of the aggregates and the manifestation of birth, etc., of beings occurs only with the acquisition of an individual existence. Therefore it is said: ‘The attainment of the aggregates and the manifestation of birth, etc., of beings occurs only with the acquisition of an individual existence. Therefore it is said: ‘The attainment of the aggregates and the manifestation of birth, etc., of beings occurs only with the acquisition of an individual existence. Therefore it is said: ‘The attainment of the aggregates and the manifestation of birth, etc., of beings occurs only with the acquisition of an individual existence. Therefore it is said: ‘The attainment of the aggregates and the manifestation of birth, etc., of beings occurs only with the acquisition of an individual existence. Therefore it is said: ‘The attainment of the aggregates and the manifestation of

original: ca paṭhamatā”ti. Bhagavato desanākkameneva vā paṭhamāditā daṭṭhabbā.🔽Parijananādīhīti pariññāppahānasacchikiriyābhāvanāhi, nissakkavacanañcetaṃ aññasaddapekkhāya.
analyzed: ca paṭhama tā ti bhagavataḥ desanā kkamena iva vā paṭhama ādi tā daṭṭhabbā  parijanana ādīhi iti pariññā appahāna sacchikiriyā bhāvanāhi nissakka vacanam ca itam añña sadda apekkhāya
translated: and the firstness of the first, etc., should be regarded as stated by the Blessed One in the order in which he taught it.🔽‘By means of the full-understanding, etc.,’ ‘etc.’ includes abandoning, realizing, and developing. The words are in the instrumental case because they are the means.

original: Dhammañāṇakiccanti sabhāvadhammāvabodhakiccaṃ. Pariññeyyādīni etapparamānevāti ito
analyzed: dhamma ñāṇa kiccanti sabhāva dhamma avabodha kiccam pariññeyya ādīni etad paramāni eva ati itas
translated: ‘The function of the knowledge of states’ is the function of the knowledge of the states of the various individual dhammas.

original: paraṃ neyyaṃ natthīti dasseti.🔽Dukkhādīnaṃ ariyasaccabhāvassa anurūpaṃ yuttaṃ, ācariyaparamparāgataṃ vā savanaṃ
analyzed: param neyyam natthi iti dasseti  dukkha ādīnam ariya sacca bhāvassa anurūpam yuttam ācariya paramparā gatam vā savanam
translated: ‘The things to be fully understood, etc., are the ultimate’: he shows that there is nothing beyond these.🔽‘The hearing’ is the hearing of the four noble truths in their true form, in accordance with their characteristics, or it is the hearing of the teaching of the Noble Ones’ True Dhamma, which is suitable and appropriate as a means for the realization of the noble truths, or it is the hearing that comes down from teacher to pupil in the succession of the Noble Ones’ True Dhamma.

original: anussavo. Sutānusārena, aññathā vā kakkhaḷaphusanādianiccādisabhāvasāmaññākārapariggaṇhanaṃ🔽ākāraparivitakko. Yathāvitakkitākārassa diṭṭhisaṅkhātāya dassanabhūtāya paññāya nijjhānakkhamanaṃ
analyzed: anussavaḥ suta anusārena aññathā vā kakkhaḷa phusana ādi anicca ādi sabhāva sāmañña ākāra pariggaṇhanam  ākāra parivitakkaḥ yathā vitakkita ākārassa diṭṭhi saṅkhātāya dassana bhūtāya paññāya nijjhāna kkhamanam
translated: ‘The investigation of ideas’ is the apprehending of the general characteristics of impermanence, etc., in the various ideas such as the disagreeable, the painful, and so on.🔽‘The reflection on ideas’ is the reflecting with the understanding called ‘view’ on the ideas reflected upon in the way stated.🔽‘The approval of ideas’ is the approval of the truths by one who has reached the path of stream-entry.

original: rocanaṃ diṭṭhinijjhānakkhanti. Ādicco viya pabhāya nirodhaṃ phusati sacchikaroti
analyzed: rocanam ādiccaḥ viya pabhāya nirodham phusati sacchikaroti
translated: ‘The decision on ideas’ is the decision on the truths by one who has reached the path of once-return.

original: kilesandhakāraṃ viddhaṃseti. Cattāripi saccāni passatīti vuttaṃ “yo, bhikkhave, dukkhaṃ passatī”tiādinā.
analyzed: kilesa andhakāram cattāri api saccāni passati iti vuttam yaḥ bhikkhave dukkham passati itiādinā
translated: and he bursts asunder the darkness of defilement. He sees the four truths: it is said, “Bhikkhus, he who sees suffering” , and so on.

original: Kālantaradassananti nānābhisamayaṃ vadati. Ekadassinoti ekasaccadassino. Na yojetabbā
analyzed: kāla antara dassanam ti nānā abhisamayam vadati eka dassino ti eka sacca dassino na yojetabbā
translated: “Seeing at different times”: he says that there is penetration of the truths at different times. “One who sees one”: one who sees one truth. “Should not be construed”🔽with the construction “and seeing all” .

original: siyāti yojanāyañca sabbadassanaṃ dassanantaraparamanti dassanānuparamo āpajjeyya,
analyzed: siyā ati sabba dassanam dassana antara paramanti dassana anuparamaḥ āpajjeyya
translated: If it were, then he would be committed to the doctrine that the seeing of all is subsequent to the seeing of one.

original: saccānañca nānābhisamaye dukkhadassanādīhi paṭhamamaggādippaheyyānaṃ saṃyojanattayādīnaṃ🔽ekadesappahānaṃ āpajjati. Tathā ca sati ekadesasotāpattimaggaṭṭhatā, tadanantarañca
analyzed: nānā abhisamaye dukkha dassana ādīhi paṭhama magga ādi paheyyānam saṃyojana ttayā ādīnam  eka desa ppahānam āpajjati tathā ca sati eka desa sa utāpatti magga ṭṭha tā tad anantaram ca
translated: And if that were so, then he would be committed to the doctrine that there is the abandoning of only part of the three fetters, etc., by the seeing of suffering, and so on, since the three fetters, etc., are only in part to be abandoned by the first path, and so on.🔽And if that were so, then he would be committed to the doctrine that there is only partial entry into the first path, and that there is only partial fruition for the fruit that is next to that,

original: pattabbena phalena ekadesasotāpannatā ca āpajjati, tasmā na saccānaṃ nānābhisamayo
analyzed: pattabbena phalena eka desa sotāpanna tā ca āpajjati tasmā na nānā abhisamayaḥ
translated: which is attained. Therefore the penetration of the truths at different times is not tenable.

original: yutto. Yathā ca nānābhisamayo na yutto, evaṃ ārammaṇābhisamayopi. Yadi hi ārammaṇakaraṇena
analyzed: yuttaḥ yathā ca nānā abhisamayaḥ na yuttaḥ evam ārammaṇa abhisamayaḥ api yadi hi ārammaṇa karaṇena
translated: And just as the penetration of the truths at different times is not tenable, so also the penetration of the object is not tenable. For if it were, then

original: catusaccābhisamayo icchito, na maggo sayameva attānaṃ ārammaṇaṃ karotīti aparipuṇṇo
analyzed: catu sacca abhisamayaḥ icchitaḥ na maggo sayam eva attānam ārammaṇam karoti iti aparipuṇṇaḥ
translated: The four truths are intended to be penetrated, not the path. The path does not make itself its own object. So the penetration of the truths is incomplete.

original: saccābhisamayo siyā. Aññena maggena maggo ālambīyatīti paripuṇṇovāti ce? Evaṃ sati
analyzed: sacca abhisamayaḥ siyā aññena maggena maggaḥ ālambīyati iti ce evam sati
translated: If it be said that “the path is made the object by another path, so the penetration of the truths is complete,” then

original: yena maggena maggo ālambito, sopi aññena, sopi aññenāti anavaṭṭhānaṃ siyā, tasmā
analyzed: yena maggena maggaḥ ālambito saḥ api aññena saḥ api aññena ati anavaṭṭhānam siyā tasmā
translated: since the path that is the object of that path is made the object by another path, and that by another, there would be an infinite regress. Therefore

original: na ārammaṇapaṭivedhato catusaccābhisamayo yutto, vuttanayeneva pana yutto. Kiñca
analyzed: na ārammaṇa paṭivedhato catu sacca abhisamayaḥ yuttaḥ vutta nayena iva pana yuttaḥ kiñca
translated: the penetration of the four truths is not tenable as object-contemplation. But it is tenable in the way already stated.

original: paricchinditabbaṃ samucchinditabbañca ālambitvā paricchedasamucchedabhāvanā maggañāṇassa🔽na yuttā tato anissaṭabhāvato, sabbasaṅkhatavinissaṭaṃ nibbānameva pana ārammaṇatā
analyzed: paricchinditabbam samucchinditabbam ca ālambitvā pariccheda samuccheda bhāvanā magga ñāṇassa  na yuttā tatas anissaṭa bhāvato sabba saṅkhata vinissaṭam nibbānam eva pana ārammaṇa tā
translated: And the development of the contemplation of cutting off and the contemplation of abandoning, which have as their object what is to be defined and what is to be cut off, is not tenable as knowledge of the path,

original: yuttā. Ahetukadiṭṭhi akiriyadiṭṭhiggahaṇena gahitā hetubyāpārova paramatthato kiriyāti katvā.
analyzed: yuttā ahetuka diṭṭhi akiriya diṭṭhi gahaṇena gahitā hetu byāpāraḥ u paramatthataḥ kiriyā ati katvā
translated: because it does not transcend that. But only Nibbāna, which transcends all formations, is tenable as the object of the path. And the view that there is no cause, which is included in the holding of a doctrine of non-causality, is included in the holding of a doctrine of non-making, taking the view that there is no cause to be the extreme of annihilation, since it is in the ultimate sense a making.

original: Pavattetīti sajjati, pavattiyā vā hetu hoti. Nivattetīti saṃharati palayaṃ gameti, palokatādivasena vā mokkhahetu hoti. Padhānatoti pakatito, yaṃ “abyatta”ntipi vuccati.
analyzed: pavatteti iti sajjati pavattiyāḥ vā hetu hoti nivatteti iti saṃharati palayam gameti palokatā ādi vasena vā mokkha hetu hoti padhānato ti pakatitaḥ yam vuccati
translated: He sets going: he is intent on, or he is a cause for the occurrence of. He stops: he gathers in, he turns away, he goes to the other side, or he is a cause for escape by means of the other-side-ness, etc., of the round of rebirths. By predominance: by what is normal, which is also called “natural.”🔽Time makes beings,

original: “Kālo karoti bhūtāni, kālo saṃharatī pajā;
analyzed: kālo karoti bhūtāni kālo saṃharati pajā
translated: Time gathers beings in,🔽Time makes the world wake up,

original: Kālo sutte jāgarati, kālo hi duratikkamo”ti. –
analyzed: kālaḥ sutte jāgarati kālaḥ hi duratikkamaḥ ti
translated: Time is hard to pass beyond.

original: Evaṃvādā kālavādino. “Kaṇṭakassa tikhiṇatā, kapiṭṭhaphalādīnaṃ parimaṇḍalatā, migapakkhisarīsapādīnaṃ
analyzed: evaṃvādā kāla vādino kaṇṭakassa tikhiṇa tā kapiṭṭha phala ādīnam parimaṇḍala tā miga pakkhi sarīsapa ādīnam
translated: So they speak, these time-talkers. “The sharpness of thorns, the roundness of the fruits of the kapittha tree, etc., the variety of animals, birds, snakes, etc.,

original: vicittabhāvoti evamādayo kena kāritā? Sabhāveneva siddhā, evaṃ sabbampi, na ettha
analyzed: vicitta bhāvaḥ ti evamādayaḥ kena kāritā sabhāvena iva siddhāḥ evam sabbam pi na ettha
translated: who made them? They are established just by their individual essences. So too all this. Herein,

original: kassaci kāmakāro”ti evaṃvādā sabhāvavādino. “Loko niyato acchejjasuttāvutābhejjamaṇisadiso,
analyzed: kassaci evaṃvādā sabhāva vādinaḥ lokaḥ niyataḥ
translated: no one has made anything” . So they speak, these essence-talkers. “The world is fixed, like the unbreakable gem described in the Acchejja Sutta ,

original: na ettha kassaci purisakāro”ti evaṃpavattavādā niyativādino, –
analyzed: na ettha kassaci evaṃpavatta vādāḥ niyati vādinaḥ
translated: herein no one has made anything” . So they speak, these fatalists.🔽They go by their own wish,

original: “Yadicchāya pavattanti, yadicchāya nivattare;
analyzed: yat icchāya pavattanti yat icchāya nivattare
translated: They stop by their own wish,🔽They experience pleasure and pain by their own wish,

original: Yadicchāya sukhadukkhaṃ, tasmā yadicchatī pajā”ti. –
analyzed: yat icchāya sukha dukkham tasmai yat icchatī pajāti
translated: So the world goes by its own wish.

original: Evaṃpavattavādā yadicchāvādisaṅkhātā adhiccasamuppattivādino ca ettha sabhāvavāde🔽eva antogadhāti daṭṭhabbā. Aṇūhi loko pavattatīti ājīvakavādaṃ sandhāyāha. So hi
analyzed: evaṃpavattavādāḥ yadicchā vādi saṅkhātāḥ adhiccasamuppatti vādinaḥ ca ettha sabhāva vāde  eva antogadhā ati daṭṭhabbā aṇūhi loko pavattati iti ājīvaka vādam sandhāya āha saḥ hi
translated: The theorists of fortuitous origination, called “the theorists of chance” and “the theorists of desire,” should be regarded as included here in the doctrine of inherent nature.🔽The doctrine of the Ājīvakas, “The world proceeds by atoms,” is referred to here. For that doctrine is a non-apprehension of causes.

original: akāraṇapariggaho. Kaṇādavādo pana issaricchāvasena aṇūnaṃ saṃyogaviyogato lokassa
analyzed: akāraṇa pariggaho kaṇāda vādaḥ pana issari chā vasena aṇūnam saṃyoga viyogataḥ lokassa
translated: The doctrine of Kaṇāda, however, maintains that the world’s occurrence and cessation are due to the conjunction and disjunction of atoms by the power of destiny.

original: pavattinivattiṃ vadati. Padhānassa appavattīti mahatādibhāvena apariṇāmo, anabhibyatti🔽vā. “Ahamañño, pakati aññā”ti evaṃ pavattapakatipurisantarajānanena attasukhadukkhamohesu
analyzed: pavatti nivattim vadati padhānassa appavattī iti mahatā ādi bhāvena apariṇāmaḥ anabhibyatti  vā aham aññaḥ pakati aññā ati evam pavatta pakati purisa antara jānanena atta sukha dukkha mohesu
translated: “The non-occurrence of striving” means non-transformation or non-manifestation in the form of greatness, etc.

original: avibhāgaggahaṇe nivattite kira vuttanayena padhānaṃ nappavattati, so vimokkhoti kāpilā.
analyzed: a vibhāga ggahaṇe nivattite kira vutta nayena padhānam na ppavattati saḥ vimokkhaḥ ti kāpilā
translated: When the apprehension of the non-differentiation of self, pleasure, pain, and ignorance is stopped by the recognition of the difference between the natural man and the man in a state of concentration, the striving does not occur in the way described above, and that is liberation, according to the Kāpilas.

original: Evamādīti ādi-saddena mahābrahmuno samīpatā, saṃyogoti evamādīnampi saṅgaho veditabbo.
analyzed: evamādi iti ādi saddena mahābrahmuno samīpa tā saṃyogo ti evamādīnam pi saṅgahaḥ veditabbo
translated: The word “etc.” in “such as” should be understood to include “proximity to the Great Brahmā” and “conjunction.”

original: Ekattāti ekabhāvato ekopi vutto. Tayoti kiccavibhāgena. Tānīti sammāvācādisīlāni.
analyzed: ekattā ati eka bhāvataḥ ekaḥ api vuttaḥ tayo ti kicca vibhāgena tāni iti sammāvācā ādi sīlāni
translated: “Unity” is mentioned as a single state. “Three” refers to the division of function. “Those” refers to the precepts of right speech, etc.

original: Chandassa saddahanānukūlāpi chandanavasena pavatti hotīti saddhindriyasaddhābalehi🔽saddhiṃ chandiddhipādo vutto. Tādise kāle upekkhānimittānubrūhanena upakārā samādhissa
analyzed: chandassa saddahana anukūlā api chandana vasena pavatti hoti iti saddhā indriya saddhā balehi  saddhim chanda iddhipādaḥ vutto tādise kāle upekkhā nimitta anubrūhanena upakārā samādhissa
translated: and it occurs as a kind of confidence in the sense of confidence in the will.🔽So the footing for success consisting of will is stated together with the faith faculty and the faith power.

original: samavāhitāvasena tādisakiccāva upekkhā veditabbā.
analyzed: samavāhita avasena upekkhā veditabbā
translated: At such a time equanimity should be understood to have the same function as the concentration that assists it by the intensification of the sign of equanimity.

original: Vighātakattāti saṃharaṇīyavasena vihantabhāvato.
analyzed: saṃharaṇīya vasena
translated: “Because it is the destroyer”: because it is the abandoning.🔽“The two noble truths”: the truths of origin and of the path.

original: Ariyasaccadvayanti samudayamaggasaccadvayaṃ. Tenevāti yathāvuttadukkhādisaddānaṃ🔽pariññeyyādivācakattā eva. Ādipadasaṅgahoti “dukkhaṃ, na ariyasacca”nti iminā catukke
analyzed: ariya sacca dvayanti samudaya magga sacca dvayam tena iva ati yathāvutta dukkha ādi saddānam  pariññeyya ādi vācaka ttā eva ādi pada saṅgahaḥ ti dukkham na ariya saccanti iminā catukke
translated: “In the same way”: because of the words “to be fully understood” and so on.🔽“The first term is included”: the term “suffering” is included in the first of the four terms, “Suffering is not a noble truth.”

original: ādipade saṅgaho. Tadapekkhanti ariyasaccasaddāpekkhaṃ dukkhasaddaṃ. Catutthapadasaṅgahoti🔽“neva dukkhaṃ, na ariyasacca”nti iminā padena saṅgaho. Avasesakilesādayoti taṇhāvajjakilesā
analyzed: ādi pade saṅgahaḥ tat apekkhanti ariya sacca sadda apekkham dukkha saddam catuttha pada saṅgahaḥ ti 🔽na iva dukkham na ariya saccanti iminā padena saṅgahaḥ avasesa kilesa ādayaḥ ti taṇhā vajja kilesā
translated: “The fourth term is included”: the term “neither suffering nor a noble truth” is included in the fourth term.🔽“The remaining defilements, and so on”: the defilements beginning with craving,

original: avasesākusalā, sāsavāni kusalamūlāni, sāsavā ca kusaladhammā. Te hi abhidhammabhājanīye
analyzed: avasesa akusalā sa āsavāni kusala mūlāni sa āsavā ca kusala dhammā te hi abhidhamma bhājanīye
translated: The rest are unprofitable and the profitable roots and profitable ideas associated with the cankers. They are stated in the Abhidhamma as the origin,

original: samudayabhāvena vuttā, na ariyasaccabhāvenāti āha “samudayo, na ariyasacca”nti. Aññāni
analyzed: samudaya bhāvena vuttā na ariya sacca bhāvena ati āha samudayaḥ na ariya saccanti aññāni
translated: not as the Noble Truth of Origin, and so he said “Origin, not a Noble Truth.”🔽The other Noble Truths are the other three Noble Truths.

original: maggaṅgānīti phalasammādiṭṭhiādayo. Iminā nayenāti etthāyaṃ yojanā – atthi samudayo,🔽na ariyasaccaṃ, atthi ariyasaccaṃ, na samudayo, atthi samudayo ceva ariyasaccañca,
analyzed: maggaṅgāni iti phala sammādiṭṭhi ādayaḥ iminā nayena ati ettha ayam yojanā atthi samudayo  na ariya saccam atthi ariya saccam na samudayaḥ atthi samudayaḥ ca iva ariya saccam ca
translated: The path factors are the right view, etc., of fruition attainment.🔽The construing here is as follows. There is origin, not a Noble Truth; there is a Noble Truth, not origin; there is origin and a Noble Truth; there is neither origin nor a Noble Truth.

original: atthi neva samudayo, na ariyasaccaṃ. Tattha paṭhamapadaṃ vuttatthaṃ. Nirodho ariyasaccaṃ,
analyzed: atthi nā iva samudayaḥ na ariya saccam tattha paṭhama padam vutta ttham nirodhaḥ ariya saccam
translated: Herein, the first term has the meaning already stated. Cessation is a Noble Truth, not origin.

original: na samudayo, taṇhā samudayo ceva ariyasaccañca, maggasampayuttā dhammā sāmaññaphalāni🔽ca yassa pahānāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussati, tadabhāvato neva samudayo, na
analyzed: na samudayo taṇhā samudayo ca iva ariya saccañca magga sampayuttā dhammā sāmañña phalāni  ca yassa pahānāya bhagavati brahmacariyam vussati tad abhāvataḥ na iva samudayaḥ na
translated: Craving is both origin and a Noble Truth. Ideas associated with the path and the fruition of monkhood are neither origin nor a Noble Truth.

original: ariyasaccaṃ. Itarasaccadvayaṃ ariyasaccaṃ tassa tassa pabhāvakaṭṭhena siyā samudayo,
analyzed: ariya saccam itara sacca dvayam ariya saccam tassa tassa samudayaḥ
translated: The other two Truths are a Noble Truth, and they may be origin in the sense of being the individual essence of origin.

original: na pana yassa pahānāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussati tathatthena. Itaracatukkadvayepi
analyzed: na pana yassa pahānāya bhagavati brahmacariyam vussati tathatthena itara catukka dvaye pi
translated: but not in the sense of that whose abandoning is the purpose of the life of purity under the Blessed One. In the other two tetrads

original: ādipadaṃ vuttatthameva. Sesesu samudayo ariyasaccaṃ, na nirodho, asaṅkhatadhātu nirodho
analyzed: ādi padam vuttattham eva sesesu samudayaḥ ariya saccam na nirodhaḥ asaṅkhata dhātu nirodho
translated: the first term in each case has the same meaning as before. In the remaining two dyads, the truth of origin is not the truth of cessation,

original: ceva ariyasaccañca, maggasampayuttā dhammā, sāmaññaphalāni ca yassa sacchikiriyāya🔽bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussati tathatthena neva nirodho, na ariyasaccaṃ. Itarasaccadvayaṃ🔽ariyasaccaṃ, nirodhadhammatāya siyā nirodho, na pana yassa sacchikiriyāya bhagavati
analyzed: ca iva ariya saccam ca magga sampayuttāḥ dhammāḥ sāmañña phalāni ca yassa sacchikiriyāya  bhagavati brahmacariyam vussati tathatthena nā iva nirodhaḥ na ariya saccam itara sacca dvayam  ariya saccam nirodha dhamma tāya siyā nirodhaḥ na pana yassa sacchikiriyāya bhagavati
translated: but the unformed element is the truth of cessation and also the truth of the noble state. States associated with the path and the fruits of asceticism are not the truth of cessation,🔽but in the sense of that whose realization is the purpose of the life of purity under the Blessed One they are the truth of the noble state. The other two truths🔽are the truth of the noble state and in the sense of having the nature of cessation they may be the truth of cessation, but not in the sense of that whose realization is the purpose of the life of purity under the Blessed One.

original: brahmacariyaṃ vussati tathatthena. Tathā nirodho ariyasaccaṃ, na maggo, ariyamaggo🔽maggo ceva ariyasaccañca, maggasampayuttā dhammā, sāmaññaphalāni ca yassa bhāvanāya
analyzed: brahmacariyam vussati tathatthena tathā nirodhaḥ ariya saccam na maggaḥ ariya maggo  maggaḥ ca iva ariya saccam ca magga sampayuttāḥ dhammāḥ sāmañña phalāni ca yassa bhāvanāya
translated: The truth of cessation is the truth of the noble state and the noble path is not the truth of the path,🔽but the noble path is both the truth of the path and the truth of the noble state. States associated with the path and the fruits of asceticism are not the truth of the path,

original: bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussati tathatthena neva maggo, na ariyasaccaṃ. Itarasaccadvayaṃ
analyzed: bhagavati brahmacariyam vussati tathatthena na iva maggaḥ na ariya saccam itara sacca dvayam
translated: but in the sense of that whose development is the purpose of the life of purity under the Blessed One they are the truth of the noble state. The other two truths🔽are

original: siyā maggo upapattimaggabhāvato, na pana yassa bhāvanāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ
analyzed: siyā maggaḥ upapatti magga bhāvataḥ na pana yassa bhāvanāya bhagavati brahmacariyam
translated: It is a path in the sense of a way of arrival at rebirth, but not in the sense of the way of development of the life of purity under the Blessed One.

original: vussati tathatthena.🔽Santanti samānaṃ. Evaṃ itaresupīti kātabbāpi kiriyā kārakarahitā kevalaṃ attano paccayehi
analyzed: tathatthena  santanti samānam evam itaresu pi iti kātabbā api kiriyā kāraka rahitā kevalam attanaḥ paccayehi
translated: “Exist” is the same as “are.” So too with the rest.🔽And although the function is performed, it is devoid of doer and causing, and when it occurs it is only a concurrence of conditions that performs the function, so that it is a mere convention.

original: tāya pavattamānāya paccayasāmaggī kiriyaṃ karotīti vohāramattaṃ hoti. Nibbutigamakesupi eseva nayo.🔽Sāsavatā asubhatā kilesāsucipaggharaṇato. Dukkhādīnanti dukkhasamudayamaggānaṃ. Samudayādibhāvoti
analyzed: tāya pavattamānāya paccaya sāmaggī kiriyam karoti iti vohāra mattam hoti nibbuti gamakesu pi esā iva nayo  sa āsava tā asubha tā kilesa asuci paggharaṇataḥ dukkha ādīnam ti dukkha samudaya maggānam samudaya ādi bhāvaḥ ti
translated: The same method applies to the case of the “village of the extinguished.”🔽“With what is subject to cankers” : the foulness is subject to cankers because of the oozing of the impurities of defilements.🔽“The suffering, etc.,” : the suffering, origin, and path.

original: dukkhassa samudayamaggabhāvo, samudayassa maggadukkhabhāvo, maggassa dukkhasamudayabhāvo
analyzed: dukkhassa samudaya magga bhāvaḥ samudayassa magga dukkha bhāvaḥ maggassa dukkha samudaya bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning of origin, etc., is this: the origin is the origin of suffering, the path is the path to suffering, and suffering is the suffering of origin,

original: ca, na pana nirodhabhāvo dukkhādīnanti sambandho. Aññamaññasamaṅgitāti dukkhādīnaṃ
analyzed: ca na pana nirodha bhāvaḥ dukkha ādīnam ti sambandhaḥ aññamañña samaṅgi tā ati dukkha ādīnam
translated: and the path is the path of suffering, but the meaning of cessation is not that of suffering, etc.🔽“The combination of each with each” : the combination of each of the three, suffering, etc., with each of the others.

original: itarītarasabhāvayogo. Taṇhāyāti ādhāre bhummaṃ. Punabbhavassāti punabhavasaṅkhātassa
analyzed: taṇhāya ati ādhāre bhummam punabbhavassa ati punabhava saṅkhātassa
translated: “With craving” : the locative case is used in the sense of basis.

original: āyatidukkhassa. Pakativādīnanti kāpilānaṃ. Vikārāti mahatādayo byattā. Vibhāvatoti
analyzed: āyati dukkhassa kāpilānam mahatā ādayaḥ byattāḥ
translated: of future suffering. The Proponents of Change are the Kāpilas. The Great One, etc., are the principles. The analysis is the analysis of the principles.

original: abhibyattito, pariṇāmato vā pubbe. Paṭippalīnā cāti pacchā pakatiyaṃ palayaṃ gatā
analyzed: abhibyattitaḥ pariṇāmataḥ vā pubbe paṭippalīnā ca ati pacchā pakatiyam palayam gatā
translated: and of future suffering. ‘The proponents of change’ are the followers of Kapila. ‘The altered states’ are the great and so on, which are ‘well-ordered’. ‘In the past’ is by manifestation or by transformation. ‘They have reverted’ is ‘they have gone back to their original nature’.

original: vesammaṃ muñcitvā sattādisamabhāvena anto samoruddhā. Tenāha “pakatibhāveneva tiṭṭhantī”ti.
analyzed: vesammam muñcitvā satta ādi sama bhāvena antar tena āha pakati bhāvena iva tiṭṭhanti iti
translated: ‘Having released the combination’ is ‘having been held within by the state of equality of being, such as being a living being, and so on’. Therefore it is said: ‘they stand in their original nature’.

original: Pakatibhāvenevāti abyattabhāveneva. Samudayabhāvenāti taṇhāsaṅkhātapabhavabhāvena.
analyzed: pakati bhāvena iva ati abyatta bhāvena iva samudaya bhāvena ati taṇhā saṅkhāta pabhava bhāvena
translated: ‘In their original nature’ is ‘in their unmixed nature’. ‘In the nature of origination’ is ‘in the nature of craving, formations, and becoming’.

original: Aññathā taṃsampayuttaavijjādīnampi samudayabhāvo labbhatevāti. Avibhattehīti vesammavirahena
analyzed: aññathā tad sampayutta avijja ādīnam pi samudaya bhāvaḥ labbhate iva ati avibhattehi iti vesamma virahena
translated: Otherwise, the nature of origination would be found in the ignorance associated with that and so on. ‘Without distinction’ is ‘without the absence of a combination’.

original: pakatibhāvaṃ gatehi. “Vikārehī”ti sāmaññato vutte “mahantā”tiādinā sarūpato dasseti.
analyzed: pakati bhāvam gatehi vikārehi iti sāmaññataḥ vutte mahanta ati ādinā sarūpataḥ dasseti
translated: ‘Having reverted to their original nature’. ‘Having altered’ is said in a general way. ‘The great’ and so on are shown in their own nature.

original: Tattha mahantoti mahābuddhi. Tañhi kāpilā “mahāajjhāsayo”ti ca voharanti. Rūpatammattādayo
analyzed: tattha mahantaḥ ti mahābuddhi tat hi kāpilāḥ ca voharanti
translated: Herein, ‘the great’ is the great intellect. For the followers of Kapila call it ‘the great abode’. The five, beginning with the mere form,

original: pañca tammattā, ahaṃkāro cāti cha avisesā. Cakkhu sotaṃ ghānaṃ jivhā kāyo vācā pāṇi
analyzed: pañca tammattāḥ ahaṃkāro ca ati cha avisesā cakkhu sotam ghānam jivhā kāyaḥ vācā pāṇi
translated: and the six, beginning with the ‘I-maker’, are undifferentiated. Eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, speech,

original: pādo pāyu upatthaṃ manoti ekādasindriyāni. Pathavī āpo tejo vāyo ākāsanti pañca bhūtavisesā,
analyzed: pādo pāyu upattham manoti ekādasa indriyāni pathavī āpaḥ tejaḥ vāyo ākāsanti pañca bhūta visesā
translated: The eleven faculties are the foot, the anus, the sex organ, the hand, the tongue, the eye, the ear, the nose, the life faculty, the mind faculty, and the faculty of femininity. The five elements are earth, water, fire, air, and space.

original: tehi. “Pakatibhāveneva ṭhitehī”ti iminā “avibhattehī”ti padassa atthaṃ vadati. Sagabbhāti
analyzed: tehi pakati bhāvena iva ṭhitehi iti iminā avibhattehi iti padassa attham vadati sagabbhā ati
translated: By the words “in their natural state” he explains the meaning of the words “without being mixed up.”

original: sabījā asuññatā. Tantūsūti suttesu samavāyikāraṇabhūtesu. Tathā kapālesu. Tividhañhi
analyzed: sa bījā asuñña tā suttesu samavāyi kāraṇa bhūtesu tathā kapālesu
translated: “With a womb” means with a seed, not empty. “In the threads” means in the threads, which are the co-existent causes in the cloth. Likewise in the potsherds. For they declare

original: te kāraṇaṃ vadanti upādānakāraṇaṃ nimittakāraṇaṃ samavāyikāraṇanti. Tattha turivemasalākādayo🔽upādānakāraṇaṃ. Tantavāyo nimittakāraṇaṃ. Tantavo samavāyikāraṇanti. Dvīsu aṇūsūti
analyzed: te kāraṇam vadanti upādāna kāraṇam nimitta kāraṇam samavāyi kāraṇanti tattha turi vemasalāka ādayaḥ  upādāna kāraṇam nimitta kāraṇam tantavaḥ dvīsu aṇūsu iti
translated: the three kinds of causes: the material cause, the cause as object, and the co-existent cause. Herein, the four sticks and the shuttle, etc., are the material cause. The air in the threads is the cause as object. The threads are the co-existent cause.

original: pathavībhūtesu vā āpotejovāyobhūtesu vā dvīsu paramāṇūsu. Idhabuddhivohārajanakoti
analyzed: pathavī bhūtesu vā āpaḥ tejaḥ vāyaḥ bhūtesu vā dvīsu paramāṇūsu
translated: In two atoms means in two primary elements, either in the earth, water, fire, and air primary elements, or in two ultimate atoms.🔽The producer of the notion and the designation “here” means

original: “idha tantūsu paṭo, idha kapālesu ghaṭo, idha bīraṇesu ghaṭo”tiādinā nayena hetuphalānaṃ
analyzed: tantūsu paṭaḥ idha kapālesu ghaṭaḥ idha bīraṇesu ghaṭa uti ādinā nayena
translated: the cause and the effect, in the way beginning, “Here in the threads there is cloth,” “Here in the potsherds there is a pot,” “Here in the reeds there is a hut.”

original: sambandhabhūtena sattānaṃ idhabuddhivohārā jāyanti. So govisāṇānaṃ viya avisuṃ sahasiddhānaṃ🔽sambandho samavāyo. Khāṇusenānaṃ viya pana visuṃsiddhānaṃ sambandho saṃyogo. Tīsu
analyzed: sambandha bhūtena sattānam idha buddhi vohārāḥ jāyanti saḥ go visāṇānam viya avisum sahasiddhānam  sambandhaḥ samavāyaḥ viya pana sambandhaḥ saṃyogaḥ tīsu
translated: The ideas and terms “here” and “there” arise in relation to beings through the conjunction called inherence. This conjunction is not different from the things conjoined, like the horns of a cow.

original: aṇūsu tiaṇukaṃ phalaṃ samavetaṃ ekībhūtamiva sambandhanti yojanā. “Samaveta”nti etassa
analyzed: aṇūsu ti aṇukam phalam samavetam ekībhūtam iva yojanā etassa
translated: But the conjunction of things that are different is called contact, like the contact of axe and wood. The meaning of the text is this: “In the three atoms there is a resultant gross visible datum, which is conjoined with them, which is to say, it is as if it were one with them.”

original: “ekībhūtamiva sambandha”nti idaṃ atthavivaraṇaṃ. Mahāparimāṇanti mahantaparimāṇaṃ
analyzed: ekībhūtam iva idam attha vivaraṇam mahā parimāṇanti mahanta parimāṇam
translated: The words “as if it were one with them” are an explanation of the word “conjoined.”

original: mahāpathavīādikaṃ ekaṃ phalaṃ, yaṃ te “kāriyaṃ drabya”nti vadanti. Yehi kāraṇehi
analyzed: mahā pathavī ādikam ekam phalam yam te vadanti yehi kāraṇehi
translated: The gross visible datum, which is of great magnitude, is a single resultant gross visible datum, which is to say, the great earth, etc., which they call the “effected substance.”🔽The causes by which the effected substance is effected are the very same causes that are thought to be contained in it.

original: āraddhaṃ kāriyadrabyaṃ, tadantogadhāni eva tāni kāraṇāni maññantīti āha “attano antogadhehi🔽kāraṇehī”ti. Sati samavāye hetumhi phalaṃ samavetanti phale hetu siyā, taṃ natthīti
analyzed: āraddham kāriya drabyam tad antogadhāni eva tāni kāraṇāni maññanti iti āha attanaḥ antogadhehi  kāraṇehi iti sati samavāye hetumhi phalam samavetanti phale hetu siyā tam natthi iti
translated: Therefore it is said: “by its own contained causes.”🔽When there is inherence, the cause is in the effect. But that is not so.

original: dassento āha “samavāyābhāvā phale hetu natthīti hetusuññaṃ phala”nti.
analyzed: dassentaḥ āha samavāya abhāvā phale hetu natthi iti hetu suññam phalanti
translated: To show this, he says: “Because of the absence of inherence, the effect is devoid of cause in the sense that the cause is not in the effect.”

original: Āhārabhedeti kabaḷīkārādiāhāravisese. Tappaccayadhammabhedeti ajjhoharaṇīyavatthusaḷāyatanaavijjāabhisaṅkhārasaṅkhāte
analyzed: āhāra bheda iti kabaḷīkāra ādi āhāra visese tad paccaya dhamma bhede iti ajjhoharaṇīya vatthu saḷāyatana avijjā abhisaṅkhāra saṅkhāte
translated: As to the difference in nutriment: as the difference in the kinds of nutriment consisting of the four nutriments beginning with physical food.🔽As to the difference in states that are conditions for that: as the difference in the states that are conditions for those nutriments, consisting of the six internal bases, ignorance, and the formations consisting of the formations of merit, etc.,

original: tesaṃ paccayabhūtadhammavisese, ojaṭṭhamakarūpavedanāpaṭisandhiviññāṇanāmarūpasaṅkhāte
analyzed: tesam paccaya bhūta dhamma visese oja ṭṭhamaka rūpa vedanā paṭisandhi viññāṇa nāma rūpa saṅkhāte
translated: or as the difference in the states produced by those nutriments, consisting of the eight kinds of physical nutriment, the materiality derived by clinging, the three kinds of feeling, rebirth-linking consciousness, mentality, and materiality.

original: vā tannibbattadhammavisese, te paccayā etesaṃ dhammavisesānanti tappaccayadhammabhedā.
analyzed: vā tad nibbatta dhamma visese te paccayāḥ etesam dhamma visesānam ti tad paccaya dhamma bhedā
translated: The meaning is that they are respectively the conditions for those states.🔽As to the difference in the kinds of object: as the difference in the kinds of object consisting of visible data, etc.

original: Rūpādiārammaṇavasena vāti yojanā. Yānadvayavasenāti samathavipassanāyānadvayavasena.🔽Kiñcāpi maggakkhaṇe samathavipassanā yuganaddhāva, yathā pana suññatādisamaññā, evaṃ
analyzed: rūpa ādi ārammaṇa vasena vā ati yojanā yāna dvaya vasena ati samatha vipassanā yāna dvaya vasena  kiñca api magga kkhaṇe samatha vipassanā yuga naddhā va yathā pana suññatā ādi samaññā evam
translated: As to the difference in the two kinds of vehicle: as the difference in the two kinds of vehicle consisting of serenity and insight.🔽And although at the moment of the path serenity and insight are yoked evenly together, still, just as there are designations such as “empty” ,

original: samathavipassanāsamaññāpi āgamanato maggassa siyunti āha “āgamanavasena vutto”ti.
analyzed: samatha vipassanā samaññā api āgamanataḥ maggassa siyun ti āha āgamana vasena vuttaḥ ti
translated: so too there are designations such as “serenity” and “insight” in order to point out the path. That is why it is said, “as to the difference in the two kinds of vehicle, which is stated in terms of the arrival.”

original: Yassa vā paññindriyaṃ adhikaṃ, tassa maggo vipassanā, itarassa samathoti evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: yassa vā paññindriyam adhikam tassa maggaḥ vipassanā itarassa samathaḥ ti evam ettha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: Or alternatively, the meaning can be regarded in this way: the path of one to whom the understanding faculty is outstanding is insight, while that of the other is serenity.

original: Samādhijāti samādhānaṭṭhova. Tato evāti samādhianuguṇakiriyattāva.
analyzed: samādhi jāti tatas eva ati
translated: and the kind of concentration is the mere steadying of the mind. “From that” is from the kind of action that is in conformity with concentration.

original: Ādāya ūhitvāti gahetvā viya takketvā vitakketvā. Dvinnanti sammādiṭṭhisammāsaṅkappānaṃ.🔽Purimakālassa viya niddeso yathā “ekaṃ khandhaṃ paṭicca tayo khandhā”ti, “ekaṃ mahābhūtaṃ
analyzed: ādāya ūhitvā iti gahetvā viya takketvā vitakketvā dvinnan ti sammādiṭṭhi sammāsaṅkappānam  purima kālassa viya niddesaḥ yathā ekam khandham paṭicca tayo khandhāti ekam mahābhūtam
translated: “Having taken it” is as though he had taken it and shaken it and stirred it up with applied thought. “Of the two” is of right view and right thought.

original: paṭicca tayo mahābhūtā”ti ca.
analyzed: paṭicca tayaḥ mahābhūtā ati ca
translated: The demonstration is as in the case of the past, as in the case of “With one aggregate as condition, three aggregates” and “With one great primary as condition, three great primaries” .

original: Ogāhitunti ñāṇena paṭivijjhituṃ. Gahetuṃ asakkuṇeyyatāya saṇhattaṃ. Sukhumāya paññāya🔽gahetabbatāya sukhumattaṃ. Itīti iminā kamenāti ayamatthoti adhippāyenāha “itisaddena🔽vijānanakkamaṃ dassetī”ti. Evaṃ pakārehīti evaṃ-saddena jotiyamāno eva attho pakāra-saddena
analyzed: ogāhitum ti ñāṇena paṭivijjhitum gahetum a sakkuṇeyya tāya saṇhattam sukhumāya paññāya  gahetabba tāya sukhuma ttam iti iti iminā kamena ati ayam atthaḥ ti adhippāyena āha iti saddena  vijānana kkamam dasseti iti evam pakārehi iti evaṃsaddena jotiyamānaḥ eva atthaḥ pakāra saddena
translated: “To penetrate” is to pierce with knowledge. “To be hard to penetrate” is because it cannot be grasped. “To be subtle” is because it can be grasped only by subtle understanding.🔽“Thus” is by this means. “By the word thus he shows the means of knowing” is what is said by the meaning of the word thus.

original: vuccatīti “evaṃ-saddena vijānanakāraṇabhūte naye dassetī”ti vuttaṃ. Itīti vā nidassanattho.
analyzed: vuccati iti evaṃsaddena vijānana kāraṇa bhūte naye dasseti iti vuttam iti iti vā nidassana atthaḥ
translated: “By the word thus he shows the means of knowing” is what is said by the meaning of the word thus. “By the word thus he shows the means of knowing” is what is said by the meaning of the word thus. “By the word thus he shows the means of knowing” is what is said by the meaning of the word thus. “By the word thus he shows the means of knowing” is what is said by the meaning of the word thus. “By the word thus he shows the means of knowing” is what is said by the meaning of the word thus. “By the word thus he shows the means of knowing” is what is said by the meaning of the word thus. “By the word thus he shows the means of knowing” is what is said by the meaning of the word thus. “By the word thus he shows the means of knowing” is what is said by the meaning of the word thus. “By the word thus he shows the means of knowing” is what is said by the meaning of the word thus. “By the word thus he shows the means of knowing” is what is said by the meaning of the word thus. “By the word thus he shows the means of knowing” is what is said by the meaning of the word thus. “By the word thus he shows the means of knowing” is what is said by the meaning of the word thus. “By the word thus he shows the means of knowing” is what is said by the meaning of the word thus. “By the word thus he shows the means of knowing” is what is said

original: Tena vuttappabhede paccāmasanavasena nidasseti. Evaṃ-saddo idamattho. Tena evaṃ pakārehīti
analyzed: tena vutta ppabhede paccāmasana vasena nidasseti evaṃsaddaḥ idam atthaḥ tena evam pakārehi iti
translated: he shows by way of the various kinds of reflection. The word “thus” has this meaning. By that “thus” he says:

original: idaṃpakārehi, īdisehīti attho.
analyzed: idaṃpakārehi īdisehi iti attho
translated: “thus-wise”, the meaning is: in this way.

original: Uddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: uddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the Enumeration is finished.

original: 1. Dukkhasaccaniddeso
translated: The Description of the Truth of Suffering

original: Jātiniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: jāti niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of Birth

original: 190. “Jātiādiniddese”ti iminā “tatthā”ti padassa atthaṃ vadati. Dukkhamātikāti dukkhadukkhādīnaṃ
analyzed: jāti ādi niddese ti iminā tattha ati padassa attham vadati dukkha mātikā ti dukkha dukkha ādīnam
translated: By the words “in the description of birth, etc.” he explains the meaning of the words “therein”. The “matrix of suffering” is the enumeration of the various kinds of suffering, such as the suffering of suffering, etc.

original: dukkhavisesānaṃ uddeso. Padadvayeti “pariyāyadukkhaṃ, nippariyāyadukkha”nti etasmiṃ padadvaye.🔽Dukkhattāyevāti nippariyāyadukkhataṃ vadati. Sabhāvena nāmaṃ visesetīti anvatthasaññataṃ
analyzed: dukkha visesānam uddesaḥ pada dvaya iti pariyāya dukkham nippariyāya dukkham ti etasmim pada dvaye  dukkhattāya iva āti nippariyāya dukkhatam vadati sabhāvena nāmam viseseti iti anvattha saññatam
translated: In the two terms, i.e., in the two terms “suffering of limitation” and “suffering of non-limitation”.🔽By “because of suffering itself” he refers to the suffering of non-limitation. He shows the “name” distinguished by its own-nature,

original: dasseti. Purimena sabhāvadukkhavācakena dukkhasaddena. So hi visesanaṃ avacchedakabhāvato🔽pacchimaṃ saṅkhāradukkhaṭṭhaṃ viseseti. So hi nivattetabbagahetabbasādhāraṇattā avacchinditabbo.
analyzed: dasseti purimena sabhāva dukkha vācakena dukkha saddena saḥ hi visesanam avacchedaka bhāvato  pacchimam saṅkhāra dukkha ṭṭham viseseti saḥ hi nivattetabba gahetabba sādhāraṇa ttā avacchinditabbaḥ
translated: by the “conventional name”. By the word “suffering” which expresses the suffering of its own-nature, in the first place. For that one distinguishes the last state of suffering of formations, by way of the state of being a distinguishing mark,🔽by way of the state of being a limitation. For that one is to be limited, because of the commonness of the state of being turned away from and the state of being grasped.

original: Tenāti vipariṇāmaadhiṭṭhānādipakāravisesena.
analyzed: tena ati vipariṇāma adhiṭṭhāna ādi pakāra visesena
translated: By that, i.e., by the distinction of the various kinds of reflection, such as the reflection of change, the reflection of determination, etc.

original: Desetabbassa atthassa saṅkhipanaṃ idha saṅkhepo, so ca tabbibhāgānaṃ sādhāraṇabhāvoti
analyzed: desetabbassa atthassa saṅkhipanam idha saṅkhepaḥ saḥ ca tad bibhāgānam sādhāraṇa bhāvaḥ ti
translated: The brief treatment here of the meaning to be taught is the brief treatment, and that is the commonality of the things belonging to that class.

original: āha “saṅkhepo sāmañña”nti. Antokaritvāti antogadhe katvā, saṅgahetvā vā. Ubhayathāpīti🔽saṅkhepatopi vitthāratopi. Sādhāraṇabhāgānaṃ vibhajanaṃ vibhāgo, vitthāroti āha “vitthāro
analyzed: āha saṅkhepaḥ sāmaññanti antokaritvā ati katvā saṅgahetvā vā ubhayathā api iti  saṅkhepataḥ api vitthārataḥ api sādhāraṇa bhāgānam vibhajanam vibhāgaḥ vitthāraḥ iti āha vitthāraḥ
translated: Hence he said, “The brief treatment is the commonality.” “Having included” means having included, having comprised. In both ways means🔽in the brief treatment and in the detailed treatment. The division of the things belonging to the commonality is the detailed treatment. Hence he said, “The detailed treatment is the distinction.”

original: pana viseso”ti. Visesantaranivattakoti vibhāgantarāsaṅgāhako.🔽191. Aparatthāti bhummavacanaṃ sāmiatthe yathā “sabbattha pādaka”nti āha “sāmiatthepi
analyzed: pana visesaḥ ti visesa antara nivattako ti vibhāga antara a saṅgāhako  aparatthā iti bhumma vacanam sāmi atthe yathā sabbattha pādakan ti āha sāmi atthe pi
translated: The occurrence of the division is the occurrence of the sub-division.

original: hi aparatthasaddo sijjhatī”ti. Siddhi pana “itarāhipi dissatī”ti iminā veditabbā.
analyzed: hi aparattha saddaḥ sijjhati iti pana dissati iti iminā veditabbā
translated: “The other meaning” is a locative case in the sense of the master. As in “The foot is everywhere,” he said, “The locative case is also established in the sense of the master.” But the establishment should be understood by “It is seen with others too.”

original: Yasmā ca evaṃ saddo sambhavati, tasmā pāḷiyaṃ sāmivasena vuttaṃ aṭṭhakathāyaṃ bhummavasena
analyzed: ca evam saddo sambhavati tasmā pāḷiyam sāmi vasena vuttam aṭṭhakathāyam bhumma vasena
translated: And since the locative case is possible in this way, therefore what is said in the text as the master is shown in the commentary in the locative case.

original: dassitanti dīpento “tesaṃ tesanti vā”tiādimāha. Aparassāti aparassa sattassa. Manussādibhedo
analyzed: dassitam ti dīpentaḥ tesam tesam ti vā tiādim āha aparassa iti aparassa sattassa manussa ādi bhedaḥ
translated: Pointing this out, he said, “Or in the sense of ‘in those and those’” . “The other” is the other being. The distinction of human beings, etc., is

original: upapattibhavo gati, tabbisesabhūtā khattiyādisāmaññādhiṭṭhānā khandhā jātīti dassento
analyzed: upapatti bhavaḥ gati tad visesa bhūtā khattiya ādi sāmañña adhiṭṭhānā khandhāḥ jāti iti dassento
translated: The rebirth-process becoming is the destiny. The aggregates, which are a particular kind of destiny, are the kinds of generation, namely, those of the warrior-noble, and so on, which are the bases for the assumption of the self. Showing this, he said:

original: “pañcagativasenā”tiādimāha.🔽Tiṇākāroti tiṇavikappo, tiṇavisesoti attho. Evanti nidassane. Tena vuttappakāraṃ🔽paṭhamaṃ viññāṇapātubhāvaṃ paccāmasati. Tadupādāyāti tato paṭṭhāya. Ariyabhāvakaraṇattāti
analyzed: pañca gati vasena ati ādim āha  tiṇa ākāraḥ tiṇa vikappaḥ tiṇa viseso ti attho evam ti nidassane tena vutta ppakāram  paṭhamam viññāṇa pātubhāvam paccāmasati tat upādāya ati tatas paṭṭhāya ariya bhāva karaṇa ttā ati
translated: The rebirth-process becoming is the destiny. The aggregates, which are a particular kind of that, and are the basis for the determination of the commonalty of the kinds of beings such as nobles, etc., are the birth. Showing this, he said, “With the five-constituent kind of being” ,🔽and so on.

original: ariyabhāvakāraṇattā. Karotīti hi karaṇaṃ. Ariyasadisattā vā ariyasīlaṃ. Puthujjanakalyāṇakānampi🔽hi catupārisuddhisīlaṃ ariyasīlasadisaṃ. Ākāravikārāti uppajjanādiākāravikatiyo.
analyzed: ariya bhāva kāraṇa ttā karoti iti hi karaṇam ariya sadisa ttā vā ariya sīlam  hi catu pārisuddhi sīlam ariya sīla sadisam ākāra vikārā ati uppajjana ādi ākāra vikatiyaḥ
translated: “Grass-like” : a tuft of grass; the meaning is, a particular kind of grass. “Thus” is a demonstrative. By that he refers to the first manifestation of consciousness of the kind stated. “From that as a base” : from then on. “Because it causes the state of being noble” : because it is the cause of the state of being noble. For a cause is a maker . Or alternatively, noble virtue is like the noble state. For the virtue of the fourfold purification of the ordinary-man-of-good-family is like the noble virtue.🔽“The mode of change” : the mode of arising, etc., and the change.

original: Sahuppādakāti uppādasahitā uppādāvatthā khandhā. Āyatanavasenāti paripuṇṇāparipuṇṇāyatanavasena.
analyzed: sahuppādakā ati uppāda sahitāḥ uppāda avatthāḥ khandhāḥ āyatana vasena ati paripuṇṇa a paripuṇṇa āyatana vasena
translated: “With the aggregates that arise together with it” : the aggregates in the state of arising that are associated with the arising. “By the bases” : by the complete and incomplete bases.

original: Yonivasenāti aṇḍajādiyonivasena. Ekekeneva padenāti yathā dutiyanaye jātiādipadesu
analyzed: yoni vasena ati aṇḍaja ādi yoni vasena ekekena iva padena ati yathā dutiya naye jāti ādi padesu
translated: “By the kinds of generation” : by the kinds of generation such as the egg-born, etc. “By each term” : in the second method, in the terms “birth,” etc.,

original: dvīhi dvīhi padehi paripuṇṇāparipuṇṇāyatanayonivibhāgena sabbasatte pariyādiyitvā
analyzed: dvīhi dvīhi padehi paripuṇṇa a paripuṇṇa āyatana yoni vibhāgena sabba satte
translated: and the birth of all beings is shown by the two words “with two” and “with two” in the analysis of the bases and the wombs,

original: jāti dassitā, na evamidha. Idha panetesu ekekeneva padena avibhāgato sabbasatte pariyādiyitvā.
analyzed: jāti dassitā na evamidha idha pana etesu ekekena iva padena avibhāgato sabba satte
translated: but not here. Here it is shown by each of the words without analysis.

original: Ubhayatthāti purimapacchimanayesu bhāvaniddesova yutto. Anabhihite vibhattividhānaṃ,
analyzed: ubhayattha ati purima pacchima nayesu bhāva niddesaḥ u va yuttaḥ anabhihite vibhatti vidhānam
translated: “In both ways”: only the description of the development is relevant in the former and latter methods.🔽The method of declension is not stated for the uninflected.

original: nābhihiteti. Pākaṭā nibbattīti abhibyattā nibbatti.
analyzed: na abhihitā iti pākaṭā nibbattī iti abhibyattā nibbatti
translated: “Uninflected”: its birth is not manifest.

original: Dvinnaṃ dvinnanti ekavokārabhave rūpāyatanadhammāyatanavasena dvinnaṃ, catuvokārabhave
analyzed: dvinnam dvinnanti ekavokāra bhave rūpāyatana dhammāyatana vasena dvinnam catuvokāra bhave
translated: “With two, with two”: in the case of the single-door rebirth-linking, with the two, namely, the visible-data base and the mental-data base; in the case of the four-door rebirth-linking,🔽with the two, namely, the mind base and the mental-data base. “With the rest”: in the case of the five-door rebirth-linking.

original: manāyatanadhammāyatanavasena dvinnaṃ. Seseti pañcavokārabhave. Pañcannanti cakkhusotamanorūpadhammāyatanavasena
analyzed: manāyatana dhammāyatana vasena dvinnam sesa iti pañcavokāra bhave cakkhu sota manaḥ rūpa dhammāyatana vasena
translated: “With five”: with the five, namely, the eye, ear, mind, visible-data, and mental-data bases.🔽For these five arise in the fine-material sphere in the five-door rebirth-linking.

original: pañcannaṃ. Tāni hi rūpabhave pañcavokāre upapattikkhaṇe uppajjanti. Kāmadhātuyaṃ
analyzed: tāni hi rūpa bhave pañcavokāre upapatti khaṇe uppajjanti
translated: In the sense sphere they arise in the single-door rebirth-linking.

original: paṭisandhikkhaṇe uppajjamānānanti yojanā. Vikalāvikalindriyānanti aparipuṇṇaparipuṇṇāyatanānaṃ
analyzed: paṭisandhi kkhaṇe uppajjamānānanti yojanā vikala avikala indriyānanti aparipuṇṇa paripuṇṇa āyatanānam
translated: “With incomplete and complete bases”:

original: sattānaṃ. Indriyavaseneva hi āyatanānaṃ vekallaṃ icchitabbaṃ. Tattha vikalindriyassa
analyzed: sattānam indriya vasena iva hi āyatanānam vekallam icchitabbam tattha vikalindriyassa
translated: For the deficiency of the bases should be understood as due to the deficiency of faculties. Herein, one deficient in faculties

original: sattannaṃ navannaṃ dasannaṃ punapi dasannaṃ, itarassa ekādasannaṃ āyatanānaṃ vasena
analyzed: sattannam navannam dasannam punar api dasannam itarassa ekādasannam āyatanānam vasena
translated: should be understood as included in seven, nine, ten, ten, and eleven bases respectively.🔽In seven: in seven, that is, in the body, mind, visible-data, sound, odour, flavour, and tactile-object bases.

original: saṅgaho veditabbo. Sattannanti kāyamanorūpagandharasaphoṭṭhabbadhammāyatanavasena
analyzed: saṅgahaḥ veditabbo kāya manaḥ rūpa gandha rasa phoṭṭhabba dhamma āyatana vasena
translated: For this is said with reference to one who is born in the womb.🔽In nine: in nine, that is, in the eye, ear, visible-data, sound, odour, flavour, tangible-data, mind, and mental-data bases,

original: sattannaṃ. Gabbhaseyyakañhi sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ. Navannanti cakkhusotasaddāyatanavajjānaṃ🔽navannaṃ. Andhabadhiravasena hidaṃ vuttaṃ. Dasannanti cakkhusaddavajjānaṃ. Puna dasannanti
analyzed: satta nam gabbhaseyyakam hi sandhāya itam vuttam navannam ti cakkhu sota sadda āyatana vajjānam  andha badhira vasena hi dam vuttam dasannam ti cakkhu sadda vajjānam puna
translated: excluding the nose and tongue faculties. For this is said with reference to one who is blind and deaf.🔽In ten: in ten, that is, in the eye, visible-data, ear, sound, odour, flavour, tangible-data, mind, mental-data, and life bases,🔽excluding the nose faculty. This pair is said with reference to one who is blind and deaf.🔽In eleven: in eleven, that is, in the eye, visible-data, ear, sound, odour, flavour, tangible-data, mind, mental-data, life, and body bases,

original: sotasaddavajjānaṃ. Andhavasena, badhiravasena cetaṃ dvayaṃ vuttaṃ. Ekādasannanti saddavajjānaṃ.
analyzed: andha vasena badhira vasena ca itam dvayam vuttam saddavajjānam
translated: excluding the nose faculty. This is said with reference to one who is blind, deaf, and mute.🔽The state of being a dukkha …

original: Taṃdukkhabhāvoti pariyāyadukkhabhāvo. Tattha nibbattinivāraṇenāti uppalapadumādīsu
analyzed: tad dukkha bhāvo ti pariyāya dukkha bhāvo tattha nibbatti nivāraṇena āti uppala paduma ādīsu
translated: … the state of being a pariyāyaduṭṭha . Herein, by preventing rebirth there is the prevention of the arising of the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind bases.

original: uppattipaṭikkhepena abhāvakathanena. Dukkhuppattikāraṇeti dukkhuppattiyā hetubhūte dukkhuppattiṭṭhāne.
analyzed: uppatti paṭikkhepena abhāva kathanena dukkha uppatti kāraṇe iti dukkha uppattiyāḥ hetu bhūte dukkha uppatti ṭṭhāne
translated: by the rejection of arising, by the statement of non-existence. The cause of the arising of suffering is the footing for the arising of suffering, which is the cause of the arising of suffering.

original: Maraṇaniddesavaṇṇanā
translated: The description of death

original: 193. Khandhabhedassāti khandhavināsassa. Soti khandhabhedo. Pabandhasamucchedoti
analyzed: khandha bhedassa ati khandha vināsassa saḥ ti khandha bhedaḥ pabandha samucchedo ti
translated: The destruction of the aggregates is the destruction of the aggregates. The severing of the bond is

original: pabandhassa accantasamucchedo. Tabbhāvatoti sammutimaraṇabhāvato. Tadekadesabhāvatoti
analyzed: pabandhassa tad bhāvato ti sammuti maraṇa bhāvato tad eka desa bhāvato ti
translated: the severing of the bond beyond measure. By that fact: by the fact of conventional death. By that part:

original: tadavayavabhāvato. Tasseva nāmanti asammohatthaṃ vuttaṃ sabbassāpi ekakammanibbattajīvitindriyappabandhavicchedabhāvato.
analyzed: tad avayava bhāvataḥ tassa iva nāman ti asammoha attham vuttam sabbassa api eka kamma nibbatta jīvitindriya ppabandha viccheda bhāvato
translated: by that component. That very name: this is said for the purpose of non-confusion, since all are the severing of the bond of the life faculty produced by a single kamma.

original: Sammutimaraṇameva hi jātikkhayamaraṇaṃ, taṃ pana jātikkhayamaraṇaṃ upakkamamaraṇaṃ,
analyzed: sammuti maraṇam eva hi jāti khaya maraṇam tam pana jāti khaya maraṇam upakkama maraṇam
translated: For conventional death is death by the exhaustion of the life span, and that death by the exhaustion of the life span is death by violence,

original: sarasamaraṇanti duvidhaṃ. Tattha sarasamaraṇampi āyukkhayamaraṇaṃ, puññakkhayamaraṇanti
analyzed: sa rasa maraṇanti duvidham tattha sa rasa maraṇam pi āyu khaya maraṇam puñña kkhaya maraṇam ti
translated: death by the exhaustion of merit, and death by the exhaustion of both. Thus it is twofold. Herein, death by violence is untimely death.🔽Death by the exhaustion of the life span is death by the exhaustion of the life span, death by the exhaustion of merit, and death by the exhaustion of both.

original: duvidhaṃ. Evametesaṃ tadekadesatā veditabbā. Yañcettha upakkamamaraṇaṃ, taṃ akālamaraṇaṃ.
analyzed: duvidham evam etesam tad eka desa tā veditabbā yat ca itthā upakkama maraṇam tat akāla maraṇam
translated: Thus it is twofold. So that should be understood as a part of that. And here death by violence is untimely death.

original: Sarasamaraṇaṃ kālamaraṇaṃ. Maraṇena sattā yathāladdhaattabhāvena viyujjantīti āha
analyzed: sa rasa maraṇam kāla maraṇam maraṇena sattā yathā laddha atta bhāvena viyujjanti iti āha
translated: Death by drowning, death by hanging, death by violence, death by accident. Beings are separated from the acquired selfhood by death. Hence he said:

original: “sampattibhavakkhandhehi viyojetī”ti.
analyzed: sampatti bhavakkhandhehi viyojeti iti
translated: “It separates from the aggregates of existence that are the result of past kamma.”

original: Kāraṇatthoti mūlattho. Mūlañhi “ādī”ti vuccati “ko cādi kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ? Sīlañca suvisuddhaṃ, diṭṭhi ca ujukā”tiādīsu. Tenāha “sandhibandhanacchedamūlakanti attho”ti.
analyzed: kāraṇa atthaḥ ti mūla tthaḥ mūlam hi ādi iti vuccati ko ca ādi kusalānam dhammānam sīlam ca su visuddham diṭṭhi ca ujukā ati ādīsu tena āha sandhi bandhana cheda mūlakanti attho ti
translated: The meaning of “root” is the meaning of “cause.” For a root is called “beginning,” as in the passages: “What is the beginning of wholesome states? Virtue that is well purified, and right view” (Sn 107). Therefore he said: “The meaning is: it cuts the root of the bond of continuity.”

original: Phalakiriyāgabbhā īdisī hetukiriyāti katvā vuttaṃ “antogadhā”ti. Byasanassa hi āpādakehi āpādanaṃ āpādetabbaāpattiyā saheva sijjhatīti.
analyzed: phala kiriyā gabbhā īdisī hetu kiriyā ti katvā vuttam antogadhā ti byasanassa hi āpādakehi āpādanam āpādetabba āpattiyā saha iva sijjhati iti
translated: The meaning of “internal” is the meaning of “cause.” For the causing of harm is established together with the harm that is to be caused by those who cause harm.

original: Sokaniddesavaṇṇanā🔽194. Sukhaṃ hinoti pavattati etenāti sukhakāraṇaṃ hitaṃ. Bhogabyasanādipadatthavisesanti
analyzed: soka niddesa vaṇṇanā  sukham hinoti pavattati etena ati sukha kāraṇam hitam
translated: The explanation of the description of sorrow.🔽What is beneficial is a cause of happiness. The meaning of the words “loss of wealth,” etc., is

original: bhogabyasanaṃ, sīlabyasananti evaṃ bhogasīlapadānaṃ vasena atthavisesaṃ. Samāsavisesanti
analyzed: bhoga byasanam sīla byasananti evam bhoga sīla padānam vasena attha visesam samāsa visesam ti
translated: a particular meaning of the words “wealth” and “virtue.” The meaning of “compound” is

original: “rogoyeva byasanaṃ, diṭṭhi eva byasana”nti samānādhikaraṇavasena samāsavisesaṃ. Annapānavatthayānādi
analyzed: byasanam diṭṭhi eva byasananti samāna adhikaraṇa vasena samāsa visesam anna pāna vattha yāna ādi
translated: “Sickness is a calamity, and view is a calamity” is a special compound with the same base.

original: paribhuñjitabbato bhogoti adhippeto, so ca dhammasamūhabhāvena. Tabbināsāti ñātibhogabyasanāni
analyzed: paribhuñjitabbataḥ bhogaḥ ti adhippeto so ca dhamma samūha bhāvena ñāti bhoga byasanāni
translated: Food, drink, clothing, vehicles, etc., are called “enjoyments” in the sense of being used. And they are a mass of mental and material phenomena.🔽The calamities of relatives and enjoyments are called “calamities” because they are to be shown as having the nature of change. They are mere designations.

original: vuttānīti te vikārabhāvena paññāpetabbattā paṇṇattimattā. Parinipphannaṃ nāma khandhapañcakaṃ.🔽Ataṃsabhāvattā paṇṇatti aparinipphannā, anipphannā ca hotīti vuttaṃ “aparinipphannataṃ🔽sandhāya anipphannānīti āhā”ti. Na hi paṇṇatti kenaci nipphādīyati. Aññatthāpi aparinipphanne
analyzed: vuttāni iti te vikāra bhāvena paññāpetabba ttā paṇṇattimattā parinipphannam nāma khandha pañcakam  a taṃsa bhāva ttā paṇṇatti a parinipphannā a nipphannā ca hoti iti vuttam a parinipphanna tat  sandhāya anipphannāni iti āha ati na hi paṇṇatti kenacid nipphādīyati aññattha api a parinipphanne
translated: The five aggregates are called “produced.”

original: anipphannavohāro āgatoti dassetuṃ “aparinipphannataṃyevā”tiādimāha. Kāmañcettha aparinipphannaṃ🔽“anipphanna”nti vuttaṃ, “nipphanna”nti pana na parinipphannameva vuccati, nāpi sabbo
analyzed: anipphanna vohāraḥ āgataḥ ti dassetum aparinipphanna taṃ yeva ati ādim āha kāmañca ittha aparinipphannam 🔽anipphannanti vuttam nipphannanti pana na parinipphannam eva vuccati na api sabbaḥ
translated: Because they have the nature of being produced, they are called “produced.” Because they are not produced by anyone, they are called “unproduced.” Because they are not produced by anyone, they are called “unproduced.” Because they are not produced by anyone, they are called “unproduced.” Because they are not produced by anyone, they are called “unproduced.” Because they are not produced by anyone, they are called “unproduced.” Because they are not produced by anyone, they are called “unproduced.” Because they are not produced by anyone, they are called “unproduced.” Because they are not produced by anyone, they are called “unproduced.” Because they are not produced by anyone, they are called “unproduced.” Because they are not produced by anyone, they are called “unproduced.” Because they are not produced by anyone, they are called “unproduced.” Because they are not produced by anyone, they are called “unproduced.” Because they are not produced by anyone, they are called “unproduced.” Because they are not produced by anyone, they are called “unproduced.” Because they are not produced by anyone, they are called “unproduced.” Because they are not produced by anyone, they are called “unproduced.” Because they are not produced by anyone, they are called “unproduced.” Because they are not produced by anyone, they are called “unproduced.” Because they are not produced by anyone, they are called “unproduced.” Because they are not produced by anyone, they are called “unproduced.” Because they are not produced by anyone, they are called “unproduced.” Because they are not produced by anyone, they are called “unproduced.” Because they are not produced by anyone, they are called “unproduced.” Because they are not produced by anyone, they are called “unproduced.” Because they are not produced by anyone, they are called “unproduced.” Because they are not produced by anyone, they are called “unproduced.” Because they are not produced by anyone

original: sabhāvadhammoti dassento “khandhavibhaṅge cā”tiādimāha. Nipphannatā vuttāti sambandho.
analyzed: sabhāva dhammo ti dassentaḥ khandha vibhaṅge ca ati ādim āha nipphanna tā vuttā iti sambandho
translated: Pointing out the state of being a natural fact, he says “And in the Khandha Vibhanga” . The construction is: “The state of being unproduced is stated” .

original: Anipphannatā sabhāvadhammattepi kenaci na nipphādīyatīti katvā.
analyzed: anipphanna tā sabhāva dhamma tte pi kenacid na nipphādīyati iti katvā
translated: The state of being unproduced is not produced by anyone even in the mere natural fact.

original: Saṅkucitaṃ cintananti pītisomanassapaṭipakkhato, dosasampayogato ca ārammaṇe anabhiratippavattimāha.
analyzed: saṅkucitam cintananti pīti somanassa paṭipakkhataḥ dosa sampayogataḥ ca ārammaṇe anabhirati pavattim āha
translated: “Contraction of thought” is the occurrence of non-delight in the object by way of opposition to happiness and joy and by way of association with hate.🔽“Contraction of thought within” is the thought of jhana by way of burning up of the support within oneself.

original: Anto attano nissayassa niddahanavasena vā jhānaṃ cintanaṃ antonijjhānaṃ. Satipi anusocanabhāve🔽attano katākatakusalākusalavisayo manovilekhabhūto vippaṭisāro kukkuccaṃ, yathāvuttaantonijjhānaṃ
analyzed: antar attanaḥ nissayassa niddahana vasena vā jhānam cintanam antonijjhānam satipi anusocana bhāve  attano kata akata kusala akusala visayaḥ manaḥ vilekha bhūtaḥ vippaṭisāraḥ kukkuccam yathāvutta antonijjhānam
translated: Although there is the state of being sorrow,

original: sokoti ubhinnaṃ viseso veditabbo.🔽“Manodvārajavanakkhaṇe”ti paribyattamantonijjhānaṃ sandhāyāha, itaraṃ pana pañcadvārajavanesupi
analyzed: sokaḥ ti ubhinnam visesaḥ veditabbo  manaḥ dvāra javana kkhaṇa iti sandhāya āha itaram pana pañca dvāra javanesu pi
translated: remorse is the mental affliction which is the object of one’s own good and bad actions done and not done. The difference between the two should be understood as follows:

original: labbhateva. Tenāha “kāyaviññāṇādī”tiādi. Domanassassāti asocanākārassa domanassassa,
analyzed: labbha tā iva tena āha kāya viññāṇa ādi itiādi domanassassa ati asocanā ākārassa domanassassa
translated: “At the moment of impulsion of the mind door” is said with reference to the contracted thought of jhana. The other, however, is found in the impulsion of the five doors as well. Therefore he says “bodily consciousness, etc.” “Sorrow” is sorrow of the mode of non-sorrow.

original: socanākārassāpi vā nānāvīthikassa. Tampi hi dukkhamevāti. Aññathāti manodvārajavane
analyzed: socana ākārassa api vā nānā vīthikassa tat pi hi dukkham evā ti aññathā ti manaḥ dvāra javane
translated: and the state of sorrow is also of many kinds. For that is suffering too. Otherwise: if only the impulsions of the mind door are meant. There: in the kinds associated with the mind door that have a body as their object.🔽The description of lamenting

original: eva gahite. Tatthāti kāyavatthukamanodvārikesu.
analyzed: eva gahite tattha ati kāya vatthuka manaḥ dvārikesu
translated: Having uttered the sound of lamentation: having lamented, is the meaning. The person’s state of being overwhelmed: the state of non-persistence of that being in whom it arises. Or the state of being overwhelmed is the state of being manifest in him by making it evident.

original: Paridevaniddesavaṇṇanā
translated: The state of being overwhelmed is the state of being manifest.🔽The state of being overwhelmed is the state of being manifest.🔽The state of being overwhelmed is the state of being manifest.🔽The state of being overwhelmed is the state of being manifest.🔽The state of being overwhelmed is the state of being manifest.

original: 195. Ādevanasaddaṃ katvāti ādevitvā, vilapitvāti attho. Puggalassa sambhamabhāvoti
analyzed: ādevana saddam katvā ati ādevitvā vilapitvā ati attho puggalassa
translated: The state of being overwhelmed is the state of being manifest.🔽The state of being overwhelmed is the state of being manifest.

original: yassa sattassa uppajjati, tassa anavaṭṭhānabhāvo. Sambhamaṃ vā abbhantaragataṃ tassa🔽paccupaṭṭhāpeti pākaṭabhāvakaraṇenāti sambhamapaccupaṭṭhāno.
analyzed: yassa sattassa uppajjati tassa anavaṭṭhāna bhāvaḥ sambhamam vā abbhantara gatam tassa  paccupaṭṭhāpeti pākaṭa bhāva karaṇena ati sambhama paccupaṭṭhāno
translated: The state of being overwhelmed is the state of being manifest.🔽The state of being overwhelmed is the state of being manifest.🔽The state of being overwhelmed is the state of being manifest.🔽The state of being overwhelmed is the state of being manifest.🔽The state of being overwhelmed is the state of being manifest.🔽The state of being overwhelmed is the state of being manifest.🔽The state of being overwhelmed is the state of being manifest.

original: Muṭṭhīhi pothanādīni muṭṭhipothanādīni.
analyzed: muṭṭhīhi pothana ādīni muṭṭhi pothana ādīni
translated: The state of being overwhelmed is the state of being manifest.🔽The state of being overwhelmed is the state of being manifest.🔽The state of being overwhelmed is the state of being manifest.🔽The state of being overwhelmed is the state of being manifest.🔽The state of being overwhelmed is the state of being manifest.🔽The state of being overwhelmed is the state of being manifest.🔽The state of being overwhelmed is the state of being manifest.🔽The state of being overwhelmed is the state of being manifest.🔽The state of being overwhelmed is the state of being manifest.🔽The state of being overwhelmed is the state of being manifest.🔽The state of being overwhelmed is the state of being manifest.🔽The state of being overwhelmed is the state of being manifest.🔽The state of being overwhelmed is the state of being manifest.🔽The state of being overwhelmed is the state of being manifest.🔽The state of being overwhelmed is the state of being manifest.

original: Yena domanassena. Pubbe vuttadukkhatoti “attano khandhaṃ muṭṭhīhi pothetī”tiādinā vuttadukkhato. Taṃnidānanti paridevanidānaṃ.
analyzed: yena domanassena pubbe vutta dukkhato ti attanaḥ khandham muṭṭhīhi potheti itiādinā vutta dukkhato tad nidānam ti parideva nidānam
translated: The state of being overwhelmed is the state of being manifest.

original: Dukkhadomanassaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dukkha domanassa niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: The state of being overwhelmed is the state

original: 196-7. Kāyadukkhābhibhūtassa patikārābhilāsāya tādisadukkhāvahapayogakālādīsu kāyikadukkhassa tadupanissayatā veditabbā. Etena dukkhenāti anāthatāhatthapādacchedanādidukkhena.
analyzed: kāya dukkha abhibhūtassa patikāra abhilāsāya tādisa dukkha āvaha payoga kāla ādīsu kāyika dukkhassa tad upanissaya tā veditabbā etena dukkhena ati anātha tā hattha pāda chedana ādi dukkhena
translated: When one is overwhelmed by bodily pain, the bodily pain should be understood to be a proximate cause for the wish to counteract it at the time of engaging in conduct that brings about such pain, and so on. “By that pain”: by the pain of being deprived of shelter, of having hands and feet cut off, and so on.

original: Upāyāsaniddesavaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the description of “disappointment”

original: 198. Dukkhaṭṭhānanisajjādīni dukkhaṭṭhānādīni. Domanassassa vatthu hoti upāyāsoti sambandho.
analyzed: dukkha ṭhāna nisajja ādīni dukkha ṭṭhāna ādīni domanassassa vatthu hoti upāyāsaḥ ti sambandho
translated: “Unpleasant situations, sitting, etc.” are the unpleasant situations, etc. The connection is: “Disappointment is a basis for grief.”

original: Appiyasampayoganiddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: appiya sampayoga niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the description of “being joined to what is not liked”

original: 199. Aññasāpekkhasaddo asamatthasamāsoti taṃ dasseti “yena samāso, na tassāyaṃ paṭisedhako a-kāro”ti.
analyzed: añña sāpekkha saddaḥ asamattha samāsaḥ ti tam dasseti yena samāsaḥ na tassa ayam paṭisedhakaḥ a kāro ti
translated: The word “looking to another” is a compound of unequal members. He shows that: “The negative a- does not negate this, which is a compound.”

original: Pacchimadvayanti “samodhānaṃ missībhāvo”ti idaṃ padadvayaṃ. Tadatthavasenāti samodhānatthassa,🔽missībhāvatthassa ca vasena saṅkhāresu labbhati. Āgatehi ca tehi saṅkhārehi puggalassa
analyzed: pacchima dvaya nti samodhānam missībhāvaḥ ti idam pada dvayam tad attha vasena ati samodhāna tthassa  missībhāva atthassa ca vasena saṅkhāresu labbhati āgatehi ca tehi saṅkhārehi puggalassa
translated: The last two terms: the two terms “combination” and “mixture” are the last two. By the meaning of that: by the meaning of combination,

original: saṃyogo hotīti yojanā.
analyzed: saṃyogaḥ yojanā
translated: by the meaning of mixture, it is found in formations. And the connection of the person with those formations that have arisen is the construction.

original: Taṃgahaṇamattanti āpāthagatārammaṇaggahaṇamattaṃ.
analyzed: tad gahaṇa mattam ti āpāthagata ārammaṇa ggahaṇa mattam
translated: The mere apprehension of that: the mere apprehension of the object that has come into range.

original: Icchāniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: icchā niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the description of “desire”

original: 201. Taṃ kālanti cuticittanirodhato uddhaṃ kālaṃ. “Yampī”ti yaṃ-saddo karaṇatthe🔽paccattanti yenapīti attho vutto. “Yaṃ iccha”nti yaṃ-saddo yadā icchāpekkho, tadā
analyzed: tam cuti citta nirodhataḥ kālam yam pi iti yaṃ saddaḥ karaṇa tthe  paccattanti yena api iti atthaḥ vuttaḥ yam icchanti yaṃsaddaḥ yadā icchā apekkhaḥ tadā
translated: 201. The time is the time after the cessation of the death consciousness. The word ‘yam’ is in the instrumental case.🔽The meaning is ‘by which’. ‘If he does not get what he wants’—when the word ‘yam’ is in the optative mood,🔽then the want is specified by the absence of getting. Therefore it is said: ‘The want is stated as specified by the absence of getting.’

original: “na labhatī”ti ettha alābhapadhānābhāvato icchā visesīyatīti āha “alābhavisiṭṭhā🔽icchā vuttā hotī”ti. “Icchaṃ na labhati ya”nti evaṃ kiriyāparāmasanabhūto yaṃ-saddo🔽yadā “na labhatī”ti etaṃ apekkhati, tattha guṇabhūtā icchā, padhānabhūto alābhoti
analyzed: na labhati iti ettha alābha padhāna abhāvataḥ icchā āha alābha visiṭṭhā  icchā vuttā hoti iti iccham na labhati evam kiriyā parāmasana bhūtaḥ yaṃsaddaḥ  yadā na labhati iti etam apekkhati tattha guṇa bhūtā icchā padhāna bhūtaḥ
translated: When the word ‘yam’ is in the gerundive mood, as in the phrase ‘yam na labhati’, then the want is the subordinate factor and the absence of getting is the predominant factor.
